webTitle: England call up Croft and Ealham

fields.headline: England call up Croft and Ealham
fields.trailText: With the first test against West Indies beginning at Edgbaston on Thursday, the England selectors have taken the need to cover all eventualities to abnormal heights by naming not so much a squad as a touring party.
fields.body:
With the first test against West Indies beginning at Edgbaston on Thursday, the England selectors have taken the need to cover all eventualities to abnormal heights by naming not so much a squad as a touring party. Fourteen names were announced by the chairman of selectors David Graveney yesterday, including the off-spinner Robert Croft and the all-rounder Mark Ealham, one of whom seems certain to make the final XI.

No room could be found, however, for Michael Vaughan, who established himself during last winter's tour of South Africa. Instead Nick Knight, his replacement, retains his place despite his unconvincing performances against Zimbabwe.

Vaughan cracked a knuckle on his left hand while making 155 against Derbyshire at Headingley in April and missed the first two tests of the summer. But he is fit now and returned for Yorkshire against Durham last week, making 94 and seven. This, apparently, was insufficient evidence of either match fitness or form.

Neither Croft nor Ealham has played a test since 1998 and, with the emergence of a strong seam bowling squad and the placing of the young leg-spinner Chris Schofield on a central contract, there seemed no prospect of them adding to their caps. Their re turn is due to a peculiar set of circumstances involving the venue and the nature of West Indies' batting line-up.

The condition of the Edgbaston pitch, which for some years has been the most capricious on the English test circuit, will be particularly intriguing. Five years ago the first ball of the match from Curtly Ambrose struck a clump of grass like a head of broccoli, cleared Mike Atherton's head and almost went for six byes. Seam has been master.

But things have quietened down this season. In three county games there have been four totals of 400 or more, including the unbroken stand of 406, little over a week ago, between the Nottinghamshire openers Darren Bicknell and Guy Welton. So, unless the test strip has reverted to type, Nasser Hussain will want to retain the balance in his attack that a spinner will bring.

The issue is confused, however, by the plethora of left-handers in the West Indies side. In the last test they played, against Pakistan in Antigua, there were six but earlier in the year, against Zimbabwe, seven of the first eight were cack-handers.

Now another, Brian Lara, could replace a right-hander. It is this, along with Schofield's jittery bowling at Trent Bridge, that brings Croft, who when he turns the ball can be expected to do so away from the left-hander, back into the fold.

However, he is a lucky fellow, his inclusion coming largely because of the eight wickets he took for Glamorgan against West Indies last week on a minefield at Cardiff. Peter Such's relegation to the Essex second XI means that there is no competition, a sorry comment on the state of English spin bowling.

No one should expect too much if Croft plays, for after a promising start his test bowling degenerated to mediocrity with only 18 wickets from the last 15 innings in which he bowled. An indication of what could happen comes from Glamorgan's match in Birmingham earlier this season when Knight, a left-hander, made 233 and Croft had fig ures of 41-11-136-1. As horses for courses go, this is running a Whitbread shire in the Derby.

It is Ealham's ability to swing the ball into the left-hander that earns him a recall, although he will play only if conditions are heavy. The likely scenario is that Schofield will be released today to play for Lancashire against New Zealand A and that Ealham and Steve Harmison will follow him back to their counties.

Craig White, who suffered an unexplained blackout a couple of weeks ago, begins his rehabilitation today with a match for Scarborough against the Yorkshire Academy and should be available for the second test.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: It was not so long ago that Lancashire chalked up one-day final wins at Lord's as matter-of-factly as Shane Warne whips up frenzied newspaper headlines. Yesterday, however, even a rollicking 64 from 47 balls by the supposedly "technically frail" Andy Flintoff could not erase the nasty aftertaste of watching Gloucestershire's Saturday heroics, Worcestershire hanging on to win by 12 runs in their National League match at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
It was not so long ago that Lancashire chalked up one-day final wins at Lord's as matter-of-factly as Shane Warne whips up frenzied newspaper headlines. Yesterday, however, even a rollicking 64 from 47 balls by the supposedly "technically frail" Andy Flintoff could not erase the nasty aftertaste of watching Gloucestershire's Saturday heroics, Worcestershire hanging on to win by 12 runs in their National League match at Old Trafford.

Flintoff's dominance was absolute. He shared a quickfire 68-run partnership with Neil Fairbrother, whose 75 underlined his continuing mastery of the short-form game, carving 11 fours and a six along the way. For about an hour Flintoff had, albeit briefly, usurped David Beckham as king of Manchester.

But therein lies the problem; had Flintoff hung around 30 minutes longer, Lancashire would have coasted home with plenty in reserve. Should England's selectors eventually jettison Flintoff's "here for a good time not a long time approach", they need look no further than Vikram Solanki, whose technical frailties are few and whose unbeaten 59 set the stage for yet another Glenn McGrath masterclass. The Australian's three for 11 neatly bookended Lancashire's innings either side of Flintoff's fireworks.

Chris Adams let his bat do the talking for a change with 52, top-scoring for Sussex in their 11-run win over Leicestershire at Horsham. A defiant 81 by Vince Wells took the visitors to within 18 runs of victory at the start of the last over, but when Aftab Habib fell lbw for 13 Sussex were assured of a rare win.

In the Second Division, Graham Thorpe started the long road back to the national side, an unbeaten 45 guiding Surrey to a three-wicket victory away to Derbyshire .

Hampshire 's batting woes deepened at Trent Bridge, the visitors crumbling for 135 as the Nottinghamshire seamer Andrew Harris racked up a career-best five for 35. Darren Bicknell's 58 not out eased the ladder leaders home by eight wickets.

 The former South Africa captain Hansie Cronje is tipped to take the stand at the King Commission this week amid speculation that he may come clean on the match- fixing allegations against him. "All the indications are that Hansie will be giving evidence this week," said Judge Edwin King. "I am on the road to getting the truth. Whether it will be the full truth remains to be seen."

fields.headline: Quinn equals Irish record
fields.trailText: Niall Quinn equalled Frank Stapleton's Republic of Ireland scoring record yesterday with the winner in their 2-1 success over South Africa in the Giants stadium, New Jersey, which gave them the runners-up spot behind the host nation in the US Cup tournament.
fields.body:
Niall Quinn equalled Frank Stapleton's Republic of Ireland scoring record yesterday with the winner in their 2-1 success over South Africa in the Giants stadium, New Jersey, which gave them the runners-up spot behind the host nation in the US Cup tournament.

Shaun Bartlett exchanged passes with the Celta Vigo striker Benni McCarthy before toe-poking the ball beyond Shay Given to give South Africa a 14th-minute lead.

The Irish were level just before the interval when Stephen McPhail swung in a vicious, curling corner from the right and the Oxford goalkeeper Andre Arendse only managed to palm the ball into the net via the crossbar, under pressure from Quinn.

Quinn's record-equalling 20th goal came when he directed home a looping header from Mark Kennedy's deep 68th-minute free-kick.

Earlier the United States took the trophy for the first time since 1995 after a 3-0 win over Mexico.

 Rushden and Diamonds have broken the non-League transfer record, paying £180,000 for the Morecambe striker Justin Jackson, who has signed a three-year deal.

 Atalanta and Brescia were promoted to Serie A yesterday , joining Vicenza and Napoli who had already qualified. Atalanta drew 1-1 at home to Cesena and Brescia drew 2-2 at Cosenza.

webTitle: Belgium turn the butterflies to bulls

fields.headline: Belgium turn the butterflies to bulls
fields.trailText: As the opening match of a major tournament is traditionally an occasion suffocated by anti-climax, Euro 2000 got off lightly. Even with a dentist as referee, this was as far removed from the usual tooth-pulling experience as could reasonably have been hoped.
fields.body:
As the opening match of a major tournament is traditionally an occasion suffocated by anti-climax, Euro 2000 got off lightly. Even with a dentist as referee, this was as far removed from the usual tooth-pulling experience as could reasonably have been hoped.

Instead there were just about all the necessary ingredients that will be needed if these finals are to be remembered for the right reasons: goals and gaffes, some reasonably efficient refereeing and an atmosphere fit for the occasion. And the southern half of the Low Countries has got wind that something special could be in the offing.

At times there has been an unmistakable air of apathy drifting across Belgium over the past few weeks. But, if the raucous horn-parping celebrations of Brussels are anything to go by, anyone en route to the capital should pack ear-plugs among their travelling essentials. Sleep is becoming an increasingly precious luxury.

After a match that by and large lived up to the pre-tournament hype Les Diables Rouges left the pitch to a slow hand-clap from their fans, although it clearly serves a different purpose than in England.

"Over here it is a sign of appreciation rather than annoyance," explained a female Belgian journalist, presumably not a member of the Women's Institute.

Last night there was even talk from politicians-who-should-know-better of a public holiday being scheduled if they win the tournament. Although Belgium is often perceived as being a tad behind the times - Abba are riding high in the charts here - the co-hosts are suddenly luxuriating in the exposure.

The nation's shopkeepers, however, need not fret about a loss in trade come early July.

That said, Belgium can confront the rest of the tournament without the butterflies that were so obvious for long spells of a match featuring a cast of heroes and villains.

"It was a nervy match," admitted their Walloon manager, Robert Waseige. "I don't think I'll surprise anyone when I say the result was excellent for us. But the way we achieved it was not exactly the way I had planned it.

"We didn't play very well but we held on to our slight advantage to the end of the match. I don't think the Swedes had more than three chances."

For Sweden the inquest starts now. Roland Nilsson's muddling allowed Bart Goor to score with a panache that demonstrates why Sunderland have made firm inquiries about his availability at Anderlecht, then Emile Mpenza was allowed to get away with a handball before rifling a spectacular second beyond Magnus Hedman within seconds of the restart.

"I don't think it was a handball, I know it was a handball," Hedman said later. "My eyes do not lie."

At least the Coventry goalkeeper was spared the sort of humiliation bestowed upon his opposite number Filip de Wilde during the type of self-implosion that will inevitably pop up in one of those tiresome Danny Baker videos.

Treading on the ball and falling on one's face is seldom done with much grace. But to do it here, with Johan Mjallby gratefully picking up the pieces, smacked of woefully bad timing.

"It was like the whole world collapsed," said De Wilde afterwards. And the inevitable excuse? "There must have been a bobble; maybe the pitch was too dry."

Nevertheless it was a lifeline that Sweden seldom seemed capable of capitalising upon once their captain Patrik Andersson had been sent off for his second industrial challenge.

Belgium are now up and running. "We have the best team spirit around, everyone wants to play and to do well for everyone else," enthused Waseige.

As if to prove it, the captain Marc Wilmots nominated De Wilde as his man of the match, not even a hint of a smile playing on his lips. They are a strange lot, these Belgians.

fields.headline: What falls through the net
fields.standfirst:
If you want to get ahead, you need to use online recruitment sites, right? Not so, says Claire Phipps . They promise far more than they deliver

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you want to get ahead, you need to use online recruitment sites, right? Not so, says Claire Phipps . They promise far more than they deliver
fields.body:
If you want a new job, you've got to get on the net, right? After all, it's the only way to get ahead of your less technologically clued-up rivals, and nobody posts a CV anymore. With a survey by the Institute of Personnel and Development last month revealing that nearly half of employers use the internet for recruitment, it seems you have to get online to get on.

But before you bin the ballpoints, it's worth digging a little deeper. Yes, 47% of employers use the internet to fill positions but, for most, what that means is advertising jobs on internal computer systems (62%) or merely receiving emailed CVs from applicants (66%).

"It's clearly a growth area, but there is a reluctance by some employers to recruit on the internet," explains Nick Isles, spokesman for the IPD. "They know they have to get onto the bandwagon, but there's an uncertainty about how effective the internet is."

Secretarial recruitment consultancy Office Angels certainly believes the internet to be an effective tool for the jobseeker: it has recently opened a cybercafe in its Cambridge branch. "The idea is to help candidates to improve their IT skills - Cambridge has the highest demand for those - and to research companies before interviews," says Sarah El Doori, spokesperson for Office Angels. "A company website gives a much stronger idea of corporate culture and the way a company works." But the PC isn't about to usurp the role of the recruitment consultant. "We do advertise positions on our website, and people do email CVs to us, but we still find that people want to come into the branch," she says. "It's a much more personalised service."

This isn't what the online job sites want to hear. In the past few months there has been a huge increase in sites dedicated to finding you work. But the number of positions on some sites is still very low - in fact, there is a danger that there will soon be more sites than there are jobs advertised on them (or jobseekers using them). What the less established sites need, then, is a gimmick; the personal touch without, well, the person.

That's certainly what you get with Talking CV! www.talkingcv.com, a service that records candidates' responses to set questions - rather like a video dating agency - and sends them straight to the potential employer's desktop. As long as their computer has the specifications to access and play the video (laptops don't), employers can check out your appearance, self-promotion skills and enthusiasm for scuba diving before they meet you. Like an interview, really, except that prospective employers doesn't get to ask any questions.

One site that claims to put the jobseeker in the driving seat is InterviewMe.co.uk. Ignore the note of desperation in the name: this is a site aimed at those confident enough to auction their skills to the highest bidder. Register, type in who you are, what you can do, and where in the country you're willing to do it, and companies can join the fight for your services by offering competing salaries. The jobseeker can take whichever offer she chooses.

Well, that's the theory. In practice, it's not so fast-moving. A look around the "secreterial" (sic) section shows 11 hopefuls punting for work in the London area, and just one in each of Scotland, north-east, north-west, and south-west England. A closer look shows that the same optimist is auctioning herself in all of those places, as well as in the Midlands, Anglia, north, central, south and south-east England. This candidate is clearly very flexible - perhaps she could be persuaded to consider Wales, which at present boasts no jobhunters at all.

"There is a lot of scepticism about how useful some of these new sites will be," says Isles. And it's not just companies which should be sceptical. Sites that promise to cut out the middleman, such as InterviewMe, can be very vocal on the disadvantages of the recruitment consultant - fees, subjective opinions, time - while failing to match their plus points. "Careers advice, guidance, knowing what options are open to them - this is very much what people are looking for," insists El Doori.

The internet promises much, but jobseekers will have to wait a little longer before it starts delivering the kind of opportunities that some sites are trumpeting. Until internet job sites attract more traffic, bigger companies won't be prepared to recruit through them. In the meantime, that leaves too many qualified hopefuls chasing that one office admin position - at £11,000 for four years' experience on one site. "As it picks up pace, it will become more of a first choice option," says Isles. "But for now it would be foolish to rely entirely on the internet."

fields.headline: Fruitful labours
fields.standfirst:
As PA to the founders of a dot.com company, Nicola de Burlet had the chance to decide what her own job would involve. Hilary Witney reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As PA to the founders of a dot.com company, Nicola de Burlet had the chance to decide what her own job would involve. Hilary Witney reports
fields.body:
'This is such a young industry that you really do get the feeling that anything could happen. That's what I love about it," says Nicola de Burlet, 29, PA to Robert Norton and Toby Rowland, the founders of clickmango.com, a natural health and beauty website.

Although clickmango.com was launched in September last year, it didn't occur to Norton or Rowland to get a PA until they realised that their business was growing so rapidly they desperately needed more staff. They had a recruitment drive at the beginning of this year, which is when de Burlet joined, and there are now 22 members of staff.

"Robert and Toby needed someone to organise their lives because things were spiralling out of control," de Burlet explains. "They hadn't had a PA before so they weren't sure how to use me. I had to be very proactive and drum it into them that I'm not just here to take messages, and it's worked out very well. They're very happy for me to get on with things as long as everything is running smoothly, so I've been able to develop the job in the direction I want it to go."

When de Burlet joined the company it had temporary offices in the Lloyd's Building in Liverpool Street. "They were nice enough offices, but they had a very corporate feel which just wasn't right for this company." In March clickmango moved to new headquarters above an enormous converted warehouse on Brick Lane, a suitably hip location for an organisation in which the majority of staff are in their mid to late twenties and the chief executive is 30. "I'd been working in Soho before, which was great, and I had a few misgivings about this area at first because I didn't know it," admits de Burlet. "But actually Brick Lane is really funky - it's definitely the right place for us."

Each morning when de Burlet arrives at the office she checks the diary to see where Norton and Rowland are meant to be. "The diary might indicate that they should be in the office, but things change so quickly that they will often have dashed off somewhere else at the last minute. I'll try to speak to them on their mobiles and find out when they'll be in. Then I'll organise any papers they need for meetings later in the day so that when they do come in we can go through what needs to be done without too much of a panic." Once Norton and Rowland are in the office, however, it's hard to get them out. "Often a taxi I've booked to take them to a meeting will be waiting for about half an hour as I struggle to get them away from the phone."

The rest of the day can be spent doing anything from hanging pictures to producing financial documents or creating complex presentations on PowerPoint. In addition to her responsibilities as a PA, de Burlet has recently become the office manager, which has a broad remit - from ensuring there are enough teabags to sorting out computer problems.

Clickmango is fortunate to be fronted by Joanna Lumley, whose on-line character introduces visitors to the website. She recently gave a webcast, answering questions in the website's chat room. De Burlet was on hand to type Lumley's replies on to the web - not as simple as it sounds. "You have to have superfast typing and be able to abridge what's being said in about one second as the reply to the next question will be coming up pretty fast. It's a bit like being a simultaneous interpreter and it's very stressful!"

It's not just de Burlet's secretarial skills that are being exercised. She has a degree in French and as the company now has business interests there, she finds she is using her language skills every day.

In the past de Burlet has worked for more conventional firms - as a secretary for an auctioneer, and as PA to the finance director at 20th Century Fox films. "I've enjoyed all my jobs and learnt a lot from them, but I saw the opening at clickmango as an opportunity to get into a booming business. Because it's such a young industry, there are no set rules. But you do have to be prepared to work extremely hard and turn your hand to practically anything." Even the chief exec answers the phone from time to time.

She is also unperturbed by the worrying numbers of dot.coms that are falling by the wayside. "My belief is that if you have a good enough team working for you, and you believe in the work you are doing, then you can only succeed

fields.headline: Music machine
fields.standfirst:
New York Philharmonic Orchestra/Kurt Masur
Barbican Hall, London
fields.trailText:
New York Philharmonic Orchestra/Kurt Masur
Barbican Hall, London
fields.body:
Once considered the greatest American orchestra, the New York Philharmonic faces stiff competition, both from its established rivals in Chicago and Cleveland, and from the emergence of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Pittsburgh Symphony as world class ensembles. Rumours that the New Yorkers' playing has diminished in quality weren't borne out. This was musicianship of scrupulous precision - yet something was missing. The players seemed to cultivate an air of hauteur, communicating little of the thrill and pleasure of music making. The impression was of a magnificent machine.

With their Music Director Kurt Masur, they've just embarked on a European tour. The programme for their first London concert consisted of Ives's The Unanswered Question and Shostakovich's Leningrad Symphony. Rooted in New England transcendentalism, The Unanswered Question pits the transient babble of humanity against the spiritual contemplation of eternity. It was beautifully done, with the strings drifting out of a vast silence, the questioning trumpet hovering in a void and the woodwind shrill and querulous.

Shostakovich's Symphony, however, didn't always strike home with full force. A war work, it should rage with grief, terror and defiance. Here it became a majestic epic which was short on brutality. Masur lingers over the cumulative sonorities of the so-called innovation theme and the passage didn't pulverise as it should. It wasn't until he got to the slow movement that the Symphony's emotions began to grip. Masur has done better recent work with British orchestras.

webTitle: Volatility cuts Egg float price to £1.3bn

fields.headline: Volatility cuts Egg float price to £1.3bn
fields.standfirst:
Abbey ups e-banking stakes

E-finance: special report
Egg
Cahoot
fields.trailText: Prudential, the assurance group, yesterday cut the price tag on its Egg internet banking offshoot to £1.3bn, despite announcing that its flotation was nine times oversubscribed.
fields.body:
Prudential, the assurance group, yesterday cut the price tag on its Egg internet banking offshoot to £1.3bn, despite announcing that its flotation was nine times oversubscribed.

The shares will cost 160p each, putting the stock in the top end of the recently expected 130p-175p range when trading starts today.

But the valuation is still well below the more excitable suggestions of up to £4bn that were common in the market prior to the sharp downward movements in hi-tech shares seen during May.

Meanwhile - in a move signalling the intensifying competition in web banking - Cahoot, Abbey National's online bank, will open for business today with an offer of interest-free credit cards and overdrafts for "at least" the first 25,000 people to open accounts.

Cahoot said also it was offering a further bundle of incentives, including £10,000 overdraft limits, no "disloyalty charge" for using other banks' cash machines and a choice of repayment methods.

In addition, it said its first 150,000 customers would be offered subsidised new generation mobile telephones, with the wireless application protocol or WAP facility, allowing users access to the internet.

Egg - which has signed one million customers since its launch two years ago - is floating an 18% stake, both to give its management capital for acquisitions and to provide incentives for staff.

Proceeds from the sale will net £150m for Egg and £86m for Prudential.

Yesterday, Prudential said the take-up of Egg shares reserved for staff and customers accounted for nearly a quarter of the equity on offer. Egg's 1,400 employees have been given £100 worth of shares free, with the chance to buy another £1,000 worth.

The Prudential's 17,485 UK staff along with Egg's 1m-plus customers were also given the chance to buy up to £1,000 worth of shares. However, because of the quantity of applications, all those - whether Egg or Prudential employees or Egg customers - who asked for full a £1,000 will be scaled back to £752, whereas those who applied for either £500 or £200 worth will receive their requests in full.

Despite this initial enthusiasm for Egg - and the suggestion that the shares could reach 170p in dealings today - there remains some scepticism as to Egg's long-term potential. HSBC analysts warned on June 8 that: "We ... worry about the risks associated with the Egg model."

Yesterday Justin Urquhart Stewart, of Barclays Stockbrokers, said: "I think 160p is fairly high, and I would have preferred to see Egg shares priced at around 140p to 145p.

"Given the nine times oversubscription there should be enough pent-up demand to get the flotation away but there will be no significant premium. What concerns me is that this is still a business which has a very limited track record and has not yet made a profit. There is a danger that despite an initial flurry of enthusiasm, the company may be overpricing itself".

Meanwhile, the managing director of Cahoot, Tim Murley, promised that the new bank would use modern technology to create "genuine relationships between a bank and its customers".

webTitle: Be a human being, not a number

fields.headline: Be a human being, not a number
fields.standfirst: Fifty ways to mark yourself out as an individual in the office
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Fifty ways to mark yourself out as an individual in the office.
fields.body:
Real eccentrics are a dying breed in the workplace. Once spotted by their colourful bow ties or packs of home-made fishpaste-and-marmalade sandwiches in the briefcase, the cult of the character is now almost extinct.

Wannabees with their ostentatious and often crusty body piercings; weird-framed designer spectacles, or Bugs Bunny ties are only pale copies of the genuine article. Here are 50 ways to forge a trail of true individualism when all around is bland.

1. Chant each morning before you start work
2. Insist on being addressed by your formal name
3. Change your name. Chose a first name with attitude for name badges at conferences and company visits; something like Spike, Nobby, Jocasta, Psi or Matrix.
4. Skip the usual desk-top snapshots of family or pets and get life-size cardboard cut-outs, instead.
5. Look happy
6. Do Yoga at four o'clock every afternoon.
7. Wear coloured ankle socks.
8. Arrive at work on one of those aluminium scooters and use it going down the corridors.
9. Wear apple green eyeshadow.
10. Never moan about anything.
11. Bake at home, and take what you make in to share with your colleagues.
12. Blow bubblegum while you're thinking.
13. Burn incense.
14. Do a French manicure the wrong way round: white nails and pink tips.
15. Get a goldfish for your desk.
16. Say you went to the same school as the chief executive.
17. Wear a hat.
18. Give yourself a scalp massage.
19. Buy a Barbie doll and dress it like yourself.
20. Sew a name tag into your laptop bag.
21. Get a flattering picture of your boss and use it as a screen saver.
22. Place a beach towel over the chair you want to save for yourself at meetings.
23. Take a small lap dog into work with you, a la Barbara Cartland.
24. Use a wicker shopping trolley to carry your work home in the evenings.
25. Keep a jar of toothpicks by your PC if you eat lunch at your desk.
26. Learn to speak Japanese.
27. Use leopard skin print paper tissues.
28. Put leaves in a jar on your desk, instead of flowers.
29. Keep a drawer of scarves and change them during the day.
30. Change your hairstyle completely each lunch time.
31. Wear trainers at work and change into killer stilettos to go home in.
32. Knit at your desk as a stress-buster (only for young women - oldies may look too much of a bad cliche)
33. Keep a bowl of ice cubes on your desk to rub across your face in hot weather.
34. Wear a stick-on tattoo.
35. Write a team jingle that you all sing before meetings.
36. Or create a team mime that you all take part in following a business success, like football teams after a goal.
37. Organise office outings to take tours of rival companies.
38. Have a t-shirt made with the company name on it and wear it into the office.
39. Buy a desk-top fountain and claim it is feng shui.
40. Pretend to have a crush on Bill Gates. Pin his pictures up everywhere.
41. Insist on using one of those small diaries with the pencil in the spine, rather than the computerised version.
42. Make up your own business jargon and use it as though you think everyone will know what you're talking about.
43. When colleagues ring you on your mobile say you're out and can you take a message.
44. Change your laugh. Acquire something throaty and sexy-sounding.
45. Become really good at something impressive, like wine-tasting or shoe repairs.
46. Go out for lunch on a dry day and wet your hair before you come back. Mumble something about fountains if anyone remarks on it.
47. Learn all about the offside rules and join in with it when the blokes at work are discussing football.
48. Organise a womens' works team.
49. Wear flesh-coloured fishnet tights.
50. Print handouts of your good business idea and give them out at the next meeting.

fields.headline: Unwrapping the M&S makeover
fields.standfirst:
After months of falling profits, the High Street chain unveils its gamble on recovery at an out-of-town shopping centre near Leicester
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The shoppers of Leicester will make or break Marks & Spencer. In the 30-mile catchment area of the out-of-town Fosse Park shopping centre, they will be among the first to deliver a verdict on M&S's desperate effort to ditch its drab image.
fields.body:
The shoppers of Leicester will make or break Marks & Spencer. In the 30-mile catchment area of the out-of-town Fosse Park shopping centre, they will be among the first to deliver a verdict on M&S's desperate effort to ditch its drab image.

Gone are the row upon row of racks stuffed with clothes and staid, beige decor. Instead, interactive touch screens help women choose bras while the walls in the children's play area are lit from within and change colour slowly during the day. Some of the shop assistants have even ditched their plain uniforms.

It is desperate action for desperate times, critics say. Fosse Park's store is the first step, M&S claims, on the road to recovery after last month's shock decision by the company to cut its dividend to shareholders for the first time in its 74-year history.

The dividend cut followed a stunning fall from grace for a group that can track its roots back to a Leeds market stall in 1884 and which until recently was the backbone of British life. While 43% of women still wear white M&S knickers, estimates by retail consultants Verdict Research show its share of the women's wear market has fallen to 13.5% from 16.19%, and to 12% from 13.9% for men.

The secret appeared to be its high quality yet affordable St Michael label. Then the shoppers stopped streaming through doors. Smaller rivals such as Debenhams and Next courted shoppers with a trendier look, and fierce competition in the high street bought M&S to its knees.

"It was a combination of disparate factors," said Richard Hyman, chairman of Verdict Research. "The tried and tested ranges were no longer relevant for the modern market."

M&S fired its long-standing head, Richard Greenbury, installed new management and brought in a foreign boss, Luc Vandevelde. In a break with the past, it hired a marketing director, Alan McWalter.

The new team's aim is to adopt the success of a big department store, bringing in a personalised service for the high street, providing everything from clothes and food to pensions and loans. Out will go the "seas of racks" - lines and lines of trousers, skirts and blouses - and in comes a "store within a store" format.

"What they are doing is what they needed to do to get the performance much better. They are going to break the product offering into smaller chunks," said Mr Hyman.

In Fosse Park, the store is split into sections, with different areas within men's wear, women's wear, food, home, the new "beauty hall" and the new baby and maternity range. M&S is trying to emulate the "customer is king" attitude of its bigger, brasher American cousins.

So, women purchasing the clothes from the new upmarket Autograph range will have each item wrapped in tissue paper by chic, black-clad shop assistants.

Revamped

In other parts of the store, manager Andrew Jackson hopes his male customer will sit in the revamped sportswear section, watching a vast TV screen while his wife "spends £500" elsewhere in the shop.

"It's much improved," was an early verdict from one Fosse Park shopper, Steve Bell, 41, who used to work for one of the group's local suppliers, many of which have now been ditched by M&S for foreign manufacturers.

"I can see they have split it all up," he says, carrying an armful of casual trousers and shorts towards the fitting rooms.

To Mr Bell, the new display makes the clothes look different, which is not always the case. It is an effect that Mr McWalter, the newly recruited marketing director, sums up by talking about "lifestyle issues" and a "leisure experience". It is all about customer-friendly presentation, the result of scrutinising the habits of its 3.5m chargecard holders. Few stones have been left unturned, it appears. Even the dirty green carrier bags have been replaced by brighter version.

Yet, while many of the changes appear shallow alterations to the image and presentation of the same old items, underneath there are attempts to instill substantial cultural change.

Last month's sacking of 75 middle managers halved the ratio of bosses to non-bosses to one to 10. For the first time, the paternal, control-freakish M&S gave staff the power to make decisions.

"People can always give more when they've got the freedom to do so. No one at home tells you when to go to tea, so why should you need someone at work?" says Richard Wolff, divisional director of M&S.

Fosse Park is one of three experimental stores to receive the makeover before M&S decides whether to roll it out nationwide. Sutton in Surrey was the first and Kensington in London will be next.

After three days' of takings at Fosse Park, M&S is optimistic, claiming it is "ahead of estimates". It is still early days, though, and analysts say the tills will need to start ringing all around the country if M&S is to prove that its recent performance can be consigned to history.

M&S: What's in and what's out

Out

Row upon row of clothes rails

Strip lighting

Control from the centre

Blacks and greys

Dirty green plastic bags

In

"Stores within stores"

Neon lights

Retrained staff

Colours

Maternity wear, nursery, furniture and prams

Beauty halls

Cafes

Credit cards

Bright plastic bags

"It was a combination of disparate factors," said Richard Hyman, chairman of Verdict Research. "The tried and tested ranges were no longer relevant for the modern market." M&S fired its long-standing head, Richard Greenbury, installed new management and brought in a foreign boss, Luc Vandevelde. In a break with the past, it hired a marketing director, Alan McWalter. The new team's aim is to adopt the success of a big department store, bringing in a personalised service for the high street, providing everything from clothes and food to pensions and loans. Out will go the "seas of racks" - lines and lines of trousers, skirts and blouses - and in comes a "store within a store" format. "What they are doing is what they needed to do to get the performance much better. They are going to break the product offering into smaller chunks," said Mr Hyman. In Fosse Park, the store is split into sections, with different areas within men's wear, women's wear, food, home, the new "beauty hall" and the new baby and maternity range. M&S is trying to emulate the "customer is king" attitude of its bigger, brasher American cousins. So, women purchasing the clothes from the new upmarket Autograph range will have each item wrapped in tissue paper by chic, black-clad shop assistants. Revamped In other parts of the store, manager Andrew Jackson hopes his male customer will sit in the revamped sportswear section, watching a vast TV screen while his wife "spends £500" elsewhere in the shop. "It's much improved," was an early verdict from one Fosse Park shopper, Steve Bell, 41, who used to work for one of the group's local suppliers, many of which have now been ditched by M&S for foreign manufacturers. "I can see they have split it all up," he says, carrying an armful of casual trousers and shorts towards the fitting rooms. To Mr Bell, the new display makes the clothes look different, which is not always the case. It is an effect that Mr McWalter, the newly recruited marketing director, sums up by talking about "lifestyle issues" and a "leisure experience". It is all about customer-friendly presentation, the result of scrutinising the habits of its 3.5m chargecard holders. Few stones have been left unturned, it appears. Even the dirty green carrier bags have been replaced by brighter version. Yet, while many of the changes appear shallow alterations to the image and presentation of the same old items, underneath there are attempts to instill substantial cultural change. Last month's sacking of 75 middle managers halved the ratio of bosses to non-bosses to one to 10. For the first time, the paternal, control-freakish M&S gave staff the power to make decisions. "People can always give more when they've got the freedom to do so. No one at home tells you when to go to tea, so why should you need someone at work?" says Richard Wolff, divisional director of M&S. Fosse Park is one of three experimental stores to receive the makeover before M&S decides whether to roll it out nationwide. Sutton in Surrey was the first and Kensington in London will be next. After three days' of takings at Fosse Park, M&S is optimistic, claiming it is "ahead of estimates". It is still early days, though, and analysts say the tills will need to start ringing all around the country if M&S is to prove that its recent performance can be consigned to history. fields.headline: Branson brokers BA peace
fields.standfirst:
Virgin boss hopes to end 10 years of airline acrimony in a friendly lunchtime chat
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The decade-long feud between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic may be brought to an end tomorrow when Sir Richard Branson holds a peace-making lunch with new BA chief Rod Eddington.
fields.byline: John Cassy  in Las Vegas and Larry Elliott
fields.body:
The decade-long feud between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic may be brought to an end tomorrow when Sir Richard Branson holds a peace-making lunch with new BA chief Rod Eddington.

After years in which the two airlines have been locked in acrimonious courtroom and media battles over alleged "dirty tricks", attempts will be made to exploit the close personal relationship between Mr Branson and Mr Eddington in order to call a truce.

With the threat of an open skies policy likely to hit the bottom line of both airlines, the two companies are eager to bury the hatchet after years in which their relationship has been soured by commercial rivalry and personal animosity.

Sources said that the two men had forged a friendship when Mr Eddington, as the head of Ansett Airways - Australia's second largest carrier - had talks with Virgin about a possible global alliance.

BA is eager to secure Virgin's support for its proposed merger with the Dutch national airline, KLM, and its alliance with American airlines.

It is thought Mr Eddington will propose that BA and Virgin should bury the hatchet by forging a united front against the eventuality of an open skies policy which would allow rival carriers such as British Midland to compete on transatlantic routes.

Increased global competition has squeezed the profit margins of airlines, leaving BA last year with its biggest loss since being privatised in 1987. However, previous attempts at bringing to an end the bitter struggle between BA and Virgin foundered on the deep mistrust between Mr Branson and the former chief executive of BA, Robert Ayling.

But Mr Ayling's departure and the arrival of Mr Eddington has opened up the possibility of an end to the war.

During the period of the battle between BA and Virgin Mr Branson has claimed that the UK's former state-owned carrier used its dominant position in the marketplace to try to secure a monopoly on lucrative transatlantic slots.

The peace attempts come amid hopes that the long-running dispute about access to Heathrow will be settled when the open skies negotiations between the US and the UK resume tomorrow.

Sir Michael Bishop, British Midland's chief executive, is optimistic that the discussions will result in his airline being given access to the lucrative slots at Heathrow, the world's busiest airport.

The last set of negotiations, held in February, ended in antagonism after a plan for British Midland to share eight extra daily flights with two US carriers fell apart at the last minute. At present only BA, Virgin, American Airlines and United Airlines are allowed to fly across the Atlantic to and from Heathrow.

British Midland has been encouraged by recent comments from Lord Marshall, the BA chairman, who signalled a relaxation of its opposition to new entrants.

Sir Michael has also been encouraged by the news of the BA-KLM merger talks, which has been interpreted as indicating that BA will not stand in the way of an agreement.

But Sir Richard, Virgin's founder, remains opposed to the arrival of new carriers, which would increase capacity on the already saturated transatlantic routes. Sir Richard Branson has been fighting for 10 years against what he believes to be a "dirty tricks" campaign which had been waged by British Airways.

He has used the courts consistently to get back at his longstanding foe, posing as David to BA's Goliath. Unlike Virgin Atlantic's predecessor, Freddie Laker's SkyTrain, Sir Richard's campaign has proved very effective.

1991 - Virgin accuses BA of poaching its passengers, hacking into its computers, hiring private investigators and feeding anti-Virgin stories to the media.

Branson writes to BA calling for the allegations to be investigated so it can be confirmed that the rival airline is not behind any anti-Virgin campaign.

Sir Colin Marshall, then BA's chief executive, replies that there is no foundation in the allegations, and BA's weekly staff newspaper suggests that Virgin has invented the claim.

It is this newspaper article that Branson seizes on to provide the basis of his libel claim against BA.

BA then also sues, alleging libel by Branson. But Virgin emerges triumphant from the high court hearing. BA is forced to admit there was some foundation for the Virgin chief's dirty tricks allegations and apologises unreservedly.

It also has to pay £610,000 in libel damages to Branson and Virgin, and pay costs of about £3m.

1993 - Virgin lodges a $1bn lawsuit in a New York court seeking compensation for the "dirty tricks".

1994 - Virgin wins a separate, long-running battle with BA over maintenance of its aircraft in the late 1980s. BA agrees to pay £2.65m compensation after Virgin says BA had kept Virgin aircraft grounded, with one airliner being out of action for three weeks during a busy summer period.

1998 - Branson attacks the proposed alliance between BA and American Airlines which he says will dominate transatlantic routes and be anti-competitive.

1999 - A US court throws out the $1bn lawsuit. Sir Richard rejects calls from a triumphant Robert Ayling, BA's chief executive, for his company and Virgin finally to bury the hatchet after almost a decade of acrimonious courtroom battles

February 2000 - On the same side, but still working separately, at least in public, Sir Richard and Ayling lobby successfully against liberalisation of routes to the US that would allow rivals to enter market.

June 2000 - Sir Richard and Rod Eddington, the new BA boss, meet to bury the hatchet.

fields.headline: Ibiza tunes for indie kids
fields.trailText:
Looper
Dingwalls, London ***
fields.body:
Looper
Dingwalls, London ***

Escaping your past can be tricky. Geri will always be an ex-Spice Girl, Robbie forever the cheeky one in Take That. For Stuart David it's his bass-playing with Belle and Sebastian that he wants to bury. Now he's got his own band.

Looper is the moonlight stint that turned into the day job. And quite a tiring one at that, with all dates on the current British tour, except London and Glasgow, cancelled due to exhaustion. Melancholy poets obviously aren't made of stern stuff.

Looper include David's wife Karn and his brother Ronnie, and we get a glimpse into this family affair thanks to two screens behind the band. Home videos are projected on the left-hand screen; on the right, photographs of the things and people that inspired each song are flashed up. It's rather like looking through someone's photo album.

All this multimedia stuff detracts from the songs, which are fragile glimpses of episodes in David's life. "This song is about being scared of the dark, even in the daylight," he explains, introducing On the Flipside, the sound of sunshine belying the terror in the lyrics, as distant vocals are married to looping drums and subtle bleeps. These are the contradictions that Looper play with, making Ibiza tunes for indie kids.

For the encore Looper return to the stage, only to admit they haven't got any more songs. As David reprises These Things, accompanied only on keyboards, the strength and beauty of the melody shines through. He can beat it up all he likes, but you can't keep a good song down.

webTitle: Equitable Life's future hangs on lords hearing

fields.headline: Equitable Life's future hangs on lords hearing
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Equitable Life's future hangs in the balance this week as the law lords begin a five-day hearing which, if it upholds a court of appeal ruling in January, could result in a £1.5bn payout to 90,000 pensioners.
fields.body:
Equitable Life's future hangs in the balance this week as the law lords begin a five-day hearing which, if it upholds a court of appeal ruling in January, could result in a £1.5bn payout to 90,000 pensioners.

The pensioners are fighting to force Equitable Life, the second largest mutual insurer in the UK after Standard Life, to stand by guarantees made in the 1970s and 1980s which they believe could increase pension payouts by up to 25%. Other life offices such as Scottish Amicable have paid out hundreds of millions of pounds to meet guarantees in pension contracts.

But Equitable Life, while accepting the right of pensioners to take up the guarantees, cut their valuable final bonuses instead, arguing that it had the right to vary final bonuses. However, the court of appeal ruled in January that the move was unlawful.

Equitable Life immediately appealed to the House of Lords, which will begin hearing the case today and is expected to make a judgement early next week.

But last night Equitable Life was playing down suggestions that an unfavourable ruling could force it into the arms of a predator and end its 238 years of independence.

It says that even if the law lords rules against the company, the cost of payouts will be closer to £200m rather than £1.5bn.

It says the £1.5bn figure has only arisen because it had to put a figure in Treasury returns last year for reserve requirements. "We were simply relabelling money we had already put aside," said a spokesman.

At issue are "guaranteed annuities" which were sold as part of pension plans between 1957 and 1988. Those who bought policies with this option believed it would assure them of a guaranteed minimum income at retirement.

Annuity rates have plummeted in recent years, which means that the guaranteees, which promised an income of 11% or more, have become very costly for pension companies - landing the industry with a bill of up to £10bn. Market annuity rates are now between 8% and 9%.

Equitable has 600,000 policyholders and £33bn under management. Many analysts argue the company could be vulnerable to takeover if it loses the case. But the company says it is an unlikely target because it is an efficient player with low free reserves.

"We have been approached by almost every player in the market, but not one has come back with a formal offer," the spokesman said.

fields.headline: Does weekend gear work?
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair's got it, John Redwood hasn't. If John Prescott tries it, we'll all be horrifed. Kate Hilpern on the perils of dressing down for the office

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's got it, John Redwood hasn't. If John Prescott tries it, we'll all be horrifed. Kate Hilpern on the perils of dressing down for the office
fields.body:
Having sorted out the new deal and the old Labourites, it was only a matter of time before Tony and his cronies turned their attention to the real issue of the day: the forces of fashion conservatism. In true laid-back new Labour fashion, Blair has finally confessed to his hatred of smart dress codes at work. "It's one of the tyrannies of modern life that men have to dress in conventional suits the whole time," he lamented in an interview with a women's magazine. The Prime Minister's mufti of choice is - appropriately - a denim shirt, the informal uniform of the mildly fashionable man. "I'm trying to get out of suits," he confessed.

And who, irrespective of gender or job, could disagree? Surely only old stick-in-the-muds such as hereditary peers actually like wearing suits, right? We're all one big Silicon Valley now, dressed in unisex Gap chinos and crisp white T-shirts, working harder than ever, but free at last from the stuffy tyranny of necktie or nylons. New Labour, new look.

It was in the internet start-ups of California and Seattle that casual dressing in the white-collar workplace began in earnest in the mid-80s. The idea of forcing iconoclastic innovators to wrap a tie around their necks or wear Edwina Currie-style power-suits seemed contrary to the very spirit of the new technological revolution - young, dynamic and creative. The success of industries such as Microsoft and Netscape created speculation that profits were inversely related to the buttoned-down formality of other industries. Not surprisingly, the new look caught on. By the mid-90s, "dress-down Fridays" were commonplace in the UK; by the millennium every day had become dress-down day for some firms - even in parts of the Square Mile.

But has the PM once again failed to catch the mood of the nation? Do we really want to go to work in civvies? "The reality is that given the chance, most employees would go straight back to posh gear tomorrow morning," says Judi James, a professional image adviser and author of Body Talk, a guide book for dressing for success. "They are totally bemused by the millennial dress code of 'smart-casual'. I recently trained a man who truly thought it meant being both at once. He wore a formal waistcoat and trousers with a Grateful Dead T-shirt. Whereas buying traditional suits requires half a brain cell, people find it stressful to learn a whole new set of rules."

Anthea Yamey, a trainer in impression management, has been employed by companies including KPMG to guide employees through this fashion minefield. "A few years ago, people like me were few and far between. But employers are now beginning to realise the impact that getting the new look 'wrong' can have on business. Is it OK, for instance, for top PAs to replace jackets with cardigans? To wear flowing flowery dresses instead of tailored suits? In some firms, of course, it's no problem, but in others it could lose them a deal."

In any case, more freedom means more room for mistakes, points out Christine Abbot, manager of personal shopping at Harvey Nichols. If in doubt, cast your mind back to William Hague's notorious informal brainstorming weekend which he attended with jumper-clad shadow cabinet members. John Redwood even turned up in combat trousers, like some cross between a chief exec and an All Saint. Hague's intentions were good, but such were the horrors of the style-free zone on display that the Tories' ratings dropped a few inches on the graph that week.

"Employers are realising that with the increase in short-term contracts, employees are dazed by the variety in rules according to each company," says Abbot. So bewildered are employees in Citibank, Merill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, for instance, that managers have had to provide written guidelines on what constitutes "acceptable casual". "Sometimes, it seems like an enforced freedom, because what counts as casual is more restrictive than a classic suit," says a PA at Merrill Lynch. Little wonder that one survey found only a third of businesspeople want to look casual at the office all the time. And over half of the staff at Arthur Anderson, which announced in January that its 7,000 UK staff would be free to wear whatever they wanted, still choose to sport formal suits.

Christopher Early, a professor of organisational behaviour at the University of Indiana, believes that introducing casual wear "can be read as just another attempt to manipulate employees". He adds that it also runs the risk of taking on an Orwellian quality. "All of us are casual, but some are more casual than others . . ." The bohemian argument that informal dress de-layers management structures, leading to a more equal working environment, also doesn't wash with Dr Rob Briner, an organisational psychologist at Birkbeck College in London. "When a company goes casual, it becomes very clear who has the money to spend on an impressive wardrobe and who doesn't. It's rather like mufti day at school, when the rich kids show off."

Despite Tony Blair's comment that "women have a lot more freedom" when it comes to dressing down, Briner believes that the disadvantages of casual dress hit women the hardest. "For females - especially those in male-oriented environments like the City - wearing the corporate uniform can be a valuable tool, allowing them to be seen as fitting in with the firm." He cites a recent research that shows when a woman wasn't wearing a jacket, 80% of those surveyed thought she was a receptionist.

Mary Spillane, American image consultant and head of Colour Me Beautiful, agrees. "It's true that women have always been more creative than men in terms of dress. But at the same time, they're still behind men in the workplace. So they need to work even harder to retain authority in every way they can. It's tempting not to bother in a climate where so many meetings have been replaced by emails and telephone conferencing, but there's always someone you'll have to impress - especially as a front-line secretary or PA. In any case, dressing with authority makes you feel like you have more authority."

Summer presents particular dilemmas in UK offices, believes Spillane. "When the sun comes out, British brains get fried. Armpits, toes and backs all start revealing themselves, breaking down any hope of professionalism. There's really no excuse with such a wide availability of linen and other lightweight dresses, suits and jackets."

Spillane claims temps must be particularly careful not to throw caution to the wind when they open their wardrobes only to find hipsters and cropped, sequinned T-shirts. "They suffer a double-edged sword, because not only are they expected to project the image of the company but also their agency. You might, for instance, get a temping agency stipulating no trousers, yet an assignment in a company where no-one is out of jeans."

True proponents of the "new economy, new wardrobe" school of thought will always be quick to tell you that it boosts productivity and reduces absenteeism. But where's the proof? A few US companies even claim the opposite may be true. Employees have been found to take lunch breaks that are two minutes longer on average than when they sport their own choice of attire. "Once you're in your weekend gear, you feel as though you're ready for the weekend," says Judi James. "It's why I suggest buying a separate set of clothes for work even if you dress casually for both." Which might also be an incentive to work harder - two wardrobes don't come cheap.

Informal may be In, but James has no doubt that Smart will be Back. "It's OK for Tony, with his stylish shirts and just-enough chest-hair poking out. He knows it suits him and he retains dignity. But would John Prescott get away with slacks and leather jacket with the collar turned up?" Let's hope Mr Blair's new informality doesn't catch on with the rest of the cabinet.

The haves . . .

Nick Moran : Dapper suits and smart street gear in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels earned him GQ's Best Dressed Man gong. Fashion experts consider him to have "the look of the moment". A must for wannabe gangsters.

Elizabeth Murdoch: Hits the perfect note between corporate professionalism and individual flair. Head for Joseph, Nicole Farhi or MaxMara if you want to do the same.

Anita Roddick: She's ditched the one-foot-in-the-hippie-camp look for unstructured but stylish trouser suits - always a good bet in the millennial office.

Hillary Clinton: Has, admittedly, taken the power-suit look a bit far on occasions, but note how the American public didn't like it when she went casual.

Ken Livingstone: Light colours and smart styles were always going to win votes - they say "friendly but in control" (ditching the 'tache was also a good move).

Matthew Freud: The PR man hits the spot with his laid-back tieless-but-suited look. He and Murdoch make a superstylish couple.

. . . and the have-nots

Martha Lane Fox: Worth millions, but the 27-year-old co-founder of lastminute.com just doesn't pull it off. Should bin the dowdy geek look for a specific, recognisable style.

Denise Van Outen: The nouveaux Essex look is fine for presenting late night TV shows but a definite no-no in the office.

Edwina Currie: Flamboyant 80s colours say "look at me" - but if you have presence at work, you shouldn't need to shout. Loud colours may make you look like you've come straight in from a night on the town.

Jeremy Clarkson: Crumpled jeans, a checked shirt and leather bomber jacket is enough to make anybody cringe. Casual dress does not mean looking as if you put your clothes on in the dark.

William Hague: He may be the youngest leader of his party in yonks and his wife may be more glamorous than Dennis Thatcher, but this guy still looks like the sort of man who owns a Corby trouser press. And pleeeease lose the baseball cap: know your limits, William.

The success of industries such as Microsoft and Netscape created speculation that profits were inversely related to the buttoned-down formality of other industries. Not surprisingly, the new look caught on. By the mid-90s, "dress-down Fridays" were commonplace in the UK; by the millennium every day had become dress-down day for some firms - even in parts of the Square Mile. But has the PM once again failed to catch the mood of the nation? Do we really want to go to work in civvies? "The reality is that given the chance, most employees would go straight back to posh gear tomorrow morning," says Judi James, a professional image adviser and author of Body Talk, a guide book for dressing for success. "They are totally bemused by the millennial dress code of 'smart-casual'. I recently trained a man who truly thought it meant being both at once. He wore a formal waistcoat and trousers with a Grateful Dead T-shirt. Whereas buying traditional suits requires half a brain cell, people find it stressful to learn a whole new set of rules." Anthea Yamey, a trainer in impression management, has been employed by companies including KPMG to guide employees through this fashion minefield. "A few years ago, people like me were few and far between. But employers are now beginning to realise the impact that getting the new look 'wrong' can have on business. Is it OK, for instance, for top PAs to replace jackets with cardigans? To wear flowing flowery dresses instead of tailored suits? In some firms, of course, it's no problem, but in others it could lose them a deal." In any case, more freedom means more room for mistakes, points out Christine Abbot, manager of personal shopping at Harvey Nichols. If in doubt, cast your mind back to William Hague's notorious informal brainstorming weekend which he attended with jumper-clad shadow cabinet members. John Redwood even turned up in combat trousers, like some cross between a chief exec and an All Saint. Hague's intentions were good, but such were the horrors of the style-free zone on display that the Tories' ratings dropped a few inches on the graph that week. "Employers are realising that with the increase in short-term contracts, employees are dazed by the variety in rules according to each company," says Abbot. So bewildered are employees in Citibank, Merill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, for instance, that managers have had to provide written guidelines on what constitutes "acceptable casual". "Sometimes, it seems like an enforced freedom, because what counts as casual is more restrictive than a classic suit," says a PA at Merrill Lynch. Little wonder that one survey found only a third of businesspeople want to look casual at the office all the time. And over half of the staff at Arthur Anderson, which announced in January that its 7,000 UK staff would be free to wear whatever they wanted, still choose to sport formal suits. Christopher Early, a professor of organisational behaviour at the University of Indiana, believes that introducing casual wear "can be read as just another attempt to manipulate employees". He adds that it also runs the risk of taking on an Orwellian quality. "All of us are casual, but some are more casual than others . . ." The bohemian argument that informal dress de-layers management structures, leading to a more equal working environment, also doesn't wash with Dr Rob Briner, an organisational psychologist at Birkbeck College in London. "When a company goes casual, it becomes very clear who has the money to spend on an impressive wardrobe and who doesn't. It's rather like mufti day at school, when the rich kids show off." Despite Tony Blair's comment that "women have a lot more freedom" when it comes to dressing down, Briner believes that the disadvantages of casual dress hit women the hardest. "For females - especially those in male-oriented environments like the City - wearing the corporate uniform can be a valuable tool, allowing them to be seen as fitting in with the firm." He cites a recent research that shows when a woman wasn't wearing a jacket, 80% of those surveyed thought she was a receptionist. Mary Spillane, American image consultant and head of Colour Me Beautiful, agrees. "It's true that women have always been more creative than men in terms of dress. But at the same time, they're still behind men in the workplace. So they need to work even harder to retain authority in every way they can. It's tempting not to bother in a climate where so many meetings have been replaced by emails and telephone conferencing, but there's always someone you'll have to impress - especially as a front-line secretary or PA. In any case, dressing with authority makes you feel like you have more authority." Summer presents particular dilemmas in UK offices, believes Spillane. "When the sun comes out, British brains get fried. Armpits, toes and backs all start revealing themselves, breaking down any hope of professionalism. There's really no excuse with such a wide availability of linen and other lightweight dresses, suits and jackets." Spillane claims temps must be particularly careful not to throw caution to the wind when they open their wardrobes only to find hipsters and cropped, sequinned T-shirts. "They suffer a double-edged sword, because not only are they expected to project the image of the company but also their agency. You might, for instance, get a temping agency stipulating no trousers, yet an assignment in a company where no-one is out of jeans." True proponents of the "new economy, new wardrobe" school of thought will always be quick to tell you that it boosts productivity and reduces absenteeism. But where's the proof? A few US companies even claim the opposite may be true. Employees have been found to take lunch breaks that are two minutes longer on average than when they sport their own choice of attire. "Once you're in your weekend gear, you feel as though you're ready for the weekend," says Judi James. "It's why I suggest buying a separate set of clothes for work even if you dress casually for both." Which might also be an incentive to work harder - two wardrobes don't come cheap. Informal may be In, but James has no doubt that Smart will be Back. "It's OK for Tony, with his stylish shirts and just-enough chest-hair poking out. He knows it suits him and he retains dignity. But would John Prescott get away with slacks and leather jacket with the collar turned up?" Let's hope Mr Blair's new informality doesn't catch on with the rest of the cabinet. The haves . . . Nick Moran : Dapper suits and smart street gear in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels earned him GQ's Best Dressed Man gong. Fashion experts consider him to have "the look of the moment". A must for wannabe gangsters. Elizabeth Murdoch: Hits the perfect note between corporate professionalism and individual flair. Head for Joseph, Nicole Farhi or MaxMara if you want to do the same. Anita Roddick: She's ditched the one-foot-in-the-hippie-camp look for unstructured but stylish trouser suits - always a good bet in the millennial office. Hillary Clinton: Has, admittedly, taken the power-suit look a bit far on occasions, but note how the American public didn't like it when she went casual. Ken Livingstone: Light colours and smart styles were always going to win votes - they say "friendly but in control" (ditching the 'tache was also a good move). Matthew Freud: The PR man hits the spot with his laid-back tieless-but-suited look. He and Murdoch make a superstylish couple. . . . and the have-nots Martha Lane Fox: Worth millions, but the 27-year-old co-founder of lastminute.com just doesn't pull it off. Should bin the dowdy geek look for a specific, recognisable style. Denise Van Outen: The nouveaux Essex look is fine for presenting late night TV shows but a definite no-no in the office. Edwina Currie: Flamboyant 80s colours say "look at me" - but if you have presence at work, you shouldn't need to shout. Loud colours may make you look like you've come straight in from a night on the town. Jeremy Clarkson: Crumpled jeans, a checked shirt and leather bomber jacket is enough to make anybody cringe. Casual dress does not mean looking as if you put your clothes on in the dark. William Hague: He may be the youngest leader of his party in yonks and his wife may be more glamorous than Dennis Thatcher, but this guy still looks like the sort of man who owns a Corby trouser press. And pleeeease lose the baseball cap: know your limits, William.

fields.headline: The low down
fields.standfirst:
Skills shortages

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Unemployment is on the rise in the United States, which, ironically, has made people feel more optimistic - except, presumably, the unemployed. It's a sign that the economy may not be overheating after all. Is the UK due for a similar dose of mixed optimism? It seems unlikely, going by the trends in the labour market last month.
fields.body:
Unemployment is on the rise in the United States, which, ironically, has made people feel more optimistic - except, presumably, the unemployed. It's a sign that the economy may not be overheating after all. Is the UK due for a similar dose of mixed optimism? It seems unlikely, going by the trends in the labour market last month.

The national job survey from the recruitment and employment confederation shows that demand for permanent and temporary staff grew, while the numbers available fell. The rate of growth fell back a little but this is mainly because of exceptionally strong growth earlier in the year. The laws of supply and demand mean these figures are also producing a rise in salaries - faster for permanent positions, but temp rates are still rising.

Despite concerns about manufacturing, the largest rise in demand was for temporary blue-collar staff. The hotel and catering sector has shot to the top of the league table of skills shortages. For a long time the table was dominated by the IT sector. But as the Y2K panic fades, this industry has dropped to third place.

Skills shortages are still having a strong influence in the secretarial sector as well. Curiously, the skill most in demand in the temp sector is for audiotypists. For some time this has been considered a moribund skill, quietly dropped from the syllabuses of secretarial courses. Perhaps there is more life to it than people think. Or maybe it's just that in a booming job market, tedious jobs are harder to fill. Demand for receptionists, the bottom rung of the secretarial ladder, is also notably outstripping supply.

Another oddity is that the only sector with any cause for pessimism over the buoyancy of the job market is the recruitment industry itself. Rising temp rates, increasing costs, and fierce competition between agencies are squeezing profit margins.

webTitle: Mpenza is off to a flier

fields.headline: Mpenza is off to a flier
fields.standfirst:
Belgium 2
Goor 43, Mpenza 46
Sweden 1
Mjallby 53
att: 50,000
fields.trailText: As co-hosts, Belgium are perceived as poor relations. But the Red Devils illuminated the stylishly rebuilt King Badouin stadium with two goals which would grace the more lauded orange or blue shirts.
fields.body:
As co-hosts, Belgium are perceived as poor relations. A Stockport County to Holland's Manchester United, lacking in the passion, the prestige, the panache of their neighbours. They may not have the boom of the oranje, but they are giving it a good go.

Being a mix of French and Dutch, Belgium must sometimes look at the pedigree over the borders and wonder where they have gone wrong football-wise, golden age of the Eighties excepted. But the Red Devils illuminated the stylishly rebuilt King Badouin stadium with two goals which would grace the more lauded orange or blue shirts.

Under the kindly eye of popular coach Robert Waseige, who took control eight months ago, they have rediscovered an enthusiasm which had all but disappeared. What a transformation since their last appearance in a major competition, when Belgium were patently the most forgettable, unglamorous bunch at France 98. They possess more colour this time around, with the speedy young striker Emile Mpenza at the hub of their hopes. They are a settled, organised, motivated unit now. Sometimes they retreat into the grey ways of old but at others they are surprisingly exciting. With home advantage they believe they possess what it takes to reach the quarter-finals at least.

Sweden came to Brussels thinking exactly the same. Justifiably so, having finished a mammoth nine points in front of England in qualifying for Euro 2000. They started confidently, piling on the early pressure. Totem striker Kennet Andersson should have opened the scoring with a firm downward header, before his lively partner Jorgen Pettersson caused such disarray in the box Lorenzo Staelens stuck out a leg and almost diverted the ball into his own net. Sweden looked like a team in control. But for all their probing they lacked the killer touch.

Having recovered from his gruesome leg break, Celtic's predator Henrik Larsson was largely restricted to stretching his legs on the athletics track. His country urgently need him to play a bigger part soon.

Belgium were wary of Sweden, whose defensive record is ominous indeed. The headline in Brussels daily Le So ir described a 'glacial monster' to be overcome. Soon enough, though, they began to pick holes in the Sweden rearguard. If Joachim Bjorklund looked uncertain, Roland Nilsson was totally bemused. The former Premiership defender has been heavily criticised for a series of blunders for Helsingborg recently. Age has suddenly caught up on him, and time and again he was guilty of miscontrolling clearances.

Belgium should have capitalised. Branko Strupar tried with a long-range bobbler and Mpenza's header from Gert Verheyen's excellent delivery from the right flank was promising. But no joy. Yet.

Nilsson's next mistake was fatal. With half-time fast approaching, he was caught in possession by Bart Goor, and the talented Anderlecht winger cantered into the box to curl the ball with a swagger past Magnus Hedman. It was the first time the Coventry keeper had been beaten in a competitive match since Alan Shearer's free-kick way back in September 1998.

Then like the buses, as they say . . . immediately after the restart Belgium conjured a second goal of sensational quality. With a shrewd backheel flick of the outside of his right boot, Strupar freed Mpenza. What a finish. The 22-year-old rammed the ball with immense power and precision - and plenty of flourish - to send the majority of the 50,000 crowd into raptures.

Sweden were stung, and in need of some divine intervention to recover. It came in the form of some diabolical defending Belgian style. Phillipe Leonard's back-pass was woefully underhit, goalkeeper Fillip De Wilde's control equally hapless, and Johan Mjallby skipped in to jab into an empty net.

De Wilde made amends of sorts with a brave save to beat away a clipped shot from the increasingly dangerous Freddie Ljungberg. On came Larsson to lend his poacher's instincts to the cause. But bouyant Belgium seemed the likelier to score again, with Luc Nilis emerging from the bench to add a purposeful creative dimension.

Sweden's hopes dwindled further ten minutes from the end when Patrik Andersson was dismissed for fouling Goor, his second booking.

Nothing could detract from the joy of Waseige's men, who deserved to milk their bows at the end. For a nation who haven't even taken part in the European Championship finals since 1984, this is one to relish.
