fields.headline: Syrian dictator Assad is dead
fields.trailText: President Hafez Assad of Syria died of a heart attack aged 69 yesterday, plunging his country into a succession crisis and throwing the troubled Middle East peace process into confusion.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg, Jerusalem, and Martin Bright
fields.body:
President Hafez Assad of Syria died of a heart attack aged 69 yesterday, plunging his country into a succession crisis and throwing the troubled Middle East peace process into confusion.

Breaking the news on Syrian state-run television, the announcer choked and wept. Shops closed and residents of the capital hung black banners from their apartment balconies. Assad - known as 'the Lion of Damascus' - had ruled his country cunningly but ruthlessly for 30 years, and most of his countrymen have known no other leader.

But he did not survive long enough to complete the preparations for his 35-year-old son, Bashar, to take over. Within two hours of the death announcement Syria's parliament had met in urgent session, with some of its members in tears, and amended the constitution to lower the minimum age for the presidency from 40 to 34.

Assad's death pre-empted a special conference of the ruling Baa'th party which had been due to meet next Saturday to confirm Bashar as the chosen successor. As word spread in Damascus people gathered in the streets near the presidential palace, chanting: 'With our souls, with our blood, we will protect you, O Bashar.'

But officials at the US State department were last night bracing themselves for a behind-the-scenes power struggle in Syria. The concern among all Clinton administration officials is 'not what is happening before the cameras but what is happening backstage', said one official. 'There's going to be a lot of movement - in the military, in the power structure and in the Assad family.'

Meanwhile the future of Syrian-Israeli peace talks, frozen since January, has never been more uncertain. One military analyst on Israeli television was categorical. 'From this day onwards, Syria is no longer Syria,' said Ehud Ya'ari.

Israelis and Palestinians alike last night declared the end of an era with the passing of Assad, who exercised a steely grip on Syria. Most expect that designated heir Bashar, despite his image as a web-surfing moderniser, eventually will prove every inch his father's son - which means holding the line in peace talks with the Jewish state. But it is unclear how the changing of the guard will rebound on events in Lebanon.

In Jerusalem the prime minister, Ehud Barak, adopted a conciliatory tone, and a veiled invitation to pick up the peace talks. 'Israel worked in the past for a peace deal with Syria and will continue to work for this in the future with all future leadership,' the prime minister's office said

. The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, declared three days of mourning for the man who had accused him of making the 'peace of cowards' with Israel.

In Britain Tony Blair called Assad 'a figure of stability in the Middle East and much respected in the Arab world and beyond. The best testimony to President Assad's memory would be for all involved to redouble their efforts to bring a just and lasting peace to the region.'

However, despite the generous condolences Assad will be remembered by many as a vicious and brutal dictator who slaughtered tens of thousands of political opponents.

fields.headline: Southpaws make England suffer
fields.standfirst: ...on the strange West Indians' leftie bias
fields.trailText: Vic Marks: England dare not ignore the facts. The West Indies, by conservative estimate, will have six left-handers in their line-up at Edgbaston on Thursday. And England's recent record against left-handers is appalling.
fields.body:
England dare not ignore the facts. The West Indies, by conservative estimate, will have six left-handers in their line-up at Edgbaston on Thursday, five of them serious batsmen. And England's recent record against left-handers is appalling.

Left-handers have tormented them over the last decade. Since Mark Taylor hit 219 at Nottingham in 1989, English bowlers have conceded seven double centuries in Test cricket. All of them have been scored by left-handers. Our bowlers tend to be neutered by anyone who bats the wrong way round. In chronological order England's tormentors have been Taylor, Aamir Sohail, Vinod Kambli, Allan Border, Brian Lara, Gary Kirsten, Sinath Jayasuriya and Kirsten again.

The West Indian southpaws come in all shapes and sizes. There's Shivnarine Chanderpaul, who still looks as if he's turned up straight from school, even if he made his Test debut in 1993, and captain Jimmy Adams, who might have been coached by Brian Bolus so often does he use his pads. The latest is Wavell Hinds, who likes to beat the ball. Ridley Jacobs is a burly and uncomplicated keeper/batsman and there's a chap called Lara.

Brian Lara's trials have provided some good copy since the West Indies have arrived in England. There's even been the suggestion that he might not play at Edgbaston. Ask the England dressing room whether they would like him in or out of the side and you would get a unanimous response. Lara will be there at one of his favourite hunting grounds and whether he scores runs at Arundel against the Zimbabweans this weekend or not he remains the most feared member of the West Indian line-up.

His rehabilitation has been hindered by a terrible pitch at Cardiff. The West Indies have not complained though they had every right to. Some England touring sides would have been up in arms if they had such a dire surface on which to prepare for an overseas Test match, but the West Indies rolled up their sleeves impressively and won by 21 runs. In the process Nixon McLean threatened the current pecking order among the West Indian pacemen.

Lara was not alone in struggling at Cardiff and I suspect he will be ready and most definitely hungry by Thursday along with his fellow left-handers. How will England's attack - the trio of pacemen are bound to stay the same despite the lack-lustre performance at Trent Bridge - cope with them all? Andy Caddick can take the wickets of left-handers but he is undoubtedly more vulnerable against them as well. His method is geared to bowling at right-handers; to shape the ball away and to aim for steep bounce around off-stump, which keeps the slip cordon busy. His margin for error is reduced significantly when trying to swing the ball back into left-handers. When the two sides last met Lara, in particular, chose to take the attack to him, and he was rattled by the assault. This duel will be fascinating.

Gough at his best threatens them with the new ball. His spell at Lord's in the second innings against Zimbabwe, when he dismissed Alistair Campbell and Andy Flower in quick succession with late in-swing was awesome. But when the ball is older his reverse swing is not so potent to left-handers. Ed Giddins has a reputation of being good at left-handers since he has the capacity to seam the ball away from them. He'll have ample opportunity to justify that at Edgbaston.

Now to Chris Schofield. Leg spin is less threatening to the left-hander, which is one reason why I would not play him at Edgbaston. Another is that he is patently not ready for Test cricket. It still bewilders me that he was given a central contract, which deliv ers the tacit message that those at the centre do not trust the coaching staffs at the counties to develop young players. Yet who is the coach at Lancashire? Bobby Simpson, who oversaw the emergence of Shane Warne and who probably knows more about wrist spinners (he was a good one himself) than anyone else over here.

Schofield, whose promise I recognise, has much to learn and I don't think his education would be enhanced by bowling at a battery of left-handers at Edgbaston. Nor would England's chances of winning the match. So Robert Croft should be recalled, partly because I can't think of anyone else, partly because he has just bowled well against the tourists at Cardiff - even though conditions were stacked in his favour - partly because off-spinners are more dangerous against left-handers. They have a better chance of finding the edge and of containing the batsmen, which is one of the spinner's roles in the modern game.

Other changes of personnel will have been discussed by the selectors last night. Andrew Flintoff was woeful against the swinging ball at Trent Bridge, leaden-footed and slow in thought. He may prefer to face an attack that sets little store by swing. England will - and probably should - retain him, but time is ticking by and the Lancashire player has still not yet made a meaningful contribution in his eight Test matches.

Nick Knight also looked technically bereft at Trent Bridge, with his head falling towards cover point against the inswinger. Here my inclination would be to replace him with Michael Vaughan, in the runs immediately on his return to the Yorkshire side after injury.

I would also be keen to recall one of England's wayward left-handers, Graham Thorpe, but he's still stuck in a deep trough. As I mentioned last week Thorpe is a quality player, but he's not Brian Lara; so he has to wait his turn.

Double centurions who have tormented England

Mark Taylor (Aus) st Russell b Cook 219 Nottingham - 1989

Aamir Sohail (Pak) b Lewis 205 Manchester - 1992

fields.bodyText: England dare not ignore the facts. The West Indies, by conservative estimate, will have six left-handers in their line-up at Edgbaston on Thursday, five of them serious batsmen. And England's recent record against left-handers is appalling. Left-handers have tormented them over the last decade. Since Mark Taylor hit 219 at Nottingham in 1989, English bowlers have conceded seven double centuries in Test cricket. All of them have been scored by left-handers. Our bowlers tend to be neutered by anyone who bats the wrong way round. In chronological order England's tormentors have been Taylor, Aamir Sohail, Vinod Kambli, Allan Border, Brian Lara, Gary Kirsten, Sinath Jayasuriya and Kirsten again. The West Indian southpaws come in all shapes and sizes. There's Shivnarine Chanderpaul, who still looks as if he's turned up straight from school, even if he made his Test debut in 1993, and captain Jimmy Adams, who might have been coached by Brian Bolus so often does he use his pads. The latest is Wavell Hinds, who likes to beat the ball. Ridley Jacobs is a burly and uncomplicated keeper/batsman and there's a chap called Lara. Brian Lara's trials have provided some good copy since the West Indies have arrived in England. There's even been the suggestion that he might not play at Edgbaston. Ask the England dressing room whether they would like him in or out of the side and you would get a unanimous response. Lara will be there at one of his favourite hunting grounds and whether he scores runs at Arundel against the Zimbabweans this weekend or not he remains the most feared member of the West Indian line-up. His rehabilitation has been hindered by a terrible pitch at Cardiff. The West Indies have not complained though they had every right to. Some England touring sides would have been up in arms if they had such a dire surface on which to prepare for an overseas Test match, but the West Indies rolled up their sleeves impressively and won by 21 runs. In the process Nixon McLean threatened the current pecking order among the West Indian pacemen. Lara was not alone in struggling at Cardiff and I suspect he will be ready and most definitely hungry by Thursday along with his fellow left-handers. How will England's attack - the trio of pacemen are bound to stay the same despite the lack-lustre performance at Trent Bridge - cope with them all? Andy Caddick can take the wickets of left-handers but he is undoubtedly more vulnerable against them as well. His method is geared to bowling at right-handers; to shape the ball away and to aim for steep bounce around off-stump, which keeps the slip cordon busy. His margin for error is reduced significantly when trying to swing the ball back into left-handers. When the two sides last met Lara, in particular, chose to take the attack to him, and he was rattled by the assault. This duel will be fascinating. Gough at his best threatens them with the new ball. His spell at Lord's in the second innings against Zimbabwe, when he dismissed Alistair Campbell and Andy Flower in quick succession with late in-swing was awesome. But when the ball is older his reverse swing is not so potent to left-handers. Ed Giddins has a reputation of being good at left-handers since he has the capacity to seam the ball away from them. He'll have ample opportunity to justify that at Edgbaston. Now to Chris Schofield. Leg spin is less threatening to the left-hander, which is one reason why I would not play him at Edgbaston. Another is that he is patently not ready for Test cricket. It still bewilders me that he was given a central contract, which deliv ers the tacit message that those at the centre do not trust the coaching staffs at the counties to develop young players. Yet who is the coach at Lancashire? Bobby Simpson, who oversaw the emergence of Shane Warne and who probably knows more about wrist spinners (he was a good one himself) than anyone else over here. Schofield, whose promise I recognise, has much to learn and I don't think his education would be enhanced by bowling at a battery of left-handers at Edgbaston. Nor would England's chances of winning the match. So Robert Croft should be recalled, partly because I can't think of anyone else, partly because he has just bowled well against the tourists at Cardiff - even though conditions were stacked in his favour - partly because off-spinners are more dangerous against left-handers. They have a better chance of finding the edge and of containing the batsmen, which is one of the spinner's roles in the modern game. Other changes of personnel will have been discussed by the selectors last night. Andrew Flintoff was woeful against the swinging ball at Trent Bridge, leaden-footed and slow in thought. He may prefer to face an attack that sets little store by swing. England will - and probably should - retain him, but time is ticking by and the Lancashire player has still not yet made a meaningful contribution in his eight Test matches. Nick Knight also looked technically bereft at Trent Bridge, with his head falling towards cover point against the inswinger. Here my inclination would be to replace him with Michael Vaughan, in the runs immediately on his return to the Yorkshire side after injury. I would also be keen to recall one of England's wayward left-handers, Graham Thorpe, but he's still stuck in a deep trough. As I mentioned last week Thorpe is a quality player, but he's not Brian Lara; so he has to wait his turn. fields.headline: Forerunners of the Caribbean juggernaut
fields.trailText: A golden age of English cricket .... and the West Indians beaten by an innings. Those were the days! Exactly 100 years ago in fact.
fields.body:
A golden age of English cricket .... and the West Indians beaten by an innings. Those were the days! Exactly 100 years ago in fact. A century ago today the West Indians played their first game in England in a tough baptism against a powerful London County side at Crystal Palace.

Appropriately for such an historic occasion the incomparable Dr W.G. Grace, then still a formidable force, faced the first ball they bowled here. The doctor, the driving force behind the County, had selected a 'capital' eleven that included, in addition to himself, Billy Murdoch, the former Australian captain who had settled in this country, and a leavening of players with Test Match experience.

Against this combination the tourists mustered what was really an ensemble rather than a team. In those days of long sea-journeys between territories they had not played together before. Several had not gone beyond their own island, found three-day cricket to be a strain, and the climate and pitches of even a good English summer quite foreign. Woods, the leading quick bowler, often lost heart, and once asked if he could bowl without boots so he could feel the earth beneath his feet.

These tourists were essentially a melange of the white plantocracy with the right social and educational connections and black labourers a generation or two out of slavery. The latter were tested socially, too, as black faces in the cricketing ranks were less than few and far between. Some could not take time off from work and duties, or afford to be away, for such a long tour. The absentees included leading batsman Harold Austin, a future captain, who was fighting in the South African War.

Yet they had performed well enough on their own pitches against largely amateur visiting teams from England to merit - at the persistence of Lord Hawke with Dr Grace's support - a chance to test their worth against England's best. The visitors admitted freely that they had 'come to learn'.

The game itself was no match at all. From the moment openers Grace and Gilman set off with a 138-run partnership the bowlers knew that they were out of their depth and in for the thrashing which century-makers Mason, possibly then the best all-rounder in the country, and Parkes administered. Facing a 538-run total the visitors lost four early wickets - three to Grace - before Goodman and Cox offered their only real resistance. Both passed 50, but when they were out Mason routed the lower-order. Handicapped by deteriorating ground conditions in the follow-on 301 runs behind, the West Indians were shot out again by Grace and Mason as the County triumphed by an innings and 198 runs.

Most of the ensuing games went the same way. There were successes, too, among the losses. Minor Counties at Northampton provided the first West Indian victory in England, Leicestershire the first over a county, and Surrey, outplayed by an innings, a prestigious scalp. Wisden commented: 'As an experiment the tour was extremely interesting and far more successful than might have been expected.'

C.A. Ollivierre led the batting, sharing in two double-century first-wicket partnerships. Wisden : 'considering his opportunities of playing cricket in St Vincent must have been very limited, his performance was remarkable'. Ollivierre returned to play with distinction for Derbyshire, forerunner of his now plentiful compatriots who have made a career in the county championship.

Lebrun Constantine scored the West Indians' first century on the hallowed turf at Lord's: his son Learie would make his own mark there and at many other grounds. Another name associated with Lord's - the name associated with Lord's - Pelham Warner, hit a hundred against Leicestershire in his only innings for his native region. He was born in Trinidad and his brother, Aucher, was the tourists' captain. In his tour report Pelham Warner wrote that there were 'plenty of good cricketers scattered over the islands'.

Woods, who had already rattled teams visiting the Caribbean, shared with Burton in bowling out Norfolk for just 32 runs in the last innings of the tour. These players would come again and how they have learned _ to the extent that we are celebrating this summer the fiftieth anniversary of West Indies winning their first Test match, and series, in England and twenty-fifth anniversary of them winning the first World Cup. Now they are here again - as Wisden foresaw 'Englishmen will be right glad to welcome another West Indian eleven'.

Just what the good doctor would have ordered.

fields.headline: Alleyne leads one-day masters
fields.trailText: For the third time in 11 months Mark Alleyne, the most self-effacing and dignified of county captains, smiled his shy smile on the Lord's balcony as he hoisted another one-day trophy to the skies.
fields.body:
For the third time in 11 months Mark Alleyne, the most self-effacing and dignified of county captains, smiled his shy smile on the Lord's balcony as he hoisted another one-day trophy to the skies. The outstanding individual performance may have come from a Welshman - or at least an adopted one - Matthew Maynard, but Gloucestershire under the calm guidance of Alleyne were patently the superior team.

Their bowlers, pop-gunners in the longer game, but now schooled and confident in one-day cricket were all on target; their batsmen all contributed and for good measure their fielders were as sharp as ever, grabbing two straightforward run-outs. Their target of 226 caused few alarms once Kim Barnett, a month away from his fortieth birthday, and Tim Hancock had launched the innings with an opening partnership of 80 in 16 overs. They cruised home by seven wickets with 3.1 overs to spare. Fittingly Alleyne was still there to make the winning hit, though for most of his innings he could look on admiringly as Matt Windows in a romp to the tape, kept hoisting the ball to the legside boundary.

The Welsh bowlers appeared neutered when bowling on a proper pitch. At Cardiff last week they could bowl a full length with impunity. Such deliveries merely shuddered the bottom of West Indian bats and went nowhere; short ones double declutched on landing and limped along the ground. Here on a blameless surface the batsmen could take liberties; half-volleys were pummelled; short balls bounced and could be attacked and Hancock, Barnett, Alleyne and Windows all enjoyed themselves.

Suddenly those bowlers that had paralysed Lara and his fellow West Indies were impotent against stalwart county pros. Glamorgan cricket and cricketers will only continue to prosper if they sort out their square.

But for Maynard we would not have had a game at all. He had to wait 16 years for the chance to display his talents in a Lord's final, but when it came he did not spurn it. Maynard is old by modern cricketing standards, but not that old. He's 34 and wasn't around when Glamorgan made their last visit to Lord's in 1977. He may also be at his peak. Yesterday he stroked a century that was flawless in judgment and execution until the final over when he erroneously sacrificed the strike. He was a rare man of the match award winner to find himself on the losing side.

Maynard has not always been so serene when responsibility has been tossed on to his shoulders. In four Test matches and 10 one-day internationals for England he failed to make an impact. We all waited for him to erupt with breathtaking strokeplay that was so familiar on the county circuit. Yesterday there were no explosions either, but this is because Maynard has matured. His strokeplay now is more calculating; he now assesses the risks and takes fewer chances.

So while his 100 was sprinkled with drives and pulls of the highest quality, there was nothing too audacious; the ball was kept on the ground; the shots were orthodox. Like other one-day 'experts' such as Neil Fairbrother he has learnt not to strive for breathtaking boundaries all the time. He now appreciates singles as well.

If it wasn't for his age and a modest record he would surely be inked into England's one day squad for the triangular series. He may still be considered for Duncan Fletcher is well aware of his capabilities, though his selection would not tie in with David Graveney's declared concern to prepare for the next World Cup in three year's time.

Maynard, having won the toss, was at the crease by the ninth over. Glamorgan stuck to their policy of opening with Robert Croft even though this ploy seems to waste the talents of an in-form Steve James as well as the sparkiness of Croft down the order.

Croft cunningly batted eighteen inches outside his crease to combat the swing of Mike Smith but soon fell at the other end, undone by Harvey's away swing. So was Matthew Elliott, who was bowled off the inside edge.

Now Maynard joined forces with Michael Powell in the only significant partnership of the innings - 137 from 31 overs. Maynard easily outpaced Powell because he always seemed to hit the gaps. None the less Powell's innings hinted at his promise. There were some superbly struck drives that often hit the field. Powell is one to follow. He is predominantly a front-foot player. Who wouldn't be when nurtured at Cardiff?

As the score mounted Alleyne shuffled his bowlers astutely and none of them let him down. But he had to wait until the fortieth over when his sixth bowler, the off-spinner Jeremy Snape induced Powell to return a straightforward catch. Even though Maynard stayed until the last over the Glamorgan innings now lost momentum as Alleyne's team closed in. From 161-2 in the fortieth over they subsided to 225 all out with three balls still remaining

There were a couple of run-outs and Harvey, who finished with the exceptional figures of five for 34, which were not at all flattering, was typically adept in those closing overs. With Russell snarling up at the stumps Harvey and his willing pupil, James Averis, delivered their usual hotch-potch of yorkers, slower balls and away-swingers, indecipherable to all but Maynard.

Croft, sure to be named in the Test squad this morning, induced Barnett to inside edge a drive on to his stumps. Watkin produced one brutish lifter for Cunliffe and Parkin held a magnificent return catch to dismiss Hancock. Thereafter Windows and Alleyne cracked 95 in 104 balls.

fields.headline: Lord's tinged by Cronje trial
fields.trailText: As Herschelle Gibbs and others turn on Hansie Cronje in Cape Town and pour out the confessions that could sink the entire game of international cricket, you cannot help but notice certain similarities between South Africa and Wales.
fields.body:
As Herschelle Gibbs and others turn on Hansie Cronje in Cape Town and pour out the confessions that could sink not only their former Springbok captain but the entire game of international cricket, you cannot help but notice certain similarities between South Africa and Wales.

OK, I know that Monnow Valley Vineyards are hardly Stellenbosch Wineries and the Brecon Beacons are mere bumps alongside the Drakensbergs, but for every flat-earth Afrikaner fundamentalist there has to be a lunatic Welsh-speaking Salem-Bethesda chapel-goer who, in a moment of weakness has like Cronje, let Satan enter.

And since Glamorgan are essentially Wales when it comes to cricket you could not help wonder what was going on in Jack Brown the Bookmakers every time something negative happened out in the middle. Two leading-edge dismissals from Robert Croft and Keith Newell must, however, be hard to manufacture.

On the other hand, the odds were probably very good. 'Bombay calling Bedlinog; 120,00 rupee-rand says Croftee-Sahib cannot edge one to mid-off in the seventh over.' The Welsh offer far more cunning than Herschelle Gibbs, whose dropped World Cup catch against Australia was amateur panto.

The Welsh are also better on stage and under interrogation. The trouble with Truth and Reconciliation Commissions is that they encourage people to, er, tell the truth. This would never do in Wales where story-telling, gloomy irony and sick-notes are national institutions.

Grown men simply do not burst into tears at the first tricky question from a posh bloke in a wig. When a rebel Welsh tour went to South Africa in the early 90s, did anybody crack, even when put on the rack by the Grand Inquisitor Vernon Pugh? You can bet they didn't.

Mind you, no Welsh captain would be allowed to do what Cronje apparently did and keep a handsome proportion of the bung for himself. That would have been unfair. Matthew Maynard is far too honourable, although, come to think of it, he did display a greedy side to his nature by hogging half the Glamorgan total for himself with an innings of 104..

In all truth it is probably stretching things a little far to imagine that Glamorgan had let Satan in. You know those similarities between the Jappies and the Taffs? Well, to be honest, Cape Town is a long way from Splott.

But what about Gloucestershire? Up on the High Veld of the Cotswolds might there be some disenchanted Wesleyan enclave dancing by moonlight with Old Nick and prepared to wage class war on cricket? A sort of post-Methodist November 17 group spurred into direct action when their Lottery application for a new thatched roof on the pavilion was turned down?

Don't scoff. What did Matt Windows use to do in the winter? Work for Sporting Index, the spread-betters, that's what. If Bourton-on-the-Water CC have a makeover because Kim Barnett and Tim Hancock took 49 balls to knock off the first 50 in their reply to Glamorgan's score, then I think Judge Edwin King should be asking some pretty stern questions in Cape Town. And, closer to home, why, after years of corruption in the Cotswolds, have the police not made a single arrest? Not even Jilly Cooper.

I apologise. Lord's was bathed in sunlight, the trains pulled into Paddington from the West alive with intermingling bonhomie and everybody down there in white in the homely bowl of the headquarters of the game was giving it their all. God, please re-enter Hansie's life. If this is all a sham, then we may as well all pack up and go home to watch wrestling on pay-per-view.

I had to find something positive on which to cling. There was the bowling action of Jeremy Snape, who, strike me down, was the spitting image of our own Vic Marks when he wheeled for Somerset. If he just drops his hands a bit in his run-up.

Ah, refuge in the past. I found I used to play club cricket against the fathers of Michael Powell and Adrian Dale. John and John of Abergavenny and Chepstow respectively. Now, those were the days...

So, there you have it. A day that swung between cynical suspicion of sport in modern times and a rather doddering retreat into times past. Cricket all over.

Reality, though, must lie somewhere between the two and maybe a few strokes were pulled in the days of WG Grace to put a new bed of thatch on the roof of a Cotswold pavilion. Maybe Satan, after taking a couple of snorters with Hansie & Co, has been shown the door. Don't bet on it.

fields.headline: Players suffer ICC bat attack
fields.trailText: Show me the green, the old days were the best, and membership (of Nottinghamshire CCC) has it priviledges.
fields.body:
Test-match outfields, once a pristine green, are now overlaid with a commercial logo. The stumps also carry the sponsor's name. Even the jackets of the Test-match umpires feature the name of a shopping chain. Now another major property - players' bats - is the focus of some agitated debate ahead of a key meeting of the International Cricket Council.

Four years ago, Sachin Tendulkar forced the issue by using a bat emblazoned with the letters MRF - Madras Rubber Factory, who are big sponsors of Indian cricket. The ICC tried to stop it but, under legal challenge, subsequently agreed to change their rules to allow a 'manufacturer's or commercial logo' on the face and back of the bat. But conflicts inevitably emerged, for example with a Coca-Cola bat in a Pepsi-sponsored competition.

Now, the ICC wants to backtrack. They seek to recognise only bona fide bat makers and moreover to restrict the maker's logo to 7.5 square inches. Slazenger's trademark panther is currently over 15 square inches, and the company is not happy. Nor are players' representatives. Smaller logos will inevitably mean smaller endorsements for players contracted to Slazenger, the biggest payers, with a knock-on effect throughout the pro game.

Manufacturers are submitting counter proposals, while international cricketers' representatives are pressing to be allowed to speak at the ICC meeting on June 22/23. Says a Slazenger's spokesman: 'We're not happy with the way it's going, the players are being by-passed.'

Jimmy Adams wins a Test match for the West Indies, falls to the grounds with arms outstretched, and is soon buried under a pile of team-mates. A few days later The Oval is witness to an identical scene. Hampshire's last pair having made 90 of the 93 runs required for victory, Alex Tudor ends it by pouching a skied caught-and-bowled, falls flat and is engulfed by players who throw themselves on him like footballers celebrating a goal.

How strange, then, the scene that celluloid has preserved from the Headingley Test of 1948 after Donald Bradman has been bowled for 33 - the sort of score at which it usually needed dynamite to remove the greatest-ever batsman. Having struck the stumps with a good 'un, Dick Pollard, he of the amiable, flat-footed run and baggy flannels, simply walks to the off-side and, smiling, receives a hand-shake from a cover fieldsman.

It was a suspect dismissal of a South African batsman, but in Darryll Cullinan's case the consequences have been confined to a change in the law. Cullinan fell to a controversial boundary catch by Sri Lanka's Chaminda Vaas in last year's World Cup, the running fieldsman making a clean catch and then getting rid of the ball before his momentum took him over the boundary. That would be not-out under the new laws, which require the catcher to have control over both the ball and his own movement. However, he could still throw the ball up before crossing the boundary and return to complete the catch.

Dry cleaning for £1.50 is currently one of the more unusual perks of Nottinghamshire membership. The company responsible for cleaning staff uniforms decided that they could just as easily collect and return members' dry cleaning as well, if it was available by 10.30am. The firm, Indigo, says it is 'testing the water' and might extend the scheme to the general public. But why stop at dry cleaning? Hairdressing and shoe polishing might also be popular. And what a great opportunity to discuss investment schemes with one of those eager advisors for whom you never seem to have the time.

fields.headline: Fallen Lara strikes back
fields.trailText: A man who had not picked up a bat for three months then made scores of 1, 1, 0 and 11 on his comeback trail would have been expected to be tense and circumspect on his next outing. But not Brian Charles Lara.
fields.body:
A man who had not picked up a bat for three months then made scores of 1, 1, 0 and 11 on his comeback trail would have been expected to be tense and circumspect on his next outing, more so with the first Test of a series only four days away. But not Brian Charles Lara.

Against only the third ball he faced yesterday, from Neil Johnson, who had claimed both the wickets the West Indians had lost in crawling to 55, he lifted his bat high and cracked it through point for the first of the 25 fours he struck, not forgetting five sixes, in a glorious 176 which left no doubt that his powers remain undiminished.

A Zimbabwean attack of near Test strength was immediately placed under seige. Brian Strang was twice driven straight, pre-empting his immediate withdrawal from the attack. Pommie Mbangwa - who, a fortnight ago, had bowled out Yorkshire almost singlehandedly - was twice hoisted over mid-wicket and, in between, driven, cut and pulled for three fours. A backfoot drive over extra-cover's head propelled Lara to his fifty off only 43 balls.

Lara's feet twinkled and his bat, lifted high, swung through with grace. The matchless splendour of Arundel Castle's ground and a large, sun-drenched crowd had Lara inspired. Having come in 16 minutes after lunch, Lara was well past his hundred at tea and the next 50 came from 45 balls.

From being audacious, Lara then became reckless. A couple of big hits were miscued and then, hitting right across the 163rd ball he received, from Bryan Strang, he was bowled.

The Zimbabweans stood up bravely to Lara's onslaught and did not lose their humour. Left-arm spinner Dirk Viljoen, who had been driven high for two sixes in the previous over, celebrated a maiden with high-fives.

Sherwin Campbell, who remained unbeaten with 141, was at his most fluent when he was in the company of Lara for 51 overs, during which 276 runs were added. Some of Lara's brilliance rubbed off on him and he played some handsome cover-drives.

For all of the morning, Campbell's main preoccupation had been the building of a foundation to the innings. The West Indians had been put in on a pitch that had traces of damp after being under covers during a very wet Friday.

It was slow in pace and the bounce was low, but did afford some movement to the seamers. Adrian Griffith was trapped lbw to one that kept low, the score then only nine. Shivnarine Chanderpaul was hard put to pierce the field and, in a stay of 110 minutes, could muster only 17 runs before Johnson found his edge for a slip catch.

Campbell, making ample use of the bottom hand to try to force the ball away, was on 31 when he was joined by Lara. He was on 118 when Lara left him, having taken 252 balls to reach his hundred, with 14 fours.

A collapse followed Lara's exit. Jimmy Adams went in the same over, caught at gulley. Young Ramnaresh Sarwan played right across the line and became Strang's third victim, and Ridley Jacobs, the fifth of six left-handers in the order, was defeated by an in-swinger of full length from Mbangwa, reducing the West Indians to 338 for six.

It would seem that the West Indians would have appreciated at least one more match before the first Test, beginning at Edgbaston on Thursday. Their batting line-up would depend on the extent of Wavell Hinds's recovery from an Achilles tendon injury and if he is fit, they might consider leaving out Griffith and promoting Chanderpaul, who made a century at Worcester, to open the innings with Campbell.

Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh, who did much hard work during the two series at home in the winter, will go into the Test cold. They were again kept under wraps. Of the other four pace bowlers in the party, Reon King was also rested while Nixon McLean, well experienced to bowl in English conditions after his stint with Hampshire, must be a strong contender after taking ten wickets in the first two matches.

fields.headline: Heath Ledger
fields.standfirst: The brawn-again wizard from Oz
fields.trailText: As far as the movies are concerned, being 'Australian' is a guarantee of uninhibited masculinity. Which might just explain the otherwise unlikely choice of Perth-born Heath Ledger to play Mel Gibson's son in the new American Revolution epic, The Patriot.
fields.body:
There's a 'fact' doing the rounds that claims Australia has more ballet dancers per capita than any other country. It's probably urban myth, along the lines of the Swedish suicide rate or the six degrees of separation. And what is certain is that no one in the film business believes it. When Ridley Scott was trying to think of an actor who was tough enough to play the lead in Gladiator, he considered Mel Gibson, then decided he was too old and went for Russell Crowe.

Because as far as the movies are concerned, being 'Australian' is a guarantee of uninhibited masculinity. Which might just explain the otherwise unlikely choice of Perth-born Heath Ledger to play Gibson's son in the new American Revolution epic, The Patriot.

'From what I've seen, it is absolutely the most perfect time for Australians to be here,' Ledger says. Unlike the New Zealand-born Crowe or the New York State-spawned Gibson, the 21-year-old Ledger is unambiguously Australian.

But like them, he looks like he could be handier in a fight than your average young Hollywoodite. In Ten Things I Hate About You, last year's teen Taming Of The Shrew reworking, Ledger's hulking build and wild hair made him seem older than most of his co-stars, even though he was actually a rare real teenager in a high-school movie.

Ledger started acting at 12, and did the usual Australian TV thing, including a spot on Home And Away and a series called Sweat in which, intriguingly, he played a gay cyclist. That led to Roar, which was a short lived American made but Queensland based series with Ledger getting to show off his brawn in the role of a fifth-century Celtic warrior. Although the show is still fondly remembered by pubescent American girls, it only lasted a season.

But not long after that, Ledger got the part of Patrick in Ten Things I Hate About You and the lead in Two Hands, a darkly comic thriller that was a big hit back in Australia. All in all, it seems like a pretty smooth rise.

Next up he'll be taking top billing in A Knight's Tale, a medieval adventure by Payback director Brian Helgeland. But Ledger's big showcase is The Patriot, made by the Independence Day team of Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich and clearly aimed at the Braveheart niche in the cinema market. As the vehemently anti-British son, Ledger is the one who spurs the initially reluctant hero (Gibson) into action.

'He's incredibly quick,' Gibson says. 'I recall how shit scared he was when we first started, but we joked around, as guys do, and before long, he fitted in perfectly.'

But maybe Heath Ledger isn't quite as much of a pure Aussie bloke as everyone thinks. He couldn't manage to be stoic through the eighteenth-century soldiering required for the part, refusing to hide the pain when he shred a finger firing a musket. 'I wasn't a brave soldier,' he confesses.

Five things you should know about Heath Ledger:

1. His favourite actor is Gene Kelly.

2. He used to have a pet kangaroo. No, really.

3. Improbably, for an Australian who also lived in LA for three years, he doesn't own a car.

4. He was told off for singing too well in the football stadium sequence in Ten Things...

5. He was a highly rated hockey player in his schooldays.

He was a highly rated hockey player in his schooldays.

fields.headline: Wooed with violence
fields.standfirst: The wonder of Woo: John Woo's balletic style has made him the most admired action film director in Hollywood. Damon Wise charts his rise from Hong Kong B-movies to Mission: Impossible 2 and finds a moralist who is inspired by the grace of Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly.
fields.trailText: John Woo is a moralist, a romantic, and a superb director of action, which makes it all the more surprising that he's only just hitting his stride in Hollywood. Damon Wise charts his rise from Hong Kong B-movies to Mission: Impossible 2.
fields.body:
There is a filmmaker working in Hollywood today who had a tough upbringing. His father was ill, so his mother worked as a stonecutter to make ends meet. He had his first lesson in life, his first indication that things were not necessarily as they should be. So he began to wonder about a spiritual dimension, and was attracted to the Catholic Church. He even trained as a priest. The seminary, however, wouldn't accept him.

Even though his films have violence on a scale seldom seen elsewhere, you can still see the moral lessons of the scriptures there, just waiting to be noticed, absorbed and learnt. This man, however, is not Martin Scorsese. He's not even Catholic: John Woo was raised in Hong Kong and his family was very definitely Protestant. Even so, there was something about the Catholic Church that appealed to his innate sense of decency. In his breakthrough film The Killer in 1989 he included a scene few outside his hardcore fans would recognise as a signature flourish: the routine destruction of a statue of the Virgin Mary.

Some would see this as a yardstick of the way culture is headed, but Woo doesn't see it quite like that. 'Those scenes,' Woo said then, 'show how war can turn heaven into hell; anything that is pure and innocent is destroyed. The Virgin Mary symbolises purity, and she's shattered by bullets.'

John Woo is a great moralist. He's also a romantic, and a superb director of action, which makes it all the more surprising he's only just hitting his stride in Hollywood with the insanely successful sequel to Brian De Palma's Mission: Impossible, an action-heavy blockbuster that made leading man (and producer) Tom Cruise a multi-millionaire (again) in its opening four-day weekend. But Woo doesn't come from Hollywood, he never ran with the Movie Brats and could not conceivably be called a wunderkind. No, John Woo is a polite, well-dressed 52-year-old with a healthy disregard for the conventions of Hollywood filmmaking but a rigid respect for its moral codes. Talking about his movies of the late Eighties, he once told a interviewer: 'I was very influenced by musicals like Singin' In The Rain and West Side Story, and dancers like Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly. They have the rhythm of life. I shoot action scenes just as though they were dance sequences. I love ballet, I love dancing.'

So how did this man come to orchestrate some of the most outrageous - if not explicit - violence in movies? Born in Guanghzhou, south China, in 1948, his family saved enough to send him to college in Hong Kong, where he joined a student theatre group and began making short 8mm films. After graduating, he began working in the local movie industry and in 1973 he joined the famous Golden Harvest company, for whom he began working as a director. When his first film, The Young Dragons, was released in 1973, it was already a milestone. 'I was 26 when I made it,' he said, 'and it was rare for anyone under 40 to be trusted to direct.' Golden Harvest liked what they saw, and Woo was given a three-year contract.

Over the next 10 years, Woo became prolific, putting out an admirable 13 movies, though not all for Golden Harvest.Yet few of them figure in his biography. Who now would dwell on 1976's Princess Chang Ping, an attempt to capture on film some of the success of the Cantonese Opera. Or 1980's From Riches To Rags, a satire on consumerism that Woo himself acknowledges owes a debt to Mel Brooks, of all people. And although it's seen as a turning point by his biographers, few know of his 1986 film Heroes Shed No Tears, which caused an irreparable rift with his paymasters. 'Golden Harvest didn't like the focus on relationships or the bleakness of the ending,' said Woo. 'But I wouldn't agree to change anything, and so I abandoned it.' The film was released only after the commercial success of A Better Tomorrow, made three years later, which dealt with themes of love, loyalty and betrayal beneath its surface story of two brothers on either side of the law. It was, he said, 'the film I most wanted to make, but I was afraid that it might fail commercially. The audience is supposed to want pace, not serious issues and frightening violence and death.'

But the film, his first collaboration with local action star Chow Yun-Fat, was a hit from its first midnight preview screenings, and Woo became something of a cult figure in the faceless world of Hong Kong cinema. Three years later, after an ill-advised sequel, he teamed up again with Fat to make the film that cemented his reputation, The Killer, in which his leading man plays an assassin, double-crossed by the mob, being pursued by a cop whose job will be on the line if he doesn't deliver. It was a classic mirror theme to which the director would return throughout his career, reflecting his concern for moral issues, identity and equilibrium outside his bravura, balletic flair for chaos and violence.

The Killer and the following year's brutal A Bullet In The Head brought Woo to the West's attention, and 1992's Hard Boiled primed him for export. The simple story of a cop trying to bust a gun-running operation, which a plain-clothes colleague has infiltrated, Hard Boiled showed some of his most inventive work, but balanced it with a sentimental storyline that proved Woo was Hollywood material.

The following year, Evil Dead director Sam Raimi brought him to California to bring oriental flair to an action movie starring Jean-Claude Van Damme. A loose remake of the 1932 movie The Most Dangerous Game, in which an insane Russian count takes pleasure in hunting humans in place of animals, the film was switched to urban New Orleans and had Van Damme as a struggling merchant sailor drawn into this ongoing snuff match by accident.

Though it suffered poor reviews for its star and dialogue, the American press were generous to Woo's vision and even seemed to sympathise when he trimmed some three minutes of violence to appease the moralistic censor. Although not successful, the film brought Woo - and Hong Kong cinema - to a wider audience. Through Woo, cinemagoers began to understand the genealogy of Harvey Keitel's two-handed gunplay in Reservoir Dogs (a film believed to have been based on City On Fire by Woo's Hong Kong compadre Ringo Lam). They began to understand that violence could have a style, a context and a moral centre.

Championed by the likes of Raimi and Quentin Tarantino - whose Rolling Thunder outlet distributed early Woo and other Hong Kong directors - Woo found Hollywood hard going. His next outing, Broken Arrow, starring a cast-against-type John Travolta as a fighter pilot involved in a plot to steal nuclear weaponry, fared little better. But everything crystallised with Face/Off , a hokey sci-fi thriller in which mad bomber Castor Pollux (Nic Cage) surgically switches identity to infiltrate the life of police officer Sean Archer (Travolta). Travolta's character responds by undergoing the same surgery, effectively becoming the villain.

The result was Woo in exelsis, showing how comfortable the good guy is in the bad guy's skin but also the bad guy's winsome envy of the good guy's lifestyle. The set-piece is undoubtedly the moment in which a child wearing headphones stumbles through a scene of wanton carnage. The song playing on his Walkman is Somewhere Over The Rainbow, a last-minute substitute for Puff The Magic Dragon. The image sums up Woo's work and his impact.

After the casual gun-slinging of the Tarantino wannabes, Woo is still determined to give his work a conscience and emotional resonance. When Tom Cruise came to him with Mission: Impossible 2, his loathing of sequels meant he nearly turned it down. 'There's nothing creative about it,' he told Entertainment Weekly. 'You have to follow the first. You have to follow the same characters.' But when Cruise offered him artistic control, Woo changed his mind, and although the finished product shows the danger of writing dialogue to accommodate pre-ordained action scenes, MI2 still bears the hallmarks of an auteur working in a genre more accustomed to seeing Steven Seagal in a singed chef's hat than Nicolas Cage suffering a crisis of conscience. It takes an age to peak, before erupting into spectacular po-faced kung fu, but MI2 still dwells on issues most other action directors ignore or sweep under the carpet. Cruise's enemy is not a convenient Cold War nemesis but an old colleague gone bad. The battlefield they fight over is a beautiful female art thief, played by Thandie Newton.

Old traditions die hard, and even after 27 years, John Woo is inclined to put core Chinese values before the dollar sign. 'All of my movies are primarily about family, friendship, loyalty and honour.' If the box office receipts for MI2 are anything to go by, Woo might be on to something. It's just a shame Hollywood took so long to get him there.

Mission: Impossible 2 opens on 7 July.

fields.headline: Chicago hope
fields.standfirst: It has all the ingredients of a predictable, mawkish romantic comedy - but sometimes love can even conquer cynicism
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: You will them to get it together - and you feel good for them when they do.
fields.body:
Many are made, but few (romantic comedies, that is) are worth choosing. Simple cinematic affairs of the heart need a mystic chemistry. The time, the lovers and the world that surrounds them have to be right, so Return to Me is more than a tested formula expertly delivered - it has the chemistry. It sits alongside While You Were Sleeping and Moonstruck and, unselfconsciously, shares their fairy-tale world.

David Duchovny, old frozen face from The X Files, is Bob the Chicago builder married to a golden dream of a zoologist (Joely Richardson) who dies too soon. Her transplanted heart goes to Grace (Minnie Driver) who waits table at her grandad's restaurant, O'Reilly's Irish-Italian trattoria. Bob, slowly surfacing from grief, stops by for a spinach pasta. A slender yarn of high predictability, with an infinite ability to leave a bad taste - cloying or just plain sick - in the mouth.

None of that happens and it's instructive to see why. First, the fledgling director and co-writer, Bonnie Hunt, knows her Chicago hometown like a worn, cherished glove. The Lincoln Park zoo, where Sydney, the gorilla Joely left behind, pines for her, is more than a standard backcloth; the blue collars and the white collars live in districts that fit; the restaurant, all wood-panelling and easy banter, is a real joint.

Second, the supporting cast is utterly human, in a softly idealised way: no funny turns, no walk-on caricatures. Maybe Carroll O'Connor's Oirish grandfather is a bit full of blarney, but put him with his pensionable mates like Robert Loggia and the fun they generate is palpable. They're enjoying themselves, goddamit! Hunt has written herself a part as Grace's best friend (married with screaming children to James Belushi's Windy City jock) and she scatters in pith whenever the mix grows too sweet.

But, as ever, the crux is how we relate to these heart-crossed lovers. Duchovny, slim and boyish in casual clothes, isn't another ordinary TV star taking time out. He makes you believe the loss of his wife; he comes out of his shell and explodes with credible happiness; he even looks as though he could run a building site. And Minnie Driver, for those who remember Big Night or Grosse Pointe Blank, has that same unembarrassed warmth and delicate vulnerability. You can see why he loves her and vice versa. You will them to get it together - and you feel good for them when they do.

There's nothing remotely 2000 about Return to Me; indeed, a soundtrack full of Dean Martin and Sinatra heads determinedly in the other direction. This is romance, it seems to say, for swinging lovers who don't fall into bed on the first date and understand a certain tenderness. That may be a little sugary for some, but there seemed plenty of suspiciously red eyes around me when the lights went up.

Oh, and one more interesting thing. Minnie Driver is English, but plays Americans time and again in a flawless accent. Joely Richardson here does the same. Samantha Morton and Emily Watson both have their Hollywood outings this year. Meanwhile, Gwyneth Paltrow does English English to the manner born and Renée Zellweger is Bridget Jones. We may not have noticed it and we may not understand why, but Britain, for actresses, is already the fifty-first state.

 Philip French is on holiday

webTitle: Ban my bombers' guide, says author

fields.headline: Ban my bombers' guide, says author
fields.standfirst: The man whose 'Anarchist Cookbook' helped fuel three decades of terrorism admits: I was misguided
fields.trailText: The man whose 'Anarchist Cookbook' helped fuel three decades of terrorism admits: I was misguided.
fields.body:
It contains the formula for nitroglycerin, dynamite and TNT. There are detailed instructions on guerrilla warfare, converting shotguns into grenade-launchers and building home-made silencers for pistols.

It teaches how to make tear gas and LSD, how to run a pirate radio station and sabotage communications networks. There are pages devoted to planting explosives in table lamps, garden gates and even fountain pens.

For more than three decades, The Anarchist Cookbook has been the bible for budding terrorists and has helped spawn bombing campaigns across the globe. More than two million copies have been sold. But in a move that will horrify legions of devoted readers, the author of the book this weekend admitted he had grown older and wiser - and was renouncing violent direct action.

William Powell, who wrote the book more than 30 years ago, is calling for it to be taken out of print and for websites carrying such information to be closed down. The book spawned many imitations, including those alleged to have been used by London nail bomber David Copeland to make devices that killed three people.

Now 53 and a father of two, Powell generally refuses to comment on his past. However, a recent communication with an Anarchist Cookbook 'fan club' obtained by The Observer has made his changed views public for the first time.

In a letter to the group, Powell writes: 'The book was written during 1968 and part of 1969 soon after I graduated from high school. At the time, I was 19 years old and the Vietnam War and the so-called "counterculture movement" were at their height. I was involved in the anti-war movement and attended peace rallies and demonstrations.

'The book was a misguided product of my adolescent anger at the prospect of being drafted and sent to Vietnam to fight in a war that I did not believe in. The central idea was that violence is an acceptable means to bring about political change. I no longer agree with this.

'I conducted the research primarily at the New York City public library. Most of the contents were gleaned from military and US Special Forces manuals.

'During the years that followed its publication I went to university, married, became a father and a teacher of adolescents. These developments had a profound moral and spiritual effect on me. I no longer agreed with what I had written, and was becoming increasingly uncomfortable with the ideas I had put my name to.

'I am not in agreement with the contents of The Anarchist Cookbook, and I would be very pleased (and relieved) to see its publication discontinued. I consider it a misguided and potentially dangerous publication which should be taken out of print.'

According to a flatmate of Powell's in the Sixties, the idea was conceived as a series of 'recipes' in the form of posters that would be pasted up all over Manhattan. The first recipe would be advice on how to throw a Molotov cocktail, the second would be how to make LSD and so on. This idea was never acted on.

'Most of the stories and anecdotes were made up. Bill was never an anarchist and had no philosophy. The [publishers'] rejection slips were fascinating. Some were actually apologetic because they couldn't publish it,' said the ex-flatmate, who wanted to remain anonymous.

It was eventually published by Lyle Stuart Inc as a gesture against attempts by CIA and FBI agents to obtain lists from libraries of anyone taking out books they considered subversive. Powell has had no royalties since 1976, when he broke with the firm.

The book describes how to make nail bombs like those that exploded in London last year. Copeland is alleged to have obtained his information from two titles on the internet, The Terrorists' Handbook and How to Make Bombs.

Copeland is said to have downloaded both titles at the Internet Café in Victoria, central London, and experimented with exploding ingredients at home in Farnborough, Hampshire.

Copeland, an engineer, has admitted three counts of manslaughter, on the grounds of diminished responsibility, but his plea was not accepted by the prosecution. He denies murder. The Old Bailey trial continues.

Charles Darwin, in The Descent of Man in 1871, spoke of 'sympathy beyond the confines of man' as a virtue beyond all others. 'This virtue, one of the noblest with which man is endowed, seems to arise incidentally from our sympathies becoming more tender and more diffused, until they are extended to all sentient beings.'

It has taken some time, but we are catching up. Or at least Steven Wise is. His book, Rattling the Cage, has caught fire on both sides of the Atlantic and with good reason. The book is a gem. I can count only a handful of books that changed the way I saw the world and this is one of them. It is a revolutionary work for the effect it may have, like the great Cautio Criminalis in the Middle Ages, which began the trend that made the burning of witches no longer thinkable. It is also a pleasure to read, giving intellectual and emotional satisfaction in every sentence. It has taken a while to get used to the moral implications of the 'inherent dignity of the human person,' as the convention against torture calls it.

Professor Wise (he teaches animal law at law schools at Harvard, Chicago and Vermont) asks us to begin to think about the same concept for animals. He is not asking us to make an imaginative leap, but is taking us step by step along a simple, logical trajectory, through the history of human attitudes towards slavery, the rights of women, of children, until we see that we are resisting the basic similarities between the great apes and humans in vain. If bonobos can understand 3,000 words, we are at a loss to understand why they should not have some of the same basic legal protections that those of us who know fewer words in foreign languages have.

Wise writes: 'Just because a chimpanzee placed before a keyboard fails to produce something worthy of Shakespeare does not indicate that he has no mind. I can't produce something worthy of Shakespeare and neither can you. If fundamental rights depend on the ability to write like Shakespeare or paint like Leonardo, almost no human beings would have them.'

I go along with this, though I accord greater importance to Darwin's notion of sentience, where what matters is not intelligence but feeling. The similarity of feelings between humans and other animals is, to me, much less of a jump, and far more fascinating, than our so-called cognitive similarities. On both counts, it is good to remind ourselves that only five or six million years ago, humans, chimpanzees and bonobos were the same animal. And as everyone knows by now, we share more than 98 per cent of our genes with chimpanzees (in fact, chimps and gorillas are more genetically dissimilar than humans and chimps).

Actually, genetically, we are not completely dissimilar from wolves, and socially we are very close to wolves, which is why we bond so easily and so deeply with dogs. If the human brain has somewhere between 10 billion and 100 trillion neurons, the complexity of the brain of just about any other so-called higher animal with three times less is not so different. It has taken us forever to acknowledge that other animals have conscious experiences, are aware, but the revolution is picking up speed and this book is giving it a mighty shove.

We are forever looking for reasons not to accord dignity (rights, value, guarantees of freedom from pain, whatever it is) to other animals. 'They can't point,' we say. It is true: I find myself wondering whether one cow is able to draw attention to something interesting for a friend. But Wise examines a great deal of research showing how many of the great apes do precisely this.

One of the great virtues of this book is to take you over ground that is both unfamiliar (the legal territory) and familiar, such as the ape-language experiments, but reviewing all with a keen intelligence. It is like having a super-smart guide on an intellectual journey, who speaks ordinary language but draws your attention to things you would never see without him.

Professor Herbert Terrace, a psychologist, achieved fame by claiming that he could not teach an ape, Nim Chimpsky, to create a sentence. Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker agree, claiming that language in humans is innate, and unique to our species. But until I read Wise's demolition of this argument, I had no idea that 240 teachers taught Nim Chimpsky, that he was punished constantly, and that Professor Terrace advocated using a cattle prod on him. Small wonder that he was a linguistic failure. Which of us would not be under these circumstances? He was taught in a windowless, empty, sterile, 8ft by 8ft, white, concrete, cinder-block cubicle.

After Nim was gone, Terrace returned to the classrooms and 'wondered how I and the other teachers could have spent so much time in these oppressive rooms'. All it takes is for Wise to put in a telling '!' After 'I' to make us see that Terrace was unaware of another sentient being in the room. You have to love him for that.

The thesis is simple but inescapable (the great apes deserve legal protection), the logic is impeccable (their minds are enough like ours that it makes no sense to deny them personhood), the language is entertaining and the scholarship is daunting. He has assimilated everything in law and primate behaviour to bring us the first book about the legal rights for animals that will not just startle you but convert you. I expect this book to become a much-cited classic.

fields.headline: To lose one parent...
fields.standfirst: Dave Eggers had to raise his small brother alone, with only a sense of irony to see them through. He tells the story in A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
fields.trailText: Dave Eggers had to raise his small brother alone, with only a sense of irony to see them through. He tells the story in A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
fields.body:
A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Dave Eggers
Picador £14.99, pp400
Buy it at BOL

Wilde's Lady Bracknell, majestically intolerant of abnormality, would not have been impressed by the predicament of Dave Eggers. At the age of 21, he was careless enough to lose both parents. Within a month, they succumbed to their separate cancers - his father in a hurry, his mother after months of messy, excruciating sickness.

The dandified autonomy of Jack in The Importance of Being Earnest, born in a handbag at Victoria Station, suggests to Lady Bracknell 'a contempt for the ordinary decencies of family life'. Eggers, who found himself bereft in earnest, recovered by reconstructing those decencies. Assuming the role of single parent, he set himself to raise his younger brother, Christopher, who was only eight. A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius is his account of this premature initiation into adulthood.

It comes armoured with ironic self-disqualifications, of which the most obvious is its title (dismissively abbreviated to AHWOSG on the book's running heads). Pretending to mumble an apology, Eggers defines his book as a 'kind of a memoir-y kind of thing', and proposes that if readers prefer to have it fictionalised, which would soften and make optional the remorseless facts it records they should exchange their copies for a digital manuscript on floppy disk; then they'll be interactively free to revise his text as they please. The whimsical gimmickry of the preface, in which Eggers winces at 'the unavoidability... of near-constant poignance' in his situation, serves as a self-disbelieving self-advertisement.

Irony is a reflex of his case-hardened weariness, a style appropriate to a generation of young people who suffer from a desolating self-consciousness. Eggers and his friends, setting up a satirical magazine in San Francisco, fuss about what to wear to the office and then 'remembering not to think about what to wear, wear what we would have worn had we not been thinking about what to wear'. They want 'to be successful without being seen as successful-successful'.

These are lives lived, as Umberto Eco remarked of postmodernism, inside inverted commas. Numbness is commended as a reaction to intolerable reality. During Eggers's childhood, a friend's father douses himself with petrol, lights a match, then incinerates himself in front of the family home; his son, Ricky, Dave's friend, goes on watching television. When Dave asks him what his dad's immolation looked like, the boy compares it to a scene from Raiders of the Lost Ark, when the heat which seethes from the sacred box melts the Nazis like wax. There is no difference between an actual catastrophe and Hollywood's simulations.

At times, AHWOSG reads like a preview of a world which is not only post modern but post-human. Why bother remaining human when that state entails perpetual pain? Why not aspire to the condition of versatile, indestructible plastic? Moving from Chicago to California after the deaths of his parents, Eggers takes his brother to play in a Berkeley park which looks like 'the grounds of a laboratory for experimental people-making', exhibiting every available ethnic and sexual combination as if in an advertising display for Benetton. Some advertising executive in the sky, rounding up Latinos and lesbians and mixing races for aesthetic effect, seems to have commanded: 'Get me the Nineties. Get me the future!'

Nevertheless, AHWOSG should not be mistaken for a chronicle of slack, anaesthetised disenchantment. Its tale of disaster and recuperation is genuinely interactive, because the writer's plight is a version of our own. We are all orphans, 'God's tragic envoys', obliged to make our way through an inimical world, fortunate if we can cling together for support. Eggers can't ironically disavow his compassion in nursing his mother while she coughs up gobbets of her liver and cracks stoical jokes, or the burden of grown-up cares he volunteers to shoulder in assuming responsibility for his brother.

The question young Dave asks Ricky about his torched parent recurs throughout the book. Wanting not to think about such things, he can't stop himself wondering what his mother's cancer looks like. Should he envisage it as a rotten fruit, an insects' hive or a metastasising tarantula? And what do her remains look like after cremation? Sifting through the contents of the urn, he separates the varieties of ash, identifying white flakes of bone and guessing that the residual black pebbles are her stricken organs, scorched to a crisp.

Though he concentrates with stark literalness on the way things look, his achievement is to tell us how such moments feel. The episode with the cinders, like much of AHWOSG, is an exercise in empathy, a solemn act of commiseration which enjoins us to share our private, unexpressed griefs with Eggers. For all his shifty irony, he offers himself to us as a martyr, who suffers on our behalf and survives traumas which, if we're lucky, we will only experience vicariously.

The values AHWOSG upholds are hearteningly traditional (which probably explains its success in America). With Christopher, Eggers is a fretful mother hen, worrying about the squalor of the apartments they rent: 'I could clean,' he ventures. Mugged by Mexicans, he recovers his faith in law and order, impersonating a policeman as he argues with his attackers: 'I am the cop, a friendly but stern cop.'

By founding his magazine, he demonstrates the efficacy of economic self-help and celebrates the sense of community he shares with his like-minded collaborators. This is a parable about virtue rewarded with happiness, hard work rewarded with wealth, and moody, aggrieved solipsism rewarded with universal admiration.

Reporting a healthy surplus left over from his advance, Eggers even pledges to distribute a percentile of the profits to the first 200 readers to make a claim. Whether or not you write to him requesting a cheque, you'll feel yourself to be richer after reading his book.
