fields.headline: My father, the invisible man
fields.standfirst: After 20 years, Paul Morley, critic and pop Svengali, has faced up to his father's suicide. In his new book, he finds a parent - and a part of himself - that he had kept hidden from view
fields.trailText: After 20 years, Paul Morley, critic and pop Svengali, has faced up to his father's suicide. In his new book, he finds a parent - and a part of himself - that he had kept hidden from view.
fields.body:
When Paul Morley was a very young man, just beyond his teens, his father killed himself. Leaving the family home in Stockport, he drove all the way to Gloucestershire, and two days later, overlooking a green English landscape, he threaded a hose pipe in through the window and lay back to die. To leave a life that had become intolerable.

When Paul Morley was told about it, he remembers that a neighbour - to give him some activity - ordered him to clean out the cooker. He mindlessly scrubbed and scrubbed the grease-encrusted interior of the oven until patches glistened silver again through the crud. Then he kind of put his father's death away. It was, he says to me, 'as if as soon as he had died, he had been dead 20 years'. For his father had been going for a long time before he was really gone, dwindling away from his own life.

In the book that Paul Morley has written two decades later about and for him, the father is an absence to the son, who doesn't really know what he does for a living, who can't really say what he looked like. He even seems to lack a name. The book is called Nothing . It is exhilarated with words and their many meanings, hooked on repetition and pun and nuance - yet it circles round and round the 'nothing' of Paul's father, as if he really were the black hole that one of Paul's sisters calls him, sucking in emotions. He never seemed to speak, never told his son he loved him, never kissed him at the end of the day but just muttered an abbreviated 'n'night', didn't laugh.

When he died, Paul Morley didn't see his body. A few years later, he saw another body, of the singer Ian Curtis of Joy Division. He stared and stared at it, but still didn't think of his father, who seemed to have slipped out of his life, leaving no trace behind him, like a ghost. For his son, the father was mute, colourless and invisible. He was a depressive and he died at the age his son has now reached, more or less.

He stares across the coffee cups on the table. Paul Morley - the rock journalist who sprinkles Barthes and Sartre through his prose, co-founder of the group Art of Noise, promoter of Frankie Goes to Hollywood, master of intellectual swagger and narcissistic cool - is not the way I had expected him to be. He is 43 now, but beneath his dark stubble, his face is rather sweet and anxious. His dark eyes look young and vaguely troubled.

And the book - though dense with the allusive, braggardly, language-intoxicated prose that Morley has made his trademark over the years, crammed with Kafka and Kierkegaard and Foucault and echoes of Italo Calvino and swoony, doomy rock stars of the Seventies such as Nick Drake and postmodern games and lists of the books he's read and the ones he's nearly written and the titles he's flirted with - is a surprise. Under the decorated and swanky surface, it is raw and self-exposing; here's a Morley who's been hiding behind himself all these years. It's about loss, grief, a shadowy bereavement that has haunted him all his adult life. It's about the father he never knew and now tries to recreate out of the 'top 10 memories' which, he says, he carries around 'like a few stones in my pocket'.

And it's about him, an awkward and solitary boy, growing up in Stockport, miserable at school, living in a house where love could not flourish in the presence of his father's despair, disconnected from himself, drifting slackly through teenage years with greasy hair and spotty cheeks, masturbating and falling in love with Marc Bolan's songs, waiting for the first kiss that would turn him from toad to prince. He doesn't really call himself unhappy: 'Or maybe I was unhappy without knowing it. Certainly, I was extremely unhappy at school. A lot of the time, I was scared. I was scared of my dad, of what he might do next. I remember looking at him, but hoping he wouldn't see me looking at him. I do have a few memories of happiness; I was happy when I bought a record. That made me happy.'

Music, and writing about music, was where he lost and found himself and his book remains obsessed with the sense that words are both a place to discover things and a place to hide; both treacherous and true. The father he creates is made up by him, self-consciously his fiction.

Very soon after his father died, Paul Morley left home. 'I fled. I became someone else. I disappeared from my old life. I disappeared into the New Musical Express and all the pop culture which I found mesmerising at the time. Maybe the reason I wrote the way I did was that I was always looking for clues and meanings, but I wasn't aware of it at the time. I would write 4-5,000 words every week. I felt I was invisible, too, like my dad. I felt I kind of flamed through life and no one really noticed me. I became addicted to my byline, even more than lots of journalists do. If my name was there, that was instant reality. I must exist.'

So he didn't think about his father at all. He went through his twenties, became famous, infamous, developed a reputation for a kind of journalistic cruelty (this seems to hurt him). Rock idols died young. But his father wasn't there, not even as a memory, a distant ache. He married, had a daughter, divorced. He started Art of Noise. His two younger sisters grew up, with some difficulty and pain (the youngest, Carol Morley, has just made a film about her promiscuous and boozy adolescent teens, The Alcohol Years), but the siblings never discussed their father's death. His mother emerged as someone loving, soft and eccentric ('almost hippyish'), but neither did she talk to her son about what had happened.

There was no guilt, rejection, anger, not even any conscious sense of loss. He was gone, nothing. He had died miles from home, in an unknown place. There was no grave to visit. Paul Morley couldn't even remember the date of his death, not the day, or month, or even year. He thought that he had died at the age of 43 and this made him ner vous; 43 was approaching, it would hit in 2000. Perhaps, he thought, there would be 'a switch'. Perhaps he would turn into his father. When he came to write Nothing , he discovered his father actually died at 41, and he'd already passed the marker, appropriate in a book that's full of botched revelations.

He always wanted to write a book but never had a subject (of course, he always had a subject; for the whole of his adult life this has been his hidden subject). Then an editor, hearing from a friend of a friend that his father had been a suicide, took him to the Savoy for tea and asked him to write an article about it.

'I started, but I couldn't do it. Not in a piece like that. But I had a beginning. I put it in a shoe box. I kept thinking about doing it, and gradually I knew it was my subject. But I still felt I couldn't deal with it. I didn't think I could remember anything. There were only these little whirlpools of memory around darkness.'

But at about the same time his daughter, who was born in 1992, started to ask questions about her dead grandfather - where is he, who was he, what happened? 'I couldn't answer and that was wrong. I realised I would have to do something. She was asking these inno cent questions and I could almost start him again from scratch for her. He could be reborn.' He pauses to sip cooling coffee. I ask if he wrote his book to find his father or maybe to love his father, who he never loved in life. 'I wanted,' he says, 'to miss him. I wanted him to be someone that I missed. I never could say, in all those years ,"I miss my dad". It seemed a terrible thing he'd died so far away and was in an unmarked grave. Agonising, really. Agonising for me, but agonising for him most of all, wherever he is now, with his feelings. Maybe there are still his feelings somewhere. I hope so.'

So he wrote Nothing, and it was in the writing that he began to recover the father he never had. Most people gradually diminish after death, smaller and smaller figures on the horizon. The opposite happens for Paul Morley, whose father, having been reduced to an invisible point, gradually becomes larger for him.

'It was an act of recovery. I had a few hard and fast facts - classic memories and voids around then. And as I wrote, I found other things, here and there. It's taken a long time to get them. I do worry, yes, that it is an exposing kind of book. I talk to my partner, and she's my best friend, too. But I don't talk to friends. I don't really have a buddy group like that. I've always been quite solitary. Maybe that's to do with Dad. And here I am, writing this book.'

At the end of Nothing he invites his two sisters and his mother to speak their (contradictory) memories into a recorder. This is the first time the family has sat down together to speak about the past; to make a book, they can remember things that are too painful recalled in the raw. 'And for them, I think the book is good. For my mother, I think she is glad that I have made him exist again, in a way. That I've made him real for me. There are private things I have gone into that are difficult, of course. But she knew I had lost my father and she is pleased I have got him back, that he exists. There is somebody now. When we talked together, we found things about each other that we had never known. If there's only an audience of three for this book, that's a good audience.'

He used not to feel very lovable. 'I struggled to find out what love was. Maybe I didn't have a good model in place. I was always making my decisions based on "love" but I think really I was looking for stability and security and felt I could contrive it. Maybe love is finding meaning in a cold universe; a father is supposed to protect a child from the cold universe, isn't he? Maybe in my twenties and thirties I was trying to find that. For a bit, pop music was my meaning.'

Perhaps, he says, he is finally growing up now (in 'a tentative kind of way'). 'It's taken a long time,' he says ruefully, 'and maybe that's to do with my past, or maybe it's a generational thing, the pop culture we grew up with. Our generation pioneered that postponement of growing up. Maybe that's why suddenly you get the Nick Hornbys and the Tony Parsons and that lot writing about the family. About bloody dads and bloody children. We've finally realised it's not the Velvet Underground or the Sex Pistols who are extraordinary after all. It's the family.' fields.bodyText: When Paul Morley was a very young man, just beyond his teens, his father killed himself. Leaving the family home in Stockport, he drove all the way to Gloucestershire, and two days later, overlooking a green English landscape, he threaded a hose pipe in through the window and lay back to die. To leave a life that had become intolerable. When Paul Morley was told about it, he remembers that a neighbour - to give him some activity - ordered him to clean out the cooker. He mindlessly scrubbed and scrubbed the grease-encrusted interior of the oven until patches glistened silver again through the crud. Then he kind of put his father's death away. It was, he says to me, 'as if as soon as he had died, he had been dead 20 years'. For his father had been going for a long time before he was really gone, dwindling away from his own life. In the book that Paul Morley has written two decades later about and for him, the father is an absence to the son, who doesn't really know what he does for a living, who can't really say what he looked like. He even seems to lack a name. The book is called Nothing . It is exhilarated with words and their many meanings, hooked on repetition and pun and nuance - yet it circles round and round the 'nothing' of Paul's father, as if he really were the black hole that one of Paul's sisters calls him, sucking in emotions. He never seemed to speak, never told his son he loved him, never kissed him at the end of the day but just muttered an abbreviated 'n'night', didn't laugh. When he died, Paul Morley didn't see his body. A few years later, he saw another body, of the singer Ian Curtis of Joy Division. He stared and stared at it, but still didn't think of his father, who seemed to have slipped out of his life, leaving no trace behind him, like a ghost. For his son, the father was mute, colourless and invisible. He was a depressive and he died at the age his son has now reached, more or less. He stares across the coffee cups on the table. Paul Morley - the rock journalist who sprinkles Barthes and Sartre through his prose, co-founder of the group Art of Noise, promoter of Frankie Goes to Hollywood, master of intellectual swagger and narcissistic cool - is not the way I had expected him to be. He is 43 now, but beneath his dark stubble, his face is rather sweet and anxious. His dark eyes look young and vaguely troubled. And the book - though dense with the allusive, braggardly, language-intoxicated prose that Morley has made his trademark over the years, crammed with Kafka and Kierkegaard and Foucault and echoes of Italo Calvino and swoony, doomy rock stars of the Seventies such as Nick Drake and postmodern games and lists of the books he's read and the ones he's nearly written and the titles he's flirted with - is a surprise. Under the decorated and swanky surface, it is raw and self-exposing; here's a Morley who's been hiding behind himself all these years. It's about loss, grief, a shadowy bereavement that has haunted him all his adult life. It's about the father he never knew and now tries to recreate out of the 'top 10 memories' which, he says, he carries around 'like a few stones in my pocket'. And it's about him, an awkward and solitary boy, growing up in Stockport, miserable at school, living in a house where love could not flourish in the presence of his father's despair, disconnected from himself, drifting slackly through teenage years with greasy hair and spotty cheeks, masturbating and falling in love with Marc Bolan's songs, waiting for the first kiss that would turn him from toad to prince. He doesn't really call himself unhappy: 'Or maybe I was unhappy without knowing it. Certainly, I was extremely unhappy at school. A lot of the time, I was scared. I was scared of my dad, of what he might do next. I remember looking at him, but hoping he wouldn't see me looking at him. I do have a few memories of happiness; I was happy when I bought a record. That made me happy.' Music, and writing about music, was where he lost and found himself and his book remains obsessed with the sense that words are both a place to discover things and a place to hide; both treacherous and true. The father he creates is made up by him, self-consciously his fiction. Very soon after his father died, Paul Morley left home. 'I fled. I became someone else. I disappeared from my old life. I disappeared into the New Musical Express and all the pop culture which I found mesmerising at the time. Maybe the reason I wrote the way I did was that I was always looking for clues and meanings, but I wasn't aware of it at the time. I would write 4-5,000 words every week. I felt I was invisible, too, like my dad. I felt I kind of flamed through life and no one really noticed me. I became addicted to my byline, even more than lots of journalists do. If my name was there, that was instant reality. I must exist.' So he didn't think about his father at all. He went through his twenties, became famous, infamous, developed a reputation for a kind of journalistic cruelty (this seems to hurt him). Rock idols died young. But his father wasn't there, not even as a memory, a distant ache. He married, had a daughter, divorced. He started Art of Noise. His two younger sisters grew up, with some difficulty and pain (the youngest, Carol Morley, has just made a film about her promiscuous and boozy adolescent teens, The Alcohol Years), but the siblings never discussed their father's death. His mother emerged as someone loving, soft and eccentric ('almost hippyish'), but neither did she talk to her son about what had happened. There was no guilt, rejection, anger, not even any conscious sense of loss. He was gone, nothing. He had died miles from home, in an unknown place. There was no grave to visit. Paul Morley couldn't even remember the date of his death, not the day, or month, or even year. He thought that he had died at the age of 43 and this made him ner vous; 43 was approaching, it would hit in 2000. Perhaps, he thought, there would be 'a switch'. Perhaps he would turn into his father. When he came to write Nothing , he discovered his father actually died at 41, and he'd already passed the marker, appropriate in a book that's full of botched revelations. He always wanted to write a book but never had a subject (of course, he always had a subject; for the whole of his adult life this has been his hidden subject). Then an editor, hearing from a friend of a friend that his father had been a suicide, took him to the Savoy for tea and asked him to write an article about it. 'I started, but I couldn't do it. Not in a piece like that. But I had a beginning. I put it in a shoe box. I kept thinking about doing it, and gradually I knew it was my subject. But I still felt I couldn't deal with it. I didn't think I could remember anything. There were only these little whirlpools of memory around darkness.' But at about the same time his daughter, who was born in 1992, started to ask questions about her dead grandfather - where is he, who was he, what happened? 'I couldn't answer and that was wrong. I realised I would have to do something. She was asking these inno cent questions and I could almost start him again from scratch for her. He could be reborn.' He pauses to sip cooling coffee. I ask if he wrote his book to find his father or maybe to love his father, who he never loved in life. 'I wanted,' he says, 'to miss him. I wanted him to be someone that I missed. I never could say, in all those years ,"I miss my dad". It seemed a terrible thing he'd died so far away and was in an unmarked grave. Agonising, really. Agonising for me, but agonising for him most of all, wherever he is now, with his feelings. Maybe there are still his feelings somewhere. I hope so.' So he wrote Nothing, and it was in the writing that he began to recover the father he never had. Most people gradually diminish after death, smaller and smaller figures on the horizon. The opposite happens for Paul Morley, whose father, having been reduced to an invisible point, gradually becomes larger for him. 'It was an act of recovery. I had a few hard and fast facts - classic memories and voids around then. And as I wrote, I found other things, here and there. It's taken a long time to get them. I do worry, yes, that it is an exposing kind of book. I talk to my partner, and she's my best friend, too. But I don't talk to friends. I don't really have a buddy group like that. I've always been quite solitary. Maybe that's to do with Dad. And here I am, writing this book.' At the end of Nothing he invites his two sisters and his mother to speak their (contradictory) memories into a recorder. This is the first time the family has sat down together to speak about the past; to make a book, they can remember things that are too painful recalled in the raw. 'And for them, I think the book is good. For my mother, I think she is glad that I have made him exist again, in a way. That I've made him real for me. There are private things I have gone into that are difficult, of course. But she knew I had lost my father and she is pleased I have got him back, that he exists. There is somebody now. When we talked together, we found things about each other that we had never known. If there's only an audience of three for this book, that's a good audience.' He used not to feel very lovable. 'I struggled to find out what love was. Maybe I didn't have a good model in place. I was always making my decisions based on "love" but I think really I was looking for stability and security and felt I could contrive it. Maybe love is finding meaning in a cold universe; a father is supposed to protect a child from the cold universe, isn't he? Maybe in my twenties and thirties I was trying to find that. For a bit, pop music was my meaning.' Perhaps, he says, he is finally growing up now (in 'a tentative kind of way'). 'It's taken a long time,' he says ruefully, 'and maybe that's to do with my past, or maybe it's a generational thing, the pop culture we grew up with. Our generation pioneered that postponement of growing up. Maybe that's why suddenly you get the Nick Hornbys and the Tony Parsons and that lot writing about the family. About bloody dads and bloody children. We've finally realised it's not the Velvet Underground or the Sex Pistols who are extraordinary after all. It's the family.' He hasn't cried for his father yet, although he cries at almost everything else ('pathetic, hopeless'),so maybe that's the same thing. At the end of Nothing , Paul Morley drives out to the place where his father took his life. He stares out across the green land. He finds the grave, has the plaque reinstated. It reads: 'At Peace'. He, at last, gives his father his name. Leslie Ronald Morley. fields.headline: Me Tarzan, you primatologist
fields.standfirst: Carole Jahme examines why women are drawn to the study of apes in Beauty and the Beasts
fields.trailText: Carole Jahme examines why women are drawn to the study of apes in Beauty and the Beasts
fields.body:
Beauty and the Beasts: Woman, Ape and Evolution
Carole Jahme
Virago £18.99, pp406
Buy it at BOL

Primatology is a young science; a broad discipline taking in cross-cultural studies of 200 ape and monkey species. In 40 years, Carole Jahme argues, 'it has become the only scientific subject to bleed into popular culture and leave a permanent mark of gender that in turn has gone on to colour the science'.

About 62 per cent of the World Directory of Primatologists' members are female. The feminisation of the study is just one area covered in this book, which grew out of a television programme Jahme made about women and primates.

A major theme is the way women who study primates become hooked on the animals they befriend. Consider Janis Carter who, as a young American researcher, bonded with Lucy, a chimp taught to use sign language. Carter flew her to West Africa to 'free' the captive-born ape, who was destined for a research lab, and spent 10 years in Gambia with a chimp colony.

Jahme suggests that it is primates' very lack of language which attracts women to the study - akin to empathic understanding of babies' needs. Here, she agrees with the palaeontologist Louis Leakey who, with his 'Trimates' Jane Goodall, Dian Fossey and Birute Galdikas and their respective studies of chimpanzees, gorillas and orang-utans, hijacked the course of primatology.

Leakey believed that studying the apes closest to our hominid ancestors could help us understand human evolution. He wanted 'intellectual blank slates' who would observe wild apes without theoretical baggage, and was convinced women were better at field studies - patient, intuitive and less likely to irritate patriarchal apes.

Jahme considers the publicity surrounding Goodall, Fossey and Galdikas. All three fell in love with the photographers who made their work famous (Goodall and Galdikas married theirs); all three were turned into legends by National Geographic. Goodall's recognition of intricate social groupings and individual chimp personalities is now part of primate lore.

While the 'Goodall Phenomenon' was crucial in popularising the science, for the lay public Gorillas in the Mist, the biopic based on Fossey's account of her life with the Virunga mountain gorillas, personified primatology and identified it with conservation. Fossey's murder added the crucial sacrificial element. The life became 'fully mythologised' when Sigourney Weaver replaced Fossey on the book jacket.

Men's interpretations of primate behaviour reveal an obsession with male dominance. Instead, Thelma Rowell logged wild female baboons guiding peaceable communities to food, 'sponsoring' younger males outside the group and consorting with them when the dominant alpha male's back was turned.

Barbara Smuts and Jeanne Altmann found baboons and other primates are matrilineal: status is passed from mother to daughter. Today, female baboons' 'dual career mothering' and 'maternal time budgets' are popular subjects with Altmann's researchers. Ironically, equally deserving men's projects such as Takayoshi Kano's study of bonobos in central Africa, lacking media appeal, may attract less funding.

Intriguingly, Japanese cultural attitudes towards 'wise monkeys', the indigenous macaques, encouraged a more anthropomorphic approach denied by rigid Western behaviourism. Now the balance has shifted and Western primatologists make unsettling leaps from ape to human behaviour: for instance from infanticide by dominant males in Rajasthan's langurs to infanticide by stepfathers in human families.

Some of Jahme's most vivid portraits are of primates who found fame through human associates. Few end their lives in comfortable retirement like Tarzan star Jiggs, who lives next door to Kirk Douglas in Palm Springs. Chimpanzees cosseted as honorary humans in infancy are turned over to laboratories for medical experiments when they become 'unmanageable'.

Today, speculation about chimpanzees' cognitive abilities is overshadowed by questions about primate survival such as how to slow the bushmeat trade which threatens to wipe out all wildlife within 50 years.

Jahme's approach to her diverse subject matter is direct and often sensational; the result is always entertaining and thought provoking, if erratically ordered and sometimes oversimplifying evolutionary theory. Popular conventions are unquestioned: Jane Goodall found fame as the first Western observer to see chimpanzees using tools, but according to Sonia Cole, Leakey's first biographer, this is incorrect. However, these women's stories are a revealing commentary on our uneasy interface with primates, and a reminder that the most heroic, individual efforts to save humanity's closest relatives will not be enough without determined political intervention.

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: A debate about vegetarianism from Booker winner JM Coetzee served up in a delicate wrapping of fiction
fields.body:
The Lives of Animals
J.M. Coetzee
Profile £3.99, pp120
Buy it at BOL

This curiosity from J.M. Coetzee is actually a moral tract, a debate about vegetarianism, wrapped in the most basic of fictions to make it more appealing.

Invited to deliver the 1997-1998 Tanner Lectures at Princeton, Coetzee instead chose to read this, a story that reflected his own situation.

In his tale, a respected feminist novelist, Elizabeth Costello, is invited to an American university to deliver a lecture on the subject of her choice; and since Costello is an ardent vegetarian (as is Coetzee), her talk deals with the consciousness of animals and man's obligation to them.

Bookending the lectures is a slight, even-handed fiction about the relationship between Costello, her son John, and his wife Norma.

Norma has no patience with Costello or her 'jejune and sentimental' ideas. The more tolerant John 'does not want to hear his mother talking about death'.

Costello does not emerge from the lectures triumphant: offence is caused by the comparisons she draws between factory farming and the Nazi death camps. Coetzee seems almost to suggest that it is impossible for vegetarians to make their points with any sort of rational power, because the subject is too distressing, and the meat-eaters too entrenched in their oblivion. Costello says: 'I seem to move around perfectly easily among people, to have perfectly normal relations with them. Is it possible, I ask myself, that all of them are participants in a crime of stupefying proportions? Am I fantasising it all?'

The Lives of Animals is concerned with the boundaries of human interaction. It's about communication without understanding.

fields.headline: That was the year...
fields.standfirst: Tim Pears attacks the injustices of contemporary England in A Revolution of the Sun
fields.trailText: Tim Pears attacks the injustices of contemporary England in A Revolution of the Sun
fields.body:
A Revolution of the Sun
Tim Pears
Doubleday £12.99, pp435
Buy it at BOL

Although Tim Pears has described his three novels as a trilogy about England, they differ widely in style and content. His first, semi-autobiographical, novel, In the Place of Fallen Leaves, was a magic realist study of a girl coming of age in a remote village. Pears dropped the dreamy lyricism of that book to write his second novel, In a Land of Plenty. In this, his third book, Pears has changed again. A Revolution of the Sun is a pun on the two meanings of revolution: not only the year measured by the revolution of the earth around the sun, but also a political revolution.

This is a book concerned to take a 'snapshot' of England at a certain time - the span of a single year, 1997, beginning at midnight on New Year's Eve 1996. But it is also his most explicitly political work to date, seeking to use both satire and realism to attack the injustices of contemporary England.

As the year progresses, the paths of a diverse group of people, including an unemployed father, an amnesiac, a pensioner and a cat burglar, weave together, as much by chance as by intention. Some of the characters raid a laboratory that has been carrying out vivisection experiments and then begin - with pairs of the freed animals - to set up a new community in a cottage.

This is an odd, frustrating book, reinforcing the sense that Pears has yet to settle as a novelist since leaving the limited world of his first and best book. He is always fiercely sympathetic to his downtrodden protagonists. But making so many characters come to life in brief scenes encourages his weaknesses as much as his strengths. As in his previous novels, characters are composed of given characteristics, rather than emerging organically.

The prose has an irritating streak of verbosity, struggling for beauty or exuberance. The cat burglar worries about 'gravity's ever-hungry pull' and a car becomes a 'juddering jalopy'.

Most problematic, however, is the incoherence of the book's central political themes. Pears's observations of a society of negative equity, casualised labour and slum living are too easily familiar and presented with too little depth to have any real force. And how seriously are we meant to take the book's satirical elements, centred on the vivisection lab? Implausibility jostles with crudity. After adverse publicity about animal experiments, the lab begins kidnapping people from illegal raves to experiment on. His characters are either fundamentally good-hearted or they are grotesque. Politics needs more subtlety than that.

fields.headline: Frank outsider
fields.standfirst: He's obsessive. He's hopeless. And he's funny. Damian Lanigan introduces Frank Stretch, 29
fields.trailText: He's obsessive. He's hopeless. And he's funny. Damian Lanigan introduces Frank Stretch, 29
fields.body:
Stretch, 29
Damian Lanigan
HarperCollins £6.99, pp313

The name's Stretch, Frank Stretch. Odd. No one else in this novel has a funny name, which left me trying to work out why the hero had to have one. The best I can come up with is that it's supposed to be ironic, because the one thing Frank Stretch doesn't do is stretch himself. But then why not call him Frank Slack instead - or plain old Mr Hopeless?

Still, never mind. It's a brilliantly funny book. And the 29 bit is easier. That's Frank's age - you know, almost hitting the big three-O (well big if you're 29), suggesting that our man is riding an age crisis, perhaps on the cusp of change.

But, better still, 29 is also Frank's 'score' as someone you might conceivably not want to meet at a dinner party - 29 as a measure of personal success in a scale of 10 categories offering a possible total of 100. One of Frank's pet obsessions is working out how much more of a failed person he is than practically everyone else he knows in terms of wealth, health, car, sex-life, job, popularity etc.

And this 'scoring' thing is how he does it. Everyone who passes through his mind gets stamped with a score - footballers, binmen, Rupert Murdoch. Frank calls it 'The Maths', which strikes me as quite a good name for a novel. Anyway, hence Stretch, 29, arch underachiever de nos jours.

Frank's own highest individual score (6) is for how interesting he thinks he is. Because despite having zero money (2), a crap job as a waiter (3), an X-reg Vauxhall Cavalier (2) and virtually no sex life (1), he is quite intriguing.

First, you might ask how on earth the maladjusted, northern, working-class Stretch finds the energy to get himself to Oxford and pass all his exams only subsequently to devote what should be his career-building years to serving mobs of shouty estate agents and slappers in some low-rent bar 'n' grill in Battersea.

Why do Frank's old chums from college - now corporate lawyers and bond traders with Maths in the high seventies - keep in touch, make allowances for his mood swings and wayward manners, play Mum, arrange job interviews with a view to Frank's socio-cultural rehab? Why do they insist on inviting him to their parties where he is likely to get reeling drunk, start a fist fight, insult the hostess, throw up, etc. How do you solve a problem like Frank? Why would you want to - eight years on?

And yet they do - even though they seem to represent all that Frank hates. While everyone else seems to have risen without much effort to a comfortable level of metropolitan repose, Frank is still temperamentally stranded in a smart-arse, ironic, cynical, student time warp, sneering at ambition, railing at the tokens of commercial success like someone who doesn't know the war has ended. Hey Frank, snap out of it, you feel like shouting, you're nearly 30!

With someone like this, you know things are going to get worse before they can get better, though it's noticeable that when Frank starts drifting from his moorings so does the plot slightly. There is a protracted car journey which can't quite be sustained by extra helpings of 'The Maths' and Frank's other pastime of writing his own amusing obituaries (entrepreneur, patron of the arts, movie director etc); and a subsequent redemptive exile in the North in which Frank gets soppy about children seems, well... over-stretched. But these are quibbles in an otherwise dazzling performance.

It's a mark of Damian Lanigan's careful handling that we can manage to love poor Frank and feel sorry for his poor rich friends at the same time. Unusually for a comic novel, there are no eccentrics competing for our attention, no egregious coincidences, no extraneous doses of good luck, no hopeful punchlines in the mouths of halfwits.

This is a book of great poise, teeming with invention, wicked humour and unforced insights ('She had the kind of face that women call beautiful and men call "all right I suppose" ').

Lanigan has a good ear for the busy, first-person vernacular that has become de rigueur in this new sub-genre of 'diary of a hopeless inadequate', but you can bet he can write in all the other languages too. Smart guy, 99.

No one else in this novel has a funny name, which left me trying to work out why the hero had to have one. The best I can come up with is that it's supposed to be ironic, because the one thing Frank Stretch doesn't do is stretch himself. But then why not call him Frank Slack instead - or plain old Mr Hopeless? Still, never mind. It's a brilliantly funny book. And the 29 bit is easier. fields.headline: I was Custer's horse
fields.standfirst: Joanna Griffiths is unimpressed with Jeremy Poolman's semi-surrealist My Kind of America
fields.trailText: Joanna Griffiths is unimpressed with Jeremy Poolman's semi-surrealist My Kind of America
fields.body:
My Kind of America
Jeremy Poolman
Bloomsbury £18.99, pp496

Buy it at BOL

Anglo-American writer Jeremy Poolman's book is a semi-surrealist tour de force, or at least tour de stamina, written in a relentless stream of many consciousnesses, offering in each sentence of internal thought a dozen or so subordinate clauses, parentheses, pauses, commas, lists, repetitions, leading the exhausted reader ineluctably across pages and pages which are a single sentence, endlessly claused and reclaused, the only moments of relief from which are sudden jolts as the main internally narrating characters, of whom there seem to be about 50, are interrupted in their musings by a question from a passing stranger, waitress, shopkeeper, usually on the subject of some tedious necessity to buy, to function, to work - 'That's $4 and 40 cents, sir.'

'WHA?' our endlessly internally musing character asks, shocked into monosyllabic grunting by the rude interruption. 'Four dollars 40, sir,' the hapless interruptee repeats, shaking his head, hoping he is not imminently to be trapped inside his own skull narrating myriad anxieties and memories for the next four pages, hoping, that is, that the plot will skate quickly over him, except there is not exactly a plot, it must be confessed, only dozens of characters plucked from the past 100 years of US history, speaking a rather stagy, not entirely goddamn convincing Americanese, musing on their terrible, unremittingly terrible lives.

Such torrents of self-examination could be an attempt to stage the mighty solipsistic mania of modern America: the psychic flotsam of the chatshow, the live TV family reunion, the prurient desire for exposure, for no-holds-barred, real-life confession. Poolman seems principally disappointed with the lassitude of this America, the slouching failure of its inhabitants to move beyond inert self-absorption. The problem with portraying inertia is not to fall into it, and Poolman veers between crafting and recrafting endless moments of abject paralysis, and jolting the reader out of sophoria by a wild array of semi-developed, symbolic undercurrents and frenzied surrealism.

What plot there is revolves - in the past - around the widow of General Custer, fighting to safeguard her husband's reputation, and - in the present - around a hapless old man, Eddie Reno, who may or may not be a reincarnation of Custer's horse. Reno thinks he has freed himself from slave-wagery by murdering his abusive boss, Mr Frampton, but then finds Frampton furiously pursuing him. Reno and Frampton are kidnapped by a Native American, who seems to be related to Little Bighorn, and history repeats itself, eternal return, says Poolman, only each time the circuit comes round again the protagonists are more lacklustre and pathetic.

Poolman goads his inert characters with a bedlam of weirdness - an army of doll-like midget prostitutes, men thought dead leering from car windows, fast-talking mystics bringing revelations of metempsychosis. This makes the book at times an effective dismantling of the stolid blandness of diners and blueberry pancakes, invading them with reincarnated lunatics and gun-toting maniacs.

Yet, the reader ends by feeling bombarded with a bemusing array of sameness - almost indistinguishable past and present, almost indistinguishable characters. In the closing stages, one of the many mysterious speakers, talking of a father apparently 'drawn to his death by a clever little fantasy', asks the reader to decide 'Which little fantasy?' and seems surprised by our bemused silence: 'Jesus. You mean you haven't guessed it?' The novel's last words reiterate the point: 'You mean you can't guess it? Christ. You people. You're all dumber than I thought.'

In the end, this sort of scornful wryness seems an attempt to suggest a single point running serenely under the wild, riotous bedlam of semi-meaning, semi-symbol, the unmanageable interchangeability of the characters. Either the novel would have led us to some apotheotic realisation had we been sufficiently sophisticated to discern it, or everything is non-meaning anyway, hence the wild meaningless of the novel, which is then merely a faithful reflection of things as they stand.

The scornful challenge - 'Think you understand? But you don't!' - seems to sound a vacant postmodern flourish, in a novel confounded by the very urge to talk-not-act which it aims to scourge.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The unique talents of Sir John Gielgud live on in his readings of Eliot and Shakespeare
fields.body:
Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats
T.S. Eliot
Read by Sir John Gielgud and Irene Worth
Listening Time 37 mins
HarperCollins Audiobooks
Buy it at BOL

Ages of Man: Readings from Shakespeare
Read by Sir John Gielgud
Listening Time 1hr, 15 mins
HarperCollins Audiobooks
Buy it at BOL

Sir John Gielgud, who died last month, was revered for his perfect pronunciation and magnificent articulation. Although he received the greatest acclaim for his roles in the theatre and in film, the humble audiobook must not be forgotten as the perfect vehicle by which to concentrate on Gielgud's unfaded voice, untouched by age.

In Eliot's sweet collection of feline rhymes, recorded in 1983, Gielgud can hardly disguise his delight at reading these amusing and enchanting verses. He may share the job with Irene Worth, who handles with dignity the imitation of a pug, but Gielgud steals the show as Old Deuteronomy, 'A cat that has lived a long time', and as Mephistopheles, 'the original conjuring cat'.

In Shakespeare's Ages of Man, recorded in 1979, Gielgud has a few tricks up his sleeve. Like a magician, he switches from one character to the next. One moment he is Caliban from The Tempest, 'the most debased of Earth's creatures', the next he is Mercutio from Romeo and Juliet.

Side one starts with 'All the world's a stage' from As You Like It, and side four ends with Prospero's final speech from The Tempest: 'Now my charms are all o'er thrown.' In Gielgud's case they live on.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A fascinating report from the front line of the internet revolution, plus Godless Morality, The Colony of Unrequited Dreams, Crimes Against Humanity and The Puttermesser Papers
fields.body:
The Nudist on the Late Shift and Other Tales of Silicon Valley
Po Bronson
Vintage £6.99, pp252
Buy it at BOL

This book could not have been written in Britain. While our internet pioneers are mainly media-friendly rich kids, Bronson zeroes in on a generation of e-dreamers who have pushed their chips over the line.

Among the office parks of California's Silicon Valley he hangs out with visionaries risking it all for money, desperate to escape the job-for-life choke chain. Take the Massachusetts homeboy who funds his ventures selling dope. Or the nudist himself - a programmer who strips off in the office because 'work has to be half work, half play'. While creativity and chutzpah might bring rewards, this feel-the-fear-and-do-it-anyway existence is also curiously empty. An illuminating freeze-frame of these edgy times.

Godless Morality: Keeping Religion out of Ethics
Richard Holloway
Canongate Books £6.99 pp163
Buy it at BOL

The contrariness of a man of God arguing that God has no place in modern morality gives the Bishop of Edinburgh's polemic bite, and shows hard thinking.

Traditional moral systems, based on blind obedience to the rules of God, have been rendered unworkable under global capitalism and rapid scientific development. Holloway rejects the nostalgic search for a fixed theory of human nature. Instead, he proposes an 'ethical jazz', a flexible moral pluralism more appropriate to today's discordant society. On a range of issues - abortion, drugs, sex - Holloway carves out a position based on principles of consent and not harming others. A passionate, provocative and common sense challenge to easy cant.

The Colony of Unrequited Dreams
Wayne Johnston
Anchor £6.99, pp562
Buy it at BOL

Joey Smallwood's snobbish headmaster, a Boer War veteran ending his days at a minor public school in Newfoundland, sees the island as 'the Elba of the North Atlantic'.

Smallwood's alcoholic father refers to their home as 'Old Lost Land'. For Joey, born in 1900, Newfoundland is a matter of destiny. In relating Smallwood's rise to becoming the first Premier of Canadian confederated Newfoundland, Johnston deftly weaves together folklore, history and the personal. After leaving school Smallwood eschews the family business, becoming a socialist, then a journalist, then a failed socialist journalist. He is dogged by Sheilagh Fielding, a writer who is both his nemesis and object of his affections. Their competing narratives of their relationship intimate a deeper account of the island itself.

Crimes Against Humanity: The Struggle for Global Justice
Geoffrey Robertson QC
Penguin £8.99, pp576
Buy it at BOL

Robertson has updated his erudite exploration of human rights law with new material on two critical international actions. He argues that the Pinochet case and the Kosovo conflict illustrate the world community's growing capacity to reject the principle of sovereign immunity in the search for justice.

If the Nuremberg trial first established that war crimes diminish humanity by their very magnitude and thus override sovereignty then, Robertson argues, the Pinochet case mapped out a method for prosecuting peacetime tyrants. He asserts that Kosovo established a right of humanitarian intervention in international law. Robertson sees the bombing as legitimate, bold in contrast to the ineffective censures of the divided Security Council. Though critical of the UN for too often respecting state sovereignty, there is optimism the human rights movement will become more proactive, increasing the likelihood of punishing crimes against humanity.

The Puttermesser Papers
Cynthia Ozick
Vintage £6.99, pp236
Buy it at BOL

Ruth Puttermesser is an ecstatic creation, a character oscillating between reality and an effervescent inner life fuelled by a strong sense of her Jewish roots and an appetite for books of all sorts. Puttermesser, a civil servant in New York, is subjected to the vagaries of Gormenghast-style bureaucracy so she escapes into her imagination. She longs for a daughter and inadvertently creates the world's first female golem, who excels at soufflé making and being over helpful. Taking the name of Xanthippe, Socrates's wife, the golem devises a plan to assist Puttermesser in achieving her ultimate fantasy of becoming mayor and realising a vision of paradise on Earth. Ozick's writing is elegant and multi-textured - intelligent and full of the peculiar.

fields.headline: The wails of Géricault
fields.standfirst: Rupert Christiansen's The Visitors is a portrait of the artists, entertainers and sportsmen who came to make money in Victorian England
fields.trailText: Rupert Christiansen's The Visitors is a portrait of the artists, entertainers and sportsmen who came to make money in Victorian England
fields.body:
The Visitors: Culture Shock in Nineteenth-Century Britain
Rupert Christiansen
Chatto & Windus £20 pp288

Contemporary British politicians would excoriate the subjects of The Visitors as shameless, if short-stay, economic migrants. All of them, as Rupert Christiansen says of the artist Géricault, hoped to access 'a free market, a large audience, and lots and lots of money'. They variously flee debt, depression and isolation, hoping to make it in boom-time Victorian Britain. They frequently encounter indifference, but rarely hostility, and their reception, fraught with unease and misunderstanding, makes for attractive narratives of cultural confidence.

Géricault abandons tormented love and a career in the doldrums to exhibit The Raft of the Medusa in Piccadilly. Wagner seeks disciples and conducts at the Royal Albert Hall. Ralph Waldo Emerson arrives from New England for a punishing lecture tour, while spiritualists, sportsmen and entertainers tickle eager consumers. Christiansen identifies a neat and intriguing subject in such raiding parties on the British purse. Unlike Ian Buruma's Anglophiles in Voltaire's Coconuts, the idea of Britain did not resonate with these artists and hucksters, and unlike the extravagant strangers of Caryl Phillips's excellent anthology, few made a home here.

Russian ballerina Tamara Karsavina remarked that the English 'are generous and tolerant' but 'don't take a foreigner seriously'. The Visitors doesn't quite portray cultural exchange: too much mutual suspicion muddies the waters. Wagner declared himself the victim of Jewish critical conspiracy - 'The whole of Israel is once more working against us,' fumed his wife - but more interesting are those who stare accurately at their hosts.

Géricault's lithographs of the London poor strike Christiansen like photo-reportage from a chill and dejected capital; even the horses are less the tumultuous creatures of previous paintings, but drudging beasts of burden. Emerson, too, was distressed by the beggars and prostitutes abandoned by a commercially buoyant nation, 'this magnificent machine', animated by 'a secret vigour, and a pulse like a canon'.

A loosely chronological structure inadvertently divides the book between high art and low, in which paint and philosophy give way to cricket and ballet girls.

Appealing nuggets stud the book - Wagner relishing whitebait suppers in Greenwich; the fraught spectator who dropped dead in the closing minutes of an 1882 Test match. Elsewhere, Christiansen prefers the raised eyebrow of speculation. What was Géricault's relationship to his assistant? Who followed Wagner's forbidding contemporary music? Did the American spiritualist David Home create illusions using a tiny trained monkey, or charge himself with electricity by sleeping with cats?

Home worked the salons of the rich and credulous and racked up more A-list celebrities than Emerson, tempting Thackeray, Ruskin and Browning, who found himself patted by an ectoplasmic hand. Christiansen is sniffy about attempts to expose Home, keeping his sympathies constant even when the lachrymose spirit-rapper defrauds an artless widow, here dismissed as 'some lunatic Dickensian obsessive'.

Cultural exchange frequently shaded into challenge. Emerson pursued a particularly intimate and anxious relationship with the old country. He prepared lists of worthies to whom he made pilgrimage, retreating disappointed from blathering old poets like Coleridge and Wordsworth, and (after initial sympathy) from the testy Thomas Carlyle.

Competition was necessarily more evident when Australian cricketers took the game back to its English creators. An engaging Aboriginal team had some success, although they were nothing, sniffed the Times, to the cultivated teams of Surrey, but later tourists stunned their hosts with bravura and ungentlemanly aggression. A convict nation, shunned in the pavilion, contested the English game and scored another victory for self-reliance.

Dancers escaped such Oedipal tussles. The disreputable display of leg had long seemed un-English, and the capital welcomed foreign attractions. Ballerinas from Italy gave way to American skirt-dancing, which dazzled with 'skyscraper kicks' and electric light. Before the First World War, London swooned at Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, applauding bounding Nijinsky and opulent exoticism. Each innovation was admired but rarely bettered, in a Britain that emerges as unexpectedly liberal but frequently prosaic. In 1919, Nijinsky confided to his diary: 'The English don't like dancing, because they have so much money in their stomachs.'

Appealing nuggets stud the book - Wagner relishing whitebait suppers in Greenwich; the fraught spectator who dropped dead in the closing minutes of an 1882 Test match. Elsewhere, Christiansen prefers the raised eyebrow of speculation. What was Géricault's relationship to his assistant? Who followed Wagner's forbidding contemporary music? Did the American spiritualist David Home create illusions using a tiny trained monkey, or charge himself with electricity by sleeping with cats? Home worked the salons of the rich and credulous and racked up more A-list celebrities than Emerson, tempting Thackeray, Ruskin and Browning, who found himself patted by an ectoplasmic hand. Christiansen is sniffy about attempts to expose Home, keeping his sympathies constant even when the lachrymose spirit-rapper defrauds an artless widow, here dismissed as 'some lunatic Dickensian obsessive'. Cultural exchange frequently shaded into challenge. Emerson pursued a particularly intimate and anxious relationship with the old country. He prepared lists of worthies to whom he made pilgrimage, retreating disappointed from blathering old poets like Coleridge and Wordsworth, and (after initial sympathy) from the testy Thomas Carlyle. Competition was necessarily more evident when Australian cricketers took the game back to its English creators. An engaging Aboriginal team had some success, although they were nothing, sniffed the Times, to the cultivated teams of Surrey, but later tourists stunned their hosts with bravura and ungentlemanly aggression. A convict nation, shunned in the pavilion, contested the English game and scored another victory for self-reliance. Dancers escaped such Oedipal tussles. The disreputable display of leg had long seemed un-English, and the capital welcomed foreign attractions. Ballerinas from Italy gave way to American skirt-dancing, which dazzled with 'skyscraper kicks' and electric light. Before the First World War, London swooned at Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, applauding bounding Nijinsky and opulent exoticism. Each innovation was admired but rarely bettered, in a Britain that emerges as unexpectedly liberal but frequently prosaic. In 1919, Nijinsky confided to his diary: 'The English don't like dancing, because they have so much money in their stomachs.'

fields.headline: Old enough to know better
fields.trailText: Five years after it was launched, the Orange Prize finally came of age this year.
fields.body:
Five years after it was launched, the Orange Prize finally came of age this year.

This was not because the organisers contrived to hold the event in the neo-gothic cavernousness of the V & A. Nor was it to do with the fact that the prize-giving party has become one of the best of its kind, attended by anyone who is anyone (and quite a few who are not) in the world of books.

And then again, it wasn't the slick audio-visual presentation, nor the head-banging cocktails, nor the thrilling Moroccan costumes worn by the Orange catering staff, nor the tom-tom rhythms of the North African drums that made it seem like an important fixture in the annual cycle of book-life and one to rival Booker and Whitbread. Moreover, in offering £30,000 to the winner, it is actually superior, in cash terms, to both.

No, the true evidence of the Orange Prize's arrival in the fiercely competitive world of literary prizes was the judging panel's decision collectively to turn its back on popular literary opinion and award the prize not to Zadie Smith's extraordinarily accomplished, landmark first novel White Teeth but to the journalist Linda Grant's When I Lived in Modern Times, at that moment emphatically untouched by opportunistic accusations of plagiarism.

In other words, the Orange Prize judges arrived at what was reported to be 'a happy and unanimous decision' in cheerful defiance of what I am quite certain the organisers had long prayed for - the media coronation, so to speak, of the fascinatingly troubled young novelist from multicultural Willesden.

There's no doubt that the book trade, desperately on the look out for an easy commercial hit, wanted White Teeth to take the palm. But in the run-up to the big occasion, it must be said that Zadie Smith did not much help her cause by some of her comments to the literary press. 'It's just another award,' she's reported to have said. 'I'm not ungrateful. I'd just rather not win.' Ms Smith also told the Times Educational Supplement: 'The book I wrote is okay but sometimes I think it's quite excruciating - the product of my adolescence.' Drawn, as a Jamaican, into the asylum row, she added that 'Ffion Hague [a judge]... can kiss my behind'.

Who knows if any of this filtered back to the Orange jury? And if so, did they care? To judge by the admirably detached way in which the panel settled on Linda Grant's novel about a young Londoner who becomes embroiled in the Zionist conflict with the British in Israel after the Second World War, probably not.

And this is why I think we should celebrate the moment that the Orange Prize joined the company of Whitbread and Booker. Here, established in an astonishingly short space of time, is a major literary prize that not only celebrates the best contemporary English and American fiction, but also has the self-confidence to ignore one of the most talked-about fictional debuts of recent years and to make a surprising, and also fairly unpopular, choice.

But there is more to Orange's new-found maturity than a willingness to flout bien pensant opinion. It has now proved, beyond question, that it has a sure touch when navigating the turbulent waters of new fiction, selecting work of excellence, originality and readability.

In its first year it picked Helen Dunmore's A Spell of Winter; in 1996 Anne Michaels' Fugitive Pieces; then Carol Shields's Larry's Party, and now finally, in 1999, Suzanne Berne's A Crime in the Neighbourhood.

And if, as many did on Tuesday, you feel that this year's award failed to recognise an important turning-point in contemporary British fiction, what greater mark of vigorous self-confidence could there be?

fields.headline: Mee, myself and eye
fields.standfirst: Andrew Crumey takes us on a romp through literary theory, quantum physics and Enlightenment philosophy in Mr Mee
fields.trailText: Andrew Crumey takes us on a romp through literary theory, quantum physics and Enlightenment philosophy in Mr Mee
fields.body:
Mr Mee
Andrew Crumey, Picador £9.99, pp344
Buy it at BOL

Andrew Crumey's new novel is very strange, but not without precedent. It rolls up a suggestively tangled mishmash of literary theory, quantum physics and bogus Enlightenment philosophy into an engagingly whimsical narrative, not short of showing-off.

The Mr Mee of the title is a delightfully unworldly Scottish octogenarian who bides his days worming happily through dusty volumes of Hume, Stevenson and Rousseau while his cleaner, Mrs B, alternately scolds him and makes him broth.

Mr Mee is intrigued by a reference to the ancient 'Xanthic sect' - which believed fire to be a species of living organism - glossed with a citation of Rosier's Encyclopedia. This mysterious, lost text - a sort of mad shadow of Diderot's - proposes an alternative theory of the universe.

The resources of his local library exhausted, Mee turns to the internet. Like all internet searchers, he has mixed results: turning up a photograph of a naked girl reading a book which may bear tangentially on his search. Such is Mr Mee's innocence, he reports: 'I was also confident that the somewhat hirsute condition of the amply exposed pubes of this unknown woman is a common feature, if not a universal one; a fact whose discovery had at last clarified for me an anecdote which long puzzled me, concerning Ruskin's wedding night in Perth.' Already, we're in the realm of something like Possession or, more aptly, Calvino's If on a Winter's Night a Traveller: the particular, academic thrill of chasing down an elusive, possibly apocryphal, text.

Two connected narratives run parallel. One, set in 1761, follows Ferrand and Minard, a couple of down-at-heel Parisian copyists mentioned in passing in Rousseau's Confessions. These are Crumey's Rosencrantz and Guildenstern: a bumbling pair of Men of Sentiment who find themselves on the run with Rosier's original text. The other concerns a university professor, Dr Petrie, who, as he introduces himself, is undergoing a colonoscopy. He is, literally, sick with love for one of his students. (The twentieth-century characters suffer very eighteenth-century afflictions.)

For Petrie, the glancing reference to Ferrand and Minard has become a scholarly obsession. If Mr Mee's intricate deferrals are like Calvino, the jaunty tone is more like Sterne or Flann O'Brien. Deconstructive silliness abounds. Here texts are literally in flight, from their authors and from the authorities. Ferrand and Minard, charged with transcribing Rosier, flee Paris fearing they are suspects in a murder committed by someone after Rosier's text.

Crumey's prose is workmanlike but unexceptional. The pleasure here is in the constant play of ideas, particularly around the notion of 'authority', in its literary more than its political sense.

Petrie tells us: 'Proust's novel concerns a person called "I", who, Proust wrote in an explanatory newspaper article, is "not always myself".'

As well as suggesting a pun in the name of our hero (shifted, perhaps, from subject to object), this question of who writes texts, let alone why, runs right through the novel. Rousseau is introduced as 'a copyist'. Gertrude Stein is quoted approvingly: 'I write for myself and strangers.'

Meanwhile, the internet's metaphorical potential - prefigured in Rosier's dotty calculating machines and mechanical devices for generating words - is used to the full. That's not to say its literal potential isn't also well explored.

With the aid of a guide to HTML, written by one 'Dr Cool', our bemused hero ends up gobbling ecstasy and, still in quest of antiquarian books, misguidedly attending a 'swinging' party.

All this may make this novel sound heavy going. It's not. Mr Mee - a messy, entertaining intellectual tease - is a literary riff on the po-faced themes of theorists and far too good-natured and incoherent to be a thesis novel. It's fluff with a degree from the Sorbonne and none the worse for it.

webTitle: Chucker Charlie's order of the bath

fields.headline: Chucker Charlie's order of the bath
fields.standfirst: Fiery Fred speaks out
fields.trailText: Fred Trueman: 'The West Indies? I'll tell you that my first tour there did for me and cost me a place on the next two England tours,' he said, as he relaxed at his home on the outskirts of Skipton. Bill Bradshaw interviews the Yorkshire legend.
fields.body:
The prospect of an England series against the West Indies is enough to have Freddie Trueman licking his lips in anticipation. The first cricketer in the world to break through the 300 Test-wicket barrier has guaranteed his own immortality through his fast-bowling deeds - but his own jousts with the Windies perhaps perfectly crystallise his remarkable career.

Trueman is now 69 but as forthright and 'fiery' - his nickname as a player - as ever. His girth is larger these days, the hair a little less luxuriant and dark, but he retains the look of formidable strength in the arms, shoulder and back that helped make him a pace legend.

He is not known for sparing his views, although his thoughts on the game are not now broadcast - literally - to a mass audience. His style fell from favour with BBC producers of Test Match Special soon after his old friend Brian Johnson died in 1995. And his regular columns for the Sunday People (he is Britain's longest-serving sports columnist for one title - 43 years) are apparently under serious threat.

But, one-to-one, the blunt, spade's-a-spade responses to the gentlest probing are reassuringly Truemanesque. And unmistakably Yorkshire.

'The West Indies? I'll tell you that my first tour there did for me and cost me a place on the next two England tours,' he said, as he relaxed at his home on the outskirts of Skipton.

'It was 1953-54 and I was only 22. They didn't like my conduct, apparently. We'd been told not to fraternise with the Windies players but lads like Gary Sobers, Lance Gibbs and Everton Weekes were mates and they became lifelong friends. I was only young and if my conduct was found wanting then it was nothing compared to that of some of the so-called senior players on that tour. I got no help from most of them.

'I was supposed to call them "mister" or "sir'"and they just called me "Trueman"! I told them straight that my parents had thought long and hard about my first name. All that amateur-professional nonsense was disgraceful.

'As for an official word on what I was supposed to have done, I don't know. I was never told.'

Trueman played in the first, fourth and fifth Tests and helped square the series after England had been 2-0 down, but he was then largely snubbed and it was not until 1957 - when the West Indies toured England - that Trueman was apparently forgiven and handed a genuine chance. He grabbed it with both hands and finished the series with 22 wickets as England triumphed 3-0 against a side packed with names such as Sobers, Frank Worrell, Clyde Walcott, Everton Weekes and Sonny Ramadhin.

'That West Indies series got me established in the England team at last,' he says. 'I was in the side pretty much all the way through for the next eight years until I finished as a Test bowler in 1965.'

Thoughts of the Sixties inevitably drift to the 1964 series against Australia when everyone who lived through those summers recalls Trueman smashing through the 300-wicket barrier against the Aussies.

Yet it was against the West Indies - that side again - that Trueman undoubtedly hit his international peak a year earlier in 1963. England lost the series 3-1 but Trueman was on fire and bagged his best- ever series haul of 34 wickets.

It was a controversial tour with the West Indies twin pace attack of Wes Hall and Charlie Griffith under scrutiny. Hall, tall, lean and athletic, was the genuine article, but Griffith - a bowler Trueman had encountered during the 1959-60 tour to the Caribbean - astounded him.

'I remembered him as a medium pacer,' he recalls. 'Then in 1963, when they played Yorkshire, I saw his run-up had lengthened by about 15 yards and his pace was absolutely electrifying. But from the moment I saw him I believed he was throwing the ball. Not just his fast delivery - they were all fast anyway - but all of them.

'He hit Doug Padgett and Jackie Hampshire and Jackie still feels the effects of it. Ken Barrington got very upset by Griffith. It wasn't that we suspected Charlie of chucking_ we knew. His pace was amazing and he had hardly any follow-through. He and Hall hit Brian Close so many times in the Lord's Test we called Closey "leopard" because the bruises looked like spots.'

For all that, Griffith helped the West Indies to a series win and he was only ever 'called' for throwing twice - once against India in 1962 and by English umpire Arthur Fagg when the Windies played Lancashire in 1966.

As Trueman recalls, it was not the only time 'throwing' became an issue in matches between the sides.

'On my first tour in 1954, Tony Lock was no-balled for throwing by Clyde Walcott's uncle who was standing as umpire. It upset Tony very, very much. Tony went away after that and worked hard on it and he got back into the England side. There was talk at that time about Sonny Ramadhin's action but he wore his sleeves down and you couldn't really see if the arm was straight or bent.

'Years later Sonny did an interview with cricket writer Peter Johnson and admitted he'd thrown it throughout his career.'

But back to the Hall-Griffith series of 1963 and Trueman has a remarkable story to tell about the second Test at Lord's. He was relaxing in the bath when he heard Dick Robins, the chairman of selectors, addressing the match umpires, Syd Buller and Eddie Phillipson.

He was telling the umpires not - repeat not - to no-ball Charlie Griffith. I could not believe what I was hearing. Some time later I recounted his story in my autobiography and a small piece appeared in the Daily Telegraph rubbishing my claim. To which I reply_ who was there in the bathroom to say I am a liar? Some can call it diplomacy and not wishing to offend; I call it a cover-up. And cricket is still covering up to this day. We see it now with the betting scandals and the only surprise is that the stories about South Africa were uncovered and put into the public domain in the first place.'

Trueman caused a stir a few years ago by raising questions about Courtney Walsh's action in delivering his quicker ball. He has no regrets but is not surprised that no action was taken.

'That's cricket,' he says. 'Courtney is a lovely guy and a fine bowler but I was concerned about his quicker ball. I know one leading umpire considered reporting him but he was told from the highest level: "don't think about it".

'I've also expressed my concern about one of our own. Darren Gough's quicker ball can look a little suspect but when I mentioned this to a leading selector at the time I was told quite plainly: "If so-and-so has got away with it for years, why should we worry about Darren?" '

Is it, I volunteered, a sensitive issue... a race issue? When Muttiah Muralitharan's action was 'called' in Australia, it was suggested there was a racist motive.

For once, Freddie was almost speechless. 'Ah,' he said at last. 'But if you get me on that subject then any loose talk from me would take us all the way back to 1954 and the reasons I was dropped after my first West Indies tour. And that would not do at all, would it?'

fields.headline: Akhtar express hits the buffers
fields.standfirst: Stephen Thorpe on how Trent Bridge's glamour signing never got going
fields.trailText: Not a great end to the week at Trent Bridge after Nottinghamshire had broken then equalled longstanding records for their first and last wicket inside four days. On Friday evening came the shattering news that Shoaib Akhtar, their charismatic overseas player and fastest bowler in the world, had been released from his summer contract due to a recurrent rib injury.
fields.body:
Not a great end to the week at Trent Bridge after Nottinghamshire had broken then equalled longstanding records for their first and last wicket inside four days. On Friday evening came the shattering news that Shoaib Akhtar, their charismatic overseas player and fastest bowler in the world, had been released from his summer contract due to a recurrent rib injury.

The Pakistani arrived from the Caribbean a fortnight ago when the problem was expected to respond to intensive treatment, but the prognosis worsened after specialist advice indicated that a reaction was occurring from a ribtip impacting on the pelvis whilst bowling. Complete rest has been ordered and his action may need to adapt to prevent a recurrence.

The club have approached the ECB to re-engage, and a replacement, whose identity remains unclear, is not likely to arrive until the NatWest match at Lords on 21 June.

Alarm bells rang in midweek when Tim Leary, the physiotherapist, observed: 'It's not your classic side strain and there can be complications with this type of injury.' Never a truer word. Akhtar has played one first-class match all year and bowled only seven overs in the Caribbean before breaking down and there are rumblings amongst the members that a much loved figure, the New Zealand all-rounder Chris Cairns, who was apparently ready and willing some months ago, would have made a far better choice.

That option is now closed and a batsman who can bowl is seen as the best way forward. Phil Simmons, the West Indian all-rounder, currently playing local league cricket has been mentioned but he has represented Wales in the NatWest Trophy and would be cup-tied. Clive Rice, the cricket manager, said: 'This is devastating news for all concerned and I'm not bothered who we get as long as it's quick.' The international touring programme is in a state of flux which also complicates matters.

Nottinghamshire, to their credit, have offered Akhtar the chance to stay on and continue his rehabilitation alongside the players, and are hoping the Pakistan Cricket Board will accede to the idea. David Collier, the chief executive, said: 'Shoaib is a popular figure already, has fitted in well in his short time here and we'll do all we can to help him.' The bulk of his contract, reputedly worth up to £100,000 based on appearances and performance, is now null and void, and Akhtar has gone away for a few days to consider his future.

Everyone with the good of the game at heart, though, must hope he makes a speedy and full recovery and returns to the fold soon. The repercussions in the local ethnic community are also uncertain. Nottinghamshire's membership increased by 20 per cent to nearly 6,000 with his signing, a significant number of whom were of ethnic origin and this content is already apparent.

Naveed Mahmood, a 13-year-old cousin of Usman Afzaal, their precocious left hander, lamented: 'It's very disappointing because I've rejoined this year in the hope of seeing him. All my friends and family were due to go to the National League match against Hampshire on Sunday but now I suppose we won't.'

Whatever else, the sad scenario is terrible luck for the player, the club and supporters and the weekend will be spent in a frantic worldwide trawl for a suitable replacement. Filling his boots will not be easy.

fields.headline: Shearer relief for England
fields.standfirst: England's hopes raised ahead of Keegan's biggest test
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer has been passed fit to play against Portugal tomorrow, much to Kevin Keegan's evident relief.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer has been passed fit to play against Portugal tomorrow, much to Kevin Keegan's evident relief.

Flying somewhat in the face of public opinion the England manager regards his captain and centre-forward his most important player, but had Shearer been forced out of the opening game of his last international tournament with the tendinitis below the knee he aggravated against Malta last week, Keegan would have been criticised for using him in three games within eight days.

'Alan is fit, ready for selection and raring to go,' Keegan confirmed after a training session in Spa yesterday. 'Despite what some people have said in the last year he is a very important member of our squad.

'Alan desperately wanted to play because this is his last tournament, and I desperately wanted him to play too, but he had to be fit. I think we have done everything right with him

'We have not pushed him when we shouldn't have - it was right to play him in Malta because he needed the game.'

The effectiveness of Shearer remains a matter for debate, but at least Keegan has no worries on the fitness front going into Euro 2000. 'The physio told me we had 22 fit guys at the end of the session, and I don't know how many other squads will be able to say that,' Keegan said, seeing a straw and clutching it.

Shearer himself remains unconcerned by the criticism, indeed he hardly knows how to enter a tournament without it.

'If only 74 per cent of the public want me out of the team this time that's an improvement on four years ago,' he joked. 'It was something like 98 per cent then. The criticism I get doesn't surprise me, nor does it bother me. I'll just carry on doing what I've been doing for the last 11 or 12 years, because that's all I know how to do. I don't believe the praise, and I don't believe the criticism, I just believe in my own ability.'

That formula has always served Shearer well, though it is surely legitimate to observe that he is a much diminished player since his injury - a fact confirmed by his own decision to retire from international football after this tournament - and he currently has no relationship with a fellow England striker as profitable as the one he formed with Teddy Sheringham at Euro 96.

'The fact that this is my last tournament doesn't really make any difference,' Shearer said. 'Of course I'd like to go out with a bang, but I'd be just as determined anyway. It's not about me, I'll be happy if England do well whoever scores the goals.

'I would prefer to score the goals, naturally, because that's my job, but there's pressure on me whether I score or not. If I score in one game there's pressure still pressure to score in the next, but I can handle that. It's just what comes with being me, and I got used to it years ago.'

fields.headline: Leicester lure Peter Taylor
fields.trailText: Gillingham manager Peter Taylor is on his way to Leicester City as successor to Martin O'Neill.
fields.body:
Gillingham manager Peter Taylor is on his way to Leicester City as successor to Martin O'Neill.

Taylor, who has just steered the Gills into the First Division for the first time in their history after 12 months in charge, is set to be unveiled as the new Filbert Street boss tomorrow when he returns from a family holiday.

Gillingham chairman Paul Scally said: 'The Leicester chairman [John Elsom] has told me that Peter is their first choice. I think it would be unfair of me to try and block the deal as this is a job that will make him a millionaire. We have to be fair to Peter and treat him well because he's treated us extremely well this year.

'I'm disappointed he's leaving, but having said that I'm grateful for what he's done this year and I wish him well in his new job.'

Taylor carved out a formidable reputation - after an unsuccessful start in management at Southend - with England's under-21 side.

England twice topped their qualifying group in the European Under-21 Championships under Taylor, but that was not enough to save him from being removed last summer as Howard Wilkinson took over his role.

But Taylor quickly showed he could transfer his success to club level as he inspired Gillingham to a successful FA Cup run and promotion to the First Division with their play-off victory over Wigan at Wembley a fortnight ago.

Scally added: 'I've told Peter that he would go with our blessing and he'll always be welcome back at Priestfield. I gave Peter my word that I wouldn't seek compensation if he moved to a big club before the end of June and obviously I'll stand by my word.'

Manchester United 'Busby Babe' Shay Brennan has died, aged 63. Brennan, who was capped 19 times by the Republic of Ireland, was the first English-born player to be picked for the country - his mother came from Co Carlow. He got into the United team after the Munich air disaster, and stayed to become a member of the club's League and Cup winning sides of the Sixties - and the European Cup-winning side in 1968. After leaving United, he moved to Ireland, playing for and managing Waterford.

He died suddenly last night in Co Waterford.
