fields.headline: And so back to bed
fields.standfirst: Eight hours good, four hours bad
fields.trailText: Good morning! Good night's sleep? According to the World Health Organisation, that's not likely. At 'any given moment', 50 per cent of us are likely to be in sleep deficit.
fields.body:
Good morning! Good night's sleep? According to the World Health Organisation, that's not likely. At 'any given moment', 50 per cent of us are likely to be in sleep deficit. Now we learn that a quarter of children are similarly sleep-deprived, with dire consequences for their education, social behaviour and, you can be sure, the mental health of their parents. Don't blame the children - they're merely copying their parents.

When Margaret Thatcher murdered sleep by claiming four hours were sufficient for vanquishing the enemies of the state, it became fashionable to be alert at all hours, snatching a nap only when convenient. The idle rich with time to pass a full eight hours comatose were consigned to the wheelie bin of history.

For the past two decades, time to spare has become the burden of the poor and not enough time to sleep a status symbol. 'Busy' is now the standard reply to the social inquiry 'How are you?', intended to indicate that the speaker, in the argot of the day, has a life.

But a change is in the air. Really Important Execs not only expect to 'knit up the ravelled sleave of care', they see a potential exclusivity in the offing: the men and women managing their lives so well that they even have time for eight hours' sleep.

We look forward to a future where the well-rested discuss their dreams over a pre-siesta lunch. This is an area where Britain could surely set the pace (slow). Still there? Go back to bed.

webTitle: Shame of child poverty in UK

fields.headline: Shame of child poverty in UK
fields.standfirst:
Almost one in five children is poor, reveals UN report

More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: Britain's shameful record on childhood poverty is laid bare today in a damning United Nations report revealing that millions of young people are trapped in conditions among the worst in Europe.
fields.body:
Britain's shameful record on childhood poverty is laid bare today in a damning United Nations report revealing that millions of young people are trapped in conditions among the worst in Europe.

The Observer has obtained a report by Unicef, the children's arm of the UN, which says that Britain has one of the worst records on childhood poverty in the industrialised world. Nearly 20 per cent of young people live in families which are below the official poverty line - judged as household income below half median earnings.

The report, which will prove an acute embarrassment to Tony Blair's government, puts Britain below countries such as Turkey, Poland and Hungary, which suffer less relative poverty than the UK.

Countries such as Sweden, Norway and Finland suffer rates below 5 per cent.

'It is a question this country must face,' said David Piachaud, expert in childhood poverty at the London school of economics. 'Do we want another generation of children who are brought up in poverty, who have worse health, worse education, worse housing and deficient lifetime prospects? Children are supposed to be the innocents.'

The report, which will be published on Tuesday, says that even when it comes to absolute poverty - households with an income below the US official poverty line - Britain still languishes in the bottom quarter of the child poverty league.

The report says that the UK fails on five key indicators of childhood poverty. The childhood poverty rate is high, the number of lone parent families suffering from poverty is high, and the number of workless households is high, as is the number of people who suffer from low wages or have low benefits.

The report, to be published on Tuesday, will reignite the debate on Britain's poor. Although it will praise the Government for taking action to lift more than one million children out of poverty, it will reveal the huge amount still to be done.

Inquiries by The Observer have discovered the true cost to children of living in households without enough money.

Children are eating main meals which consist of little more than toast and beans and rice pudding. Many live in terrible surroundings, with damp running down the walls and inadequate heating. Parents often cannot afford to buy new clothes as the little money they have is spent on food. Some lone parents have less than £100 a week with which to bring up their children and pay the bills.

Poor nutrition leads to bad performance at school and worse health, with associated costs to the National Health Service.

It is estimated that it would cost Britain £10 billion to eradicate the problem.

fields.headline: Italy's season of discontent
fields.standfirst: Italy deserve nothing but failure at Euro 2000 after a poisonous domestic season, which ends when Serie B wraps up this afternoon
fields.trailText: Italy deserve nothing but failure at Euro 2000 after a poisonous domestic season, which ends when Serie B wraps up this afternoon, writes Joe McGiniss.
fields.body:
Here is how bad things have become in Italy: in the town of Camorosso, north of Trieste, children have been prohibited from playing football in the street. Residents complained that the noise of the games, played late into midsummer evenings, distracted them while they were watching television.

The town council responded with a by-law that makes playing football on any public street or square an offence punishable by a £15 fine and confiscation of the ball. But let's not be too quick to judge these good burghers harshly: it is probable that their real motivation is to discourage their young ones from embarking on a life of crime.

If it is true that every Italian football season is composed of equal parts, scandal, hype, and genuine magnificence, this was the one in which Serie A found the third in such short supply that it tried to compensate by doubling up on the first, leaving even the most credulous of tifosi gagging and the always malleable sporting press calling it 'The Poisoned Season.'

'Remember,' an Italian player said to me three years ago, as I was nearing the end of my season-long stay with the Serie B team of Castel di Sangro, 'we are the land not only of Dante, but Machiavelli.' True enough, but Machiavelli at least preached efficiency.

One would have to go back to the bestial Borgias of the Fifteenth Century to find ancestry for this year's calamities, which occurred in three main areas: on the field, in the stands and under the table.

On the field, the picture was starkly etched: for the second successive season, Italian clubs, who had won or reached the finals of the Uefa Cup in all but one other year of the decade, failed to get past the last 16. And only Lazio squeezed through the quarter-finals of the Champions League only to be immediately routed by Valencia.

As for the national team, who qualified for Euro 2000 with only a one-point margin over Denmark and Switzerland, their season-long diversion seemed to determine against which unheralded opponents they could play worst in a friendly: the home losses to Belgium and Denmark ran neck and neck for top honours, though last week's defeat in Norway was pretty poor, too.

The cause of the collapse was excruciatingly apparent to anyone who forced himself (as I did, for reasons that are unclear even to my therapist) to watch attentively from September to May.

For this was the year when the obsession with defence, of which the Italians have never quite rid themselves grew like some horrid mutant fungus, choking off the oxygen supply on which the poetry of the game depends for its survival.

Even in midfield and on what passed for attack it was the monotonous chant of 'legs and lungs, legs and lungs' that drowned out all else, to the point where anyone who displayed even a trace of creative impulse was certain to be benched.

Consider the fate of the magnificent Roberto Baggio, who at 32 but with his skills refined rather than diminished, found himself suddenly chained to the bench by Marcello Lippi at Inter Milan. Baggio is, and always has been, a magician, his almost preternatural vision supported by an astonishing array of ballistic acrobatics that produce positively hallucinogenic effects, not to mention, goals, assists and victories.

Less apparent to the oblivious, among whom Lippi shamefully numbered himself, is that Baggio possesses also as hard and fast and relentless a will to win as any man who has ever played the game. Lippi, however, was enamoured of the vision of a phalanx of muscular automatons: robotic football, designed for our Brave New World.

Not only did he mistrust the sublime, he couldn't even recognise it as it happened. This caused him to cast an openly spiteful eye on Baggio, whose football begins at just that point beyond which the X's and O's of the chalkboad cannot go.

All season long, Baggio suf fered with the silent dignity of a champion, but make no mistake: he suffered dearly. I spoke with him in early November, and even then the pain was apparent beyond the surface glimmer of the eyes, the anguish behind the brave attempts to smile.

And that was only at the beginning of the year of large and small humiliations the sadistic Lippi made him endure in what seemed a campaign of cruelty designed to break Baggio's indomitable spirit.

But by no means only at Inter was a sterile hyper-tacticality the new order of the day in Italy. This may have simplified the lives of the managers, who are cloned at Italy's national coaching academy and licensed to practice only after all traces of daring and imagination have been stamped out, but clearly it failed to charm the fans.

It took no elaborate polling, only a counting of empty seats, to demonstrate that Serie A's sudden affliction with the calcio of constipation had the tifosi stampeding for the exits.

At £100 a seat, they had come to expect football, not tic-tac-toe. Defending champions Juventus saw attendance fall by more than 10 per cent as defence and defence only reigned supreme; while at Perugia - after the sale of their one exciting player, Hidetoshi Nakata - gate revenues plunged by more than 25 per cent.

Even the notoriously head-in-the-sand Federazione sensed something was wrong when fewer than 300 turned out to see Lazio play an Italian Cup match in Venice. While the spectacle in the stands might have been more vivid than the rigor-mortis setting in on the pitch, it was seldom edifying. There were also scandalous outbreaks of violence and racism in the domestic game. And then there was the end of season farce.

For years, virtually everyone in Italy who is not a Juventus supporter has been convinced that the club's success has come less from merit than from intricate arrangements with an entire generation of referees.

It is an article of faith among many that over the years Juventus have created an entire platoon of Manchurian Candidates, who can peacefully and calmly live their cover story lives, and work honestly as referees. But then one day the call comes, the conditioning kicks in, the dirty deed is done, and Juventus win yet another title.

The man behind the puppet screen has long been presumed but never proven to be a certain Luciano Moggi, officially sixth down on the Juventus organisational chart, but widely perceived as the Agnelli family's Rasputin.

With Juventus two points ahead of Lazio on the season's penultimate weekend, a young referee named De Santis was assigned to their crucial match against Parma. In the final seconds of the game, with Juventus 1-0 up, Parma's Cannavaro scored an impeccable header from a corner. The match was tied 1-1, and so it would end, leaving Lazio even on points with Juventus.

But wait. De Santis waved off the goal, then spun and ran toward the opposite end of the field, blowing his whistle to end the match along the way, then disappearing immediately into the tunnel that led from the field and into his car conveniently awaiting him in the nearest possible parking lot.

Players from both sides, dozens of commentators, hundreds of journalists, thousands of spectators and millions of television viewers around the world (including this one) were mystified. What possibly could have led to the annulling of the goal?

Two dozen replays, freeze-frames and slow-motions from every possible angle demonstrated beyond any doubt that absolutely nothing irregular had occurred.

It was then that the inexperienced De Santis made the blunder that will cost him his career. An enterprising journalist obtained the referee's mobile phone number and called him in his car. Instead of terminating the call instantly, the flustered young man tried tried to explain.

He'd seen pushing in the area even before the kick had been taken and had blown his whistle in an attempt to sort it out. Therefore, he had not, in reality, annulled any goal, for there had been no goal to annul.

Ah, but he'd failed to take television into account, and replays showed irrefutably that the ball was already bulging in the back of the Juventus net before De Santis had even begun to raise his whistle to his lips.

Caught on audiotape now, in a lie both barefaced and pathetic, De Santis simply disappeared and has yet to resurface. Only the most dramatic of reversals could now dampen the flames of outrage threatening to destroy the whole edifice (or should that be artifice?) that had made Italy the envy of the footballing world.

But let it never be said that either Moggi, God or Lucifer acts by the half-measure.

The following Sunday a downpour inundated the Perugia ground at halftime.

This was of interest only because Perugia's opponents were Juventus, who needed only a draw to secure the title, and who had seemed quite content to be 0-0 at half time. It became apparent that the Federazione was not going to permit this Poisoned Season to extend even a microsecond longer than necessary, even if it meant issuing scuba gear for the second half. Although the pitch was under water and the game held up, the referee ruled that play would continue and five minutes into the second half a lumbering Perugia defender reached into the muck in front of the Juventus goal and flipped an object - by God, it was the ball! - past the stunned Juventus keeper.

So the game ended 1-0, which coupled with Lazio's easy home win over Reggina sent the title to Rome.

Ten days later, having just played perhaps the finest match in what might well come to be viewed as the greatest career any Italian footballer has ever achieved, a slight and shy man named Baggio, who the day before had earned Inter qualification to next year's Champions League, scoring two goals that can only be described as brushstrokes on the Sistine Chapel ceiling, parked his car in front of the house in which he'd grown up, in the small northern village of Caldogno. He knew he would would never wear Inter's shirt again.

To ensure that his town would never be mistaken for Camorosso he removed from the trunk a brand new football and began dribbling it down the main street until joined by enough adoring children to assure the commencement of a game which, without riling the neighbours in the slightest, would last until well after midnight.

fields.headline: Trouble over bridged waters
fields.standfirst: First shaky steps across the Thames
fields.trailText: They had taken fewer than a dozen steps when eight-year-old Thomas grabbed his father's hand and tried to stand still. He wobbled over sideways, sending another small child flying, but regained his balance and dug his heels in more firmly. 'It's shaking. I'm scared. Daddy - I don't want to do this.'
fields.body:
They had taken fewer than a dozen steps when eight-year-old Thomas grabbed his father's hand and tried to stand still. He wobbled over sideways, sending another small child flying, but regained his balance and dug his heels in more firmly. 'It's shaking. I'm scared. Daddy - I don't want to do this.'

The same thought had already occurred to his father and, turning round, they pushed their way back along the new Millennium Bridge through the swaying, slipping crowd to the safety of the riverside.

'And this is before the gin and tonic,' said one woman cheerfully as they passed. Her companion, an architect, was less chipper. 'No bridge should do this,' he muttered. 'There's something seriously wrong with the design.'

The first new river crossing to be built in central London for more than 100 years opened to the public yesterday for the second time - the Queen's ceremonial unveiling last month was somewhat premature.

It closed briefly 15 minutes later as huge numbers of pedestrians eager to cross, coupled with high winds, sent the structure bucking and writhing like a fairground attraction.

'It's supposed to do this,' said David Bell, chair of the Millennium Bridge Trust as he tried to lead the hesitant crowd across the much-praised but, until yesterday, barely-travelled 'blade of light'.

'It's because people were walking in step,' he explained to police. 'It's perfectly safe. The problem was accentuated because people were crossing in lumps.'

In the end, Bell's suggestion of 'a one off - one on' operation was adopted by police and charity workers who had organised the sponsored walk for Save the Children.

The £18.2m bridge is an impressive structure and the wobble a minor glitch. A co-operative project between Foster and Partners architects, sculptor Sir Antony Caro and the engineers Ove Arup and Partners, it is elegant and confident, spanning the Thames with a gossamer delicacy enhanced by the sturdy stolidness of Southwark Bridge and Blackfriars Bridge, which flank it on either side.

'I've visited most major cities in Europe this month and London is far and away the most impressive of the lot in terms of culture, architecture and sheer style,' said Canadian student Josh Rauchwerger. 'There's nothing like this back home.'

Back at the foot of the bridge, Thomas's father had engaged Bell in an intense discussion. 'I've just seen the film about the Tacoma Narrows Bridge disaster,' he explained. 'That started like this.'

Thomas clung to his father's leg and looked horrified. 'Thomas,' his father said gently. 'We've got to go back: our car is over there.'

Nine minutes later, clutching a celebratory can of 7-Up, Thomas contemplated his odyssey. 'It was quite scary even when it was emptier,' he said. 'But a lot of things made for the millennium have had a little bit wrong with them. My friend's coming later. I'm going to tell him it's good.'

amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Euro 2000: The diary
fields.trailText: Fun-lovin' criminals, big in Holland and Henrik 'Lazarus' Larsson.
fields.body:
Lock-up stock freed up

Criminals in Belgium are getting an unexpected two-week 'holiday' to make sure that there are enough cell places for all the hooligans expected to cause trouble at Euro 2000. The timing may be coincidental but the 'escapees' begin their fortnight's break tomorrow - the day England play Portugal. Spaces freed up by the initiative will be used to house miscreants caught up in the 'quick justice' system the Benelux authorities have put in place for the tournament, which will see suspects locked up for up to five days before they go before a judge. Happily the Belgian Justice Ministry's brainwave won't mean that scores of murderers are let out; only villains given less than three years are eligible for Euro 2000 parole, and sex criminals have to stay behind bars.

Such a big boy

Edgar Davids is huge in Holland - quite literally. An enormous billboard image of the Dutch midfield dynamo has been stuck onto the side of Holland's tallest building, the Delftse Poort in Rotterdam, where the co-host nation play Denmark on Friday. At 150 metres tall it's the same size as the Statue of Liberty and 60 times bigger than real life. The people behind the stunt are Nike, Holland's kit sponsors, who are keenly aware of the bespectacled one's superstar status in his homeland. But the 4,500 individual graphic panels, which weigh a staggering two-and-a-half tonnes and together form the world's largest building-wrap project, were actually printed in Reading. If Davids can burst through French, Danish and Czech defences as dramatically as he charges out of the Rotterdam billboard, the Orangemen might just survive the 'Group of Death'.

One of our players is missing

The player at Euro 2000 who nobody really expected to be there (apart from Gary Neville, obviously) is Celtic's dreadlocked Swedish striker Henrik Larsson. His miraculous recovery from serious injury means his inclusion in World Soccer magazine's 'missing' list of 'big names who'll be watching Euro 2000 on TV' (Ruud Van Nistelrooy, David Batty, Joe Cole) was premature. Likewise the Times ad for their tournament fantasy football has Italy's Gianluigi Buffon -- who is out of action after breaking his hand against Norway last weekend -- in goal. Other absent friends we'll miss over the next three weeks include Gazza, who's filled in the time he's not been with Kevin Keegan's squad by admitting to Rangers magazine that attacking ex-wife Sheryl is the only thing he really regrets -- no, he didn't mention wasting all that talent. Also missing, of course, is French reject David Ginola who sadly isn't even part of the BBC commentary team. He's been keeping busy doing a TV ad about drug smuggling, visiting Cambodia on Red Cross anti-landmines duty (chronicled in the latest Hello! ) and finalising his new autobiography, due in the autumn. Not sure Gérard Houllier, the French manager who discarded him so cruelly in 1994, will enjoy reading that.

What's your name, son?

Rainbow, stickmen and stats

Unrivalled, original day-by-day Euro 2000 coverage will be running throughout the tournament on The Observer network at www.footballunlimited.co.uk. In addition to live minute-by-minute coverage of every match, Football Unlimited has put together a package of top features - including Euro notes, a guide to the players to watch this summer; Ormondroyd's Euro 2000 stickmen cartoons; an interactive, downloadable wallchart, and Jamie Rainbow's month in an armchair, where Jamie Rainbow spends a month in an armchair. All this plus a daily guide - 'The Euro' - emailed to you every morning during the tournament - for free: visit www.footballunlimited.co.uk/theeuro to sign up.

fields.headline: Sleep loss blights the family
fields.standfirst: Mind control drug prescribed for children by mistake, warns scientist
fields.trailText: Mind control drug prescribed for children by mistake, warns scientist
fields.body:
Children are suffering an 'epidemic of sleeplessness' so severe it is damaging their performance at school and their social relationships. Some pupils are so inattentive from fatigue that they are being misdiagnosed as having a serious mental illness and put on a mind control drug related to cocaine.

Sleep experts say that children are not getting enough sleep because their bedrooms have been turned into entertainment centres, there is more permissiveness about bedtimes, and working parents are keen to spend time with their children after coming back late from the office.

According to a study in the June edition of the Journal of Sleep Research, a large proportion of children are either not sleeping long enough, or their sleep is of poor quality. One in four children aged between nine and 14 do not feel rested at school, and 15 per cent have sleep problems.

The author, Anne Meijer, studied what effect this had on school performance and concluded: 'Children who feel better rested display a more positive self-image, more achievement motivation, have more control over their aggressive behaviour, are less bored and are more receptive to their teacher.'

The study covered Dutch children, but British experts say the position in this country is exactly the same.

Professor Gregory Stores, head of research into child sleep disorders at Oxford University, said: 'Sleep disturbance is very common among young children. Their school attainment and performance is affected, as well as their social relationships. It's happening on a large scale and it's likely it's getting worse. It is an epidemic of sleeplessness way above the levels usually expected.'

Children's sleep suffers because of computers, televisions and videos in their bedrooms, encouraging them to stay up late and not 'wind down' before settling.

Many sleepless children's symptoms were misleading, and unlike those of adults. Such pupils tend to be irritable, depressed, inattentive, disruptive and hyperactive.

As a result, they can be diagnosed wrongly as having Attention Deficit-Hyperactivity Disorder and often put on Ritalin, a drug related to cocaine, which can disturb sleep. This can make the problem worse, Stores warned.

fields.headline: The Observer: more sales success
fields.trailText: The Observer's impressive sales growth of the past eight months continued during May with year-on-year increases well ahead of the rest of the Sunday market.
fields.body:
The Observer's impressive sales growth of the past eight months continued during May with year-on-year increases well ahead of the rest of the Sunday market.

We sold an average of 408,748 copies a week last month, an increase of 2.21 per cent on May 1999, the best-performing title in the Sunday broadsheet market. In the six months to May 2000, we sold 410,700 copies a week, up 1.37 per cent on the six months to May 1999, and again the highest year-on-year increase in the market, according to the latest figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

webTitle: England fans pour in for trouble

fields.headline: England fans pour in for trouble
fields.standfirst:
Hooligans are barred at borders as Dutch police warn 'violence will be met with violence' at Euro 2000

Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: More than two dozen England fans trying to reach Euro 2000 were turned away at the Dutch and Belgian borders yesterday. Up to 17,000 England fans travelling without tickets are expected to be in Eindhoven tomorrow for the team's opening game with Portugal, raising fears of violent clashes between rival thugs.
fields.body:
More than two dozen England fans trying to reach Euro 2000 were turned away at the Dutch and Belgian borders yesterday. Up to 17,000 England fans travelling without tickets are expected to be in Eindhoven tomorrow for the team's opening game with Portugal, raising fears of violent clashes between rival thugs.

The names of the men turned away were on a list of known or suspected hooligans. A Home Office spokesman said: 'That should get the message over that if you're on the list, don't travel.' Another fan who has been banned from travelling to international matches after a conviction for soccer violence was stopped by police at Harwich, Essex, as he tried to board a ferry to Holland.

The fans who get through are expected to congregate in an area of Eindhoven dubbed 'Bar Street' by locals because it is packed with 80 adjacent pubs and clubs. Some bar owners were yesterday tying their chairs to the tables amid fears that trouble could erupt.

As police warned potential English troublemakers that 'violence will be met with violence', an Observer investigation has established that English thugs are preparing to lead a 'united front' of racist troublemakers from across Europe to target Turkish people and businesses.

Security forces in the Netherlands and Belgium fear hooligans from several countries will join forces to attack Turkish targets in a bid to avenge the recent murders of two Leeds United fans in Istanbul.

The March killing in Istanbul, followed by fresh Anglo-Turkish battles in Copenhagen last month, have produced a lethal rivalry.

'What everybody dreads is a repetition of what happened in Istanbul: that somebody gets killed in violence involving English supporters and Turkish people,' said Els Cleemput of the gendarmerie, Belgium's national police force.

'We are worried about Turkish people being targeted. This is very much a concern for us, and all our local brigades have been informed of the threat. We will monitor English fans and try to avoid them meeting Turkish people.'

Euro 2000 security chiefs admit the sizeable Turkish populations in both countries, and the dozens of predominantly Turkish areas, could make policing difficult. They fear a skirmish between a handful of hooligans and Turks could quickly escalate into a large-scale riot.

The readiness of young Turks to respond to aggression, and the high number who carry knives, worries authorities. Both Leeds fans were stabbed to death, and several Arsenal fans were knifed in Copenhagen last month. The violence flared as the English teams were playing Turkish side Galatasary.

Young Turks in Holland and Belgium have pledged to defend themselves, their shops and their homes if attacked. But German, Dutch and Belgian hooligans have indicated they might help English thugs carry out assaults.

Belgian police fear that a pan-European racist alliance plans to provoke major unrest in Brussels on 19 June, when Turkey plays Belgium at the stadium where 39 Juventus fans died in 1985, when Liverpool supporters attacked the Italian fans.

Police have established that neo-Nazi Belgian hooligans have been in contact with English thugs by telephone and the internet offering to join forces. Last month several people were stabbed when racist followers of Belgian side Antwerp ran amok in a Turkish area after a game. Some Dutch hooligans have also pledged to attack Turks in Amsterdam.

Hooligan websites across Europe are full of anti-Turkish threats and abuse. The Hooligans Forum, an English site, sums up the mood: 'For all the Turks out there, fuck you and Ataturk. Bring those body-bags we sent you for the earthquake to Euro 2000, you'll need them. And as for everyone not Turkish, UNITE!'

Hardcore elements who follow England abroad believe the almost invincible aura gained by English fans after decades of causing trouble around Europe is at risk after two successive 'defeats' by Turkish opponents.

Another English thug wrote in The Hooligans Forum: 'Wigan, Everton, Stoke, Chelsea, Millwall, Burnley are all taking big squads. Let's make each other known and unite and kill the Turk bastards.'

The nightmare scenario for Euro 2000 organisers is an England versus Turkey match. If both qualify from their groups they could meet in a potentially explosive quarter-final on 24 June.

The authorities' plan to use stewards rather than police inside the eight stadiums hosting Euro 2000 games could also backfire. Commander Biot said: 'We call it "soft policing". The idea is not to strike an aggressive pose to fans.'

webTitle: Leaders of the Swinging Sixties reveal their long-held secrets

fields.headline: Leaders of the Swinging Sixties reveal their long-held secrets
fields.standfirst: They wanted to change the world - with the help of music, sex and drugs
fields.trailText: She's now the feminist academic who spends more time gardening than protesting. He's an ageing disc jockey who brings Saturday-morning listeners a celebration of modern family life. But back in the Sixties Germaine Greer forced John Peel into a fling that he regretted.
fields.body:
She's now the feminist academic who spends more time gardening than protesting. He's an ageing disc jockey who brings Saturday-morning listeners a celebration of modern family life. But back in the Sixties Germaine Greer forced John Peel into a fling that he regretted.

The secrets emerge tonight in the new BBC series My Generation in which religious programme presenter Joan Bakewell prompts frank confessions from her contemporaries about their memories of the Sixties.

Peel tells Bakewell how he had a fling with Greer, claiming that she seduced him.

Speaking for the first time on television about the affair, Peel says: 'All I thought about was getting my end away. Germaine taught me a valuable lesson. She was a friend, somebody who I liked and admired and then she decided to presume on friendship and push it a step too far. I actually found myself saying: "Look, I like you too much. I don't want to do this." And she just made me, really. I thought: "Oh shit, that's what it's like".'

Both Peel and Greer declined to comment further about the programme.

Bakewell admits to having had affairs and smoking marijuana herself, but told The Observer she was surprised by some of the frank recollections, including Peel's. 'When it came up, I thought: "We can't transmit that." But the editor said it makes a very positive point. Women didn't come on in those days. When Germaine did, it was a shock to John. It showed him how women might feel when men did it to them.'

The interviews reveal Bakewell's contemporaries - who came to be seen as the country's new, media-based establishment - as a group of people, intent on pushing back political and social barriers, fuelled by a potent mixture of alcohol and sex. The largely Oxbridge-educated media stars stretched to the limit the laws of the day, particularly those on divorce.

Novelist Beryl Bainbridge got a divorce by paying a woman to sleep with her husband, Austin Davies, at a party where the soon-to-be famous Beatles played. This was, she said, common practice pre-1969.

Bainbridge recalls: 'It was all arranged. I took the children up the road, with a cot. There was a girl who, for a certain sum of money, put herself forward as co-respondent and that went down on my divorce petition.'

In My Generation , Bakewell discusses with jazz singer George Melly their open marriages at the time they were presenting the BBC talk show Late Night Line-Up. 'I knew George and Diana [then his wife] and I sort of knew George wouldn't mind talking about it,' Bakewell said.

In the programme, Melly says: 'One was with one's partner for a certain number of years during which one loved her very much and then inevitably the sex thing dies away and in some cases we had open marriages. We had affairs. The others knew about it. But we didn't break our marriage. We simply stretched the elastic.'

Literary biographer Claire Tomalin claims 'slightly mixed feelings' about the decade of free love. 'My marriage simply foundered on all the fun that was happening in London, as it were. The fun was largely happening for Nick [her husband] and I was in fact bringing up small children.'

Free love and free-flowing alcohol were central memories of heavy-duty partying for comedian Barry Humphries. Appearing on Late Night Line-Up was, he said, a famous route to regular drinking sessions. The BBC hospitality room became a byword for excess. Bakewell recalls Melly dancing naked. 'Quite likely,' Melly ruminates. 'It wasn't aesthetically pleasing. It was because I was drunk.'

Bakewell said the point of the programme was to show how the Sixties laid the foundations of civilised society. 'Nobody would go back to the days of hanging, or criminalising homosexuality, or backstreet abortions.'

She said that making it brought home to her that the political consciousness so vivid in her generation, particularly about nuclear weapons, has petered out. 'We were all absolutely terrified by the Cuba crisis. I really expected to be dead by the end of the day. I was waiting for a blinding white flash.'

But her contemporaries confess that, despite their fear, the ban-the-bomb marches were often glorified picnics. Theatre director Jonathan Miller says: 'I'm not sure that I cared that much. It was a tremendously convivial get-together. You met all your friends in duffel coats in Trafalgar Square and had a jolly good royster.'

After one march, Melly was carted off to Acton jail for a night, which he whiled away playing charades with a fellow inmate, the young actress Vanessa Redgrave.

But principles went only so far: Bakewell said women she interviewed, such as child psychologist Penelope Leach and novelist Margaret Drabble, remember spending much of the decade bringing up their small children.

Bakewell insisted that the programme, made under the auspices of the BBC's religious department, aims to show how the liberal Left ideas of the Sixties gave way to the rise of the Right.

She and her contemporaries admit that the 'drug-raddled' Seventies took things beyond their comprehension. Film censor James Ferman said: 'It was when the freedoms went wrong.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Police seize £11m cannabis
fields.body:
Police seize £11m cannabis

Three men and a woman were being questioned after nearly three tonnes of cannabis with a potential street value of £11 million was seized at a smallholding north of Bracknell, Berks. Police also recovered just under £1m in cash.

Clearwater Estates

In early editions last week a caption in an article on property tycoon Graham King of Clearsprings Management (Ltd) incorrectly identified his offices as those of Clearwater. Clearwater Estates is a specialist leisure, retail and restaurant property company and has no connection with Clearsprings. We apologise for this error, which was corrected in later editions.

King of the castle

Michael Morpurgo has won the Child-ren's Book Award for his adventure story Kensuke's Kingdom.

Show us your teats

Because of falling milk prices, dairy farmers Peter and Julie White of Pentridge, Dorset, are selling exotic lingerie over the internet.

Police search uncovers body

Police searching for Lynsey Quy, 21, who disappeared from her Southport home in 1998, have found a body at Birkdale Village. Her husband Mitchell, 25, was charged with her murder on Friday and yesterday his brother Elliott Quy was remanded in custody on charges of helping to dispose of the body.

Former Busby babe dies

Shay Brennan, former Irish soccer captain and Busby babe, has died, aged 63. The son of an Irishwoman, he was the first English-born player to be picked for the Irish Republic and was capped 19 times. A member of the 1968 Manchester United team which won the European Cup, he later managed Waterford.

Fans hurt in comic's show

Police in Birmingham questioned comedian Roy 'Chubby' Brown after fans were injured when he smashed a glass during his show.

Dome sermon

Churches are celebrating the millennium in more than 200 events. The Archbishop of Westminster's sermon from the Dome will be broadcast on Radio 4 at 8.07am.

fields.headline: Major shake-up for state schools
fields.standfirst: Overhaul of comprehensives will send pupils to specialist sites for lessons
fields.trailText: Overhaul of comprehensives will send pupils to specialist sites for lessons
fields.body:
Children will no longer attend a single secondary school from the age of 11 and the traditional school day will be scrapped, in a radical overhaul of the English school system designed to attract middle-class parents back into the state system.

The planned changes, being prepared by Downing Street and a new Policy and Innovation Division within the Department for Education and Employment, will effectively consign the comprehensive system - the great egalitarian dream of the Sixties - to history.

A senior DfEE adviser involved in drawing up the plans told The Observer: 'The idea that one school can provide for the needs of 1,000 inner-city children is just bonkers.'

The centrepiece of the new plan will be the break-up of the traditional comprehensive, designed to teach children of all abilities under the same roof, and changes will be implemented in schools as early as September.

Schools will be encouraged to specialise and children will take lessons in different institutions, receiving expert coaching in languages, music and advanced mathematics - in some cases from teachers in the private sector. Secondary schools will end the 9am-3.30pm routine to adapt to the changes, with many adopting the Continental system of an earlier start and finish to allow for sporting and cultural activities.

As part of the plans, Education Secretary David Blunkett will next month officially launch the City Academies: inner-city centres of academic excellence to be jointly run and funded by private business, charities or churches and the Department for Education and Employment.

But Graham Lane, education adviser to the Local Government Association, responded furiously last night: 'It's the most dangerous proposal to come out of this Government. This is the dismantling of comprehensive education. Private industry is working with the churches and the Government to destroy local accountability.'

The new 'independent' state schools, established where schools have been designated as failures by inspectors, will operate outside the control of local authorities and will blur the divide between state and independent schools.

Boots the Chemist and Reg Vardy, the north-east car dealer, are already involved in plans to set up new schools, which will be allowed to select 10 per cent of pupils. Critics believe it will lead to the establishment of 'a grammar school in every town' - John Major's big idea.

A spokeswoman for the National Union of Teachers said: 'There is no reason to attack the comprehensive system, which develops every pupil without pretending they can be put into pigeon holes early in their lives.'

A manifesto pledge on secondary schools will replace the pledge on primary schools used in the 1997 election campaign. Labour will promise to raise the numbers of teachers, classroom assistants and mentors for 11-14 year-olds. Ministers are known to be concerned that standards of literacy and numeracy drop in the early years of secondary school, especially among boys.

As part of the package, the DfEE will introduce a series of measures during the next academic year, including:

 Special lessons for children who failed to reach the required standard in literacy and numeracy at 11.

 All 11-year-olds to reach this level in the next decade - at present the target is 80 per cent by 2002.

 Each child to have his or her own set of targets to reach by the age of 14.

 Extension of the literacy and numeracy hour into secondary schools.

 Introduction of a 'science hour' under strict guidance from Whitehall.

Education Secretary David Blunkett said the reform of primary schools had led to a serious problem when children transferred at 11. 'Too many secondary schools are organised to deal with children coming from primary schools as they used to be,' he said.

webTitle: Downing Street rolls out pro-European big guns

fields.headline: Downing Street rolls out pro-European big guns
fields.standfirst: Hague pounds the streets
fields.trailText: Foreign Secretary Robin Cook will this week set the single currency bandwagon rolling again amid signs that Downing Street is finally unleashing its pro-Europeans.
fields.body:
Foreign Secretary Robin Cook will this week set the single currency bandwagon rolling again amid signs that Downing Street is finally unleashing its pro-Europeans.

The rallying of the euro on the currency markets, plus Treasury figures suggesting that Britain is starting to converge with euroland, have helped to persuade Tony Blair that sympathisers can stick their necks out.

Three heavyweight pro-Europeans will join the debate this week, following Trade Secretary Stephen Byers's declaration that Britain had to put the case for joining, in an apparently concerted effort to balance William Hague's snowballing 'Save the Pound' campaign. The Tory leader insisted yesterday that 'the vast majority' of the country was rallying behind his Eurosceptic banner, and taunted Blair for not coming off the fence.

The Foreign Secretary is expected to use a debate on Europe in the Commons on Thursday to talk up the case for the euro, following a little-noticed warning to MPs earlier this week of the dangers of being left behind. He told the Foreign Affairs Select Committee last week that with Greece joining the euro and Denmark and Sweden both moving towards it, 'plainly a consideration for the British debate is the extent to which the balance of forces shifts further every time somebody else joins... the longer the euro continues and achieves stability and soundness, the greater the arguments tip in favour of Britain eventually becoming a member'.

The pressure group Britain in Europe, quietly egged on by Downing Street, will launch a pamphlet by leading economists tomorrow arguing the case for joining, followed by a speech from the former Tory Chancellor Kenneth Clarke warning of the perils for business of staying out.

Engineering union leader Sir Ken Jackson, a close ally of Blair, will pick up the same theme in a keynote speech in Blackpool.

Government insiders trace the shift back to Blair's public declaration in the wake of the Dagenham redundancies that the pound was too strong. One source said there was a clear change of gear: 'Britain in Europe certainly feel that No 10 is giving them a much freer rein to step up the case for the euro, and then there is the way they clearly authorised Stephen [Byers] to say what he did. Possibly people feel the climate is more favourable.'

Another insider said the changing fortunes of the euro and the damage caused to manufacturing by the high pound had been the turning points.

Meanwhile, it emerged that John Major's former constituency, Huntingdon, has selected a right-wing Eurosceptic, Jonathon Djanogly, to succeed him. Djanogly has close links to the arch-Thatcherite group Conservative Way Forward.

fields.headline: More courage, more conviction
fields.standfirst:
New Labour must be bloody-minded
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It has not been New Labour's year. If the trends continue, some mutter, the Tories could even mount an effective challenge at the general election. The days of effortless superiority are over.
fields.body:
It has not been New Labour's year. From the debacle of the Millennium Dome opening to Mr Blair's experience before the Women's Institute, it has been a series of mishaps and PR disasters, intermingled with a poor performance in local elections and some below-the-belt strikes from William Hague. If the trends continue, some mutter, the Tories could even mount an effective challenge at the general election. The days of effortless superiority are over.

What should the Government do? There is little doubt that the Prime Minister will want to continue to make overtures to the Centre and the Right while offering the liberal Left just enough to keep it on board. The conservatism of the British electorate cannot be underestimated, he will argue. It was only by becoming New Labour that Labour won in 1997. It must accelerate its progress to becoming all things to all men.

This is where his problem lies. The Government complains that any political project defines itself by its opponents, and that the weakness of Tory opposition has paradoxically hindered the Government. This is only a fraction of the story. The Government lacks definition because lack of definition is what New Labour is all about - a project that wants simultaneously to be Right and Left, which even the WI can now see through.

This is New Labour's dangerous conceit. It believes only New Labour could have won in 1997, and that what the nation wanted was broadly conservative social and economic policies but executed more kindly and more competently and with less prejudice. Wrong and wrong again. Labour under either Kinnock and Smith would have won, perhaps with smaller majorities, because the country wanted a new emphasis. It wanted better quality public services, more justice and the closing of social wounds opened up by inequality. It wanted more transparent and less corrupt government. It wanted a reassertion of tolerance and fairness, while keeping the gains of a more dynamic capitalist economy.

But here is the irony. This is the direction in which this surprisingly competent Government is moving, albeit too slowly for it and the country's good and which it refuses to acknowledge in its rhetoric. It continues to genuflect before Conservative totems, to present and even adopt some policies as quasi-Conservative. Yet by hedging its bets on issues of social equality, justice and fairness, while asserting its business friendly credentials and hostility to liberalism, it makes two fatal mistakes. It does not begin to win the political argument that will justify what it is doing covertly and which it should be doing openly, and it seems to have no political momentum. When William Hague says it is lost in blather and guff, he hits home.

New Labour should argue openly and unapologetically for a progressive agenda. Part of this is to carry through the reforms and higher public spending it has begun; and part is to start to be braver. For example, it does not need to be so business friendly that it allows its economic policies to be run by business lobby groups; it can assert the case for corporations to accept social responsibility and behave more as citizens rather than as simple profit maximisers. It can insist that along with being tough on crime it also believes in rehabilitating offenders. It can argue that rigour on sending home economic migrants posing as asylum seekers can co-exist with treating genuine asylum seekers properly. In short it can become the modern progressive Government it says it wants to be.

Liberal Britain can help it. It was outrageous that so few backed the Chancellor over the Spence affair; two thirds of candidates with three straight As come from comprehensives, yet gain less than half the places at our leading universities - a prejudice that should be remedied. We can hardly expect New Labour to move to the Left if it is unsupported when it tries, whatever the presentational inadequacies of the case or Labour's former feebleness on the issue.

What is required, in short, is some progressive leadership around a remade coalition of the Centre and Centre Left - and a dropping of windy big tent rhetoric and the attempt to steal Conservative policies. Mr Blair and Mr Brown are more than capable of moving in this direction. They have run an efficient government and made none of the spending and economic mistakes of their Labour predecessors. Now they must show both their party and the country that they are made of genuine progressive steel. No more gifts to Mr Hague.

fields.headline: Fury at police DNA database
fields.standfirst: Samples from innocent suspects are kept illegally on computer
fields.trailText: Police are building up a vast computer database of DNA samples held illegally, sparking fury among civil liberties campaigners.
fields.body:
Police are building up a vast computer database of DNA samples held illegally, sparking fury among civil liberties campaigners.

Sources within the Forensic Science Service (FSS), which manages the DNA database for the police, have told The Observer there are 'thousands' of samples illegally held.

Police forces now routinely take DNA samples along with fingerprints from anybody charged with an offence. But under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act, if charges are dropped or the person is acquitted, the DNA sample must be destroyed.

Last month the Court of Appeal ruled that two men accused of rape and murder could not be convicted, despite 'compelling' evidence, because DNA samples held illegally by the police should have been destroyed.

Sources within the FSS - who are not prepared to be named for fear of losing their jobs - said there is real concern that, unless steps are taken to 'clean up' the database, then many other prosecution cases could falter on similar grounds.

Unpublished figures from the FSS, obtained by The Observer, appear to confirm that the process of removing DNA samples when a person is acquitted or no longer facing charges is not operating effectively. While there has been a dramatic rise in the number of samples being put on the database by the police, there has been a sharp fall in those being taken off.

Last year the police put 174,000 DNA samples on their computer - a rise of some 20 per cent. But the number of samples coming off fell by 40 per cent to 15,000. There are now over 775,000 DNA samples on the computer database in Birmingham.

Sources at the FSS said: 'It is up to each police force to tell us when to take a DNA sample off the database. But some forces are better than others and, to be honest, some haven't got a clue. There must be hundreds, if not thousands, of samples on the computer that should have been taken off by now. Many of us are worried that, if something is not done, then more criminals will escape prosecution.'

Chief Constable Bill Gunn, head of the Association of Chief Police Officers' forensic division, admitted he was concerned. He said: 'There is absolutely no excuse for police forces not to inform the FSS as soon as possible that a DNA sample should be removed. The law is perfectly clear. But like in other areas human error and human failings creep in and it may be that sometimes the samples are not taken off the database as quickly as they should be.'

The revelations have prompted civil liberty groups to consider legal action against the police. John Wadham, director of Liberty, said: 'Innocent people should not have their DNA on some police database. It is an infringement of their privacy and it is clearly unlawful. These revelations confirm our suspicions of the way information is collected by the police. We will seek to challenge this in the High Court and, if necessary, in the European Court.'

The alleged rapist whose case was thrown out by the Court of Appeal last month had his DNA taken when he was arrested for a burglary in January 1998. He was later acquitted and his DNA sample should have been removed from the database.

He was then arrested when a DNA sample, taken from a 66-year old woman who had been raped at her home in London, matched his sample that was left on the police database.

A Home Office spokesman said: 'We are carefully considering the implications of these cases in consultation with the FSS and ACPO to determine, what if any, steps need to be taken to improve the current system.'

webTitle: Spies posing as patients to test the NHS

fields.headline: Spies posing as patients to test the NHS
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Government spies will pose as patients or relatives as part of a new review of the standard of care given by hospitals.
fields.body:
Government spies will pose as patients or relatives as part of a new review of the standard of care given by hospitals. The new hospital inspectorate - the Commission for Health Improvement - sees 'mystery shoppers' as essential to find out how patients are really treated.

CHI - which Tony Blair dubbed 'Ofsted for hospitals' - will review every NHS hospital, health authority and GP group every four years, rooting out poor performance and encouraging what is considered best practice. A review team will investigate all aspects of each hospital's performance.

However, CHI is concerned that hospitals will conceal the true picture of what goes on. The Observer has learnt that, as a result, CHI has decided that reviews of hospitals will include sending anonymous inspectors into both accident and emergency and outpatient clinics. The inspectors may pose as a friend or relative of the patient, or in certain clinics, as patients themselves.

CHI officials believe A&E departments are so busy that staff will not become suspicious of the inspectors. In an orthopaedic clinic, for example, the nurses are unlikely to become suspicious of an inspector on crutches since they would be indistinguishable from someone with a real broken leg.

'Mystery shopping is the only way to get a true picture of what is going on,' said a senior official at CHI. Last week CHI announced its first reviews, of Bangor, Southampton University, Sunderland City and Chesterfield and North Derbyshire Royal hospitals. Peter Homa, the director of CHI, said: 'The patient's experience will be fundamental, because it is one of the key tests of how well the NHS is working. In effect, CHI will hold up a mirror in front of the NHS, so that it can see itself as the public sees it.'

CHI will not be the first public body to use the mystery shopper technique to identify the true public experience of a service. The Metropolitan Police uses the technique to investigate racism amongst its officers. The new Financial Services Authority is also set to use mystery shoppers as part of their investigations of the sales techniques used by mortgage lenders and pension companies. Certain health managers have already used the technique themselves. One newly appointed hospital chief executive arrived for his first day at work in a wheelchair to see how he was treated. Nobody recognised him and he was appalled by what he found. Another hospital boss spent a few days before he took up his post riding in the lifts to hear what staff were really talking about and find out what was really going on.

Nigel Edwards, of the NHS Confederation, which represents hospital managers, welcomed the idea of widespread and regular use of mystery shoppers: 'As long as it doesn't waste the time of staff, I don't have a problem with it. We should adopt as many methods of inspection as possible.'

Certain health managers have already used the technique themselves. One newly appointed hospital chief executive arrived for his first day at work in a wheelchair to see how he was treated. Nobody recognised him and he was appalled by what he found. Another hospital boss spent a few days before he took up his post riding in the lifts to hear what staff were really talking about and find out what was really going on. Nigel Edwards, of the NHS Confederation, which represents hospital managers, welcomed the idea of widespread and regular use of mystery shoppers: 'As long as it doesn't waste the time of staff, I don't have a problem with it. We should adopt as many methods of inspection as possible.'

webTitle: Byers to block big pay-outs to failed bosses

fields.headline: Byers to block big pay-outs to failed bosses
fields.trailText: Shareholders are to be given new powers to block huge pay-outs to executives leaving a company as part of a sweeping government attack on the culture of so-called 'fat cat' bosses.
fields.body:
Shareholders are to be given new powers to block huge pay-outs to executives leaving a company as part of a sweeping government attack on the culture of so-called 'fat cat' bosses.

Stephen Byers, the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, will this summer announce new legislation as part of an overhaul of company law enabling shareholders to inspect and reject the amount of money that boards pay to those leaving a company. He also wants to see greater transparency in annual reports, so that the public are clear on who is getting paid what.

The news comes two days after the controversy over the pay-out for Bob Ayling, the former chief executive of British Airways.

The airline's annual report revealed last week that his golden handshake would be worth nearly £2 million, despite criticism about BA's performance under his control. He will also get a pension of £260,000 a year.

'BA are allowing their former chief executive to fly away with this huge amount,' said John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union. 'We have had fat cats, now we have a fat bird.' BA pointed out that Ayling's package was 'compensation for loss of office'.

Speaking to The Observer before news of Ayling's huge pay-out emerged, Byers said that it was time to stop large golden handshakes unless the company's performance warranted it.

'There has been widespread support for action to tackle the issue of rewards for failure - a big pay-out when you have been sacked for doing badly,' he said.

'High rewards for failure run counter to our recognition that top salaries need to be for high-class performance.'

The DTI launched a review of fat-cat salaries last year after concerns were raised that pay for senior executives was outstripping inflation. A recent survey revealed that the heads of Britain's biggest companies enjoyed salary increases of 30 per cent last year, six times the growth in average earnings and more than 13 times the rate of inflation.

The research revealed that the gap between the salaries of top managers and the pay of ordinary workers was the highest it had been since the Eighties.

Although DTI officials stressed that they did not have a problem with high-class managers receiving large salaries, they said they were planning more action on unreasonably high directors' pay.

The Government wants to strengthen the role of shareholders, who will be given greater powers of scrutiny over boardroom pay. At the moment company annual reports, which contain limited details of boardroom pay, are usually submitted to shareholders after the deadline for putting down anti-pay proposals at the annual general meeting.

Byers is aware that action on super-salaries is likely to play well with Labour supporters. Sir Michael Angus, the chairman of Whitbread, has written to Byers warning that directors' salaries are in danger of spiralling out of control.

The company secretary of the bus firm, Stagecoach, also criticised fat-cat pay. Derek Scott admitted that companies failed to disclose full details of remuneration packages, which were 'beyond the ken' of many actuaries.

fields.headline: TV allies go on warfooting
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Broadcasters are on a war footing ahead of the Euro 2000 championships. Reporters are being given body armour and training on how to avoid getting caught up in violence.
fields.body:
Broadcasters are on a war footing ahead of the Euro 2000 championships. Reporters are being given body armour and training on how to avoid getting caught up in violence.

In an unprecedented move, the BBC and Sky have agreed to co-operate if trouble starts.

Richard Sambrook, deputy director of BBC News, said: 'We do not want minor scuffles to become a "British thugs on the rampage" story just because we do not have enough time to assess a story in the rush to be the first to get it on air. We will relax competitive pressures and discuss stories with Sky News before going on air to make sure we all make the right decisions and cover any violence responsibly.'

webTitle: 'Ethical' Britain invites military dictator to shop here for arms

fields.headline: 'Ethical' Britain invites military dictator to shop here for arms
fields.trailText: Officials from dozens of the world's most repressive regimes have been invited by the Government to view and buy high-powered military equipment at Farnborough Air Show next month
fields.body:
Officials from dozens of the world's most repressive regimes have been invited by the Government to view and buy high-powered military equipment at Farnborough Air Show next month. Many will have a significant proportion of the expenses of their trip paid by taxpayers through the UK Defence Export Sales Organisation.

On the list to attend the show in Hampshire are Indonesia and Pakistan. The armed forces in both countries have been harshly criticised by the Foreign Office. Human rights campaigners argue that government invitations like these make a 'mockery' of its so-called ethical foreign policy.

The international community imposed an arms embargo on Indonesia last September after its army was involved in atrocities committed in East Timor. Although Britain lifted its own arms embargo last January, the US refuses to sell military equipment until those who committed war crimes are brought to justice.

British Aerospace, which sold Indonesia Hawk jets that were used in East Timor, will be exhibiting at the show. It is supplying planes to the recently appointed Prime Minister B.J. Habibie.

Chandra Yudha, a spokesman for the Indonesian High Commission in London, said: 'We are really keen to be there because [it] will provide a really good opportunity for Indonesian interests.'

The invitation to Pakistan will also spark a row. The country, which has nuclear weapons, is ruled by an autocratic military regime, led by General Pervez Musharraf, after a coup last October. The coup provoked Commonwealth sanctions and harsh condemnation from Britain.

A spokesman for the Pakistani High Commission in London confirmed last week that it had an invitation to the show and said that a representative of the Chief of Air Staff, Pervaiz Qureshi Mehdi, would be attending. The new invitation to Islamabad is likely to spark a fresh row.

A number of Middle Eastern regimes will be receiving invitations. Nassr al-Farsi, the military attaché of Kuwait, will be at the show, an embassy spokesman said. Saudi Arabia will also be invited. Both countries have poor human rights records.

'Shows like this are the shop window of the repression trade,' said a spokesperson for Amnesty International. 'Given the countries invited, there are grave concerns that equipment will be used for internal repression.'

Other exhibitors at the show include GKN, which manufactures military helicopters, and Hunting Engineering, a maker of cluster bombs. Other exhibitors at the show, which starts on 24 July, include firms linked to the production of tear gas and riot control equipment.

Even senior military figures involved in procurement have expressed discontent. 'We just need to know where we stand. Either we have an ethical policy or we don't,' said one senior officer.

Last September the Government was lambasted by campaigners for staging one of the world's largest arms shows in Surrey.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Defence said: 'It is perfectly normal to offer hospitality at a major international defence exhibition.

'But any contracts signed or exports agreed will be subject to regulations on defence exports. The [invitation] list is being drawn up taking account of current marketing campaigns, longer-term prospects for business... political issues, arms embargoes and international relations.'

fields.headline: National parks 'designed for townies'
fields.standfirst:
Legislation being rushed through to protect Loch Lomond will damage our communities, say Highland campaigners

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Concern is growing that Scotland's new national parks will be less democratic than their English equivalents and may pit new 'green lairds' against local interests across the Highlands.
fields.body:
Concern is growing that Scotland's new national parks will be less democratic than their English equivalents and may pit new 'green lairds' against local interests across the Highlands.

National parks with strict planning controls were set up in England in 1945, but moves to establish them in Scotland failed because of the power of the land-owning lobby.

Increased mobility has brought vast tracts of Scotland within easy reach of the urban masses, while devolution has brought the need to control and contain pressures on the environment, particularly around Loch Lomond, the Trossachs and the Cairngorms, to the top of the political agenda.

But it is feared that the bill to set up national parks, now going through the Scottish parliament, will please only 'townies with knapsacks'. The Executive is accused of rushing through legislation which is establishing general principles to cover widely varying situations. Campaigners believe that solutions designed for Loch Lomond and the Trossachs could wreak havoc in the Cairngorms and other parts of the Highlands.

As the bill began its second stage in Holyrood last week, it became clear Highland campaigners are far from happy. At issue is the accountability of the park authorities. The rural affairs committee wants to ensure the national parks allow freedom for economic development, while the transport and environment committee wants the parks to make the environment its priority. Opposition MSPs and local campaigners fear they won't have time to improve the legislation as the executive has allowed only a few weeks for amendments before it enters its third stage and becomes law.

The bill sets out general principles and each park will come into existence through its own designation order. This approach is working smoothly for Loch Lomond and the Trossachs, set to be the first park. The area is within an hour's drive of most of the central belt and the hope is that park status will protect it from over-use.

Argyll and Bute, Stirling, and West Dunbartonshire councils are all in agreement that the park authority should be composed of 10 representatives nominated by the executive and 10 councillors. The councils are happy that the authority will assume planning control for the area and an interim committee has already been set up to shadow planning decisions.

Things can't move fast enough for the chair of the interim committee, Gillies Thomson. 'We want royal assent stamped on the bill by August. There are plenty of models to draw from across the world, and so this should be straightforward,' he said.

Lloyd Austin, of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, is also happy that the 'priority is that the environment will be conserved in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs'.

It's talk like that which sends shivers of anxiety down Highland campaigners' spines. For them the Executive's rush to have the legislation completed by the summer, so they can add it to their list of 'delivered' policies, is preventing proper scrutiny. 'Pre-legislative scrutiny was trumpeted as one of Holyrood's assets over Westminster, but this rushed timescale has made it impossible,' said David Green, the head of Highland Council.

The concern in the Highlands is that if there is not greater local representation on the park authorities, then 'people like the RSPB will be telling us what to do. That's the trouble with this bill, it's designed to meet the concerns of townies with knapsacks, not living communities,' said one senior campaigner.

The proposed Cairngorm national park is vast, covering land in five local authorities. Highland Council is leading the effort to amend the bill. It wants four of the Executive's 10 seats on the authority to be given to community council representatives. England's environment act 1995 allows for 20 per cent of the authority to be drawn from parish councils. Campaigners say it would be ludicrous if Scottish legislation was less democratic than that south of the border.

Local authorities in the Highlands say they will not give planning control to the Cairngorm authority for fear all economic activity will be stifled by extra costs. Legislation allows for this, but it is unclear how effective a park authority can be without these powers. They are also demanding that the Executive stump up new money to pay for the park.

The anxiety is fuelled by a simple worry. If the initiative is a success it could only be time before great tracts of the Highlands and Islands are designated as parks. Wester Ross, Assynt, Glencoe, the Flow Country and Cannich have all been mentioned as potential parks. 'The demand for parks came from the central belt to protect Loch Lomond. We never asked for them, yet they could dominate life in the region,' said one senior source .

Labour MSP Andy Kerr, who chairs the transport and environment committee, says the bill allows for different solutions in different areas. David Green of Highland Council says: 'If you want different solutions, then you should legislate separately. This catch-all bill is letting the Highlands down.'

webTitle: If you need an alibi... hope the boss doesn't read this

fields.headline: If you need an alibi... hope the boss doesn't read this
fields.trailText: A confession: sometimes even the most dedicated souls find temptation irresistible. Sometimes the prospect of a day enduring the constant nasal whining of the boss fails to appeal, and the urge to beat the system with, say, a sneaky early-summer day on the golf course becomes overwhelming.
fields.body:
A confession: sometimes even the most dedicated souls find temptation irresistible. Sometimes the prospect of a day enduring the constant nasal whining of the boss fails to appeal, and the urge to beat the system with, say, a sneaky early-summer day on the golf course becomes overwhelming.

But decent excuses were in short supply last week. My superiors had become suspicious of my unfeasibly large tally of great-aunts prone to fatal accidents, and the bad back excuse had worn extremely thin. Something a bit more clever was required.

Thankfully, the renowned inventiveness of the Scots has come up with the answer: a phone and internet service to provide bogus alibis for people having illicit affairs, dodging family commitments or simply escaping the shackles of work for the day. After the pneumatic tyre, malt whisky and golf sweaters, lying looks set to provide Scotland's next major export boom.

Ace Alibi, which operates from a series of front rooms in Inverness, will underline its global leadership in the art of pulling a fast one when a new franchise goes live in Florida this week.

In the year since it launched, the company has picked up more than 1,100 clients and has enjoyed such success that Hollywood studios are now queuing up to buy the film rights. The company has rejected one major bid and is now holding out for a bigger offer.

Ace already has a franchise in operation in New Hampshire, and is considering 15 licence requests from California alone. Other interest comes from entrepreneurs with a penchant for the clandestine in Australia, New Zealand and Hong Kong, Singapore, France and Spain.

Officially, the company will not provide alibis to get people off work because they fear they could fall foul of employment contract law, especially in the American market.

But John Taylor, a former hardware store owner who founded Ace with his friend, Scott Hall, conceded there is little the company can do to stop people using the service to take a day away from the office. 'If somebody uses an invitation in that way, we are not going to know about it, so we are not in a position to stop them,' he told The Observer .

The deceits centre on a seemingly plausible, tailor-made invitation to a bogus event, usually a business seminar. The letters provide the clients with evidence of the unfortunate but inescapable need for them to be elsewhere. They include a contact telephone number, masquerading as the number for the hotel or trade fair where they are meant to be.

In fact, the numbers connect to an Ace agent, posing as a hotel receptionist, conference organiser or whoever the alibi requires. The staff will take messages or divert calls to wherever the client really is. On one recent weekend, a bogus hotel set up by Ace 'hosted' 23 different clients, all of whom were up to no good at hotels scattered across Britain.

'So far none of our clients has been caught out, but we almost had trouble when we first started operating,' said Taylor.

'We double-booked a number, so we had two clients meant to be staying in two different places using the same contact number. But we were lucky: when the phone rang we had a 50-50 chance of getting it right - and we did.'

Such elaborate skulduggery does not come cheap. The initial fee is £20. Bogus invitations cost a further £20, while for £15 Ace will provide telephone confirmation of the fake appoint ment. The phone back-up costs an extra £10 for each message taken.

Inevitably, the service has come in for criticism. The Catholic Church has led the attack, saying that 'anyone with a sense of morals would be appalled by this materialistic venture'. There has also been stiff opposition from marriage and family counselling groups.

But Ace, which says 35 per cent of its clients are women, remains unrepentant. Its website www.ace-alibi.com claims the service may actually save rather than destroy relationships: 'We realise when most people "stray" it is only short-term'.

Taylor said: 'If someone is going to lie, they will do it anyway. We don't encourage them to do it; all we do is give them a smokescreen. And we will not provide long-term cover. We believe that, if it gets to that stage, people should have the moral courage to sort themselves out.'

Maybe I should - but only after a couple of well-deserved days off work at the seaside.

webTitle: New way to get rid of varicose veins

fields.headline: New way to get rid of varicose veins
fields.trailText: Britain's six million sufferers from varicose veins are set to benefit from a revolutionary technique hailed as the biggest advance in treatment of the disease for 2,000 years.
fields.body:
They're the curse of old age. They're very ugly and just as painful, but so difficult and bloody to take out that few people dare do it. However, Britain's six million sufferers from varicose veins are set to benefit from a revolutionary technique hailed as the biggest advance in treatment of the disease for 2,000 years.

In Britain, 100,000 people undergo operations for varicose veins every year, but the number is expected to rocket as people take advantage of the new 'minimally-invasive' Trivax treatment, using fibre optic technology. It is cheaper, quicker and less painful than the old technique.

Trivax was authorised by the US government last year, but has been available there for only two months. It is undergoing clinical trials on 20 patients in the UK, and is to be launched in July. Last week it was presented to a group of British vascular surgeons, one of whom called it the biggest development since Fleming discovered penicillin.

The traditional technique for cutting out varicose veins dates back more than 2,000 years. It involves threading a wire though the vein, down the leg, attaching a hook at the other end, and stripping out the vein. But residual bits of vein are left and must be cut out blind by multiple incisions. Because the surgeon cannot see where all the bits of left-over vein are, he or she often cuts in the wrong place. The patient will then need another operation to cut out the parts left.

Trivax, developed by the medical equipment firm Smith and Nephew, involves inserting a fibre optic light below the skin, so the surgeon sees the vein through the flesh.

The time for the operation is reduced from around two hours to 40 minutes, far fewer cuts are made, and recovery is quicker. The only other treatment for varicose veins - which are caused by failed valves letting blood flow back into the leg rather than to the heart - are pressure socks, which delay progression of the disease.

The inventor of the technique, Dr Gregory Spitz, said that in the US there had been a rise in the numbers seeking treatment.
