webTitle: Dome adverts to admit it's a flop

fields.headline: Dome adverts to admit it's a flop
fields.standfirst: Rebranding is last desperate bid to lure customersThe Millennium Dome: special report
fields.trailText: In a last-ditch effort to rescue the ailing Millennium Dome, an advertising campaign is being prepared that will acknowlege what most people have known all along: the attraction is a gigantic flop.
fields.body:
It has been dubbed Mission Impossible. In a last-ditch effort to rescue the ailing Millennium Dome, an advertising campaign is being prepared that will acknowlege what most people have known all along: the attraction is a gigantic flop.

Senior figures, including Dome boss Lord Falconer, are pressing for a multimillion-pound rebranding strategy with advertisements using the 'Marmite strategy': expensive television commercials that play perversely on the idea that not everyone likes the product.

The rebranding exercise is a final attempt to get the struggling attraction back on track and make sure it hits its reduced target of 6 million visitors by the end of the year. The operators were given £3m to spend on publicity as part of the £29m handout from Lottery funds approved last month.

Under the plan the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the Dome, will dump its 'One amazing day' slogan. New commercials, being drawn up in time for the summer holidays, will admit that critics have rubbished the Dome, but argue that 85 per cent of 'real people' who visit it like it - and urge the public to go and see for themselves.

Advertising giants Saatchi & Saatchi created the initial ads for the Dome, with images of the dawn rising on a new century. But insiders now admit the campaign did not give people enough good reasons to go.

Dome insiders concede that, with no new money to revamp the contents of the Dome, rebranding is the only option left to save the attraction. The Millennium Commission, which is being consulted on the ad campaign, wants to see more hyping of specific attractions, like the central show. It also wants more travel promotions to back up the ads.

A source said: 'It is quite a difficult problem. They're having an enormous battle because the product is good, according to the people who have gone, but then you are coping with the unprecedented public relations negativity. I think that is a message that they want to get across to people - go and make up your own mind.'

Despite claims that the new campaign will be a fresh start, image-makers have dismissed the rebranding as too little, too late. PR guru Max Clifford agrees that the torrent of criticism has to be confronted, but he says that the Dome should be transformed into a giant sports theme park and the new stadium turned over to the nation as soon as possible.

Charles Wright, managing director of Wolff Olins, brand consultants, added: 'An advertising blitz will not save the Dome. The public has an impression that the product itself is flawed. If that's the case and the product is no good, then no amount of advertising will change it.

'You only have to look at the Tate Modern or the London Eye to see what the Dome is up against. They have very clear attributes and they deliver. They have a "Wow" factor.'

'When you go down to the Tate on a wet Sunday you see queues 500 yards long, with all sorts of ordinary folk joining the art lovers and tourists whom you would expect to see. The risk is that all the new advertising will be seen as window dressing. You have to say, "Why bother?".'

David Rivett, managing director of international brand consultants Design Bridge, warned that the new campaign could end up doing more harm than good. 'It is sadly a doomed endeavour that could actually end up increasing the disappointment.

'The risk with any relaunch is that you increase the hype without actually changing the product. People who are tempted to visit after seeing the new advertisements may feel let down because it promises a whole lot more but is in fact just the same old Dome.

'If it is a choice between "Come and see for yourself. It really is a nice day out. It's not perhaps as good as we said at first but it is a fun day for all the family" and "One amazing day", I would be tempted to stick with "One amazing day".'

webTitle: Vets say hunted foxes die in agony

fields.headline: Vets say hunted foxes die in agony
fields.standfirst: Home Office post-mortems refute the claims of the hunting lobby by proving blood sports inflict suffering
fields.trailText: Harrowing evidence that foxes and hares killed by dogs suffer painful deaths has dealt a blow to pro-hunt supporters who claim that blood sports are not cruel.
fields.body:
Harrowing evidence that foxes and hares killed by dogs suffer painful deaths has dealt a blow to pro-hunt supporters who claim that blood sports are not cruel.

Tomorrow the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, will announce that the Government is to table a Bill offering a range of options on the future of hunting. The pro-blood sports Countryside Alliance was hoping that the lack of evidence of cruelty would help its campaign.

But independent forensic evidence by university veterinary surgeons on foxes killed by hunts and hares caught by greyhounds during coursing show that it is extremely rare for hunted animals to be killed instantly.

Post-mortems commissioned by the Home Office inquiry into hunting - and seen by The Observer - show no evidence to support claims by hunt supporters that foxes are killed by a 'quick nip to the back of the neck' and finds that in many cases foxes are disembowelled first. Five of the 12 hares killed were pregnant, and all had their necks broken by humans after bites by greyhounds had failed to kill them.

Independent vet Professor David Morton, who heads the department of biomedical ethics at Birmingham University, has examined the post-mortems carried out by vets from Bristol and Cambridge universities. He said: 'The fact that none of the animals died instantly clearly shows that they would have suffered. But probably more important is the mental distress these animals would have suffered before they were killed or caught.'

Vets from Bristol University examined the corpses of four foxes killed by hunting. Two of the foxes were shot, having gone to ground. Although the first fox hunted in Cotswold Park near Cirencester was killed by a single bullet, the post-mortem examination found evidence of 'trauma before death'.

The second fox hunted on Salisbury Plain had to be shot twice. Having gone to ground a terrier with a radio collar was sent down, and after 25 minutes of digging the fox was found. The first shot went through the animal's shoulder and failed to kill it, so another shot was required.

But the post-mortem of the fox found it had suffered from multiple bite wounds on the face and the top of the head, damage to the right eye, and bite wounds round the throat.

In both cases where the fox was killed above ground by hounds, evidence was found of 'profound trauma'. In neither case was there major damage around the head or neck, as pro-hunt supporters claimed. The post-mortems showed the foxes had been attacked around the rib cage with the heart, lungs and stomach bitten. Morton said: 'In one case, the fox probably died from suffocation which might have taken several seconds, and in the other, where the heart was severely damaged, it looks the fox would have been attacked while upside down or on its side.'

But the post-mortems of animals killed in hare-coursing paint an even more disturbing tale of animal cruelty. The 12 post-mortems by vets of Cambridge University show that it is probable that 11 of the hares were not killed by the greyhounds despite suffering severe injuries through bites. The vets concluded that their deaths were likely to have been caused by men breaking their necks after they had been caught.

The hares' agonising deaths were revealed in The Observer in March when hidden film was taken of the premier hare-coursing event, the Waterloo Cup, attended by members of the Burns inquiry team. In some cases, men made several attempts to break the hare's neck after greyhounds fought over it.

This latest evidence of animal cruelty comes as an investigation by the International Fund for Animal Welfare revealed how the Royal Beaufort Hunt - used by Prince Charles, his sons and Princess Anne - has been breaching the rules of hunting. Hidden cameras filmed how an employee of the hunt had been rearing fox cubs for hunting. Animal rights groups want legal action to be taken against the master of the hunt, who include Captain Ian Farquhar, a close friend of Prince Charles.

webTitle: Livingstone race adviser calls for Gladiator boycott

fields.headline: Livingstone race adviser calls for Gladiator boycott
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's race adviser, Lee Jasper, has called on the British public to boycott the hit film Gladiator, following a row about the involvement of director Ridley Scott's production company in a 'racist, sexist and union-busting advertisement'.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's race adviser, Lee Jasper, has called on the British public to boycott the hit film Gladiator, following a row about the involvement of director Ridley Scott's production company in a 'racist, sexist and union-busting advertisement'.

Jasper called on the Commission for Racial Equality to launch an immediate inquiry into how Britain's racism watchdog came to be filming a television advert with the same company.

Ridley Scott Associates, the production company owned by Scott - who also directed Alien, Blade Runner and Thelma and Louise - has also fallen foul of the American Screen Actors' Guild, which describes the press advertisement as 'totally offensive and absolutely insulting not only to our members but to all women everywhere - especially African-American and elderly women'.

The advert, intended to break the SAG's strike against commercial companies which shoot advertisements, shows an elderly black South African woman naked to the waist with drooping breasts. Carrying the Scott logo, it appeared in a recent edition of the American magazine Shoot. Underneath the picture are the words: 'In South Africa this is what SAG means'. It goes on to promote a temporary South African film production office where 'they have never heard of the Screen Actors' Guild'.

A CRE spokesman said the organisation had no plans to sever its links with Scott. 'We are working with an advertising company on a TV ad which involves celebrities speaking out against racism and celebrating diversity. They have chosen to contract the filming work out to Scott and we don't have any control over third parties. We expect anyone who provides goods and services for us to be fair and not racist.' A spokeswoman for Scott in London confirmed its employees had done filming on the project.

The actors' strike, which centres on rates of pay for commercials, is backed by scores of Hollywood celebrities. The advert has incensed the union. The SAG president, William Daniels, wrote to Bruce Martin, president of Ridley Scott US: 'We feel RSA USA Inc's running of this blatantly offensive ad indicates total disregard for multicultural and sexual sensitivity.'

In a statement, Scott and his film-director brother, Tony, said: 'We knew absolutely nothing about this advertisement and are as upset, sickened and appalled by this situation as anyone else... RSA USA made a huge mistake.' A later statement said those responsible for the ad had resigned.

Jasper, race adviser at the Greater London Assembly, said: 'I think it's outrageous that the CRE should not undertake ethnic equality investigations with companies with whom it has contracts.

'I would call on the CRE commissioners to immediately launch an inquiry into why the UK's leading authority on matters of race has ended up in bed with an organisation branded as strike-busting, racist and sexist. People in Britain should respond by boycotting Gladiator .'

webTitle: No tie required: Britain ends its stuffed-shirt image

fields.headline: No tie required: Britain ends its stuffed-shirt image
fields.trailText: From Oscar Wilde to Sir John Harvey-Jones, the tie has been the ultimate symbol of sartorial respectability and power. You couldn't get into the Savoy without one, work for the Times or play for England. But now men are loosening their collars and puffing up their chests.
fields.body:
From Oscar Wilde to Sir John Harvey-Jones, the tie has been the ultimate symbol of sartorial respectability and power. You couldn't get into the Savoy without one, work for the Times or play for England. But now men are loosening their collars and puffing up their chests. The stiff white collar and Windsor knot are being replaced by a look fashion writers have dubbed 'tie die'.

Last week Tony Blair posed with his son Leo in open-necked denim, while Ken Livingstone turned up for work in his favourite cream number with the top two buttons undone. Guy Ritchie left his tie in the closet as he posed with Madonna at the premiere of her new film The Next Best Thing.

Geordie Greig, the old Etonian editor of Tatler magazine, turned up for work without even a hint of old school silk. Businessman Charles Dunstone left his jugular exposed as he announced the £2 billion flotation of his firm, Carphone Warehouse. And when the England squad flew out to Belgium to begin their campaign in Euro 2000 they left their ties in their luggage - for the first time in the history of the game.

Once a starched-collar nation, Britain is increasingly cutting formal ties with the past. Wesley Taylor, style director for Burton Menswear, who designed England's grey suits, says the players are reflecting a broad trend. 'Ties once meant power but now men of influence want to exhibit their status by not wearing neckwear. It says, "no one tells me how to dress. I am in control".'

The tie's decline has been swift and dramatic. It used to commemorate life's important milestones - weddings, christenings, funerals, and job interviews. Styles changed but it was always there. Now there are few ties on the catwalks of Milan, and this autumn Louis Vuitton will launch its first line of collarless shirts in Paris.

The loosening of Windsor knots has outraged many traditionalists. 'A tailored suit without a tie is like a Rolls-Royce without the silver winged mascot,' spluttered Tony Edwards, spokesman for the Guild of British Tie Makers. 'The England team look pathetic. Taking off your tie is as vulgar as dropping your trousers and mooning.'

webTitle: Father of the web lashes snooping Bill

fields.headline: Father of the web lashes snooping Bill
fields.trailText: Tim Berners-Lee, regarded as the father of the world wide web, has launched a blistering attack on government plans to give the security services sweeping powers to intercept emails and monitor traffic on the internet.
fields.body:
Tim Berners-Lee, regarded as the father of the world wide web, has launched a blistering attack on government plans to give the security services sweeping powers to intercept emails and monitor traffic on the internet.

The computer scientist who invented the technologies which underpin the web told The Observer that the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill would stifle the development of the internet.

He said the Bill - now going through the House of Lords - would have been thrown out 'in a second' in the US. 'It gives a government great power to abuse personal and commercial innovation.'

Once the Bill becomes law every internet service provider (ISP) in the UK will be required to install a link to the security services, whichwill then be able to monitor internet traffic. Security services will be able to find out which websites users look at, which pages they download, and which chatrooms or discussion groups they frequent.

Even more controversially, the Bill gives the Home Secretary the power to demand the surrender of keys to en-crypted data - a proposal which has been fiercely criticised by civil liberties and business organisations alike.

Other campaigners have pointed out that the Bill does not recognise the global nature of the internet and is therefore doomed to failure.

Berners-Lee believes the Bill fails to make governments accountable for their actions: 'There's very little protection. There's no recourse if your information has been pilfered by the Government, and even if it comes to light there is very little you can do.'

He is also concerned that third parties will be unable to monitor the authorities' actions: 'Is there any way the press can ever find out to what extent this is happening? Is there any independent agency which has the right to follow up every request and find out statistically to what extent some of these things were just abuses of power?'

Some commentators claim that an unregulated internet is far more dangerous than the threat of a strong-armed Government. They cite the example of David Copeland, currently being tried at the Old Bailey for causing bomb explosions in London, who allegedly found out how to make bombs on the web.

But Berners-Lee argues that you cannot shoot the messenger. 'The internet is an enabling technology. Information has always been powerful and suddenly we have a much more powerful information tool, and this poses challenges to society to use it for good rather than bad.'

His attack comes days after the Bill was attacked by the Institute of Directors. Professor Jim Norton, head of e-business policy, expressed fears that the Bill could be interpreted too broadly - giving government excessive powers and even forcing companies to move abroad.

'Is it really the intention to provide Inland Revenue or VAT inspectors or DTI company investigators with these powers?' he said. Many companies were worried, 'especially multinationals who contrast the proposed UK legislation with far more business-friendly proposals in Ireland, France, Germany and even the US.'

The Government will come under further pressure later this week when the London School of Economics releases a research paper highly critical of the Bill. The paper - commissioned by the British Chamber of Commerce - will argue that the Bill risks inflicting serious damage to both business and civil liberties.

Even more controversially, the Bill gives the Home Secretary the power to demand the surrender of keys to en-crypted data - a proposal which has been fiercely criticised by civil liberties and business organisations alike. Other campaigners have pointed out that the Bill does not recognise the global nature of the internet and is therefore doomed to failure. Berners-Lee believes the Bill fails to make governments accountable for their actions: 'There's very little protection. There's no recourse if your information has been pilfered by the Government, and even if it comes to light there is very little you can do.' He is also concerned that third parties will be unable to monitor the authorities' actions: 'Is there any way the press can ever find out to what extent this is happening? Is there any independent agency which has the right to follow up every request and find out statistically to what extent some of these things were just abuses of power?' Some commentators claim that an unregulated internet is far more dangerous than the threat of a strong-armed Government. They cite the example of David Copeland, currently being tried at the Old Bailey for causing bomb explosions in London, who allegedly found out how to make bombs on the web. But Berners-Lee argues that you cannot shoot the messenger. 'The internet is an enabling technology. Information has always been powerful and suddenly we have a much more powerful information tool, and this poses challenges to society to use it for good rather than bad.' His attack comes days after the Bill was attacked by the Institute of Directors. Professor Jim Norton, head of e-business policy, expressed fears that the Bill could be interpreted too broadly - giving government excessive powers and even forcing companies to move abroad. 'Is it really the intention to provide Inland Revenue or VAT inspectors or DTI company investigators with these powers?' he said. Many companies were worried, 'especially multinationals who contrast the proposed UK legislation with far more business-friendly proposals in Ireland, France, Germany and even the US.' The Government will come under further pressure later this week when the London School of Economics releases a research paper highly critical of the Bill. The paper - commissioned by the British Chamber of Commerce - will argue that the Bill risks inflicting serious damage to both business and civil liberties.

webTitle: Last leap for the wild salmon

fields.headline: Last leap for the wild salmon
fields.standfirst: Once, Highland rivers teemed with them. Now global warming, pollution and intensive sea farming are being blamed for the near-extinction of the king of fish
fields.trailText: Once, Highland rivers teemed with them. Now global warming, pollution and intensive sea farming are being blamed for the near-extinction of the king of fish
fields.body:
A still summer evening, and Jim Semple stood beside the stretch of river he has fished since he was a boy. For decades, this place, on one of the most beautiful rivers in the Scottish Highlands, was the epitome of abundance, the wide pool so stuffed with salmon that he and his brothers often caught more than a dozen in a day.

But last week, these memories brought as much anger as joy. 'On a night like this, the river would have been alive with fish,' Semple said. 'You would have seen them leaping out of the water in their dozens. Now look at it. Virtually nothing.'

Across Scotland, the story is the same: wild salmon, the flashing silver symbol of the nation's natural heritage, are scarce. Where there were so many that nineteenth-century mill workers demanded not to be paid in salmon more than three times a week, numbers have dropped alarmingly.

Official figures to be released this year will show that 1999 brought another all-time low, prompting the Scottish Executive last week to announce a consultation exercise on how to conserve stocks. No rivers have escaped unscathed, even the most prestigious wild salmon fisheries on the Tay, Royal Deeside and the Tweed.

But it is on rivers such as Semple's in the west Highlands where the crisis is most sorely felt. Here, some salmon populations face extinction, and it may be fast becoming too late for the 'king of fish'.

The Lochy, for example, was once the region's most productive salmon fishery, with up to 1,200 fish caught in a season. Last year, the catch was 100. In smaller rivers up and down the north-west coast, stocks have collapsed, with juvenile salmon - a key sign of future conditions - missing or extremely rare.

'I used to worry about poachers,' said Semple, who spoke on condition the name of his own river would not be revealed for fear that adverse publicity will destroy his and his fellow proprietors' hopes of selling any fishing rights this season. 'Not any more. There are so few fish now that it is not worth their effort.'

Voices of alarm come from far beyond the landed gentry traditionally associated with salmon fishing. The decline of Scotland's premier game fish has appalled environmental ists and locals as much as the angling fraternity.

There are signs it is having a devastating effect on fragile rural communities that depend on angling tourism. The crisis also highlights the parlous state of marine and river habitats in Scotland, and the global environment.

'Salmon are a very good indicator species for the state of our rivers,' said Jon Watt, a biologist with the Lochaber Fisheries Trust, a charity that covers rivers around the Fort William and Ben Nevis area. 'They need a healthy river environment, rivers that are not falling apart and rivers that provide them with enough nutrition, because they are pretty high up the food chain. People might not worry too much about salmon but all these things are important for the survival of species they do care about, like otters and kingfishers.'

It is not only the salmon that are disappearing. The sea trout, Scotland's other big migratory fish, is in equally drastic decline. Nowhere is that clearer than in Loch Maree, north of Fort William. For more than a century, the loch was renowned as the finest sea trout fishery in the world. The 10 fishing boats are owned by the Loch Maree Hotel, built in 1870 to provide accommodation for anglers, which until four years ago employed a head 'ghillie' - or Highland fishing guide - and 10 full-time ghillies.

But fishing has deteriorated so badly that by last year, the staff was down to one full-time and one part-time ghillie. This year, the full-timer has left and the part-timer has only been required four times.

Last week, the hotel should have been gearing up for the influx of anglers and the start of the sea trout season proper. But the loch was empty, as the hotel's boats floated untouched by the shore. Signs of economic decay are clear in the small towns dotted around the loch. Five self-catering holiday units have been put up for sale this season as the owners bail out.

'When the fish numbers started to go down, we thought we were having a bad year and they would recover,' said Frank Buckley, the hotel's former head ghillie. 'But things have got worse and now I think that unless something is done, people will start to move away and the communities will die.'

Mark Vincent, who bought the hotel with three partners 10 years ago, agreed. 'It has been a financial disaster. Numbers were down then but we thought if we restocked the loch and managed it well, things would recover. In fact they've gone from bad to worse.'

While it is clear salmon and sea trout are in trouble, explanations are murkier. Theories range from global warming's effect on ocean feeding grounds to Britain's massive seal population eating too many adult salmon. Pollution of spawning rivers by pesticides and erosion of river banks caused by logging and livestock grazing are also thought to contribute.

All these factors are almost certainly to blame for the decline in salmon numbers, but on the west coast, massive losses in both salmon and sea trout stocks have been blamed on fish farming. In wild fisheries elsewhere in Scotland, stock declines have been nowhere near as large as in the north-west Highlands. The region is home to Britain's intensive aquaculture industry, with about 360 farms situated in lochs along the coast. The industry claims to be worth more than the Highland beef and lamb industries combined, employing 6,000 people, 4,700 of them in the Highlands and Islands.

Intensive methods used on the farms are leading many to question whether economics alone are enough to justify their continued existence in the present form. On any single farm, up to 250,000 farmed salmon are locked in close confinement in cages and there is mounting evidence that the infestations of sea lice this causes is helping destroy wild fisheries.

The sea louse is a natural parasite and healthy migratory fish could have five or six lice on them. But in wild fisheries close to fish farms, sea trout have been found with up to 500 lice, eating the fish gradually.

Sea trout were regarded as more at risk of infestation because they frequent inshore waters close to the farms, while salmon only pass them on their way out to sea.

But new research from Norway suggests that in long, narrow fjord-like sea lochs and rivers like those in north-west Scotland, where the salmon have a long journey out to sea, they can be heavily lice-infested when they reach open water.

Evidence of the salmon farming's role in the decline of wild fish has provoked fury on the west coast, where there are calls for farms to be moved away from wild fisheries, and for farmed fish to be subject to independent inspection.

Scottish Quality Salmon, the aquaculture industry's umbrella body, insists its members are doing all they can to control infestation, and says farms are working with government and the wild fisheries' proprietors to deal with the problem.

webTitle: Hope is a luxury she can't afford

fields.headline: Hope is a luxury she can't afford
fields.standfirst: Moriom's children live on rice. Margaret makes pennies last for days. The rest of the country ignores them
fields.trailText: Like millions of Britons, Margaret will collect her benefits cheque tomorrow. The cash - £96.30 - is not much for one week, not in Newtown, north Birmingham. Not anywhere, in fact.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
Like millions of Britons, Margaret will collect her benefits cheque tomorrow. The cash - £96.30 - is not much for one week, not in Newtown, north Birmingham. Not anywhere, in fact.

Since she moved there a year ago, the council has taken to sealing off the alleyways to stem the tide of 'snatch and run' muggings. There has been a shooting every week. Each evening, at the parade of shops at the bottom of the street, the gutters are filled with litter and the local kids sit around the phone box, a little stoned and a little angry.

Margaret doesn't go to the shops very often, partly through fear, partly because she can't afford to. She shops once a week, hoping it will last until the next cheque. Last week it didn't, and she had to live on £2.18 for three days. Her two children, aged six and four, sometimes eat pizza and sausages, but mostly live on beans and toast. Last month the family sat down to eat two tins of rice pudding for dinner. There was nothing else left.

This is a story of everyday life in Britain. As the chattering class sits around its collective coffee table and argues about who should go to Oxford or Cambridge, or about whether the Women's Institute was rude when it heckled Tony Blair, a whole sector of society simply gets on with harsh lives in hidden places, rarely given the oxygen of media publicity.

This week a damning report by the children's arm of the United Nations, Unicef, will reveal the real plight of Britain and the world's poor. Leaked to The Observer, it makes sobering reading. One in six children in the rich, industrialised nations lives in poverty. In terms of relative poverty - the number of families living on less than half median earnings - Britain finds itself in the bottom four, below Turkey, Poland and Hungary. Of the 23 countries surveyed, only Italy, the US and Mexico have a worse record on poverty.

Nearly 20 per cent of Britain's children live in poverty, between three and four million people. That compares to 2.6 per cent in Sweden and 3.9 per cent in Norway, the two countries which could teach our stratified, wealth-obsessed country a thing or two about being a caring and equitable nation.

Blair has made the eradication of childhood poverty one of the key planks of his Government's term of office. He says he wants to see an end to children eating beans for tea while the damp runs off the walls. He wants childhood poverty to end 'in a generation'. It is a tall order.

The report makes much of what the Government has done in the past three years. It agrees with the claim that policies aimed at the problem - increases in child benefit, the working families tax credit, the new deal to get more poor parents into jobs - are working. To an extent. More than a million children have been lifted out of the poverty gap. But that still leaves three million too many languishing in a world of tinned rice pudding and few life chances.

Child poverty experts, such as Jonathan Bradshaw from the University of York, say that much of the problem can be tracked back to the years of Margaret Thatcher when redistribution of wealth was a swear word, not a policy.

The economics of trickle-down and rampant unemployment created an underclass against which Britain is still struggling. Bradshaw says that, despite progress, the problems run so deep that the country still finds itself in the position of the heartless man of Europe.

To tackle the problem seriously will need a huge redistribution of wealth. And that needs political guts and political action, action which critics say the Government is reluctant to undertake fully, aware as it is of the important audience of Middle England. Experts estimate that it will cost another £10 billion to heave Britain up to the position enjoyed by Sweden or Norway.

'It begs the question whether there is the political support for that,' said David Piachaud, child poverty expert at the London School of Economics. 'Can you make such fundamental changes if you continue on this policy of redistribution by stealth? At some point people are going to notice it.'

Gordon Brown, the Chancellor, will use this summer's spending review to announce further measures worth hundreds of millions of pounds. But as Brown gets up on Thursday evening to face the serried ranks of black-tied businessmen for his Mansion House speech, he will do so with the uncomfortable knowledge that each week, once Margaret has paid the bills - gas, electricity, telephone and water - her family has £25 to live on.

Margaret's youngest daughter 'celebrated' her fourth birthday yesterday. But Margaret won't be able to get to the shops to buy her anything as simple as a present until tomorrow's money rolls in. Her daughter's shoes are falling apart, and she sleeps on a mattress some friends had thrown out. Their house has no television or carpets.

Last week there was food enough in the cupboard - Margaret had budgeted carefully - but the bills she has paid means she calculates that she's already spent £4.14 of next week's money.

Theresa, a mother of three from Acomb in York, remembers the moment when she felt most hopeless, about a year ago. She and her three children had just moved into a long-awaited council house. There were no carpets, and the walls were filthy. Her son, Lewis, nine at the time, was too scared to sleep in his room, the walls defaced with graffiti and stained black from a recent house fire. He clambered into his mother's bed for comfort. Theresa found it hard to soothe him: she was just as scared herself.

Theresa's family have lived on the breadline since her husband left six years ago. In 1992 she received around £80 a week with which she had to pay her bills and feed the four of them. Now, she gets £93. Once the bills are paid, she has £45 a week to buy food and clothes. It's taken her a long time to learn how to budget it well.

'I'm allowed to earn an extra £15 a week from cleaning. I end up spending whatever's in my purse. My daughter asked me for 20p last week. I had to say no. I hope that she understands. I hate the pettiness that poverty brings - I'm always on at the kids to turn off the bathroom light, as every penny counts. This week has been particularly bad. I'm two months behind on the sewage and water bills.'

Two hundred miles away, in the shadow of London's Canary Wharf, a group of four tower blocks are known collectively as Will Crook Estate. On the top floor of Devitt House lives Moriom Begum. She is 44 and was born in Bangladesh. In 1991, her family of five moved into a two-bedroomed flat. Her son, 21, and daughter, 16, share one room, and the youngest, who is six, sleeps with her husband in their bed. The room was not even big enough for a cot.

Her husband has recently become unemployed and the family claim a Jobseekers Allowance of £179 every 14 days. From this they must pay their gas, electricity and telephone bills, which leaves them with £57 to spend on food for five each week. Moriom buys a big bag of rice at the beginning of the week to feed the family. Within 10 days, the money is exhausted, and four days pass during which they eat whatever is left. She can't afford to purchase clothes for her daughters costing more than £5.

Margaret in Newtown can see no way out. 'The council are trying to get me to go back to work at the moment,' she says. 'But it's impossible with the kind of childcare available. People don't seem to value family life any more.'

webTitle: Recycled Good Life moves out of suburbia

fields.headline: Recycled Good Life moves out of suburbia
fields.trailText: It was the television sitcom that defined a generation and a class system. Whether viewers identified with the bourgeois Margo and Jerry Leadbetter or the idealism of Tom and Barbara Good, the BBC's The Good Life came to represent a certain moment in English social history.
fields.body:
It was the television sitcom that defined a generation and a class system. Whether viewers identified with the bourgeois Margo and Jerry Leadbetter or the idealism of Tom and Barbara Good, the BBC's The Good Life came to represent a certain moment in English social history.

Now the BBC is pinning its hopes on a Good Life story for the 21st century. But this time the well-spoken actors who played the original couple - Felicity Kendall and Richard Briers - and became heroes of the dissatisfied commuter belt of the Seventies are absent.

Their new counterparts will be the more human Pauline Quirke, from Birds of a Feather, and Warren Clarke, best known for the quirky detective series Dalziel And Pascoe .

Like Tom and Barbara Good, the new leading couple will struggle with self-sufficiency after leaving their jobs in the city. Unlike Tom and Barbara, however, they must survive after their business collapses.

The six-part series, Down to Earth, has begun filming in London and in the quiet village of Cheriton Bishop, near Dartmoor in Devon.

'The series tells some fantastic stories,' said the BBC's Alan Ayres. 'In Down to Earth the couple will be based on an isolated farm, so there will be no immediate neighbours, although there will be other characters. They will also have three children.'

The show is produced by Rosemarie Whitman of Whistling Gypsy Productions, who sold the idea to the BBC. She says it will be as close to veterinary classic All Creatures Great and Small as to The Good Life.

Because the show is set in the countryside, she believes it will have a more rough and ready feeling.

'It is based on the real life of a family trying to make their living from the land,' she told a Devon newspaper last week. The first series will chart the family's move to Devon and efforts to start a smallholding growing vegetables and keeping animals.

Local actors and extras have been used in the series to ensure genuine accents.

Like Tom and Barbara Good, the new leading couple will struggle with self-sufficiency after leaving their jobs in the city. Unlike Tom and Barbara, however, they must survive after their business collapses. The six-part series, Down to Earth, has begun filming in London and in the quiet village of Cheriton Bishop, near Dartmoor in Devon. 'The series tells some fantastic stories,' said the BBC's Alan Ayres. 'In Down to Earth the couple will be based on an isolated farm, so there will be no immediate neighbours, although there will be other characters. They will also have three children.' The show is produced by Rosemarie Whitman of Whistling Gypsy Productions, who sold the idea to the BBC. She says it will be as close to veterinary classic All Creatures Great and Small as to The Good Life. Because the show is set in the countryside, she believes it will have a more rough and ready feeling. 'It is based on the real life of a family trying to make their living from the land,' she told a Devon newspaper last week. The first series will chart the family's move to Devon and efforts to start a smallholding growing vegetables and keeping animals. Local actors and extras have been used in the series to ensure genuine accents.

webTitle: Death of the toxic heroin wholesaler

fields.headline: Death of the toxic heroin wholesaler
fields.standfirst: The Irish drugs war is spilling viciously into Amsterdam's suburbs, report John Sweeney and  Henry McDonald
fields.trailText: Not a fake Rembrandt or ganja shop or coke peddler in sight. It would be hard to find anywhere more anonymous in Amsterdam than the boring brown brick-and-glass flats in Singerstraat on the wrong side of the A10 inner motorway from the city centre.
fields.body:
Not a fake Rembrandt or ganja shop or coke peddler in sight. It would be hard to find anywhere more anonymous in Amsterdam than the boring brown brick-and-glass flats in Singerstraat on the wrong side of the A10 inner motorway from the city centre.

The dullness is deceptive. Number 81 was the home of the man Ireland nicknamed 'Maradona' (real name Derek Dunne), a one-time gifted footballer, father of two and heroin wholesaler. Dunne's drug shipments from Amsterdam were on an industrial scale - he is the 'Mr Big' thought responsible for the heroin cut with toxic 'wound botulism' which has killed more than 30 hardcore junkies in Ireland, Scotland and Liverpool in the past month.

And that's not counting the deaths to come: Dunne is one of the men behind the irresistible rise of heroin in Dublin, which boasts 14,000 abusers, many of whom will die decades before their time.

Dunne lived in Amsterdam with his girlfriend, Rachel Mitchell, and her two children, aged six and two. Mitchell is the daughter of another Irish trafficker, George 'The Penguin' Mitchell. The flat may not have been up to much, but Dunne motored in style: first, top-of-the-range BMWs, followed by a series of high-powered sports cars which he appeared to change the way other men change their socks.

Then, eight days ago, Dunne's life in the fast lane came to a dead stop in the early hours of Saturday morning - an odd time for a social call on number 81. The visitors had tracked Dunne down, it is believed, thanks to a 25-year-old Liverpudlian whose hands were cuffed behind his back. The visitors had caught him somewhere else, made him an offer he couldn't refuse and he led the killers to the right address.

The door opened and another friend of Dunne's, a psychopathic thug who used to be in the Irish People's Liberation Army, tried to block their entry. The psycho is an old friend of John Gilligan, the silver-haired drug baron who was recently extradited from the UK by the Irish Gardai to stand trial for allegedly ordering the hit on Dublin crime reporter Veronica Guerin, gunned down in 1996.

Dunne came to the door and screamed at the visitors to go. Seven shots rang out. Neighbours woke up, went to the windows and started watching. 'It was like a gangster film,' said one man, who wouldn't give his name.

Superintendent Klaas Wilting of the Amsterdam police said the shooting began after Dunne shouted at the men to leave. Dunne staggered after the visitors, hit the pavement and lay there, a pool of blood widening beneath him. The handcuffed man ran after them, screaming that it was about money he owed them and that it was his fault, before he collapsed outside number 98.

The visitors ran to their car, later found abandoned on the other side of the city, in Diemerzeedyk. Last Friday the blood had been washed down the drains and all that remained of the shooting was a cracked window covered with Dutch newspapers. When The Observer called, a woman came to the door and pulled back one of the newspapers. She had brown hair, a thin, creased face and could have been beautiful once. A bloody bruise stood on her forehead. She said 'No' and then a man's voice said in a thick Dublin accent: 'Tell him to fuck off.'

Killing Irish drug traffickers is all the rage in the Netherlands these days. Only a month ago another lot of visitors paid an unwelcome call to a much more upmarket address in the seaside resort of Scheveningen, just along from The Hague.

Police were called to a fire at apartment 1058, one which burnt so viciously all the residents of the modern block of flats had to be evacuated. The Dutch police discovered three charred corpses, and first thought they were victims of an accidental fire. The pathologist's report came as something of a shock. Two of the men had been sliced up with a knife. They had been mutilated while still alive.

But the third? The pathologist found some weird stuff inside him, something he had never seen before, and sent it off to the path lab to get it analysed. According to one Dutch source, it was polystyrene cavity wall filler, the kind you inject from a big syringe into gaps in masonry. It balloons out after contact with air: shoved down a man's throat, it would cause horrible suffocation as it filled out in the lungs and down the gut. Then the visitors dragged all three into the bathroom, poured petrol over them and burnt them, dead, dying or alive.

In the flat, police found a drug trafficker's do-it-yourself kit: amphetamines and a tablet-pressing machine. They also discovered five passports: two belonging to innocent parties, the first to Vanessa Cope, 27, from Newry, Co Down; the second that of John Nunan, 27, from Fermoy, Co Cork. His was stolen two years ago.

The other three passports turned out to belong to the dead men. The police checked with the landlord. The tenant was one Damien Monaghan, 25, who had rented the two-bedroom flat last year. It cost £600 a month, not bad for the eldest of 11 children from a working-class housing estate in Cloughleigh, Co Clare.

He moved to the Netherlands when he was 19, six years ago. Monaghan lived with Vincent Costello, 29, from Bansha, near Cahir in Co Tipperary. Costello had been in the Netherlands for two years, but returned home regularly. His younger brother Morgan, 22, who worked in an abattoir at Cahir, was visiting him on a week's holiday.

The killings come at a grim time for all those in Ireland who are worried sick about the rise and rise of heroin addiction in their country. When Guerin was killed four years ago, there were around 7,000 heroin-users in her native Dublin. As Hollywood prepares to release the first film about her life and death - When The Sky Falls - the number of users has doubled.

What is all the more depressing is that Ireland now has some of the most aggressive anti-drug legislation in Europe. In the wake of Guerin's murder, the Dail passed an act creating the Criminal Assets Bureau, which gave police powers to confiscate money and assets of known criminals.

The beauty of the legislation for law-enforcers is that it switched the burden of proof. Before, the Gardai had to prove that, say, a heroin baron's house had been paid for by drug money; since the act was passed, the heroin baron has to prove that he acquired the money legally. If he cannot do so, then the house is forfeit.

But the Irish 'Mr Bigs', such as Dunne and his not-so-successful protector, 'Penguin' Mitchell, quit Dublin for Amsterdam. Dunne wasn't just on the run from the law. He had beaten a relative of another criminal, Gerry 'The Monk' Hutch, to a pulp, putting him into a coma, and was under sentence of death.

Dunne, a chastened man, later paid 'The Monk' £200,000 to have the contract annulled. ('The Monk' gets his name from his abstemious habits. He neither drinks nor smokes, and certainly doesn't take drugs.)

Out of Dublin, but not out of pocket. One law enforcement source explained the Irish traffickers were happy to place themselves in Amsterdam for four reasons: first, they could escape the Gardai; second, they were out of the way of the IRA, which has been making itself popular in the grimmest Dublin council estates by kneecapping, and sometimes killing, drug traffickers; third, they were on top of Europe's biggest wholesale market of drugs; and, fourth, they knew that there would always be a number of footsoldiers willing to move the 'gear' - heroin, Ecstasy, amphetamines - to Dublin.

Life can be tough for the footsoldiers. Patrick Murray, 19, and Darren Carey, 20, would have been paid handsomely for flying to Amsterdam to collect £30,000 worth of heroin. But they were arrested by the police last November, and the drugs seized. Prison would have been safer. The 'Mr Big' behind the deal suspected a double-cross. Murray and Carey were fished out of the Grand Canal, near Newcastle, Co Dublin, three months ago. Before they shot him, Murray had been tortured.

But, still, the money's good.

fields.headline: 'Walkman' kit predicts labour
fields.trailText: Scientists have pinpointed electrical signals that are emitted by women as they go into labour. The discovery means researchers should soon be able to design home-testing kits to tell mothers exactly when they will give birth.
fields.body:
Scientists have pinpointed electrical signals that are emitted by women as they go into labour. The discovery means researchers should soon be able to design home-testing kits to tell mothers exactly when they will give birth.

'A simple Walkman-like device strapped below a mother's waist would be enough,' said researcher Nigel Simpson of Leeds University. 'A green signal would indicate everything was fine, an amber one would show that labour will begin in a couple of weeks, and a red one provide a precise two-day warning of a baby's arrival.'

Such a device would have enormous benefits. At present, only one in 20 babies arrives on their due date. A home labour kit would remove uncertainty and let pregnant women know whether they can go on business trips, holidays or visit the mother-in-law.

The device would also help pregnant women who have had a premature baby and, therefore, are at greater risk of having another. A home labour kit would reassure them that they are not about to go into early labour, a constant fear for such women, or provide early warning that they are about to give birth, giving doctors time to intervene.

'Our system works just like an electro-cardiograph,' added Simpson. 'Just as with the heart, whose muscles contract when electrically stimulated, we can pinpoint the faint electrical signals that direct the uterus to contract as it prepares to expel the baby it is carrying.'

To do this two electrodes are taped over a woman's abdomen to detect the electricity emitted from her uterus. 'It sounds easy, but there is a mass of background electrical activity going on,' added Simpson, who has worked on the project with Professor James Walker at St James University Hospital.

'To get round those problems, we have to find ways to isolate the relatively weak signals coming from a mother's uterus while cutting out the background noise. Then we use powerful mathematical techniques to analyse patterns that we can precisely correlate with the onset of labour.'

In this way, the team were able to establish the particular electrical activity emitted by a pregnant woman as she approaches labour and isolate the signals that gave the best indication birth is about to begin.

'We are now going to hone our techniques on a larger study, and once we have done that we can begin to design the right kind of devices for exploiting this new understanding,' added Simpson.

fields.headline: Met Office charts supermarket sales
fields.trailText: We buy more buns, beer and cold cures when the weather is warm, but less cat food, toilet paper and ginger ale, according to a new study.
fields.body:
We buy more buns, beer and cold cures when the weather is warm, but less cat food, toilet paper and ginger ale, according to a new study.

Engage, a limited-access internet site launched by the Meteorological Office last week, aims to help retailers keep their finger on the pulse of consumer demand by combining long-term weather forecasts with the most detailed research ever undertaken into shoppers' whims.

The site reveals secrets such as the specific temperature at which shoppers stop swigging mineral water and start sipping tonic water (15 C) and the inexplicable taste Britons develop for lemonade around Christmas time when sales soar by more than 200 per cent.

Engage, the first programme of its kind, has already won the approval of four of the five main food retailers in Britain. Safeway, which has been working with the Met Office on the system's prototype, claims it saves the company around £3,000 a week at each outlet by letting store managers fine-tune stock levels, promotions and product placement.

'We've been using the trial system for just four months and already it's indispensable,' said Mark Aylwin, supply chain director at Safeway.

'It's only recently we've appreciated the huge impact that weather has on sales, but now our team members log on to the site every morning and base their plans entirely according to its predictions.'

Retailers pay an undisclosed sum to the Met Office for access to the site, which combines records of general and store-specific sales statistics with long-term weather records to create an instant picture of how the weather has affected the performance of each store.

The Met Office hopes the site will reduce the threat of further government cuts. Chancellor Gordon Brown ordered the closure of five weather centres earlier this year.

Trends discovered by Engage show that the public's yen for hot, buttered toast in cold weather sends sales of bread soaring in bad weather, while demand for cold and flu remedies rises during mild weather as incubating germs inflict summer colds.

Other discoveries are that sales of cat food fall in extremes of hot and cold weather while toilet paper sales increase by around 20,000 packs a month during early summer as hay-fever sufferers become afflicted by the rising pollen count.

webTitle: Diary reveals lesbian love trysts of suffragette leaders

fields.headline: Diary reveals lesbian love trysts of suffragette leaders
fields.trailText: Entries in the diary of a suffragette have revealed that key members of the Votes For Women movement led a promiscuous lesbian lifestyle.
fields.body:
Entries in the diary of a suffragette have revealed that key members of the Votes For Women movement led a promiscuous lesbian lifestyle.

The diaries of supporter Mary Blathwayt, kept from 1908 to 1913, show how complicated sexual liaisons - involving the Pankhurst family and others at the core of the militant organisation - created rivalries that threatened discord.

'Mary, who had been something of a favourite, often wrote quite bluntly about the situation. It does sound as if she was occasionally quite jealous,' said Professor Martin Pugh, an expert on the history of the movement, who came across the relevant and explicit pages in Blathwayt's little-known diary.

'This part of the diary puts the whole campaign in a truer perspective,' he added. 'All these women were under an enormous amount of pressure from around 1912, while the Home Secretary was trying to suppress their activities.'

Pugh, of Liverpool John Moores University, said the tensions felt, both physically and psychologically, meant the activists had to find sus taining relationships within their own ranks.

Emmeline Pankhurst and her three daughters, Sylvia, Christabel and Adela, were the leading figures in the battle to win votes for women. Founding the hardline Women's Social and Political Union in 1903, Mrs Pankhurst, as she was popularly known, went to prison 15 times for her political views and had a close relationship with the lesbian composer Ethel Smyth for many years following the death of her husband Richard in 1898.

'Dame Ethel had realised early on in life that she loved women not men and was fairly bold about things. They were often in Holloway together and shared a cell,' said Pugh.

Members of the union were social pariahs and the butt of music-hall jokes, but they were also criminals. Under the slogan 'Votes for Women and Chastity for Men', they bombed and set fire to churches and stations, threw bricks through windows, cut telegraph wires and tied themselves to railings.

'This was a period in which these women were carrying out something like guerrilla war - they felt they were engaging in battle with the Home Secretary, who was using all the tools of the state to oppress them,' said Pugh, who is researching a biography of the Pankhurst family.

Christabel was the most classically beautiful of the Pankhurst daughters and was the focus of a rash of 'crushes' across the movement. Pugh now believes she was briefly involved with Mary Blathwayt who, in her turn, was probably supplanted by Annie Kenney, a working-class activist from Oldham.

'Christabel was an object of desire for several suffragettes,' he said. 'She was a very striking woman.'

Many of the short-lived sexual couplings referred to in the diary took place in the Blathwayt family's Eagle House home in Batheaston, near Bath.

Kenney's frequent visits to Eagle House, and to the family's Bristol lodgings, receive most scrutiny from Mary Blathwayt. Pugh's research shows that her name can now be linked to up to 10 other suffragettes.

'Mary writes matter-of-fact lines such as, "Annie slept with someone else again last night," or "There was someone else in Annie's bed this morning," said Pugh. 'But it is all done with no moral opprobrium for the act itself.

'In the diary Kenney appears frequently and with different women. Almost day by day Mary says she is sleeping with someone else.'

Kenney, organiser for the South West, volunteered to join the suffragettes after hearing Christabel Pankhurst speak at a rally in 1905. The two were sent to prison together that year after disrupting a public meeting and had an intimate friendship for several years until Christabel became involved with another woman, Grace Roe.

While the affairs and one-night-stands at Eagle House provoked competitive rivalries, it is also clear they held the movement together. Many of the relationships provided emotional support for members of a group isolated from the rest of society.

'Biographers, while acknowledging a small lesbian element in the movement, have all skirted around the issue,' said Pugh.

'For those times the matter-of-fact tone Blathwayt adopts about the affairs did surprise me.'

The union suspended its militant activities to help the war effort in 1914 and women over 30 gained the vote in 1918. Equal suffrage was finally achieved in 1930.

'Christabel was an object of desire for several suffragettes,' he said. 'She was a very striking woman.' Many of the short-lived sexual couplings referred to in the diary took place in the Blathwayt family's Eagle House home in Batheaston, near Bath. Kenney's frequent visits to Eagle House, and to the family's Bristol lodgings, receive most scrutiny from Mary Blathwayt. Pugh's research shows that her name can now be linked to up to 10 other suffragettes. 'Mary writes matter-of-fact lines such as, "Annie slept with someone else again last night," or "There was someone else in Annie's bed this morning," said Pugh. 'But it is all done with no moral opprobrium for the act itself. 'In the diary Kenney appears frequently and with different women. Almost day by day Mary says she is sleeping with someone else.' Kenney, organiser for the South West, volunteered to join the suffragettes after hearing Christabel Pankhurst speak at a rally in 1905. It should have been a gentle return to work. But Blair's speech to the WI caught Labour on the back foot. Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff assess the damage: 'As he got up to speak to the WI, everything was rosy. Thirty-five minutes later came meltdown'
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText:
It should have been a gentle return to work. But Blair's speech to the WI caught Labour on the back foot. Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff assess the damage: 'As he got up to speak to the WI, everything was rosy. Thirty-five minutes later came meltdown'
New Labour in power: special report
fields.body:
Alastair Campbell sat alone in Downing Street and flicked on the television. The Prime Minister's official spokesman was in relaxed mood, every now and then indulging in his well-practised habit of leaning back in his chair and propping his feet on the desk.

That morning's newspapers had been full of headlines about the Prime Minister's speech to the Women's Institute. 'Blair's back with an appeal to tradition,' said the Daily Telegraph . 'Blair retreats from class war to the safety of old values,' said the Independent .

Campbell's briefing to political editors the day before was paying dividends. The Government was back leading the news agenda after a rocky few weeks during which the Conservatives had suddenly found their claws and started scratching.

On the screen in front of him - beyond the desk piled with briefing papers and along from the wall decorated with pictures by his children - Adam Boulton, political editor of Sky News, was reporting from Wembley Arena.

Blair's big speech was just about to start. As Blair got up to speak, Campbell's world looked rosy. Thirty-five minutes later came meltdown. A turning point. A moment when the Prime Minister revealed an essential lack of judgment, a failure to connect with that key sector of the voting public - the fabled Middle England. Ever since that Wednesday morning effort to show the Prime Minister's 'big tent' credentials, the day the forces of conservatism got up and slapped him around the face, the Government has been on the back foot.

The saga explains much about today's political landscape: the Government's problem with women, the New Labour message, the essential conservatism of a large chunk of British society, Blair's standing as leader, the rebirth of the Tories and the bizarre world of political spin. It is a story that stands as a picture of modern government and its relationship with the people.

It is also a story about the two leading political parties. As Labour stumbles, the Tories have had success: Tony Martin, crime, pensions and asylum - culminating in this weekend's attack on the Government's European policy.

This new mood in politics can be traced back to the first meeting of Downing Street's Strategic Communications Unit early in 1998. In the room were Siobhan Kenny, head of the unit, two special advisers - Phil Bassett and David Bradshaw - and Alan Evans, later to become John Prescott's media manager. They were there to discuss co-ordinating strategy and planning ahead. The Government needed to connect with women after concerns that their support for Labour was softer than men's.

They decided to contact the WI, the Townswomen's Guild, and a raft of women's magazines, many of which had been knocking on Downing Street's door asking for greater access.

Eileen Meadmore,the WI chairwoman, was asked if she would like to meet to discuss closer connections with the Government. Meadmore agreed.The Government saw it as a useful way of getting its message out. It was the first step to last week's disaster.

A few weeks later Siobhan Kenny, arrived at WIheadquarters with a high-powered team concerned with women's issues. .

With Meadmore, they planned a series of question and answer sessions to be published in the WI magazine, Home and Country . Prescott would do the first, followed by the Women's Minister, Tessa Jowell, and other members of the Government.

The series worked, the message was getting out. Everybody was relaxed. It was the next step to last week's disaster. Meadmore asked if Blair would consider speaking at the annual conference the following summer, 1999. Blair was too busy. How about 2000?

This would be a big event at which thousands of members would expect a major speaker. It was, surely, a better platform for Blair. Reynolds took the idea back to Campbell and Anji Hunter, Blair's diary secretary and key fixer in Downing Street. The date went into the diary. A ticking bomb.

Last Sunday night Blair's inner circle heard their home faxes whirring. As the weekend came to an end, Blair - returning from his limited paternity leave - wanted advice on his first major speech since Leo's birth.

He had written the draft in longhand at Chequers, his official country residence, before passing it to a secretary to be typed up. Blair writing a full draft himself is unusual. More often, he writes a series of key points and Campbell, Jonathan Powell, Blair's chief of staff, and David Miliband, head of the policy unit, write the actual words.

This was different. Blair had laboured for hours about the key messages and how he wanted to put them across. Opportunity for all and a respect for tradition. Perfect Blairite territory. The speech was read by the inner circle - Campbell, Powell, Sally Morgan, Blair's political secretary, Miliband and Peter Hyman of the policy unit.

Some faxed back ideas, a couple rang Blair to chat about his words. The WI's plea for a 'non-political' speech was taken to mean 'no Tory bashing'. Any references to the Conservatives were taken out. The speech had to be practical and refer to the WI's campaigns on breast cancer, Aids and domestic violence. Bassett had prepared a briefing paper for Blair on the history of the WI. The Prime Minister based the opening of his speech on Bassett's work.

It was all very calm. On Monday, at the week's key strategy meeting, Charlie Falconer, Labour peer and Blair's political confidante, saw the speech. He agreed with the fundamental message. Campbell planned his Tuesday briefing. No one saw the elephant trap.

So Campbell, in his office on his own on Wednesday morning, was left to watch with increasingly incredulity as a speech so well prepared, so well briefed, started disappearing in the slow hand-clapping and heckling. At first Campbell wasn't sure what the background noise he could hear from the television actually was. But as the cameras cut away to show the walk-out, it all became clear. Blair's face told the story.

Campbell went straight into the lobby briefing - the daily jousting match between the official spokesman and Westminster journalists - his mind made up about the line to take. He would not attack the WI directly, but put the debacle down to a few bad-mannered oppositionists.

After the briefing he admitted to friends that he had been too emollient about the WI, particularly when they suggested that it was Blair who had asked to be invited. 'That just isn't true,' he said.

Campbell hadn't even bothered travelling to Wembley. He had decided to stay at Westminster for the lobby briefing. He wanted to push the message that many more trainee teachers were taking up positions at college. The message was lost.

At Wembley, the fleet of cars ready to whisk Blair away contained a chastened set of occupants. In the front car Blair sat with Hunter. In the second car came Lucie McNeill, of his strategy team, and David Peel of the press office. McNeill had spoken with the WI director of communications about setting up interviews with 'modern looking' WI members who could give their reaction to the Blair speech. All the plans had to be abandoned. Hunter said she felt personally let down by the WI. Their rudeness had been inexcusable.

At Millbank, Phil Murphy, the deputy general secretary of the Labour Party, was on the phone to the BBC - complaining about the use of Tory polls to lead news bulletins - when Boulton's report started. Staff watched in silence as television screens revealed Blair's disaster. Many knew it had been a mistake. By tomorrow they would be in action.

Blair went into Downing Street and straight into a meeting about that afternoon's Prime Minister's Questions in the House of Commons. Campbell briefed him to expect some 'grisly headlines' the next day - but they agreed that it would be a 48-hour wonder and that he still had to get his message out. Blair decided to make a joke about the heckling during his appearance in the Commons.

By Thursday, the Government message was in a mess. The press agreed that Blair's speech had been misjudged. At that morning's nine o'clock meeting, the launch pad for the day's events, Godric Smith, Campbell's deputy, looked at a barrage of negative front pages. Lance Price, another senior press officer, was equally gloomy.

'In these situations the tone is one marked by a sort of gallows humour,' said one official at the meeting. 'You have to shrug your shoulders and get on.' They agreed that they would brief on the events of the day; the launch of a new set of Beacon Schools, the drug treatment agency, new training appointments. They knew no one would be interested, three positive stories would be lost.

Millbank was brought in to start work on trying to redirect the story. The leaders of the heckling, Marion Chilcott and Chris Short, were put through Excalibur, Labour's computer database, to see if they brought up any useful, anti-Government, connections. Neither did.

Helen Carey, who had taken over from Meadmore, was a slightly better target. Excalibur coughed up an article in the Times in November 1998. 'Carey is among those who point out that Labour selling its message to women voters is quite separate from delivering women-friendly policies,' the Times said, before quoting Carey as say ing: 'I haven't seen anything tangible coming out of this feminisation of the party.'

It would do as a starting point in the campaign to reveal the WI as a bunch of Tory blue-rinsers. Journalists were briefed about the article. Millbank also started handing out phone numbers of disgruntled WI members who had rung to tell of their dismay at the treatment of Blair. Officials decided to concentrate on the message that the WI was not, necessarily, a reflection of modern Britain.

The Mirror interview with Chilcott the following day helped even more. 'I don't think that baby should ever have been born at her age,' she told the paper, referring to Leo. 'But of course, Cherie's a Catholic, isn't she?' She said her mother voted National Front.

How damaging has this been? The Government says that in a crowd of 10,000 it would be unusual not to find a few naysayers.

'Just because a few women at the WI out of an audience of 10,000 decide they are going to duff up the PM doesn't mean we stop talking to the WI branches or stop recognising the importance of the WI,' said one source: 'The great risk is that politics becomes a private conversation between Westminster and lobby journalists which is overheard by the rest of the country. '

A few months ago Campbell said at a meeting of special advisers that the Government needs to be more political, needs to get its message across more aggressively. The strategy unit also sent out a memo in May demanding greater co-ordination between departments over political announcements.

The Labour election machine is now creaking back into action. Four days ago 80 MPs trooped through a small wood-panelled room in the Commons to have photographs taken with Alistair Darling, each to be duly printed up in leaflets or sent to local papers to publicise a new campaign on pensioners' benefits.

There will be a new blitz on pensioners this winter, when Gordon Brown's £150 cheque for fuel bills lands on doormats, warning them to 'come out and vote to save your £150 or the Tories will take it away'.

On the other side of the equation sit the Tories, playing their full part in the rebirth of politics. Just as the whisper is gaining currency that Blair has a bit of the John Major about him (the inability to understand why he's not connecting with the public, the trouble with Europe, the tendency to blame the cynical media for not getting the message across) there is another rumour afoot. The Tories are transforming themselves into a sharp, fighting machine.

Martin and pensioners have already been mentioned. But the broader and more revealing battle has ben over elitism and the row about Laura Spence, the comprehensive school girl from Tyneside turned down for a place at Oxford.

It is worth picking apart the elitism debate to understand what has happened to the Tories.

The fightback on the subject began on an afternoon just over two weeks ago in the Atrium wine bar, the hang out of choice among the Westminster plotting brigade. Amanda Platell, Hague's press secretary, and her deputy, Nick Wood, were sharing a bottle of wine and discussing tactics. On the other side of the bar Charlie Whelan, Gordon Brown's formidable former spin doctor, was holding court over a pint.

Brown had just said that the Spence issue was 'scandalous'. Hague had been telephoned on holiday in Israel to agree a line to take, and - after waiting nervously for 12 hours to gauge press reaction - Smith Square had released a statement from Shadow Minister David Willetts accusing Brown of 'class war'.

It worked. Charges of Cabinet splits were splashed across the Sunday papers - while Hague was pictured striding around in a wetsuit after swimming with dolphins.

Then just as the row was in danger of dying came a breakthrough, thanks not to the vigilance of a media monitoring unit as slick as Labour's but to a Tory peer tuning into Question Time late one Thursday night.

Baroness Blatch, a former Education Minister, heard Labour peer Baroness Jay describing her 'pretty standard grammar school'. Blatch knew Jay had actually gone to fee-paying Blackheath and, scenting a story, promptly dialled Central Office.

The result was a front page headline in the Daily Mail attacking Jay. When the Hague inner circle convened on Monday morning for the regular weekly meeting of its strategy group, the talk was of how to keep up the pressure.

The result was Tuesday's speech attacking a 'liberal élite'. Hague had previously used the words 'Islington élite' and talked about a liberal establishment. Speechwriters George Osborne and Danny Finkelstein quickly welded the two ideas into a new catchphrase.

By lunchtime, when Shadow Minister Andrew Lansley - a key figure in the strategy group - went on the radio amid clamours for names of this so-called élite, he had a hurriedly scribbled a list of Baroness Jay, Baroness Blackstone and Lord Falconer. Within hours, the Tory war room had between them cobbled together six more names.

So who should get the credit for creaking the Smith Square warhorse back into action? Platell, the former newspaper executive and 'bonkbuster' author is cited by many.

'The inner team is William, Amanda and Seb [Coe, Hague's chief of staff], while Andrew Lansley has quite a useful advisory role,' said one senior figure.

'Amanda deserves a lot of credit. She stuck at it when many others were either not doing anything or actually being rather unhelpful. Amanda has protected William, supported William, given William some of his ideas and seen off the threat from people who prefer Portillo.'

As Blair looks back on the detritus of the past week, he will reflect on a missed opportunity and the Tories' new sure-footedness.

The question in his mind must be how a keynote speech became such a fiasco. Rest assured, as he travels the country this week, to Scotland tomorrow for the health summit, to the Police Federation bravery awards on Thursday, to Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday, he will be watching for elephant traps.

No more screw-ups. That's the message now.

How to give as good as you get

Tony Blair has been accused of being unable to handle heckling, once a staple of political dialogue. Here some experts offer tips on dealing with an unruly audience

'A bit of work and you wouldn't heckle so stupidly'
John Major

'What exactly is on your mind - if you'll excuse the exaggeration?'
David Letterman, US chat show host

'Just you shut up mate or I'll come and sit on your face'
Jo Brand, comedian

'You're a bit of a Babe, you - have you seen the film?'
Craig Charles

'Your bus leaves in five minutes - be under it'
Mark Lamarr, comedian

'Do you have any problems? Other than that you're unemployed, a moron and a dork?'
John McEnroe

'When they put teeth in your mouth, they spoilt a perfectly good bum'
Billy Connolly
