Ros Coward looks at why the WI's forces of decency unleashed 'crone power' against a decent man
New Labour in power: special report
fields.body:
Most commentators have overlooked the fact that what happened between Tony Blair and the Women's Institute last week had a deeply personal element.

They have downplayed what happened as a spin-doctor fiasco or a confrontation between Left and Right. The Daily Mirror has managed to present the WI as 'Blue Rinse Tories', more evil than the November 17 group.

But this was no orchestrated political plot. Most of the women had booked their places at this event long before they knew the Prime Minister was coming.

In interviews given subsequently, it is apparent many are thoughtful people with interesting, progressive views on sustainable development, the environment or rural transport.

Of course, politics came into it. They didn't care for the 'party political broadcast' tone, and they didn't appreciate the renewed attack on the forces of conservatism, with a small 'c', since most probably still identify with that. Norm-ally, though, good manners and deference would have inhibited an attack on a Prime Minister.

What happened was more complex and important, a spontaneous protest producing the astonishing paradox of the forces of decency turning on a decent man.

What was it this audience of grandmothers heard and rejected in Blair's speech? I think they heard a boastful potency which neither valued nor mirrored their own exper-ience. Their slow handclap went beyond political disagreement. It was a corrective to hubris - of a politician, a father and a leader. 'What we saw,' says Andrew Samuels, professor of analytical psychotherapy, 'was, on a psychoanalytical or anthropological level, the power of elderly women against the male tyrant'.

The message they delivered 'was a reminder that, however kingly the king, the mother has power'. This might sound fanciful, but the media seem to echo him; the blue-rinse brigade have 'humiliated' the invincible leader.

Ironically - given the family focus of the WI - the subconscious trigger for this showdown may have been the birth of the Blair baby. It's no coincidence that this happened on the first public appearance of the Prime Minister after Leo's birth.

The press had predicted the opposite: the nation would go gooey and Tony Blair would get a massive boost in the opinion polls. We have been told the Blairs are the nation's role model. Tony is a 'sharing dad', Cherie is an example for modern women; their family is an icon of the stability this society needs.

Yet WI women will cer tainly feel differently. Theirs is a generation whose experience of mothering defines their identity. Most stayed at home with their children. They did not employ nannies. Nor did they ask their husbands, in far lowlier jobs than that of Prime Minister, to change nappies.

They limited their family size because of financial and practical considerations, making sacrifices of their own desires and ambitions because they thought they were right for the community and their children as future citizens.

The lifestyle of Blair's generation - my generation - are difficult for these women and many of us have at some point been on the receiving end of their ambivalence. One moment we feel our mother's pride in us as high-achieving daughters. The next, we en-counter the critical mother-in-law who seems to envy and disapprove of us.

Family affection usually moderates these negative feelings. But they flare up again when the Blairs are elevated as the symbolic family. This is the ultimate have-it-all family; both parents in highly paid jobs, foreign holidays galore, nannies for the difficult bits and now a little extra Leo on top. Their lifestyle seems to say the sacrifices of the previous generation of women are meaningless.

It's easy to see why these women might rebel when they hear 'community' - the ideology in whose name they made sacrifices - rammed down their throats as the cornerstone of a modern Britain which disregards them.

Addressed by the country's leader, they would have been looking for validation of their lives and reassurance of a payback in terms of health care and the future of their local communities and environment. What they got instead was rhetoric.

'Older women,' says Andrew Samuels, 'are highly intuitive. They know a lot but don't know how to express it. They often haven't had form-al education but they know a lot about life. What they heard was thin, desiccated, out of touch with these experiences. In psychoanalytic terms, what happened was a counter-transference, a nega tive hostile reaction that what they were getting wasn't true, wasn't real.'

Currently spin doctors, politicians and some newspapers are set on discrediting these women as Conservatives (capital C). They are using offensive, sexist language about false teeth, grey armies and blue-rinse bri-gades. Such hostility only confirms that 'crone power' is potent and real.

These older mothers are important not just because women over 55 are floating voters and could swing the next election. They are also symbolically important. Socially, the grandmother represents the voice of experience and, if her consent is actively and angrily withheld, a leader may not be able to lead.

History provides plenty of examples of this. Before Blair's Ministers crack any more jokes about their fear of the monstrous regiment of grandmothers, they would do well to remember it was just such women who brought down the Argentine junta and helped destabilise the old communist order.

fields.headline: They've got your number
fields.standfirst:
In a few days, scientists will reveal humanity's genetic blueprint. But is it a triumph for pure science or a goldmine for big business, asks Robin McKie
Special report: The ethics of genetics
fields.trailText:
In a few days, scientists will reveal humanity's genetic blueprint. But is it a triumph for pure science or a goldmine for big business, asks Robin McKie
Special report: The ethics of genetics
fields.body:
Above the dark green reception desk and easy chairs in the entrance hall of Cambridge's Sanger Centre, a large electronic ticker displays a series of endlessly changing figures. The glowing green numerals look like fluctuating share prices - until you notice the absence of numbers, and the presence of only four letters.

Over and over again, different permutations of As, Cs, Gs and Ts scurry across the screen, a new letter appearing every few seconds. Every minute of the day, every day of the week, for the past five years, this ceaseless alphabetical outpouring - from the centre's hundreds of automatic DNA sequencers - has been displayed this way.

What is being uncovered, before visitors' eyes, is nothing less than the genetic blueprint of humanity. Each A,C, G and T is a unit of DNA, and in a few days, having spewed out several hundred million such letters, that ticker will approach its first major milestone: the first working draft of the entire human genome.

In collaboration with US government researchers, scientists at the Sanger Centre, backed by the Wellcome Trust, will announce they have decoded more than 90 per cent of the 3 billion units of DNA that determine our physical and mental characteristics. They will, in effect, have made the first biological blueprint of our species.

'Think of the human genome as the Book of Life,' says John Sulston, director of the Sanger Centre. 'We are about to read the first proof copy, as important an understanding as learning the Earth goes round the Sun or we are descended from apes.'

It is an astonishing achievement, one that reveals how life's mysteries are now succumbing to the onslaught of science. At this rate, scientists will produce their second, final, full draft of the human genome next year, or by early 2002, at least three years ahead of schedule.

'We know we have now decoded between 88 and 92 per cent of human DNA,' Dr Michael Morgan, head of the Wellcome Trust's genome endeavours. 'We just have to run the figures through our computers to make sure we have pased the 90 per cent milestone mark.'

It is certainly a dramatic achievement, though it has not been made without casualties. Indeed, the human genome project has become one of the most controversial scientific endeavours ever undertaken, riddled - as it now is - with exchanges of abuse, accusations that scientists are privatising the human soul.

This hostility has been triggered, virtually single-handedly, by Craig Venter, the abrasive, ambitious geneticist whose intervention into the genome project turned a cosy academic enterprise into a bitter race that has provoked the consternation of Bill Clinton and Tony Blair.

It was Venter - backed by a vast pyramid of venture capital - who launched his private company Celera, based in Rockville, Maryland, as a straight competitor to the public international effort and claimed he would unravel the human genome's 3 billion DNA units quicker than they would, and at a profit. Give up now, he told genome scientists in 1998, and save your efforts for simpler creatures like the mouse.

Now, two years later, Celera has produced its own working draft - or first assembly, as Venter calls it - of the human genome, and this weekend, like the scientists at the Sanger centre, its researchers will put their final, frantic touches to their first folio of the Book of Life. In the next few days, the world will find which team got there first.

But the battle between Celera and the public Human Genome Project - a collective enterprise involving 16 different world institutes, with the Sanger Centre taking on by far the greatest workload - is not just a business of two outfits seeking precious scientific priority for a major discovery. They are divided by a far greater gulf: the very ownership of the genes of the human race.

Venter aims to recoup his investment by selling his data to pharmaceutical companies and by taking out patents on the most promising genes he finds. These would form the basis of new medicines - for heart disease, diabetes, mental illness and cancers - in the next decade, he believes.

But the idea that human genes can be patented this way, thus restricting their use to only a select few, is anathema to the Wellcome Trust, the Sanger Centre, and their US publicly funded counterparts. Indeed, the British Cabinet's chief scientific adviser, Sir Robert May, believes it would be a 'screaming disaster' if such patents were granted.

Yet this is exactly what Venter expects. 'One hundred to 300 of the most promising genes - out of the tens of thousands in the whole human genome - that we find should be enough to give us a tidy return,' he says.

But to do that, he will have to do more than just isolate a gene, which is typically made up of a few thousand DNA units. He will have to find out what protein that gene makes in the human body, and also work out how to interfere with its biological activity. Only then can he claim he has the right to hold a patent on it. Many scientists doubt if Venter has the resources to do that. Just working out the basic make-up of the human genome will keep him busy for the next year or so. He remains confident, nevertheless.

The dispute is therefore about how medical science will proceed in the 21st century, with Venter, the research raptor who hunts genes for cash, encapsulating the approach of the ultimate capitalist, while John Sulston fulfils the part of the committed public servant. Certainly, the comparison is stark.

Venter turns up at meetings in hired Jaguars, snappy clothes and a gold Rolex watch. When not checking the soaring price of share options, he sails his own yacht. Sulston runs a second-hand car, reads The Observer , and is opposed to global capitalism. Their only common denominator is science.

However, it would be wrong to underestimate Venter, despite his upstart ways. He was a former medical orderly during the Tet offensive in the Vietnam War, where he started to ask himself 'big, naive questions', as he recalls. 'What is life in the first place? What makes it work?', he demanded. On his return to the US, he determined to find the answer and studied biochemistry, establishing a reputation as an innovative researcher, albeit one for whom the lure of lucre has been a prime motivation.

By contrast, Sulston - the son of a vicar and a teacher - was a committed opponent of the Vietnam War and remains modest to the last, describing his work as nothing more than 'solid, middle-of-the-road science'. Money appears to have little appeal. In their different ways both have had a considerable impact on science, of course: Sulston in his quiet determined way, Venter in his role as a brash stimulator of genetic research - though scientists on either side of the Atlantic dispute his claims that his intervention was responsible for galvanising the human genome project, and bringing forward its completion date.

'Competition is always good for efforts like ours,' says Dr Morgan. 'But the truth is that there were other, far more telling factors.

'The development of new generation DNA analysers in the late Nineties dramatically improved sequencing rates, both for us and for Craig Venter. Similarly, we have come under increasing pressure from scientists to speed up our work. They have found our information so valuable they have pushed and pushed us to increase our output, and we have obliged.'

For his part, Venter retains his main ire for British researchers. It was Morgan and Sulston, after all, who flew to the USA in 1998 immediately after Venter had announced his bid to privatise the project. There they pledged that they would double the United Kingdom's investment in unravelling the human genome, a move that restored US government researchers' dented morale, and raised the Sanger centre to the role of being the public project's prime opponent to Celera, much to Venter's annoyance.

According to him, the Wellcome Trust - which has bankrolled Britain's entire £240 million involvement in the project - has merely involved itself in human genomics to try to cover up massive losses. It is not a point that impresses Dr Morgan. 'We are a charity. We can't hide our losses. In any case, if Venter had decided to co-operate with us, if he had decided to share the workload, instead of going into this thing as straight, competitive battle, we would be completing the full final draft, not the 90 per cent first draft, by now.

'We would be a couple of years further down the path towards understanding our genes and their role in determining our health. That's why this stressing of a race is so harmful.'

Life's building blocks

Our bodies are made up of billions of cells, and each of these cells has a central core called a nucleus. Inside this nucleus are found the chromosomes. Each of us has 46 chromosomes in each one of our cells.

Chromosomes are carriers of our genes, the units of information that direct our bodies to manufacture the various proteins that make up our bodies. Our total complement of chromosomes is known as the genome.

We have about 100,000 genes parcelled up inside these 46 chromosomes and these are made of the chemical deoxyribonucleic acid: DNA.

A total of about 3 billion units of DNA coil up inside the nucleus to form our chromosomes. These units of DNA are known as 'bases' and they come in four varieties: adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G) and thymine (T). Our genes are made up of different combinations of As, Cs, Gs, and Ts, a typical gene consisting of several thousand bases.

Not every piece of DNA goes to make up a gene, however. Along our chromosomes, there are gaps between our genes - stretches of As, Cs, Gs, and Ts that have no obvious function. These are known as junk DNA, and their role in human biology remains a mystery.

DNA holds key to beating disease

No two people on Earth have the same genetic make-up, apart from identical twins who are essentially human clones.

On average each person on the planet has about one million bases of DNA different from the next individual. Put another way, this means that each of us share 999 out of every 1,000 units of DNA. The remaining thousandth accounts for the myriad differences that separate each member of our species.

These mutations are spread along the genome and are known as single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs).

These are the genetic roots of individual differences and they hold the secret of medicine in the future.

Scientists want to study these SNPs because they believe they will allow them to pinpoint individual susceptibilities to disease. By correlating particular SNP mutations with individuals prone to certain illnesses they will be able to pinpoint versions of genes that leave people vulnerable to specific diseases.

'SNPs will allow disease associations to be determined for common disorders so drugs can be tailor-prescribed for the patient's particular mutation,' says geneticist Professor Kay Davies, of Oxford University. 'This will be very important in many disorders, but particularly in cancer and neural degenerative disorders like Alzheimer's Disease. The impact is some way off, but it will be enormous.'

fields.headline: Race row blights executions
fields.standfirst: Bush's defence of capital punishment shaken by revelations of repeated death row mistakes
fields.trailText: Bush's defence of capital punishment shaken by revelations of repeated death row mistakes
fields.body:
At least nine men were sent to death row in Texas after a psychologist recommended the death penalty partly because of the defendant's race, a review has found.

The death sentence that prompted the review was thrown out last week by the US Supreme Court, after it learnt that the chief criminal psychologist for the Texan criminal justice department, Walter Quijano, had testified that an Argentinian, Victor Hugo Saldano, a convicted murderer, was a future danger to society due to his Hispanic heritage.

Texas attorney-general John Cornyn began investigating in April after his office found problems with the Saldano case.

The Saldano case is the latest embarrassment for supporters of the death penalty in the United States.

Explosive DNA evidence has recently proved that several death row inmates were actually innocent. And a botched execution in Florida last week, where technicians took 33 minutes to find a vein to inject the poisonous chemicals intended to kill, has not helped their case either.

Recent scandals over race, innocence and bungled executions appear to have put the death penalty on trial. The issue has enveloped the presidential race, as the spectre of innocent men and women being sent to their deaths haunts the candidate who has sent 131 people to death row - George W. Bush, Governor of Texas, overseer of the busiest execution system in the Western world.

In his autobiography, Bush writes that 'the worst nightmare for a death penalty supporter, and of anyone who believes in our criminal justice system, is to execute an innocent man'.

As one state, New Hampshire, becomes the first to abandon the death penalty and another, Illinois, imposes a moratorium after 13 men on death row were proved inno cent. Bush said recently that he was convinced that all 131 convicts executed 'under my watch' in Texas were guilty. He likes the death penalty to be, he says, 'swift and sure'.

But a former judge on the Texas bench, Charles Bard, in Washington to announce the launching of a committee to stop wrongful convictions, cast doubt on the governor's confidence.

When asked if he agreed with Bush that all 131 of the people executed under his regime had been guilty as charged, Bard replied: 'Everyone in Texas hopes and prays that is the case. I do not share his view'.

Even members of the hardline Texas Pardons Board, which has rejected countless pleas for clemency and other appeals, are doubtful. One of them, Paddy Burwell, said last week: 'I worry that we may execute an innocent person. I think our system needs to be improved'.

Bush himself is showing signs of concern over Texan judicial process, recently granting the first ever stay of execution in his tenure as governor, and allowing DNA tests on Ricky McGinn, a mechanic convicted of raping and killing his 12-year-old stepdaughter minutes before his own death.

But it is the question marks raised over the evidence of state psychologist Quijano that have created the greatest scandal, appearing to confirm what many ethnic minorities have long believed - that their high representation on death row was nothing less than racism. The death sentence that prompted the review was against convicted murderer Saldano, which was thrown out by the Supreme Court after it learnt that Quijano had testified at his trial that, since blacks and Hispanics are over-represented in jail, ethnicity 'was a factor weighing in favour of future dangerousness'.

To impose death under Texan law, a jury must conclude the convict is a future danger.

The death penalty debate in the US was emphatically reopened when the hardline Republican Governor George Ryan of Illinois - a long-time proponent of capital punishment - imposed a moratorium after new evidence exonerated 13 men sent to death row.

Establishing the execution freeze, the governor said: 'I don't know if we'll ever go back to the death penalty as we knew it'.

Public support for the death penalty is dwindling - a national survey in February found endorsement of capital punishment at 66 per cent, its lowest level for 19 years.

Now, the focus is on Texas, the state that is America's unrivalled execution capital, and home turf of the man currently leading the polls to become the next President - and the focus is on procedure, evidence, DNA and race.

Most prisoners on death row cannot afford lawyers and are assigned court-appointed attorneys. In a number of recent cases, these lawyers were found to have slept through trials. One of these was that of grandmother Betty Lou Beets, who had killed the husband who beat her.

Her lawyer was regularly asleep, having been drinking heavily until late before the court heard of crucial evidence the next day.

Other dead or condemned prisoners have been defended by court-appointed lawyers with extensive disciplinary records for professional misconduct.

McGinn's lawyer was twice reprimanded by the Texas state bar. Last year, however, Bush rejected a Bill designed to improve legal representation for poor defendants.

Now the attention is on DNA. In recent years, DNA testing has freed 72 inmates from prison, eight of them from death row. Bush himself was obliged to free two of them, both on rape charges.

Yet only two states -- New York and Illinois - have mandatory DNA testing by law after the conviction of those sent to death row, as a final check.

In the McGinn case, it took an investigator from outside the state and the superstar attorney Barry Scheck to push for the DNA testing, despite rulings against it by the state court and the board of pardons.

fields.headline: Who is protecting N17 killers?
fields.standfirst:
Speculation mounts that Greek terror group has links to country's elite. Helena Smith in Athens and Jason Burke report Useful links: Audio from Helena Smith in Athens Eleftherotypia (in Greek)
Statement by foreign secretary Robin Cook
Prime Minister's response
fields.trailText: Like all good soldiers Brigadier Stephen Saunders was an early riser. Last Thursday he got up and took his dog for a walk, stopping to talk to his neighbours as usual, in the leafy Athenian suburb of Erythraia.
fields.body:
Like all good soldiers Brigadier Stephen Saunders was an early riser. Last Thursday he got up and took his dog for a walk, stopping to talk to his neighbours as usual, in the leafy Athenian suburb of Erythraia.

The fresh-faced Englishman was a modest man. Only hours before - because it had been a long night - he had been dining with Baroness Symons of Verlham Dean, Britain's deputy Defence Minister, her Greek counterpart and the British ambassador. But when chatting to those who also lived on the tree-lined street he kept his high-powered evening to himself.

His two teenage daughters were away at school in Britain so Saunders, who had been in Athens for a year, just said goodbye to his wife, Heather, at the door of the couple's spacious, two-story brick villa before getting into his white Rover saloon and setting off for the British Embassy.

Thursday was an unusually hot morning. As soon as the sun rose above Mount Parnassus the haze over the Greek capital thickened. Amid the rush-hour bustle on the busy Kifissias Avenue Saunders, 52, would not have seen the men on the motorbike weaving in and out of the traffic behind him.

When the white Rover slowed at a red light they drove up to the passenger side of the British diplomat's near-stationary car and - almost without stopping - opened fire.

It was over in seconds, eyewitnesses say. The man riding pillion produced a pistol, fired four bullets before the motorbike, a powerful white Enduro, sped off into the urban sprawl flanking the road.

The dying soldier just managed to open the car door before collapsing on the road in a pool of blood. He had become the 23rd victim of November 17 (N17), perhaps Europe's most enigmatic and elusive terror group. In exactly the same manner, on almost exactly the same stretch of road, 17 years ago N17 had murdered a US navy captain.

Six years later they repeated the feat and gunned down a prominent Greek industrialist. And in exactly the same manner as last week the gunmen had disappeared into the district of Halandri, a labyrinth of twisting, narrow streets.

When doctors at Athens Red Cross Hospital broke the news of Saunders's death to his wife, the British nurse queried his evident lack of protection.

Unlike his colleagues at the American Embassy - which spends more on security measures in Greece than anywhere else in the world - Saunders was, despite his sensitive position, both unguarded and in an unarmoured car. For N17 he was a sitting duck.

The Observer has also learnt that British intelligence agencies warned diplomats and other high-profile figures serving overseas that they should expect attacks from terrorists to coincide with the first anniversary of Nato's intervention in Kosovo.

The group first burst on to the international terrorist scene on 23 December 1975 when three men assassinated the CIA chief in Athens as he returned from a party with his wife. Since then, not one of its members has ever been captured, or identified.

So now investigators - despite the assistance of three officers from Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist branch - have little to go on. N17's strikes are clinical, methodical and almost anonymous. Witnesses have merely said that the helmeted gunman who killed Saunders was a muscular young man with a scar on his neck.

Though Greek police have conducted a thorough forensic search at the site of the murder, security sources are scathing about their ability to use such evidence.

And few clues are offered by a 13-page proclamation issued by November 17 on Friday. The group claimed to have murdered Saunders because of his role in Nato's bombardment of Serbian targets. They said that the Brigadier - the military attache at the Embassy - was a 'professional murderer' who worked for a government that had committed 'Nazi-like crimes'.

Another problem faced by the investigators is the lack of detailed information about the group.

They are known to be well organised and follow a dogmatic left-wing agenda - although recent pronouncements have been more nihilistic than the closely-argued polemics of their early years. Western experts believe there may be only 20 active members with five or six main 'planners'.

'They are obsessed by their cause, however anachronistic and irrelevant it may now be,' said George Kassimeris, a Greek political commentator and expert on terrorism. As a result they are very difficult to penetrate.

The group grew out of the violent political turmoil of Greece in the early Seventies and is named after the day when tanks crushed student protests in 1973. It quickly established a reputation for being methodical - even going to the effort of using the same typewriter to claim responsibility for each attack to guard against imposters.

The group's extraordinary durability has fuelled speculation that it has the protection of powerful figures within the Greek establishment. In an interview published in Greece on the day that Saunders died, James Woolsey, who headed the CIA between 1993 and 1998, claimed that individuals in the ruling Socialist Pasok party 'knew' members of November 17. Yesterday, the Greek courts challenged Woolsey to name the Greeks and Greek Cypriots he believed were members of the group. His allegations appear to be based on Pasok's origins as an armed resistance movement.

Formed as the Panhellenic Resistance Movement (PAK) by the late Andreas Papandreou, former Prime Minister, the movement fought the hated 'Colonels' who ruled Greece from 1967 to 74 and was openly supported by the Americans.

PAK members are believed to have received weapons training in the Middle East. Tests have shown N17 bombs to have been made by people trained by Arab terrorist groups.

Simitis appears sensitive to his country's poor record and last week he pledged to work harder to combat terrorism.

But few are optimistic of early success. Even Greek officials admit that for a long time there has been little 'political will' to deal with N17. Many Greeks saw it as a Robin Hood-type outfit targeting the rich and representatives of foreign countries bent on meddling in Greek affairs. With its populist and at times even amusing declarations, N17 fired the popular imagination.

But this is different. Saunders' cold-blooded murder has caused genuine embarrassment to a modernising government determined to integrate Greece into western Europe and improve its image abroad. There are now fears that concerns over terrorism could scupper Athens' chances of hosting the 2004 Olympic Games and affect tourism, the mainstay of the economy.

'For a long time there was a silent acceptance of the group,' says one political analyst. 'But times have changed. Greeks feel they have been shamed internationally... They now realise that N17 is hurting the way the outside world sees them and their country.'

webTitle: Old warrior who never gave in to Israel

fields.headline: Old warrior who never gave in to Israel
fields.standfirst: Hafez Assad's vision of a Middle East free of Zionism has gone with him to his grave
fields.trailText: Hafez Assad, the autocratic Syrian president who ruled for three decades but never realised his dream of a united Arab front and a humiliated Israel, has died aged 69. He had been ill for some time.
fields.body:
Hafez Assad, the autocratic Syrian president who ruled for three decades but never realised his dream of a united Arab front and a humiliated Israel, has died aged 69. He had been ill for some time.

The country he led was isolated and economically troubled but Assad never hinted that he saw himself as a man defeated.

A case in point were on-again, off-again negotiations with arch enemy Israel. Analysts had said the 1999 election of moderate Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak was Assad's last chance at a deal with the Jewish state to return the Golan Heights, captured in 1967 when Assad was defense minister.

When his army regained a slice of the Golan in 1973 fighting, Assad himself raised the Syrian flag there, demonstrating the area's political importance. But Assad would not be hurried or pressured in talks that resumed in December after a hiatus of nearly four years. Negotiations were suspended again in January when Syria insisted Israel commit to returning to prewar 1967 borders.

A skilful and ruthless politician, Assad often succeeded by keeping both foes and friends guessing, then suddenly reversing course when he saw an advantage.

Syria put aside enmity with the United States to join the US-led coalition against longtime rival Iraq during the 1990-91 Gulf war. Assad sent troops to help drive Iraq out of Kuwait, and later reaped diplomatic and financial benefits that included $2 billion from Saudi Arabia.

Assad could never be discounted in the Middle East equation. 'The Lion of Damascus' - his family name means lion in Arabic - was one of the Middle East's longest-serving leaders. He was credited with bringing political stability to a country of 9 million that had seen repeated coups since independence from France in 1946. Assad's bloodless takeover in 1970 was the last.

Assad built a Soviet-style personality cult at home, his portrait plastered everywhere in Syria. His rise was an extraordinary feat for a man who began life as a peasant boy from the minority Alawite Muslim sect, born on 6 October 1930 in Syria's coastal hills. He plotted his way to power through the ranks of the military and the socialist Baath Party.

He worked long hours and prided himself on managing the minutest details of his administration. His discipline extended to his private life - he was a vegetarian who abstained from alcohol, but rumours about ill health have dogged him since a heart attack in 1983.

He survived several reported coup attempts, including a failed 1984 effort by his ambitious brother Rifaat.

Like his hero Saladin, the Kurdish warrior who defeated the Crusaders in the 12th Century, Assad dreamed of becoming the unchallenged leader of the Arab world.

His attempts to rally Arab leaders against Israel gained little ground. He derided Egypt for signing a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, Jordan signed its own peace in 1994 and the Palestinians were pursuing yet another settlement with the Jewish state. Syria and Lebanon faced the prospect of being the last of Israel's neighbours to work out a peace deal.

Assad's confrontation with Western-backed Israel led to close ties with Moscow during the Cold War. The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 was a blow, but also presented an opening for much-needed reform.

Legislation meant to encourage private investment was enacted in 1991 but progress has been slow.

Syria, historically a regional trade centre, has seen its neighbours rush into new technologies and a competitive global economy, while agriculture remains the mainstay of its economy.

If ordinary Syrians are frustrated at being left behind they have said so quietly.

Assad maintained a vast army of secret police and informers. His government jailed thousands of political prisoners without trial, according to human rights groups.

Nonetheless, discussion of economic problems began to appear in Syria's state-controlled media in recent years. Occasionally, government ministers were criticised, though no one dared target Assad himself.

March saw the first Cabinet reshuffle in eight years, part of the leadership's attempt to modernise the administration and eradicate corruption.

Bashar Assad, his father's chosen heir, has championed economic reform and led the anti-corruption drive but it remains to be seen whether he has his father's skills.

Bashar Assad's elder brother Basil had been groomed as heir, until his death in a 1994 car crash.

Assad had three other sons and a daughter. He married an Alawite woman from a prominent clan. The presidential family was rarely seen in public.

fields.headline: Mayor tainted in poll scandal
fields.trailText: Two judicial inquiries into alleged vote-rigging in Paris have thrown up evidence of electoral fraud in the French capital on an unprecedented scale - and may yet lead to the head of state, President Jacques Chirac, being hauled before a court as a witness.
fields.body:
Two judicial inquiries into alleged vote-rigging in Paris have thrown up evidence of electoral fraud in the French capital on an unprecedented scale - and may yet lead to the head of state, President Jacques Chirac, being hauled before a court as a witness.

The inquiries focus on the capital's third and fifth arrondissement , strongholds of the Gaullist RPR party which Chirac founded and to which his successor as mayor of Paris, Jean Tiberi, belongs.

They have revealed that electoral rolls have been stuffed since the early 1980s with the names of people who did not live there. In exchange for their votes, faux électeurs were promised council-owned accommodation, a place in a council creche or a job at the town hall.

'The deliberate falsification of a vote, whether by stuffing an electoral roll or inventing phantom voters, is utterly reprehensible because it strikes at the very heart of the democratic process and ridicules the fundamental values of the Republic,' said the authoritative Le Monde in an editorial referring to a 'banana republic' in the heart of Paris.

Fifteen officials of the RPR and the Union for French Democracy (UDF) were last week placed under investigation for their alleged roles in organising fraud in the third arrondissement , where police have identified 859 phantom voters. In the fifth, the fiefdom of Tiberi - and, for nearly 20 years until 1995, of Chirac - the suspect names total 3,315.

Sometimes the name on the roll is that of someone who died years ago. Often, the address given for phantom voters does not exist. This was the case of a West Indian-born voter, Marlene P, who told investigators she was introduced to one of Tiberi's aides, Anne-Marie Affret, by a friend.

'I was working as a concierge in the council block in the twelfth arrondissement, and I was afraid of losing my job,' Marlene said. 'I told this to Ms Affret, and she said that if I wanted to work for the city, it would be good to register myself as a voter in the fifth arrondissement and to join her party, the RPR. I did that, and I kept my job.' Marlene was given a fabricated voting card and registered, with 11 other phantom voters, as an inhabitant of 373 rue Saint-Jacques. There is no such building.

The allegations are not new. In 1998, the Council of State recognised there had been serious fraud during the 1997 general elections, in which Tiberi was returned as MP for the constituency that encompasses the fifth arrondissement. It refused to overturn the election result because 'the numbers involved were not enough to have affected the outcome'.

The latest inquiries, however, involve numbers considerably higher than those earlier reported, and a Green Party member, Pierre-Alain Broussault, has demanded that Tiberi and Chirac be interviewed by the investigating magistrate to establish 'whether these manoeuvres were carried out by RPR party functionaries on the instructions of their superiors'.

Chirac is already implicated in an alleged payroll fraud at Paris town hall. It is alleged that up to 300 RPR activists were given non-existent jobs by the city and paid up to £10 million from public funds while Chirac was mayor from 1977 to 1995. But it remains uncertain whether the head of state could be prosecuted.

Fifteen officials of the RPR and the Union for French Democracy (UDF) were last week placed under investigation for their alleged roles in organising fraud in the third arrondissement , where police have identified 859 phantom voters. In the fifth, the fiefdom of Tiberi - and, for nearly 20 years until 1995, of Chirac - the suspect names total 3,315. Sometimes the name on the roll is that of someone who died years ago. Often, the address given for phantom voters does not exist. This was the case of a West Indian-born voter, Marlene P, who told investigators she was introduced to one of Tiberi's aides, Anne-Marie Affret, by a friend. 'I was working as a concierge in the council block in the twelfth arrondissement, and I was afraid of losing my job,' Marlene said. 'I told this to Ms Affret, and she said that if I wanted to work for the city, it would be good to register myself as a voter in the fifth arrondissement and to join her party, the RPR. I did that, and I kept my job.' Marlene was given a fabricated voting card and registered, with 11 other phantom voters, as an inhabitant of 373 rue Saint-Jacques. There is no such building. The allegations are not new. In 1998, the Council of State recognised there had been serious fraud during the 1997 general elections, in which Tiberi was returned as MP for the constituency that encompasses the fifth arrondissement. It refused to overturn the election result because 'the numbers involved were not enough to have affected the outcome'. The latest inquiries, however, involve numbers considerably higher than those earlier reported, and a Green Party member, Pierre-Alain Broussault, has demanded that Tiberi and Chirac be interviewed by the investigating magistrate to establish 'whether these manoeuvres were carried out by RPR party functionaries on the instructions of their superiors'. Chirac is already implicated in an alleged payroll fraud at Paris town hall. It is alleged that up to 300 RPR activists were given non-existent jobs by the city and paid up to £10 million from public funds while Chirac was mayor from 1977 to 1995. But it remains uncertain whether the head of state could be prosecuted.

webTitle: Kiwis plunged into depression by brain drain

fields.headline: Kiwis plunged into depression by brain drain
fields.trailText: New Zealanders are leaving their native shores in droves, placing a strain on the country's economy and painting a grim picture for its future.
fields.body:
New Zealanders are leaving their native shores in droves, placing a strain on the country's economy and painting a grim picture for its future.

Last year 70,000 Kiwis jumped ship, 35,000 of them crossing the Tasman Sea (the 'Ditch') to their bigger and more successful neighbour, Australia. Another 15,000 left for Britain, 3,000 to other countries in Europe, and 4,000 to America and Canada. Roughly 90 per cent were leaving permanently.

Although New Zealand's population increases each year through births exceeding deaths, the emigration figure has been going up annually by about 5,000 and for the past two years more people moved out than moved in.

It is mainly the professional middle class who are leaving, unable to resist the lure of higher wages and better exchange rates overseas. With a population of just 3.83 million, it is an exodus New Zealand can ill afford. The nation's health services are panicking. Public hospitals are suffering serious staff shortages as doctors leave. One in 10 junior doctor positions is vacant nationally.

Junior doctors get £6 an hour here compared with colleagues in Australia earning £30. A first-year house surgeon in New Zealand earns £12,650 a year compared with one in Britain on £17,650. Nurses and senior doctors are also in short supply.

General secretary of the Resident Doctors Association Dr Deborah Sidebotham said the situation is getting desperate. 'Doctors are resigning daily - this really is quite severe. Junior doctors already work 16 hours a day and with the 10 per cent increase in demand on health services we experience every year, patient safety is being compromised,' she said.

The share market is under siege from foreign buyouts and big firms moving voluntarily overseas, mainly to Australia. Even education is at risk. Waikato University recently lost part of a technology department when a US company bought it.

The situation reached melting point a few weeks ago when some members of Team New Zealand, the crew that in March won yachting's greatest prize, the America's Cup, defected. Two key members of the team accepted offers to sail for a Swiss syndicate for substantially more money. The yachtsmen cited disproportionately low wages for jumping ship. Since than another three have left.

The cumulative effect of this brain drain is an uncharacteristic faltering of Kiwi confidence, economically and socially. The recently elected Labour Prime Minister Helen Clark has pledged to rebuild the economy in an effort to entice Kiwis to stay at home and draw more foreign investment. A spokesman for her said: 'We are very concerned about this brain drain. We have got to make people realise New Zealand is an attractive place to live but we are never going to be able to pay the sort of wages that the US or Australia pay.'

webTitle: Putin thirsts after the vodka empire

fields.headline: Putin thirsts after the vodka empire
fields.standfirst: Moscow acts to end bootleggers' windfall
fields.trailText: A shake-up of Russia's alcohol industry is provoking fears among Moscow's vodka magnates that Vladimir Putin's government is determined to bring their empire back under state control.
fields.body:
A shake-up of Russia's alcohol industry is provoking fears among Moscow's vodka magnates that Vladimir Putin's government is determined to bring their empire back under state control.

The new crackdown has taken its toll on the industry already. One of the most powerful vodka merchants is in hospital with a heart condition after he was ousted in a boardroom coup; threats to another vodka businessman made him spend two days in hiding; and a third faces criminal proceedings after his offices were raided by special economic crime police.

Senior officials are already working on restructuring the vodka industry, concerned that a flourishing black market is costing millions of dollars in lost taxes. Last month the government set up a state watchdog to oversee the bulk of Russia's alcohol production.

Rosspirtprom will give the government huge influence over any of the partly state-owned 'drunken enterprises' (the Russian term for alcohol businesses), which most of them are. Officials will be able to make key industry appointments and clamp down on manufacturers not making adequate profits.

Boris Yeltsin considered such measures but was stopped by the fierce opposition of vested interests. Vladimir Putin's new regime is more confident and swiftly signed the decree last month.

The benefits to the government are clear: the average Russian is estimated to drink between 50 and 90 half-litre bottles of vodka a year. There is a vast domestic market to be tapped, even before potential export profits are taken into account.

Even with the bootleg industry accounting for 45 per cent of sales, liquor taxes bring the government almost as much in taxes each year as the oil industry. Annually the state receives about 24 billion roubles (£600 million) from alcohol profits, compared with 30bn roubles (£750m) from oil. If illegal sales were ended, the government's alcohol income would double.

There is also a more high-minded motive. A recent, dramatic rise in the consumption of bootleg vodka - after prices on legal spirits rose when new duties were imposed in Janu ary - has resulted in a surge in deaths from alcohol poisoning. In the first two months of the year more than 6,000 people died after drinking cheap alcohol surrogates - everything from industrial cleaning fluid to nail varnish remover and very low quality vodka, priced at as little as 30p a bottle. The figure was an increase of 2,000 on the same period last year.

Reactions to the creation of the industry watchdog are divided: some vodka industry leaders believe it a step back towards creating a state monopoly on vodka production, while others believe it is an attempt to recoup profits from alcohol bootleggers.

Workers at the Cristall factory in eastern Moscow - Russia's largest vodka producer and manufacturers of Yeltsin's favourite tipple, Gzhelka - are still reeling from a management coup late last month.

Last week they sent Putin an open letter, published in several Russian daily newspapers, pleading for the reinstatement of their director, Yury Ermilov, who is recovering in hospital from the shock of his forced dismissal.

He was removed by the board - led by a powerful figure within the Moscow administration - for 'gross violation of financial practice' on 25 May, two days after the tax ministry awarded the company a prize for being Russia's best taxpayer (a significant accolade in Russia, where non-payment of taxes continues to cripple the economy).

A government insider was brought in from the state-controlled oil business to replace Ermilov, but employees refused to let him in the building. When he returned with a team of private security guards, 200 workers still prevented him from entering.

Earlier this month, the factory's deputy director, Vladimir Svirsky, received a number of threatening phone calls, warning that dreadful things would happen to him and the company if the new director was not allowed to start work. 'I spent two nights inside the factory office. I was frightened of what might happen if I left the premises,' he said.

For the monent there is stalemate. Svirsky is still waiting for a response to his appeal to the President. 'It is a fight for control. Cristall is an extremely profitable business and there are a great many people who would like to see their man installed as director here,' he said.

Another leading vodka enterprise in Moscow is shaking from a separate crisis - also prompted by the government's thirst for control. Government investigators have raided the offices of Soyuzplodimport, the vodka export company responsible for selling about 50 of Russia's most famous brands abroad, and searched for evidence of financial malpractice.

The company is suspected of having illegally secured the rights to popular trademark brands at absurdly low rates, and of selling them on to companies abroad, thereby cheating the government of tax. Its directors deny any wrongdoing.

fields.body:

A UN women's conference in New York approved measures to combat violence against women and called for action against Aids and trafficking in women and to end to the gender gap in schools.

Thirty-five people were hurt when two mountain trains crashed in Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Bavaria.

Road death of Serb Minister

The Serbian education minister Milivoje Simonovic, 49,was killed in a motorway car crash near Belgrade.

webTitle: Living dead invade serial murders trial

fields.headline: Living dead invade serial murders trial
fields.standfirst: It was easy for the police as the Yemen Ripper confessed to killing girl students. Then 'victims' turned up alive, reports Brian Whitaker
fields.trailText: Yemen has been shaken by a grisly and baffling murder drama in which at least two women have died, their alleged killer has confessed to more crimes, and some of his 'victims' have made a surprise appearance - alive and in court at his trial.
fields.body:
Yemen has been shaken by a grisly and baffling murder drama in which at least two women have died, their alleged killer has confessed to more crimes, and some of his 'victims' have made a surprise appearance - alive and in court at his trial.

The 'murders in the morgue' case has led to allegations that it is linked to a trade in body parts. It began on 10 May, when two mutilated female bodies were found at the university in Sana'a, the capital. Two days later, police arrested a mortuary technician at the medical school, saying he had confessed to raping and killing five women.

Muhammad Adam Omar, a 45-year-old Sudanese, not only admitted a growing number of murders - 16 in Yemen and at least 24 in Sudan, Kuwait, Chad and the Central African Republic - but named members of the university's teaching staff who, he said, were involved in a racket for sale of body parts.

He had enticed women students to the mortuary with promises of help in their stud ies, then raped and killed them, videotaping all his actions. He kept bones as mementos, disposed of some body parts in sewers and the university grounds and sold others together with his victims' belongings. Newspapers published pictures of the accused, looking wild-eyed behind the bars of his cage, and - although he was described as a drunk and drug addict - everyone seemed ready to believe his story.

Yemen's students took to the streets. Thousands marched, demanding that Adam be executed. Why, people asked, had the university not done more to protect its students or investigate the disappearances? The Prime Minister suspended the dean of the medical school and his deputy and sacked the university's head of security.

Such was the atmosphere that when the trial started, Adam's defence lawyer felt unable to appear in court. But Adam said he didn't mind.

Adam gave police all the help they needed. His statement said the first killing occurred in 1995, when he met Fatima, a Somali girl, in the centre of Sana'a and convinced her that he was a well-known professor at the medical school. Lured by money, she visited him repeatedly at the mortuary, where he had sex with her more than 12 times before killing her. In 1996, another young woman came to the mortuary to collect body parts. As she entered, he sprayed a chemical on her face, rendering her unconscious. Then he realised her friend was outside, so he invited her in, repeated the process, and disposed of the unconscious bodies in acid.

The confession went on and on, murder after murder: an open-and-shut case, or so it appeared until newspapers published the names of the women Adam had confessed to killing. Several of his 'victims' then turned up - alive.

One was Nada Yassin, who left her family home in Abu Dhabi in 1991 to study medicine at Sana'a university. According to her sister, Aisha, she was in touch with her family regularly until October 1998 when telephone calls ceased and she stopped collecting her monthly allowance. After his arrest, Adam identified Nada from a photograph and described in detail how he had killed her.

But when the trial resumed on 3 June, a woman cloaked in black, with only a narrow slit for her eyes, announced to the startled court that she was Nada Yassin.Aisha, who was also in court, confirmed her identity.

Not everyone was convinced. A journalist noted that the woman in black looked different from photographs of Nada and some of the things she said in court did not tally with what her relatives had said earlier.

Two other women contacted the Associated Press news agency, saying they were medical students who had been reported murdered by Adam. A doctor, Amira al-Tawati, who graduated from the medical school in 1993, also claimed that she was listed among the victims.

Adam, who has retracted his confession, now says he killed 'only' two women. The police insist they have parts from at least five separate bodies. Forensic experts say they have found the bodies of boys, as well as girls, which are not listed in the mortuary records.

One of the two dead students who have been identified was Iraqi-born Zainab Saud Aziz, 22, who disappeared last December. Relatives believe she was abducted while on her way to testify to a university inquiry about grade-rigging by fellow students. The other was Hossn Ahmad Attaiah, a member of one of Yemen's largest and most influential tribes, the Hamdan. Her tribe has already caused disturbances in court and is threatening action if Adam's presumed accomplices are not brought to justice.

Last week three members of the university's teaching staff - a Yemeni, an Iraqi and a Sudanese - were arrested. They had been named by Adam as involved in trading body parts. It was also disclosed that last December the university had sacked Adam for bribery, but had then mysteriously reinstated him.

The case has brought out attitudes and prejudices rarely expressed directly. In a country with high unemployment, Adam is an immigrant with a job. A union leader has said that the employment of a foreigner as a university technician contravened a presidential decree. Fearful of a backlash, the Sudanese community, several thousand strong, has condemned Adam's 'heinous crime'.

For ultra-traditionalists the case is further proof that educating women can only lead to trouble. In such a climate the presumption is that when a young woman goes missing she has gone astray morally. Zainab's mother was allegedly told to search the dance floors when she reported her daughter's disappearance.

fields.headline: Labour needs to be managed
fields.trailText: Euan Ferguson (People, 28 May) is appalled by my assertion that the Labour Party requires better management from its National Executive Committee. 'Members do not need to be managed,' adds NEC member Anne Black sternly (Letters, last week).
fields.body:
Euan Ferguson (People, 28 May) is appalled by my assertion that the Labour Party requires better management from its National Executive Committee. 'Members do not need to be managed,' adds NEC member Anne Black sternly (Letters, last week). Their reaction demonstrates a failure to understand what good management means. It's certainly not about manipulating people. It means ensuring their voice is heard at the highest level, that internal elections are fair and above board, preventing politicians from interfering in party procedures, and enabling members who are discriminated against to challenge and overturn that discrimination.

There's no point NEC members luxuriating in the moral high-ground but allowing archaic and unfair practices to be perpetuated. The NEC's prime responsibility is managerial. When our industries go into decline and our members are made redundant, we in the Labour movement often point the finger at bad management. It's high time we learnt what good management is, and introduced it into our own organisations.
Tony Robinson
London NW1

fields.headline: Ingrams errors
fields.trailText: Richard Ingrams says (Comment, last week) that the Press Complaints Commission 'is composed entirely of newspaper editors'. It is not. It is composed of seven editors and nine lay members all of whom - including me - are completely unconnected with the press.
fields.body:
Richard Ingrams says (Comment, last week) that the Press Complaints Commission 'is composed entirely of newspaper editors'. It is not. It is composed of seven editors and nine lay members all of whom - including me - are completely unconnected with the press. That guarantees the independence of the PCC from the newspaper industry, one of the essential prerequisites of effective self-regulation.

He also says that in our adjudication about share dealing at the Mirror , we 'accepted [the editor's] unlikely version of events' and 'let [him] off with only mildest of reprimands'. Wrong again. The PCC found a number of serious breaches of the editors' Code of Practice - so serious that we referred the whole adjudication to the newspaper's publishers. A case of bark and bite being as severe as each other.
Lord Wakeham
Press Complaints Commission
London EC4

fields.headline: Lottery losers
fields.trailText: Trying to make Lottery distributions 'fair' misses the point (News, last week). Unlike progressive taxation, the Lottery takes most from the poor and least from the rich.
fields.body:
Trying to make Lottery distributions 'fair' misses the point (News, last week). Unlike progressive taxation, the Lottery takes most from the poor and least from the rich. Structurally, its grants represent a diversion from locally accountable provision, of health, education and social services. It is an unfair system in an unfair society.
John Nicholson
Manchester

webTitle: The big idea: Captain Corelli's Mandolin

fields.headline: The big idea: Captain Corelli's Mandolin
fields.trailText: The reason why  Captain Corelli's Mandolin (News, last week) has such an anti-communist bias is clear from the book's bibliography: his main source on that matter was  Eleni by Nicholas Gage, whose Greek American whose mother Eleni was executed by communists during the civil war.
fields.body:
The reason why Captain Corelli's Mandolin (News, last week) has such an anti-communist bias is clear from the book's bibliography: his main source on that matter was Eleni by Nicholas Gage (not to be confused with Nicholas Cage, now coincidentally starring in the film of Louis de Bernières' book). Mr Gage is a Greek American whose mother Eleni was executed by communists during the civil war.

Friends of mine who met him in Greece while he was researching the book found him to be 'unbalanced on the subject of communists to the point of questionable mental health', and it was never on the cards that his book would be anything other than exceedingly biased.

When Eleni was published, in English and Greek, it caused considerable uproar in Greece, far more than Captain Corelli's Mandolin is doing now, and a very competent rebuttal of his historical inaccuracies was published in response, but only in Greek.

It seems a shame that Louis de Bernières chose apparently to rely so heavily on one American's view of such a complex matter as the Greek civil war, rather than consulting indigenous sources where the general view is that awful atrocities were indeed committed during that period, but both sides were equally culpable. And that the problems would have been better resolved without the interference of Britain and the United States, given their existing anti-communist prejudice.
Sylvia Rose
London SE5

 Perhaps the most telling aspect of Louis de Bernières' protestations concerning the furore surrounding the filming of his book is that he is so ignorant of Greece, its people and its history that he is seems incapable of understanding the profound insult that his distortion of history has inflicted. Along with countless Jews deported from Greece by the Nazis were socialists held in prison by the ruling dictators (who had taken power in 1936) and willingly handed over to the invader. If, as he suggests, the communists learned from the Germans, it was from the unenviable vantage point of a concentration camp.

In fact if anyone can be said to have inherited the Nazis' mantle, it must be the barbarous post-war regime which produced its own version of the concentration camps on remote islands such as Makronisos, imprisoning and executing political opponents in vast numbers.

It would have taken little research for de Bernières to have uncovered widows of men who died in these camps, either directly at the hands of the rulers, or hanging themselves with their own clothing - men whose only crime was to write a critical poem, or simply to have a brother who fell foul of the regime.

For him to seek, at this point, to lecture the friends and relatives of those victims of savagery is simply shameful.
Jeremy Henderson
Aberdeen

fields.headline: Kwai memorial
fields.trailText: There is an irony in your choice of photograph to accompany the article 'Veterans demand British memorial to Kwai dead', (News, last week). The British ex-POW in that photo is Dudley Cave, who together with several Japanese friends, succeeded in erecting a memorial not   only to cruelty and death, but to the hope of reconciliation.
fields.body:
There is an irony in your choice of photograph to accompany the article 'Veterans demand British memorial to Kwai dead', (News, last week). The British ex-POW in that photo is Dudley Cave, who together with several Japanese friends, succeeded in erecting a memorial not only to cruelty and death, but to the hope of reconciliation. There may be a case for a further commemoration but there is already something which offsets the 'fun-fair' aspect of the railway, a memorial to the terrible deaths and cruelties inflicted on POWs and Asian labourers, but also to the remorse of many Japanese over their government's crimes during the war. Sadly Dudley died last year, but the bell and its hopeful message remains.
Betty Scharf
London NW11

fields.headline: Failing tests
fields.trailText: Oxford Don John Stein (Interview, last week) has singularly failed to understand his critics. It is no good arguing that state school pupils 'have no training for interviews' or 'need summer schools to reassure them'. What is wrong is that applicants who have obtained top grades against considerable odds are made to undergo the Oxbridge grilling at all.
fields.body:
Oxford Don John Stein (Interview, last week) has singularly failed to understand his critics. It is no good arguing that state school pupils 'have no training for interviews' or 'need summer schools to reassure them'. What is wrong is that applicants who have obtained top grades against considerable odds are made to undergo the Oxbridge grilling at all.

Oxbridge should accept As and starred-As at a comprehensive as sufficient proof of intelligence. If there is any case for conducting tests, it would be among the more mixed-ability applicants from private schools.
E. Schaffer
London N6

 Lydia Aers writes that at her school in her year, 30 gained straight As at A-level (Letters, last week). This highlights a fundamental problem with present standards in these examinations in that they do not really give much of a clue of the relative academic merit of the candidates. When I took A levels, in 1957, it was unheard of for anyone to get straight Grade 1s. I do not believe that academic ability has improved so much. Examinations must be made much tougher.
Rodney Davis
Wallingford, Oxfordshire

 Peter Wilby is wrong to say that entry to the two ancient universities is as socially exclusive as it was 30 years ago (Comment, last week). It would then have been impossible for me to study where I did, at Pembroke College, Cambridge. Women were barred from my college until 1984, but now make up around 50 per cent of the undergraduates.
Rebecca Reeves
London N1

A recent DETR report shows that voter turnout is greater where Lib Dems are actively involved in the electoral process. The problem is that Lib Dem politicians are rarely given widespread coverage allowing them to 'engage our deepest feelings and deepest prejudices'.

fields.headline: Genocide needs to be understood
fields.trailText: Jay Rayner's thoughtful critique (Comment, last week) of the Imperial War Museum's new Holocaust Exhibition nevertheless assumes that what is unique is also incomparable.
fields.body:
Jay Rayner's thoughtful critique (Comment, last week) of the Imperial War Museum's new Holocaust Exhibition nevertheless assumes that what is unique is also incomparable. Without being polemical, the exhibition invites visitors to compare the fate of the Jews with that of other victims of Nazi persecution and provokes reflections on the menace of racism that cannot fail to have a wider application.

Each genocide has its specific causes and until we analyse what these are we cannot compare one with another. If we can't understand them, we can't hope to anticipate or prevent their recurrence - which is the whole point of the IWM's exhibition.
David Cesarani
University of Southampton

 Indebted as I am to Professor Steiner's profound erudition and sagacity of mind, it is with great sadness that I see him resort to 'the German character' and 'the German sensibility' which, he believes, 'underwrote' the butchering of Jews even within earshot of the advancing Russians (Review, last week). I thought these fictitious Platonised entities like 'the German mind or sensibility' had been put to rest as explanatory concepts some time in the 1960s.

Of course the Holocaust is a uniquely German problem and they must never be allowed to forget it, but it is also a singular human problem, of what men can do to men. The moment we speak of 'the German mind' or character as the cause and cauldron of evil most foul, we lose sight of a historical watershed which affects all of us without exception.
Dr A.K. Wiedmann
Goldsmiths College, University of London

fields.headline: Can you handle the risks?
fields.standfirst: Spread betting is not for the faint hearted - especially when it happens online, warns Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Spread betting is not for the faint hearted - especially when it happens online.
fields.body:
Immune to the thrills of stockmarket investment? Blas about the rough and tumble of internet start-ups? Then spread betting might provide just the level of risk you are looking for.

Spread betting can expose you to an almost unlimited amount of risk. It allows gamblers to bet on the difference between a bookmaker's prediction of what will happen and the actual result. The punter 'buys' the higher price of a spread or 'sells' the lower price depending on what they think will happen and what the bookmaker says will happen. The fluid nature of this form of betting carries much greater risk because both the upside (what you can win) and the downside (how much you can lose) are not fixed.

Consider this example provided by online spread betting firm IG Index (www. indexdirect.co.uk). The firm quotes the total number of goals in a match between Tottenham Hotspur and Arsenal at a spread of 2.4 to 2.7. As an astute observer of north London football derbies you believe this to be something on the high side.

So you decide to sell for £150 per whole goal in the belief that, between them, the teams will score less than 2.4 goals. Unfortunately for you, Ginola of Spurs ends up scoring a hat trick. The old warhorse Tony Adams manages to bang one in for the Gunners, bringing the total number of goals to four.

The difference between the closing level (ie four goals) and the opening level below which you sold (2.4) is 1.6. So 1.6 multiplied by £150 means you end up owing your bookmaker £240. Imagine what would have happened if Arsenal's Dennis Bergkamp hadn't been sent off. He could have gone on to bag a hat trick - and the difference between the closing price (seven goals in total) and the opening level (2.4) would have been 4.6. Multiply this by £150 per goal and you end up having to shell out a whopping £690.

There are numerous variations depending on which sport you bet on. And while you can reduce the damage by putting limits on the bet, it is still not for the faint-hearted.

Addiction charities report that the most significant rise in compulsive gambling this year is from City traders spread betting on the net. Those who work in the Square Mile, it seems, cannot help turning their financial skills to other matters.

Spread betting on Gordon Brown's speech is a perennial favourite in the City. Indeed you can bet on practically anything. Many bookmakers will offer spreads on the markets, everything from interest-rate fluctuations to the price of copper on London's Metals Exchange.

And, increasingly, they are allowing you to do it online. In addition to IG Index, City Index (www.cityindex.co.uk) and Sporting Index (www.sportingindex.com) allow you to spread-bet online. High street bookmaker William Hill has a site (www.williamhill.co.uk) that links you to its spread-betting arm, although this will allow you to gamble only on sports, not the markets. There is even an online firm which offers advice to spread-betting fans. The site (www.sportsadviser.com) offers a subscription service and has links to bookmakers' sites. Other big name bookmakers are expected to start offering online spread-betting services soon, possibly from tax havens such as Gibraltar which enable the gambler to avoid paying betting tax.

To start spread betting you need to open an account. You can do this online, filling in a number of boxes to confirm things such as your age, telephone numbers (both home and work) and your address. You will be asked how long you have lived at the address, so the bookmaker can conduct a credit check.

You will also be issued with a password. Some online firms give you a choice of accounts, usually based on your attitude to risk.

After having clicked through the options you will be asked to transfer some money into your account, usually using your debit card. Each time you bet you will be asked whether you want to pay gaming tax of 9 per cent on your stake or your winnings.

If the idea of spread betting appeals, take care in your selection of bookmaker. Some of the companies operating in cyberspace are based in some fairly exotic places. If the company folds or makes a mistake, your avenues for redress are rather limited.

The big name City spread-betting firms, in comparison, are licensed under the Financial Services Act which means, by law, they have to put aside sufficient cash to cover any eventuality.

webTitle: So you think you can dotcom

fields.headline: So you think you can dotcom
fields.standfirst: Bridget Cleverly, co-founder of Webweekends.co.uk, has learnt a lot in her company's hectic first six months
fields.trailText: Bridget Cleverly, co-founder of Webweekends.co.uk, has learnt a lot in her company's hectic first six months.
fields.body:
Webweekends.co.uk was conceived over a bowl of spaghetti bolognaise with my former flatmate Sophie Campbell. As a travel journalist, she had just been asked by a reader where he could take his girlfriend for a romantic weekend. He wanted somewhere hot, near water and in the country - golf and a tennis court would be an advantage.

'Where would you have gone for advice?' she asked. I said I would probably have relied on word of mouth or, in extremis, a travel agent. We both agreed there was no organisation that specialised in providing customised information and ideas on weekend breaks. Why not launch one that operated over the net - our own dotcom?

We started with a business plan, which was fairly easy to write because we had a clear idea of what we wanted to create. Then came the board, selected on the basis of the skills that we needed to set up and run a company. We have a lawyer, a marketeer (me), a senior travel industry insider, a travel expert (Sophie), and a banker who is experienced in selling internet companies. All of the board members had full-time jobs and we couldn't afford to employ staff without money, so we needed to raise some cash to get started. Our £600,000 start-up capital was successfully achieved in December 1999 through a private placing. There was no silver spoon for this company; the first office address was a lowly business centre in Battersea. The whole board turned out to paint the new office, visit Ikea and assemble the desks. Our first two full-time employees were Sophie, who gave up travel journalism to become managing director, and Chris, who became our technical director having left a merchant bank where he was head of European IT. Three weeks later Mick joined us from a travel industry magazine to be the sales director and we hired an office administrator. Anxious to be careful with our capital, we stopped hiring and set our executives off to work 18-hour days to get the business off the ground.

Chris and Sophie were in charge of developing the site and with the help of our internet design and build company, Motion Pixels, produced a working model which could be used to present our concept to potential weekend providers.

Then the real work started. We gave ourselves 10 weeks to fill our database with 2,000 individually inputted weekend breaks from tour operators and hoteliers. With hindsight we should have hired a second salesman earlier. Luckily, we reached our target, largely thanks to the support of weekend providers who liked our concept.

What has been most notable about starting an internet business is the speed at which things move and change. The business plan has been rewritten twice since January. The company was launched as an online directory, but intends to offer online booking of weekends by the autumn. The site is likely to be offered via interactive TV by this autumn. The board - which thought it was non-executive - has found the website has turned into a second full-time job. With 20:20 hindsight, were there things we would have done differently? Yes. Were there things that we got right? Again, yes. Was launching a new internet company as easy as we thought it would be? Yes and no. Yes, because writing the initial business plan and forming a board was relatively easy. No, because our advance planning seemed to exist in one-month spans before things evolved. Our advice to anyone considering something similar: time flies.
