fields.headline: That won't do nicely ...
fields.standfirst: With banks scared off the net by online fraud, fledgling dotcoms are being driven into the costly arms of specialist providers, writes Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: The adult entertainment industry did for Betamax. The sex industry's decision to record its films on VHS tape meant Betamax, its technologically superior rival, stood not a chance. It's the same with all media: from newspapers to Channel 5, sex has been a driving force in boosting audiences.
fields.body:
The adult entertainment industry did for Betamax. The sex industry's decision to record its films on VHS tape meant Betamax, its technologically superior rival, stood not a chance. It's the same with all media: from newspapers to Channel 5, sex has been a driving force in boosting audiences. And the internet is no exception. More people look for sex on the net than anything else.

But recently the UK purveyors of online adult entertainment have hit a wall. Fraud in the industry is running so high that the big banks, not to mention the likes of Visa and Mastercard, won't allow them to trade online. Instead, consumers dialling up an adult website now find, more often than not, that they are given a telephone number to ring if they want to subscribe to a service or order a product, rather than an icon to click on.

The problems facing the adult entertainment industry are symptomatic of a wider malaise at the heart of e-commerce, chiefly the confusion over security for internet payments. The big e-tailers don't have to worry: they have developed their own bespoke transaction systems. But the smaller players enjoy no such comfort.

This has huge implications for e-commerce - mainly on the question of whether it will take off as quickly as analysts and the Government expect. According to the Boston Consulting Group (BCG), Europe's online retail market grew by 200 per cent last year: the total value of transactions reached 3.5 billion euros. By the end of this year, that figure is predicted to have risen to 9bn euros. In two years' time, the total online retail market should, according to the BCG, be worth 45bn euros.

But with the banks and the likes of Visa reluctant to get involved with many dotcom companies because of the high levels of risk, e-commerce appears to be heading up a cul-de-sac. But the impasse has created an opportunity for new players to fill the gap left by the banks.

'The banks are paralysed,' said Nigel Wallbridge, co-founder of Global Internet Billing (GIB), an online payment solutions provider. 'They're pulling back from the market. This creates an interesting space for non-banks. Payment over the internet is going to be a huge growth area.' He singles out pay-per-view television on the internet and music downloads as two key areas likely to see their growth frustrated if concerns over the security of e-commerce are not ironed out.

'There's a massive amount of shoplifting going on on the internet,' Wallbridge added. 'The banks see it as a huge risk because there are massive amounts of fraud. The problem has become so bad that the banks are not giving online accounts to new e-tailers.'

GIB's solution to fraud concerns has been to develop a series of pre-pay charge cards which can be used to buy goods online. The company also offers a service that charges the costs of goods and services bought over the internet to your telephone bill.

This may be attractive to consumers, but it is not a complete solution for e-tailers, who have to swallow hits from credit card fraud. Online consumers are able to obtain a refund if they can prove their card has been used fraudulently. But e-tailers have no such defence: they have to pay these costs, known in the industry as 'charge backs'. And while the e-tailer takes the hit, the company's bank will also have to process the charge-back claim. This costs anything between £7.50 and £20 a time. This may sound insignificant but when it is multiplied several thousand times, it is clear why the banks are reluctant to get involved with those dotcom companies which they consider high-risk.

Couple this with the fact that dotcom companies have been known to go bankrupt, and it is clear that internet start- ups face some serious problems when trying to get established.

As a result, several companies - known in the trade as 'payment solutions providers' (PSPs) - have emerged in recent years, aiming explicitly at the e-tail market. Well-known names include WorldPay (in which, significantly, NatWest has a 13 per cent stake), Secure Trading and NetBanx.

These companies make their money by processing the online transactions of those e-tailers the conventional banks consider too risky.

Critics of Visa and Mastercard argue that the confusion and widespread fraud permeating the e-commerce sector would not have been so rife if they had managed to develop their own online security systems more quickly. Much was made of Secure Electronic Transaction (SET), an industry-wide initiative that will see the introduction of a new automatic authentication system. Using SET, e-tailers would be immediately alerted when a fraudulent card was used. The system is currently being trialled with more than 100 pilot companies but, as a spokeswoman for Visa admitted: 'It has been slower to roll out than we anticipated.'

For now, start up e-tailers have little choice but to use the new wave of PSPs, who don't ask to see two years' worth of accounts before agreeing to process a company's online transactions.

Of course the quid pro quo for the fledgling start-ups that are regarded as liable to go bust overnight is that they have to pay the PSPs higher transaction fees. Whereas normal high street stores could expect to pay their bank fees of up to 2 per cent per transaction, the new wave of e-tailers normally pay around 4 per cent or more.

'There is a feeling that they are having to pay excessive fees,' said Peter Jones of Payments Systems Europe, a payment consulting company. 'Anecdotal evidence suggests some companies, desperate to get going, are paying between 9 and 10 per cent per transaction.'

And, of course, we, the consumers, ultimately end up footing the bill. The PSPs argue that cutting their fee structures is impossible because of the high rates they have to pay the banks. But unless the banks are prepared to accept more risk, the cost of processing online transactions will remain higher than in the high street - and the internet's bete noire remains.

fields.headline: No justice for crime site
fields.standfirst: Merciless market may see off award-winning US news dotcom, reports Melinda Wittstock
fields.trailText: APBnews had become the latest victim of Wall Street's increasingly bearish outlook for content-driven websites following the 14 April meltdown of technology stocks on the Nasdaq market. Venture capital is drying up for internet companies
fields.body:
The all-points bulletin came at 9.30am last Monday, less than 48 hours after the internet news site APBnews.com had collected its latest, and perhaps last, award for excellence in investigative journalism. Staff of the hard hitting and highly respected site devoted to crime and justice learnt two things: crime does not necessarily pay, and justice doesn't always prevail.

The money - all $23.5 million of it - had run out, chief executive Marshall Davidson told 140 staff crammed together in the lower Manhattan newsroom. Their 'speeded up' pay cheques would be their last from APBnews.com - unless a cash injection could be found within days.

APBnews had become the latest victim of Wall Street's increasingly bearish outlook for content-driven websites following the 14 April meltdown of technology stocks on the Nasdaq market. Venture capital is drying up for internet companies, even if, like APBnews, they boast one million hits a day and consistent critical acclaim.

'We were halfway through our game plan, and we ran out of juice,' says chief executive Mark Sauter. 'Everything changed that day in April. Until then, our investors were telling us to spend as much as we needed to expand into an international multimedia brand. Now they're only looking for small, cost-effective, immediately profitable sites.'

But hope of a rescue was kept alive into this weekend, as APB talked to potential partners. It extended at least until tomorrow its deadline for a shutdown.

The failure of privately-owned APB Online Inc to complete a crucial third round of financing came in a week that also saw significant cost cutting and big job losses at online magazine Salon.com, women's website and cable channel Oxygen Media and the CBS television network's internet division - along with the closure of the respected not-for-profit media website NewsWatch.org after an investor refused to stump up $1m.

But such is the loyalty of the APB site's award-winning team that after Davidson broke the bad news, they gave him a standing ovation and vowed to continue working without pay until Friday - the company's deadline for finding a major media partner.

'About 80 per cent of us are still here - every editor, every reporter - working to keep the site going while negotiations continue,' says Hoag Levins, the executive editor who built the scoop-driven newsroom. 'I've been in the business 30 years, and I've never seen this kind of loyalty.'

APBnews made its web debut in November 1998, with live police scanner webcasts under the motto: 'to inform and serve'. Staffed by a mix of fresh-faced unknowns, Pulitzer Prize-winning veterans such as Sydney Schanberg - whose reporting on Pol Pot's Cambodia was immortalised in The Killing Fields - and big name columnists such as former New York City police chief William Bratton and O.J. Simpson prosecutor Marcia Clark, it had certainly lived up to its heady journalistic ambitions.

Brill's Content, the US media magazine, had named it 'one of the best news sites' on the internet; TV Guide called it 'the CNN of police and crime news.' Major news sites including America Online, Yahoo!, Snap, MSNBC and NBCi were syndicating APB content, and just about every newspaper and broadcaster was following up its many scoops.

APB could also boast some of American journalism's highest honours. Only last Saturday, Levins had celebrated a special citation from the prestigious Investigative Reporters and Editors Inc - only to be shut down two days later. 'No small irony,' he said, deadpan.

'The lesson for every "startup.com" now seems to be: no matter how great the content or vision, you're entirely at the mercy of the markets. The irony here is that it was the internet that wildly altered the markets, introducing unprecedented volatility with day traders and the like, and it is that volatility that's to blame for the downturn in stock prices that has claimed our funding.'

But unlike the online magazine Salon.com, forced last week by its Wall Street underwriters to cut 13 top jobs and slash costs, APBnews was meeting revenue targets.

Launching its third planned round of financing in March, APBnews had raised another $3.6m before the April Nasdaq crash. 'We had been on target to break even less than two years from now, with total losses over four years of less than $60m. That's incredibly modest when you think of the sums other sites have haemorrhaged,' says APB corporate spokesman Joe Krakoviak.

'But our investors are prepared to let great journalism go down the drain all because of current market conditions. And the tragedy is, even if the market regains its senses in six months, it will be too late for us. They want to see profitability right around the corner, but no one has ever gone from startup to profitability in just two years,' says Krakoviak. 'Just think where USA Today would be in today's conditions: it lost a billion dollars before it turned a profit, and now it is the most profitable newspaper in the country.'

But even if APBnews finds a deep pocketed saviour among the big media goliaths it is understood to have been negotiating with, its difficulty finding finance is a harbinger of doom for independent and original content-driven sites.

'The prognosis is poor,' says media pundit Mark Crispin Miller, a professor at New York University. 'This should help dispel the hearty myth that everything lost in the old media will thrive in the new. For all the talk of new media as virgin territory where independent plants may bloom, the fact is the entities with the biggest, deepest pockets, the ones already powerful in the "old" media, are the ones that are thriving in the "new" media. And to the extent that good journalism is now wholly dependent on venture capital and shareholders, we're in serious trouble.'

Salon.com's chief executive Michael O'Donnell says the cutbacks will buy his site several more months before he must return to his investors for more cash. He says: 'Our feeling was, we'd like to be around a year from now, so we thought we'd take these steps now, however difficult. You need to be sure that you'll live another day.'

Among the 13 Salon staffers now uploading their CVs are the site's respected media editor Sean Elder, as well as its book review editor, book reporter, and New York correspondent. Salon has closed its Seattle bureau, and O'Donnell admits there will be a 25 per cent reduction in content.

Wall Street analysts say the internet shake-out is only just beginning - there will be many more cost-cutting announcements, lay-offs, closures and frantic searches for bigger, more powerful media partners.

Strange, only a month ago former New York Magazine editor Kurt Andersen had been boasting about how easy it had been to raise $28m of Wall Street capital for his new media and entertainment website, Inside.com: 'As easy as getting laid in 1969,' he'd said.

But that was then.

fields.headline: 'Merger fever' threatens Virgin
fields.standfirst: The prospect of fresh competition has Richard Branson feeling anxious, reports Joanna Walters
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson declared last week that he is more worried about his airline Virgin Atlantic than at any time since he started the business 16 years ago.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson declared last week that he is more worried about his airline Virgin Atlantic than at any time since he started the business 16 years ago.

The reason is not hard to find: it lies in the new open skies deal that could be struck this summer that will allow fresh competition between Heathrow - the world's busiest and most important airport - and the US.

British and American civil servants meet in London on Tuesday and will talk again in Washington next month about the highest chance for 26 years to open the skies across the north Atlantic.

Virgin Atlantic feels threatened. More threatened than ever before might be an exaggeration, given the travails it went through in the early Nineties. But Branson is afraid.

He told The Observer this weekend: 'We will fight this tooth and nail. No government has ever indicated in 16 years that they would throw in the towel to the US.'

Could more of the giant US airlines piling into Heathrow mean the end for Virgin Atlantic? 'No. But we would be competing with our hands tied behind our back,' said Branson.

The airline is a vital cash generator for the Virgin group and Branson conceded that it would be damaged unless he, too, joined one of the large airline partnerships now emerging, in order to find strength in numbers.

Britain's other two major scheduled airlines, British Airways and British Midland, support the idea of a new agreement to open up Heathrow gradually.

BA has opposed such a move for years and has long been accused by airlines such as Virgin of trying to stifle competition - with the backing of the UK Government. But BA wants to cement its long courtship with Dallas-based giant American Airlines (AA). BA appears reluctantly to accept that extra access for US airlines to Heathrow must be conceded in return.

This led BA chairman Lord Marshall to tell the parliamentary transport select committee last week: 'I would be disappointed if the UK-US talks failed. There is an opportunity over the next few months and if we get nowhere we would be no further forward with our alliance with American Airlines.'

BA believes the UK should not play the 'ace card' - access to Heathrow - unless it is allowed initially to market its flights jointly with AA. After that it wants the power to seek immunity from the US anti-trust cartel laws so the two giant airlines can effectively merge their transatlantic operations.

British Midland has plans to launch its own transatlantic services and play a full part in the powerful Star alliance, led by its partners, United Airlines of Chicago and Germany's Lufthansa. It is fighting on a platform of launching a business class fares war on the Atlantic. The UK Government appears to be on the side of BA and BM. Where does that leave loner Virgin?

'Screwed,' said one City analyst bluntly last week. Branson has a limited alliance with Continental Airlines and is now 49 per cent owned by Singapore Airlines (SIA) on the other side of the world.

Branson told the select committee: 'If we did not set up our own domestic airline in the US there is a possibility we could lose our shirt across the Atlantic.'

But the UK Government has given every indication that it is going to give up fighting for UK carriers to have the right to start their own airlines in the US. It's one they cannot win.

Branson's only alternative is a substantial alliance in the US. He warned that 'if competitors are damaged irreparably, that will damage the consumer', should BA and AA win anti-trust immunity. Branson is taking the 'all or nothing' approach - arguing for completely free access and merger rights between Europe and the US. But an airline industry source familiar with Virgin's strategy said: 'This is a polite way of saying "We do not want any more competition in the meantime."

'The idea of Branson starting his own domestic airline in the US, so-called "cabotage", is a complete red herring, as is the issue of investment in US airlines.' He needs to stop the deal because it threatens him and his current stance is a way of doing it without appearing anti-competitive.

Branson was adamant this weekend, however, complaining at the launch of his flights to Las Vegas that he was free to buy a casino in the city if he wanted but not an airline. The source said: 'An impartial observer would say that Virgin are protecting themselves against new entrants. Particularly British Midland, which is linking up with the largest airline in the world in United.

It is difficult to read how the UK-US talks over the next month will be influenced by the spectacular outbreak of merger fever that has just hit the US and European industries. United Airlines has announced it will buy US Airways and suddenly American wants to buy Northwest, or maybe Delta. BA wants to extend its alliance with AA and, as The Observer revealed last month, buy KLM - which just happens to be the partner of Northwest.

If a deal is struck and Virgin Atlantic suffers, where does that leave the Virgin Group? Question marks were raised late last year when Virgin's Our Price record chain ran up losses of £172 million in bank debts. Branson confessed the money men wanted to 'grab the cash in the tills' after the Christmas shopping season and close the business down. 'We have never let a company go,' he said.

Instead of paying off debts he waited. Waited, in fact, until he had stashed the £400 million net proceeds from the sale of 49 per cent of Virgin Atlantic to SIA. At that point he settled with the banks and decided to save Our Price by turning it into a mobile telephone retailer.

Virgin admitted to the Economist in April that without the money from SIA, Virgin would have had to approach the trustees of Branson's offshore family trusts, which are the ultimate controllers of his 200-plus separate companies.

The trusts invest and lend to Branson's businesses, mainly drawing on the proceeds from the £600 million sale of the Virgin music business to EMI in 1992.

The trusts would have been paid back out of Virgin Atlantic's summer revenues. The financial position of the private trusts, based in the Channel Islands, is secret. Add to the Our Price scrape the drain on group resources from the start-up V2 record label, the missed targets for Virgin Cola and cosmetics and clothes venture Victory and losses at the Virgin Express cut-price airline in Brussels, and cracks appear in the billionaire's empire.

But Branson is ebullient: 'The group is cash rich. The banks gave us two months to negotiate on Our Price. They ended up happy, with more money than they would have got from the tills, and we saved the shops and paid the banks less than we would have if we had not negotiated.'

Branson said the group had raised £1.5 billion from deals in the last year, including the sale of Virgin cinemas, Virgin radio and the stake in the air line, as well as the recent investment of $500m by Singapore Telecommunications into his Asian mobile phone venture.

'We have no companies that lose any large sums of money at all. Our Price is the worst hit we've had. We invest when we make money.' he said.

The deal with SIA valued Virgin Atlantic at £1.2bn. It is almost impossible to value the group or Branson's personal wealth. It is all tied up in aircraft, paper hidden in the trusts and brand values. He said: 'We only become worth a lot of money if we sell out.'

Shouldn't he throw his empire's finances open to public scrutiny if he expects to put his name to the next national lottery franchise, being decided between incumbent Camelot and a rival consortium in which Branson has an interest?

'Let the Lottery Commission decide,' he said. 'Virgin is a cash-rich group in, I suspect, the best position we have ever been in.'

While the group remains private, it is hard to argue.

'Screwed,' said one City analyst bluntly last week. Branson has a limited alliance with Continental Airlines and is now 49 per cent owned by Singapore Airlines (SIA) on the other side of the world. Branson told the select committee: 'If we did not set up our own domestic airline in the US there is a possibility we could lose our shirt across the Atlantic.' But the UK Government has given every indication that it is going to give up fighting for UK carriers to have the right to start their own airlines in the US. It's one they cannot win. Branson's only alternative is a substantial alliance in the US. He warned that 'if competitors are damaged irreparably, that will damage the consumer', should BA and AA win anti-trust immunity. Branson is taking the 'all or nothing' approach - arguing for completely free access and merger rights between Europe and the US. But an airline industry source familiar with Virgin's strategy said: 'This is a polite way of saying "We do not want any more competition in the meantime." 'The idea of Branson starting his own domestic airline in the US, so-called "cabotage", is a complete red herring, as is the issue of investment in US airlines.' He needs to stop the deal because it threatens him and his current stance is a way of doing it without appearing anti-competitive. Branson was adamant this weekend, however, complaining at the launch of his flights to Las Vegas that he was free to buy a casino in the city if he wanted but not an airline. The source said: 'An impartial observer would say that Virgin are protecting themselves against new entrants. Particularly British Midland, which is linking up with the largest airline in the world in United. It is difficult to read how the UK-US talks over the next month will be influenced by the spectacular outbreak of merger fever that has just hit the US and European industries. United Airlines has announced it will buy US Airways and suddenly American wants to buy Northwest, or maybe Delta. BA wants to extend its alliance with AA and, as The Observer revealed last month, buy KLM - which just happens to be the partner of Northwest. If a deal is struck and Virgin Atlantic suffers, where does that leave the Virgin Group? Question marks were raised late last year when Virgin's Our Price record chain ran up losses of £172 million in bank debts. Branson confessed the money men wanted to 'grab the cash in the tills' after the Christmas shopping season and close the business down. 'We have never let a company go,' he said. Instead of paying off debts he waited. Waited, in fact, until he had stashed the £400 million net proceeds from the sale of 49 per cent of Virgin Atlantic to SIA. At that point he settled with the banks and decided to save Our Price by turning it into a mobile telephone retailer. Virgin admitted to the Economist in April that without the money from SIA, Virgin would have had to approach the trustees of Branson's offshore family trusts, which are the ultimate controllers of his 200-plus separate companies. The trusts invest and lend to Branson's businesses, mainly drawing on the proceeds from the £600 million sale of the Virgin music business to EMI in 1992. The trusts would have been paid back out of Virgin Atlantic's summer revenues. The financial position of the private trusts, based in the Channel Islands, is secret. Add to the Our Price scrape the drain on group resources from the start-up V2 record label, the missed targets for Virgin Cola and cosmetics and clothes venture Victory and losses at the Virgin Express cut-price airline in Brussels, and cracks appear in the billionaire's empire. But Branson is ebullient: 'The group is cash rich. The banks gave us two months to negotiate on Our Price. They ended up happy, with more money than they would have got from the tills, and we saved the shops and paid the banks less than we would have if we had not negotiated.' Branson said the group had raised £1.5 billion from deals in the last year, including the sale of Virgin cinemas, Virgin radio and the stake in the air line, as well as the recent investment of $500m by Singapore Telecommunications into his Asian mobile phone venture. 'We have no companies that lose any large sums of money at all. Our Price is the worst hit we've had. We invest when we make money.' he said. The deal with SIA valued Virgin Atlantic at £1.2bn. It is almost impossible to value the group or Branson's personal wealth. It is all tied up in aircraft, paper hidden in the trusts and brand values. He said: 'We only become worth a lot of money if we sell out.' Shouldn't he throw his empire's finances open to public scrutiny if he expects to put his name to the next national lottery franchise, being decided between incumbent Camelot and a rival consortium in which Branson has an interest? 'Let the Lottery Commission decide,' he said. 'Virgin is a cash-rich group in, I suspect, the best position we have ever been in.' While the group remains private, it is hard to argue.

webTitle: Unilever is changing fast - is the fat in the fire?

fields.headline: Unilever is changing fast - is the fat in the fire?
fields.trailText: Unilever has been changing at least as much as P&G. Last week's $24.3 billion (£16bn) acquisition of Bestfoods, owner of brands such as Hellmann's and Knorr, was the culmination of a spending spree which has seen it mop up Ben & Jerry's ice cream, SlimFast and Grupo Cressida in South America, all within three months.
fields.body:
Niall FitzGerald, joint chairman of Unilever, must have felt a shiver down his spine as arch-rival Procter & Gamble announced the departure of Durk Jager, his counterpart at the US consumer products giant. Jager's successor, Alan Lafley, said: 'With hindsight, it's clear we changed too much too fast.'

Unilever has been changing at least as much as P&G. Last week's $24.3 billion (£16bn) acquisition of Bestfoods, owner of brands such as Hellmann's and Knorr, was the culmination of a spending spree which has seen it mop up Ben & Jerry's ice cream, SlimFast and Grupo Cressida in South America, all within three months.

Then there is the small matter of Path to Growth, the restructuring programme announced in February, which will see it shed 10 per cent of its workforce, close 100 factories and cull 1,200 of its 1,600 brands. Will that prove too much, too fast, for Unilever?

Naturally, FitzGerald is confident that it will not. SlimFast and Ben & Jerry's may have cost $2.6bn between them but, for a company with sales of $45bn, those were small deals. Bestfoods may be much larger but, leaving aside the bakery products division which it will almost certainly sell, the business will account for just a quarter of Unilever's food business.

The other parts of the division - and Unilever's other business - will be unaffected by the deal if not by the restructuring. Analysts say that part of the attraction of Bestfoods to Unilever is the quality of its management, and FitzGerald hopes that the 'vast majority' will stay.

Certainly Bestfoods performance has been much better than Unilever's. Over the last five years, the US group has increased sales by 4.7 per cent and earnings by 14.7 per cent. Last year, its margins before depreciation were 18.4 per cent.

That is a sharp contrast with Unilever, which has been struggling to increase sales, and where margins in the first quarter of the year were just 11.2 per cent. That is partly because Bestfoods brands are in growing markets: more and more of us are choosing convenience foods which we can cook quickly, such as Knorr soups and sauces, while trying to cut out Unilever's fats.

Adding those faster-growing brands should make a dif ference to Unilever's performance: its sales growth target has been lifted from 5 per cent to 6 per cent, and it is now promising margins of between 16 and 17 per cent by 2004, up from its previous goal of 15 per cent. And it is promising some chunky synergy benefits: $750m by 2003 from eliminating overlaps and combining suppliers.

If the deal lives up to its promise, it should be good for Unilever. But that is a big if. FitzGerald has proved himself one of the most able and innovative Unilever chairmen for decades. But even he cannot alter the fact that it is a big, unwieldy and inherently conservative group. Forcing radical change through a smaller, enterprising company would be hard enough. Implementing it at Unilever is, as P&G's experience shows, fraught with pitfalls.

That said, FitzGerald's record, combined with Unilever's lowly rating, means he should be given the benefit of the doubt. Buy, but be prepared to wait for results.

Going nowhere

John Peace, new chief executive of Great Universal Stores, must envy Luc Vandevelde, his Marks & Spencer counterpart. Getting sales moving at M&S may look daunting but it is as easy as selling ice creams in summer compared to the task of stabilising a home-shopping business in accelerating decline.

GUS did at least admit last week that it - or at least the previous management - should take the blame for failing to act sooner. It is easy to see why they were reluctant to change. Home shopping through big book catalogues has been declining gradually for decades, but it still threw off masses of cash which could be recycled into more interesting businesses - property, consumer finance, Burberry and, more recently, ecommerce. Throw in a bit of inflation, which gave the illusion of growth in sales, and the business didn't look that broke.

It could have carried on doing nothing for another decade had it not been for the disappearance of inflation. As both Matalan and M&S will attest, that has made consumers price conscious. Catalogues like GUS's, where prices are fixed for six months not to mention inflated by the need to recoup the costs of the 'free' credit and agent's commission, were always going to be first in the firing line.

The acquisition of Argos shows that GUS saw what was coming. The problem is, it seemed to think that buying Argos was enough on its own. Instead of merging it with its home shopping arm, it simply let the two carry on their separate paths.

Two years on, it is finally carrying out the integration. It promises £80m of savings and a much more loyal customer base to which it will sell credit cards and a variety of other financial services. That means shedding unprofitable customers from its 4 million-strong list - GUS will not say exactly how many are loss-making but it is likely to be a high proportion.

The fall in sales will be compensated for by extra sales from Additions, the catalogue distributed through Argos stores which carries a similar product range to the mail order book but at much lower prices. Based on the tests carried out so far, it expects sales as high as £300m a year. But Additions will not be available nationwide until next year, so it is impossible to judge how realistic that figure is. The strategy sounds sensible enough. The trouble is that, even if it achieves all the cost savings it promises, home shopping will still be a business going nowhere. Emily Shamma at WestLB Panmure estimates that, even with the full £80m savings, it will make just £30m profit in three years time, only £9m more than last year.

Unfortunately, there are no real alternatives. Selling it would mean GUS loses the logistics business which is so crucial to its ecommerce plans - besides, buyers are hardly queuing up. Withdrawing from agency and converting to a direct selling business would involve such enormous costs, and at least an initial slump in sales, that even a private equity buyer would baulk at it.

To make matters worse, its Experian information services is not growing quite as fast as both GUS and the City had hoped. GUS's shares may be near rock bottom but that does not make them cheap. Until it is clear that there is a solution to the home shopping disaster, there is no point buying.

webTitle: Cheer up Bill, the PC is on its way out anyway

fields.headline: Cheer up Bill, the PC is on its way out anyway
fields.trailText: Question: How many Microsoft programmers does it take to change a light bulb? Answer: none - Bill Gates defines darkness as the standard.
fields.body:
Question: How many Microsoft programmers does it take to change a light bulb? Answer: none - Bill Gates defines darkness as the standard. However gratifying Judge Jackson's predictable ruling might be, one has the nagging feeling that it won't make much difference in the long run.

This has nothing to do with the fact that the appeal process will drag on so long that by the time it gets to the Supreme Court everyone will have forgotten what it was all about in the first place. No, the main reason for feeling relaxed is that Microsoft's dominance is of the personal computer and the PC as we know it is doomed.

Let me explain. The PC is an incredibly complex device because it is a general-purpose machine. With the appropriate software you can use it to process words, do numerical calculations, create dazzling graphics, edit video and audiotapes, listen to the radio, play music CDs, send email, browse the web, chat to other people online, create genealogical charts of your family, build a database of bootleg Elvis recordings and so on ad infinitum.

The present-day PC, in other words, is a bit like the domestic electric motors that appeared on the market in the early years of the last century. I have before me as I write a page from the 1918 Sears, Roebuck catalogue. Under the heading 'Aids that Every Woman Appreciates' [sic] it extols the virtues of the 'Home Motor'. With the right attachments, the ad explains, one can use the motor to power a fan, drive a sewing machine, power a portable vibrator ('very useful and satisfactory for home service'), drive a butter churn, whip cream, mix dough, etc.

The electric motor was the ultimate in domestic high-tech in 1918. But spool forward 80 years and look what's happened. Electric motors are everywhere - in wristwatches, in hi-fi systems, VCR machines, cameras, fax machines, shavers, toothbrushes - and, yes, even in vibrators.

Electric motors have become ubiquitous, miniaturised, highly-specialised and, well, invisible. Why? Because in the end people value specialised machines which enable them to do specific jobs, rather than a clumsy generalised machine which, with the right attachments, can do anything.

Much the same will happen to the PC. Most people nowadays buy a PC because they want to send email and browse the web. But in order to do this they have to acquire an expensive, ludicrously over-powered, general-purpose machine which is extraordinarily difficult to master. What they really need is a simple device they can plug into the phone line, switch on and use to send and receive messages.

You have to be a masochist to use a PC. I was reminded of this many times last weekend when helping some friends come to grips with their first computer. Like the child who points out that the emperor has no clothes, my friends kept innocently revealing the absurdities and contradictions that us seasoned PC-addicts have accepted and internalised.

'How do you shut the machine down?' they asked. 'You click on the start button,' I replied, and was hurt when they burst out laughing.

They plugged the modem into the phone jack and then asked why they weren't connected to the net. 'Ah well,' I said, 'first you have to launch a dial-up connection to log on and then you need to launch an email client and then you ...' 'Eh?' they said, and who could blame them?

The PC is doomed because the world supply of masochists like me is finite and already nearing saturation point. Any company whose fortunes are linked to it is likewise doomed. I don't suppose that Bill Gates realises it, but Judge Jackson has probably done him a favour.

fields.headline: Paralysed in the euro quicksand
fields.trailText: Are you old economy or new? For some time this office has been divided into those with a soft spot for cranes, and the young - and some not so young - Turks who spurn the hard hat in favour of weightless stock.
fields.body:
Are you old economy or new? For some time this office has been divided into those with a soft spot for cranes, and the young - and some not so young - Turks who spurn the hard hat in favour of weightless stock.

An even greater degree of partisanship was evident in the markets, where the scarf-waving for dotcoms made them Manchester United to the struggling Maine Roaders of boring old factories. Then the fashionable team turned out to have players who couldn't dribble, let alone score, and suddenly, as in real life, 'Man City' was promotable again.

Of course, this isn't the first time the economy has been too conveniently divided. Remember the early Eighties when the plight of industry was deemed to be unimportant because the service sector was going to support us all. Shipbuilding - not wanted on voyage. Cars - drive them in from the docks. Coal - send it to Newcastle, where it could be forgotten like all those Geordies who had nothing to contribute to the Thatcherite revolution.

And of course North versus South has always been with us. But these inflated divisions, and the favouring of one sector at a time, are mistaken. Any economy needs diversity, not least to hedge its bets against an uncertain future.

It is to be expected that there will be contradictory special pleading coming from different sectors within it. So it is unusual to hear almost all of British industry, and indeed agriculture, singing from the same hymn sheet. Their anthem? That the overvalued pound is making exporting impossible, undermining production by forcing the use of more overseas components and destroying jobs.

You would think that, faced with this chorus, a government would have acted. But this one has seemed paralysed by indecision. Of course, one does have some sympathy for them. Every Labour administration since Clement Attlee slipped into Downing Street has been forced to devalue, castigated by the Tories for its unpatriotic failure to manage the economy and eventually beaten by the voters.

Now, it could be argued that there were other factors in Harold Wilson's 1970 defeat by Ted Heath - not least his growing reputation as a slippery character who refused to face up to harsh decisions - and that Uncle Jim Callaghan might have survived in '79 had it not been for the 'winter of discontent'.

But even if historically-minded Ministers accepted this, it is not at the heart of their problem. Their chief worry is that one cannot even discuss sterling without talk of the euro, and suddenly you're back in the quicksand of Britain's position in Europe. One false move, thinks Hysterical of Millbank, and it's 'Bye bye sovereignty' in the press and bye bye the elusive voters of Middle England, driven into the open arms of W Hague.

Under the circumstances it was surprising that last Friday Stephen Byers came out so strongly in favour of euro membership. Admittedly the Trade and Industry Secretary has been 'beleaguered' for some time, and may have figured he might as well nail his colours to some sort of mast before he was becalmed in a Cabinet reshuffle. And now he apparently has the PM's backing.

But when you look beyond the headlines even Byers is only talking of 'the debate beginning to start' and that 'the case will need to be made' before public opinion looks 'very hard at the benefits and disadvantages of joining'. It all sounds like a project that can be allowed years to get off the ground. Or at least one year.

The Government must be hoping that, with a little bit of industrial aid here and a focus on their core issues of education and health (keep your fingers crossed that the Chancellor's largesse massages those class sizes and waiting lists in time, lads), the election will be safely won and it can contemplate the sterling/euro conundrum across the safe expanse of another term.

But what then? The problem, like the song, remains the same. Intervention in the markets will still seem as doomed to failure, and our economic cycle could be just as out of kilter with the pumping pedals of our Continental cousins. The only question is how many extra jobs will have been lost, how many perfectly useful and otherwise sound components of the British economy thrown away?

Perhaps Ministers should remember that you gain no credit for an action you have been forced to take. Previous Labour governments devalued when they were absolutely cornered - when it was too late. Must history repeat itself?

Perhaps Ministers should remember that you gain no credit for an action you have been forced to take. Previous Labour governments devalued when they were absolutely cornered - when it was too late. Must history repeat itself?

fields.headline: Down on the farm
fields.standfirst: Sterling's strength is adding to agricultural job losses, says Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: British agriculture really is in crisis. The industry lost 22,000 full-time jobs last year - one in 12 of the workforce, says the National Farmers' Union. A similar number are likely to go this year.
fields.body:
The everday story of countryfolk that is Radio 4's long-running soap opera The Archers contains many commercial mysteries. How do Nigel and Elizabeth run a conference centre without any apparent secretarial help? Why does the Bull lurch so quickly from financial crisis to seeming prosperity and back again?

But two recent storylines are absolutely grounded in commercial reality: the Grundys bankrupted and losing their farm, and the Archers themselves getting out of pig farming.

British agriculture really is in crisis. The industry lost 22,000 full-time jobs last year - one in 12 of the workforce, says the National Farmers' Union. A similar number are likely to go this year. Redundancies are now spreading to farm equipment makers and their sales staffs. But as job losses to any one company are few, they rarely make news.

According to the Countryside Agency, the Government's official adviser, the rural counties of Cornwall, Northumberland and Shropshire have the lowest weekly wages in England. Cornwall's, at £292, is £98 below the national average.

And economic activity in the countryside has been undermined by a rash of shop, pub and post office closures. In addition, social cohesion is strained by an influx of rich city slickers. In one Wiltshire village, says the agency, a third of the households live on incomes below £6,000, while a further third pull in more than £40,000.

British farming is being killed by a worldwide drop in commodity prices, caused partly by an oversupply of food. In Britain, the strength of sterling, particularly against the euro, is causing acute pain. British farmers' efforts are uncompetitive on the Continent, and their Common Agricultural Policy subsidy is paid in euros, making it less valuable than before.

James Black farms pigs in mid-Suffolk. He owns 5,000 sows and employs 75 staff, which puts him in the big league. Black says his business has 'fallen dramatically over the last two years'.

He is competing in a world economy in which one American firm, Smithfields, owns more sows than the entire UK sow population of 640,000.

Black attributes the collapse of British pig farming, which is losing £4 million a week, to increased welfare costs associated with the BSE crisis, high production in other European Union countries and the strong pound.

Last year, the strength of sterling cost the British pig industry £1.5m a week. 'We can't compete and we're not making any money,' says Black. 'Prices are beginning to come back to where they were in April 1998 but our sector is in decline and we're all suffering.'

UK food manufacturers are now moving production overseas. The Unigate food processing subsidiary Malton Foods last week revealed that the amount of pork it imports has tripled over the last two years to 40 per cent. It blames sterling's strength.

The UK farming crisis is unlikely to change. If the EU is to enlarge, it won't be able to pay the current levels of subsidies to farmers. In addition, debate is raging within the World Trade Organisation over how farm subsidies should fall.

The only comfort for the industry is that last month's entry of China to the WTO may give farmers a new market. Even then, it will take years to establish.

On Friday, Vincent Watts, vice-chancellor of the University of East Anglia and chairman of the East of England Development Agency, will blame the strong pound for undermining farmers. 'Farming endured the equivalent of a Longbridge closure last year,' Watts will say at the East of England Agricultural Show. 'And it could be worse this year. In 1984, spot grain prices were £130 a tonne. Four years ago they were £120. Today they are £70. The average income for a farmer is £6,000. That's below the minimum wage.'

Watts will urge the Government to set up an emergency fund similar to the package won by the coal industry last April. This would be on top of the cash provided by the Agriculture Ministry to help farmers; it should be used to provide business training for farmers and to support new rural businesses.

The battle, he says, is to shift the rural economy from being too reliant on farming. If this sounds perverse, it has to be remembered that commodity prices are unlikely to rise for several years.

In less than three months, John Prescott's Department of Transport, Environment and the Regions will publish a Rural White Paper. It may propose a small tourism tax, which would go into the local economy, and road tolls in popular areas to cut congestion. A key part of the White Paper will be to revitalise Britain's 900 market towns.

One idea, advocated by Ewen Cameron, chairman of the Countryside Agency, would see teams of experts going into market towns, drawing up regeneration contracts with 'stakeholders' and inviting in agencies like English Heritage, housing associations or National Lottery bodies, depending on whether a town needed restoring, more social housing or more leisure provision.

Watts and others hope the White Paper plans will include relaxing tough interpretations of the planning laws protecting much of the country, so farmers can apply to change the use of their land. Many want to diversify and start small businesses.

Such moves will be politically explosive and refocus the arguments about what the countryside is for, and who owns it. But it is not only the farming lobby which fears that if such proposals are not implemented the countryside's decline will be terminal.

webTitle: The bubble that has to be burst

fields.headline: The bubble that has to be burst
fields.standfirst: Bankers' bank is worried about optimism, says William Keegan
fields.trailText: The instability of the world's foreign exchange and stock markets is a major theme of the annual report of the Bank for International Settlements. The BIS warns that 'ironically, as history has repeatedly shown, even well-founded optimism has the insidious tendency to transform itself into excess'.
fields.body:
The instability of the world's foreign exchange and stock markets is a major theme of the annual report of the Bank for International Settlements. The BIS warns that 'ironically, as history has repeatedly shown, even well-founded optimism has the insidious tendency to transform itself into excess'.

Known as 'the central bankers' bank', the Basle-based BIS was one of the few official institutions that sounded the alert about a possible East Asian crisis in 1997. It now says the unexpectedly speedy recovery may reduce the sense of urgency for economic reform in Asia - 'short-term optimism', it says, may tend 'to undermine the very foundations necessary for longer-term optimism'.

But its biggest worry is the continuing euphoria about the US economy, and the dangers of a hard landing via a collapse of Wall Street and the dollar. The bank has little difficulty accounting for the weakness of the euro during most of the past 18 months. While the euro-zone has run a current account balance of payments surplus, it has exported masses of capital to the US and Japan, which depressed the exchange rate.

'What is indisputable,' says the BIS, 'is that there were large recorded outflows of longer-term capital from Europe into both the US and Japan, primarily into high-tech sectors promising attractive rates of return. In a sense the newly created euro may have proved too successful. Larger and more liquid markets, with relatively low interest rates, encouraged the issue of euro-denominated bonds whose proceeds could then be exchanged and used to finance investment elsewhere.'

The capital flows meant that 'despite the further rise in the US current account deficit, the US dollar was largely stable in effective terms.'

The BIS puts the US expansion that attracted so much capital into historical perspective. 'Even during the last four years, average [US] growth only just reached that of the expansion of the Eighties and remained well short of the Sixties,' it points out.

The BIS believes that in the US 'equity prices and the financial wealth of households have increased by more than can be justified by the rise in potential growth to about 3.25 per cent, implying that the demand-side effects of higher productivity growth have outpaced the supply-side effects.' The equity and investment boom has coincided with a squeeze on profit margins and higher corporate debt.

The bank warns that 'a fall in US equity markets, coupled with a weakening dollar, could potentially exert a deflationary influence on the rest of the world'. On the other hand it concludes that 'The relationship between exchange rate movements and stock market returns is weak.'

While sharing the general view that the dollar is overvalued and the euro undervalued, the BIS points out that 'taking a "synthetic" euro as the benchmark, the euro touched a 13-year low against the dollar in March 2000, but was still trading well above its all-time low reached in the mid-Eighties'.

The BIS estimates that the euro last year was only 4 per cent below its Nineties average.

'The biggest policy challenge,' it says, 'could be coping with a sudden reversal in the fortunes of the dollar. The additional disinflationary impact on Japan would clearly be unwelcome, although much less so in Europe, where inflationary concerns have mounted.'

Nevertheless, deflationary problems could arise 'if a rebound of the euro went too far and too fast'.

As an illustration of just how volatile the foreign exchange markets can be, the BIS notes that 'from its lows in 1998 to its highs in early 2000, the yen posted an almost 45 per cent gain against the dollar, and a 65 per cent appreciation against the euro'.

It says both the strength of the yen and the weakness of the euro have been inconsistent with domestic policy objectives, and wonders what might be done. 'The current answer appears to be, not much. One reason might be concerns in Europe that intervention would be misread as signalling a dilution of the commitment of the newly created central bank to price stability.

'And as for multilateral intervention involving the US, concerns have been expressed that this might be interpreted as a harbinger of a managed global exchange-rate system, for which there currently seems to be little official enthusiasm.'

The BIS, while greatly concerned about asset price bubbles, concludes that they are difficult to deflate 'gently'. Slight policy tightening by central banks can renew the market's confidence in the boom.

'Policymakers can arguably only eliminate perceived bubbles by tightening aggressively,' it concludes. In any case, certainty that there is a bubble may only emerge well into the cycle, when 'it may be too late for policymakers to insulate the economy from the consequences of an asset price adjustment'.

In other words the central banks may find that the only way to deflate the bubble is to burst it.

webTitle: British Energy to buy Millstone plant

fields.headline: British Energy to buy Millstone plant
fields.trailText: Nuclear generator British Energy is lining up the Millstone nuclear power station in Connecticut as its next acquisition in the US.
fields.body:
Nuclear generator British Energy is lining up the Millstone nuclear power station in Connecticut as its next acquisition in the US.

The Edinburgh-based company, which is also negotiating a £1 billion deal for two nuclear power stations in Canada, is keen to keep up momentum on US acquisitions.

Millstone's owner, Northeast Utilities, said last year that it wanted to sell the 2000 megawatt plant by this summer.

Sources close to British Energy say that recent discussions between its US Amergen joint venture and Northeast indicate that it will be sold within two months.

Amergen - which it 50 per cent owns with Peco Energy of Philadelphia - has been in constant contact with US utilities which are looking to sell plants because of deregulation in American electricity markets.

'Amergen is interested in any plant that comes along. Millstone is up for sale and it is very likely to be the next one in line,' said one.

In addition to the negotiations on the Canadian stations - Bruce A and B in Ontario - British Energy has already bought five other US stations: two at Nine Mile Point in New York State, one at Three Mile Island (TMI) in Pennsylvania, and one each in Illinois and Vermont.

British Energy has been linked with the Millstone plant before, but has played down speculation that it would make an offer.

But its chief executive, Peter Hollins, is keen to continue expansion in the US, as the outlook for UK electricity prices is bleak. Prices have dropped dramatically this year, hitting electricity generators.

He believes the US operation is proving highly successful. A high proportion of costs for nuclear plants comes from financing initial construction, but several of the US plants were bought for very small sums - TMI, for example was $23 million plus fuel costs - and have proved to operate well and profitably. Hollins has said that Amergen's holdings of plants could move into double figures.

fields.headline: Let them in. It'll pay
fields.standfirst: Often vilified, immigrants could be vital to pay pensions, reports Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: The term 'economic migrant' has pejorative overtones: would-be workers are vilified as sponging squeegee merchants or benefit fraudsters.
fields.body:
The term 'economic migrant' has pejorative overtones: would-be workers are vilified as sponging squeegee merchants or benefit fraudsters.

But while politicians compete to reduce the incentives for coming here, the Department for Education and Employment is devising economic incentives to lure highly skilled workers - presumably also economic migrants - to fill acute skills shortages.

In the US there are moves to lift the cap on foreign high-tech workers, and a remarkable coalition of conservatives, liberals and trade unions is pushing for a total amnesty for up to 6 million illegal immigrant workers. Even Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has given tacit approval.

But make no mistake, this is not a bout of compassion. National self-interest is the driving force. Immigrants, legal and illegal, have played a vital role in the US in building the so-called 'Goldilocks' economy (strong technology-driven growth that nonetheless avoids inflation). Western European demographics also point to the need for immigration. The economic migrant will be essential, it seems, to protect your state pension.

Analysis of migration has been traditionally couched in negative terms. Mass population movement has been closely entwined with slavery, bonded labour and expulsions.

More generally, 'pub' economics leads to negative sentiment towards immigrant labour which is seen as displacing native workers from their jobs. This is based on the fallacy that there is a fixed number of jobs available.

But economic development depends on waves of migration. The oldest 'stages of development' theories emphasise that rural-urban migration is a key engine of economic growth. Applied globally, this means that though capital is mobile, restricting labour mobility inhibits optimum production.

Similarly, trade theory suggests that free movement of labour across borders is a necessary counterpart to free capital movements. Such theories are not just pie in the sky - they form the economic basis for the existence of the European Union.

Immigrant workers increase the size of the pie being prepared before slices can be taken from it. In purely demographic terms, this is because immigrants tend to be concentrated in age groups where people contribute more to the public coffers.

The EU population is declining and ageing rapidly. Overall population is expected to decline by five million in 25 years and by 40 million by 2050. It is also ageing at an unprecedented rate. A recent United Nations study said the EU will need 159 million immigrants to maintain the current ratio of people of working age to the retired population.

Net migration to the UK was 660,000 people between 1990 and 1998, an average of 73,000 a year. The UK population would remain constant if these numbers stayed the same. But net inward migration would have to double to maintain the current numbers of working people. Without it, the retirement age would have to rise to about 72 to maintain the 'support ratio' at 4.1 in 50 years.

In theory, one might dispute the contention that the 'support ratio' should stay constant. If there are wild jumps in productivity, perhaps aided by technology, then the required ratio of working to non-working people could go down, obviating the need for immigration.

But the recent leaps in productivity associated with technology are rooted in immigrant labour, and these foreigners are most definitely 'economic migrants'.

In the US, from corporate boardrooms and influential venture capital firms to the Ivy League business schools and saffron start-ups, it is workers from India who are making their mark on Silicon Valley and the internet economy, driving growth.

Immigrants made up 32 per cent of Silicon Valley's scientific and engineering workforce in 1990, and that number will have increased thanks to a loosening of immigration restrictions, according to a report by AnnaLee Saxenian, a University of California professor at Berkeley. It showed that Chinese and Indian engineers were senior executives in businesses that together accounted for more than $16.8 billion in sales and 58,282 jobs.

There is concern, however, that developed nations might siphon off the cream of developing countries' talent, setting back their economic development further - although the increasing trend for Asian expats to invest heavily in their country of origin would mitigate this.

The success of immigration of the highly skilled has not been lost on EU governments. Germany and the UK have announced schemes to attract high-tech workers along the lines of the American H-1B programme, which allows skilled foreigners to work in the US. The US scheme is set to expand from 115,000 visas to 200,000. From October 1998 to March 1999, 46 per cent of the visas went to Indians.

The German government's plan to issue 20,000 special visas is under threat because conservative politicians want the money that would be spent on Indian workers to go into education. Schooling is clearly a good long-term aim, but the skills shortage is here and now.

According to research by the International Data Corporation and Microsoft, by 2003 Europe will lack 1.7 million technology workers. The cost of that would be it £232bn.

The UK will be among the hardest hit: 14 per cent short of the high-tech workers it requires. There are already 50,000 IT vacancies here, but only around 18,000 graduates coming out of university. Industry bodies said that training unskilled workers would take a minimum of five years. An Arthur Andersen report forecasts 80,000 unfilled vacancies in the internet economy by 2002.

Inflationary pressures will build up if these are not filled - in practical terms, highly-skilled foreign workers will mean that British technical staff will not be able to charge such a high premium for their services, and might lose out.

The 6 million illegal immigrants in the US - many from its poorer neighbours - mainly work in low-skilled, poorly paid jobs and are often open to exploitation. Rarely are they considered the object of union sympathy. But it is their role in tempering simmering inflationary pressures that is leading to calls for an amnesty.

In practice, this means that some poor immigrants receive real wages that are lower than people who did the same jobs 20 years ago. It explains why the immigration enforcement agencies have been relaxed about illegal employment.

Some economists have suggested that entry visas should be auctioned, a process that would naturally select highly-skilled immigrants.

But this seems a long way off when Scandinavian immigrants such as Linus Torvalds, inventor of the Linux operating system - considered a challenger to Microsoft Windows - is still waiting for his Green Card.

The US scheme is set to expand from 115,000 visas to 200,000. From October 1998 to March 1999, 46 per cent of the visas went to Indians. The German government's plan to issue 20,000 special visas is under threat because conservative politicians want the money that would be spent on Indian workers to go into education. Schooling is clearly a good long-term aim, but the skills shortage is here and now. According to research by the International Data Corporation and Microsoft, by 2003 Europe will lack 1.7 million technology workers. The cost of that would be it £232bn. The UK will be among the hardest hit: 14 per cent short of the high-tech workers it requires. There are already 50,000 IT vacancies here, but only around 18,000 graduates coming out of university. Industry bodies said that training unskilled workers would take a minimum of five years. An Arthur Andersen report forecasts 80,000 unfilled vacancies in the internet economy by 2002. Inflationary pressures will build up if these are not filled - in practical terms, highly-skilled foreign workers will mean that British technical staff will not be able to charge such a high premium for their services, and might lose out. The 6 million illegal immigrants in the US - many from its poorer neighbours - mainly work in low-skilled, poorly paid jobs and are often open to exploitation. Rarely are they considered the object of union sympathy. But it is their role in tempering simmering inflationary pressures that is leading to calls for an amnesty. In practice, this means that some poor immigrants receive real wages that are lower than people who did the same jobs 20 years ago. It explains why the immigration enforcement agencies have been relaxed about illegal employment. Some economists have suggested that entry visas should be auctioned, a process that would naturally select highly-skilled immigrants. But this seems a long way off when Scandinavian immigrants such as Linus Torvalds, inventor of the Linux operating system - considered a challenger to Microsoft Windows - is still waiting for his Green Card.

webTitle: Rates uncertainty takes its pound of flesh

fields.headline: Rates uncertainty takes its pound of flesh
fields.standfirst: John Grieve Smith says it is time to put exchange rates on the agenda for the 'new global architecture'
fields.trailText: The worst may be over as far as the over-valuation of the pound is concerned; but the problem for industry is that no one knows how far it will fall - or how long it will stay there. It is not just periodic over-valuation, but the instability of sterling that plagues industry
fields.body:
The worst may be over as far as the over-valuation of the pound is concerned; but the problem for industry is that no one knows how far it will fall - or how long it will stay there. It is not just periodic over-valuation, but the instability of sterling that plagues industry. When exchange rates are so uncertain, it is difficult for firms to make sales plans or determine labour requirements even a few months ahead, let alone make decisions to invest in new capacity which may take years to come to fruition.

This is not just a British problem. As firms increasingly function on an international scale, the need for exchange rate stability becomes greater if they are to invest and operate effectively. The recent difficulties in the motor industry are just one example.

While floating rates have become excessively volatile, a return to the post-war Bretton Woods system of so-called 'fixed' rates is not the answer. Exchange rates need to be adjusted with changing circumstances, not left until weaker countries eventually become forced to devalue in crisis conditions. 'Pegging' currencies to a major currency, such as the dollar, raises similar problems. Currency unions, such as Emu, avoid this difficulty, but they are only a workable solution for groups of countries already integrated.

The answer is to look for ways of managing exchange rates in a flexible manner. This must be done on a two-tier basis, regionally and globally - since it is only practical to operate such arrangements between a limited number of countries.

There are lessons to be learnt from experience with the exchange rate mechanism (ERM). The first is the need to adjust rates relatively frequently and by small amounts, rather than waiting to make major adjustments when they have become well out of line. For example, in an ERM-type system with +/-2.5 per cent bands, parities might be reviewed monthly and changes made in steps of say, 1 per cent. The new parity would then still be within the old band, and the changes in spot rates following the monthly review would not provide scope for the sort of major speculative gains associated with sterling's exit from the ERM in 1992.

The second lesson is the need to build in arrangements for automatic intervention if the agreed bands are threatened. This should be the responsibility of a special fund with borrowing powers, rather than left to central banks with limited resources.

Such an arrangement would be a particularly appropriate means of managing the relation between sterling (and the currencies of other EU members outside Emu) and the euro. It would leave open the question of whether we eventually joined, but stabilise the sterling-euro relationship in the interim. To benefit British industry, however, it would be essential to agree a competitive rate for the pound. But with the Emu authorities worried about the weakness of the euro, this could be a good moment to negotiate a mutually beneficial deal which would lower the pound and strengthen the euro.

Such a new-style ERM should go hand in hand with arrangements to manage the rate between the euro and the dollar. This is particularly important for the UK. We should not want greater stability against the euro to be purchased at the cost of continuing instability against the dollar and other currencies. Such a limited arrangement should be expanded as soon as possible into a tripolar system involving the yen. This should evolve into a formal system under the IMF, with stated parities and bands, and effective intervention arrangements. We should see the development of regional currency arrangements in the western hemisphere and Asia based on the dollar and the yen.

One corollary of exchange rate stability would be that countries would no longer be free to use monetary policy as the sole instrument of demand management. Interest rates in different countries would have to remain broadly in line (after allowing for differences in inflation) and their level would reflect the general state of the world economy. Countries would then have to make more active use of budgetary policy to dampen or stimulate demand. This is the situation in Emu today, although the European Central Bank and governments have been slow to recognise it.

Gordon Brown may have thought that leaving demand management to the Monetary Policy Committee, and exchange rates to the workings of the market, would absolve him from the political crises that beset his predecessors. But it is clear that the electorate still blames the Government for crises in industry as it suffers from over-valuation. Perhaps he will now be more eager to put the question of stabilising exchange rates on the agenda for discussion of the new 'global financial architecture'. So far it has been conspicuous by its absence.

John Grieve Smith is the author of a forthcoming Fabian pamphlet 'Reforming the Global Financial System'.

fields.headline: Divergent views on convergence
fields.trailText: So the Oganisation for Economic Co-operation and Development says the British economy is converging on the eurozone, does it? Well, hang on a minute...
fields.body:
So the Oganisation for Economic Co-operation and Development says the British economy is converging on the eurozone, does it? Well, hang on a minute...

There is a difference between the way the OECD's 'verdict' has been reported, and what it actually said. The key point is that the OECD (or part of it) has concluded that Britain is likely to be 'as close, or even closer, to the economic centre of gravity of the euro area' than some existing, or prospective, members.

Thus the author of the OECD report is quoted as saying: 'If Greece is deemed fit to join, it would be strange if the UK wasn't.' You do not need to have been diverted from Oxford to Harvard to note that there are several deductive leaps in such interpretations. The fact, if fact it is, that some of the others have converged even less with the core European economies is not by any means reliable evidence that Britain is ready.

The OECD is a centre of excellence and does not always speak with one voice. Its half yearly Economic Outlook contains information which makes me reluctant to conclude that British performance is quite as good as it is cracked up to be, or that we are converging on the 'core' economy, Germany.

In its section on Germany, the OECD (writing a few days before the recent minor recover of the euro) notes: 'The euro has continued to depreciate, and despite last year's rise in unit labour costs, German competitiveness remains favourable.'

Wow, I thought! Unit labour costs are a worry in Germany are they? Well, yes, up to a point: further inspection reveals that 'unit labour costs increased by 0.7 per cent in 1999'. Even closer inspection unearths the fact that unit labour costs fell in Germany in 1997 (by 1.1 per cent) and 1998 (0.6 per cent) and are expected by the OECD to fall again (0.6 per cent) in celebration of this millennium year.

Perhaps, in raising interest rates sharply last week, the European Central Bank does not believe costs are falling enough in the 'core economy', but that is not my point. Let us now turn to the section on the British economy, where we find that unit labour costs rose by 3.3 per cent in 1997, by 5.1 per cent in 1998, by 4.1 per cent in 1999 and are expected to celebrate millennium year with a further 3.7 per cent rise.

As every good Keynesian knows, the course of unit labour costs is the key to domestically generated inflation. 'Core' inflation has little to do with the kind of monetary statistics cited by the ECB in justification of last week's rise. The Thatcher government discovered this in the early 1980s.

The good news is that Britain's core inflation rate is a lot lower than it used to be in the bad old days. It was because our unit labour costs tended to rise a lot faster than those of Germany that the pound had to be devalued against the D-mark over the years. It is no good saying, 'What good did those devaluations do?' The point is that they were necessary to put the British economy back on to level pegging with the German one. Otherwise our performance would have been even worse, because we should have been even more uncompetitive than we were.

Which brings us back to the euro: it is fashionable to say that the Chancellor's convergence tests are irrelevant, because the eventual decision will be political. It certainly will be, just as Chancellor Helmut Kohl overrode all the economic conditions the Bundesbank would have liked to impose before German monetary unification after the fall of the Wall.

But that does not mean Gordon Brown should not be doing everything in his power to make the British economy fitter, or less unfit, to join the eurozone.

At a seminar last week organised by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research and Vincent Cable MP, the former Bank of England economist Christopher Taylor (now at the NIESR) made the point that the famous five tests did not include the exchange rate. The seminar was entitled 'The High Exchange Rate: a Problem for Whom?' But Ed Balls, Chief Economic Adviser to the Treasury, gave the impression that one way of interpreting the Government's strategy is that it is trying to do everything it can to stabilise Britain's real exchange rate.

This might seem odd at a time when the exchange rate - both nominal and real - is causing such manifest problems. The OECD calculates, by the way, that our export performance will have deteriorated by about 15 per cent between 1997 and this year.

Given the trend of unit labour costs, the pound should have been falling in order to maintain price competitiveness. In fact, until its recent change of direction, it had been rising fast, thereby compounding the real exchange rate problem. And, paradoxically, the rise in the pound has been making our underlying inflation performance look better than it really is.

Balls made it clear that he saw the Government's emphasis on stability as a way of avoiding the pressures on demand that traditionally exacerbate the trend of unit costs and hence the real 'exchange' rate. In this we evidently have some way to go. Entry to the euro would remove a devaluation as a means of adjustment. All the emphasis then would be on doing a lot better on core inflation than at the moment.

William Keegan's book '2066 and All That', is published this week by Iynx, price £6.99.

webTitle: Doctors urge surgical intervention against Bupa

fields.headline: Doctors urge surgical intervention against Bupa
fields.trailText: Doctors are pressing the Government to block one of the biggest takeovers in the private health sector. The doctors are accusing market leader Bupa of trying to increase charges and reduce patient choice,
fields.body:
Doctors are pressing the Government to block one of the biggest takeovers in the private health sector. The doctors are accusing market leader Bupa of trying to increase charges and reduce patient choice,

Trade Secretary Stephen Byers must announce by Thursday whether he is going to refer Bupa's £230 million takeover of Community Hospitals to the Competition Commission.

If he waves the bid through, the Government faces further confrontation with the British Medical Association, which last week lambasted Government plans to alter the role of consultants.

The BMA has written to the Office of Fair Trading, stating: 'Bupa is continuing to acquire companies supplying hospital beds with the sole intention of reducing overall capacity in order that Bupa hospitals can subsequently increase their charges. The effect is to strengthen Bupa's control of individual clinicians and reduce patient choice.'

Bupa believes the BMA claims are unjustified.

The Consumers' Association and MPs from all parties have objected to the bid.
