fields.headline: Oryx float killed by FO
fields.standfirst: Link with Congo conflict scuppers diamond firm's ambitions  Adviser Grant Thornton quits
fields.trailText: Pressure from the Government has forced the controversial diamond mining company Oryx to pull its UK flotation, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
Pressure from the Government has forced the controversial diamond mining company Oryx to pull its UK flotation, The Observer can reveal.

Senior London Stock Exchange officials told advisers to Oryx, which has links to the Zimbabwe and Congo governments, that it would not be allowed to go ahead after objections from UK authorities.

It is understood that the Foreign Office pressed the exchange to halt the flotation. Government officials said there were concerns about the company's mining in the Democratic Republic of Congo, formerly Zaire.

The highly unusual Stock Exchange move came days after Oryx's adviser, Grant Thornton, stated: 'We are satisfied Oryx has fulfilled all appropriate criteria required for admission to the Alternative Investment Market.'

But after the exchange had closed last Friday, Grant Thornton wrote to tell Oryx it was no longer prepared to act as its adviser. UK stock exchange regulations say any company seeking a listing must be approved by independent advisers.

The Observer has established that a 'highly placed individual' approached the exchange regulators several days ago, expressing concern about the flotation. Peter Hain, the Foreign Office Minister, has criticised Oryx because its diamond concession, which the firm believes could be worth $1 billion, was in the southern Congo - 'a clear conflict zone' in the country's bloody civil war.

Oryx disputes this, saying the concession, near the town of Mbuji Mayi, is hundreds of miles from the fighting in Kisangani, where hundreds died last week following clashes between rival rebel factions backed by Rwandan and Ugandan troops.

United Nations observers, however, reported fighting earlier this year between Congolese government troops and rebel forces in the Kasai region, in which Mbuji Mayi is situated.

Oryx, registered in the Cayman Islands, has been criticised for its links with Zimbabwe and Congo through two joint ventures. Under the terms of the Mbuji Mayi concession, Oryx and the Zimbabwean government each receive 40 per cent of future dividends. The Congolese government takes the rest.

The flotation, which was to have been through a reverse takeover of Petra Diamonds, will intensify the focus on gem mining in the Congo. Only a few miles from the Oryx concession, the Belgian company Sebeka, partly owned by De Beers, has mined for several years. The Millennium Diamond - the huge, apparently priceless gem displayed in the Millennium Dome - was mined near Mbuji Mayi, although De Beers claims it was unearthed before the current conflict.

Geoffrey White, Oryx's deputy managing director, was angry about the pulling of the flotation, due on Tuesday. 'The attraction of seeking a listing through Petra was that we believed London had total transparency, and we could operate on a clear commercial basis,' he said. 'We're outraged by what's happened.'

Petra Diamonds, whose shares are suspended, was due to hold an extraordinary general meeting tomorrow, so shareholders could vote on Oryx's reverse takeover. Asked if legal action was possible, White said: 'That's under review.'

fields.headline: Future not Orange: Branson
fields.trailText: Virgin is in talks with German, Japanese and US mobile phone network operators in a bid to tie up a series of deals and 'go global' before rival Orange.
fields.body:
Virgin is in talks with German, Japanese and US mobile phone network operators in a bid to tie up a series of deals and 'go global' before rival Orange.
The group plans to plough at least £200 million into joint ventures worth at least £2 billion to expand into major new international markets in the next three years. Virgin Mobile executives have begun talks with formerly state-owned Deutsche Telekom about a deal to tie up and expand into France, Italy and Spain. Informal discussions have also begun with Japanese telecoms giant NTT Docomo, which is furthest advanced in developing mobile phone access to the internet there.

Virgin said it is also talking to other potential Japanese partners in what it admits is a crowded market. In the US, it is weighing up a joint venture with one of the three firms that are closest to providing coast to coast networks - MCI Worldcom, Bell Atlantic and SBC Ameritech.

Virgin group chairman Sir Richard Branson said this weekend: 'We are trying to beat Orange to be the first global mobile phone company. We are a long way behind but we will be first. We are not far off announcing Japanese, US and European network partners.'
Virgin Mobile has attracted 300,000 subscribers since it launched in the UK last November in conjunction with the fourth largest UK network operator, One2One, and aims to become profitable in March 2002.

It has just struck 50-50 joint ventures with local network providers in Singapore and Australia. The deal with Singtel (Singapore Telecommunications) is meant to be a stepping stone for India and most of the rest of Asia, excluding Japan.

Orange chief Hans Snook has said he wants to take his brand global within five years. Virgin has now set itself a target of three. Branson said: 'Within 12 months I hope we will be up and running in most of the major markets in the world.'

fields.headline: Saved as Blair digs deep
fields.standfirst: New Labour intervenes so often in industry, companies are encouraged to beg for cash, writes  Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: New Labour intervenes so often in industry, companies are encouraged to beg for cash
fields.body:
Beads of sweat broke out on the Secretary of State's forehead, and it wasn't because of the bright sunlight pouring through the window of his spacious Whitehall office.

'But John, you said you'd be able to hold it together for at least 12 months... the election's only a month away.'

'I know Steve, but the bad news is the Germans left it in a damn mess, and we only found out once we'd done proper due diligence. I've done what I can but I'm afraid it's going to be 7,000 jobs gone unless...'

It's the nightmare scenario. A month before a May 2001 election, John Towers comes cap in hand to Stephen Byers at the Department of Trade and Industry, asking for £100 million to bridge the gap between a cash-starved Rover and the deal - just over the horizon - with a foreign car giant that will secure the company's future.

If he doesn't get it, Rover will turn into a niche builder of sports cars under the MG brand, employing 1,500 people at its once-massive Longbridge plant. The headlines are not to be countenanced.

But what's worse is that on Friday 4 May 2001 - the day after Labour is returned to power - the wily Towers pulls out of the hat a miraculous deal with Volkswagen to build a new generation of cars, securing 10,000 jobs. The question of the £100m is lost in the post-election afterglow.

This is a thoroughly hypothetical situation, of course, but it raises issues that are coming to the top of economists' minds.

There has been much comment about the Government's abandonment of its early free-market credentials in favour of increasing intervention in industry. Examples have come thick and fast, from the 1998 Energy Review, which halted the 'dash for gas' and saved coal miners' jobs by restricting permission to build new power stations, to £530m for Airbus, £100m for coal (effectively RJB mining), £152m offered to BMW for Rover and last week's £15m for textiles

But what signals is this sending out? To some experts, this Government has opened itself to 'gaming' by big companies.

Economist John Kay says: 'The Government has laid itself open to this kind of thing. In a way we have moved back to a situation which used to be the norm. We were unusual in having, during the Thatcher years, a government which just said no to companies which came begging.'

There is evidence that as the pace of state 'rescue packages' has increased, companies have cottoned on.

RJB head Richard Budge played a shrewd public hand over coal, issuing timely warnings of potential crises such as the closure of Ellington colliery, close to Byers's North East constituency, and even the efficient Selby super-pit in Yorkshire.

Last month privatised rail operator Railtrack said the Government had to give it a further £1 billion a year in subsidy if it wants the top class railway it has promised voters. And the week before that information leaked into the public domain on came British Nuclear Fuels, suggesting it may need more aid if Ministers are to achieve their long-term ambition of seeing it privatised. Steelmaker Corus and even telecoms giant Vodafone have not been above such tactics.

The subject is horribly complicated - the more intervention there is, the less clear become the rules for industrial policy. The help sought is not always a direct handout. Influence on fiscal measures or legislation may be just as valuable. And the private, as opposed to public, negotiating positions between businesses and governments, and possibly the full extent of any deals done, may never become clear. On top of that, the law of unintended consequences takes hold.

Kay acknowledges this, but says the problem is unique to this Government. 'Industrial actions never have intended consequences. Privatisation is the same as nationalisation in this respect. The Government set up autonomous bodies to oversee the industries, but it soon turned out that they did not work as planned.'

So how is this Government different from previous administrations, particularly Conservative ones?

Economists identify several factors. First, New Labour is more fenced in by European regulations than the nationalising administrations from the end of the Second World War to the Seventies.

Second, it appears more prepared to be drawn in public on industrial issues and on specific companies and sectors than any Government for three decades.

Third, as Kay suggests, it is less ready to leave regulators to oversee industries independently.

John Quelch, dean of the London Business School, says: 'You might call it Dome syndrome. There is an enterprise that the Government wishes to be commercially viable, but which consumers still perceive to be the responsibility of government.

'Also, Ministers are making comments regarding levels of service and performance, and reinforcing the idea that government is responsible for this. So the managers of that enterprise have the ability to go to government and ask for further support.'

Kay points out that the sectors that have most leverage have close relationships with governments. Some are privatised utilities; some are transport or telecoms companies. Others, such as pharmaceuticals and defence companies, for example, rely on government as their major purchaser.

In each case there is evidence that government getting involved directly, rather than via a regulator, has increased under Labour.

For example, the Government has directed new electricity trading arrangements, framed a Utilities Bill to make companies reduce bills and become more 'consumer- focused', and pronounced on internet access charges. Firms such as Northern Electric, National Grid, BT and Thames Water have taken the opportunity to play on their relations with government in public.

In pharmaceuticals, where the Government has introduced a new drugs evaluation agency called Nice, the situation is similar. Last autumn Nice decided the NHS should not pay for a new Glaxo flu treatment. Glaxo felt its viability in the UK was being undermined, and threatened to leave the country.

Another key, and complicating, factor is jobs. Rover, RJB, and Courtaulds may not be regulated, or sell to government, but they all employ thousands of staff in Labour-held constituencies.

Quelch says: 'The Government has not established clear criteria regarding what it is prepared to listen to. This sends the message that it is always worth queuing up to negotiate.'

Beyond this, governments find it hard to resist the temptation to fix independent regulators, Kay says.

Professor Stephen Littlechild, the first privatised electricity regulator and one of the key post-privatisation figures, gives several examples. 'When these industries were privatised, the government could get out of them, and the regulator would be left to run competition.

'This Government wants to do things directly with the industries - for example, saying there must be 10 per cent of electricity generated from renewable [energy sources] by 2010.

'And in the Utilities Bill that is going through, Ministers have the power to direct the regulator on things like environmental issues.'

Littlechild believes the consequences are costly: 'There is a cycle to these things - the Government gets more and more involved, companies play along, then Ministers realise it is too costly and try and extricate themselves.'

But there are sceptics who believe the Government may not be as soft a touch as is supposed. Tim Besley of the London School of Economics says that until clear figures are produced, proving Labour to be more interventionist, such arguments are purely speculative.

And Cambridge economist Paul Seabright says that although this Government may be more involved than previous ones, it is not softer, and may be more knowledgeable. After all, it was Rover that provided an embarrassment for the Thatcher government when it emerged that British Aerospace had been offered 'sweeteners' to take the car firm off the DTI's hands.

It is, however, the way this Government auctioned off third-generation mobile spectrum, generating £22.5bn for the exchequer, that tells Seabright there has been a change.

Instead of privatisations followed by reports from the National Audit Office and the Public Accounts Committee criticising the process for short-changing taxpayers, New Labour has shown itself prepared to bargain with business for public assets, which will no longer be undervalued.

'The rules of the game are changing dramatically,' says Seabright, 'and in surprising ways. It will be difficult to predict how they will turn out. The Government has shown that it wishes to occupy the driving seat.'

That may be true for assets in high demand. But a true sign of the success of the government's commercial touch in industrial investment would be a similar auction for a stake in Rover - should Ministers agree to provide any aid in the first place.

Now why does that seem less likely?

Rescues that went wrong

Concorde: The Anglo-French joint venture was launched in 1962, driven as much by political motives (Europe) as commercial ones. Only 18 were built, costing the UK billions.

Rolls Royce: In 1971 receivers were called into the engineering company. A state aero engine company was formed, while the car business was sold. RR was privatised in 1987.

Upper Clyde Shipbuilders: UCS received funds from the Shipbuilding Industry Board set up after the 1967 Geddes report. It became a byword for 'lame duck' industry in the Seventies. Shipbuilding has never recovered.

British Leyland: Formed in 1968 and nationalised in 1974. Renamed Rover in 1987, it was sold to British Aerospace, which sold it to BMW in 1994. They dumped it this year.

British Steel: Another Wilson nationalisation, in 1967. Rows with the government and appalling labour relations hampered performance. It was privatised in 1988, then merged with Hoogovens and renamed itself Corus.

fields.headline: IT skills crisis splits Whitehall
fields.trailText: Britain's acute shortage of IT workers has prompted a bitter falling out between the Department for Education and Employment and the Home Office. Such is the dearth of IT workers, the Government is committed to a scheme which will allow foreign students on technology courses to apply immediately for jobs after finishing their degrees, rather than having to leave before applying for UK work permits.
fields.body:
Britain's acute shortage of IT workers has prompted a bitter falling out between the Department for Education and Employment and the Home Office. Such is the dearth of IT workers, the Government is committed to a scheme which will allow foreign students on technology courses to apply immediately for jobs after finishing their degrees, rather than having to leave before applying for UK work permits.

The DfEE is so alarmed by the shortage of IT graduates that it is pushing to 'fast-track' the scheme for this year's intake of foreign students - a move being fiercely resisted by the Home Office.

One IT source familiar with the situation said: 'The Home Office is cautious about the move because of the current debate about asylum seekers.'

The spat comes in the wake of a report by Spectrum Strategy Consultants which forecast that a predicted shortage of 80,000 skilled IT workers by 2002 severely threatens Britain's place in the digital economy. Tony Blair has stressed that turning the UK into a European ecommerce leader is one of the Government's key objectives.

A recent report by International Data Corporation found that there will be a staggering 1.7 million job vacancies in Western Europe's IT sector by 2003. It also found that there are already 50,000 IT vacancies in the UK alone.

Experts fear that the shortage of skilled employees in the UK's technology sector will damage inward investment projects. 'If we don't match the skills around companies, particularly foreign companies will go elsewhere,' said Janice Hughes, managing director of Spectrum Strategy Consultants.

The skills crisis prompted education secretary David Blunkett to launch a raft of initiatives last month. In addition to making it easier for foreign nationals to obtain work permits, the Government is to increase their duration and introduce 'season tickets' which allow foreign IT employees to work in the UK for short periods at a time.

'There can be no doubt that the economic capacity of the UK is being held back by the shortage of skilled people. Fast-tracking foreign students is a partial solution to the problem,' said John Higgins, director-general of the Computing Services and Software Association, which advises the Government on IT matters.

However Higgins warned that the Government and the UK IT industry must not rely on mopping up foreign talent.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: It's not only brothers who can play for England. Twins Gemma and Carly Hunt play for the under-18s and hope to turn professional when women's football is recognised in 2003. If not, there's always firefighting.
fields.trailText: It's not only brothers who can play for England. Twins Gemma and Carly Hunt play for the under-18s and hope to turn professional when women's football is recognised in 2003. If not, there's always firefighting.
fields.body:
Gemma Hunt: We had been kicking the football around in the back yard since we could walk. We used to live in Greenwich and there was a flower shop down the road run by a woman who played for a local women's team, and she said to my dad, 'You should take your girls to football.' We were nine when we first went to training and we have been playing ever since.

We played at secondary school with the boys, which was a lot more physical. When it got too much, we used to stop. I prefer playing with girls. It's a different game, a lot more skilful, not as fast as the men's, just better all round. Most of the boys were behind us. But when we were 14, we weren't allowed to play with the boys any more.

Our teacher at school had played women's football, so when we asked her to form our own team, she knew where we were coming from. We were the only girls in the boys' team, but as soon as they announced a girls' team, there were loads of girls wanting to play football, and we started an 11-a-side team. Our teacher would take us to different schools and we started a league. We started winning medals and it went from there. We moved to Dartford a couple of years ago, so we switched teams from Millwall to Croydon, which practises nearby, and were league cup winners and FA Cup winners last year.

It's good being a twin, but then I don't know what it's like just being on my own. We used to fight a lot, but as we're getting older we get on better. But there is a downside. If one of us does something wrong, we both get blamed for it. We can't really get away with much because everyone knows who we are. We are not really competitive with each other, but there is a pressure to keep up. At the end of the day, we have to work as hard as each other and if Carly's in form, then she should play - likewise, if I am. Being sisters, we do push each other and back each other. If she gets tackled, I'm right there backing her up. I think we're quite aggressive players.

We are always called Twinny, it's never Gemma or Carly, and then some people call us The Rottweilers, because we are small on the football pitch - we're only 5ft 2in - and we are playing against some really big women. But we don't take no prisoners. We are always at people's feet, tackling them. It's only in the past year that I've had my hair short. People can tell us apart now; they never used to. Carly's a lot bigger than me because she does weights. But when we are on the field, we wear headbands, and no one can tell us apart.

Carly Hunt: We finished school two years ago and did a one-year sports science course at college. Since then, we have been coaching kids on Saturdays and working with schools.

We'll train twice a week for Croydon, and then when we have international matches, we'll train twice a day. We were 16 when we played our first match for England under-18s. I am the captain, and I have been called into the England seniors, but I couldn't go this year because of a cartilage injury. So I'm going to spend a final year with the under-18s. Gemma hasn't been called up yet. Hopefully, we'll both be going up next year. That's been our ambition, to play seniors and win the World Cup, which America holds at the moment. We've always done everything together. We both even play midfield. If we both get asked to seniors, great. Or it might take some time, like it did for Gary and Phil Neville.

The FA is committed to making women's football a professional sport in 2003. We are only 18 now, so in three years it would be great to start playing professionally. It was annoying at school: we were technically better than the boys, and they could go on and play for money, whereas we couldn't. The only money we earn is what's left over from our expenses when we go abroad with the England team. It is frustrating. If we were men, playing at our level, we might be earning thousands of pounds a week.

When we were at school, teachers asked us what we wanted to do when we left, and we'd always say we'd be professional footballers. They'd say that wasn't realistic, so I used to say I'd like to be a firefighter. So if the professional league doesn't happen, that's what we're going to do.

We do get the odd comment about women not being able to play football, the women's game not being as good as the men's. We are not saying it's as good, it's a different game to watch. I think opinion is changing. The last FA Cup was televised - Gemma scored the winning goal - so the profile is growing. But the television series Playing the Field was disgraceful, and really set back women's football. That's not how women footballers are.

Women's football is bitchy, but male footballers say it's the same. A lot of people say that we must be butch to play. But you've only got to look at us to see we're quite slight. We like to go clubbing, Gemma loves shopping and dressing up and music. There has been talk of a record company wanting us to bring out a single. We can't sing, we can't dance, but we'll give it a go.

fields.headline: The kids go free
fields.trailText: I've barely traipsed back from my weekly undignified half-naked sprint down the drive in pursuit of the dustmen, whose sole purpose in life is to arrive every week just as I'm getting in the bath, when my absent wife is on her mobile phone from Robin Hood's Bay gently wondering if the rabbit is still alive.
fields.body:
I've barely traipsed back from my weekly undignified half-naked sprint down the drive in pursuit of the dustmen, whose sole purpose in life is to arrive every week just as I'm getting in the bath, when my absent wife is on her mobile phone from Robin Hood's Bay gently wondering if the rabbit is still alive, which of course is really her way of asking whether I've been managing the affairs of our empty house with the required degree of assiduity or staying out late and getting drunk.
'He's fine. I can actually cope, you know.'
'OK, OK, just asking,' she says. 'So you've watered the children's tomatoes in the bathroom?'
'Were they on the list?'
'Yes.'
'Well, I must have then,' I say, perhaps a little too mischievously for someone in imminent danger of being quizzed about tadpoles, which appear to have mysteriously dwindled in number since last Saturday, or at least... well, let's say it's been a while since I saw two at the same time. I admit it's possible that I might have been a bit ungenerous with the old fish flakes, but didn't I read somewhere that tadpoles are supposed to eat their own tails if they get hungry, rather than, say, each other?
Luckily, the children are now clamouring to have a turn at shouting at me long distance, except our nine-year-old bookworm, who gives me a hurried precis on the subject of fossilised dinosaur turds before passing the phone on like a stick of live uranium to the toddler before he catches a brain tumour. It turns out that the little poppets are having a grand old time without Dad around to spoil everything by being reluctant to scrabble about looking for crabs in the pouring rain at seven in the morning. Ah, I do miss them all.
Still, must press on if I'm to finish the last of my chores in time to get to London this evening to meet my old chum Constance, who I'm supposed to be going out to see a film with, unless she rings as usual the minute I'm leaving to cancel owing to someone more interesting having unexpectedly just flown in from Phnom Penh or New York or Neptune.
I return to my ablutions followed by a spot of work, so it's not until mid-afternoon that I suddenly remember how I was obliged to leave the laughable brown Metro at John's house last night due to faculties beyond my control, so it's up the hill 14 miles on foot to the village to take my venerable old boots to the cobbler's, buy a wholemeal TV dinner at the organic shop to get my body back into peak condition after eating instant noodles and Frosties all week, and pop into Oxfam with my equally venerable classic raincoat, which I have finally been forced to concede no longer qualifies in the developed world as a recognisable article of clothing, though arguably with the addition of a large turnip and a trilby it could still usefully measure out its days flapping about on a stick in a ploughed field. But then the stumbling block turns out to be the pet shop, where I'm supposed to get some wood shavings and straw for Lucky's bed. Imagine my surprise when the woman comes out of the back with two sacks the size of barns, which means me staggering down the high street looking like a haywain with legs, much to the entertainment of everyone I pass, in particular a group of street urchins who draw my attention to the trail of sawdust following me down the pavement.
Amazingly, I'm in town with plenty of time to hang around waiting hours for Constance to remember to turn up in her half-moon specs, which make her look perfectly brainy for reading in but do slow her down a bit when it comes to walking. It seems she is keen to see American Psycho - a thoughtful study of a man so alienated by the grasping corporate ethos of 80s America and tipped into madness by a script that seems to have been written for the versatile character actor Jim Carrey, that he hacks the rest of the cast to death in his front room. Afterwards we nip into some designer cafe for a tenner's worth of bar snacks, though there's no chance of getting drunk with Constance, who turns into a deep-fried parsnip wedge after one gin and tonic, so I'm back home well in time to pick up another message from the north.
Bleep. 'Just to say, hope you had a good time. Oh and don't forget the tadpoles...'

fields.headline: Pilots circling Prescott
fields.trailText: Airline pilots are demanding an emergency meeting with Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott amid fears that a new deal allowing certain UK and US airlines greater access to each other's markets will result in thousands of job losses in Britain.
fields.body:
Airline pilots are demanding an emergency meeting with Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott amid fears that a new deal allowing certain UK and US airlines greater access to each other's markets will result in thousands of job losses in Britain.

The British Airline Pilots Association is leading four other unions against a new round of 'open skies' talks between UK and US airlines which start in London this week. A deal would allow greater access to transatlantic routes.

Balpa assistant general secretary Mike Sparham said new conditions on the talks, which effectively mean only those in transatlantic alliances are to be included, would face British carriers with major disadvantages.

'Only British Airways and British Midland have alliances, which leaves Virgin and charter operators out in the cold. If they have to compete with Americans on short-haul routes without doing the same in the US, they will be very vulnerable.

'We fear this would have a dramatic impact on companies and will lead to the loss of thousands of high quality jobs.'

Last week Virgin Atlantic said it will be forced to seek a major US partner if the talks go ahead.

Virgin chairman Sir Richard Branson fears he could be swamped by a deal that strengthened the position at Heathrow of the Oneworld alliance, led by BA and American, and of Star group, led by United, Lufthansa, SAS and British Midland.

He said: 'If a deal happens we will have to protect our position and will most likely enter into a transatlantic alliance with an American carrier.'

This week's talks come against the background of a dramatic wave of merger mania in the airline business. British Airways has pledged to co-operate fully with the European Commission in its bid to take over Dutch national carrier KLM - as revealed in The Observer last month.

webTitle: Click 'n mix at the online superstores

fields.headline: Click 'n mix at the online superstores
fields.standfirst: They pile them high so you can buy 'em cheap, says Rachel Fixsen
fields.trailText: Internet-based fund supermarkets, which sell unit trusts and other investment funds, are being launched by major financial groups.
fields.body:
A new type of supermarket is opening to UK consumers. But it doesn't sell fresh vegetables, anti-bacterial dish sponges or Australian chardonnay. Internet-based fund supermarkets, which sell unit trusts and other investment funds, are being launched by major financial groups.

This is not the first time investors have been able to invest in collective funds directly on the internet. Fund management groups M&G and Legg Mason (formerly Johnson Fry) already let people invest directly through their websites.

And discount brokers such as TQ Direct enable you to invest your Individual Savings Account (Isa) allowance in the funds of about 10 different fund managers, while rebating a large chunk of the initial charge in the form of cash or extra units.

But now the fund managers themselves have started selling the funds of other investment houses. Like more traditional supermarkets, they work on the basis of piling the products high and selling them cheaply.

But the biggest advantage of buying through a fund supermarket is that you can combine funds from different providers in just one Isa wrapper - a service previously only available at much greater cost through a few stockbrokers.

Last week Fidelity launched FundsNetwork (www.fidelity.co.uk), a supermarket which enables investors to 'click and mix' from a range of more than 250 funds from 14 leading investment houses. The investor can choose any selection of funds, subject to investing a minimum of £1,000 in each one.

Anyone can use the service - all you need is a debit card to make your payment online. Likewise, Egg has offered a fund supermarket service (www.egg.com/investments) since March, which allows investors to combine up to six different funds per ISA (minimum investment of £20 per fund). Egg, however, offers a more limited choice of 150 funds from 12 providers. The service is available to anyone who opens an Egg savings account, which is used as the settlement account for fund transactions.

Interactive Investor International (www.iii.co.uk) also launched a supermarket last week, which will offer funds from up to 20 providers by this Friday. But its initial charges are higher, payments must be sent in by cheque and its ISA can accept only one fund at a time.

More supermarkets are likely to be launched later this year, including one run by South African financial giant Fedsure, which will offer about 650 funds from 27 providers, and another planned jointly by Gartmore, Jupiter, M&G and Threadneedle.

Like most new ideas in the financial services industry, the concept of investment supermarkets came from the United States, where the market is dominated by Fidelity and stockbroker Charles Schwab. Schwab says 50 per cent of its fund sales in the US now take place through its fund supermarket website.

Because the supermarket is dealing in bulk, investments are usually available with discounted charges compared to the price you would pay if you were buying the investment directly from the fund manager or an independent financial adviser.

Nearly 90 per cent of the funds on offer through FundsNetwork will have an initial charge of 1.25 per cent or less. And, until 30 June, customers at the Egg supermarket will be given a 1 per cent cashback on any Isa investment. This will be pure profit for many since most of the Isas offered have no initial charge. Where there are initial charges, Egg discounts them to bring them down to a maximum of 1.5 per cent. Even fund management groups that operate their own direct-selling websites say they welcome the new breed of fund supermarket. Legg Mason's product director Brett Greatrex says: 'Our view is that if this brings more mutual funds to the consumer, it is probably a positive step.' Anyone buying an investment from a direct seller should be fairly knowledgeable about investment and stockmarkets.

Both Fidelity and Egg provide portfolio management tools, statistics and information about the funds offered on their sites. But many investors are still likely to want professional advice so Fidelity has also made its site available to independent financial advisers, to help them work with their clients to develop the right portfolio.

fields.headline: Money Writes
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I fall ill and my cover goes sick

I Have a Lloyds TSB Gold Service Account which includes free travel insurance, running from July to July. Last November, I booked a holiday to Canada and paid £180 deposit. In mid-December, I had chest pains which were diagnosed as angina, and I started treatment. In April, I told the doctor about my holiday plans and he said there was no problem, other than to inform the insurer. When I did, Lloyds TSB cancelled my cover on the basis that my illness was pre-existing. Yet when I booked the holiday I had no idea that one month later I would be ill.

KS, Bristol

Lloyds TSB regards conditions as pre-existing if they occur at any time before you start your holiday, however healthy you were when you bought the policy and booked the trip. This surprised me because I thought annual insurance was valid on the terms agreed at the outset for the whole year.

Lloyds TSB admits it was wrong to tell you that your policy would not cover cancellation costs, so it will now reimburse the deposit if you change your mind about going. But the bank insists that it will not insure you to go on holiday.

This is important for holidaymakers to appreciate, particularly if you have annual insurance, and could travel many months after buying the policy. Even if the wording indicates that you must inform the insurer if you suffer a serious condition before booking your holiday, companies will probably reject a claim caused by an illness that did not arise until after booking unless it knew before you left and agreed you could travel.

This is standard practice with travel insurance, although most insurers will continue the policy, provided you are not travelling against your doctor's advice. Here, if you make a claim , the GP must write a letter confirming that you were fit to travel.

Saving in euros? On no account

My wife and I plan to buy a French property. We have a £10,000 deposit and, as sterling is strong, wonder whether it is best to invest this in a euro account until we find the home we want?

DJ, Saffron Walden

The pound has weakened against the euro, so it is probably not worth doing. Euro accounts pay little interest, anyway. Your £10,000 is worth about 16,000 euros. The best rates are 2.75 per cent from Abbey National (01534 885000) and from Halifax (Isle of Man 01624 612323 or Jersey 01534 759340). Onshore accounts pay more than 6 per cent.

Mobile mistake: Sliced by Orange

My Abbey National statement in February showed that £101 had been deducted on 25 January. The bank said it was an electronic direct debit set up by Orange mobile phones. But I have no such phone. Orange admitted the mistake and promised to refund £101, plus £14.50 they had taken from my account in February. They could not explain why and how they had been able to take my money without knowing my name, or having my authority.

LK, Lewes

When the Orange operator was selling this phone, he typed in the wrong account number. Abbey National's system asks the operator to confirm that both name and number are correct. The operator, presumably without checking, said they were. Abbey then failed to spot that the Orange client's name did not match yours, and activated the direct debit. When you complained, Abbey refunded the money to you under the direct debit indemnity, which obliges banks to immediately reimburse their customers and sort out the problem afterwards. Abbey has now recouped the money from Orange.

Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Include a phone number, but not SAEs or documents. Letters are chosen for publication. We cannot give personal replies. The paper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

fields.headline: Lloyds top the list
fields.standfirst: Investor of the year
fields.trailText: The results and winners have been calculated for the month of May in our Investor of the Year competition, with Lloyds TSB Group the outstanding performer.
fields.body:
The results and winners have now been calculated for the month of May in our Investor of the Year competition, sponsored by Fleming Asset Management and run in conjunction with our sister publication Money Observer.

Eighteen companies managed to register a gain during the month, with banking giant Lloyds TSB Group by far the outstanding performer, with an increase in share price of over 15 per cent. Lloyds had actually experienced a slump in May and the share price fell back to 644p from a high of near 740p. But this left the shares cheap and positive notes from brokers coupled with the prospect of favourable interest rates meant they began to climb, ending May at 714p.

The second-best performing share was retailer Boots, finishing the month with a percentage gain of just over 12 per cent.

The ideal result in full was Lloyds TSB Group (number 18 on your original coupon) +15.29 per cent; Boots (6) +12.02 per cent; Royal & Sun Alliance Insurance Group (24) +11.02 per cent; Tate & Lyle (27) +10.6 per cent and P&O Steam Navigation (21) +10.57 per cent. This made an average gain for the month of 11.9 per cent, with 18 shares registering an increase.

No-one managed to select the ideal combination, how ever, meaning that Mr R Maskell from Rowland's Castle in Hampshire wins our first prize. He picked the top three, sixth and seventh best performing shares, making an average gain of 11.636 per cent, and scoops a cheque for £500.

Mr Maskell also wins our fifth prize, £100 in premium bonds, as another of his entries also performed strongly.

Second placed was P.A. Bury from Staining in Blackpool, with a combination of the top four and eighth best performing shares to give an average gain of 11.544 per cent. A cheque for £200 is winging its way to Blackpool.

Two others scoop our third and fourth runners up prizes of £100 in premium bonds. They are Mr W.W. Hendry from Cairney Hill in Dunfermline, with an average gain of 11 per cent and Mr C. Lochen from Goring-by-Sea, Worthing, with an average gain of 10.902.

 Unfortunately, we were unable to print the Investor of the Year results last week. This week we are publishing both the results and the winners' details.

Details of the 30 shares' performance during June will appear in Cash on 2 July, with winners' names a week later.

webTitle: A crash? Maybe not, but watch out

fields.headline: A crash? Maybe not, but watch out
fields.standfirst: Perhaps the most startling thing about the recent surge in shares is that most analysts are still trying to make the case for prices rising further.
fields.trailText: Perhaps the most startling thing about the recent surge in shares is that most analysts are still trying to make the case for prices rising further.
fields.body:
In the last five years, the FTSE 100 index has doubled and the Dow Jones Industrial Average in the US has risen more than threefold, even after recent dips. That is a spectacular performance by any standards, marking the climax of a bull run which can be traced as far as the start of the Eighties.

But perhaps the most startling thing about the recent surge in shares is that most analysts are still trying to make the case for prices rising further. Few are willing even to entertain the idea that what goes up does, eventually, come down.

That is understandable. Five years ago, commentators, myself included, were warning that shares were overvalued. This was clearly wrong, and even the most pessimistic commentators - with a few exceptions, such as economists Tim Congdon and Robert Schiller in the US - have stopped crying wolf. Instead, most have tried to construct theories, usually a variation on the idea that new technology has transformed world economies, which explain why ever-rising share prices can be relied on.

So is last week's warning from the Bank for International Settlements about global overvaluation of equities just another example of a Cassandra who will be proved wrong? Or should investors start to re-examine their exposure to the stock market?

The BIS makes some salient, if hardly revolutionary, points. Traditional valuation measures such as dividend yields and price/ earnings ratios on equities across the world are well above their historic average. That is partly due to technology stocks which, even after recent corrections, are discounting growth rates far above historic levels.

But even old economy stocks are highly rated, particularly this late into the economic cycle and on a background of rising interest rates. The BIS warns that when valuations retreat to historic averages it is more likely to be a result of share prices falling than earnings or dividends rising.

Others make similar observations but reach different conclusions: shares may not rise much more, but they should not collapse. Analysts at ABN Amro, for example, point out that historical average valuations are based on the twentieth century, which was characterised by two world wars, the Depression, two oil shocks and numerous policy errors. They do not think such events will recur - indeed, they believe economic cycles have been, if not eliminated, then certainly blunted.

The BIS, however, comments: 'As history has repeatedly shown, even well-founded optimism has the insidious tendency to transform itself into excess.'

And it points out that Japanese investors believed they had cracked the cycle in the late Eighties. Those who bought shares just before that theory was shown to be spectacularly incorrect in 1989 have still not recouped their original investment.

Having been proved wrong over the last five years, I am not about to predict whether, let alone when, the stock market will crash. There are, however, growing signs that the forces which have driven the market higher in the last five years are moving, albeit slowly and uncertainly, the other way.

First, interest rates are now rising everywhere, including the US. It may be true they will peak not much above current levels, but every survey showing rising employment and spending makes it less and less likely.

Then there is the technology boom. Billions of pounds have been poured into financing companies which are expected to prosper in the new economy. Yet even the most die-hard technology addicts admit that much of the enthusiasm will prove misplaced.

That realisation has already pushed technology stocks sharply lower, but there could be further to go following, say, disappointing news from one of the new economy stars. A scenario that could spark a panic which could easily spread to other sectors - remember 50 per cent of Americans now hold shares.

It is still too early to say where the technology jitters will end. Nervous investors may decide now is not the time to be committing substantial extra sums to shares. Those who are willing to take the risk should consider dribbling money in through regular savings schemes.

webTitle: Marooned by the cost of a ketch

fields.headline: Marooned by the cost of a ketch
fields.standfirst: The Bishops cottage was 'a pile of rot in a bog' but their main ambition is for sailing adventure, reports Margaret Dibben.
fields.trailText: SUSANNA BISHOP
fields.body:
SUSANNA BISHOP

Age: 46

Lives in: Chelmondiston, Suffolk

Occupation: Actress

Earns: £10,000

Mortgage: £46,000

Debts: None

Investments: Husband has $90,000

Pension: Small amount with Equity and a personal pension

Aim: To finance a year-long sailing trip

The American husband of Susanna Bishop has such an expensive sailing habit that they spent more money on buying a boat than they did on their home. They paid £46,000 for a tiny cottage when they left London for East Anglia 10 years ago and £56,000 for a 40ft steel ketch.

A small place was suitable because they intended staying only six months before sailing away. But Susanna fell pregnant twice in quick succession and in 1998 discovered she had breast cancer. So they had to put their adventure plans on hold and look for a larger home for Elise, now 8, and Hayden, 7. They found an idyllic clapboard cottage but had to fight off London weekenders who pushed the price from £85,000 to £116,000 despite its dilapidated state. 'We bought a pile of rot in a bog,' says Susanna. They have since spent £30,000 renovating the cottage and converting the loft. Brad, who is a carpenter, did much of the work himself. The local vicar bought their previous cottage and let them stay in it while they worked on the new one.

Susanna is an actress but now spends more time teaching drama and looking after the children. Their income varies wildly, and this year they reckon to earn about £25,000 between them. They have £30,000 life insurance bought with their London flat, but they have not increased it since. Pensions are not high in their priorities. Susanna contributes about £60 a month; Brad has nothing put by, except a small pension through the American Union of Carpenters and a $90,000 shares inheritance he would like to keep as his last link with America. If they cashed in the shares to fund the trip, they would have to pay a lot of tax.

Susanna is not worried about pensions, as they have no plans to retire: 'As an actor, I hope to go on for ever. We are both the kind of people who go on until we drop.' But they are determined to achieve the sailing trip - next year before Elise starts secondary school. Susanna has thought of various ways of financing it: selling the boat when they return (although Brad is unlikely to agree); using the boat to earn money; filming or writing about the trip. They will rent out the cottage, in a popular sailing area, which should cover the mortgage and provide a small income. But she asks: 'Could we approach the building society for an increased mortgage?' When they return, they will want to borrow to extend the cottage further.

Adviser 1: Joanne Cox

The most obvious means of funding the trip is from Brad's US shares. He could reduce the tax liability by cashing them in over the year rather than all at once, particularly as he will have no income while they are sailing. Or he could take an income from the shares. If they prefer a loan, they should start with the Britannia, where they have a track record. The share portfolio is probably sufficient security for all their borrowing and is a valuable safety net, particularly as their incomes vary. They need Britannia's permission to let the property and should establish their financial position should the property not be let for some time: do they need a slush fund to cover mortgage costs or will the Britannia allow them to defer their payments until they return?

A letting agent can suggest appropriate rent, and they should decide on house insurance and whether or not to let the property fully furnished. Ideally, they should start saving now for next year with cash Isas, looking at internet, phone or postal accounts. Pension contributions can be made only out of earned income, so Susanna may need to cancel payments during the trip. She should check the implications of this with the provider or her adviser.

They should start investigating travel insurance. Because of Susanna's ill-health, underwriting may take some time and, if left to the last minute, could delay the trip.

Joanne Cox is a financial adviser with the Co-op.

Adviser 2: Janine Starks

Susanna's ideas for financing the trip will not provide hard cash upfront. Their mortgage already takes them to retirement age, so they should not extend it. They could, though, release some of the equity in the house, arrange a secured loan, and use some of the US money.

Flexible mortgages allow payment breaks but Britannia does not offer them and they could face penalties if they paid off their existing loan. As they obviously have a good relationship with Britannia, they should ask for a secured loan with a charge against the house; this is flexible because they can draw down money as they need it, although the interest rate would be higher. Touching the US money may cause a capital gains tax problem, but the longer they leave it the greater the problem will become. It is reasonable not to touch the money because it's their only retirement provision, but, in any case, their US investments need a full review. A more balanced portfolio would include investments in the UK, Europe, and other international areas. By rearranging their US investments, they can take advantage of UK tax benefits on Isas and pensions.

They should reconsider their life assurance; Susanna's history of breast cancer will make insurance expensive, so they should start by increasing Brad's cover.

Janine Starks works for Bath-based adviser Chase de Vere.

Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Carers who are still the poor relations

fields.headline: Carers who are still the poor relations
fields.standfirst: As Carers Week begins, Neasa MacErlean reports on the problems faced by the selfless
fields.trailText: Tomorrow sees the launch of Carers Week - a campaign by the Carers National Association to highlight the financial plight of the other 5.7 million carers in the UK.
fields.body:
If her life had gone a different way, Hilary Robbins of Plymouth estimates she would now be earning £30,000. But six years ago she gave up her job to look after her father. Her income is now about £2,100 a year from Invalid Care Allowance - although it is topped up by Income Support. Now 57, she has not had a holiday since 1994, and struggles to pay her mortgage. She window shops rather than buying anything new.

'Your whole life changes overnight,' she says of the move to look after her 87-year-old father, who suffers from emphysema, arthritis, chronic bronchitis and partial deafness. 'If my father had gone into a home, it would be costing the state about £500 a week. The disparity between that and what I am getting is not right. The Government is using carers. It's emotional blackmail.'

Tomorrow sees the launch of Carers Week - a campaign by the Carers National Association (CNA) to highlight the plight of Ms Robbins and the other 5.7 million carers in the UK. Diana Whitworth, CNA chief executive, hopes to keep the political pressure up to put carers on the election agenda. In fact, the carers have already had one significant coup. Shadow social security secretary David Willetts announced last month that a Tory government would accept applications for Invalid Care Allowance from people aged 60 to 65. At the moment, you have to be under 60 to start claiming - a regulation that particularly hurts carers who start to look after ailing parents. In February 1999, the Government published the 'National Carers Strategy' for England. A Scottish version has also been published and the Welsh one is due this year. (Northern Irish carers are still waiting to hear if they will get one.) But, as the CNA says in its report Caring on the breadline, published tomorrow: 'The only areas not to have been addressed by any of these strategies are the financial difficulties faced by carers, and measures to combat them.' Tomorrow's report will show just how widespread poverty is among carers.

The CNA is arguing for higher rates of Invalid Care Allowance and more generous qualification rules. Under the current system, you have to be caring for at least 35 hours a week and the person you are helping needs to be on either Attendance Allowance or the middle or higher rate of the care component of Disability Living Allowance. Carers and pensioners will be particularly interested in the Department of Health's white paper on long-term care which is planned for July. Carers hope it will pave the way for more help for the disabled in their own homes. There are many arguments for this - not least that it is far more cost-effective to the Government in the long-run. However, sources close to Government policymakers expect the aim will be to keep costs down in the short-run.

There are some pieces of good news for carers, however. Former Labour MP Tom Pendry's Carers and Disabled Children's Bill is expected to come into force next April. It will now explicitly apply to the parents of disabled children and also introduces the right of a carer to get a local authority assessment even if the person they are caring for has not also been assessed.

Contact the CNA Carers Line free on 0808 808 7777.

webTitle: Great guy, great CV - shame about the genes

fields.headline: Great guy, great CV - shame about the genes
fields.standfirst: There are fears that the growing trend towards the use of genetic testing for employment purposes in the US may soon be reflected in the UK and Europe.
fields.trailText: Insurers are not the only ones who would like to know a little more about your internal make-up before becoming involved with you. Employers will also begin taking a close interest in our DNA as genetic testing develops.
fields.body:
Insurers are not the only ones who would like to know a little more about your internal make-up before becoming involved with you. Employers will also begin taking a close interest in our DNA as genetic testing develops.

A report published in July last year by the Human Genetics Advisory Committee found that the Ministry of Defence was the only employer which had a formal policy for the specific use of such tests. In that case, applicants for aircrew training are screened for sickle cell disease, which can be triggered by low oxygen pressures in flight. The committee found no other evidence of a trend towards the use of genetic testing for employment purposes in the UK or Europe. But there is evidence of its growing use in the US, where the trend is being driven by insurance worries: there is no universal health care system in the US, and access to health cover is usually through people's jobs.

In the UK, a number of employers told the committee that 'as genetic technology becomes more cost effective it is possible that pressure may come from the company's insurers to adopt practices that involve genetic testing'. The committee urged that people should not be required to take a genetic test for employment purposes. 'An individual's "right not to know" their genetic constitution should be upheld,' its members said. However, it also noted that there are possible exceptions which mean that such tests should not be banned completely. For example, 'if it were possible for a genetic test to identify, with a high degree of probability, that possession of a particular gene may increase the risk of a heart attack, then it might be in the public interest for airline pilots to be tested for the gene'.

To test or not to test

Elaine Cousins comes from a family with a history of breast cancer. Her maternal grandmother, her mother and her aunt all contracted the disease around age 40, as did her elder sister and, lastly, herself. After her sister, Annette, developed breast cancer, she encouraged Elaine to undergo genetic testing. Elaine resisted the idea, partly because she was worried about its psychological effects. 'I was also worrying about insurance,' she said. 'That's why I didn't have it done.' She was particularly concerned that the test might make it difficult for her to take out a new mortgage.

After she developed the disease five years ago, she decided to have the screening to see if there was a genetic defect running through the family. Her concern was for Annette's two daughters and twin granddaughters. She, Annette and one of Annette's daughters all took the tests and were found to be in the clear for BRCA1. They have never had a conclusive result for the BRCA2 gene. 'The [BRCA1] result means that I would have been lulled into a false sense of security by having the test earlier,' she says. 'But I do think it is sad that people should decide for monetary and not for health or medical research reasons whether to have the tests.'

She believes that the insurance industry's attitude towards genetic test results is simplistic. 'It is an intrusion on your personal rights, and I still think there is no absolute certainty that a family gene will produce a cancer,' she says. 'More research is needed into other genes.'

webTitle: Mao is making eyes at me

fields.headline: Mao is making eyes at me
fields.standfirst: Nixon in China is a breathtaking opera that transforms one moment in modern politics into a timeless myth. It even portrays the former President as an idealist
fields.trailText: Nixon in China is a breathtaking opera that transforms one moment in modern politics into a timeless myth. It even portrays the former President as an idealist.
fields.body:
Nixon in China, English National Opera, The Coliseum, London WC2

Two operas, oil and water artistically but premiered within a year of each and both set to English texts, tower over the past quarter of a century. One, Harrison Birtwistle's The Mask of Orpheus (1986), ignited dormant mythology with a flame of contemporary resonance. The other, John Adams's Nixon in China, transformed a bathetic moment in modern politics into timeless myth.

First performed in Houston in 1987, with a television screening and an Edinburgh staging soon after, Nixon had not been seen in London until last week. The long, if inexplicable, wait was worth it. This is a winner. We should thank the production's chief patron, Bob Borzello, whose personal enthusiasm (and cheque-book) provided the necessary impetus.

It's not easy to say quite why the work makes such an addictive and overwhelming impact. Adams, now in his fifties, started out as an East Coast, Harvard-trained heavyweight who only found musical freedom when he moved to California in 1971. He wrote Nixon when 'minimalism' was still a nasty word, sputtered by serious music types as if through a mouthful of lemon.

The term, borrowed from art criticism and brought in to general musical use by Michael Nyman, provided a useful catchphrase for anything which, as one dictionary frowningly put it, abjured 'the increasing complexity that has marked most Western music since 1600'. To applaud the repetitive, gradually shifting rhythms and harmonies of Riley, Glass, Reich and now Adams, too, was an affront to taste and high art, never mind that in their own way Bach and Wagner were frequent flyers with the same strategies.

To the further shock of the avant-garde consensus, pop, jazz and non-Western traditions suddenly dared inhabit the same stave. Tunes and harmonies made a prodigal return and a new, if runtish hybrid known as 'crossover' was born.

Now, if still apologetically in some circles, these musical milestones have disappeared into a new, less Balkanised landscape which no longer feels the same need to tag, label and point. Adams is justifiably admired, especially for Nixon in China, a work of such real and exposed complexities it's a wonder anyone ever thought the description 'minimalist' would do.

The starting point for this collaboration between Adams, the American poet, Alice Goodman, and the director, Peter Sellars, was President Nixon's six-day visit to China in 1972. Nixon, here a romantic idealist, as yet untarnished by impeachment, dreams that he, alone, with a little help from Henry Kissinger and enough prime-time coverage on television, can achieve world peace where others have failed.

In the opera's six tableaux, he arrives by plane, meets the decrepit philosopher Mao in his book-crammed study, watches a violent Chinese ballet, The Red Detachment of Women, and encounters the screeching Madame Mao and the wise, sad, insomniac premier, Chou En-lai. Nixon's wife, Pat, visits children, a hospital and a factory, is given a glass elephant ('Brings back so many memories') and speculates, in a moving aria, on life's dreams and regrets and her own, impoverished background.

The curtain rises on a sombre chorus of peasants intoning the Three Main Rules of Discipline against a backdrop of bare trees, with the roar of the approaching presidential plane growing louder. At last, in an exuberant moment of high theatre, the Spirit of 76 descends and the American President appears, followed by a scarlet-clad First Lady.

A perfect ballet of bows and handshakes with Chou En-lai (the sensitive baritone David Kempster) takes place on the tarmac. Almost at once, Nixon breaks into the dazzling 'News' aria which, like Madame Mao's chilling coloratura aria ('I am the wife of Mao Tse-tung') and 'The Chairman Dances', has become familiar through concert performance.

The only surviving cast member is the baritone James Maddalena, formidable in the title role. So unnervingly faithful is his Nixon, with receding hair-line, chipmunk nose and a spectrum of facial twitches now spiced with a warming touch of Tony Blair, it's hard to imagine anyone else ever daring to play the part.

He sings expressively and endows his character with moving dignity, which makes his vanity and folly all the more human. His clumsy relationship with Pat (an excellent Janis Kelly) is painfully convincing. Alice Goodman's text, written in heroic couplets and full of sharp humour, avoids the easy lure of cynicism which hindsight might legitimately have allowed. Her voice is every bit as distinct in this work as the composer's (though the ENO programme gives her puzzlingly short biographical shrift), her serious and skilful words a mature complement to his moments of Wagnerian caprice and jazzy pastiche.

Shunning operatic habit, the work moves from public spectacle to, in the final scene, private contemplation, like a symphony unexpectedly ending with a slow movement then dying away quietly. This remains the most problematic section, not entirely resolved here and not helped by the dodgy string solos of the otherwise valiant ENO orchestra (though after three-and-a- half exhausting hours without let up, the closing bars are a rough time to be given stretching solos).

The other, John Adams's Nixon in China, transformed a bathetic moment in modern politics into timeless myth. fields.headline: Chicago hope
fields.standfirst: It has all the ingredients of a predictable, mawkish romantic comedy - but sometimes love can even conquer cynicism
fields.trailText: Return to Me
fields.body:
Return to Me (116mins, PG) Directed by Bonnie Hunt; starring David Duchovny, Minnie Driver

Many are made, but few (romantic comedies, that is) are worth choosing. Simple cinematic affairs of the heart need a mystic chemistry. The time, the lovers and the world that surrounds them have to be right, so Return to Me is more than a tested formula expertly delivered - it has the chemistry. It sits alongside While You Were Sleeping and Moonstruck and, unselfconsciously, shares their fairy-tale world.

David Duchovny, old frozen face from The X Files, is Bob the Chicago builder married to a golden dream of a zoologist (Joely Richardson) who dies too soon. Her transplanted heart goes to Grace (Minnie Driver) who waits table at her grandad's restaurant, O'Reilly's Irish-Italian trattoria. Bob, slowly surfacing from grief, stops by for a spinach pasta. A slender yarn of high predictability, with an infinite ability to leave a bad taste - cloying or just plain sick - in the mouth.

None of that happens and it's instructive to see why. First, the fledgling director and co-writer, Bonnie Hunt, knows her Chicago hometown like a worn, cherished glove. The Lincoln Park zoo, where Sydney, the gorilla Joely left behind, pines for her, is more than a standard backcloth; the blue collars and the white collars live in districts that fit; the restaurant, all wood-panelling and easy banter, is a real joint.

Second, the supporting cast is utterly human, in a softly idealised way: no funny turns, no walk-on caricatures. Maybe Carroll O'Connor's Oirish grandfather is a bit full of blarney, but put him with his pensionable mates like Robert Loggia and the fun they generate is palpable. They're enjoying themselves, goddamit! Hunt has written herself a part as Grace's best friend (married with screaming children to James Belushi's Windy City jock) and she scatters in pith whenever the mix grows too sweet.

But, as ever, the crux is how we relate to these heart-crossed lovers. Duchovny, slim and boyish in casual clothes, isn't another ordinary TV star taking time out. He makes you believe the loss of his wife; he comes out of his shell and explodes with credible happiness; he even looks as though he could run a building site. And Minnie Driver, for those who remember Big Night or Grosse Pointe Blank, has that same unembarrassed warmth and delicate vulnerability. You can see why he loves her and vice versa. You will them to get it together - and you feel good for them when they do.

There's nothing remotely 2000 about Return to Me; indeed, a soundtrack full of Dean Martin and Sinatra heads determinedly in the other direction. This is romance, it seems to say, for swinging lovers who don't fall into bed on the first date and understand a certain tenderness. That may be a little sugary for some, but there seemed plenty of suspiciously red eyes around me when the lights went up.

Oh, and one more interesting thing. Minnie Driver is English, but plays Americans time and again in a flawless accent. Joely Richardson here does the same. Samantha Morton and Emily Watson both have their Hollywood outings this year. Meanwhile, Gwyneth Paltrow does English English to the manner born and Renée Zellweger is Bridget Jones. We may not have noticed it and we may not understand why, but Britain, for actresses, is already the fifty-first state.

 Philip French is on holiday

fields.headline: Clear the decks
fields.standfirst: He's a DJ who's moved into soundtracks for dark, warped movies - but David Holmes had his biggest hit on Match of the Day
fields.trailText: He's a DJ who's moved into soundtracks for dark, warped movies - but David Holmes had his biggest hit on Match of the Day.
fields.body:
The first time I saw David Holmes he was crouching over a turntable in a humid Dublin bar. His head was cocked as he balanced a large pair of headphones and played everything from The Clash to Brigitte Bardot. The crowd was small but enthusiastic. Next door, in the main room, the masses stomped and strutted to ear-splitting techno. Holmes, the evening's big-name DJ, seemed oblivious to the irony. He was lost in his music.

Sitting in his PR's London office almost a year later, the DJ turned soundtrack specialist seems tired of talking about himself. The phone rings and it's another music press query. No, he is not going to produce the next Manic Street Preachers album, he says wearily in a soft Belfast accent.

He has flown in to London to talk about his new album Bow Down to the Exit Sign - a beguiling collection of blunted dance beats and psychedelic echoes partially inspired by listening to 'Miles Davis's Bitches Brew and a lot of old, twisted, dirty funk albums'.

It's also the soundtrack to an as yet unmade film, provisionally titled Living Room , a dark tale of urban dystopia. There are memorable vocal contributions from Bobby Gillespie and Tricky's former muse Martina.

Indeed, Bow Down to the Exit Sign often bridges the gap between Tricky's urban paranoia and Primal Scream's recent electro-punk. It builds on the success of Holmes's critically acclaimed Let's Get Killed in 1997 and the funky soundtrack to Steven Soderbergh's smart thriller Out of Sight the following year.

Fortified by a BLT sandwich and Marlboro Lights, Holmes becomes loquacious. He runs his fingers through spiky, peroxide hair between puffs. It quickly becomes apparent that 'twisted' and 'dirty' are his favoured musi cal adjectives. And he likes a whole lotta music.

He grew up the youngest child of a large Catholic family. He shared a bedroom with four brothers and his passion for music was inspired by them, imbibing second-hand soul and R&B. However, the first single he got was The Sex Pistols' 'Pretty Vacant'. By 15, he was DJ-ing at local parties and came of age during the euphoric summer of '88, spinning Acid House tunes.

His own music is a surprising hybrid of what he plays in his sets. His signature track, 'My Mate Paul', fused Sixties soul and techno and became a staple on Match of the Day.

The Holmes oeuvre is often called 'cinematic'. 'When I started making music, people started telling me that. I thought, "Ooh, that's a really good avenue to go down". So I started buying soundtracks and getting ideas from them.'

He also owes a big debt to New York where he has recorded his last two albums. 'I love the street culture and the energy. It's such a cliché but you get yourself in some strange situations and meet some outrageous people.' The more outrageous ones ended up between tracks on Let's Get Killed . Holmes and his friends got drunk, posed as journalists and raced around the streets with a DAT machine. 'I didn't want to sample other people's dialogue any more so I thought I'll go and get my own.'

The latest album and movie project were devised simultaneously. Lisa Barros D'sa, a Belfast friend, has written the screenplay and the pair are wooing potential producers on both sides of the Atlantic. Inspired by Midnight Cowboy and Performance , Living Room charts the story of a small-town young man who goes to the big smoke in search of his wayward brother and 'encounters all these sort of strange experiences and relationships. He eventually experiments with a futuristic drug that causes dysphasia'.

Ask him about his fame as a DJ and it's clear Holmes doesn't want to spend his life watching revolving black vinyl. His future is in soundtracks. He has just signed up to score actor Adrian Dunbar's directorial debut Stations of the Cross , a Belfast-set thriller. Then he reunites with Soderbergh for the Ocean's Eleven remake starring George Clooney, Julia Roberts and Brad Pitt, and possibly Bruce Willis and Michael Douglas. 'It's going to be a dirty, funky movie,' he enthuses. Soderbergh has got the right man for the job.

 Bow Down to the Exit Sign is released tomorrow on Go! Beat.

fields.headline: Kids wanna rock!
fields.standfirst: Muse are in search of teen spirit
fields.trailText: Muse
fields.body:
Muse, London Astoria

It's not easy being the best new rock band in Britain these days. Radio stations don't want to play your singles, newspapers don't want to write about you; one of my colleagues even has a theory that the audience for dark, angsty guitar music - exactly the kind in which Muse specialise - has disappeared with the rise of ecstasy. The huge success of Radiohead may seem to refute this, but their fans are mostly in their twenties and thirties. Is there a serious possiblity that the army of moody adolescents who made stars of bands such as The Cure and The Smiths have deserted rock because the drugs keep them happy?

Certainly, Muse have had to work a lot harder than most of their predecessors to get the modest success they've had to date (250,000 albums sold worldwide, a new single trying to fight its way into a Top 10 dominated by UK garage and teen-pop), but you could put that down to them simply not being good enough. Their first album, last year's Showbiz, though it contains four or five great songs, is too full of wearying bluster and derivative filler to be taken entirely seriously. Then again, so was Pablo Honey , Radiohead's largely forgotten debut. Thom Yorke and friends came good through constant touring and the onset of maturity.

With an average age of 21, Muse are clearly in the same bracket - and, on the evidence of this intense, exciting show, heading in the right direction (though it's notable that most of the faces in the crowd look slightly older than those on stage). Of the 16 songs they played last Tuesday night, four are new, and shot through with a sense of confidence and ambition reminiscent of The Bends .

Admittedly, critics have written similar things before about bands such as Strangelove and Geneva, only for them to fall by the commercial wayside, but Muse are different in several respects. They're a trio, so they're naturally leaner and more direct than a five-piece. Like most good rock bands, Muse lie somewhere between the antithetic poles of punk and prog - but on stage they're closer to Nirvana than to Pink Floyd.

Having said that, there's more depth and density to the sound than you might expect. Matt Bellamy is an astounding vocalist, a ferociously accomplished guitarist and plays odd snatches of keyboard too; Chris Wolstenholme switches between bass guitar and an oddly shaped electric double bass; and Dominic Howard hits his drums scarily hard.

Listening to Bellamy's tumbling, squealing falsetto and watching his hollow cheeks and staring eyes, the person who comes to mind is the late Jeff Buckley, though without quite the same level of animal charisma or vocal virtuosity. What really let Muse down, though, are the tunes. With a few golden exceptions - the arpeggio keyboard riff of 'Sunburn', the atypically gentle new single 'Unintended' - the songs are more dynamic than memorable. They need an anthem - a 'Creep' or a 'Smells Like Teen Spirit'.

But at least this is rock played with vitality and without irony by a young British band. That in itself is pretty rare these days. When Muse trash their instruments at the end of the last song, 'Showbiz', it feels like neither a cliché nor a joke, just an exhilarating act of catharsis by three gangly boys. Now all they have to do is find some tormented teenagers to share their pain.

 'Unintended' is out now on Mushroom Records

webTitle: Woody jazzes it up and McDowell gives it both barrels

fields.headline: Woody jazzes it up and McDowell gives it both barrels
fields.standfirst: Allen rediscovers the virtue of pathos, while British gangster movies find their true guv'nor
fields.trailText: Sweet and Lowdown (95mins, PG). Directed by Woody Allen; starring Sean Penn, Samantha Morton
fields.body:
Sweet and Lowdown (95mins, PG). Directed by Woody Allen; starring Sean Penn, Samantha Morton

Gangster No.1 (103mins,18). Directed by Paul McGuigan; starring Malcolm McDowell, David Thewlis, Saffron Burrows

Eye of the Beholder (112mins, 18. Directed by Stephan Elliott; starring Ewan McGregor, Ashley Judd

Drive Me Crazy (91mins,12). Directed by John Schultz; starring Melissa Joan Hart, Adrian Grenier

The Underground Orchestra (108mins, PG.) Directed by Heddy Honigmann

The Barber of Siberia (195mins,12). Directed by Nikita Mikhalkov; starring Julia Ormond, Richard Harris

Samantha Morton doesn't say a word. She is Hattie in Sweet and Lowdown, and also its heart. 'It's my day off, and I want a talking girl,' Sean Penn complains to begin with. 'Goddamn mute, orphan half-wits,' he adds shortly thereafter. This is a modest return to directorial form by Woody Allen after the barren Celebrity . He wrote it years ago and took it off the shelf in critical adversity, a return to roots.

Penn, all primped hair and horrendously tight suits, is Emmet Ray, the allegedly second greatest jazz guitarist (after Django) of the Thirties. A warped ego; a chauvinist pig; a pimp; a drunk, coward and kleptomaniac. But magic when he plucks the strings. Morton, in this phoney docubiography, is the girl he met on the boardwalk, lived with for a year and never quite got out of his pathetic system.

Penn gives another virtuoso performance, the genius with a heart of crud. The chuckles, if not outright laughs, keep coming. Maybe it tails away a bit as Penn moves on to marry Uma Thurman's randy socialite or grow desperate with Gretchen Moll's blank floozy. Nevertheless, the essential pathos is there.

He's a shell who needs his silent partner, Morton's wonderfully mobile face moving from adoration to desolation, a mime of the mind. When she's gone, he is gone as well.
