Saffron Burrows is not, by any means, the only good thing about Gangster No.1; but after an iffy run of parts she is notably fine as a mobster's moll with a faithful heart. Burrows, long, feisty and talking the London lingo she grew up with, needs a director who brings out the best in his cast. Paul McGuigan, going big screen after the triumphs of The Acid House , is clearly that.

There isn't a false note in this artfully structured saga of gang life through the past 30 years. Paul Bettany, with baby face and Cagney eyes, plays No.1, an upwardly muscular hood from the tower blocks who falls under the spell of the local Mr Big, Freddy Mays (David Thewlis). Together, they rampage, maim and extort in the hallowed Kray way.

But Thewlis falls for Burrows and (as hooligans do) begins to grow gooey. Bettany, passion thwarted, stitches him up and sends him away until the present day, when the prison doors swing open. Ashley Judd, she of the chipmunk smile and haunting eyes, is a star without modern parallel, a child of the Forties reincarnated. Last year, she was June Allyson, radiant mum, in Double Jeopardy , battling wife fighting back. Eye of the Beholder makes a Gene Tierney of her: a beautiful, serially driven murderess who bewitches a British secret service agent with domestic troubles of his own (Ewan McGregor). She drags him, in obsessive love, across the cities of America and the wastelands of Alaska as her guardian angel.

Stephan Elliott, from Priscilla, Queen of the Desert , doesn't really know whether this is macabre romance or portentous thriller. McGregor is required to be pretty anonymous again - and spends (our) taxpayers' money so lavishly that Gordon Brown might drop Oxbridge and turn on MI6. Higher tosh! But Judd, clothed by Valentino in dresses to die for, is a treat, the undoubted reason why this was a brief box-office champion in the States.

And the other big question about romantic comedies - endlessly recycled across the movies of the past two years - is, of course: who's taking who to the high-school prom? Drive Me Crazy has nothing original to offer by way of answers. The two stars get it together. Why else are they stars? But Melissa Joan Hart (Sabrina the resting teenage witch) and Adrian Grenier are winsome enough, more able than usual to make up their own minds. Rob Thomas's screenplay has some nice sight gags, as when Hart drops her mobile phone from a great height on to a screaming cat. John Schultz directs with an amiable zest.

It isn't great, but it isn't bad, and it prompts only one big question in return. Why are America's teen turn-ons, as here, always a good six years older in real life than the characters they play? Hart looks like a pastier Doris Day; Grenier is out of university, never mind college. Do their audiences want to pile on the years of self-identifying maturity? And, if so, when do they want to start shedding them again?

Recipe time (1). Take no money worth talking about, one Dutch documentary maker (Henny Honigman) and an original idea. Call it The Underground Orchestra. Go to Paris, go to the Metro, and talk to the street musicians scraping a living.

They are the dispossessed of the globe; from Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe, Arabia, Latin America. They have trouble with visas and landlords and the police. But they love their music and play it well - and so they become defined human beings to us, not statistics on some asylum-seekers' chart.

They are artists we can relate to, and are thus infinitely sympathetic. It is a brilliant notion, brilliantly executed. What's the difference between political and economic refugees? Nothing here. They are all people like us. We bleed when they bleed. The Romanians on the streets have never been so human or so comprehensible. Bring Ann Widdecombe or Jack Straw if you see them in the foyer - but go.

Recipe time (2). Take $35 million and one lauded Russian director (Nikita Mikhalkov). Mix Dr Zhivago, Titanic and Chitty Chitty Bang Bang. Season with talent from seven European countries and decorate with sumptuous scenes from inside the Kremlin. Add passionate love, heartbreak, tragedy, outrageous comedy.

It's got everything, so surely it must be a Hollywood-shaking success, a bombe surprise ? No, it's The Barber of Siberia. Just a bomb. This Barber opened at Cannes last year and exited to boos and groans. It has not been much heard of since.

The unluckiest actress of the week, Julia Ormond, working to Mikhalkov's own screenplay, is a seasoned American adventuress in1885 Moscow, recruited by Richard Harris, a crazed inventor of the monstrous tree-felling machine he calls his barber, to con development cash out of Tsar Alexander the Third (the modest Mikhalkov again).

She falls for a young mili tary cadet called Tolstoy (Oleg Menshikov). He falls even harder for her. Thereafter, amid much epic to-and-froing across continents and decades, everything falls apart. To be fair, some audiences (Eastern European ones especially) seem to have found this operatic blending of emotions ripely enchanting, but that can only be a question of national taste.

Here it just feels odd and dislocated, which makes it almost impossible for the imported actors. Menshikov, touching 40, plays 22 with total self-belief, but Harris resorts to berserk grotesque and Ormond is a true victim. She is a competent, comely non-star of an actress. Here, she's supposed to be Audrey Hepburn (in War and Peace), Julie Christie and Garbo rolled into an impossible bundle. Mikhalkov has a damnable habit of shooting her straight on, emoting, to camera. Cruel impossibility. She's innocent, OK?

This is a disaster without villainesses.We learn two things. That you can only make memorable movies (like Oblomov ) if you stick to what you know, stay with your cultural roots, forget pastiche Hollywood. And, second, that time can be an implacable enemy. This Barber lasts for three hours. You go in feeling spruce and you stagger into the light needing a haircut.

fields.headline: Where's the beef?
fields.trailText: Once We Were Warriors | Child of our Time
fields.body:
Once We Were Warriors R5

Child of our Time (R4)

There are times when only radio will do. We heard two of them last week. The first was George Mitchell's description in Once We Were Warriors (Radio 5) of a wrestling match between Giant Haystacks and Big Daddy. Five million viewers, mainly women, switched on regularly every Saturday afternoon in the Seventies to watch fighters such as Mick McManus and Jackie Pallo slug it out in the ring on ITV. As examples of beefcake they were prodigious, nay awesome, but still sufficiently nimble on their feet to chuck each other about and put on an entertaining show. Sometimes they got so excited the audience joined in. A woman once scrambled through the ropes and bit Adrian 'Nature Boy' Street in the leg.

Wrestling changed in the Eighties. Beef gave way to lard. Giant Haystacks was 6ft 9ins, weighed 39 stone and, recalled Mitchell, came out of his corner wearing only a napkin. Not a pretty sight, just listening to it turned my stomach. In the circs, I respect the then newly appointed head of ITV Sport's decision in 1988 to drop wrestling from the schedule because it was out of touch. It was a brave decision - I personally wouldn't care to antagonise anyone weighing 39 stone, wearing a napkin. Despite protests and threats to do him over, Greg Dyke stuck to his guns. Sadly we weren't told what the new BBC director general thinks of the extraordinary success of American WWF wrestling on Channel 4 these days.

The second example of quintessential radio was the first play in Radio 4's five-part drama series Child of our Time. Was it coincidence that echoes of Spoonface Steinberg's piping little voice came to me as I listened to 13-year-old refugee Sia Mia's account of rape and murder at the hands of Sierra Leonean rebels? It was Lee Hall, author of Spoonface, who together with Kate Rowland, head of radio drama came up with the idea of dramatising the views of five real children from totally different backgrounds in Africa, Brazil, Lapland, Korea and finally Britain. The playwrights, including Hall, interviewed the children and wrote the plays based on their stories.

So why not just make documentaries? Well, in part they are. Behind the voice of Bemnet Tadesse who plays Sia Mia you can hear her real voice and the voices of the children in the refugee camp on the borders of Guinea and Liberia.

Here's where the skill of the dramatist comes into its own. Jill Adams's interpretation of Sia Mia's harsh, raw and probably jumbled account gives hope to hopelessness and point to apparent futility. We were warned beforehand that the play contained powerful images. The most powerful that I was left with was that children still represent the only hope the world has.

It was an ambitious concept, and probably a fairly expensive one too but if this is a taste of the four to come it is a risk that has definitely paid off.

webTitle: The many faces of Morris, dancer

fields.headline: The many faces of Morris, dancer
fields.standfirst: Sometimes he's an elephant; at others, he's Dracula; occasionally, he resembles Bette Davis. In whichever manifestation, Mark Morris is always the choreographer who speaks first and thinks later
fields.trailText: Sometimes he's an elephant; at others, he's Dracula; occasionally, he resembles Bette Davis. In whichever manifestation, Mark Morris is always the choreographer who speaks first and thinks later.
fields.body:
The face which thrusts itself into your face when you meet Mark Morris is rather scary, especially if it's early in the morning. 'How insulting!' he shrieked when I commiserated with his bloodshot eyes. Then he checked them in a mirror and winced at the twin sunsets he saw. 'Ohmygod,' he wailed, 'that's the red wine.'

He then retreated behind a pair of shades and further obfuscated himself in a cloud of fag smoke. His voice, thanks to the liquor and fumes, is a foghorn, but it booms from inside a body which is frisky and androgynous, despite his black stubble and marauding chest hair. Crossing his legs, he displayed a pair of lurid socks which seemed to go with the wine he'd been drinking and began to complain - or should I say bitch? - about the enforced trek from his West End hotel to rehearsals in north London. 'I'm stay ing in Leicester Square because it's near the Coliseum. Then they tell me the rehearsals are in Hampstead, and I'm like, "Excuse me?" It's far away and it's filthy dirty, and anyway I'm thirsty. No wonder I look a mess.'

As he talked, Morris flapped the air with his hands and stirred up minor cyclones. Even when seated, he is - as befits a great choreographer and dancer - a whirling dervish. Yet whereas traditional ballet seeks to achieve lift-off, imitating the aerodynamism of angels, his style of dancing emphasises rootedness, earthy contact with the floor. At his beefiest, Morris resembles one of the pirouetting pachyderms in Fantasia . 'Big bottoms, large breasts - OK with me!' he once remarked in describing the approved physique for members of the Mark Morris Dance Group; their dances resound with the percussive din of bare feet stamping on the floorboards.

Now at ENO, you can see the Maoist marches and ballroom tangos he choreographed for John Adams's opera Nixon in China , which inaugurates a virtual Morris season at the Coliseum. His exultant, pantheistic production of Handel's cantata L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato, which in 1997 played to full houses, returns on 30 June; on 28 June, he pairs Purcell's Dido and Aeneas with a new production of Four Saints in Three Acts, a rarely seen mystical farrago with music by Virgil Thomson and a babbling, blissed-out text by Gertrude Stein.

The Handel and Purcell productions date from Morris's residency at the Theatre de la Monnaie in Brussels a decade ago, when he outraged the Belgians. After being presented to Queen Fabiola, he reported: 'Best blowjob I ever had!' This did not deter him from describing Fabiola's helmet-like coiffure as 'a Maggie Thatcher hairdo of death'.

Remembering his antics in Brussels, he told me: 'I was symbolic of something those people didn't like about each other.' It pleases Morris to think of himself as a nightmare, the energetic embodiment of everything abominated by the stiff, timid bourgeoisie. A nocturnal prowler, outfitted in black except for those red socks and his flaring eyes, he resembles Dracula in drag. His witchy malevolence and his slippery gift for commuting between genders will be displayed in the Purcell opera, in which, while the mezzo-soprano Sarah Connolly sings from the pit, he dances both Dido and the Sorceress who plots her downfall.

'I try to make them as different as possible, though they're opposites who are secretly alike. It's the hair thing that distinguishes them - up for Dido, down for the Sorceress.' He illustrated by imperiously flicking his mane, a raven's nest of entangled strands.

This flouncing reminded me of the resemblance between Morris's Sorceress and two Hollywood bitch goddesses. 'Yeah, Joan Crawford and Bette Davis; those are fabulous actresses. And I also based her on Cruella de Vil. She's gleeful and vindictive, she has just the greatest time with her evil powers.' The Sorceress enjoys herself so much, in fact, that she visibly masturbates during her revels: Morris's female homage, perhaps, to the solitary climax which Nijinsky dramatised by grinding his hips on the scarf of the elusive nymph at the end of L'Après-midi d'un faun e.

In Brussels, people also fussed when Morris's Dido had alfresco sex with the swarthy Aeneas of Guillermo Resto. 'Big deal,' he yawned. 'Dido and Aeneas fuck - why not? It's only showbiz. Everyone in the court is trying to per suade her to get back into dating; that's what it's about. So you see me come. But the sex scene is very formally choreographed, in an archaic style. Anyway, these days it's a middle-aged memory of lust; Guillermo and I are the two ancientest people in my company.'

Morris used to insist on performing Purcell's brief opera on its own. 'It's a tragedy, with the comic witches in the middle of it. Why would you want anything else? Now we're doing it as a double-header. You see one piece, you have a drink - no, a couple of drinks - then you see another piece.' Dido will be preceded by Four Saints , which Morris has long wanted to stage. In doing so, he's aware of the need to combat the hyperbolic legend of the work's premiere.

The first American production of Four Saints in Three Acts, at Hartford in 1934, made modernism chic. High society cherished the piece as a specimen of high camp and referred to the collaborators as Miss Thomson and Mr Stein. Though no one understood Stein's mystically inane libretto, her title became a commercial catch-phrase, and the window of Gimbels department store on Fifth Avenue soon advertised 'Four Suits in Two Acts'.

The jazzy saints, who crooned and strutted in a cellophane heaven, were recruited in Harlem nightclubs. The choreographer, Frederick Ashton, conducted auditions horizontally; Thomson likewise, enthusing over the attributes of black performers, confessed: 'I went up to Harlem and I ended up with my end up in Harlem.'

As Morris admits: 'A lotta people know about Four Saints just as an event. It was like the first night of The Rite of Spring - everyone in the world claimed that they were there, even though they weren't. But I want to get over all that, to make it new again. I always loved Stein's writing, though it's easy to make fun of. It's like your bookmark could be anywhere. You think duh, did I read this already? Not everyone gets what she does, but it provokes thought and produces pleasure.

'Thomson, too, said that his music wasn't for everybody - it was for anybody. Nowadays, postminimalistically, the score sounds different. It's open but it's not empty. There's space in it. Sure, nothing happens. But what could happen? They're in heaven, right? So they're in rapture all the time. It's a festival, a festivity. And it's a fiesta, too. Teresa and Ignatius are Spanish saints; you can hear Spanish folk dances in the music, along with the gospel songs and fugueing tunes and protestant hymns.'

The spirit of revelry - both carnal and spiritual, demonic and divine - is what animates Morris's best dances and explains their popularity. Dance, after all, is jubilant and, therefore, a mode of worship. 'I want the religion in Four Saints to be fun. Next spring, in a retrospective, we're going to pair it with my production of Handel's Dixit Dominus . The God in that is grim, relentless; it's not an easy one to watch. But Four Saints is about people in ecstasy, who just float off the ground. What I love is baroque religiosity. I went to an Orthodox wedding in Skopje. You stand around for hours and get high on incense, then everyone does fabulous dances and gets drunk. I thought, "They sure know how to get married here!" It's the same in India, where they have all these thousands of gods partying in the pantheon. How do they remember all their names?'

When Morris mentioned India, I recalled a glimpse he'd once had of a woman who was the namesake of Stein's Teresa, and is touted by some as a candidate for sanctity. 'Sure, I went to Mother Teresa's outfit in Calcutta one evening. We sat on the floor with those fabulous sisters and shared their prayerbooks. But do I think she was a saint? No, I don't believe in any of that, though I'm happy if other people do. I'm faithless, but I believe in magic. For me, the weird thing was that the visit happened in the evening after I'd been at a temple dedicated to Kali, where I saw this really scary, violent ceremony.'

The conjunction of opposites is typical of Morris, who discovers both Dido and the Sorceress within his polymorphous body. On an average day, he can divide himself between the charitable, celibate crone and the goddess festooned with blood-gorged penises; he attends a mass after witnessing an orgy. He is exuberant and thoughtful, like the schizoid temperaments contrasted in Handel's cantata, but never moderate. He is a force of nature, infectiously rampant. He may even, come to think of it, be Mother Nature in person.

 Mark Morris dance company is at the Coliseum, London WC2 from 28 June

Crossing his legs, he displayed a pair of lurid socks which seemed to go with the wine he'd been drinking and began to complain - or should I say bitch? - about the enforced trek from his West End hotel to rehearsals in north London. 'I'm stay ing in Leicester Square because it's near the Coliseum. Then they tell me the rehearsals are in Hampstead, and I'm like, "Excuse me?" It's far away and it's filthy dirty, and anyway I'm thirsty. No wonder I look a mess.' As he talked, Morris flapped the air with his hands and stirred up minor cyclones. Even when seated, he is - as befits a great choreographer and dancer - a whirling dervish. Yet whereas traditional ballet seeks to achieve lift-off, imitating the aerodynamism of angels, his style of dancing emphasises rootedness, earthy contact with the floor. At his beefiest, Morris resembles one of the pirouetting pachyderms in Fantasia . 'Big bottoms, large breasts - OK with me!' he once remarked in describing the approved physique for members of the Mark Morris Dance Group; their dances resound with the percussive din of bare feet stamping on the floorboards. Now at ENO, you can see the Maoist marches and ballroom tangos he choreographed for John Adams's opera Nixon in China , which inaugurates a virtual Morris season at the Coliseum. His exultant, pantheistic production of Handel's cantata L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato, which in 1997 played to full houses, returns on 30 June; on 28 June, he pairs Purcell's Dido and Aeneas with a new production of Four Saints in Three Acts, a rarely seen mystical farrago with music by Virgil Thomson and a babbling, blissed-out text by Gertrude Stein. The Handel and Purcell productions date from Morris's residency at the Theatre de la Monnaie in Brussels a decade ago, when he outraged the Belgians. After being presented to Queen Fabiola, he reported: 'Best blowjob I ever had!' This did not deter him from describing Fabiola's helmet-like coiffure as 'a Maggie Thatcher hairdo of death'. Remembering his antics in Brussels, he told me: 'I was symbolic of something those people didn't like about each other.' It pleases Morris to think of himself as a nightmare, the energetic embodiment of everything abominated by the stiff, timid bourgeoisie. A nocturnal prowler, outfitted in black except for those red socks and his flaring eyes, he resembles Dracula in drag. His witchy malevolence and his slippery gift for commuting between genders will be displayed in the Purcell opera, in which, while the mezzo-soprano Sarah Connolly sings from the pit, he dances both Dido and the Sorceress who plots her downfall. 'I try to make them as different as possible, though they're opposites who are secretly alike. It's the hair thing that distinguishes them - up for Dido, down for the Sorceress.' He illustrated by imperiously flicking his mane, a raven's nest of entangled strands. This flouncing reminded me of the resemblance between Morris's Sorceress and two Hollywood bitch goddesses. 'Yeah, Joan Crawford and Bette Davis; those are fabulous actresses. And I also based her on Cruella de Vil. She's gleeful and vindictive, she has just the greatest time with her evil powers.' The Sorceress enjoys herself so much, in fact, that she visibly masturbates during her revels: Morris's female homage, perhaps, to the solitary climax which Nijinsky dramatised by grinding his hips on the scarf of the elusive nymph at the end of L'Après-midi d'un faun e. In Brussels, people also fussed when Morris's Dido had alfresco sex with the swarthy Aeneas of Guillermo Resto. 'Big deal,' he yawned. 'Dido and Aeneas fuck - why not? It's only showbiz. Everyone in the court is trying to per suade her to get back into dating; that's what it's about. So you see me come. But the sex scene is very formally choreographed, in an archaic style. Anyway, these days it's a middle-aged memory of lust; Guillermo and I are the two ancientest people in my company.' Morris used to insist on performing Purcell's brief opera on its own. 'It's a tragedy, with the comic witches in the middle of it. Why would you want anything else? Now we're doing it as a double-header. You see one piece, you have a drink - no, a couple of drinks - then you see another piece.' Dido will be preceded by Four Saints , which Morris has long wanted to stage. In doing so, he's aware of the need to combat the hyperbolic legend of the work's premiere. The first American production of Four Saints in Three Acts, at Hartford in 1934, made modernism chic. High society cherished the piece as a specimen of high camp and referred to the collaborators as Miss Thomson and Mr Stein. Though no one understood Stein's mystically inane libretto, her title became a commercial catch-phrase, and the window of Gimbels department store on Fifth Avenue soon advertised 'Four Suits in Two Acts'. The jazzy saints, who crooned and strutted in a cellophane heaven, were recruited in Harlem nightclubs. The choreographer, Frederick Ashton, conducted auditions horizontally; Thomson likewise, enthusing over the attributes of black performers, confessed: 'I went up to Harlem and I ended up with my end up in Harlem.' As Morris admits: 'A lotta people know about Four Saints just as an event. It was like the first night of The Rite of Spring - everyone in the world claimed that they were there, even though they weren't. But I want to get over all that, to make it new again. I always loved Stein's writing, though it's easy to make fun of. It's like your bookmark could be anywhere. You think duh, did I read this already? Not everyone gets what she does, but it provokes thought and produces pleasure. 'Thomson, too, said that his music wasn't for everybody - it was for anybody. Nowadays, postminimalistically, the score sounds different. It's open but it's not empty. There's space in it. Sure, nothing happens. But what could happen? They're in heaven, right? So they're in rapture all the time. It's a festival, a festivity. And it's a fiesta, too. Teresa and Ignatius are Spanish saints; you can hear Spanish folk dances in the music, along with the gospel songs and fugueing tunes and protestant hymns.' The spirit of revelry - both carnal and spiritual, demonic and divine - is what animates Morris's best dances and explains their popularity. Dance, after all, is jubilant and, therefore, a mode of worship. 'I want the religion in Four Saints to be fun. Next spring, in a retrospective, we're going to pair it with my production of Handel's Dixit Dominus . The God in that is grim, relentless; it's not an easy one to watch. But Four Saints is about people in ecstasy, who just float off the ground. What I love is baroque religiosity. I went to an Orthodox wedding in Skopje. You stand around for hours and get high on incense, then everyone does fabulous dances and gets drunk. I thought, "They sure know how to get married here!" It's the same in India, where they have all these thousands of gods partying in the pantheon. How do they remember all their names?' When Morris mentioned India, I recalled a glimpse he'd once had of a woman who was the namesake of Stein's Teresa, and is touted by some as a candidate for sanctity. 'Sure, I went to Mother Teresa's outfit in Calcutta one evening. We sat on the floor with those fabulous sisters and shared their prayerbooks. But do I think she was a saint? No, I don't believe in any of that, though I'm happy if other people do. I'm faithless, but I believe in magic. For me, the weird thing was that the visit happened in the evening after I'd been at a temple dedicated to Kali, where I saw this really scary, violent ceremony.' The conjunction of opposites is typical of Morris, who discovers both Dido and the Sorceress within his polymorphous body. On an average day, he can divide himself between the charitable, celibate crone and the goddess festooned with blood-gorged penises; he attends a mass after witnessing an orgy. He is exuberant and thoughtful, like the schizoid temperaments contrasted in Handel's cantata, but never moderate. He is a force of nature, infectiously rampant. He may even, come to think of it, be Mother Nature in person.  Mark Morris dance company is at the Coliseum, London WC2 from 28 June

webTitle: All sweeties and light (not to mention the go-go dancer)

fields.headline: All sweeties and light (not to mention the go-go dancer)
fields.trailText: Felix Gonzalez-Torres
fields.body:
Felix Gonzalez-Torres Serpentine Gallery until 16 July, and at various London venues, including the V&A, Camden Arts Centre and the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital

At dusk, garlands of golden light bulbs glow above the car-jammed streets of Camden. At the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, a whorl of bulbs radiates benign warmth among the children's wards. From Paddington to Lambeth, the image of an ample bed appears on high billboards. At the Serpentine Gallery, a carpet of silver sweets covers the floor like sparkling snow. Take one - as the signs encourage - and the dazzling rectangle will slowly melt away. This is the work of Felix Gonzalez-Torres, the Cuban artist who died at the age of 39 in 1996. During his short lifetime, Gonzalez-Torres had shows all over the world, culminating in a retrospective at the Guggenheim in his adoptive New York.

His work is permanently displayed - or endlessly replenished - in many European cities; every day, people take sheets from his poster stacks in Munich, liquorice from his sweet spills in Paris and Bilbao. There is always more - and much of it has finally arrived in London: an art of slender means, an ephemeral art.

Gonzalez-Torres makes poetry out of almost nothing. At the Serpentine Gallery, curtains of blue chiffon billow gently in the breeze, filling the room with fluctuating waves of marine light. Twelve strands of glowing bulbs cascade from the ceiling, collecting on the floor in a pool of golden bubbles. A curtain of glass beads, silver and turquoise, twinkles in the light like a continuous waterfall. Walk through it and you experience the approximate sound and motion of tumbling water.

This is all intensely seductive and beautiful, guaranteed to evoke visions of moonshine, summer seas, the aurora borealis, even sultry afternoons in beachhouse bedrooms. Everything is achieved with great simplicity and tact: discreet charm being both the characteristic and the idiom of Gonzalez-Torres's art.

His needs are few - some fabric, bulbs, sockets and sweets. But is what he makes as simple as it looks?

Take that field of toffees wrapped in silver foil, a double enticement long ago concocted by Quality Street. Eat Me, says the label. But what if you do? That pristine sight will disappear, short-lived as the toffee in your cheek. Perhaps you pinch a lime sherbet from the take-one heap. What if it's the last one - will that be the end of the artwork and how can it still be the property of a private collector, as the caption insists, if the final grains of sugar have just dissolved on your tongue?

Ownership, consumption, dematerialising objects, open-ended ideas versus unique works of art: all of them debated to death, you might think, by the conceptualists in the late Sixties. It's true that Gonzalez-Torres continues to thwart the market: no Manhattan millionaire can sell his G-T print if an unlimited supply of duplicates exits every day from the Serpentine Gallery. It's also true that his ideas were blithely unprescriptive: museums can choose their own confectionery, hang those light-strings almost any way they like. Since there was no original, no intellectual copyright, the artist was always surprised that people didn't just buy some bulbs and make their own versions.

But Felix Gonzalez-Torres was never a theorist. He loved minimalism - its elegant restraint, if not its austere detachment.

Look at his lights and you see Dan Flavin's cool neon defrosted; every floor-piece of sparkling sweets winks playfully at Carl Andre. But this formal aesthetic always has another dimension in his art: a sense of time sifting by, of the hourglass waiting to be upended.

Paper stacks shrink, light bulbs expire, sweet spills dwindle to nothing. The question of whether or when to replenish them is out of the artist's hands.

'Without a public my works are nothing.' The literal truth of this statement runs right through the Serpentine Gallery.

Without dancers, Gonzalez-Torres's dance floor is only a square of light bulb bunting and a Walkman with two headsets tuned to a waltz.

His paper stacks - two piles, one bearing the legend 'Nowhere better than this', the other 'Somewhere better than this' - come alive only when people choose between them. His mirror is just a square of blue glass until someone looks into it and sees the world reflected in spectral shadows.

The mirror is called Untitled (Fear) . Gonzalez-Torres makes light of this metaphor, tucking its pri vate meaning - he was suffering from Aids - discreetly between those brackets. There is the same lightness of touch in the memorials to Ross, his long-dead lover. The endless heap of sherbets is subtitled Rossmore (also the name of the street where they lived). A pair of clocks, ticking in synchronised unison, is subtitled Perfect Lovers .

In a sense, Gonzalez-Torres's art now consists of a set of instructions for a posthumous party: the lights, the sweets, the waltzes, the chiffon, even the go-go dancer who appears for five silent minutes each day at the gallery, dressed in silver lamé.

The Serpentine has never looked better, filled with these bright, delicate, minimal works. But the experience is inevitably elegiac. The sweet you take as a souvenir today was for Gonzalez-Torres a memento mori.

webTitle: Last night a DJ made a killing

fields.headline: Last night a DJ made a killing
fields.standfirst: Choose disc. Place on turntable. Put the needle to the record. Become deified and immensely rich... Why?
fields.trailText: Of all the things that you imagine £10,000 will get you, a DJ is probably not what springs to mind. But that's what you'd have to pay for three hours' work by a premier-league record spinner if you're promoting a night at one of the hipper clubs in town.
fields.body:
Of all the things that you imagine £10,000 will get you, a DJ is probably not what springs to mind. But that's what you'd have to pay for three hours' work by a premier-league record spinner if you're promoting a night at one of the hipper clubs in town. The wages commanded by some of the stars behind the turntable decks have reached such dizzying proportions that one London promoter recently started a lobby to combat the inflation.

As the members of this exclusive set fly over to Ibiza this week for the start of a lucrative summer playing dance records to barely-conscious ravers, it's time to blow the whistle on this most over-valued of modern occupations.

First, let's be fair. It has not been an overnight success story, nor entirely undeserved: DJs have played an important part in the dissemination of black and popular music for years. They were crucial to the birth of rock'n'roll and hip hop. They furthered the cause of disco, where 'the mix' - the continuous flow of beats - moved the energy from the stage to the dancefloor.

Some time in the Nineties, however, the DJ became deified. Hitherto invisible, he was moved into the spotlight. You can now see him on the sleeves of stylishly presented compilation or mix albums. The INCredible Sound Of... series put the likes of Trevor Nelson, Gilles Peterson and Jo Whiley on expensively packaged CDs.

It was, of course, simply a response to the need for personalities, for 'faces'. The problem is that the issue of creative rights in dance music has become blurred in the process. The very name of the compilation The INCredible Sound Of... posits the DJ as creator. But whose music is it really? Who wrote it? Who made it?

Trevor Nelson didn't, nor did Jo Whiley. Compiling and mixing a CD takes skill but it shouldn't be portrayed as a form of composition. Putting DJs on sleeves consolidates the overrated status they enjoy in clubs. A promoter told me: 'DJs have turned into the rock stars I hated in the first place.'

The term 'DJ' now covers a variety of occupations: some produce, some remix, some create their own music - Masters At Work, for instance, use musicians as well as samples - and some just play records on the radio, like they did in the old days. We welcomed DJs because we were sick of guys with phallic Fender guitars but they're now being pulled down a similarly conceited route. Sexism is rife - the most publicised female DJ in Britain, DJ Rap, is a former Page Three model - and racism bubbles below the surface.

'DJs are to dance music what the Spice Girls are to pop,' says Lyn Cosgrove, the woman who co-ordinated The INCredible series. 'They've become the pop stars of the new century.'

Dance music has mutated from rebellious subculture to corporate superculture, and everything about it - from the door price to the factory-size dancefloor to the DJ's fee - has swollen wildly out of proportion.

At New York's Paradise Garage, probably the most legendary of all clubs, you couldn't actually see the DJ booth - it was deliberately hidden to shift the focus to the dancefloor. Larry Levan's sets were famous, but he was never bigger than the musicians whose records he played.

Even more important than the division between the DJs and musicians, is the schism between the superstar DJs (Fatboy Slim, Pete Tong, Paul Oakenfold, Sacha et al ) and the underground selectors. This echoes the growing divide between dance music and black music.

In the Eighties, Indeep sang 'Last Night a DJ Saved My Life' - and it was kitschy, unpretentious. In the Nineties, Faithless claimed 'God Is a DJ' and the joke was lost. The problem now is that DJs think they are gods and the people around them are too mesmerised or obsequious to let them know the truth - that all they do is spin records made by other, more talented people.

We live in an age that glorifies spin. To quote Artful Dodger's recent number one... let's rewind, selecta.

webTitle: With colours courtesy of My Little Pony

fields.headline: With colours courtesy of My Little Pony
fields.trailText: The Sleeping Beauty
fields.body:
The Sleeping Beauty Royal Albert Hall, London SW7

Derek Deane's new Sleeping Beauty for English National Ballet introduces Aurora into an arena filled with celebrants, surrounded by a sea of spectators. She has to make her way into the heart of the swirling action, where she will be promenaded by four suitors as she balances with her leg raised in an elegant attitude, a test of nerve as well as of skill. Erina Takahashi came through with shining confidence at Thursday's premiere. Twenty-three years old, she is the first product of the English National Ballet School to claim such a demanding role.

The balletic society on the Albert Hall stage is both strange and familiar. Deane has rechoreographed most of The Sleeping Beauty, the most symmetrical of ballets, to suit the setting in the round. It is as if Tim Rice had rewritten the libretto of an opera while keeping the famous arias (more or less).

This is Aurora lite. The heavy version will be at the Royal Opera House from tomorrow, when the Kirov performs its reconstruction of the 1890 production for the Imperial Ballet. Deane has reduced the pomp and invented his own circumstance, with the help of Roberta Guidi di Bagno, the designer of his Romeo and Juliet in-the-round.

She has transformed the Albert Hall's organ loft into a multi-storey castle, with the orchestra placed along the battlements. The cast pours out into the arena like skaters in an IceCapades spectacular. Gliding ladies-in-waiting, long skirts concealing their feet, do resemble skaters. But then come cohorts of fairies in tutus, an assurance that this is a ballet, performed by beautifully trained dancers.

Although the designs are inspired by Fragonard paintings, the colour palette seems closer to My Little Pony, with added spangles. The contrast is all the greater when Carabosse crashes the christening party. Glamorous in black, she is accompanied by fiends who whirl her around in a serpent carriage, before holding her aloft to deliver her curse on the court.

Anastasia Volochkova, made even taller by a Cruella de Vil hairdo, towers over Cecilia Kerche's Meissen Lilac Fairy. Deane has placed the emphasis of the ballet on the power struggle between good and evil. Aurora is a pawn, her prince a knight in thrall to rival queens. Kerche dances with truth and dignity; Volochkova, formerly with the Kirov and Bolshoi, delivers a Russian temptress, all high kicks and baleful stares.

Her role goes awry in Act II, when she tries to seduce the prince (Dmitri Gruzdyev) during his search of Aurora. He's not Siegfried, torn between sultry Odile and virginal Odette; he's Florimund, a man with a mission. He gets there in the end, though Carabosse's descent through a hole in the forest floor is so riveting that I barely noticed Aurora's filigree bed of thorns.

The Act III wedding is celebrated in the prince's palace, with guests in tails and ballgowns. The entertainers are in fancy dress, hired, perhaps, from the court ballet company. The fairies pay a courtesy visit only once Aurora and Florimund have completed the pas de deux solemnising their marriage.

Takahashi and Gruzdyev danced Deane's adaptations with aplomb. Aurora can show that she has grown up a bit, but not that she brings a history of classical dancing as her dowry. A shower of fairy dust has to compensate for a lack of magic in the last act. Until then, Deane has succeeded in democratising this hierarchic ballet without diminishing its power.

Anastasia Volochkova, made even taller by a Cruella de Vil hairdo, towers over Cecilia Kerche's Meissen Lilac Fairy. Deane has placed the emphasis of the ballet on the power struggle between good and evil. Aurora is a pawn, her prince a knight in thrall to rival queens. Kerche dances with truth and dignity; Volochkova, formerly with the Kirov and Bolshoi, delivers a Russian temptress, all high kicks and baleful stares. Her role goes awry in Act II, when she tries to seduce the prince (Dmitri Gruzdyev) during his search of Aurora. He's not Siegfried, torn between sultry Odile and virginal Odette; he's Florimund, a man with a mission. He gets there in the end, though Carabosse's descent through a hole in the forest floor is so riveting that I barely noticed Aurora's filigree bed of thorns. The Act III wedding is celebrated in the prince's palace, with guests in tails and ballgowns. The entertainers are in fancy dress, hired, perhaps, from the court ballet company. The fairies pay a courtesy visit only once Aurora and Florimund have completed the pas de deux solemnising their marriage. Takahashi and Gruzdyev danced Deane's adaptations with aplomb. Aurora can show that she has grown up a bit, but not that she brings a history of classical dancing as her dowry. A shower of fairy dust has to compensate for a lack of magic in the last act. Until then, Deane has succeeded in democratising this hierarchic ballet without diminishing its power.

fields.headline: Singular couples
fields.standfirst: The writer of Strictly Ballroom steps confidently onto the stage
fields.trailText: Speaking in Tongues, Hampstead, London NW3
fields.body:
Speaking in Tongues, Hampstead, London NW3

Five Kinds of Silence, Lyric Hammersmith, W6

Hard Times, Haymarket, SW1

Speaking in tongues cynical cycle of love, the couples involved here suffer and falter - and their circle shatters to become a broken line. The play is written by Andrew Bovell, co-author of the film Strictly Ballroom - and although much darker than the film, is every bit as captivating.

Two couples are slow-dancing with a mirror behind them like a pool. At times, they speak in unison to comically suggestive effect. They reflect the abject way in which people in love talk - they can become possessed by cliché as well as by each other. And when individuals speak out or voices fail to collide, there is a sense of how solitary each person is within a relationship.

The play is a quartet but each actor plays more than one part. Nigel Le Vaillant is riveting as three men (each harrowed for different reasons). Jonathan Guy Lewis is superb as Nick and as Leon, a cop who struggles to police his own feelings. Juliet Prew affectingly conveys two women who, although superficially different, share their vulnerability. And Katharine Rogers as Sonja and Sarah shows there is a price to be paid for being too poised.

Bovell explores love, marriage, strangeness, intimacy, trust, betrayal, obsession, self-punishment and detachment with generous emotional intelligence. And the play has such pace and dynamism that the audience is never bogged down. Mark Clements directs with flair. What more can I say? It is beaut, mate.

In Shelagh Stephenson's Five Kinds of Silence there is only one way of talking: the hard way. This is a harrowing play about sexual abuse in which two daughters shoot their abusive father. Tim Pigott-Smith gives a terrifying portrayal of a man who haunts himself. He is a control freak who knows - as such people do - that chaos is beating at his door.

The play is never sensational; it is outraged, claustrophobic and frightening. It is a portrait of women whose feelings have become atrophied, who come 'from a different world'. Linda Bassett plays Mary, the mother. She movingly parodies the ordi nariness that eludes her. Gina McKee's Susan is superb: at once wounded and defended. Janet (Lizzy McInnerny) is disturbingly distrait. She lost the ability to smile while her father was alive; now her face is taking lessons in living again.

Ian Brown directs this powerful piece with a sure hand and Peter McKintosh's design is oppressive in exactly the right way (three scarlet coats hang on a peg looking criminal). But for all the production's ingenuity, there is no disguising the fact that Five Kinds of Silence started life as a radio play.

The musical Hard Times is not a period piece. It never reaches Victorian England. If it looks dated, it is because it is. It was written by Christopher Tookey and Hugh Thomas 30 years ago. A secondhand wardrobe seems to have been emptied for the occasion - its costumes all faded to rouge. This might not matter - we could pull a moth-eaten veil over it - were it not that Tookey's direction is so hand-me-down too.

The novel has been irregularly served by making circus performers and Dickens himself act it out. Brian Blessed plays the novelist as a smiley charlatan in a ticking waistcoat, and his Thomas Gradgrind is an implausibly soft-centred utilitarian. Malcolm Rennie's Bounderby is as benign as Gradgrind. He is a hot-air balloon waiting to be punctured. Forget Dickens's Coketown. This is Joketown. Every scene is compered by Roy Hudd as Mr Samuel Sleary, the circus-owner who, when he isn't pretending to be a nerdish countrywoman in a showercap, is cracking jokes, panto-style.

Dickens's genius was his animation and intellect; he never had to strain to entertain. He was energetically sentimental. If he had a flaw, it was that he did not understand romantic love. But at least his sentimentality tastes as sweet as a violet pastille. Here, the sentimentality is all humbug.

Only Peter Blake as Mr James Harthouse, a stereotyped seducer in a dressing gown with an alligator grin, brings light, lewd relief with his repeated one-liner: 'Haven't we met somewhere before?' But these Times are not Hard, they are Dull. We are in an old lack-of-curiosity shop where everything has been sung before.

 Susannah Clapp is on holiday

fields.headline: Steely span transforms the capital
fields.standfirst: The new crossing over the Thames is like a floating magic carpet. On it London looks and sounds different
fields.trailText: The new crossing over the Thames is like a floating magic carpet. On it London looks and sounds different.
fields.body:
The great thing about the seven-minute walk from Bankside to St Paul's, across London's first new bridge in a century, as compared with a trip around the London Eye, say, is that you are actually going somewhere. The bridge offers a perspective of London just as astonishing in its way as the view from the London Eye. But at the end of the trip you don't have that slightly lame feeling of being right back where you started.

The bridge has the effect not just of changing how a key part of the river looks, but also how it functions. For the first time it is possible to walk directly from the trading floors and the corporate headquarters of the north bank to the ducking- and-diving, south-of-the-river world of lock-up garages, council flats and railway arches that is still at the heart of Southwark, despite the epidemic of urban regeneration triggered by the Tate.

Negotiating the bridge is also an intensely physical experience. Under a thundery gun-metal grey sky, there is the unmistakable gamey tang of low-tide London mud in the air. You can feel the beginnings of rain in the breeze, and the slight bouncing judder of aluminium underfoot. And of course there is a remarkable unfolding perspective of London as you move forward.

Southwark's foreshore is one of the few vantage points from which it is possible to understand the pattern of London's growth and to get a sense of the city as a physical entity. You can see the mark left on London's topography by what, beneath all the reinforced concrete and plate glass, is visibly still the same marshy flood plain pockmarked with gravel banks that the legions of Emperor Claudius I encountered in AD43. From here you can read London's history, economic, and political, inscribed in the physical form of the city, like the rings of a tree.

Despite such violent intrusions from the twentieth century as the instantly recognisable saw-toothed silhou- ettes of the Barbican's towers and the stainless steel rolling pin that was once the National Westminster Bank's high-rise headquarters, only the dome of St Paul's itself stands out, clearly defined against the skyline effortlessly crushing a riverfront scrum of buildings of bone-chilling mediocrity from the 1960s and 1970s.

As you walk across, the viewpoint shifts, and the dome of the cathedral gets bigger and bigger, until you find yourself drawn into the north bank, where it appears almost vertically above you at the top of a river of stone steps. Stop midstream, and there is the remarkable sense of being afloat on a waterscape as if you were on a tightly rigged racing catamaran. The silence is in sharp contrast to the rumbling thunder of trains that made London's other pedestrian crossing, Hungerford Bridge, so daunting.

The design is the product of an unusually diverse group of people. Norman Foster was the architect. Ove Arup were the engineers. But it was the sculptor Antony Caro who brought the team together to win the competition for the commission, beating among others, Frank Gehry and Richard Serra. They have created a bridge that is a beautiful object, lithe and delicate, but which still manages to acknowledge the magnitude of the task facing its builders. Spanning a fifth of a mile of water with just two supports is no party trick. But the bridge doesn't want to boast about it either. Rather than pumping up the structure like a bodybuilder on steroids, they have given the bridge muscles that ripple under the skin, like a sleek racehorse.

Teamwork is one of those touchy-feely words that architects love to use, but which seldom describes the reality of warring egos, and competing claims for credit. For once it actually reflects what really happened. Without the engineers, the bridge would not stand up. Without the architects, there would never have been the manic attention to detail that treated the design of every bolt head and weld as a major architectural issue. Without Foster's design skill, and highly effective championing of the bridge against doubters it would never have been built.

And without Caro? In its present form it's hard to see Caro's direct involvement, but without him it would have been an entirely different bridge. He remained fully involved, even when the original design, a project that would have had a much clearer Caro signature, was modified in response to the request from the competition judges for a less sculptural design. 'People ask me which part of the bridge is mine,' says Caro. 'And, of course, I can't point to any single aspect of it. But that isn't really the issue. The idea of a sculptor, an architect, and an engineer working together is what really makes this bridge different, and I was there when all the important decisions were made.

'Asking a sculptor to do a handrail at the last moment is the old-fashioned way of working. We did it the new fashioned way, and that was wonderful. I've learnt that architects think differently from us artists. We can say things they wouldn't dare to, like "why not try it upside down?". We think from a unexpected standpoint. We don't take practicality into account. On the other hand they can tell us quite a bit about scale.'

The brief for the competition organised by the Financial Times was a paradoxical one. The bridge had to be beautiful enough to be considered worthy of celebrating the millennium. But it also had to be invisible enough not to compromise the view of St Paul's. For the engineers that meant a low structure which did not have the effect of creating a visual tunnel, or cage. 'We wanted people to be able to see out at every point,' says Roger Risdill-Smith from Arup. 'We saw it as a flying magic carpet floating just above the river.'

The solution is a flat suspension bridge, consisting of a deck, and two piers in the river. It may not look like a suspension bridge. There are none of the characteristic towers to hold up the cables, but that is what it is. Rather than rise above the bridge deck, the cable bunches are grouped on either side of the structure, like the outriggers of a canoe, barely rising above the level of the main bridge structure. What makes a bridge such a demanding design task is that every aspect is on show, and is visible from every direction.

There is no room for camouflage. Everything is visible, nothing is hidden. It is an aesthetic conception distilled to its essentials. The bridge is as beautiful as the smallest bolt head, and as the springing curves of the suspension cables. It achieves a balance between the solidity of its graceful piers, and the lightness of the aluminium deck, and has the curious effect of feeling as if it had always been there.

 Blade of Light: The Story of the Millennium Bridge by Deyan Sudjic is published by Penguin at £14.99. To order this book for the special price of £11.99 plus 99p p&p call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171

webTitle: I fell for a false siren call from across the hall

fields.headline: I fell for a false siren call from across the hall
fields.trailText: True confessions
fields.body:
Looking back now, now, several years later, I remember hearing about other women obsessed with boyfriends, or celebrities and, rather than shake my head or tut-tut, I understood, because I was obsessed at the time with the man across the hall from me.

I was at the lowest ebb of my life, when, one day, this new neighbour held the door of the lift open for me. I remember not being able to believe someone like him could have moved in so close to me. I barely said a word or raised my eyes. I was dazzled, as if he had thrown glamour dust at me.

He was so beyond my reach I didn't think much of him, until one summer day, I ran across him again. The sexual tone of his voice and the prolonged eye contact was all I needed to start hoping. Suddenly he was no longer beyond my grasp and it was then that I became infatuated. Living so close I could hear his comings and goings without even trying. I overheard his conversations with friends and I learnt that he was a civil servant, aged 30, but no amount of knowledge seemed to be enough. It only meant that I wanted to know more.

We saw each other occasionally and the general atmosphere was sexual; I noticed he never asked personal questions. At first, the thought of a quickie was enough to sustain me, but then I thought no, I wanted him to love me! It was absurd.

And then the unbelievable happened. On New Year's Day, I heard him say to a friend, that he was going to be taking down his Christmas decorations that afternoon. An hour later, he was bringing a stack of boxes down eight floors and I noticed he hadn't locked his door. It was a chance to enter my fantasy lover's inner sanctum. It wasn't even a matter of choice: I had no choice. I had to go into his flat...

It was immaculately clean and almost looked unlived in, like a showroom. The carpet was white, his audio and video equipment were brand new, and his bed was made without a crease in the linen. I quickly fled. I couldn't believe what I had done. But there was more to come. One night, when I was coming home and saw him get into his car after throwing out the garbage, I did the maddest thing I've ever done: I decided to go through it! I took the garbage bag up to my room and opened it. Thank God he was a clean freak. The ooky bits were in separate bags. I learned he liked orange juice and milk! The best find was an old severance sheet showing his work history, and where he'd lived before. It was all too much, and I hurriedly took the bag back outside.

And so it went on, until one fine afternoon, he told me he was moving. He even said, 'we'll have to keep in touch', although, when I said yes, there was only a sort of leering response from him. He looked me up and down again.

I slowly began to realise it would never be anything more than this. The strangest thing is, when he finally did move out, my mania for him stopped. It was as if, while he was around, I was caught in a vortex. We spoke to each other by phone only once and the conversation was strained, and led nowhere. I had made a fool of myself over a siren song that wasn't real.

 If you have a true confession email kim.bunce@observer.co.uk

webTitle: How can I stop my husband beating our son?

fields.headline: How can I stop my husband beating our son?
fields.trailText:
My husband and I have a son, six, and a daughter, three. I have never smacked or disciplined them. However, my husband believes in corporal punishment. Recently, the situation seems to have become worse, generally resulting in in our son being smacked for every mistake. I have threatened to take the children away because they are frightened to sit at the dinner table in case they knock the salt over. My husband was ill-treated as a child and is prone to depression. The children are not being abused, but I am concerned they will end up hating their father.
J.R. of Ruislip
fields.body:
My husband and I have a son, six, and a daughter, three. I have never smacked or disciplined them. However, my husband believes in corporal punishment. Recently, the situation seems to have become worse, generally resulting in in our son being smacked for every mistake. I have threatened to take the children away because they are frightened to sit at the dinner table in case they knock the salt over. My husband was ill-treated as a child and is prone to depression. The children are not being abused, but I am concerned they will end up hating their father.
J.R. of Ruislip

 This is not a happy situation and it is not in anyone's interest to let it persist. Your husband's obsession with discipline is more than extreme, it is pathological; it is cruelty to those who cannot retaliate.

Many parents, myself included, have found the occasional slap to be effective; but liberally used, such reprimands can descend into self-indulgent, ill-tempered, gratuitous viciousness. It is all too easy to unleash anger on a child, especially where it may have been kept on a tight rein all day in the world of competitive adults.

Your nature sounds gentle and placatory. You have already taken evasive action, stood between your children and your man and made impotent threats. These are the actions of a deferential female. Now it is time to become a ferocious mother bear. Get angry. He may be intimidated and the children will be impressed, and briefly feel protected. Insist that never again does he hit them - or you will walk out, all three of you. But you have to mean it.

The fact you must face is that he is not going to change, though the focus of his savagery may. Your husband does not seem to have found a legitimate outlet for his particular nastiness.

You have three choices - stay, walk out or persuade him to go. If you stay, you will be obliged to be constantly vigilant, erecting a barrier between him and them, being a stronger figure than you are naturally - an exhausting business and risky. It is likely his violence will be turned on you.

Should you decide to leave, you can get help from the local social work department or children's centre. Finally, if you have a showdown with your husband, who may turn to jelly like many a bully when you confront him, you might be able to give him his marching orders. Your first duty is to your children. They must be removed from his power before more damage is done.

Readers' replies

I trust it is not true that you have never disciplined your children; it is the role of parents to enable their offspring to be self-controlled. If you are lax, your husband might be over-compensating. However, guidance should never be harsh. My sister and I were both uncomfortable at our father's funeral, listening to the plaudits. I was 15 when he stopped hitting me, at my mother's insistence. In apology, he said he loved me and I suspect this explains my subsequent confusion over the term. Like your husband, he had a harsh childhood and he was a Dunkirk rescuee. I think he just could not cope if his adult years were not calm and perfect.

You and your husband must seek counselling.
S.M. of Peterborough

A climate of fear and tension is not conducive to a stable environment. Parenting is a big responsibility. Much of what is learnt is from parents. You and your husband are your children's role models for femininity and masculinity. Your husband's childhood victimisation is no excuse for his behaviour. He needs help to understand the gravity of his actions.
N.G. of Swindon

Next week's dilemma is from L.R. of Ilford

My mother is 82 and has senile dementia. Three months ago I persuaded her to give up her home (she rented a flat for 52 years) and move in with me, my husband and two grown-up children of 21 and 18. She has her own room but is prone to tempers and tearfulness and needs care virtually 24 hours a day.

Our family life is going to the dogs. My husband is losing his patience and is now suggesting that we put her in a home. I can't do this as I am sure it will be the end of her. In more lucid moments she has joked about bottles of pills and whisky rather than a home. At the same time I do not want to destroy the home we have built for our children. Her dementia is only going to get worse and this could continue for a number of years. Where do my loyalties lie?

fields.headline: 'It's a new Cultural Revolution'
fields.standfirst: They romped in their underpants on Tracey Emin's bed and had a naked ketchup fight outside Buckingham Palace. But Cai and Xi are not pranksters - they're serious artists. Or so they say...
fields.trailText: They romped in their underpants on Tracey Emin's bed and had a naked ketchup fight outside Buckingham Palace. But Cai and Xi are not pranksters - they're serious artists. Or so they say...
fields.body:
Around 3.20pm last Saturday, 10 people dropped their trousers in front of Buckingham Palace in protest at the British monarchy. They were hauled away by the police and the crowd broke up. But then a cameraman found a spot of brown liquid on his clothes. He wiped it off, looked at the sky. What kind of rain was this? He soon found his answer. Two men, both stripped to the waist, each flicking a bottle of either ketchup or soy sauce at the other, lurched into view giggling hysterically. They continued pelting each other, hitting onlookers indiscriminately, until eight bottles were empty, and their bodies were drenched in sauce.

The performance complete, the two men reached into a plastic bag and started handing out leaflets describing the 'Naked Soy Sauce and Ketchup Fight At Buckingham Palace'. The leaflet invited 'all visitors... to participate' and then gave the names of the 'performers': Yuan Cai, 44, and Jian Jun Xi, 38, two former art students from north London. 'Long Live the People', it proclaimed in large print. The people looked on, bemused.

To the crowd, Cai and Xi may have appeared familiar. Last October they found their performance art - or 'live art' as they prefer it to be known - all over the papers. One afternoon, the two Chinese artists discreetly joined a party of Japanese tourists who were weaving their way through the Tate Gallery towards Tracey Emin's latest work, My Bed - a dilapidated collection of skid-marked sheets, used condoms and vodka bottles strewn around a mattress. The two men sprang from the crowd, stripped down to their underpants and then began romping on the exhibit. A pillow fight ensued. They shouted something in Mandarin. Cai tried to put on a pair of underpants he found on the bed. Then the police arrived. The Tate declined to press charges.

Cai and Xi are keen to harvest some artistic credibility from their new-found fame. Sitting in the WKD bar in Camden, they describe themselves as 'heroes... ahead of our time', searching for a 'new route' in art. Emin, however, says they are 'gimmicky', and wishes that the Tate, whose responsibility she considers it to look after her work, had had them charged. 'It was upsetting and disturbing - a criminal offence,' she said. 'I wouldn't go round to someone's house, smash up a coffee table and call that art. It's terrorism - like some failed artist threatening to jump off Waterloo bridge unless they're given a gallery.'

Cai and Xi prove unfazed when I convey Emin's comments. 'She's the failed artist, struggling in the system to network with the right people and hang out with the critics. Tracey's been recruited to the London Mafia of artists - a gang who try to dominate the scene.'

Cai and Xi first performed together at Cité des Arts in Paris, colluding in 1994 for the 'Shit a Day' piece, for which they defecated daily on to a plate, before sitting down to eat it. Another recent stunt was on 21 May, again at the Tate, when they made a contribution to Marcel Duchamp's seminal work, the Fountain, a factory-made urinal he chose to autograph in 1917 and call art. Cai and Xi urinated on it for over a minute, their contribution kept away from Duchamp's porcelain by the work's Perspex case. Some say they missed the point.

The Tate are not amused with Cai and Xi, choosing only to fax a terse statement about their exploits. 'The pleasure of our visitors has twice been disrupted by two artists who have threatened works of art and our staff. Tate will be taking action to protect the interests of visitors, the safety of the works of art in the collection and its employees.' They declined to say what the action would be.

Cai and Xi take their art very seriously, despite frequently collapsing into giggles when talking about it. I ask why they felt they had to add to Duchamp's work. 'The urinal is there - it's an invitation,' says Cai. 'As Duchamp said himself, it's the artist's choice. He chooses what is art. We just added to it.'

Xi, the stockier and friendlier of the pair, jumps in. 'Modern British art is getting worse and worse. They haven't taken any risks. The mainstream are caught in a circle, and we are outside that circle - pissing in.'

One might dismiss them as publicity-hungry charlatans, leeching off a renaissance in British art. But wasn't that renaissance built on sensation? Pickled sheep, elephant dung, tents filled with the names of the artist's ex-lovers - all grabbed the headlines with cynical ease. Cai and Xi have, for the majority of their works, relied on defacing or 'contributing to' the work of another artist. When we met last week, they told me how they intended to add to their canon. Yesterday, at the Institute for International Visual Arts in Hoxton, in front of the assembled luminaries of British art, Cai was supposed to lie down in the middle of the floor and make a crucifix pose. He would then invite Xi to be the first of the onlookers to urinate into his mouth.

I ask them, three days before this event, if they worry that their coprophilia means they'll never be taken seriously. 'We are not ashamed, we have no roots. We can eat our shit in public,' insists Xi. 'We want to make people think. We are ahead of our time. Future generations will understand us.' I ask them what exactly the future generations will understand - what they are trying to say. 'The statement we're making is "yes, this is a new possibility",' explains Xi.

These kind of exploits have been seen before, of course. In 1976 Carl Andre's bricks at the Tate were sprayed with blue food dye, by a man protesting against their purchase, and dye was added to Damien Hirst's sheep installation at the Serpentine in 1994.

Minor works of vandalism - such as pencil scratching on paintings - were found by a recent survey of museums to be surprisingly common. But major attacks were a different matter: their perpetrators were mostly men who want publicity and make no attempt to escape from the scene of the crime. More than half such attackers have been detained under the Mental Health Act. It is thought that, for some, an attack on a piece of work is a substitute for an attack on a person. And one defence is common: the assailant is making a 'positive contribution' to the work.

Cai and Xi do not seem in need of a sectioning order. They are two sane, talkative men, who live on Becks beer and cigarettes. Cai is a father of three, Xi is divorced. They grew up in China, under Mao's Cultural Revolution. Cai found himself in trouble at the age of 16. He had been listening to Simon and Garfunkel on the radio. A former member of the Maoist boy scouts, the Little Red Guards, he plotted to flee to Russia. His father, a state publisher, informed on him. Cai spent three years in jail, one of them doing hard labour.

He and Xi met at art college in Nanjing. They married English nationals and got UK passports. Then they went to art school. 'At Chelsea and the Royal College of Art, I was in the same college as Tracey Emin and Dinos Chapman,' says Cai. 'They were both doing boring pictures of squares and flowers - no skill at all.' Xi graduated from Goldsmith's.

In 1996 they joined forces again for a piece called 'New Directions' in the Venice Biennale, in which they erected 125 misleading road signs, suggesting for example that there was a toilet down a street where there wasn't one. The next year, they graced the Museum of Modern Art in Oxford: Xi lay on the floor, and Cai drew a white line around his body, as though it were a murder scene. Recently they have lived off various commissions, one for a festival of Chinese art funded partly by the Arts Council. In 1998 Xi attempted a piece called 'Week Of Suffering'. He stuck chillies up his nose and mouth, lay with a raw fish down his throat and rammed a marrow in his mouth. Someone took pictures - these are an essential part of the piece. Then came Emin's bed, and stardom.

'Since we jumped on the bed we see so many possibilities,' says Cai. 'We are determined to make a new way of looking at art. No artist can take the risks we do or have our ideas.' Again, I ask what their 'new way' is. The response - from Xi - is incomplete. 'It's action, direct action. We are also anti-class system,' he says. 'We want people to think that our work has political elements.' Elements that say what? What is the message? 'Look at this!' he says, raising his hands to an imaginary work of art. 'That is the message.' We agree to meet again the following day to give them more time to formulate a proper answer.

The next day Cai complains of a troubled sleep. They haven't been able to find an answer to the question - what are they trying to say? They can say, however, that they want to 'make people happy' and bring attention to art and society. They have big plans for July and have targeted some unlikely sponsors for a new piece. They intend to ask a restaurant - the New Cultural Revolution, in Camden, north London - to collect the faeces of a week's customers. Cai and Xi will smear themselves in it and then go to the Tate, where they will walk around the exhibits discussing the works and recording their conversation. The owner of The New Cultural Revolution has yet to hear of their plans.

After this, they intend to go one stage further. Chairman Mao, at the beginning of the Cultural Revolution, swam the Yangtse River to prove his physical fitness. Once they leave the Tate, Cai and Xi will swim across the Thames. The river police put their chances of survival as 'slim'. Still, at least they won't have to wash those trousers.

fields.headline: I'd rather be 40 than 14
fields.standfirst: Buying a bullet belt for my stepson, I realised I wasn't having a midlife crisis after all
fields.trailText: Buying a bullet belt for my stepson, I realised I wasn't having a midlife crisis after all.
fields.body:
Here are some examples of 'difficult' ages: 0-three months (anarchy); eight months ('separation anxiety'); two ('terrible'); 13-18 (adolescence); 30 (unwelcome end to youth); 40 onwards (midlife crisis); old age (no gloss needed). We are all 'going through a stage'. We are - most of us - at a 'difficult age'.

But what's age got to do with it, as Tina Turner almost sang (as the greatest age-defier in the pop world, she should have done). We all defer to age. We look at each new decade as if it were an augury, a predictor of our state of mind. We expect age to be a symbolic key, but it cannot tell us much. If anything, it is like one of those gold-coated plastic keys that used to be stuck on twenty-first birthday cards. It is not reliable. And, like those birthday keys, it cannot open any real doors.

I asked my grandmother one day (I was seven) while we were picking lavender, how old she was. There was a pause. 'Ninety-nine,' she replied tartly. There was no mistaking the rebuke. Age evidently was a subject to be tidied away, like the lavender we would later tuck into muslin bags. I was put out that she did not want to answer my question. I was hurt to be thought tactless and felt cheated by her lie. For children, 'How old are you?' is the first and most important question to settle.

As a child, you boast about your age; later, you may lie about it. For a child, each new year is a higher score. And then suddenly you want to shout 'stop!' My mother-in-law advises me to 'stay 39' but I've let things slide. I am 42. For many people, their twenties are the most unhappy time of their lives - partly because they are not advertised as 'difficult'. In the same way that parties are often disagreeable because you are obliged to look as though you are having a good time, it can be a strain being in your twenties. I am all for an official 'terrible twenties' label.

I have often wondered whether I might have a midlife crisis. The idea of reinventing yourself is always attractive. And this week I have had a guide to hand: Martin Amis's autobiography (curious that even his initials should stand for middle age). Oddly, I had been pondering the implicit expectation in the book that the forties almost routinely bring turmoil in their wake when something happened to suggest that the reverse might be true. Perhaps, like all age clichés, this one needs to be taken with a pinch of salt. Midlife crises may not be all they are cracked up to be.

I was on a mission to buy my stepson a belt. He is 12 (a difficult age). He and his 14-year-old brother are converts to the charm of heavy metal (music and props). I'd been given some hints (more rumour than precise instruction) from my stepson about where to go and presently found myself in Camden Town in north London. The market has been a favourite haunt of adolescents for decades. It is crowded, seedy, trendy and inexpensive. I wound in and out of shops before fetching up outside one I was not quite sure about entering. At the door was an assistant in black leather, dripping with chains who looked like a bouncer and was pierced in many places like an abortive stapling experiment.

I stepped inside the shop which was dark, small and malodorous. It smelt of leather and of something else, more unsavoury, harder to identify. A pale girl with hair like turquoise cotton wool stared at me over a bank of silver jewellery. Studded belts hung from the walls like whips or nooses and an atmosphere of passive violence obtained. In the corner a fat, swarthy man, who was almost as old as me, skulked.

I felt intensely self-conscious. My clothes were wrong: my rusty linen suit, my stone-grey, tailored jacket, my middle-aged face and middle-class voice. I was an alien and the assistant evidently thought so too. He was breathing down my neck, as if he didn't trust me at all. I stared at studded chokers in mauve, scarlet and fake zebra skin. What I wanted, I ventured uncertainly, was a belt to go round the waist. 'Most belts do,' he said in an unfriendly way. I had been feeling small, now I felt invisible. 'I don't know where any of these things are supposed to go,' I protested weakly. And it was at this point that he produced the belt.

It was composed entirely of silver bullets, hanging like fierce pods in a row and all strapped together with rubber. It was a ludicrously macho, violent yet original item, unlike anything else in the shop. One of the bullets had been painted a lethal scarlet. It weighed a ton. And even the smart-alec assistant was none too clear about how to get the damned belt round his waist. He wrestled with it for some time before getting the better of it. It was costly and frightening - too frightening to turn down. 'I'll take it,' I whispered.

The man in the corner stepped forward, the manager as it turned out. He looked me up and down dismissively. 'Come with me,' he said, 'I have the perfect trousers for you. Upstairs.' 'No,' I said, with effort. 'I have quite enough trousers already. I am happy with my trousers.' I headed for the street.

At the time, in the shop, I thought this is what it means to be middle aged. But now I see that what I was feeling was nothing of the kind. It was a flashback to being 14: self-conscious, hoping I looked right, hoping not to be too ridiculous, hoping I might have chosen the right belt.

Nothing has changed. That 14-year-old is still inside but must not be let out again on any account. 'You're as young as you feel,' the cliché goes. Well, thank God it isn't always true. I suddenly saw what is seldom acknowledged, that middle age is not a crisis but an oasis: the relief, the joy of not being 14 any more!

But never let on that you know what it is to be anything other than middle-aged. I must find my equivalent of the bullet belt, and belt up. I know because I once enthusiastically volunteered at supper time that, as a teenager, I too had been a regular in Camden Town, down at the market. And I was well into describing the furs, the battered army coats, the cracked leather jackets, the second-hand granny dresses, before I looked up and saw my stepson's face registering polite incredulity and an alarmed disinclination to hear more.
