We are all 'going through a stage'. We are - most of us - at a 'difficult age'. But what's age got to do with it, as Tina Turner almost sang (as the greatest age-defier in the pop world, she should have done). We all defer to age. We look at each new decade as if it were an augury, a predictor of our state of mind. We expect age to be a symbolic key, but it cannot tell us much. If anything, it is like one of those gold-coated plastic keys that used to be stuck on twenty-first birthday cards. It is not reliable. And, like those birthday keys, it cannot open any real doors. I asked my grandmother one day (I was seven) while we were picking lavender, how old she was. There was a pause. 'Ninety-nine,' she replied tartly. There was no mistaking the rebuke. Age evidently was a subject to be tidied away, like the lavender we would later tuck into muslin bags. I was put out that she did not want to answer my question. I was hurt to be thought tactless and felt cheated by her lie. For children, 'How old are you?' is the first and most important question to settle. As a child, you boast about your age; later, you may lie about it. For a child, each new year is a higher score. And then suddenly you want to shout 'stop!' My mother-in-law advises me to 'stay 39' but I've let things slide. I am 42. For many people, their twenties are the most unhappy time of their lives - partly because they are not advertised as 'difficult'. In the same way that parties are often disagreeable because you are obliged to look as though you are having a good time, it can be a strain being in your twenties. I am all for an official 'terrible twenties' label. I have often wondered whether I might have a midlife crisis. The idea of reinventing yourself is always attractive. He is 12 (a difficult age). He and his 14-year-old brother are converts to the charm of heavy metal (music and props). I'd been given some hints (more rumour than precise instruction) from my stepson about where to go and presently found myself in Camden Town in north London. The market has been a favourite haunt of adolescents for decades. It is crowded, seedy, trendy and inexpensive. I wound in and out of shops before fetching up outside one I was not quite sure about entering. At the door was an assistant in black leather, dripping with chains who looked like a bouncer and was pierced in many places like an abortive stapling experiment. I stepped inside the shop which was dark, small and malodorous. It smelt of leather and of something else, more unsavoury, harder to identify. A pale girl with hair like turquoise cotton wool stared at me over a bank of silver jewellery. Studded belts hung from the walls like whips or nooses and an atmosphere of passive violence obtained. In the corner a fat, swarthy man, who was almost as old as me, skulked. I felt intensely self-conscious. My clothes were wrong: my rusty linen suit, my stone-grey, tailored jacket, my middle-aged face and middle-class voice. I was an alien and the assistant evidently thought so too. He was breathing down my neck, as if he didn't trust me at all. I stared at studded chokers in mauve, scarlet and fake zebra skin. fields.headline: 'What? Frasier playing Macbeth?'
fields.standfirst: The cast: America's biggest TV star; the English stage director; and an Observer journalist.  The setting: Boston and New York.  The time: The present...
fields.trailText: The cast: America's biggest TV star; the English stage director; and an Observer journalist. The setting: Boston and New York. The time: The present...
fields.body:
Is this a Frasier I see before me? No, it's the classically-trained actor Kelsey Grammer, who just happens to have found fame and fortune as TV's Dr Frasier Crane, strutting the Shakespearean stuff he has loved since childhood. During Frasier 's summer break, Grammer could be forgiven for lolling beside his LA pool like any other superstar, counting his money in the sun. Instead, he has chosen to take a chance on Broadway, braving one of the stage's ultimate dares: Macbeth.

Thanks to Cheers and Frasier, Grammer is the most successful star in the history of US television, now enjoying an unrivalled eighteenth year in the top 10 ratings, and said to earn seven figures per half-hour episode. So why is he putting himself through this? 'I know, we never learn, do we?' he shrugs with a wan grin at Sardi's, Broadway's favourite watering-hole. 'It may sound corny, but the stage is my first love. It's where I started out. In television, you lose that intimate contact with the audience. If I don't go back to live theatre every few years, I begin to feel... rusted.'

It is 24 hours before Macbeth 's first public preview and a week till opening night. The critics, he thinks, will be out to get him on Thursday, even before they file into the Music Box Theater. 'Oh sure, even when it was first announced, they started yelling What? Frasier playing Macbeth? That guy?' It is only thanks to Grammer's grace under such pressure, both onstage and off, that the production has made it this far. It's been a long, hard road to the Great White Way.

Clowns proverbially want to play Hamlet. But 45-year-old Grammer is no mere clown, more a gifted and versatile actor who has tackled plenty of Shakespeare since his student days at New York's Julliard School, and in rep before 'lapsing' into TV. He has played Richard II and supporting roles in Hamlet and Othello . But he's been haunted by Shakespeare's murderous thane for 20 years, since fate propelled him into the title role as a 25-year-old Broadway understudy. 'I wasn't very good,' he recalls matter-of-factly. 'I was too young.' Back in 1980 noted thesp Philip Anglim pulled out because, to Grammer's tactful memory, 'he got sick'. Broadway veterans recall that it was more to do with 'lousy reviews'. Which makes the progress of Grammer's latest Macbeth from New England to New York all the braver. For last month's notices of his Boston try-out were worse than he feared.

'You can take the boy out of Frasier , but you can't quite take Frasier out of the boy,' wrote Ed Siegel of the Boston Globe . Grammer's Macbeth was 'capable and often daring' but 'rarely distinguished'. The Boston Herald pinned the blame for 'this mess' on its British director, Terry Hands, he of 25 years with the Royal Shakespeare Company. To the Herald 's Terry Byrne, Hands had 'no respect for the text'. Grammer's performance offered 'absolutely no insight' into the character. William K. Gale of the Providence Journal-Bulletin proved a lone voice in the critical wilderness: 'How is Kelsey Grammer? Well, he's pretty darn good.'

Backstage in Boston, despite packed houses and standing ovations, crisis duly loomed. For a few days, the show's future teetered as the producers considered pulling the plug and Grammer pondered the wisdom of braving New York's notoriously hard-to-please critics. Maybe, for all the advance hype - whole page ads in the New York Times, Frasier's sonorous voice repeatedly telling upscale radio listeners just how 'complex... driven... dark' Macbeth is - the men in suits would chicken out and cancel the Broadway transfer.

So it was to a tense Colonial Theater in Boston, right around the corner from the Cheers bar where Grammer first made Frasier's name, that I hied me 10 days ago to judge for myself. As a devout Frasier fan, I wanted to catch what might prove my only chance to see a production surely destined for legendary status, whether as triumph or disaster, even as legendary, perhaps, as Peter O'Toole's 'tomato ketchup' Macbeth at the Old Vic in 1980. So did Macbeth's 'vaulting ambition, which o'erleaps itself', apply to Frasier's attempt to play Shakespeare's 'butcher' king? No, not at all. I wound up agreeing with Mr Gale: Kelsey Grammer's Macbeth was pretty darn good.

OK, Laurence Olivier he ain't. More Kenneth Branagh, thoroughly convincing and excellent in parts without leaving all that much etched on your soul. But there were certainly those vital benchmarks by which an accomplished actor makes so huge a part his own.

A naturally introspective stage presence, Grammer can be sinister at unexpected moments; by the wily way he asks Banquo: 'Is't far you ride?', you know just what's on his dastardly mind. He speaks the verse well, is spot-on with the rhythms and emphases of the big soliloquies, and grows persuasively deranged as he progresses from warrior-hero to murderous tyrant to fatalistic corpse-in-waiting.

Macbeth's confrontation with Banquo's Ghost (unseen in this production by the audience) is particularly effective. With only a handful of guests at the vast table to point up the tyrant's growing isolation, Hands craftily places Lady Macbeth (the excellent Diane Venora) in the empty seat, so that her husband winds up nearly throttling her. As his comeuppance nears, at the hands of the feistiest Macduff I have ever seen (Bruce A. Young), his eyes go Archie Rice-dead as the news of his wife's death has him tomorrowing toward all our yesterdays.

Because we already warm to Grammer via Frasier as a genial, vulnerable if uptight sort of guy, the thane we first meet really is 'too full of the milk of human kindness' to proceed all that blithely with the murder of Duncan. But there are fewer pros than cons to Grammer's celebrated alter ego. An undeniable (and seemingly unavoidable) problem arises when an actor with such familiar comic body language decides to go legit. Grammer's natural walk, for instance, is a laborious sub-Groucho Marx waddle, all splayed feet and bent knees, neck bobbing like a chicken's. It works to great effect in Frasier , when he lopes across the room to tackle some passing crisis, but proves less apt when his Macbeth is required to stride off one side of the stage while, in true RSC fashion, the next scene is already under way on the other. But you can't do much about that, I told Hands down the phone to Wales, where he was taking a break between Boston and Broadway to deal with a crisis of his own at the Clwyd Theatr Cymru, which he now runs. 'Oh yes, I can. What else?' So I told him about the bouncing eyebrows. To my surprise (and horror), Hands relayed this to Grammer, who apparently 'cracked up' when I was quoted as calling the production 'too RSC'.

More phone calls followed. By the time both men arrived in New York last week, Grammer having persuaded the producers that, to hell with the critics, the show must go on, I almost felt part of the production team. By Thursday night's dress rehearsal, I was backstage at the Music Box as Hands tried to erase the last vestiges of Grammer's Frasier from Grammer's Macbeth in time for the first preview.

The new-grown beard helps, and the smaller theatre offers a better focus for Grammer's resonant voice and Hands's cleverly orchestrated shafts of light amid the claustrophobic darkness. But that measured Frasier tread... it even sparked recognition in the eyes of passers-by as Grammer, otherwise anonymous behind his shades, plodded across West 44th Street from Sardi's to the theatre.

'I hope I've shed Frasier's mannerisms,' he told me. 'I really don't want his nervous tics coming along for the ride. It's the same voice, of course, but I use it quite differently. As for the walk... ' A shrug, and he waddled off to don his make-up.

Hands is cunning enough to hide Grammer's famous face behind an elaborate helmet on his first entrance, denying audiences their chance to applaud this stellar Macbeth before he has opened his mouth. Well, this is America, where Shakespeare gets a brief programme note plus credits as 'playwright', alongside a synopsis of the play which does not shrink from giving away the ending.

New York audiences will no doubt compensate, as did Boston's, with a thunderous standing ovation at the end. But are catharsised Frasier fans applauding Kelsey Grammer or Frasier Crane, or Grammer's Frasier, or Frasier's Macbeth, or even Grammer's Frasier's Macbeth? It was the question which dared not speak its many names as I tried to avoid putting Grammer off his Shakespearean stride.

So I asked it anyway. 'Look,' he sighed with an authentic Frasier grimace, 'Frasier's a breeze compared with this. I think the real point is that stage acting is quite different from small-screen work. You use the same techniques and skills, but in a much larger way. And Shakespeare, of course, makes for a different kind of theatre. Here in America, there's a built-in reverence - this is distant, this is grand. People don't expect a production to be urgent, gripping, as I hope this one is. But I've noticed, after a tuning-in period of 10 minutes or so, that they're on the edge of their seats. A lot of them, I'm delighted to say, are people who've never been to Shakespeare before.'

En route to this 'major moment' in his career, Grammer has lived through serial drama and tragedy of Shakespearean proportions. Born in the US Virgin Islands, he was 12 when his father was shot dead, by a man subsequently acquitted on grounds of insanity. Eight years later, his sister was abducted, raped and murdered in Colorado. Five years after that, his two half-brothers died when attacked by sharks while scuba diving.

Small wonder, perhaps, that Grammer found solace in drink and drugs. Busted for drunk-driving and cocaine possession, then rearrested for violating his probation, he served 30 days in jail, flipped his car again and finally checked himself into the Betty Ford Clinic in 1990. When his second marriage collapsed amid it all, his wife suffered a miscarriage while attempting suicide, then told all to tabloid TV.

Shakespeare, he says, helped him through all this. At 13, traumatised by the death of his grandfather (of natural causes) so soon after his father's murder, he was introduced by a 'wonderful' teacher to Stoicism as exemplified by Brutus in Julius Caesar. 'I had already been turned on by Shakespeare's language as young as 10.' From Brutus, he learned that 'we can maintain an essential dignity while not allowing our emotions to rule our lives'. He had found 'a refuge' in Shakespeare and 'a passion for his language'.

Third time around, he has now found teetotal happiness in marriage to a former MTV dancer, Camille Donatacci. A visit to their website (www.kelseylive.com) reveals that their surrogate (as yet) children are two Basenji dogs named Little Red and Prince Bakuma Zen Koji. Grammer posts his views on subjects ranging from alcoholism to the bombing of Iraq and the impeachment of Clinton ('I wish that whatever occurred in the Oval Office had never taken place'). He videotapes monthly greetings to his fans, answering their painfully predictable questions with infinite patience. Post-tax profits from the site are devoted to worthy causes supported by his charitable foundation.

Does he find himself drawing on his own tragedies when squaring up to a role like Macbeth? 'No, I'd rather not. I managed to play Laertes without having to think of my own dead sister to grieve for his. Because I'm on TV, almost everything I do seems to have huge consequences, whether I like it or not. You could say the same of Macbeth. But any incidents that may have occurred in my own life are never as interesting as what's in the play. If something from the past passes through my mind on a particular evening, though, then that performance can take right off.'

Hands considers Grammer's Macbeth 'outstanding - quite worthy of Stratford'. When I suggest casting him next as Iago, to Bruce Young's Othello, he agrees: 'Nice idea. But you know who I actually see Kelsey as, milking both his comic skills and his dramatic power? Richard III.'

The dress rehearsal is done, the walk straightened out and the box office is doing booming business. Tomorrow, the punters will start arriving, followed on Thursday by the critics. Is Grammer superstitious? 'No. I don't have a problem saying the name of my part backstage.' But will the jinx on the 'Scottish play' strike yet again this week, in the shape of the New York critics' make-or-break reviews? 'Life,' groans Grammer, 'is designed to be tough.'

Whatever the critics say, summer audiences on Broadway seem likely to follow Boston's lead in taking no notice and plonking sell-out bums on seats. Fail? Frasier fail? Kelsey Grammer has screwed his courage to the sticking-place and does not deserve to fail.

The dress rehearsal is done, the walk straightened out and the box office is doing booming business. Tomorrow, the punters will start arriving, followed on Thursday by the critics. Is Grammer superstitious? 'No. I don't have a problem saying the name of my part backstage.' But will the jinx on the 'Scottish play' strike yet again this week, in the shape of the New York critics' make-or-break reviews? 'Life,' groans Grammer, 'is designed to be tough.' Whatever the critics say, summer audiences on Broadway seem likely to follow Boston's lead in taking no notice and plonking sell-out bums on seats. Fail? Frasier fail? Kelsey Grammer has screwed his courage to the sticking-place and does not deserve to fail.

fields.headline: Now God is cool
fields.standfirst: Kids don't want cant. They despise spin. They are searching for answers. That's why they're saying God bless Christianity
fields.trailText: Kids don't want cant. They despise spin. They are searching for answers. That's why they're saying God bless Christianity.
fields.body:
Ask most people what they think of when the words Born Again Christian are mentioned and before you can say Cliff, they will talk about sandals, fanatics and happy-clappy church services. They may offer opinions on Glenn Hoddle's god squad or Jonathan Aitken's evangelical Rolex or a bloke they once knew who went to Wembley Stadium to hear Billy Graham and was never quite the same again.

Nine out of 10 will conclude their remarks with a snatch of The Lord's Prayer sung to the tune of 'Auld Lang Syne'. Labels die hard.

Fortunately for Christianity, or at any rate most people's perception of Christianity, there is now a new, improved - dare one say cool - way to salvation which is simultaneously solving the perennial 'more-bums-on-pews' dilemma. It's called Alpha. In its present form (it originated in the late Seventies but was updated 10 years ago) Alpha has successfully rebranded Christianity to appeal to people, mainly young people - the average age of those who have taken an Alpha course is 27 - who would rather be crucified than wear sandals. Muscular Christianity these days refers to New Age Christians who belong to a gym.

Charlotte Bromley Davenport, aged 25, public school and university educated, did the Alpha course in January. She is tall, slim, bright, friendly, funny, beautiful, talks about films, fashions and boyfriends and works as a photographer for Vogue . She now runs a group specifically geared to take Alpha into prisons. She is a totally committed Christian but at the same time completely relaxed about her faith.

'If it comes up in conversation, of course I'll talk about it but I don't bang on about it.' Her friends include converts and non-believers. She recently dumped a boyfriend after much agonising because he was a committed atheist but is that so different from a twitcher dumping a self-confessed pigeon strangler? Is the Alpha course at all similar to Billy Graham's way of teaching? 'Who is Billy Graham?' asked Charlotte.

Seven thousand churches in Britain, 15,000 worldwide, covering every Chris tian denomination from lowest Baptist to highest Catholic run the Alpha course. So do 80 of our 170 universities and colleges and 120 out of 158 prisons. When the Reverend Sandy Miller, rector of Holy Trinity, Brompton in Knightsbridge first thought of running the course Alpha was designed for regular churchgoers. It was his curate Nicky Gumbel, a barrister by training, who turned it into a sort of beginners' guide to Christianity for non-believers, or at least people who when filling in forms automatically put C of E in the religious box without knowing why.

At 63, Sandy Miller says he belongs to a generation who went to church but never thought to question their religion. It was something you were taught at school, like Latin. Today's sceptical, streetwise younger generation are curious. They won't be fobbed off with cant; they want explanations, answers, inspiration. A 10-week Alpha course including a couple of voluntary residential prayer weekends provides them with all of these.

The 900 or so students arriving at Holy Trinity, Brompton, just around the corner from Harrods, for the fifth lecture in the current series 'Why do we pray and how do we pray?' last Wednesday night did not look like your stereotype happy-clappy. The sessions started at seven and many of them had clearly come straight from work, young men still making deals on their mobiles as they turned into the tree-lined lane that leads to HTB, girls in sleek designer suits and high heels carrying briefcases. Overheard snatch of conversation: 'Are you going to Archie's do tomorrow night?' 'Yes, but later - I've got a presentation at six and t'ai chi at eight.' The atmosphere inside the church falls somewhere between school assembly and a cocktail party except that there's no alcohol and no one is trying to look obviously cool. Everyone looks happy, friendly and alert, unlike the disciples at the Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh's ashram in Poona where everyone looks happy, friendly and stoned. There's a queue for supper - £2.50, shepherd's pie and coleslaw on paper plates and juice in plastic cups. 'For Christssake Kev watch me head with that frigging pole,' says a bearded man in jeans. Illusions shattered? No, it's someone from the television crew here to film the evening for a future David Frost special. There are cables everywhere and a huge screen to the right of the altar. Before Nicky Gumbel starts the official lecture, he apologises for the intrusion but there's no point in denying that publicity is important. This is only a rehearsal. The real filming is next week. People who don't want to be filmed should arrive early and stand in the left-hand supper queue. The cameramen have had strict instructions. Banalities over we are invited to stand and sing along to a guitar played by a young man with a voice like Mark Knopfler.

As a speaker, Gumbel sounds disconcertingly like Tony Blair - same boyish sincerity, same halting but heartfelt delivery. He prays, he tells us because it is the way, the only way to have a relationship with God. And because it's effective. He keeps a prayer diary and ticks those prayers that have been answered. There are a lot of ticks. Sometimes his prayers are not answered. There was the time he was playing tennis with a friend, who suddenly collapsed on court with a heart attack. All night Gumbel prayed for his friend's recovery. Why God, why, he asked miserably, furiously in the morning, did you let a happily married man with a loving wife and six children die? He realised he had a choice. He could either stop believing in God or accept the mystery of the Almighty and carry on praying. He stayed with the mystery.

By the way, had we heard the story about the atheist who fell of a cliff, clutched at a tuft of grass and cried: 'Oh God, if you really are up there help me'? 'Let go of the tuft of grass,' boomed a voice from above. The atheist hesitated for a moment then said: 'Is there anyone else up there?'

Gumbel's combination of humour, anecdote, metaphysics, quotations from the bible and complex theology are both persuasive and compelling. On the form that they are invited to complete when they finish the Alpha course, students are asked 'would you have described yourself as a Christian before you took the Alpha course?' Most of them write 'sort of' or 'more or less' or 'Christian-ish'. And would they describe themselves as Christians now? Most of them write yes.

Was there a specific moment during Charlotte's journey to Christianity when she knew that she had seen the light? Oh yes, said the girl who shunned religious groups at university because she wanted to do normal things like go clubbing and get pissed. It was at a Pontin's holiday camp in Chichester, West Sussex's answer to Damascus, that the group had taken over for their residential weekend. 'They were talking about the Holy Ghost and I suddenly felt all shivery and then gradually felt myself becoming filled with love and peace.' She said it matter of factly as if she were describing flu symptoms.

It's first their normality then their niceness that distinguishes young New Age Christians from the weirdo born-again Cliff Richard brigade. Their agnostic contemporaries don't consider them odd. 'If the rest of us are bitching about someone, the Christians will probably stand up for them, they are really nice that way,' said Gary Matthewman, second-year piano student at the Royal College of Music, which has its fair share of Alpha converts. 'They may not get as drunk as we do and they go to bed earlier but there's nothing weird about them. They are ordinary violinists and saxophonists and pianists who happen to believe in God.'

What was it that finally decided Charlotte to take the Alpha course? 'I suppose I was fed up with all the crap, the posing, the image obsession. That probably sounds strange coming from someone whose job is all about image but that's strictly work. This is different. This is my whole life. It's real, it's true, it's for ever. Just say I became blind and I couldn't be a photographer any more. What would happen to Charlotte? What would I be? What would I have? Now I know.'

fields.headline: Six of the best...
fields.standfirst: ...places to buy strawberries, or pick your own.
fields.trailText: ...places to buy strawberries, or pick your own.
fields.body:
The pleasure a strawberry gives depends partly on its freshness, so one of the best options is to pick your own. To find the nearest outlet, write to the Farm Retail Association (PO Box 575, Southampton SO15 7ZB) and enclose a first-class stamp.

Another contributor to flavour is the variety. Elsanta is the most widely grown, not for taste but because it has a long shelf-life and can be handled and stored easily, so is most likely the one you will find in your local supermarket. Sadly, the combination of Elsanta and early picking means that most of these make extremely disappointing eating. The Gray family at Gray of Wokingham (Grays Farm, Heathlands Road, Wokingham, Berkshire; 01189 785 386) grows eight or nine varieties (including Elan), all chosen for flavour; because of their different ripening times, these guarantee a regular supply and a long season. The Grays operate PYO (expect to pay around £2.40 per kg) and also sell some in the farm shop. Donald Gray advises eating them within a day, two at most, and if you must freeze them, do so in jelly, so that when they're defrosted they will retain their shape and not turn to mush.

Charles George at The Fruit Garden (Groesfaen Road, Peterston-super-Ely, near Cardiff; 01446 760 358) mollycoddles his 'contented plants', growing them on raised beds in poly tunnels with a computer-controlled watering system. The fruit is at eye level ('head level for the average Welshman'), and quite apart from being beyond the reach of children (a major source of wastage in the PYO industry), they are much easier to harvest. George operates a shop and PYO. Scathing about some varieties (late-cropping Everest tastes 'like an old turnip'), he is particularly proud of French Mara des Bois, and Belgian Elan, which are the crème de la crème. Expect to pay around £2.50 per half kg.

The season at Perry Court Farm (Bilting, Ashford, Kent; 01233 812 408) starts under polythene, moves to fields, and ends when the plants are covered in straw (hence the name strawberries), taking in 10 varieties along the way. Heidi Fermor sells at the farm gate, operates PTO, and supplies Asda and Tesco, but is such a fan of farmers' markets that she goes to 30 or more, including London Farmers' Markets (020 7704 9659). This gives her the chance to offer tastings and explain how varieties differ. Pay £2.20 per kg at the farm, £2.50 in London.

Determined to put as much distance between himself and Elsanta as possible, Stephen Holmes at Wellbrook Farm in Faversham, Kent (01227 751 022; wellbrook@talk21.com) specialises in the niche market of 'heritage fruit', growing wild, woodland and traditional old English varieties. Cambridge Vigour has a 'knockout flavour', while Mara des Bois is a favourite because it has the taste of wild strawberry but is much larger. Expect to pay around the £4 mark for a 100g punnet. Best of all, visit Stephen Holmes and lots of other specialist producers at Henrietta Green's Food Lovers' Fair at Highclere Castle in Berkshire from 30 June to 2 July (ticket hotline 01483 577 123), where all stallholders are vetted to a high standard. There is another fair at Loseley Park from 14 to 16 July.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide

fields.headline: Spanish flyer
fields.standfirst: The Seat 20V T Sport has been designed to appeal to wide boys and wise women. By Miranda Sawyer
fields.trailText: The Seat 20V T Sport has been designed to appeal to wide boys and wise women. By Miranda Sawyer
fields.body:
I have no doubt that Observer readers are the type who listened in Spanish classes. So you all know how to pronounce this little baby. Say-at Lay-on. Not Seet Ly-own, as a mate of mine had it when it first arrived, which sounds like a sofa covered in animal hide. Still, such a flashy piece of furniture would, no doubt, meet the approval of a Seat Leon owner. Despite multiple protestations in the PR literature ('These are not cars aimed at the boy racer'), the Leon - especially the top-of- the-range Sport and Cupra - has a whiff of the wide boy about it.

Which is more than fine by me. Wide boys and women have been the driving force (sorry) behind most of the last decade's motoring innovations. When women started getting behind their own wheel (as opposed to behind the wheel of their husband's motor), a whole new category of car came on the scene: the rinky-dink safe-as-you-like supermini - the Twingo, Ka, Micra, Yaris, Matiz, Lupo. And when more and more wide boys were pulling doughnuts in lowered Ford Escorts and tweaking the engines of their Novas and Renault 5s, the manufacturers eventually had to respond. Now, most mid-range cars have a sport version that's aimed more at the Max Power reader than it is at the peruser of Middle-Management Weekly .

The Seat Leon combines the best of the women's cars (safety, VFM, styling) with the wide boys' (pizzazz, driving ability, styling). Its generously equipped entry version - anti-lock brakes, four air bags - costs just £10,995. The 20V T Sport is under £16,000, and that has air-con and six gears. Once you get to the SE, the Sport and the Cupra models, lowered suspension is standard. And, aside from satisfying the ladies and the lads, all this is offered in a vehicle that appeals to the Beemer or VW owner. Meaning, it has a more grown-up status.

All in all, it's a pretty package. Especially when, as my 20V T Sport did, it comes in bright yellow. The door handles matched (all versions are five-door) and blended into the banana-mobile. Only the boot handle didn't, and that was masked by a great big Seat S - ace. The wheels were vast and spoked - double ace. There was a double-piped chrome exhaust - ace squared. Other than these aspects, though, I thought the Leon was a little discreet with its exterior. But then ever since driving the Nissan Skyline, my taste has warped. I look at a perfectly styled Mercedes and think: boring. BMWs aren't look-at-me enough. A Lotus makes me stifle a yawn. The Leon looks OK, though, I suppose. Yellow's second only to black for gangsta cool.

I was only allowed the Leon for the weekend, which is never long enough to test a car. I never made use of the sixth gear: just trundled about in the lower three. I think I once made fourth, in a rash moment on London's Holloway Road, but immediately dropped back down to second because of the speed cameras.

I liked the interior. I like cars to be flash-as-you-like on the outside and easy-to-read on the inside. The radio was a bit fiddly - as always - though the knobs on the steering wheel helped (they override those on the central console, so you can really wind up your passenger). The driver could also flick a switch to control all electric windows. Plus, there were individual heating controls, too. All in all, plenty of arguments pending. What else? Big S in the middle of the steering wheel. Dashboard instruments lit up red, seats with red'n'black Escher cube patterns. Gear stick with six gears glinting at you. Boo!

Still, London does provide a test of two aspects. Parking ability. And pose factor. Parking was remarkably easy. I usually find anything bigger than a Golf irritatingly difficult to park, as today's cars are all rump and no back window. But the Leon wasn't half bad. I didn't have to hang out of my window or anything. Pose factor? Slightly disappointing. The yellow got it noticed, but a spot more wide boy and a tad less sense wouldn't have gone amiss.

In the end, what the Leon reminded me of was a BMW 3 series - with more poke. Spinning off from the traffic lights was a heavenly rocket trip. I'd have loved to take it further, open her out (as proper car journalists say), but it wasn't to be. The impression I gained from a few short hours was that whoever designed the Leon had really thought hard about it. The attention to detail, the responsiveness of the drive, the feeling of safety, the space, the comfort. It's a smart package: whether you're a harassed mother, a teenage brother or an AN Other. And with a three-year mechanical warranty, 12-year anti-perforation warranty, and three-year paintwork warranty, you're unlikely to go wrong with this one. Even the sell-on is impressive - only the VW Golf keeps its value better. So what are you waiting for? And once you've bought one, tell me how the sixth gear feels.

In the end, what the Leon reminded me of was a BMW 3 series - with more poke. Spinning off from the traffic lights was a heavenly rocket trip. I'd have loved to take it further, open her out (as proper car journalists say), but it wasn't to be. The impression I gained from a few short hours was that whoever designed the Leon had really thought hard about it. The attention to detail, the responsiveness of the drive, the feeling of safety, the space, the comfort. It's a smart package: whether you're a harassed mother, a teenage brother or an AN Other. And with a three-year mechanical warranty, 12-year anti-perforation warranty, and three-year paintwork warranty, you're unlikely to go wrong with this one. Even the sell-on is impressive - only the VW Golf keeps its value better. So what are you waiting for? And once you've bought one, tell me how the sixth gear feels.

fields.headline: Alternatives
fields.standfirst: Homeopathy without history, support for victims, and why the brain's a work of two halves. By Richard Lawrence
fields.trailText: Homeopathy without history, support for victims, and why the brain's a work of two halves. By Richard Lawrence
fields.body:
Your Body

The first ever Homeopathy Awareness Week starts next Tuesday. Practitioners and supporters throughout the country will take part in a campaign to raise public awareness of this increasingly popular therapy which a growing number of GPs are incorporating into their surgeries. In among the many aspects of homeopathy being promoted, is a comparatively new method of diagnosis known as the Sehgal method. Championed in this country by two homeopathic practitioners, Andree Sanford and Lisa Barrett, it was originally introduced in India some 20 years ago by Dr ML Sehgal. While classical homeopathy takes a holistic approach with diagnosis taking into account the whole history of a patient, often going back to their childhood, the Sehgal method departs from this by focusing exclusively on the patient's physical, mental and emotional reactions to the illness itself. These reactions then determine the type of homeopathic remedy to be prescribed. 'I have used both classical diagnosis and the Sehgal method, and have found the latter to be far more accurate,' Sanford says.

Your Mind

Last week's announcement by the Home Office that victims of crime and their families will be able to give a personal statement on how a crime has affected them will, says Jack Straw, 'make victims feel that they are at the heart of the Criminal Justice System'. These statements will now be taken into account by the police, CPS, judges and magistrates, when it comes to prosecuting and sentencing. Simultaneously, having their feelings acknowledged in this way, will also help victims of crime to recover more quickly psychologically.

Another approach to treating trauma has been recently developed by Californian therapist Dr Francine Shapiro and is called Eye Movement De-sensitisation and Reprocessing (EMDR). Terry O'Neill, one of the counsellors in the occupational health unit of the South Yorkshire police, says, 'It is a much more powerful technique than conventional therapies, as it quickly helps clients to bring feelings and memories to the surface'. The patient first focuses on the trauma and then silently follows the fingers of the therapist with the eyes. This apparently causes the two hemispheres of the brain - the left governing rational thought and the right governing creativity - to link up, which is crucial for those recovering from post-traumatic stress and enabling the patient able to move on.

Your Questions

My son is completing a reflexology and massage course in Malaysia. To practice in Britain, does he have to register with any institute?
Mrs Sharmis, Surrey

Your son is not legally obliged to register with any institute, although he might consider the British Register of Complementary Practitioners (BRCP), which has both a massage and reflexology division. Massage and reflexology are not yet incorporated into the National Health Service, unless a GP chooses to use part of their fund-holding budget within their own practice. Your son will probably need advice on how to practise privately. To contact the BRCP, call 020 7237 5165; brcp@icmedicine.co.uk

Enquiries to Richard Lawrence c/o Life Magazine , The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email: alternatives@richardlawrence.co.uk

fields.headline: Down to the liver
fields.standfirst: The last thing a stressed liver needs is too much alcohol or rich, fatty foods - so help it out and keep things simple
fields.trailText: The last thing a stressed liver needs is too much alcohol or rich, fatty foods - so help it out and keep things simple
fields.body:
Underneath our ribs lies the largest and one of the most vital of our organs: the liver. The liver performs many important functions relating to the blood, manufacturing substances that enable the blood to clot effectively, as well as others that regulate the digestion, absorption and storage of nutrients, such as vitamins A, B, K and folate. It also converts vitamin D into its most useful form for our bodies, which has implications for calcium's bone-maintaining functions.

People often first become aware of their livers when they receive abnormal results from a routine blood test and are informed that they have raised levels of liver enzymes. The presence of abnormally high levels of such enzymes as gamma glutamyl transpeptidase (gamma GT) or alkaline phosphatase in the blood suggests that the liver is working at a reduced capacity and is struggling to perform its essential duties. Because raised levels of liver enzymes can occur for many reasons, your doctor will need to investigate further to ascertain whether they have been caused by the hepatitis virus, the side effects of certain drugs - perhaps strong anti-inflammatories - or, in rare cases, a cancerous tumour. In the majority of cases, however, there is no underlying cause except for your liver's inability to cope with your eating and drinking habits. In such instances, regard high enzyme levels as a warning that you must start looking after your liver.

Because the liver is the organ that primarily filters, digests and metabolises food, what we eat and the liquids we drink have a huge impact on its health. Everything that you swallow is metabolised by the liver, so I don't recommend that you take any medication, whether it be a natural remedy or an over-the-counter or prescription drug, unless you have discussed it with your GP first. I once saw a patient who had been advised by a friend to soak his feet in potassium-permanganate solution to help his eczema (a treatment that might have been effective had it been supervised by a trained professional) and who ended up with severe liver problems.

The most common reason that the level of liver enzymes may shoot upwards is drinking too much alcohol, in which case your doctor will tell you that your gamma GT reading is higher than usual. Although some people are astounded by this diagnosis, especially if they don't drink much, it may be that their livers are extremely sensitive. Or it may be the result of a previous illness. If this is the case, your doctor won't worry about this unduly, unless the levels change significantly. You will probably be told to start looking after your liver and after a few months your enzyme levels should return to normal.

You may be advised either to avoid alcohol for a few months or to cut down your intake. Many people find that spirits, which have a high alcohol content, hit the liver harder than wine. It's therefore generally better to stick to wine and not to drink on an empty stomach, which unleashes a rush of concentrated alcohol into your system, making your liver work overtime. Drinking a small amount of wine with a meal is the best plan, because food keeps the alcohol in the stomach for longer, slows down its absorption rate and enables the liver to work at a comfortable pace. (Not all wines suit a stressed liver, however, and dessert wines can be particularly aggravating.) Although beer seems to be well tolerated by the liver, its main drawback is that we tend to drink it when we are not eating. Yet many beers provide an excellent accompaniment to food - light beers suit Japanese food very well, for example, while a Guinness complements a ploughman's lunch perfectly - just remember to have a few mouthfuls of food before sipping your pint. Caffeine also irritates the liver, so reduce your intake of caffeine-containing drinks to a maximum of two a day.

If you have raised liver enzyme levels, but no other medical problems, a daily combination of a well-balanced, healthy diet, comprising lots of fresh vegetables, fruit, lean proteins and fibre, with 2.5 litres of water (which helps the liver to rid itself of unwanted waste products or toxins) will enable your liver to return to normal as quickly as possible.

There is one nutritional substance to which you should pay particular attention, however: fat. Whether it is of vegetable or animal origin, fat is one of the hardest foods for the body to break down and metabolise, which makes it even more difficult for a stressed liver, triggering indigestion, nausea, bloating, wind and a general feeling of heaviness (hence the expression 'feeling liverish'). It's therefore best to keep your intake of fried foods, cream, butter-rich pastries and cheese to a minimum. The liver hates having to cope with concentrated fats, so either eat a little fat often or accompany a fatty food with a fibre-containing one - have a piece of cheese with a slice of wholegrain bread or some grapes, for instance. Keep your food simple and chargrill fish, roast lean meats, steam young vegetables and dress them with fresh herbs and a drizzle of olive oil instead of dowsing them with lashings of béchamel-type sauces. If your weight tends to be on the low side, and you are worried about cutting out such a rich source of calories from your diet, step up your intake of starchy foods (carbohydrates), such as pasta, rice, potatoes, bread and desserts made with sugar and fruit, such as sorbets, chocolate dishes, stewed rhubarb or poached peaches.

Regard receiving a diagnosis of raised levels of liver enzymes as an opportunity to re-evaluate your diet and to adopt eating habits that you'll enjoy for a long time to come. Even when your readings return to normal, your liver will thank you if you continue to give it a break and don't demand such a high, and frequently unachievable, performance from it.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books

fields.headline: Wake-up call
fields.standfirst: Fifteen minutes can make all the difference. Sophie Radice on the rejuvenative powers of a quick kip
fields.trailText: Fifteen minutes can make all the difference. Sophie Radice on the rejuvenative powers of a quick kip
fields.body:
When afternoon fatigue makes the computer screen go blurry and the mental picture of a big bed with a warm duvet seems the most seductive thing in the world, I, like most people, reach for the coffee or a bar of chocolate and wait for the caffeine to kick in or the blood-sugar level to rise.

My grandmother has long disapproved of my chemical fix for daytime drowsiness. She tells me to 'cut out the espressos and take a short kip'. And when she says short, she means 10 to 15 minutes at the most. More than that, and the daytime napper will be unable to easily snap back into useful wakefulness.

Gran was taught the 'controlled doze' by a doctor who also happened to be her second husband. He had picked it up from an enlightened fitness instructor who went round bomb shelters during the Blitz teaching stressed-out women to sleep at will. Gran always took a nap under the desk at her office in the lunch break to give her the energy she needed to raise nine children, and at 85 she is more alert than I am at 36.

Typically, I have only started to concede that my grandmother might have a point because a friend shoved a glossy, hardback tome by the world's leading sleep expert, Dr William Dement, into my hands; they were fed up of hearing me moan about how tired I was. In The Promise of Sleep (Macmillan, £16.99) Dr Dement, director of the sleep disorders clinic and research centre at Stanford University, painstakingly takes the layman on an easy-to-read journey through his many years of scientific sleep research. He states that 'nature definitely intended that adults should nap in the afternoons because just as we have a significant drop in body-core temperature and alertness at night, we also have a similar but smaller drop in the middle of the day'. Which is why most of us - especially those who have a significant sleep 'debt' because they have difficulty sleeping at night, or go out partying too much, work long hours or have small children - feel particularly tired between the hours of 2pm and 4pm.

The nap, Dement says, should be short because the brain and body must stay within the realms of the first two stages of sleep and not enter into deep sleep. In these early stages, your breathing rate begins to slow, as do your brain waves, your eye movements and your heartbeat. You may have fleeting visual imagery, or 'hypnagognic hallucinations'. Your muscles will briefly relax and your brain-stem stimulation via muscle nerves will be reduced. You will become disengaged and blind and deaf to most outside stimulation for a short while, but you should either train yourself to wake up or use an alarm at this point. If you sleep for more than 30 minutes, you will enter a deep sleep and your muscles relax completely. Blood pressure drops, pulse and respiration are slowed and the blood supply to the brain is minimal. If you are then awakened from stage three and four sleep, you will feel distinctly groggy.

Churchill advocated the need for a quick nap long before the Stanford research, and is famous for planning his cabinet war meetings around his afternoon shuteye. Mike Jackson, commander of the Nato peace-keeping force in Kosovo, kept a camp bed by his desk so he could take a nap whenever he felt his mental agility was being impaired by sleepiness. Other famous nappers include Napoleon, Albert Einstein and Thomas Edison.

More average workplaces tend not to be conducive to napping, though, despite a great deal of effort in the mid-90s by Professor James B Maas (author of Miracle Sleep Cure - The Key to a Long Life of Peak Performance ; Thorsons, £7.99) to promote 'the power nap'. While a few companies installed quiet areas and Richard Reeves, director of futures at the Industrial Society, predicted that in the 'near future most companies will install bunk beds for power naps', the idea never really caught on because workers were unwilling to be seen as dozy wimps with a kindergarten routine.

Last month, the American National Sleep association released the results of an extensive sleep survey which showed that although one-third of workers felt they needed a nap during the day, less then 10 per cent of those had ever slept at work. All of them gave their bosses' negative reactions as their main reason for not napping.

There is certainly a lot of guilt associated with any kind of afternoon sleep in this country. While the sexy siesta is unashamedly taken to escape the midday sun, the nap is associated with infants and senior citizens in 'lazy-boy' chairs. We are 'caught napping' and try to excuse ourselves when we are woken with a start by saying that we were just taking '40 winks'. The World Nap Organization, which aims to promote 'guilt-free' naps, says that even at the weekend, spouses were the main 'guilters', with 67 per cent of the 600 people it surveyed saying that their partners made them feel lazy when they took a mid-afternoon sleep. This, of course, is due to every couple's lifelong tiredness competition, with the weekend nap used either as a bargaining tool ('All right, you sleep now if I can lie in tomorrow') or as a sign of rebellion or retreat against the idea of a jolly family weekend.

The sleepy spouse might like to point out to the 'guilter' that the nap now has the backing of the Department of Transport. As most car accidents happen either in the middle of the night or in the afternoon when we fall into our sleepiest 'trough', the Highway Code recommends that a nap is the best response to feeling tired at the wheel. As Professor Jim Horne, director of sleep research at Loughborough University, says: 'The Highway Code advises drivers who feel drowsy to pull in at the nearest service station and take a brief nap. This shows that governmental Health and Safety bodies recognise that a light sleep of 15 minutes will make the driver feel refreshed and able to safely continue. It can do wonders for the mental performance - and the same thing can be applied to situations other then driving.'

The House of Commons is probably the only place packed full of unabashed guilt-free catnappers because of late-night sit-ins, long lunches and, perhaps, the Churchillian catnap as precedent. Although some MPs snooze discreetly in their offices, many simply put their feet up in the main chamber and openly snore their way through a minor speech.

In your own office, try and find a nearby chair, sofa or soft floor. Alternatively, bring in a comfortable pillow and put your head on your desk, with your arms folded above your head. Turn off the ringer on your phone, let everyone know that you are trying this experiment to keep you alert, and see if you can train yourself to doze for a short space of time. You could do what a friend who works in a particularly dynamic PR company does each lunchtime, which is go to the quietest place in her local library and have a quick zizz. 'No one cares because everyone is so used to people dropping off there,' she says. Another friend working in the film industry always takes his deckchair on set and places it as far away from everyone else as he can.

Try and talk to your boss about the reduction in errors and accidents and the increased productivity and improved atmosphere that a nap-friendly atmosphere would encourage. Invite a sleep expert to give a seminar to your company. If all else fails, quote Churchill: 'Don't think that you will be doing less work because you sleep during the day. That's a foolish notion held by people who have no imagination.' *

The art of napping

 The nap should be about 10 to 30 minutes long. Any longer, and your body will fall into delta, or deep, sleep. The body only needs a short sleep because the nervous system is very resilient and easily rejuvenated . If the nap is too long, slow- wave sleep will occur and all of the body's systems will slow down.

Use an alarm if you do not trust yourself to wake up within this time and if you are severely sleep deprived and feel you must nap for longer, extend your sleep to 90 minutes, but don't expect to be fully alert until at least an hour after a long nap.

 If you want to start napping, then reduce your caffeine intake. Caffeine is only a brief fix for tiredness, whereas a nap is what your body needs.

 A nap is not a good idea if you have severe difficulty falling asleep at night. If you are taking a regular daytime nap for longer than 30 minutes, you may find that this is what is stopping you from having good, continuous night-time sleep.

 If you are going to take a controlled nap in the day, try to make a habit of it. A sudden irregular nap might disrupt your internal body clock and nocturnal sleeping pattern.

 Taking naps only at weekends will not do a lot for your general alertness. Brief naps taken daily are far healthier than sleeping in or taking very long naps at the weekend. Weekend napping is like only dieting and exercising at weekends - it won't work as a way of reaching your 'peak performance'.

 Late-afternoon napping is not recommended by any of the sleep experts. It can delay your falling-asleep time in the evening and begins to shift your biological clock, making getting up in the morning a struggle.

 You might decide that a refreshing nap is a good idea but find that you can't seem to fall asleep. It may be that you are getting enough sleep anyway, and just relaxing with your eyes closed will be beneficial in restoring your energy.

 If you have excessive daytime sleepiness, recurring episodes of naps or lapses into sleep, then you may have a more serious problem than sleep deprivation. Narcolepsy is a medical condition in which the sufferer will sleep for15 to 20 minutes and wake up feeling refreshed, only to feel chronically tired again within the next two to three hours. Sudden sleep attacks can occur in situations when sleeping is quite inappropriate, such as while eating, talking, laughing or driving. It is thought that one in every 2,000 people suffers from narcolepsy, although 80 per cent go undiagnosed. With controlled sleep and proper medication, narcolepsy can be managed.

Websites

www.sleepnet.com/
Everything you want to know about sleep but are too tired to ask. Provides some good statistics as well as links to lots of other sleep-related sites

www.sleepfoundation.org/
Get the answers to your sleep and nap questions. A direct link to the best-known American non-profit foundation for sleep

www.narcolepsy.org.uk/
Very informative British site dealing with the diagnosis and treatment of narcolepsy

As most car accidents happen either in the middle of the night or in the afternoon when we fall into our sleepiest 'trough', the Highway Code recommends that a nap is the best response to feeling tired at the wheel. As Professor Jim Horne, director of sleep research at Loughborough University, says: 'The Highway Code advises drivers who feel drowsy to pull in at the nearest service station and take a brief nap. This shows that governmental Health and Safety bodies recognise that a light sleep of 15 minutes will make the driver feel refreshed and able to safely continue. It can do wonders for the mental performance - and the same thing can be applied to situations other then driving.' The House of Commons is probably the only place packed full of unabashed guilt-free catnappers because of late-night sit-ins, long lunches and, perhaps, the Churchillian catnap as precedent. Although some MPs snooze discreetly in their offices, many simply put their feet up in the main chamber and openly snore their way through a minor speech. In your own office, try and find a nearby chair, sofa or soft floor. Alternatively, bring in a comfortable pillow and put your head on your desk, with your arms folded above your head. Turn off the ringer on your phone, let everyone know that you are trying this experiment to keep you alert, and see if you can train yourself to doze for a short space of time. You could do what a friend who works in a particularly dynamic PR company does each lunchtime, which is go to the quietest place in her local library and have a quick zizz. 'No one cares because everyone is so used to people dropping off there,' she says. Another friend working in the film industry always takes his deckchair on set and places it as far away from everyone else as he can. Try and talk to your boss about the reduction in errors and accidents and the increased productivity and improved atmosphere that a nap-friendly atmosphere would encourage. Invite a sleep expert to give a seminar to your company. If all else fails, quote Churchill: 'Don't think that you will be doing less work because you sleep during the day. That's a foolish notion held by people who have no imagination.' * The art of napping  The nap should be about 10 to 30 minutes long. Any longer, and your body will fall into delta, or deep, sleep. The body only needs a short sleep because the nervous system is very resilient and easily rejuvenated . If the nap is too long, slow- wave sleep will occur and all of the body's systems will slow down. Use an alarm if you do not trust yourself to wake up within this time and if you are severely sleep deprived and feel you must nap for longer, extend your sleep to 90 minutes, but don't expect to be fully alert until at least an hour after a long nap.  If you want to start napping, then reduce your caffeine intake. Caffeine is only a brief fix for tiredness, whereas a nap is what your body needs.  A nap is not a good idea if you have severe difficulty falling asleep at night. If you are taking a regular daytime nap for longer than 30 minutes, you may find that this is what is stopping you from having good, continuous night-time sleep.  If you are going to take a controlled nap in the day, try to make a habit of it. A sudden irregular nap might disrupt your internal body clock and nocturnal sleeping pattern.  Taking naps only at weekends will not do a lot for your general alertness. Brief naps taken daily are far healthier than sleeping in or taking very long naps at the weekend. Weekend napping is like only dieting and exercising at weekends - it won't work as a way of reaching your 'peak performance'.  Late-afternoon napping is not recommended by any of the sleep experts. It can delay your falling-asleep time in the evening and begins to shift your biological clock, making getting up in the morning a struggle.  You might decide that a refreshing nap is a good idea but find that you can't seem to fall asleep. It may be that you are getting enough sleep anyway, and just relaxing with your eyes closed will be beneficial in restoring your energy.  If you have excessive daytime sleepiness, recurring episodes of naps or lapses into sleep, then you may have a more serious problem than sleep deprivation. Narcolepsy is a medical condition in which the sufferer will sleep for15 to 20 minutes and wake up feeling refreshed, only to feel chronically tired again within the next two to three hours. Sudden sleep attacks can occur in situations when sleeping is quite inappropriate, such as while eating, talking, laughing or driving. It is thought that one in every 2,000 people suffers from narcolepsy, although 80 per cent go undiagnosed. With controlled sleep and proper medication, narcolepsy can be managed. Websites www.sleepnet.com/ Everything you want to know about sleep but are too tired to ask. Provides some good statistics as well as links to lots of other sleep-related sites www.sleepfoundation.org/ Get the answers to your sleep and nap questions. A direct link to the best-known American non-profit foundation for sleep www.narcolepsy.org.uk/ Very informative British site dealing with the diagnosis and treatment of narcolepsy

webTitle: Will the real Andrew Smith step forward

fields.headline: Will the real Andrew Smith step forward
fields.standfirst: Five men called Andrew Smith - just a select few of the 7,645 in this country. But which is the actor, the pop star, the illustrator, the TV producer? Here, Andrew Smith, the writer, investigates what it is like to live with England's eighth most common name
fields.trailText: Five men called Andrew Smith - just a select few of the 7,645 in this country. But which is the actor, the pop star, the illustrator, the TV producer? Here, Andrew Smith, the writer, investigates what it is like to live with England's eighth most common name
fields.body:
To most of you, it was just a news story, but to me it was something more. In 1991, a 19-year-old former public schoolboy named Andrew Smith arrived in New York to take up a place at art school. He found that student digs weren't to his liking, so, being an ambitious sort, checked into the glamorous Pierre Hotel, blowing his $4,500 savings on a binge that lasted a week. A fortnight later, he returned and - check this for style - stayed for five whole months, amassing a bill of $45,000. With no hope of paying, he signed an American Express voucher belonging to another Andrew Smith and scarpered, but was caught by the FBI, charged with fraud, and sent home to south-east London to await trial.

This was strange, yet still short of bizarre. That came next. Smith did a runner to France, where he became a celebrity cat breeder and hit trouble only last year, when he called the Pierre with an offer to pay back the money he owed. Rather than accept, they alerted Interpol, and on 19 February of this year, Smith's home in Bourg-en-Bresse was raided by 10 gendarmes who had failed to wonder whether he would in fact be in. He wasn't, went into hiding, and was at large until a fortnight ago, when he was finally apprehended in Lyon. He is currently on hunger strike in a French prison.

Now, like you, I read all this assuming it had been scripted by John Cleese or Michael Frayne. Until I got to the end. This was where Smith claimed that he never meant to sign someone else's credit-card slip, but that the hotel staff had mistaken him for another Andrew Smith, who had stayed there earlier. To the lay person, this defence may sound lame, implausible, preposterous even, but I know where he's coming from and I've got at least 7,645 countrymen who are with me on this. If we banded together and marched over to France, we could probably spring him ourselves. Allow me to explain.

There's this joke that I've always loved. It's old and may strike some readers as mildly profane, though I can't help but see it as poetic and strangely moving. It goes something like this.

'A young Native American brave goes to see his chief one day. "Chief," he asks, earnestly, "how do you choose what names to give us?" The chief looks down at the boy, then up into the far distance as he slips into a reverie. "Why, I look to the earth and the sky for guidance," he says. "If I see the moon rising among the stars, I name the brave Rising Moon. If I spy the buffalo sweeping majestically across the plain, I name him Running Buffalo. If the eagle swoops above, he will be Flying Eagle. Anyway, why do you ask, Two Dogs Humping?"'

Like any decent person, I can empathise with poor Two Dogs, forever having to spell his name three times over to querulous bank tellers and at airport check-ins. At the same time, part of my amusement at this joke undoubtedly stems from a conviction that Two Dogs's plight could have been very much worse. He could, for instance, have been named Two Dogs Smith.

According to the Office for National Statistics, eight out of the top 10 most common names in England (no figures exist for the UK as a whole) end in Smith. My own weighs in at number eight, well down on the chart-topping David (my brother and 13,621 others) and James (my father), but enough to spread confusion wherever I go and be a constant source of chagrin.

The truth is that Andrew on its own would have been bad enough. In itself, it's a good name, of Greek origin, meaning 'manly, with strength', but that's not the whole story. No one knows why some names explode in popularity at given times - although Professor David Hargreaves of Surrey University has a theory of 'cyclical vogues' (Sharon is due round again soon, you might like to note) - but from the mid-50s through to the 60s, mine did. There were always three or four others in my form at school and, like many Andrews of our generation, I have had to live with the disturbing thought that I might have been named after Prince Andrew, and, speaking personally, I would rather have been named after a mound of Tesco own-brand lard.

At the moment, we Andrew Smiths seem to be popping up all over the place. Apart from our representative in France, there is the prolific striker who plays for Kilmarnock in Scotland and Andrew Smith MP, who has managed the considerable feat of being Chief Secretary to the Treasury while remaining absolutely true to the anonymity implied by his name.

To be sure, having such a common handle has brought certain advantages. At school, it was usually possible to avoid unpleasant rituals like cross-country runs by feigning the assumption that all of the 'A Smiths' on the starter's sheet referred to someone else. And I get other people's email every day, including one long and fruity exchange between a namesake and the woman with whom he is having a torrid affair, which arrived faithfully every day for a time, like my own personal soap opera.

Mostly, though, there has been the irritation of being confused for others and feeling your own identity in the world compromised, diluted if you like, through being shared with so many others. Picture my horror when, stumbling across a numerology website in the course of researching this article, I tapped in the names of several friends and family members, to be given back values of 54, 68, 74, then keyed in my own and received a huge, mocking '0' in return. This really happened.

And still I went into a profession where your name is really all you have. I've always been suspicious of this. Was I trying to claim it, finally, for my own? If so, was I alone in feeling that impulse? All of which begged a greater question. When we have children, we agonise over what to call them, instinctively realising that our decision will impact on their subsequent lives. Equally, performers understand that different names carry different expectations, independently of the person they're attached to, which is why they often change them. To what extent, then, do they shape us as we travel through life, and how?

A Puritan preacher supposedly once told his congregation that 'a good name is a thread tyed about the finger, to make us mindful of the errand we came into the world to do for our master.' According to Elsdon Smith and his Treasury of Name Lore , a good name would have been along the lines of Flie-fornication, or Steadfast-on-high, or Obedience (these are the people who founded the USA, lest we forget), but while we might quibble his reading of the details, the preacher's point stands. Name is identity, a place in the world.

It turns out that surnames have only been used in the way that we use them since the end of the 16th century. They were initially intended only to distinguish between people of the same given name and could be based on a father's first name or occupation (David's son, O'Kelly, Plumber, Smith), a place of residence (York, Hastings), or an epithet based on some notable personal trait (Swift, Little, Arm-strong). These only turned into hereditary surnames in the early Middle Ages, beginning, scholarship suggests, with aristocrats and in the cities. Women forfeited their surnames on marriage, just as slaves in the southern states of America were initially denied them. As Amy and Leon Kass of the University of Chicago note: 'The slaveholders understood perfectly that this made the childish station permanent, with neither a public life, nor a properly private life possible in relation to the wider world.'

So, names also represent power. Anthropologists tell us that in many pre-industrial societies, naming ceremonies mark the bestowing of a soul upon the child, while in Christian doctrine, they signify a claiming of the soul. In either case, notes Deluzain, the effect is the same: 'The person who receives a name thereby receives an identity and place in society.' The registering and granting of certificates of birth thus represent a contract between the individual and society. If either side is deemed to have failed its part of the bargain, dissatisfaction is often expressed through the changing or withholding of names, as when Cassius Clay rejected his 'slave name' in favour of Muhammad Ali, or when prisoners are forced to exchange theirs for numbers.

Similarly, the oldest debating trick in the book is to mispronounce an opponent's name. Freud purported to notice that aristocrats mispronounced their doctors' names more than others and thought that this was an unconscious means of recovering some of the power that any patient surrenders on walking through a surgery door. In his book Real Men , author Frank Rose describes the process by which recruits are ejected from the ranks, which involves being marched to the gates, accompanied by slow drum rolls and imprecations never to mention the disgraced soldier's name again.

'From a strictly objective point of view, blotting out a person's name in a club registry or forbidding cadets to mention a name in the future does absolutely nothing to change either the person or what he or she did. However, the link between name and identity is so strong and the importance of the symbolic name bargain so great that we genuinely feel that actions of this type somehow have the desired effect of making the person a nonentity.'

Where does this leave us Andrew Smiths? Halfway between White City and Television Centre, as it happens. Meeting up with a sample was a comic exercise in itself. At the BBC, I trailed from one building to another as receptionists insisted that they had dozens of Andy Smiths and the one I was looking for, like corkscrews and torches whenever you need them, was always somewhere else. The matre d' at the restaurant where I met Andy the illustrator asked for my name and that of the person I was meeting three times before finally surrendering to the fact that they were the same, even though we manifestly weren't. By the time I found him sitting at the bar, he had convinced himself that the whole thing was a cruel hoax perpetrated by his agent.

Everyone mentioned the same things: the nudges and winks at seaside hotels and B&Bs when you book a room for yourself and your girlfriend and give your name as Smith; receiving the wrong post ('I feel like I know the other Andy Smiths at the BBC, because I'm always opening their letters by mistake'); phone conversations which stutter to a halt in the realisation that the other party thinks you're someone else they know of the same name; irritation at credit-card ads which use 'A Smith' as a cipher for 'any old sod' or 'anonymous'. Everyone had had the feeling that they've had to work harder to be noticed at various points in their lives, even if, in retrospect, they were misguided. We all got on well and mixed easily. The photo shoot was simply surreal.

Of course, we have it very much easier than some. As a kid in California, I went to school with Larry Lefbom, Roslyn Belch, Janet Crapper and Lancelot Bent. Larry's grandfather had been a French immigrant named Le Bon, who thought that he'd be doing his heirs a favour by Americanising the family title. Peeking out from behind his fog of nicknames, Larry didn't agree.

Most of the research carried out on the effects of an odd or unusual name is American, highly anecdotal and frequently contradictory. There are many case studies based on people with names like Stankey, who get called 'Stinky' at school and come to take the nickname literally, developing obsessions with odours and their own hygiene. When adults join in the ostracism, it starts to have severe consequences for the child involved.

More generally, researchers at Tulane University in the US once asked a group of teachers to rate names in terms of desirability and undesirability, then went into schools and claimed to find that children in the first category had 'a considerably higher level of adjustment'. Four separate studies conducted over a 20-year period also want to show that tendencies to psychosis or neuroses are higher among people with unusual or uncommon first names and that this is most marked among men, in whom quirky names are less well tolerated in society - which is why 'fad names' are far more common for girls than boys, for whom the list of most common Christian names remains relatively constant.

Make of this what you will. Deluzain goes so far as to suggest that bizarre names which are clearly going to cause ridicule can be 'unconscious messages from the parents that the children are a burden, or peculiar and deserving of ridicule,' adding that, 'if this is the case, then the name is probably only the first of many such messages these children get from their parents during the time their self-concepts are developing'. Thus, as so often in these cases, we're into a chicken-and-egg situation with names and 'self-concept'.

Professor Albert Mehrabian of UCLA points out that most of us choose names for our children which have strong associations for us, ignoring the fact that these 'rarely reflect consensus associations within the general public'.

'There are a lot of studies showing that people with more common names tend to be more successful in school situations, professionally and so forth,' he adds. 'People with less common, unique or unusual names don't seem to be doing well. If a person's name is somewhat bizarre, they are less likely to be taken seriously.'

Staff at the Florida Office of Vital Statistics collect peculiar names. Over the years, they have picked up Vaseline Lewis, Emancipation Proclamation Cogshell, Winnie Mac Pough, Texas Moon, Toyota Corona Maria Collier and Ima Rose Bush. In 1995, the most common names for boys and girls in the state were Michael and Ashley, respectively, but their details supposedly sat in the records next to Cotton-eyed Joe Smith, Chickenbone Robinson, June Flood, More Payne, Dilemma Lafern and Cherry Pye. What, you wonder, was going on with their parents?

Against all this doom for the owners of odd monikers, Professor Edward Callary of the University of North Illinois and editor of Names , the journal of the American Names Society, believes that such apparent handicaps can act as a spur to achievement, forcing people to work harder to be taken seriously. As evidence, he points to McGeorge Bundy, a member of JFK's cabinet and Kingman Brooster, a former president of Yale. He will still cite studies aiming to show that names can carry strong hidden messages. Damon ('for some reason') implies untrustworthiness, Roxanne immorality (see the Police song about a prostitute of that name), Howard foursquare solidity, Herman tedium, Tiffany popularity, Cindy fun and Edna shyness.

In fact, we don't need research to tell us these things: as anyone called Nigel or Jeremy will realise, we understand them as we understand our own language, intuitively. Psychologists should generally be approached with the same scepticism as lawyers and estate agents, but what they tell us here makes sense. If people perceive a name in a certain way, they will tend to treat its owner in that way, and the owner, in turn and over time, will tend to behave as they are expected to behave. They're dangerous things, names.

The longer I looked at this, and the more I talked to my namesakes, the more clearly our attitudes to our names came to seem like an enduring symbol of the struggle with our parents. Men typically get their names and their first lessons in being men from their father, and their attitude to both seems linked. There is the despised middle name, which was the father's first name, or evidence of unfulfilled aspiration; the father who left or died, leaving only his name behind. Hardly surprising that our att- itudes to what we are called are complex and hard to define. After meeting the other Andrew Smiths a couple of times, however, a strange thing happened. I found myself feeling an affection for the name, which had previously eluded me. We wore it rather well, I thought. *
