'People with less common, unique or unusual names don't seem to be doing well. If a person's name is somewhat bizarre, they are less likely to be taken seriously.' Staff at the Florida Office of Vital Statistics collect peculiar names. Over the years, they have picked up Vaseline Lewis, Emancipation Proclamation Cogshell, Winnie Mac Pough, Texas Moon, Toyota Corona Maria Collier and Ima Rose Bush. In 1995, the most common names for boys and girls in the state were Michael and Ashley, respectively, but their details supposedly sat in the records next to Cotton-eyed Joe Smith, Chickenbone Robinson, June Flood, More Payne, Dilemma Lafern and Cherry Pye. What, you wonder, was going on with their parents? Against all this doom for the owners of odd monikers, Professor Edward Callary of the University of North Illinois and editor of Names , the journal of the American Names Society, believes that such apparent handicaps can act as a spur to achievement, forcing people to work harder to be taken seriously. As evidence, he points to McGeorge Bundy, a member of JFK's cabinet and Kingman Brooster, a former president of Yale. He will still cite studies aiming to show that names can carry strong hidden messages. Damon ('for some reason') implies untrustworthiness, Roxanne immorality (see the Police song about a prostitute of that name), Howard foursquare solidity, Herman tedium, Tiffany popularity, Cindy fun and Edna shyness. In fact, we don't need research to tell us these things: as anyone called Nigel or Jeremy will realise, we understand them as we understand our own language, intuitively. Psychologists should generally be approached with the same scepticism as lawyers and estate agents, but what they tell us here makes sense. If people perceive a name in a certain way, they will tend to treat its owner in that way, and the owner, in turn and over time, will tend to behave as they are expected to behave. They're dangerous things, names. The longer I looked at this, and the more I talked to my namesakes, the more clearly our attitudes to our names came to seem like an enduring symbol of the struggle with our parents. Men typically get their names and their first lessons in being men from their father, and their attitude to both seems linked. There is the despised middle name, which was the father's first name, or evidence of unfulfilled aspiration; the father who left or died, leaving only his name behind. Hardly surprising that our att- itudes to what we are called are complex and hard to define. After meeting the other Andrew Smiths a couple of times, however, a strange thing happened. I found myself feeling an affection for the name, which had previously eluded me. We wore it rather well, I thought. *

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ...New Art from Old
fields.trailText: ...New Art from Old
fields.body:
However radically contemporary art may differ from the art of the past, without old masters we obviously wouldn't have any new ones. Rubens drew from Leonardo, Manet studied Rembrandt and Cézanne spent hours sketching at the Louvre.

To highlight this tradition, the National Gallery has invited 24 international artists to pick a painting from the gallery's collection and use it as a starting point to create a work of their own. The results, by a line-up that includes David Hockney, Louise Bourgeois, Richard Hamilton, Frank Auerbach and Antoni Tapies, go on show this week in Encounters - New Art from Old.

'The fact that artists have always referred back is sometimes lost in all the excitement about the Sensation generation,' says exhibition curator Richard Morphet, 'but those artists are just as interested in the past as other generations have been.' Witness the Chapman brothers' particular take on Goya's Disasters of War.

For Encounters, Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen have taken Vermeer's A Young Woman Standing at a Virginal (far left) and created what happens next in the form of a peep-show box. Vermeer's woman stands in front of a portrait of Cupid. In Resonances after JV , Oldenburg and van Bruggen show the scene post-passion, after Cupid has shot his bow and hit the target. Antoni Tapies's piece was inspired by Rembrandt's A Woman Bathing in a Stream and Jeff Wall has responded to Stubbs's majestic equine portrait Whistlejacket with a photograph of a Blackpool donkey.

'These works show the unpredictable and surprising takes that some of our most distinguished living artists can have on the art of the past,' adds Morphet. 'Vermeer and Rembrandt would be amazed if they could see it.'

 Encounters - New Art from Old is on at The National Gallery, Trafalgar Square, London WC2 (020 7747 2885) from 14 June to 17 September. Tickets £3 to £7

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ... Best friend
fields.trailText: ... Best friend
fields.body:
The idea of a perfect best friend is not merely unimaginable but somewhat horrifying to me. I like everyone I know to have a full collection of flaws - it makes my own shortcomings seem so much less lamentable in comparison. Thus the first thing a perfect best friend would be is imperfect. But that wouldn't be enough. They would have to possess the right kind of imperfections.

Everyone has their own tolerances and intolerances as regards those you make friends with, and the nature of such limits will say a great deal about who you yourself are. It does not escape my own notice that the flaws I can tolerate in others are those that are so obviously present in myself; what this means I am not sure, but if you are a good friend to me, doubtless you will refrain from letting me know.

So much for the dark side. What makes for a perfect best friend other than imperfection? A perfect friend performs the following tasks seamlessly: telling me the truth, but only when I am in a state of ripeness to hear it. Comforting me, most particularly when I am unable to ask for it. Supporting me, but not out of pity. Loving me, but without mailing me an emotional invoice for it.

A perfect friend would never turn up more than five minutes late for dinner, would be ready to show their own vulnerabilities, pay for their round, and smoke Marlboro Reds (so I could bum one occasionally). They'd not be afraid to give compliments (something that men find perplexingly difficult), and would criticise only in order to heal rather than to harm.

Now that I think about it, if I had a perfect best friend, I'd marry them. Yet the friends I do have are wonderful in their imperfections, and they are the best friends I could ever hope for in a world in which imperfection is the rule and in which I myself am about as far as you can get from being an exception to that rule.

 White City Blue , Tim Lott's Whitbread Award- winning novel about male friendship, is published by Penguin, price £6.99

fields.headline: The new sexy
fields.standfirst: Why dirty books are back
fields.trailText: Why dirty books are back
fields.body:
Move over, Charlie Dimmock. Sex is the new gardening. Sex hogs whole channels on our televisions and sells glossy magazines and broadsheets. Mail-order catalogues exhort us to buy equipment and try special techniques, while doctors affirm the health-conferring properties of an activity which requires only minimal outlay and a little exercise. Friends and fellow enthusiasts make themselves available for help and advice. Goodbye sexual revolution; hello sex as a hobby, a wholesome leisure activity, a majority interest.

At your local video shop, Eyes Wide Shut will take you to orgies and Romance will expose that old staple of the censors' banned list, the male erection. A magazine advertisement for beds includes handcuffs dangling from the headboard; a television commercial depicts a woman with a dog-collar, lead and biddable man. Any 15-year-old boy with a bit of nous and a modem can see every possible assembly of body parts (indeed, any nine-year-old - my nephew, sent to investigate the Thrust land speed record on the net, had his education rapidly expanded when he typed it into a search engine). Any 15-year-old girl can probably get out of the house with her parents' blessing in a short skirt, red-sequined bodice and lizardskin stilettos.

Sex is out in the daylight, and the moral minority must be rejoicing as, along with Turkish delight and oysters, human appetite proves sated by too rich a diet of what it thought it wanted. No more smug smiles on the Tube to work at the thought of the forbidden delights of the night before. No lonely torment: 'Am I the only one to fantasise about that act, those circumstances?' No policing of our teenagers' sexuality, no empirically defiant incredulity at our parents' un-dead libidos. We are not alone with our desires and fantasies, but horribly in company.

What used to give sex its frisson was the sense of it being a rare commodity which might run out at any minute. There was also the anxiety that if you did tap into a reliable source, it would be of inferior quality, so there was constant speculation as to what everyone else might be doing - how, how often and who with. It was one of the reasons that marriage with 2.5 children held little sexual allure - the imagination was satisfied. For advertisers, families were for selling healthy, no-sex items like Bisto, or slab-shaped cars, the antithesis of aerodynamic. Single women, slightly foreign and long-legged, promoted sensuous things: chocolate, perfume, strong coffee.

In sex, inaccessibility was all. If Lady Chatterley's Lover had been required - rather than forbidden - reading in the 60s, an A-level set text, say, would it ever have become the sexual exemplar that it did? My mother instructed my teenage self never to read Peyton Place , which instantly put it at first place on my reading list. But the real fascination in reading it with my friends was in contemplating which scene had so upset my mother's sexual sensibilities.

And now dirty books are back. The upmarket Erotic Review has a circulation the envy of many other literary magazines; the Black Lace, Nexus, Idol and Sapphire imprints stand on groaning shelves previously occupied by the racier end of Mills & Boon. Freed from the constraints of the photo shoot, they explore sex in unfamiliar landscapes, with historical figures or with improbable strangers. Why? Because, bored to torpor by anatomically correct contemporary sex, we are forced to the periphery to reinsert that essential ingredient: imagination. Crucially, these are texts without photographs - and photographs have been the principal medium not so much to explore as to make an end of all our exploring into sex. Reading is harder work than peering, and we are designed to exert ourselves in pursuit of sex; putting the chase back into it all makes sex feel less like a team sport and more like an uncertain adventure.

Sex thrives on opacity. It is an impressionistic art; detail reduces rather than adds. It thrives, despite its ubiquity, in illusions of intimacy and uniqueness. It is not just a case of 'bend along the dotted line and insert tab A into slot B'. As we dissect it with cameras and analysis, so the invisible element which makes the heart lurch slips away. Pictorial pornography has tried to respond to this with reinvented furtiveness: videocams, woman-next-door subjects and a sudden interest in 'wives'. Married sex is apparently the new transgression. Meanwhile, Bridget Jones has demystified the single girl in the popular imagination. She is no longer the object of unattainable desire, but desperate to be attained.

Because while sexual variety and mechanics are anything but arcane, sexual curiosity is finding a different focus. New eroticism eddies around couples who stay together, puzzles over the intensity and secrecy of monogamy. Here is the new unknown, is the mystery and exclusion. What are they doing that the rest of us aren't?

And as for me? Well, for my old-fashioned erotic tastes, the sexiest book of all time is Jane Eyre: arousal through chemistry rather than biology, and not a body part in sight.

fields.headline: Building blocks (and blobs)
fields.standfirst: A younger generation of British architects - the new YBAs - will bring their vision of the future to the Venice Biennale, which opens next week. But why are they better known over there than over here?
fields.trailText: A younger generation of British architects - the new YBAs - will bring their vision of the future to the Venice Biennale, which opens next week. But why are they better known over there than over here?
fields.body:
Britain's architects have a spring in their step, thanks to all the city bonuses splurged on Clerkenwell's lofts and the restaurant epidemic in London - both of which came on top of the tidal wave of Lottery-funded projects. At last they have a chance to design real buildings, and buildings that get noticed, at that. Their new museums, apartments and bars, with their Eames chairs and blonde-wood floors, are published in all the glossies. Their portraits get in the papers. Tony Blair invites them for drinks in Downing Street. There is a palpable sense that architects feel better about themselves than they have done for 30 years, that they are not being ignored in the way they so comprehensively once were - and the Prince of Wales is nothing but a bad memory.

If there was anything sadder than the sight of a breast-beating British architect of the 70s blaming himself for all the failures of high-rise housing, it was the spectacle of a British architect of the 80s jogging forlornly in the dust, trying to leap on to the running board of Britain's fundamentally literary culture. 'Look,' they would tell anybody who would listen, 'everybody abroad loves what we do; they hire us to build the Pompidou and redesign the Reichstag, so we are important. We matter even if everybody back home ignores us. We aren't just builders or boring engineers.' Now, even the notoriously cautious founder of Future Systems, Jan Kaplicky, is beginning to look more cheerful: people are giving him work, though he was well past 50 before he got to build the press box at Lord's cricket ground, the first decent-sized project of his entire career to date.

But it's still easy to get the impression that there is nothing Britain's young architects - and this is a description that has very little to do with calendar age - would like to be so much as young British artists. It's so much more fun being Tracey Emin, Damien Hirst, the Chapman brothers or Sam Taylor-Wood, than it is being David Chipperfield, Nigel Coates or Will Alsop. Let alone being Alex de Rijke, Sally Mackereth or Louisa Hutton. For a start, things happen so much quicker. Hirst was cleaning up in the shark business straight after his degree show. Chipperfield is still fighting for work at home 20 years after he left the Architectural Association. Of course there is a generational mismatch: Chipperfield's art-world equivalent would belong to the Richard Long or Antony Gormley era of those who have already made it big time, but Chipperfield is only just beginning to surface in the cultural bigger picture. Hutton, 10 years younger than Chipperfield, belongs to the young British artists' generation, but she has had to move to Berlin to get to build anything larger than domestic conversions, and is still all but invisible in London.

It's also more fun being an artist because you don't have to labour under the burden of an all-consuming paranoia about being overtaken by your contemporaries in the ceaseless and pitiless struggle for the next commission. Tate Modern is good news for every young British artist. They may not get to exhibit their work there right away, but they still have a chance next year, or even in the next decade. But for architects, it's very different. There is, by definition, only one chance to design the most important new art gallery in Britain for 50 years, every 50 years. So you could see decidedly mixed feelings on the faces of a lot of the not-so-young British architects as they walked around the Tate's opening party last month. They were too smart to say it, but there was a palpable sense of 'it could have been me' in the air.

Architecture, like art, is a conversation, with private languages, cliques and alliances. But, in the end, nothing matters more for an architect struggling to establish a reputation than the chance to build. There are so few chances to build projects that really matter, that nothing else - certainly not group loyalty, friendship or artistic alliances - comes before the determination to get the job.

And the group now taking on the role of Britain's leading architects can still remember the fate of their predecessors who taught them in the 70s, condemned by the three-day week, the oil shock and the miners' strike to a career of paper architecture and unbuilt competition wins. They don't want to go the same way, but their prospects are still cluttered up by the big beasts ahead of them that so obstinately refuse to move over to let them move up. Norman Foster is still the most respected British architect internationally, and he is still busy soaking up the lion's share of the best jobs in town.

Richard Rogers is still the best politically connected architect in Britain since the 30s. Nick Grimshaw, far from fading away as a hi-tech period piece, is putting on a late burst of speed, picking up significant new projects. Terry Farrell is continuing to reinvent himself. And if the Alsops and the Chipperfields still aren't where they think they ought to be by now, where does this leave the generation coming after them?

The subtext to the Architecture Biennale in Venice is intimately connected with all these tangled concerns. The Biennale is deep in art community's territory. It's where the British Council gave everybody from Anthony Caro to Gilbert and George a highly visible platform. It's where Norman Foster and James Stirling were lionised. And this year it's where the fading classical stucco of the British pavilion will house work by four London-based architects: Will Alsop, Nigel Coates, Zaha Hadid and David Chipperfield - a choice that embodies the dilemmas and tensions underlying contemporary British architecture. The Venice Architecture Biennale is a curious event, a cross between the Royal Academy Summer Exhibition and a low-rent expo. It's staged as often as the city of Venice manages to raise enough cash - which makes for intervals that can be rather longer than its title implies.

And it sprawls far beyond the grandeur of the Biennale garden, with its collection of national pavilions, and out into the old ropery and warehouses of the Arsenale and the city itself. It is, so Venice would like us all to think, the most important event in the architectural calendar bar none. To be invited to exhibit represents major recognition. To be the commissioner means a chance to change the course of architectural history. Certainly that happened back in the early 80s, when one particular biennale turned out to be a mass rally for the forces of soon-to-be ubiquitous postmodernism which went on an unstoppable rampage all over the world soon afterwards. Its impact is still being felt, from the terracotta towers of Canary Wharf to the business parks of Shenzen.

This year's commissioner is Massimiliano Fuksas - an architect from Rome who is trying to give it a point of view by setting the Biennale theme on a course that is ostensibly an exploration of the social concerns of architecture rather than its aesthetics. Britain's role is directed by the British Council - the first to admit that when it comes to architecture it is on ground much less solid than it is with art or literature. But it seized on the social theme of the Biennale, and decided to make the remarkable collection of new architecture along London's Jubilee Line extension the focus for the exhibition. It wanted to look at the impact of architecture on regenerating east London.

In the event, the show isn't about that. The British Council couldn't raise the money. What it is now setting out to do is mark a changing of the guard. David Chipperfield, Will Alsop, Zaha Hadid and Nigel Coates are all in the late-forties to early-fifties age bracket - that sets them up as the generation taking over from Norman Foster, Richard Rogers and James Stirling. Those were the big three who set the tone for British architects for almost 25 years. Now it's time for a fresh look at the nature of British architecture. The trouble with architecture in Britain is that it carries the burden of utility in a way that its practitioners never quite know how to deal with. It has had the effect of creating a massive inferiority complex among the architects, when they compare themselves with artists. Go around an average school of architecture now, and you will find them turning out projects that look more and more like bad art. You'll find architecture students fiddling about with video cameras, constructing automatic drawing machines, working on installations - almost anything, in fact, but dealing with the tiresome quest for designing buildings that keep the rain out.

And this anxiety about art and status is, to some extent, reflected in the British quartet at Venice. It is a group which is, of course, not really a group: four architects who might be characterised as representing the war between the blob tendency and the box faction. On one side is Will Alsop who, after a shaky start as a postmodernist, built a very big, blobby, blue building outside Marseille, which serves as a town hall for the area. On the other is the cooler rationalism of the box tendency, represented in Venice by David Chipperfield. Nigel Coates, with his partner Doug Branson, is certainly in the blob camp, with an exhibit at Venice called Ecstacity. It was Coates who shaped the baroque muscles of the Dome's Body Zone, and who created the ill-fated National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield. Hadid doesn't do blobs. She makes boxes that have been shattered and sliced open. Her contribution to the Venice show is a vivid display on three bridges.

The underlying premise behind all the fuss about Venice is that Britain is world class when it comes to architecture. Is this true? Well, the common thread shared by all the British exhibitors is that they have built hardly anything at home. David Chipperfield is master-planning the Museum Island in Berlin. He is also building a law court in Salerno and an institute of contemporary arts in Milan. But in London he was beaten by Nick Grimshaw to do a new building for the Royal College of Art. Hadid is the architect who was the subject of the absurd row over the Cardiff Bay Opera House, a project killed off by the very same millennium commissioners who authorised yet another emergency multi-million bail-out for the Dome, because the project, in their judgment, lacked a proper business plan. Abroad, she's building in America and Italy. Alsop has managed to build rather more than the rest, but even he is doing more in Germany than at home.

Are they as good, for example, as those international protagonists in the battle between the blob and the box: Frank Gehry and Herzog and de Meuron? The four have yet to prove themselves. They have so far shown promise, as have so many other architects that the British Council might have selected to exhibit at the Biennale. Though they all have yet to build the buildings that will really mark their coming of age.

Chipperfield is still fighting for work at home 20 years after he left the Architectural Association. Of course there is a generational mismatch: Chipperfield's art-world equivalent would belong to the Richard Long or Antony Gormley era of those who have already made it big time, but Chipperfield is only just beginning to surface in the cultural bigger picture. Hutton, 10 years younger than Chipperfield, belongs to the young British artists' generation, but she has had to move to Berlin to get to build anything larger than domestic conversions, and is still all but invisible in London. It's also more fun being an artist because you don't have to labour under the burden of an all-consuming paranoia about being overtaken by your contemporaries in the ceaseless and pitiless struggle for the next commission. Tate Modern is good news for every young British artist. They may not get to exhibit their work there right away, but they still have a chance next year, or even in the next decade. But for architects, it's very different. There is, by definition, only one chance to design the most important new art gallery in Britain for 50 years, every 50 years. So you could see decidedly mixed feelings on the faces of a lot of the not-so-young British architects as they walked around the Tate's opening party last month. They were too smart to say it, but there was a palpable sense of 'it could have been me' in the air. Architecture, like art, is a conversation, with private languages, cliques and alliances. But, in the end, nothing matters more for an architect struggling to establish a reputation than the chance to build. There are so few chances to build projects that really matter, that nothing else - certainly not group loyalty, friendship or artistic alliances - comes before the determination to get the job. And the group now taking on the role of Britain's leading architects can still remember the fate of their predecessors who taught them in the 70s, condemned by the three-day week, the oil shock and the miners' strike to a career of paper architecture and unbuilt competition wins. They don't want to go the same way, but their prospects are still cluttered up by the big beasts ahead of them that so obstinately refuse to move over to let them move up. Norman Foster is still the most respected British architect internationally, and he is still busy soaking up the lion's share of the best jobs in town. Richard Rogers is still the best politically connected architect in Britain since the 30s. Nick Grimshaw, far from fading away as a hi-tech period piece, is putting on a late burst of speed, picking up significant new projects. Terry Farrell is continuing to reinvent himself. And if the Alsops and the Chipperfields still aren't where they think they ought to be by now, where does this leave the generation coming after them? The subtext to the Architecture Biennale in Venice is intimately connected with all these tangled concerns. The Biennale is deep in art community's territory. It's where the British Council gave everybody from Anthony Caro to Gilbert and George a highly visible platform. It's where Norman Foster and James Stirling were lionised. And this year it's where the fading classical stucco of the British pavilion will house work by four London-based architects: Will Alsop, Nigel Coates, Zaha Hadid and David Chipperfield - a choice that embodies the dilemmas and tensions underlying contemporary British architecture. The Venice Architecture Biennale is a curious event, a cross between the Royal Academy Summer Exhibition and a low-rent expo. It's staged as often as the city of Venice manages to raise enough cash - which makes for intervals that can be rather longer than its title implies. And it sprawls far beyond the grandeur of the Biennale garden, with its collection of national pavilions, and out into the old ropery and warehouses of the Arsenale and the city itself. It is, so Venice would like us all to think, the most important event in the architectural calendar bar none. To be invited to exhibit represents major recognition. To be the commissioner means a chance to change the course of architectural history. Certainly that happened back in the early 80s, when one particular biennale turned out to be a mass rally for the forces of soon-to-be ubiquitous postmodernism which went on an unstoppable rampage all over the world soon afterwards. Its impact is still being felt, from the terracotta towers of Canary Wharf to the business parks of Shenzen. This year's commissioner is Massimiliano Fuksas - an architect from Rome who is trying to give it a point of view by setting the Biennale theme on a course that is ostensibly an exploration of the social concerns of architecture rather than its aesthetics. Britain's role is directed by the British Council - the first to admit that when it comes to architecture it is on ground much less solid than it is with art or literature. But it seized on the social theme of the Biennale, and decided to make the remarkable collection of new architecture along London's Jubilee Line extension the focus for the exhibition. It wanted to look at the impact of architecture on regenerating east London. In the event, the show isn't about that. The British Council couldn't raise the money. What it is now setting out to do is mark a changing of the guard. David Chipperfield, Will Alsop, Zaha Hadid and Nigel Coates are all in the late-forties to early-fifties age bracket - that sets them up as the generation taking over from Norman Foster, Richard Rogers and James Stirling. Those were the big three who set the tone for British architects for almost 25 years. Now it's time for a fresh look at the nature of British architecture. The trouble with architecture in Britain is that it carries the burden of utility in a way that its practitioners never quite know how to deal with. It has had the effect of creating a massive inferiority complex among the architects, when they compare themselves with artists. Go around an average school of architecture now, and you will find them turning out projects that look more and more like bad art. You'll find architecture students fiddling about with video cameras, constructing automatic drawing machines, working on installations - almost anything, in fact, but dealing with the tiresome quest for designing buildings that keep the rain out. And this anxiety about art and status is, to some extent, reflected in the British quartet at Venice. It is a group which is, of course, not really a group: four architects who might be characterised as representing the war between the blob tendency and the box faction. On one side is Will Alsop who, after a shaky start as a postmodernist, built a very big, blobby, blue building outside Marseille, which serves as a town hall for the area. On the other is the cooler rationalism of the box tendency, represented in Venice by David Chipperfield. Nigel Coates, with his partner Doug Branson, is certainly in the blob camp, with an exhibit at Venice called Ecstacity. It was Coates who shaped the baroque muscles of the Dome's Body Zone, and who created the ill-fated National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield. Hadid doesn't do blobs. She makes boxes that have been shattered and sliced open. Her contribution to the Venice show is a vivid display on three bridges. The underlying premise behind all the fuss about Venice is that Britain is world class when it comes to architecture. Is this true? Well, the common thread shared by all the British exhibitors is that they have built hardly anything at home. David Chipperfield is master-planning the Museum Island in Berlin. He is also building a law court in Salerno and an institute of contemporary arts in Milan. But in London he was beaten by Nick Grimshaw to do a new building for the Royal College of Art. Hadid is the architect who was the subject of the absurd row over the Cardiff Bay Opera House, a project killed off by the very same millennium commissioners who authorised yet another emergency multi-million bail-out for the Dome, because the project, in their judgment, lacked a proper business plan. Abroad, she's building in America and Italy. Alsop has managed to build rather more than the rest, but even he is doing more in Germany than at home. Are they as good, for example, as those international protagonists in the battle between the blob and the box: Frank Gehry and Herzog and de Meuron? The four have yet to prove themselves. They have so far shown promise, as have so many other architects that the British Council might have selected to exhibit at the Biennale. Though they all have yet to build the buildings that will really mark their coming of age.

fields.headline: Self control
fields.standfirst: After two decades of chronic heroin and alcohol abuse, Will Self is finally off everything, including ginger beer. Now, he also says he is giving up journalism. Lynn Barber talks to Britain's most literate ex-junkie about family, fiction and his feminine side
fields.trailText: After two decades of chronic heroin and alcohol abuse, Will Self is finally off everything, including ginger beer. Now, he also says he is giving up journalism. Lynn Barber talks to Britain's most literate ex-junkie about family, fiction and his feminine side
fields.body:
I'm off everything now. I couldn't have written another book if I hadn't cleaned up.' Yep, Will Self, at 38, is free of his long addiction to drugs and alcohol, and prepared to shed whatever dubious glamour that gave him. Before, he's always fudged the issue. His line for many years was that he'd been a heroin addict in his late teens and early twenties, but cleaned up in 1986.

This was true as far as it went - but didn't really address the question of how far he'd relapsed in subsequent years. It was always obvious that he was on something , the only question was what. He says now that he never went back to injecting heroin, but he did use it - and cocaine, and alcohol, and anything else going. For most of the 90s, he says, 'I was pushing a bottle of Scotch a day. But I never in all those 10 years ended up back on heroin because my body just couldn't take it - I'd use it for a few days or at most a few weeks and I'd become too physically ill and run-down to continue. I'd go on a binge, then come off with pot and booze, or try and taper off and maintain that, and then relapse on to heroin - over and over again trying to switch combinations and trying to find a way in which I could continue to get loaded without it being a problem.'

He thought no one knew, though he realises now that 'a highly visible addict is like a child who hides behind a tree and thinks they can't be seen because they can't see you. But after the incident of 1997 [when he took heroin on the prime minister's plane] anybody who read a tabloid knew that I had a drug problem, while I still obstinately refused to acknowledge that I did myself.'

But, since last October, he has been sober and seems confident that he can remain so. Some of his friends are more sceptical - they say things like, 'It's early days,' and point out that he cleaned up once before. But certainly the determination is there. He bought a bottle of posh ginger beer from Sainsbury's the other day and took a swig and thought: 'This contains alcohol,' and looked at the label and found it was 0.05 per cent proof. So he went and poured it down the loo.

He looks good on it, too - though altogether quieter than I have known him. But then, in the past, I've always known him in partying mode. This time he's at home, with his wife Deborah Orr, and their two-year-old son Ivan, and a book called Beyond Toddlerdom open on the sofa. The house is immaculate and surprisingly grand. He always says he lives in Vauxhall, which sounds rather raffish, but it's a lie - his house is in fashionable Stockwell and could feature in a design supplement any day. 'We live like kings!' he laughs. He does, too. Being married to Deborah Orr automatically makes him the envy of most male journalists in London. She is an unconventional beauty with great swags of tawny hair who was The Guardian Weekend editor and is now an award-winning columnist for The Independent . My colleague Euan Ferguson describes her as a 'proper tykey wee Motherwell bauchle,' which is evidently Scottish for a Good Thing.

They married three years ago, and the marriage got off to a rocky start. Deborah was four months pregnant in April 1997 when Self was sacked from The Observer for taking drugs on John Major's plane. At the time, he was very loud and fierce in blaming The Observer; now he says demurely, 'I just blame myself. I mean, it was a shitty imbroglio and I put my disease at the centre of it all. Nobody at The Observer behaved badly. In fact, Will Hutton [the then editor] wrote and offered me money for treatment out of his own pocket, which I think was a saintly gesture.' The only person he remains furious with is Rosie Boycott, whom he claims betrayed him by printing a conversation in The Independent on Sunday which he thought was off the record. He will never speak to her again - 'But I wouldn't hire a hit man!'

The dark suspicion at the time was that his heroin-taking was a stunt, that he was trying to 'do a Hunter S Thompson'. On the contrary, he says, he didn't give it a second thought. 'After all, at that point in my life I'd been taking heroin off and on for two decades - it was all in the day's work for me. In fact, the only thing that occurred to me - because I was smoking a lot of pot - was that I must stay downwind of the PM's special branch.' He spent what for him was a boring day covering Major's campaign in Derbyshire, filed his (perfectly coherent) copy, and thought no more about it. But apparently a Sunday Express man gleaned some gossip from Tory press minders, and cooked it up into a story.

Self repeatedly told Hutton that there was no truth in the story, and Hutton went out to bat for him on that basis. But when Observer lawyers asked Self to sign an affidavit, he refused, and at that point Alan Rusbridger, the editor-in-chief, sacked him. Self recalls the final scene at The Observer, with Rusbridger asking how he could lie to his editor for three days and himself thinking, 'I was doing class-A drugs at 17. I have lived the bulk of my adult life on the wrong side of the law, and you're asking me how I could have dared to tell a lie ?'

Self's friends at the Groucho were disposed to cheer, regarding it as a heroic adventure. Self disagrees. He says the whole experience was horrible and humiliating - Deborah didn't eat for a week, neither of them slept, they had reporters camping on their doorstep, his older children (from his first marriage) heard gossip at school, it was all a nightmare. Indeed, he says solemnly: 'I do think I have a responsibility to point out, very clearly, that I don't think that my talents or my success as a writer have anything to do with my drug use or drinking. On the contrary, I've always had to fight against them in order to get any serious literary work done. So I think it is important for me to put that on the record. You know, drug addiction is as bad as your parents tell you it is. It really is.'

Coo-er. This is the man who once said that telling people not to take drugs was like telling them not to breathe. But now he is eager to forget all that - he even claims that none of his writing ever glamourised drug use (oh come, Will!). When I mentioned that I loved his short story, Tough, Tough Toys for Tough, Tough Boys, he said he found it too poignant to re-read because, 'I realise now it's very much an anticipatory suicide note, written when I was struggling against alcoholism and really going under.' He rejects huge swathes of his past as tainted with addiction. Even his exciting pre-Deborah love life, when Tatler described him as 'the rock star of the literati with his own groupies', has been confined to the dustbin. Promiscuity, he says, was merely another symptom of his addictive personality - 'just a need to fix myself at a very primary level of feeling. And to gain the approbation and security of people being prepared to go to bed with me.' All his vastly complicated psychiatric history, in which he has been variously diagnosed as depressive, hypermanic, manic-depressive and even, when he was 19, borderline schizophrenic, can now be reduced to one simple diagnosis: 'I'm as sane as you are. But I am an addict.'

This seems a tad simplistic. Even sober, he is a very dark and complex character, driven by strange guilts and fears and paranoias, unable to relax. Apart from all his other addictions he is a workaholic, who published eight books between 1991 and 1998, and probably wrote as much again in journalism. His current commitments include a weekly television review and occasional interviews (always with women) for The Independent on Sunday, a regular column for American GQ, and for the architects' paper Building Design, and a weekly 'essay' for the Today programme. He pops up on television arts programmes, and is currently doing an improbable stint as a 'live writer' in Jay Jopling's White Cube gallery. He is also writing a film script based on The Picture of Dorian Gray and a book about masculinity based on interviews with a woman-to-man transsexual ('We're just getting to his penis'). But all this is subsidiary to what he sees as his main job - writing fiction.

Self's new novel, How the Dead Live, is literally 'long-awaited' - it was due out last year, but he was in no state to write it. He describes it now as 'the book that saved me'. It is written by a dead woman who is clearly his mother, and continues the theme of one of his first and greatest short stories, The North London Book of the Dead. But he has made one significant biographical change: he has given her two daughters (one of whom is a heroin addict) rather than three sons. Why? 'Well, I think partly, at the rather flip level, from a desire to recreate myself as a beautiful woman! Cocteau said that all artists are hermaphrodites, so I suppose there was a desire to maximise my feminine side. And again, Freud said that all art is wish-fulfilment and my mother had always wanted daughters. She didn't want sons and always had a very uneasy relationship with our masculinity.'

Self seems to be actually haunted by his mother, who died of cancer in 1988. She was an unhappy woman, unmaternal, whom he describes as 'very loving and very aggressive'. After she died, he read her diaries and was shocked to find how coolly and critically she described her children. 'I think in the end she loved and disparaged us all equally. But I was the youngest and around her most, so I had the most intimate relationship with her by virtue of proximity.' His father, an LSE professor who first left home when Self was nine, was a remote and intimidating figure - 'a man who used dialectics the way the Japanese used bamboo slivers during the war'. The marriage was on, off, on, off for several years and ended in divorce when Self was 18. His cousin, Susannah Self, has recorded: 'There was a sense that the one thing that held together their difficult marriage was their total adoration of their little Willy. Day in, day out, they had nothing but pathological wonder for their incredibly naughty and difficult creation.'

If he thought he had to be naughty to keep his parents' marriage intact, he certainly did his best - he started smoking dope at 12, was a regular in Hampstead pubs by 14, and first injected heroin at 17. When he went to Oxford to read PPE he was 'never for a second without some drug or other'. Mark Honigsbaum, who shared a flat with him in Oxford, recalls him in his final year 'holed up with Kant and a syringe'. He got a third. After that he devoted himself full time to being a junkie, till his mother paid for him to dry out in 1986.

He was abstinent for three-and-a-half years, during which he worked for an industrial publisher, writing articles on deep-bore oil-well drilling. He survived his mother's death sober, but then started drinking again the next year. It was joy, not sorrow, that unhinged him. 'I was already wholly focused on literary ambition at that point - I really, really wanted to publish a book, that was my alpha and omega. My life up till then had really been a sort of brilliant mistake and I thought it would all be redeemed by having a book accepted. And when The Quantity Theory of Insanity was accepted in late '89, I felt I'd arrived, and all the brakes went off. I thought: "Here I am, a proper citizen, I'm married, I've got a book coming out." So I didn't really believe what had been told to me - that I had an addictive disease that would never be cured.'

By the time he arrived on the literary scene in 1991 - chosen as one of Granta 's Best Young British Novelists before he'd even published a novel - he was back on drugs and drink full time, and so he remained for most of the 90s. His pattern was to binge in London and then escape to the country - usually the Orkneys, which he loves - to clean up and write. But things started to go wrong in the summer of 1998 when he set off on one of his escapes and found he couldn't drive any more, he was too sick from drugs and blood-poisoning. His oldest friend, a consultant psychiatrist, managed to get him admitted to a private clinic, expecting him to be put in the drying-out ward. But Self fought that idea tooth and nail and persuaded the doctors that he was suffering from depression. 'So they put me on Prozac, which was ridiculous - I'm not a depressive. It made me completely mad, completely.'

He was supposed to be delivering How the Dead Live in the autumn of 1998, but he missed that deadline, and the next. He knew he would have to be sober to write it, but he kept putting it off. In March last year, he achieved a DIY detox from hard drugs and booze, but he was still smoking enormous quantities of pot - 'A couple of Masai warriors had to pitch bales of the stuff into the basement every day.' Eventually he decided that only total abstinence would work and in October presented himself at an AA meeting, saying he was helpless in the face of addiction. 'I was 38 years old. I was in one shape or form addicted to drugs for nearly 20 years.'

Then he went to the country and wrote How the Dead Live . Deborah had been urging him to do it fast - 'Do a bosh job, bosh, bosh, bosh, write a novella, fulfil your contract.' But in the end he wrote 400 pages. He says it was the hardest work he's ever done. In the past, he would write all day, stop at 7pm and reward himself with four Scotches and two joints then re-read what he'd written and go, 'Oh ha ha, that's quite good!' But with this one there was no reward. 'I couldn't get any zip going. And I didn't get any sense of completion until I was very near the end, when suddenly I could look back and see that it was working. But up till then I was in the dark wood.' Normally, he would celebrate the delivery of a manuscript by going on a bender. This time he took his seven-year-old daughter to buy presents in Hamleys.

Many of his friends believe his drug problems over the past decade have been connected to guilt over the bitter break-up of his first marriage, to Kate Chancellor (sister of the actress Anna 'Duckface'), in 1993. He left his children, Alexis and Madeleine, when they were only two and six months. He has been a conscientious visiting father all these years, always turning up on the dot to collect them from school or take them swimming, however smashed or hungover he might be, but he admits, 'There's no doubt in my mind that my addiction has affected them - how can you be a good father when you're that self-destructive?' And he thinks it is no coincidence that he finally decided to sober up just when his children were becoming old enough to hear the gossip about their father.

He says that obviously his life has changed with abstinence - though it was changing anyway, what with being married, having a new child and growing older. 'I have become just a helluva lot quieter. I don't go out much - I'm quite comfortable with that for the moment, but in due course I'd like to be a lot more sociable again. I just don't see anybody.' Oddly - for one who is so keen on women - he says he wishes he had more men friends, he wishes he'd kept a gang from school or university. But his drink and drugs - and the paranoia that went with them - gradually blew them all away. I know quite a few people who were friends with Will Self but had some terminal row with him. His current close friend is the writer Andrew O'Hagan - he and Deborah are going on holiday with him and his girlfriend India Knight - but Will says that even Andrew got fed up with him being 'fucking out to lunch'.

Also, he is really too dazzling to be a good friend. I remember in 1995 taking an incredibly long train journey back from the Cheltenham Festival with Will and his then girlfriend, Victoria Hull. He was wildly entertaining, ranting on about all the contemporary writers he hates. But it was more like a performance than a conversation - and it went on for five hours.

He is to some extent an actor; he knows it, and is troubled by it. 'There's a part of me that plays to the gallery and a part of me that would sooner slink underneath it and go home. I'm not so sure that the latter person isn't truer to my nature, but I'm quite confused about it. Deborah says it's vulgar to be famous - and I do have quite a lot of regrets about having a public profile which, for whatever reason, militates against the work being considered on its own merits.'

This is a constant beef - that in Britain he's seen as a media performer first, and a novelist second. In America, it's the opposite - they treat him as a serious literary figure and call him 'Mr Self'. He gets very tetchy here when people say - as they often do - that they love his journalism and short stories but find his novels unreadable. This is a very sore topic indeed - when I raised it I suddenly saw a flash of the old Will, ranting on about people who were too lazy to read books. I got the same blistering when I said I wished he wouldn't use 'dictionary' words. He actually boasts that he uses a thesaurus and that, 'To me, a writer saying he doesn't use one is like a mechanic saying he doesn't use a socket set.'

But what's the point of using words that have no life outside a dictionary? I think the explanation is that he has an inferiority complex about his literary credentials - he read PPE at university, not Eng Lit, and says that the difference between him and Martin Amis is that Amis is a 'writer's writer', steeped in literature, whereas he writes 'novels of ideas'. He puts his writing manifesto on the cover of How the Dead Live: 'I don't write fiction for people to identify with and I don't write a picture of the world they can recognise. I write to astonish people.' For me, it sums up the fatal flaw in his fiction - a certain condescension in his attitude to the reader. He wants to dazzle and astonish more than he wants to communicate.

Whereas his journalism, I think, is brilliant - just as dazzling but mercifully shorter and cushioned by the surrounding stodge. I love his interviews for The Independent on Sunday , but am also quite relieved to note their diminishing frequency, which he explains is because 'My subjects are becoming distinctly elusive - my quarry is scampering over the veldt ahead of my gun!' He likes interviewing women because he thinks he's somehow reconnecting with his mother. But there is no doubt in his mind that his journalism is secondary to his fiction - 'Fiction is where I really find myself as a writer. It's the mother lode. It's where I get my jollies.'

Next year, he thinks he might give up journalism to concentrate entirely on novels. He wants to write bigger novels - 'Bigger canvas, longer time span, more characters and more gearing into the world. In my twenties and thirties, I had that kind of fashionable deconstructionist view that it was meaningless to write about what characters thought because it was such an artificial construct - and I think in my case that was also a reflection of my own immaturity. But the interesting thing about middle age is that you begin to see how people change over time, and how they change in relation to social change, and you begin to get an inkling of why the 19th-century novelists were so preoccupied by this phenomenon. It requires a big canvas and a lot of space and a lot of oomph to bring it off, and I'm really interested in doing it.'

Is he confident that he can stay clean? 'Today, yes, today. I don't know for the future, but I sincerely hope so because - I don't want to be melodramatic about it but I don't need to be - it fucking nearly killed me. And I love my life and I love my wife, I love my children, and I love such friends as I've managed to keep despite the disease, and I don't want to spoil that. But it's pointless to make pledges for the future - it's about dealing with the day.'

 How the Dead Live (Bloomsbury, £15.99) is published on 22 June

But when Observer lawyers asked Self to sign an affidavit, he refused, and at that point Alan Rusbridger, the editor-in-chief, sacked him. Self recalls the final scene at The Observer, with Rusbridger asking how he could lie to his editor for three days and himself thinking, 'I was doing class-A drugs at 17. I have lived the bulk of my adult life on the wrong side of the law, and you're asking me how I could have dared to tell a lie ?' Self's friends at the Groucho were disposed to cheer, regarding it as a heroic adventure. Self disagrees. He says the whole experience was horrible and humiliating - Deborah didn't eat for a week, neither of them slept, they had reporters camping on their doorstep, his older children (from his first marriage) heard gossip at school, it was all a nightmare. Indeed, he says solemnly: 'I do think I have a responsibility to point out, very clearly, that I don't think that my talents or my success as a writer have anything to do with my drug use or drinking. On the contrary, I've always had to fight against them in order to get any serious literary work done. So I think it is important for me to put that on the record. You know, drug addiction is as bad as your parents tell you it is. It really is.' Coo-er. This is the man who once said that telling people not to take drugs was like telling them not to breathe. But now he is eager to forget all that - he even claims that none of his writing ever glamourised drug use (oh come, Will!). When I mentioned that I loved his short story, Tough, Tough Toys for Tough, Tough Boys, he said he found it too poignant to re-read because, 'I realise now it's very much an anticipatory suicide note, written when I was struggling against alcoholism and really going under.' He rejects huge swathes of his past as tainted with addiction. Even his exciting pre-Deborah love life, when Tatler described him as 'the rock star of the literati with his own groupies', has been confined to the dustbin. Promiscuity, he says, was merely another symptom of his addictive personality - 'just a need to fix myself at a very primary level of feeling. And to gain the approbation and security of people being prepared to go to bed with me.' All his vastly complicated psychiatric history, in which he has been variously diagnosed as depressive, hypermanic, manic-depressive and even, when he was 19, borderline schizophrenic, can now be reduced to one simple diagnosis: 'I'm as sane as you are. But I am an addict.' This seems a tad simplistic. Even sober, he is a very dark and complex character, driven by strange guilts and fears and paranoias, unable to relax. Apart from all his other addictions he is a workaholic, who published eight books between 1991 and 1998, and probably wrote as much again in journalism. His current commitments include a weekly television review and occasional interviews (always with women) for The Independent on Sunday, a regular column for American GQ, and for the architects' paper Building Design, and a weekly 'essay' for the Today programme. He pops up on television arts programmes, and is currently doing an improbable stint as a 'live writer' in Jay Jopling's White Cube gallery. He is also writing a film script based on The Picture of Dorian Gray and a book about masculinity based on interviews with a woman-to-man transsexual ('We're just getting to his penis'). But all this is subsidiary to what he sees as his main job - writing fiction. Self's new novel, How the Dead Live, is literally 'long-awaited' - it was due out last year, but he was in no state to write it. He describes it now as 'the book that saved me'. It is written by a dead woman who is clearly his mother, and continues the theme of one of his first and greatest short stories, The North London Book of the Dead. But he has made one significant biographical change: he has given her two daughters (one of whom is a heroin addict) rather than three sons. Why? 'Well, I think partly, at the rather flip level, from a desire to recreate myself as a beautiful woman! Cocteau said that all artists are hermaphrodites, so I suppose there was a desire to maximise my feminine side. And again, Freud said that all art is wish-fulfilment and my mother had always wanted daughters. She didn't want sons and always had a very uneasy relationship with our masculinity.' Self seems to be actually haunted by his mother, who died of cancer in 1988. She was an unhappy woman, unmaternal, whom he describes as 'very loving and very aggressive'. After she died, he read her diaries and was shocked to find how coolly and critically she described her children. 'I think in the end she loved and disparaged us all equally. But I was the youngest and around her most, so I had the most intimate relationship with her by virtue of proximity.' His father, an LSE professor who first left home when Self was nine, was a remote and intimidating figure - 'a man who used dialectics the way the Japanese used bamboo slivers during the war'. The marriage was on, off, on, off for several years and ended in divorce when Self was 18. His cousin, Susannah Self, has recorded: 'There was a sense that the one thing that held together their difficult marriage was their total adoration of their little Willy. Day in, day out, they had nothing but pathological wonder for their incredibly naughty and difficult creation.' If he thought he had to be naughty to keep his parents' marriage intact, he certainly did his best - he started smoking dope at 12, was a regular in Hampstead pubs by 14, and first injected heroin at 17. When he went to Oxford to read PPE he was 'never for a second without some drug or other'. Mark Honigsbaum, who shared a flat with him in Oxford, recalls him in his final year 'holed up with Kant and a syringe'. He got a third. After that he devoted himself full time to being a junkie, till his mother paid for him to dry out in 1986. He was abstinent for three-and-a-half years, during which he worked for an industrial publisher, writing articles on deep-bore oil-well drilling. He survived his mother's death sober, but then started drinking again the next year. It was joy, not sorrow, that unhinged him. 'I was already wholly focused on literary ambition at that point - I really, really wanted to publish a book, that was my alpha and omega. My life up till then had really been a sort of brilliant mistake and I thought it would all be redeemed by having a book accepted. And when The Quantity Theory of Insanity was accepted in late '89, I felt I'd arrived, and all the brakes went off. I thought: "Here I am, a proper citizen, I'm married, I've got a book coming out." So I didn't really believe what had been told to me - that I had an addictive disease that would never be cured.' By the time he arrived on the literary scene in 1991 - chosen as one of Granta 's Best Young British Novelists before he'd even published a novel - he was back on drugs and drink full time, and so he remained for most of the 90s. His pattern was to binge in London and then escape to the country - usually the Orkneys, which he loves - to clean up and write. But things started to go wrong in the summer of 1998 when he set off on one of his escapes and found he couldn't drive any more, he was too sick from drugs and blood-poisoning. His oldest friend, a consultant psychiatrist, managed to get him admitted to a private clinic, expecting him to be put in the drying-out ward. But Self fought that idea tooth and nail and persuaded the doctors that he was suffering from depression. 'So they put me on Prozac, which was ridiculous - I'm not a depressive. It made me completely mad, completely.' He was supposed to be delivering How the Dead Live in the autumn of 1998, but he missed that deadline, and the next. He knew he would have to be sober to write it, but he kept putting it off. In March last year, he achieved a DIY detox from hard drugs and booze, but he was still smoking enormous quantities of pot - 'A couple of Masai warriors had to pitch bales of the stuff into the basement every day.' Eventually he decided that only total abstinence would work and in October presented himself at an AA meeting, saying he was helpless in the face of addiction. 'I was 38 years old. I was in one shape or form addicted to drugs for nearly 20 years.' Then he went to the country and wrote How the Dead Live . Deborah had been urging him to do it fast - 'Do a bosh job, bosh, bosh, bosh, write a novella, fulfil your contract.' But in the end he wrote 400 pages. He says it was the hardest work he's ever done. In the past, he would write all day, stop at 7pm and reward himself with four Scotches and two joints then re-read what he'd written and go, 'Oh ha ha, that's quite good!' But with this one there was no reward. 'I couldn't get any zip going. And I didn't get any sense of completion until I was very near the end, when suddenly I could look back and see that it was working. But up till then I was in the dark wood.' Normally, he would celebrate the delivery of a manuscript by going on a bender. This time he took his seven-year-old daughter to buy presents in Hamleys. Many of his friends believe his drug problems over the past decade have been connected to guilt over the bitter break-up of his first marriage, to Kate Chancellor (sister of the actress Anna 'Duckface'), in 1993. He left his children, Alexis and Madeleine, when they were only two and six months. He has been a conscientious visiting father all these years, always turning up on the dot to collect them from school or take them swimming, however smashed or hungover he might be, but he admits, 'There's no doubt in my mind that my addiction has affected them - how can you be a good father when you're that self-destructive?' And he thinks it is no coincidence that he finally decided to sober up just when his children were becoming old enough to hear the gossip about their father. He says that obviously his life has changed with abstinence - though it was changing anyway, what with being married, having a new child and growing older. 'I have become just a helluva lot quieter. I don't go out much - I'm quite comfortable with that for the moment, but in due course I'd like to be a lot more sociable again. I just don't see anybody.' Oddly - for one who is so keen on women - he says he wishes he had more men friends, he wishes he'd kept a gang from school or university. But his drink and drugs - and the paranoia that went with them - gradually blew them all away. I know quite a few people who were friends with Will Self but had some terminal row with him. His current close friend is the writer Andrew O'Hagan - he and Deborah are going on holiday with him and his girlfriend India Knight - but Will says that even Andrew got fed up with him being 'fucking out to lunch'. Also, he is really too dazzling to be a good friend. I remember in 1995 taking an incredibly long train journey back from the Cheltenham Festival with Will and his then girlfriend, Victoria Hull. He was wildly entertaining, ranting on about all the contemporary writers he hates. But it was more like a performance than a conversation - and it went on for five hours. He is to some extent an actor; he knows it, and is troubled by it. 'There's a part of me that plays to the gallery and a part of me that would sooner slink underneath it and go home. I'm not so sure that the latter person isn't truer to my nature, but I'm quite confused about it. Deborah says it's vulgar to be famous - and I do have quite a lot of regrets about having a public profile which, for whatever reason, militates against the work being considered on its own merits.' This is a constant beef - that in Britain he's seen as a media performer first, and a novelist second. In America, it's the opposite - they treat him as a serious literary figure and call him 'Mr Self'. He gets very tetchy here when people say - as they often do - that they love his journalism and short stories but find his novels unreadable. This is a very sore topic indeed - when I raised it I suddenly saw a flash of the old Will, ranting on about people who were too lazy to read books. I got the same blistering when I said I wished he wouldn't use 'dictionary' words. He actually boasts that he uses a thesaurus and that, 'To me, a writer saying he doesn't use one is like a mechanic saying he doesn't use a socket set.' But what's the point of using words that have no life outside a dictionary? I think the explanation is that he has an inferiority complex about his literary credentials - he read PPE at university, not Eng Lit, and says that the difference between him and Martin Amis is that Amis is a 'writer's writer', steeped in literature, whereas he writes 'novels of ideas'. He puts his writing manifesto on the cover of How the Dead Live: 'I don't write fiction for people to identify with and I don't write a picture of the world they can recognise. I write to astonish people.' For me, it sums up the fatal flaw in his fiction - a certain condescension in his attitude to the reader. He wants to dazzle and astonish more than he wants to communicate. Whereas his journalism, I think, is brilliant - just as dazzling but mercifully shorter and cushioned by the surrounding stodge. I love his interviews for The Independent on Sunday , but am also quite relieved to note their diminishing frequency, which he explains is because 'My subjects are becoming distinctly elusive - my quarry is scampering over the veldt ahead of my gun!' He likes interviewing women because he thinks he's somehow reconnecting with his mother. But there is no doubt in his mind that his journalism is secondary to his fiction - 'Fiction is where I really find myself as a writer. It's the mother lode. It's where I get my jollies.' Next year, he thinks he might give up journalism to concentrate entirely on novels. He wants to write bigger novels - 'Bigger canvas, longer time span, more characters and more gearing into the world. In my twenties and thirties, I had that kind of fashionable deconstructionist view that it was meaningless to write about what characters thought because it was such an artificial construct - and I think in my case that was also a reflection of my own immaturity. But the interesting thing about middle age is that you begin to see how people change over time, and how they change in relation to social change, and you begin to get an inkling of why the 19th-century novelists were so preoccupied by this phenomenon. It requires a big canvas and a lot of space and a lot of oomph to bring it off, and I'm really interested in doing it.' Is he confident that he can stay clean? 'Today, yes, today. I don't know for the future, but I sincerely hope so because - I don't want to be melodramatic about it but I don't need to be - it fucking nearly killed me. And I love my life and I love my wife, I love my children, and I love such friends as I've managed to keep despite the disease, and I don't want to spoil that. But it's pointless to make pledges for the future - it's about dealing with the day.'  How the Dead Live (Bloomsbury, £15.99) is published on 22 June

fields.headline: Playing the fame game
fields.trailText: My best friend, also a journalist, is the most celebrity-friendly person I know. Whereas most of my interviews tend to end with me being escorted off the premises by publicists holding mobile phones like guns, hers invariably terminate in a flurry of bear hugs, shopping tips and home phone numbers
fields.body:
My best friend, also a journalist, is the most celebrity-friendly person I know. Whereas most of my interviews tend to end with me being escorted off the premises by publicists holding mobile phones like guns, hers invariably terminate in a flurry of bear hugs, shopping tips and home phone numbers. She also gets marched away by publicists, but only because celebrities like her too much. My friend is so A-list simpatico, sometimes I wonder if she is in training to become a celebrity herself.

'I'm not obsessed with celebrity,' she corrected me recently. 'I'm obsessed with talent. ' A good point, beautifully put, though slightly undermined by the copy of Now magazine spread across her lap, opened at a story about how 'deeply distressed' the public was about Matthew Perry's yo-yoing weight. An image flashed into my head of people slumped tearfully in church pews: 'How can there be a God in a world where Matthew Perry's weight won't stabilise?' More recently, it was Danniella Westbrook's turn to 'deeply distress' the public. She used to play Sam Mitchell from EastEnders, a Cockney beauty with two nostrils. I mention the number of nostrils because Westbrook seems to have since sacrificed her septum to cocaine, leaving her with one gaping hole where two little ones used to be.

The resulting photographs were classic paparazzi porn, just like the infamous Sammy Davis Jr throat-cancer shots, or the ones revealing that, close up, Michael Jackson's nose resembled something a four-year-old might fashion out of Play-Doh. Looking at the Westbrook pictures, one couldn't register the hole in her nose without also thinking of the bigger, uglier void that must surely lie at the centre of her being. Westbrook is now safely ensconced on brain-death row at the Priory. A 'friend' commented to the press: 'Cocaine has done everything but kill Danniella. She's lost her looks, her job, her men, her money, and her dignity.' The striking thing was how, if you replaced the word 'cocaine' with 'celebrity', the sentence still worked.

Westbrook's problem isn't drugs, it's celebrity, just as Paula Yates's problem isn't sex, it's celebrity. Indeed, celebrity's ongoing devaluation is such that if you floated 'celebrity' on the stock market right now, the smart money would be on pig livers. It's so obvious, you wonder why people still bother. One could understand why somebody would want to be wealthy, but celebrity seems to be a chalice so poisoned that the amount of people hellbent on drinking from it is positively mystifying. At the start of her career, Patsy Kensit said: 'Every night, I kneel by my bed and pray to be famous.' And look at her now - a woman who gets to visit the most beautiful cities in the world and have nervous breakdowns in all of them. Rather than being an object of desire and envy, the modern celebrity has become little more than a cautionary tale with portfolio. And yet still, for most of us, celebrity retains its irresistibility.

To illustrate: one evening not so long ago, my friend and I hooked up with a very fashionable comedian in a late-night drinking club. He sat slumped between us on the sofa, a tumbler of vodka in each hand, hiccuping softly. 'I am dwarfed by your wit and intellect,' he told me. 'I dream of being with you.' Seconds later, he turned to my friend and, with his hand still on my knee, said: 'I am dwarfed by your wit and intellect. I, erm, (hic) dream of being with you.' For all his deep patheticness, the fact remained that my friend and I were even more pathetic. The comedian was completely resistible on all levels bar his celebrity, but we weren't going to let him, or his anecdotal potential, go without a fight. A little later, instead of taking him back to our place as promised, we turfed him out of the cab on to a traffic island, near a deserted motorway junction, in freezing rain, at 5.30am. We drove off cackling, but later agreed guiltily that we'd never have treated a 'real person' like that.

It made me realise that, while celebrity is always blamed on celebrities, maybe it's the public's fault. Maybe celebrities are selfless beings who become celebrities so we don't have to. It certainly figures that, if we didn't encourage them so much, poor souls like Christopher Biggins wouldn't end up at premieres still pretending to be famous, just as a bald man combs over his hair pretending that he's not losing it. It's too easy to feel superior. All of us are mere outlines waiting to be coloured in by our experiences and other people's perceptions. However, with certain celebrities, it's as if even the outline is missing, and they are less people than they are coloured mists, rainbows. Like rainbows, they certainly make sense from a distance. Close up, all that is beautiful and bright about celebrity seems to disappear. Toto tugs away the curtain and the Wizard of Oz is revealed to be a fat old fraud with a paunch, or an ex-soap actress with one nostril. Or indeed just another sad sack waiting for a cab in the early-morning drizzle.
