fields.headline: The Dutch Master
fields.trailText: Diego Maradona is addicted to cocaine. Johan Cruyff is addicted to football. The Dutch Anglophile who lives in Spain has a serious problem.
fields.byline: Johan Cryuff interviewed by Simon Kuper
fields.body:
When he is not travelling around Europe watching games, he sits in the television room of his Barcelona mansion channel-hopping from match to match. At 53, he still plays quite often.

One recent evening the man voted European Player of the Twentieth Century tried to go cold turkey. With Champions League matches on TV in the other room, and his daughter popping in occasionally to relay scores, he talked at length to The Observer.

Thankfully the topic was football, and Euro 2000 in particular.

Cruyff talked and talked and talked in his own unique language. (One crucial rule: he often uses the word 'you' to refer to himself.) Along the way, he explained how to score in a penalty shoot-out. The moment the interview ended, he dashed back to the television room.

SK Are you looking forward to Euro 2000 - yet another big football tournament, or is the football diet too rich?

JC There's much too much football. So it's important that you start imposing restrictions. I think you have to start with a simple fact: that there are 52 weeks in a year, and that you have to have four weeks holiday, four weeks preparation for the season, and two weeks that you say, 'It's raining,' or 'it's snowing,' or 'it's [pause] Christmas' or, yes, whatever. Well, that leaves 42 weeks, and you can play, say, one and a half games a week. That's, say, 65 games. And then you can give maximum quality, because what's lacking now is quality. The quality is going down because there is too much football.

SK The Champions League is a scandal in that respect, isn't it?

JC Absolutely. Ridiculous. It's much too much. Everything is too much.

SK Is the European Championship as important as it used to be, or has it been devalued by the increase in club football?

JC I think it has to be important. You have to make it very important. Look, I am professional enough to know that money matters, but a national team is a national interest. And you as a club have to cooperate with that. So you don't need eight foreigners in your team.

I think that, just as wingers died out in England, you now have to prevent national teams from dying out. All borders have already gone, or are going, or are half gone. You don't need a passport any more, or a lot less than before. OK. I don't mind that at all. You all have the same currency. Also not a problem at all. But isn't it wonderful that you can see your own national team play? What is there against that?

SK But haven't you become a European? You've lived half your life outside Holland.

JC I am and always will be a Dutchman, for the very simple reason: I have the Dutch mentality. [Laughs.] I don't have a Spanish mentality or a German or an Italian. Just be pleased that we have so many different beautiful mentalities. And go to work with them. That's culture. It's what you take from history.

SK Which players have you particularly enjoyed watching this season?

JC Well, there's several players who have that. I've really enjoyed Luis Figo, I've enjoyed that, that Shevchenko, what's he called, from, eh, Milan. And that, that Veron. Couple of good things. That Salas at first. Yes, of course those are nice things. You've enjoyed that, eh, that Yorke in the beginning.

So of course these are snapshots. But yes, there are some footballers who I simply like. Owen a little less because he has had a lot of injuries.

But those are people of whom you say: 'Hey, well, yes, you watch them.' I think for instance someone who can defend well, if I see Jaap Stam defending, I think that's attractive too. How he does it, and what he does. And yes, mistakes or not, there are nice things in that.

SK I want to ask you about the Dutch team. It's not a Cruyffian side, as they play without wingers, and...

JC No, first of all, responsible for that team is Frank Rijkaard. He has his own way of seeing things. Well, you have to appreciate that. But I've always said that if we play differently from the others we have more chances, because we do have more initiative.

SK Holland's playing style originated with you.

JC It happened midway through the Sixties. I was the second full professional in Holland, in 1964 I think. Think about it: it hasn't existed that long. Piet Keizer was the first, I was the second. Half the players trained in the evenings and the other half during the day. Well, that hadn't happened in England since the Fifties.

And yes, I thought English football with wingers was fantastic. Stanley Matthews and so on. That was gigantic, eh? And at some point, through certain ideas, that changed. And I don't agree with that change. I think the wing is one of the most beautiful positions. People who can play there... it's a delight to see them. If you see someone like Figo you say: 'Guys, that's beautiful.'

SK Figo is a winger after your heart.

JC For instance, yes. Can do everything: can cross, can cut inside, can shoot with his right or left. Yes, he really has everything. And of course there are others. Dennis Bergkamp always played outside-right.

SK Do you think he could do that again?

JC Oh, everyone can do it. Why not? If you have the qualities. And it's the most beautiful position because you can have a great time dribbling, if you position yourself rightly. You're always playing one against one, you can create so much space for your team. Yes, I always loved that spot. I almost always began on a wing.

SK You often went down the left and then...

JC Left, hop. I began from there.

SK What has happened to Bergkamp? In recent years he has become a 'moments footballer' with very few moments.

JC Yes, but that's a consequence of football today. I remember when I was being brought up in the past, they said: 'Hey, forwards aren't allowed to run. Calm down. All your strength for the decisive action.' Nowadays there isn't a person on the pitch who runs as much as a forward. Diving into the gaps, running, pulling, you name it. It's totally different. I prefer the other way.

SK But surely Patrick Kluivert is a hard-working centre-forward, not Bergkamp?

JC Yes, that could be. But I mean, Bergkamp, he could be one of the ones from the past. Like [Marco] Van Basten, Romario. Isn't it a waste if Romario runs himself silly from left to right? He should be somewhere near the penalty area and get everything out of that that he can.

SK So you think it's fine that Bergkamp stands there doing nothing for ages and then...

JC Oh, that depends. But then you have to adjust your style of play. Of course you can also play with two strikers. But then you have to show a high rate of return. Romario stood still, but he has a high rate of return. They have to think about return, you know. But with me a beautiful footballer always has an advantage.

SK So you give Bergkamp the benefit of the doubt, or...

JC Always. But of course he has to show a return. You have to keep us Dutchmen awake or else we go weak. Well, in England they don't do that, so Bergkamp will have moments of weakening. You mustn't see that as a failing. That's just the way we Dutch are.

SK Bergkamp has landed up on the Dutch bench once or twice recently.

JC Yes, the returns weren't there. So many similar players, drawn games. Yes, then you'll have to change.

SK Kluivert has developed terrifically.

JC In part. He did well against Belgium, or against Germany, against Czechoslovakia and so on. It's all drawn matches, of course that's not much cop.

SK But he plays well at Barcelona, doesn't he?

JC Yes, but that's not the Dutch team.

SK No, but...

JC As a striker he has developed well, but I've known Kluivert since he was nine or ten years old [holds his hand a couple of feet above the floor]. So: surprising, surprising, well no.

SK You always saw it in him.

JC Saw him coming, and you saw his development, and of course football nowadays is much more physical, and that suits him perfectly. Well, apart from his physique he has a lot of vision and a reasonable-to- good technique.

SK If you see Holland now, does it make your heart leap?

JC No, not yet, not yet.

SK But I mean, do you watch as a fan? Do you hope Holland will win?

JC Yes, of course. Particularly since all those boys have well, all is exaggerated, but almost all of them made their debuts with me [when Cruyff was manager of Ajax]. JC A Dutchman likes doing something beautifully. In that situation you should just run up, eyes shut, and shoot.

SK Against Brazil at the World Cup, Phillip Cocu and Ronald de Boer missed penalties they took with the inside of the foot.

JC Yes, those are things that can't be done after two hours of football, you don't have an inside any more. Then it's a case of: close down your brain, don't look [mimes blasting a penalty-kick].

SK Did you ever take a crucial penalty?

JC Yes, of course you take a penalty occasionally, because it happens, but we had specialists. I wasn't a specialist. At Ajax it was Gerrit Muhren, at Barcelona there was [Carles] Rexach, and they just stood there with the ball and well, [Ronald] Koeman. Recently Koeman. Well, of the ten penalties eleven went in. So that was never a problem.

SK Holland have just switched from white shorts to black ones, the colour they wore in the Seventies. Do you approve?

JC Yes, no problem. I think it has a certain impact. Orange is a difficult colour. So you have to have a very good orange shirt because it has to emit something.

SK Very bright orange.

JC Yes, has to be very orange. Particularly if it gets sweaty. It mustn't go dead. That's a problem in itself, you know. I played here at Barcelona, they had blue-and-red shirts, and it depends on the material, but when those boys began sweating, you could still see them from the stands, because you were seeing them against the green pitch.

So, the first thing I did when I came here as manager was to find a shirt made of a material (by the way: not that I know anything about materials) that you could say, 'Hey, if someone's sweating, I want to be able to see him.'

Another thing I did at Barcelona: I wanted our second colour to be an orange shirt, aggressive orange. So that if we went somewhere nobody could think: 'Who are those guys?' That's us. And the colour orange is fantastic for that.

For the Dutch team too. Awing the opposition is the best thing there is, isn't it?

SK So if a team like Germany, or Bayern Munich, play in grey

JC No, I don't like that. Rubbish. Barcelona's change kit is grey now. What is that? [Sniffs.] Not colours for me.

SK While Euro 2000 is on, will you be able to walk around in Amsterdam?

JC Yes! I find it pleasant everywhere, never have trouble. Never trouble anywhere.

SK Thank you very much for the interview.

JC OK. I'm going to watch the second half. Real Madrid.

fields.headline: Go for it
fields.standfirst: Late bargains
fields.trailText: Late bargains
fields.body:
Holidays

Cornwall

For a Father's Day treat, and some fresh air, what about a free round of golf at the Lostwithiel Golf and Country Club? Crystal Premier Britain (0870 848 7002) are running the offer throughout June. Two nights' B&B accommodation and golf will be £90 per person on Father's Day weekend.

Montreux

The 34th Montreux Jazz Festival begins 7 July by the shores of Lake Geneva. Jazz is a broad church, but performers at the festival also include BB King, Lou Reed and Deep Purple, which does seem to stretch its definition. Lakes and Mountains Holidays (01329 844 405) have three night breaks throughout the festival at the Hotel de Chailly from £344, including flights.

Bahamas

Discover the World (01737 218 800) have availability on a 10 day swimming with dolphins holiday departing 23 June to North Bimini island, with opportunities to join spotted and bottlenose dolphins in the water on six special four-hour cruises. The holiday costs £1,599 per person, including return flights, seaplane transfers, accommodation and a guide.

France

Every child should be familiar with the adventures of Asterix and Obelix and SeaFrance are offering one free child ticket to the Parc Asterix in Picardy to every adult booking a crossing with SeaFrance (08705 711 711). SeaFrance 24-hour fares start from £54 for a car and up to four passengers.

Mongolia

The Land of the Khans trip to Mongolia from The Imaginative Traveller (020 8742 8612) is more of an adventurous proposition. Two departures on 13 and 14 July coincide with the Naadam festival which celebrates the tribal traditions of archery, wrestling and horse-racing. £1,650 will cover internal travel and accommodation and a guide, but not external flights and the itinerary also includes the Gobi desert.

Flights

Australia

Check on the progress of Australia's Olympic preparations with flights to Sydney or Brisbane from Heathrow for £465. The flights are with All Nippon, through Flightbookers (020 7757 2468), are available until 13 July, with an optional stopover in Osaka.

Cuba

Thomas Cook (0870 752 0066) have flights to Havana with Iberia for £384 from Heathrow (or for £388 from Manchester) until 30 June, with all travel to be completed by 16 July.

fields.headline: Bridging the Nordic divide
fields.standfirst: Dee O'Connell takes a trip over untroubled waters and discovers a brand-new money-saver
fields.trailText: Dee O'Connell takes a trip over untroubled waters and discovers a brand-new money-saver.
fields.body:
Travel bargain-hunters will be able to enjoy two city breaks for the price of one from next month with the opening of the five-mile Öresund bridge linking Sweden and Denmark. From 1 July a visitor to Copenhagen can hop on board a train to Malmö, Sweden's third city, and be there in a mere 35 minutes for just 60 Danish Kroner, or about £5, one way.

Past tensions between the two countries resulted in a reluctance to join forces in promoting tourism to the Öresund region, which takes its name from the body of water separating the Danish capital from the southern Swedish region of Skane. The knock-on effect was that foreign visitors took a short break either in Denmark or Sweden and were not tempted to journey across the border. While exact figures for travel between the two countries are unavailable, they are thought to be low. But the coming of the bridge is expected to increase the number of tourists and holidaymakers making the crossing by three or four-fold.

Travel across the Öresund has always been possible by hydrofoil, but having crossed the bridge by bus last week on a preview journey from Copenhagen to Malmö, the attraction of this new route is obvious. The bridge itself is a beautiful piece of design and the feeling of leaving Denmark and passing the 'Welcome to Sweden' sign inspires a childish desire to stand with one foot in Denmark and the other in Sweden - a sentimental indulgence missing from the choppy hydrofoil ride back to Copenhagen.

The new bridge also provides a direct rail link from Copenhagen's city centre and airport to Malmö, with trains leaving every 20 minutes. Cars will also be able to cross the 7,845-metre (4.7 miles) bridge, but the toll to be charged is still the subject of wrangling between the Swedish and Danish authorities. But there is still good news for bargain-hunters: Go's flights to Copenhagen and Ryanair's new route from Stansted to Malmö will allow great flexibility for travellers from Britain. Those wishing to visit either city can choose the most competitive flight and use the bridge to cross to their final destination.

This ease of passage between the two countries will mean that people taking weekend trips can enjoy the traditional attractions of Copenhagen, such as the Tivoli Gardens, Museum Street and the burgeoning café and shopping scenes, and then go on to explore the Sk ne region of Sweden.

If you're planning a trip to the Öresund region, it's worth remembering that Malmö's Form/Design Centre will hold a large Mies van der Röhe exhibition later in the year, while a Peter Greenaway event is also expected in the city. If your tastes are more of the outdoor kind, there is great golfing and fishing to be enjoyed in Skane.

Danish tourist information: www.visitdenmark.com or 020 7259 5955. Swedish tourist information: www.visit-sweden.com or 020 7870 5600. Bridge info: www.oresundkonsortiert.com.

webTitle: Where King Puffin rules the roost

fields.headline: Where King Puffin rules the roost
fields.standfirst: On Britain's original observatory, off the Pembrokeshire coast,  Alan Road finds 400,000 birds... and very few humans
fields.trailText: On Britain's original observatory, off the Pembrokeshire coast, Alan Road finds 400,000 birds... and very few humans.
fields.body:
Hitchcock might have choreographed the scene of death: it is midnight on a headland at the south-western tip of Skokholm Island, off the coast of Pembrokeshire. Slowly revolving beams from an automatic lighthouse droop like the rotors of a helicopter. The inky drizzle is filled with the wings of incoming sea birds, and from time to time there is a flash of silver as one is trapped for an instant by a relentless beam.

On an escarpment behind us a sinister welcoming party of great black-backed gulls is squawking in anticipation of a winged takeaway. In an effort to avoid such a fate, the Manx shearwaters have evolved the ploy of returning home under cover of darkness after fishing expeditions that might have taken them as far afield as the Bay of Biscay.

Sadly, it is not universally effective, and from time to time the night is riven by a piercing scream as a gull gets lucky in this life-and-death lottery. It is said they can turn the smaller bird inside out with a flick of their strong necks. Morning will reveal the night's tally of shearwaters in a scattering of carcasses over the clifftops.

Though wonderfully aerodynamic in flight, the bird's anatomy is not ideally suited to life on land. Its feet seem set too far back on its body, so it can only scrabble clumsily on its belly towards the subterranean safety of its nest. Shearwaters live in clifftop rabbit burrows, from which they evict the previous tenants each spring on arrival from wintering off the coast of Brazil.

Along with neighbouring Skomer, this island hosts the world's largest known concentration of the species, with almost 200,000 breeding pairs in occupation. Both islands are administered by the Wildlife Trust West Wales, which also runs the Welsh Wildlife Centre on the River Teifi at Cilgerran, near Cardigan. The trust will arrange a five-day package involving visits to all three centres.

Our hosts warned in advance of the vagaries of the Celtic climate in April. In the event, the only protection that proved indispensable was sunblock. Our arrival on the island aboard the ferry Dale Princess had been observed with bored indifference by three portly grey seals lolling in the morning sunshine on rocks near the tiny landing place. On the slipway to greet us is Graham Thompson, the island's knowledgeable warden. When the ferry leaves for the half-hour return trip to Martins Haven, we find ourselves alone with the seals, the birds, Thompson and his handful of staff. Before the advent of the mobile phone, our sense of solitude would have been complete.

The accommodation is comfortable, but basic. Lighting, cooking and refrigeration operate on gas, and the warden's computer is powered by the sun and wind. Drinking water is pumped from a spring, and running water for washing, bathing and showers is the kind of luxury only Sue Lawley could promise on Desert Island Discs . The less than hi-tech privy is only partially compensated for by the quality of bird art painted on its walls by previous occupants.

Presiding over mealtimes in the attractive dining hall is Alice Williams, the busty figurehead of a ship that foundered on the island in 1928. It is said that coal from the wreck kept Ronald and Doris Lockley warm for five years. Ronald had asked her whether, if he could build her a house in a year and a day, she would marry him. He could and she did. They farmed the island, and in the Thirties he established Britain's first bird observatory.

Only weeks after reading the glowing obituaries that appeared on his death in New Zealand at 96, it is moving now to sit in that house he built, and read a signed copy of one of the more than 20 books this early ecologist wrote.

Meals are cooked by Theresa Purcell, the warden's partner, and guests are expected to help with the washing-up. Long before we have finished a delicious dinner of fish pie and baked apple, gulls are gathering noisily on the roofs of farm outbuildings in another scene reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock's Sixties chiller, The Birds. The contents of a bucket filled with the day's left-overs and emptied by a volunteer on a lawn vanish instantly in a flurry of wings and stabbing beaks. 'Our waste-disposal unit,' he says.

The island has no drinks licence, but guests are welcome to bring their own. Now, over a glass of wine it is time for the umpteenth retelling of the tale behind a trio of mysterious gravestones we have observed on the cliffs. They mark the last resting places, says the warden, of three lighthouse keepers murdered by an outraged Chinese cook who awoke one night to discover they had cut off his pigtail during a drunken spree. Sceptics' attention is drawn to the pigtail still hanging above our heads.

Violence is not unfamiliar to the island. Vikings used Skokholm as a springboard for their raids on the Pembrokeshire coast in the tenth century. Its ancient Norse name translates as Wooden Isle. Through the year its treeless landscape is bathed by successive washes of colour, as bluebells are succeeded in turn by red campion and bracken.

In the absence of land-based predators on Skokholm, rabbits introduced centuries ago threaten to undermine the entire island with their burrows. Yet, if they were wiped out, the whole ecology would change.

Vertical cliffs, like great apartment buildings, provide layers of accommodation for various species of birds in separate horizontal colonies. Pecking orders don't come more literally. Noisy kittiwakes occupy the basement ledges. Above them are the razorbills (thugs in dinner jackets, as our guide dubs them). Higher still, guillemots settle for the overcrowded ledges, and puffins sun themselves in their clifftop penthouses.

If the island has an emblem, it is the puffin. This winged comic with the Charlie Chaplin gait looks like a kind of parrot with the colour contrast switch turned low. Like the shearwater, it inhabits clifftop burrows. Its has to flap its economy-size wings frantically to fly, but it can swim underwater like a fish.

Craftily, the neighbouring guillemot lays a pear-shaped egg that is less likely to fall from its precarious lodgings. Three-week-old chicks hurl themselves, kamikaze-fashion, from the ledges into the breakers below and swim away to sea, only to return years later to breed within feet of their birthplaces.

Our party includes a couple of serious birdwatchers, for whom this trip must be a preview of the promised land. They came expecting to see the full range of sea birds, from cormorants to kittiwakes, but are surprised by the bonus of a variety of land birds, such as swallows, skylarks and chiffchaffs. Each night in the library, the warden holds a roll-call of the day's sightings of rarer birds.

It is said that when ornithologists took a Manx shearwater from its breeding site on Skokholm and released it in Massachusetts, the enterprising bird was back with its mate and chick in 12 days. There are recorded instances of human visitors returning to this magical isle year after year with similar dogged loyalty. It is not difficult to see why.

Three nights' full board on Skokholm costs £159 per person (seven nights £259), including ferry and landing fees from the Wildlife Trust West Wales on 01437 765462. The Posthouse Hotel, Dale, (01646 636201) is recommended for overnight stays on the mainland. B&B in a double room costs £48. Information from the Wales Tourist Board (029 20 49990 9)

Slowly revolving beams from an automatic lighthouse droop like the rotors of a helicopter. The inky drizzle is filled with the wings of incoming sea birds, and from time to time there is a flash of silver as one is trapped for an instant by a relentless beam. On an escarpment behind us a sinister welcoming party of great black-backed gulls is squawking in anticipation of a winged takeaway. In an effort to avoid such a fate, the Manx shearwaters have evolved the ploy of returning home under cover of darkness after fishing expeditions that might have taken them as far afield as the Bay of Biscay. Sadly, it is not universally effective, and from time to time the night is riven by a piercing scream as a gull gets lucky in this life-and-death lottery. It is said they can turn the smaller bird inside out with a flick of their strong necks. Morning will reveal the night's tally of shearwaters in a scattering of carcasses over the clifftops. Though wonderfully aerodynamic in flight, the bird's anatomy is not ideally suited to life on land. Its feet seem set too far back on its body, so it can only scrabble clumsily on its belly towards the subterranean safety of its nest. Shearwaters live in clifftop rabbit burrows, from which they evict the previous tenants each spring on arrival from wintering off the coast of Brazil. Along with neighbouring Skomer, this island hosts the world's largest known concentration of the species, with almost 200,000 breeding pairs in occupation. Both islands are administered by the Wildlife Trust West Wales, which also runs the Welsh Wildlife Centre on the River Teifi at Cilgerran, near Cardigan. The trust will arrange a five-day package involving visits to all three centres. Our hosts warned in advance of the vagaries of the Celtic climate in April. In the event, the only protection that proved indispensable was sunblock. Our arrival on the island aboard the ferry Dale Princess had been observed with bored indifference by three portly grey seals lolling in the morning sunshine on rocks near the tiny landing place. On the slipway to greet us is Graham Thompson, the island's knowledgeable warden. When the ferry leaves for the half-hour return trip to Martins Haven, we find ourselves alone with the seals, the birds, Thompson and his handful of staff. Before the advent of the mobile phone, our sense of solitude would have been complete. The accommodation is comfortable, but basic. Lighting, cooking and refrigeration operate on gas, and the warden's computer is powered by the sun and wind. Drinking water is pumped from a spring, and running water for washing, bathing and showers is the kind of luxury only Sue Lawley could promise on Desert Island Discs . fields.headline: 'Ere we go, it's Luis Figo
fields.standfirst: 'England will be strong. Germany are dangerous but this Portugal side can win it'
fields.trailText: 'England will be strong. Germany are dangerous but this Portugal side can win it'
fields.body:
Somewhere in the back of the minds of 352 professional footballers recently arrived in the Low Countries lurks the same fantasy: Rotterdam, 2 July, around 7.55 in the evening local time, and there they are standing tall, breathing deep, the sound of their own national anthem filling the air, about to play the Euro 2000 final.

Luis Figo has thought about this moment. He wants it to be Portugal against Spain. His country - naturally - against the country where he plays his football, who happen to be his tip for the tournament. No guessing the outcome of his imagined dream final. 'We will win,' he announces, although his bravado is diluted by a grinning dose of self mockery. He knows the prospect of Portugal rising above 15 of Europe's finest is a joke in most people's eyes.

For a decade Portugal have been classic underachievers. Figo belongs to a golden generation, an exceptional group crowned the best in Europe at under-17 level and World Champions at under-20. With the inventive Rui Costa and the twinkle-toed Joao Pinto, when they joined up with Vitor Baia, Fernando Couto and Paolo Sousa (who were only a year or so older than the wonderkids) in the senior squad, Portugal expected years of greatness. Instead people have been scratching their heads to work out why they haven't matured as an international force.

Each of them has proof of glittering club careers at home on mantelpieces laden with prizes. As for the national team, well, they didn't even qualify for the last World Cup. Figo is not alone believing the time has come for the golden generation to prove their worth in the red and green. This summer is, according to Sousa, 'the moment of truth.'

They are the most talented squad in Group A when it comes to pure technique and imagination. But they can also be the most over-elaborate, which was their undoing last time around at Euro 96. Coach Humberto Coelho, whose steadying leadership qualities have made Portugal a more compact, disciplined unit, has concentrated on adding toughness to a game plan that depended on trickery.

For the perfect example he needs look no further than his captain, Figo. Those daring, creative raids down Barcelona's right have made him the most hacked down player in La Liga, but, intriguingly, he also commits the most fouls. He seems at ease with his volatile temperament: 'I'm a calm person off the pitch but I'm very aggressive on it. You have to be.' Supporters at the Nou Camp cherish Rivaldo but they love Figo more, because he always gives everything.

Considering he's both an idol and an artist he has very few prima-donna tendencies (save the occasional theatrical dives). With Pep Guardiola absent from the team for much of last season Figo was handed the captaincy but such is his modesty he would only refer to himself as vice-captain. In spite of soaring popularity, responsibility and fame he remains level headed, kind, genuine.

He sometimes goes horse riding or plays golf to relax. He spends time with his Swedish girlfriend, a model, and their year-old daughter. Figo is happy living in Barcelona, and seems contented enough to see out the remaining four years of his contract even through transfer speculation has been rife since manager Louis van Gaal left town.

With a buy-out clause put at up to £31.5 million the Catalans would make a considerable profit on the arch-creator they bought for only £1.5 million from Sporting Lisbon. Back then, in 1995, he was cheap because a move to Serie A collapsed in controversy when he and his agent signed contracts with two different clubs and he was banned from playing in Italy for two years. Just think, at the time Manchester City tried to sneak in when Brian Horton had a vision of this young, little-known Portuguese called Luis Filipe Madeira Caeiro Figo linking up with rising England starlet Garry Flitcroft...

He has always been coveted, since childhood in the 'Os Pastilhas' district of Lisbon, dribbling and tormenting his pals on sandy playgrounds until he was spotted by Sporting, the club his father supported. There would be uproar if Figo was allowed to leave Barcelona now. He is 27 and enjoying those radiant moments when an athlete's levels of energy and experience exist in perfect harmony.

Be it Phil Neville or Gareth Barry, Dennis Wise or Steve McManaman, whoever undertakes the burden of patrolling England's dreaded left side when England make their first foray into Euro 2000 will be hoping upon hope Figo is shunted to the other side and out of harm's way. In a recent warm-up match against Italy he switched flanks and away from his favoured right side. That, for a team as tilted as England, would be a blessing. But not much. Players possessing his bewildering brand of skills are a danger anywhere. Anyway, it would be naive to assume Coelho hasn't spotted England's most exploitable weakness and won't position his most potent weapon accordingly.

Figo believes it will be a close run thing between all the group contenders: 'England practise a more European style of football now,' he says. 'They have very good players who play in some of Europe's greatest teams and they are great going forward. I like Paul Scholes, Alan Shearer and David Beckham, they are all players who could do us harm. They had difficulty in qualifying but will be strong at Euro 2000.

'Germany are in transformation. They are rebuilding and need a bit more time to form a new team but they will still be very dangerous opponents. They practise strong football and with good players like Mehmet Scholl, Lothar Matthaus and Oliver Bierfhoff you can never write them off.

'Romania are the team we know best because they were in our qualifying group. We played them twice so we know each other quite well. Georghe Hagi is a very important member of the team but there are others too, such as Adrian Ilie and Constantin Galca.'

The qualification meetings were tight affairs, a 1-1 draw in Bucharest, while Romania edged it by a single goal in Lisbon. 'We fear all our rivals and it's difficult to know what will happen,' he adds. 'It's a difficult group but Portugal have as good a chance as anyone.'

Is it time for Portugal to come of age? They are confident, having qualified in high-scoring style and enjoyed a 14-match unbeaten run which only recently came to an end in a friendly in Italy. 'In the past we haven't played enough as a team, we've been too individualistic. We tend to play well against strong teams but sometimes underperform against weaker ones,' admits Figo. 'But we can get it right now and we can go all the way at Euro 2000. Portugal can win it. Why not? We have the ability and we have a lot of hope.'

fields.headline: A portrait of the artist
fields.trailText: David Beckham is ready to prove just why he's England's finest midfielder
fields.body:
He is clustered among a group of British sporting heroes, dominating Michael Owen, in Soviet-hero style pose, and next to Gary and Phil Neville, who are looking like the Kray twins of football.

To his right, Gary Lineker seems to sulk, as if annoyed at being consigned to a corner. The eye is drawn to him even though Richard Branson should dominate the room.

Just around the corner in the hall are such luminaries as the Alans, Ayckbourn and Bennett, and Sir Elton John, along with someone he will certainly recognise in Paul Smith. In a room across the corridor, Seamus Heaney, bearing a striking resemblance to Tommy Docherty, looks as if he is holding court. Posh and the girls are in another ante-chamber, laughing (all except Geri), perhaps at Gilbert and George, who strut nearby in all their manhood.

This is the ground floor of the newly extended National Portrait Gallery and a moody black and white study of David Beckham has duly taken its place amid the nation's significant figures since 1990. It is a picture, by Lorenzo Agius, who was also responsible for the street-cred poster of Trainspotting, that does genuinely say much about Beckham, both as professional and person.

The hair is carefully unkempt - as Dolly Parton once said: 'It costs a lot of money to look this cheap' - and just one eye peers through the locks. Beckham himself has said, forlornly in these voracious media shark-tank days: 'All I want to be known as is a great footballer.' There is both a shyness and steeliness in the gaze. The wispy beard and moustache suggest full maturity still to come. The right side of his face is in shadow. We have indeed seen a dark side.

Today, Middle England seems to be passing through. 'He looks better like that than with that awful skinhead cut,' says one handbag to her fellow blue-rinsed day-out companion. You can bet that Beckham's mum, once a hairdresser, has told him as much herself but kids today, eh? It made the bulletins not long ago when it was announced that Beckham would be replacing Lady Thatcher, who was to be kicked upstairs to the 1960-90 section of the gallery.

Actually, he didn't oust her. Any other newly fashionable figure could have been seized upon. It is just that Beckham has become a modern icon for use in headlines, neatly twinned as he is with a celebrity wife. Two for the price of fame of one.

The problem was that of the former Posh and Becks figures, Paul Gascoigne - no sign of his portrait here - shot his bolt and Princess Diana proved mortal. When Gazza recently admitted that he was once sent home from training when in Glasgow with Rangers for being drunk, it merited a paragraph or two. Tell us something we hadn't guessed. A successor from the new showbusiness that is English football was needed. The problem is that Beckham does not really conform to the flawed-genius figure so prevalent in football's, sport's, and life's modern era.

So the boy and his missus buy a Hertfordshire South Fork. So he spends £300 on a haircut that yer average suits-you-sir barber would have done for a fiver. So he drives his Ferrari a bit too fast now and then. So he has the name of the baby he dotes on tattooed on his back, an angel added to watch over Brooklyn. So he likes the odd fashion show and has been a victim of the sarong. And, snigger, snigger, his wife, wearing her mouth on the sleeve of her little Gucci number, has revealed that he has been known to don her underwear. Thongs ain't what they used to be.

He was sent off against Argentina in that World Cup match in France 98, though, wasn't he? And he has reacted angrily to some verbal abuse from the cheap seats hasn't he? The boy can have a bit of a temper on him, as well. Heinous crimes in these black-and-white, tabloid times. The drawback is that he drinks only the odd beer and likes nothing better than a Saturday night in front of Blind Date with Posh and pizza. It is a red-top shame that he genuinely seems head-over-heels in love with Victoria. And when he did have a spat with Sir Alex Ferguson, leading to his being dropped from the Manchester United team to play Leeds after missing training twice in a week, it was all over in a few days.

As frenzied speculation mounted that he was under the thumb of his wife, who was supposedly involved in a battle of wills with Sir Alex Ferguson, Beckham simply swallowed his pride, declared that United had always been his club, having been given it by his father Ted (not that one), and got back to doing what he does best: being a footballer.

And it is that - what a relief - to which the nation turns it lonely eyes for Euro 2000. It is hard to see Kevin Keegan ignoring those wicked, curling crosses, free kicks and corners for England's opening game against Portugal in Eindhoven tomorrow night the way the idiosyncratic Glenn Hoddle did at the start of France 98.

The next few weeks will determine whether that experience, and St Etienne, proved formatively valuable, on the gain-through-pain principle, and whether we concern ourselves with what David Beckham really is about or whether all the peripherals of celebrity/notoriety intrude anew.

This time, Beckham is coming into a tournament refreshed by a holiday rather than stressed out by Manchester United's duel with Arsenal in 1998 and tension at England's training camp. This time, though at 25 he is still two or three years from his peak, he has honed the game and has developed the temperament to make amends for 30 June, 1998. Any repeat of the first of only two red cards in his career and the phone-in lines will hum with more personal name-callers.

It was certainly a key period in the life and career of David Beckham, as he himself has recognised going into the subsequent major championship. 'I know I have a short fuse at times but I don't think what went on against Argentina will happen again,' he insists. 'It has made me stronger mentally.'

'In hindsight, it was an accident waiting to happen,' recalls his team-mate Graeme Le Saux of the episode. 'The whole World Cup and before at La Manga, you could see the frustration in him building up.

'He was away from his girlfriend and coupled with things that were said and which happened it was very difficult for him, although he never showed it, apart from maybe to the Manchester United lads he was close to. He wasn't treated well by Glenn Hoddle and maybe indirectly it contributed.'

After the experience, Sir Alex Ferguson urged Beckham to get back to the people he loved and it is in such an environment that he has since flourished, despite the personal terrace abuse - or, dare one suggest, even perhaps because of it. Stalkers and death threats, both of which Beckham has been subjected to, are quite another matter, however.

Le Saux has also had to endure terrace vilification. 'You hear it but it's at a distance. Sometimes it just doesn't bother you if you are focused,' he says. 'Sometimes it eats at you and maybe that explains why David reacted to it early on. In my opinion it's a sad reflection on some people who watch football.

'We should be looking at someone like David Beckham and saying: "It's great that he's playing football in this country for us and our kids to see." Yes boo him, but why pick on him? It's disgusting. I just think people deserve some sort of respect, especially people who are very good at their job.' This time Kevin Keegan appears to have talked him up and made him feel secure pre-tournament by starting him in all three warm-up games. 'There's never been a player who can cross the ball like him,' says the England manager. 'He's one of a kind, an exceptional talent. He'd be a key player in Brazil's side. No one in the game underestimates his ability.'

And it is that ability, his character having come through a searching examination, which is crucial to England's chances. He still harbours a desire to play in the centre of midfield, to become the No10 that seems to bestow true greatness - emulating the man who beat him to World Player of the Year, Rivaldo.

But though Beckham performed adequately in the role for Manchester United in the European Cup final against Bayern Munich last year as replacement for the suspended Roy Keane, more recently against Brazil he wandered through 30 minutes looking lost, his concerns about his positioning and defensive role undermining his creative function.

It is something Hoddle eventually had in mind for him, during the time before he had second thoughts. 'He sees the furthest pass first,' said the then admiring Hoddle, who no doubt believed the boy embodied something of himself. It is still as the modern wide player, though, that Beckham looks best equipped to serve the national team, utilising the move infield only as variation to disrupt the opposition.

At first sight, he does not seem blessed with great pace, or the dribbling skills to go past defenders, though a weaving goal against Real Madrid this season showed the close control developing in his game. More, his trademark has been manipulation of a football that has been developed as a result of the modern plastic, lacquered balls which swerve and dip as encouraged of manufacturers by the game's excitement-seeking governing bodies.

Perhaps Beckham's boots - silver being the latest trend for the lad who said that he has always taken a pride in his appearance since choosing an extravagant outfit as a pageboy at a family wedding - also have something to do with it. Unusually, as most players prefer worn old favourites, he changes them every few games for a new hand-stitched pair, retaining the ones he has done well in out of superstition.

Le Saux has played against him many times, both for Chelsea and in England training. 'The most important thing is to stop him crossing the ball because his supply is so consistent,' he says - and Andy Cole has described it as 'like Christmas coming every Saturday'. Le Saux adds: 'Manchester United gear themselves up to providing him with the ball in areas where he is dangerous. But it's very difficult to get to him before he has had a touch and set himself for the cross.

'As a full-back, I am always trying to edge myself towards him so that I get there as the ball is arriving. If you get there when he has had his first touch, it is too late because he will whip the ball around your ears. Normally I would leave the wide player and cover for the centre backs but United switch the ball very quickly from right to left, quicker than you can get there.

That came against Colombia, the only free kick converted directly at France 98. He also points up the difference between himself and Ryan Giggs. I recall seeing him in a warm-up against Chelsea once curling one home via the underside of the crossbar. Twenty minutes into the game he repeated it for real. As a boy he scored 101 goals in 115 games for his club, Ridgeway Rovers and first came to United's notice when he won a Bobby Charlton Soccer Skills challenge with record points. 'Shoot at all times if you get a chance,' Sir Bobby told him. So skinny was Beckham, though, that he couldn't make the England Schoolboys team.

Ferguson knows that a one-eyed Beckham, not sidetracked by abuse or involved in feuds and irrelevant issues on the field, is potentially a footballing vision. 'David Beckham is Britain's finest striker of a football not because of a God-given talent but because he practises with a relentless [that word again] application that the vast majority of less gifted players wouldn't contemplate,' Hugh McIlvanney wrote on Ferguson's behalf for his autobiography.

There is, too, an arrogance to Beckham on the pitch. 'The great ones can have that. Cantona did,' Ferguson said once. But it is not evident off the pitch. 'Anyone who says that doesn't really know me,' Beckham has said. Once after giving a press conference, he inquired after the identity of a certain journalist. The man stepped forward to be told by Beckham that, having written a recent piece questioning whether he was getting big for his boots, he should not judge people without knowing them.

That press conference was a vicarious, excruciating experience. It was in La Baule in '98, a few days after he had been left out of England's opening game against Tunisia. One thing it did prove was that his Essex drawl giving the impression of dullness merely covered a brave sincerity at a time when he must have felt bemused at the offhand behaviour of his boyhood hero Hoddle.

Ferguson has also admitted that Beckham's stubbornness has caused him to disagree with his player but that he admires his resolve. 'When the chips are down on the football field, you can bet your life that David Beckham won't be found wanting,' he has said.

In turn, Beckham undoubtedly trusts and respects his manager, even if he can resent the authoritarianism at times. He has spoken of how he came to see that a loan spell to Preston North End that Ferguson arranged five years ago was a valuable learning and motivational experience.

Ferguson has noticed, he added, that Beckham has gone from being a fun-loving boy to a more introverted man in recent years.

It may be just a maturing process but if not, it is a shame if all the vilification and the Becks and Posh, thick and thin, jokes, have subdued him. Why is it that we expect people paid to be articulate with their feet to be so with their mouths?

Let the TV impressionist Alistair MacGowan say it for him. In a brilliant sketch going beyond taking the mickey to affectionate admiration, MacGowan had him sat at dinner with Posh and two critics not dissimilar to Tom Paulin and Germaine Greer, unable to resist trying to impress him and Posh with their erudition and insight.

'The thing I like about art and sport,' said a humble Becks, 'is that they are both about creating, expressing yourself as a human being. If you are not creating, you are just on the sidelines shouting abuse. And at the end of the day, a lot of criticism can be destructive. Look at Gazza. Look at Gary Barlow. I just think we should respect all artists, all creators.'

Just around the corner in the hall are such luminaries as the Alans, Ayckbourn and Bennett, and Sir Elton John, along with someone he will certainly recognise in Paul Smith. In a room across the corridor, Seamus Heaney, bearing a striking resemblance to Tommy Docherty, looks as if he is holding court. Posh and the girls are in another ante-chamber, laughing (all except Geri), perhaps at Gilbert and George, who strut nearby in all their manhood. webTitle: It's the taking part that counts

fields.headline: It's the taking part that counts
fields.trailText: Think football, play football, play football some more - then talk football. What the game means to the people of the Netherlands
fields.body:
When I moved to the Netherlands in October 1976, I was seven years old and had never previously heard of the country. Only later did I realise I had arrived in the middle of a Golden Age.

My father had taken a job in the town of Leiden, and our new house stood in what I now know to be a typical Dutch street. The tiny terraced houses were fronted by huge windows, through which passers-by could peer in to make sure nothing untoward was happening.

On our first Dutch evening, my brother and I ventured on to the street to meet the other children. They greeted us by singing what were probably the only English words they knew: 'Crazy boys, crazy boys!' But over the next few evenings relations improved. Soon we became regulars in the street's daily football match.

I had barely kicked a football before. In London, nobody I knew had. But in Leiden everybody did. The Netherlands was then the best footballing country on earth. In 1974 the Dutch team had reached the final of the World Cup playing a brand of football that tens of millions of people today still remember. 'Total football' the English called it, while the Hispanic countries named the team 'la naranja mecánica', or The Clockwork Orange. From Jacques Tati to Rudolf Nureyev, the world watched entranced.

At the next World Cup, in 1978, Holland reached the final again. Playing against Argentina in Buenos Aires, in a stadium packed with armed soldiers and the generals who then ruled the country, the Dutch went 1-0 down. Then, a lanky flower seller from the north of Holland named Dick Nanninga headed the ball into the confetti-strewn Argentina net. I can still hear the cheer erupting from our neighbouring houses. In the end Argentina won 3-1.

I left the Netherlands in 1986, and I now feel Dutch in one regard only. At Euro 2000 I will be rooting for Oranje (as we call them in Holland). So will millions of other people from Jakarta to Timbuktoo who barely know that the Netherlands is a country as well as a football team. The reason is not merely that the Dutch have an excellent team, although they do: they are the bookmakers' favourites to win this championship.

The important thing is that the Dutch play the beautiful game. In February, after they had humiliated Germany in a friendly, Oliver Kahn, the German goalkeeper, said: 'We have played against the finest that there is in European football. It's madness when you see these perfect footballers.' In the Seventeenth century the Dutch produced great and distinctive painters. Now this overcrowded country of just 16 million people manufactures footballers. Why? At the risk of giving away the secret, I will explain.

Soon after my arrival I discovered that every boy in Holland belonged to a football club. In Leiden, which then had just over 100,000 inhabitants, there were dozens. Some of them fielded twenty senior teams, seven teams of under-eights, and so on. Not to play football was not to exist.

My brother and I joined the Ajax Sportman Combinatie, a club founded in 1892, which had once been one of the best in Holland and still possessed a genuine stand. ASC was no longer any good, but that never deflected me.

As a child I would rise each Saturday at 7am and race to the ground. The gates would still be locked, but my team-mates and I would rattle them until, at last, at about 8am, someone unlocked them. Then we would play on ASC's gravel pitch until our match kicked off. Afterwards we would hang around the ground hoping for a game with another team. Then we would go to someone's house to play football.

When the football was rained off we would race to the ground anyway, where we would be taken to a hall to play indoors, or be shown videos of the 1974 and 1978 World Cups.

Almost all Dutch boys spent their youth much as I did. Of the 14 million people living in Holland in the Seventies, one million played football at clubs like ASC. No other country had a higher proportion of registered footballers. Franz Beckenbauer said he finally understood why Dutch players were so good when he flew over Holland in a helicopter and saw that it consisted chiefly of football grounds.

No wonder we all played. My parents paid ASC about £50 a year, and in return my brother and I were allowed virtually to live at the club. Twice a week we were trained by coaches who had completed long courses for the privilege. One had played professional football. We played on pitches obsessively watered and mowed by the local council. Dutch football, in fact, is a testament to Dutch social democracy.

In England, when two lovers of football meet, the first question is: 'Which club do you support?' In the Netherlands, the question is, 'Which club do you play for?' The Dutch are players first, fans second. I once asked Boudewijn Zenden, who plays for Barcelona and Holland, which club he had supported as a child. None, he said. Nor did he have posters of idols on his walls. Zenden played.

When I returned to England, I met people who professed to love football, watched their team each weekend, but never kicked a ball. I discovered that in England it is hard to get the chance. It is no myth that Margaret Thatcher sold off the school playing-fields. She did. Between 1981 and 1997, an estimated 5,000 playing fields were sold in Britain and turned into houses and supermarkets. There are other problems besides. The Liverpool and District Sunday League has lost more than half its teams in recent years, as councils raise the pitch rent and players get fed up changing in the bushes to play in the mud.

I now live in central London. Within a few miles there are a couple of million people, but they are served by fewer football pitches than are the people of Leiden. No wonder England is not very good at football.

Albert Camus, the late goalkeeper and sometime novelist, said: 'All that I know most surely about morality and the obligations of man, I owe to football.' Well, all that I know most surely about Holland, I owe to football. Playing the game was an education in the country.

We encountered teams from seaside villages where the people were so devoutly Protestant they only played on Saturdays. They lived on brown bread, fish and dairy products, so that even in the under-elevens many of them stood six feet tall. Edwin van der Sar, the giant who is today Holland's goalkeeper, comes from one of those clubs.

In villages further inland, where the local farmers had become millionaires selling flower bulbs to the world, the local teams would draw crowds of several thousand. The best players received such lavish payments under the table from the farmers that many of them refused to turn professional, saying they could not afford to. Each club we played against had a distinctive culture: Protestant or posh, bulb-farming or Dutch West Indian.

The Netherlands, I discovered, is a country of clubs. The Dutch have the time for it. Particularly in the 1970s, vast numbers of people did not work. They had once gone to a doctor complaining of stress or tiredness or minor backache, and had been told to retire and draw 70 per cent of their last salary ad infinitum. Those who still worked did so gently. Even today, virtually every office in Holland is deserted by 5pm. My father usually returned home at lunchtime and spent the afternoon skulking indoors in case a colleague saw him.

When he went outside, my father used his leisure time to play cricket. Most people used it for football. But playing was only one way of passing time at the club. Many Dutchmen think that their real job is chairing their football club, or its materials committee, or coaching the fourteenth team. Club culture in Holland was universal. Ajax Sportman Combinatie was one of the worst clubs in the country, yet it was recognisably related to the best, which also happened to be called Ajax.

When Ajax of Amsterdam was founded, in 1900, its board wrote to my club asking permission to use the name Ajax. We granted it, but said we would review the matter a hundred years later. Ajax agreed. Sadly, by the time 2000 rolled around it turned out that ASC had mislaid Ajax's letter. The Amsterdammers have thus retained their name.

In the 1970s Ajax of Amsterdam was still a neighbourhood club rather like ASC. It just happened to be the best neighbourhood club in the world.

Ajax won three consecutive European Cups between 1971 and 1973, with a team consisting mainly of local boys who would provide the nucleus of the 'naranja mecánica'. Barry Hulshoff, the bearded socialist, then the Ajax centre-back, ran into an old man in a Greek mountain village many years later. 'He took my hands and held them and he cried,' Hulshoff recalls. 'It went on for four or five minutes. I was very embarrassed. I just didn't know what was going on.

Later my translator explained it. He said there was no television in the village, so this old man used to walk for two hours to reach another village to watch Ajax games on television. The man had loved Ajax and now, in front of him, he saw one of the players he used to watch.'

The players whom the Greek had watched came predominantly from Amsterdam-East. Sjaak Swart, the Ajax outside-right, and Piet Keizer, the outside-left, grew up around the corner from each other a short walk from the old Ajax ground. Johan Cruyff, the centre-forward, as a child used to wander up the road to watch the Ajax first team train.

Last December I met Swart in his restaurant above an ice rink, just behind where the old Ajax stadium had stood. 'The other day,' said Swart, 'I walked into the canteen at the new Ajax ground and Johan and Pietje were sitting there. ''There they are again, the great forward-line!'' I shout.

Then they all had a cup of coffee. I can imagine a similar scene at ASC.

So rooted are almost all Dutchmen in club culture that when a star retires, he often instantly finds himself another, lesser club. Swart played nearly 20 years of amateur football after retiring from Ajax. Wim Meutstege, an Ajax player in the late 1970s, later joined ASC. Frank Rijkaard, another Ajax man and the current Oranje manager, plays for the third veterans' eleven of his local club, Abcoude.

Rijkaard, still only 37, said: 'We have a nice team, a team of friends, and for an hour and a half we chase, run, play football. Well, fantastic! And then you've sweated, you've done something, and you go into the canteen and drink a beer and chat about the game. Often you have a nice opponent, have a joke along the way. I have no aspirations to anything more.'

This winter I watched Rijkaard's contemporary, Ruud Gullit, play for the fifth team of an Amsterdam club, AFC. The opponents were the third eleven of a club called OSDO, and there were about 20 spectators.

'By half time Gullit's side were 5-0 down, though they eventually recovered to lose just 5-3. Yet Gullit looked happy. Once or twice he almost scored, but on each occasion he missed the ball entirely. After the game he shook everyone's hand and congratulated the pygmy woman referee. As he walked off the pitch, he exclaimed to no one in particular: 'The second half was better!' We have all left the field on a Saturday afternoon thinking exactly that.

The mere fact that almost everyone in Holland plays football cannot itself explain the country's success. Until the 1970s Dutch football was mediocre. Holland would occasionally lose to Luxembourg, and considered their main rivals to be Belgium.

It was Johan Cruyff who made the Dutch good at football, but it took me a while to realise this. In October 1976, when I first began to ponder these questions, Cruyff was starting to disappear from the scene. He still played for Barcelona, but had already said he would skip the World Cup in Argentina. He retired from football in 1978. Then, discovering that he had lost all his money in a pig-farming venture, he began playing again in the US.

So I got an inkling of who he was only on December 6, 1981, when he returned to Ajax. This little man, whose body had been wrecked by two decades of chain-smoking and being kicked, astounded me most Sundays for the next three years. I remember a penalty-kick he took on December 5, 1982 against Helmond Sport. Instead of shooting in the conventional manner, he passed the ball forward and to his left. There his team-mate Jesper Olsen, running into the penalty area, collected it, and passed it back to Cruyff, who placed the ball in an empty net while the Helmond keeper watched open-mouthed and motionless.

Cruyff shaped all Dutch footballers: Gullit and Rijkaard who played with him, the Dutchmen who will appear at Euro 2000, and all of us at ASC. The main change he unwittingly effected in Leiden was to get us talking about football.

Cruyff was the man who turned Dutch football into a sort of academic debating society. 'Football is a game you play with your head,' he once said.

Other countries do not see it that way. I once asked Gullit to compare the English, the Italians and the Dutch. 'In a Dutch changing room,' he said, 'everyone thinks he knows best. In an Italian changing room everybody probably also thinks he knows best, but nobody dares to tell the manager. And in an English changing room, they just have a laugh.'

I have interviewed British chief executives, Argentine generals and Ukrainian mafiosi, but the most talkative people I know are Dutch footballers. You speak to them for an hour and a half, ask every question you can think of, and when you finally turn off the tape recorder they hold forth for another half hour. Sjaak Swart had told me at the start of the interview that he had no time, but when I finally managed to cut him short he said: 'Another cup of coffee, boy?'

I will be rooting for the Dutch this month. And I know they are the most gifted team in the championship. But I expect them to lose. That is because the Dutch think winning is beside the point.

The master himself has taken to saying that Holland 'really' won the World Cup of 1974, even though they lost in the final. How so? Well, according to Cruyff, everyone still remembers the beautiful football Holland played, and that is a victory more enduring than mucky gauges like final scores.

Guus Hiddink, coach of the Dutch side that reached the semi-finals of the 1998 World Cup playing beautiful football, said later: 'You have to say that our style, our philosophy has impressed the world and that's what I'm proud of.' He added: 'I don't know if I'd have been happy with a World Cup won in a bad way. We couldn't have done that.' No coach of any other country could have said that.

Rijkaard says he wants to turn Dutch players into winners. This summer, he won't be happy if Holland end up with plaudits but no prize. Or so he says. Win or lose, come autumn he will be chasing after the ball at Abcoude again.

fields.bodyText: When I moved to the Netherlands in October 1976, I was seven years old and had never previously heard of the country. Only later did I realise I had arrived in the middle of a Golden Age. My father had taken a job in the town of Leiden, and our new house stood in what I now know to be a typical Dutch street. The tiny terraced houses were fronted by huge windows, through which passers-by could peer in to make sure nothing untoward was happening. On our first Dutch evening, my brother and I ventured on to the street to meet the other children. They greeted us by singing what were probably the only English words they knew: 'Crazy boys, crazy boys!' But over the next few evenings relations improved. Soon we became regulars in the street's daily football match. I had barely kicked a football before. In London, nobody I knew had. But in Leiden everybody did. The Netherlands was then the best footballing country on earth. In 1974 the Dutch team had reached the final of the World Cup playing a brand of football that tens of millions of people today still remember. 'Total football' the English called it, while the Hispanic countries named the team 'la naranja mecánica', or The Clockwork Orange. From Jacques Tati to Rudolf Nureyev, the world watched entranced. At the next World Cup, in 1978, Holland reached the final again. Playing against Argentina in Buenos Aires, in a stadium packed with armed soldiers and the generals who then ruled the country, the Dutch went 1-0 down. Then, a lanky flower seller from the north of Holland named Dick Nanninga headed the ball into the confetti-strewn Argentina net. I can still hear the cheer erupting from our neighbouring houses. In the end Argentina won 3-1. I left the Netherlands in 1986, and I now feel Dutch in one regard only. At Euro 2000 I will be rooting for Oranje (as we call them in Holland). So will millions of other people from Jakarta to Timbuktoo who barely know that the Netherlands is a country as well as a football team. The reason is not merely that the Dutch have an excellent team, although they do: they are the bookmakers' favourites to win this championship. In February, after they had humiliated Germany in a friendly, Oliver Kahn, the German goalkeeper, said: 'We have played against the finest that there is in European football. It's madness when you see these perfect footballers.' In the Seventeenth century the Dutch produced great and distinctive painters. Now this overcrowded country of just 16 million people manufactures footballers. Why? At the risk of giving away the secret, I will explain. Some of them fielded twenty senior teams, seven teams of under-eights, and so on. Not to play football was not to exist. My brother and I joined the Ajax Sportman Combinatie, a club founded in 1892, which had once been one of the best in Holland and still possessed a genuine stand. ASC was no longer any good, but that never deflected me. As a child I would rise each Saturday at 7am and race to the ground. The gates would still be locked, but my team-mates and I would rattle them until, at last, at about 8am, someone unlocked them. Then we would play on ASC's gravel pitch until our match kicked off. When the football was rained off we would race to the ground anyway, where we would be taken to a hall to play indoors, or be shown videos of the 1974 and 1978 World Cups. Almost all Dutch boys spent their youth much as I did. Of the 14 million people living in Holland in the Seventies, one million played football at clubs like ASC. No other country had a higher proportion of registered footballers. Franz Beckenbauer said he finally understood why Dutch players were so good when he flew over Holland in a helicopter and saw that it consisted chiefly of football grounds. No wonder we all played. My parents paid ASC about £50 a year, and in return my brother and I were allowed virtually to live at the club. Twice a week we were trained by coaches who had completed long courses for the privilege. One had played professional football. We played on pitches obsessively watered and mowed by the local council. Dutch football, in fact, is a testament to Dutch social democracy. In England, when two lovers of football meet, the first question is: 'Which club do you support?' In the Netherlands, the question is, 'Which club do you play for?' The Dutch are players first, fans second. I once asked Boudewijn Zenden, who plays for Barcelona and Holland, which club he had supported as a child. None, he said. I discovered that in England it is hard to get the chance. It is no myth that Margaret Thatcher sold off the school playing-fields. She did. The Liverpool and District Sunday League has lost more than half its teams in recent years, as councils raise the pitch rent and players get fed up changing in the bushes to play in the mud. I now live in central London. Within a few miles there are a couple of million people, but they are served by fewer football pitches than are the people of Leiden. No wonder England is not very good at football. Albert Camus, the late goalkeeper and sometime novelist, said: 'All that I know most surely about morality and the obligations of man, I owe to football.' Well, all that I know most surely about Holland, I owe to football. Playing the game was an education in the country. We encountered teams from seaside villages where the people were so devoutly Protestant they only played on Saturdays. They lived on brown bread, fish and dairy products, so that even in the under-elevens many of them stood six feet tall. Edwin van der Sar, the giant who is today Holland's goalkeeper, comes from one of those clubs. In villages further inland, where the local farmers had become millionaires selling flower bulbs to the world, the local teams would draw crowds of several thousand. Each club we played against had a distinctive culture: Protestant or posh, bulb-farming or Dutch West Indian. The Netherlands, I discovered, is a country of clubs. The Dutch have the time for it. Particularly in the 1970s, vast numbers of people did not work. They had once gone to a doctor complaining of stress or tiredness or minor backache, and had been told to retire and draw 70 per cent of their last salary ad infinitum. Those who still worked did so gently. Even today, virtually every office in Holland is deserted by 5pm. 'It went on for four or five minutes. I was very embarrassed. I just didn't know what was going on. Later my translator explained it. fields.headline: Party time for Belgians
fields.standfirst: Carnival night of balloons and Walloons as the locals savour triumph
fields.trailText: Who would have thought that Belgium v Sweden could seem so sexy, for all the liberalism of the two nations' late-night television, which makes Channel 5 look like Nickelodeon?
fields.body:
How football has changed, mostly for the better. It is 15 years last month since 39 Juventus fans, under attack from Liverpool supporters infused with the malign spirit of the Eighties, perished in the crumbling wreck of a Brussels arena. Now the Heysel has been replaced by the all-seated King Baudouin Stadium, a monument to the rebuilding of the game's image for the first European Championships of the new millennium.

There is, now, that which was denied those poor Italian fans; room to breathe. Outside the main entrance stand floral gardens, a little like Aldershot on that walk from the High Street into the Recreation Ground. Inside, only that which should never be seen inside a ground for anyone who recalls Hillsborough - fences - mars the more modern, civilised watching experience. But for some, still the memories haunt. Michel Platini, scorer of the winning penalty for Juve in that meaningless European Cup final and now a Fifa official, will not return even to watch France if they make a semi-final here.

Such sentiments render petty the irritations of bureaucracy and security that accompany a major tournament these days, but still they irk. The opening ceremony was a dream sequence depicting a young boy's desire to become a footballer - Gazza, perhaps, given the blobby white figures walking around in the centre circle - but with tickets going missing and barriers everywhere preventing freedom of movement amid fears of the ongoing blight of hooliganism, it can all seem like a nightmare. The trouble is that football is too damn sexy these days, its administrators struggling to satisfy the public and media nymphomania.

Thankfully when you do survive the Belgian motorways and the thumping pre-match music stops, there is the game itself to remind you of why you suffer it all. And who would have thought that Belgium v Sweden could seem so sexy, for all the liberalism of the two nations' late-night television, which makes Channel 5 look like Nickelodeon?

The problem is that all the weeks of build-up and thrilling TV sight-bites raise expectation of instant gratification. The game is not always like that. There is often thought and manoeuvring that has to go into the outset of a game, a tournament, before the cut and thrust. As the game has become more athletic, so the patience of spectators can seem shortened. Pace is king; in the stands, too. The time between kick-off and the first Mexican wave is decreasing.

Brian Clough once said that it takes only a second to score a goal but it can take 89 minutes of wearing opponents down. For Belgium, looking initially as if they might subside defensively under the Swedish high ball to Kennet Andersson and lacking confidence in their goalkeeper Fillip De Wilde, it took 42 minutes of clinging on before cutting loose to fuel an improving contest.

Their experienced defender Lorenzo Staelens says they have no chance of winning the tournament, that they lack the quality Enzo Scifo and Franky Van Der Elst used to provide, but there is a collective willingness to help each other through their shortcomings, which was touching to witness.

Marc Wilmots is ageing, like several areas of the team, but he remains inspirational at the front of a diamond midfield. Bart Goor, scorer of the first goal, could alert several Premiership managers, while the swift Emile Mpenza, scorer of a sensational second, could alert several in Serie A. He also has an uncanny ability to make Derby County's lumbering Branco Strupar - one of 67 British-based players in the tournament and one of the worst - look reasonable.

De Wilde, confirming the earlier impression of his defence's uncertainty, gifted Sweden a route back into the game, then made amends as Freddie Ljungberg burst through in a crucial moment. It said much about the co-host nation's heart, as did their regaining of the initiative with some lively attacking movement that left Sweden trailing, illustrated in Patrik Andersson's red card. Brave little Belgium indeed, as Churchill once noted.

For all a stung Sweden's revival from two adrift, giving them more the look of the team which took four points off England and won the qualifying group by nine, the Belgians deserved their party, not least because they spared us the 1-1s of the previous three tournaments' opening games (quiz question: name them).

It was a night of balloons and Walloons. You can only hope that England's sinister element catch this mood rather than that of May 1985.

fields.headline: He scores goals...
fields.standfirst: but all Scholes ever wanted was to be half as good as Gazza
fields.trailText: When Romania's assistant coach, Dan Apolzan, watched Brazil play at Wembley last month and described England as a one-man team, the object of his admiration was Paul Scholes.
fields.body:
England being called a one-man team is nothing new, yet it is surprising how many different individuals have put the rest in the shade in the past few years.

It used to be Paul Gascoigne, then it was Alan Shearer, although there were those who thought Teddy Sheringham was the only England player with true footballing intelligence. When Johan Cruyff complimented one individual last year it was David Beckham, whereas when Romania's assistant coach, Dan Apolzan, watched Brazil play at Wembley last month and described England as a one-man team, the object of his admiration was Paul Scholes.

The fact that no-one dismissed Apolzan's view as barmy illustrates the giant strides Scholes has made in a few short years. He is never going to be a player to hog the limelight like Beckham, capture the headlines as Gascoigne did or bang the England drum like Shearer, but in his quiet way he has become indispensable.

Even two years ago he was regarded as a bits and pieces player, a hot and cold midfielder with a knack for scoring useful goals. Now he is the England heartbeat, Kevin Keegan's grenade carrier, and he is also attracting backing to finish Euro 2000 as his side's leading goalscorer.

Just two years ago in France his stated ambition was to 'do half as well as Paul Gascoigne has done'. Even at the time that seemed a somewhat limited goal, given that Gascoigne failed to do half as well as he should have done, but you have to remember that Scholes was 15 when Gazza was alerting an appreciative nation to his apparently limitless potential at Italia 90.

Like Beckham, Scholes grew up with a regard for Gascoigne bordering on hero-worship. Also like Beckham, a young and impressionable Scholes was then granted the privilege of close proximity to the (to him) Godlike Eric Cantona. 'I spent a couple of years watching him in training,' Scholes said. 'I wasn't told to, I just knew he was a great player who could teach me a lot, and he did. I think I learned a lot about when to pass and when to keep hold, to always look for the runs the forward players are making and then try to get up in support. Eric was great at all that.'

If Cantona ever tires of the acting there must surely be room for him as a coach. Talk to any of the generation of 'kids' Manchester United brought through in the Nineties, especially the attacking players like Ryan Giggs, Beckham and Scholes, and they speak of the Frenchman in almost open-mouthed awe. 'It is impossible to overemphasise the effect Eric had on all of us,' Giggs explained. 'I had seen him playing for Leeds without being unduly impressed - I don't mean I didn't rate him but he didn't strike me as exceptional - yet as soon as we were in the same team it was obvious the man was a genius.'

Now Keegan reckons Scholes is the genius, and it is entirely possible that the next generation of England attacking midfielders will have gained inspiration from a home-loving, clean living Oldham Athletic fan who cheerfully admits to being 'completely boring'. A player who now regularly shines against the world's finest but has a special place in his heart for Andy Ritchie, Frankie Bunn and Rick Holden.

'Nothing fazes Paul Scholes,' Glenn Hoddle once said, and it is endearing to discover the famed insouciance is not an act. 'What I've been brought up to believe is that if you have the talent it will come through,' said Scholes. 'Perhaps it helps that I'm used to playing in big games with my club, but I honestly can't say I've been worried by anything so far in my career. If the manager puts me in the team, he obviously thinks I can play. The problem really is when you are left out. As long as you can play, why be afraid of anyone?'
