Also like Beckham, a young and impressionable Scholes was then granted the privilege of close proximity to the (to him) Godlike Eric Cantona. 'I spent a couple of years watching him in training,' Scholes said. 'I wasn't told to, I just knew he was a great player who could teach me a lot, and he did. I think I learned a lot about when to pass and when to keep hold, to always look for the runs the forward players are making and then try to get up in support. Eric was great at all that.' If Cantona ever tires of the acting there must surely be room for him as a coach. Talk to any of the generation of 'kids' Manchester United brought through in the Nineties, especially the attacking players like Ryan Giggs, Beckham and Scholes, and they speak of the Frenchman in almost open-mouthed awe. 'It is impossible to overemphasise the effect Eric had on all of us,' Giggs explained. 'I had seen him playing for Leeds without being unduly impressed - I don't mean I didn't rate him but he didn't strike me as exceptional - yet as soon as we were in the same team it was obvious the man was a genius.' Now Keegan reckons Scholes is the genius, and it is entirely possible that the next generation of England attacking midfielders will have gained inspiration from a home-loving, clean living Oldham Athletic fan who cheerfully admits to being 'completely boring'. A player who now regularly shines against the world's finest but has a special place in his heart for Andy Ritchie, Frankie Bunn and Rick Holden. 'Nothing fazes Paul Scholes,' Glenn Hoddle once said, and it is endearing to discover the famed insouciance is not an act. 'What I've been brought up to believe is that if you have the talent it will come through,' said Scholes. 'Perhaps it helps that I'm used to playing in big games with my club, but I honestly can't say I've been worried by anything so far in my career. If the manager puts me in the team, he obviously thinks I can play. The problem really is when you are left out. As long as you can play, why be afraid of anyone?'

webTitle: Lucky Keegan? Forget it and take France again

fields.headline: Lucky Keegan? Forget it and take France again
fields.standfirst: The form book does not favour England - they will struggle
fields.trailText: Group A is far from intimidating, and a win over Portugal in Eindhoven tomorrow could open up a path all the way to the semi-finals, writes Paul Wilson.
fields.body:
Spend a couple of hours driving around Brussels in the afternoon and you will feel like packing a picnic hamper the next time you venture out on to the M25.

If you are lucky, and you wait long enough, you might get into third gear. If you are really lucky, and you wait even longer, you might spot a poster advertising Euro 2000.

As the first and only directional assistance your road rage correspondent received on arrival at the hub of Europe was a single sticker inconveniently sited in a busy underpass, he is already predicting that Belgium, perhaps miffed by its distinct second-billing status behind Holland, has resolved to be underwhelmed by this tournament.

Early organisational indications appear to be that the size and sophistication of the European Championship have taken one if not both of its host nations by surprise, and, perhaps the safest prediction to make at this stage - apart from the obvious one that England v Germany in Charleroi is not going to pass off quietly - is that Uefa will think long and hard before ever letting two countries share a tournament again.

As the next World Cup in Korea and Japan looks like being an even bigger slap in the face to those old-fashioned creatures who actually want to pay money to watch matches, some sort of decision will shortly have to be made about which way football goes in the 21st century. Pay at the gate or pay-per-view?

Governments and police forces would no doubt prefer it if people stayed at home and watched major tournaments on television, but it is disappointing to find football authorities and tournament hosts apparently pushing the same line.

Compared to say, the Champions League, that other competition which Uefa find no difficulty in organising and promoting, the amount of thought and effort which has gone into Euro 2000 appears from the ground to be minuscule.

If Uefa cannot be bothered to do any better they would be well advised to concentrate on the Champions League and let Fifa go ahead with their plans for a World Cup every two years. If the European Championship is not the main event in Europe, what is the point of it?

But enough complaining. Gripes and dire predictions are not what is required at the start of a tournament, even one kicking off in Belgium. Best to stick to more traditional predictions like who is going to win the forthcoming feast of football, who will score most goals, and how far England will go.

The delicate subject of England's prospects can be left until last, except to note that along with Germany and Italy they have been unimpressive of late. All three are declining forces, and while any could conceivably win the tournament it would be a surprise if they managed it this year.

'It is very unlikely we will be able to retain our title,' Germany's Jens Jeremies has said with the bluntness which has endeared him to a succession of coaches. 'Nothing has changed or improved since we lost to Holland in March. We only went down by a single goal, but maybe it would have been better if we had lost 5-0 and opened everyone's eyes to the situation of the team.'

Germany, like England, may be playing for pride and patriotism in Charleroi on 17 June, but they can only win the tournament by default. There are at least three better sides at Euro 2000, and something unexpected is going to have to happen to all of them to let Kevin Keegan or Erich Ribbech's stretched resources seize the day.

The form teams are clearly France, Spain and Holland. Two of those - France and Holland - are in the same group, the inevitably styled Group of Death which also includes the far from negligible Czech Republic and Denmark. Spain, on the other hand, are in Group C with Norway, Yugoslavia and Slovenia, arguably the easiest of the lot.

All three sides should make it to the quarter-finals, but France and Holland will have encountered each other already and possibly settled a few psychological scores. This ought to favour Spain, notorious tournament underachievers who need all the help they can get, though the reality is that their first game after the group stage is likely to be a quarter-final against Holland or France.

It is not possible for the three form teams to progress to the last four and, though some say the omens are good in a year in which Spain dominated the Champions League, it would take a brave gambler with a short memory to put money on them getting past any team emerging from Group D.

There could be some jockeying for position in the Group of Death to avoid meeting Spain in the quarter-finals, but few other sides in the competition hold any fears for France and Holland. Which of those two will end up overall winner is a tough call. France have pretty much the side which won the World Cup, except they have improved it by discovering a clutch of world-class strikers. Holland are playing at home, and, as Arsenal are very much aware, players like Dennis Bergkamp and Marc Overmars have been saving themselves for this tournament.

But if it turns out to be a France-Holland final anything could happen (how predictable was the 1998 World Cup final?). In Rotterdam one would have to fancy the Dutch, but at this stage of the competition, before any football or falling out has taken place, one would have more confidence in the ability of France to reach the final.

In normal circumstances the Golden Boot award will go to a player whose team reaches the last four, so it is difficult to favour Alan Shearer or Michael Owen, even though the latter is available at a tempting 25-1.

If patriotism demands backing English players, most bookmakers are offering separate odds on the top England goalscorer of the tournament, and with Shearer and Owen poor value at around 2-1, more interesting selections might be Paul Scholes and David Beckham, 7-1 and 20-1 respectively with the Tote. Bear in mind that if England go out around the quarter-finals stage, just two or three goals could be enough.

In the competition overall the bookmakers favour Patrick Kluivert, Raul and Thierry Henry, all reasonable bets at around 8-1. A little shopping around, however, will reveal Nicolas Anelka at an outstanding 16-1. This is a risk, since the Real Madrid striker is unsure of a place in the French starting line-up, but Anelka has goals in him and certainly has the potential to finish top scorer.

Backing Anelka would be a lot easier than backing England, who if anything are an even bigger enigma. It is tempting to conclude that the bookies have it right and that England will either fail to get out of their group or go out at the quarter-finals stage.

Little from their last half-dozen games suggests otherwise. Keegan might be pinning his hopes on a massive improvement once the tournament starts, and England do have a squad experienced enough to put in a performance when it matters, but form should always take precedence over fancy and the sad truth, reinforced by watching teams like France romp through their warm-up against Morocco, is that England have no form at all.

Yet Group A is far from intimidating, and a win over Portugal in Eindhoven tomorrow could open up a path all the way to the semi-finals. Should England manage to win their opening game they would probably qualify, and though they could meet Italy in the quarter-finals, it could just as easily be Belgium or Sweden. England cannot encounter France, Holland or Spain until the semi-finals stage.

Keegan is a lucky manager, they say, and if he gets the breaks, particularly in the first match, his England could make an impact on this tournament even if it is impossible to envisage them going all the way. Impossible for anyone except Keegan, that is.

Yet the form book simply does not favour England. It is all too easy to let Keegan's optimism become infectious, and the manager deserves some sort of reward for putting a brave face on some of the most threadbare performances in recent memory, but based on what we have seen, rather than what we might see, England will struggle to get out of the group.

Predictions: Winners - France; Golden Boot - Nicolas Anelka; England will finish - third in Group A.

fields.headline: Keegan's moment of destiny
fields.standfirst: A bad start against Portugal could see Keegan out in weeks
fields.trailText: The enormous banner draped across the front of the team hotel in Spa reads: 'We are crossing our fingers for England'. It is meant to be encouraging, but international sides on the eve of major tournaments have probably received less equivocal votes of confidence.
fields.body:
The enormous banner draped across the front of the team hotel in Spa reads: 'We are crossing our fingers for England'. It is meant to be encouraging, but international sides on the eve of major tournaments have probably received less equivocal votes of confidence.

There will be quite a few people crossing their fingers for England tomorrow, not least Kevin Keegan, who acknowledges that Holland and France are the form teams in Euro 2000 and accepts his own side will need whatever luck is going.

'I'm not allowed to bet because I am an employee of the FA,' Keegan said with a wry smile at his minder. 'But if I was betting I would go for Holland or France. That's not to say I don't think England have a chance. I think we've got a good chance, and we're a decent price.'

Keegan certainly knows how to keep things light. A German journalist at his major press conference of the week asked in surprise whether England briefings were always conducted with so much knockabout and self-deprecating humour. 'I am not used to this sort of thing with the German managers,' she said. 'This is more like the Muppet Show.'

No-one ever said that of Glenn Hoddle's press conferences so Keegan must be doing something right, though he is acutely aware that the time has arrived for action to back up the banter. He is sick of hearing he has no tournament experience, fed up with fielding negative questions about Alan Shearer, and anxious for the football to start. He needs a win against Portugal not just to simplify England's route to the second stage, but to buy himself some breathing space.

Keegan has never entirely won over his doubters, and popularity will not help him if England make an unconvincing start to this campaign. To put the matter bluntly, a poor result in Eindhoven tomorrow evening could initiate a downward spiral that could see Keegan out of a job within a few weeks.

The manager still insists England can win the competition if they play as well as they can, but admitted last week he has never actually seen them play as well as they can during his time in charge. If the hoped-for improvement fails to materialise in the next fortnight, or if Keegan is charged with not knowing how to get the best out of his team, there would seem little point in continuing the same wait-and-see policy into the next World Cup.

'Every coach has his own methods, and it's fair to say mine are still under scrutiny,' Keegan said. 'But I do get a bit annoyed with people saying I have no tournament experience as a manager. I know that as well as anyone. No-one gets a grounding in this job. Very few people take on the job knowing what international management is all about. You just fly by the seat of your pants.'

Keegan knows one thing though. Tomorrow's game is the big one. Bigger than Germany next week. Because England's performance will dictate what happens in the rest of the tournament. Whether qualification is easy or difficult, whether Keegan has got the team right or whether it needs to be changed, whether the manager gets the nation's backing.

'We haven't even looked at Germany yet, I think it would be wrong to do so,' Keegan said. 'Everything is focused on Portugal at the moment. The million dollar question is how you win your first game without leaving yourself open and jeopardising the points. We certainly want to win it, if we come back with three points we will know exactly what we need to do in the other games, but it's equally important we don't lose.'

The manager is not disclosing what formation he prefers, but it sounds like a risk-free 4-4-2, especially as he claims to have settled on the side for the Portugal game a fortnight ago. That would suggest Denis Wise on the left, rather than Nick Barmby or Steve McManaman, in a line-up similar to the one that started against Brazil except for Tony Adams coming in for Martin Keown.

It is possible Keegan is coming round to the view that three central defenders and wing-backs best utilise England's resources - he played that system at Newcastle after all - but he is unlikely to try anything too surprising in the first game. 'It's very important not to get beat in the first match,' said Shearer, doubtless echoing his manager's view. 'I'm not saying we will be going out for a draw, but a draw wouldn't be a bad result,' the captain added.

'You've got to look at who you are playing,' Keegan said. 'Portugal play with two wide players and just one up front. What I want is first to pass the ball at our pace rather than the opposition's, which is something we didn't manage in Malta last week, and secondly to be playing most of the game in their half. With the players we've got we need that to happen.'

Keegan is also looking to keep the players he has got on the pitch until the end. England's rash of dismissals in qualifying for Euro 2000 has become a fading memory, but competition always brings a competitive edge. 'I want players who have got character and guts, players who are winners, and if you want players like that it is unreasonable to expect them not to pick up bookings from time to time,' he said.

'But I do want to keep 11 men on the pitch, that's the last thing I say to the lads before they go out. Losing a man always makes life difficult. You can compensate to a degree, but it ain't half hard work. It is vitally important we don't put ourselves at such a disadvantage.'

webTitle: Does Beckenbauer know something the rest of us don't?

fields.headline: Does Beckenbauer know something the rest of us don't?
fields.standfirst: Now there's no Klinsmann, no Sammer and much, much worse there is  no team spirit
fields.trailText: Beckenbauer believes Germany can successfully defend the European title they won four years ago at Wembley. 'Not because we've dramatically improved in the last few days. But because there are not really any who're better than us.'
fields.body:
Franz Beckenbauer is Germany's supreme optimist. He strongly fancies Erich Ribbeck's team to beat all comers at Euro 2000.

Beckenbauer believes Germany can successfully defend the European title they won four years ago at Wembley. 'Not because we've dramatically improved in the last few days. But because there are not really any who're better than us.'

The Kaiser has spoken. But there has been no round of applause or nods of support. There are few, if any, in the land of the champions who share his optimism. In fact an almost embarrassing silence has followed the Kaisers' remarks.

Even those as well qualified as Beckenbauer have been much more careful about Euro 2000. Notably Gunter Netzer who played as elegantly for Mönchengladbach and with as much sophistication as Beckenbauer for Bayern Munich in Germany's good old days.

He hopes but does not believe Germany can win it again. 'We've got a problem that no one ever reckoned with. We're short of first-class defensive players. And defence has been the basis of our success in international football to date,' says Netzer.

The Kaiser can fool some of the Germans some of the time. But nowadays too many of them, brought up on the rich diet of success at World as well as European championships, know the real thing from a poor substitute.

And Erich Ribbeck's lot are poor substitutes compared to the teams that Helmut Schön (1972), Jupp Derwall (1980) and Bertie Vogts (1996) guided to victory in Europe. The dearth of young talent coming into the game is one of the main causes for Germany's steadily declining standards. Germany's football bosses reacted too late to the need for better and more widely organised coaching schools and courses to attract young players.

The appeal of other sports, notably tennis through the success of Steffi Graf and Boris Becker, has left football struggling to fill its youth and amateur ranks. The increasing number of foreign professionals in the Bundesliga has not helped make it any easier for the young German athlete to consider a career in the professional game.

But missing from Germany's Euro 2000 squad is something much more important than natural talent. It has got much to do with character and personality. There is no team spirit. And no one is more aware of it and no one is more concerned about it than Markus Babbel.

The Bayern Munich star who will play for Liverpool next season says 'four years ago in England we had people like Klinsmann, Sammer, Helmer and Köpke who could pull a team together. 'Someone like Klinsi or Matthias Sammer gave the team status.

'When they said something about the game, you were convinced, you believed in them,' adds Babbel, an automatic Ribbeck pick. But there is no Klinsmann to inspire Germany this time. And there is no Sammer to guide them if things go horribly wrong, as they sometimes did at Euro 96. 'We only have individuals like Ollie Kahn or Oliver Bierhoff,' says Babbel. 'But they've got problems of their own to worry about without having to bother about the rest of us.

'There's no fire in the team,' admits Babbel. 'Its difficult to find someone who can make us believe in ourselves. Everywhere you go all you hear is that we'll be going home after the first round.'

A 3-2 win against the Czech Republic in a friendly at Nuremberg last Saturday is the only recent result to suggest Germany might survive the first round. After all the Czechs, finalists at Euro 96, were unbeaten in qualifying for Euro 2000.

But closer examination at Nuremberg shows Bierhoff headed an unexpected winner in injury time long after the Czechs had settled for a draw. After all it was only a friendly. And what of Germany's 8-2 win over Leichtenstein last Wednesday night in Freiburg? It took the Germans over an hour to get ahead. And five of their goals came in the last nine minutes when Leichtenstein's amateurs ran out of steam.

'I'm not so optimistic as Beckenbauer,' said the young German fan who followed me out the ground at Freiburg. 'There's no Leichtenstein at Euro 2000.'

Notably Gunter Netzer who played as elegantly for Mönchengladbach and with as much sophistication as Beckenbauer for Bayern Munich in Germany's good old days. He hopes but does not believe Germany can win it again. 'We've got a problem that no one ever reckoned with. We're short of first-class defensive players. And defence has been the basis of our success in international football to date,' says Netzer. The Kaiser can fool some of the Germans some of the time. But nowadays too many of them, brought up on the rich diet of success at World as well as European championships, know the real thing from a poor substitute. And Erich Ribbeck's lot are poor substitutes compared to the teams that Helmut Schön (1972), Jupp Derwall (1980) and Bertie Vogts (1996) guided to victory in Europe. The dearth of young talent coming into the game is one of the main causes for Germany's steadily declining standards. Germany's football bosses reacted too late to the need for better and more widely organised coaching schools and courses to attract young players. The appeal of other sports, notably tennis through the success of Steffi Graf and Boris Becker, has left football struggling to fill its youth and amateur ranks. The increasing number of foreign professionals in the Bundesliga has not helped make it any easier for the young German athlete to consider a career in the professional game. But missing from Germany's Euro 2000 squad is something much more important than natural talent. It has got much to do with character and personality. There is no team spirit. And no one is more aware of it and no one is more concerned about it than Markus Babbel. The Bayern Munich star who will play for Liverpool next season says 'four years ago in England we had people like Klinsmann, Sammer, Helmer and Köpke who could pull a team together. 'Someone like Klinsi or Matthias Sammer gave the team status. 'When they said something about the game, you were convinced, you believed in them,' adds Babbel, an automatic Ribbeck pick. But there is no Klinsmann to inspire Germany this time. And there is no Sammer to guide them if things go horribly wrong, as they sometimes did at Euro 96. 'We only have individuals like Ollie Kahn or Oliver Bierhoff,' says Babbel. 'But they've got problems of their own to worry about without having to bother about the rest of us. 'There's no fire in the team,' admits Babbel. 'Its difficult to find someone who can make us believe in ourselves. Everywhere you go all you hear is that we'll be going home after the first round.' A 3-2 win against the Czech Republic in a friendly at Nuremberg last Saturday is the only recent result to suggest Germany might survive the first round. After all the Czechs, finalists at Euro 96, were unbeaten in qualifying for Euro 2000. But closer examination at Nuremberg shows Bierhoff headed an unexpected winner in injury time long after the Czechs had settled for a draw. After all it was only a friendly. And what of Germany's 8-2 win over Leichtenstein last Wednesday night in Freiburg? It took the Germans over an hour to get ahead. And five of their goals came in the last nine minutes when Leichtenstein's amateurs ran out of steam. 'I'm not so optimistic as Beckenbauer,' said the young German fan who followed me out the ground at Freiburg. 'There's no Leichtenstein at Euro 2000.'

webTitle: Free Trains, but tickets will cost you

fields.headline: Free Trains, but tickets will cost you
fields.trailText: Ignore the watered-down beer, rip-off hotel prices, near certainty of hooliganism and aggressive policing and Euro 2000 is potentially a great football tournament for fans - especially those lucky (or rich) enough to have tickets to see some of the games.
fields.body:
Ignore the watered-down beer, rip-off hotel prices, near certainty of hooliganism and aggressive policing and Euro 2000 is potentially a great football tournament for fans - especially those lucky (or rich) enough to have tickets to see some of the games.

Provided you get into the Low Countries without any problem - the authorities have been refusing entry to English troublemakers on a 1,000-name blacklist - and don't behave idiotically when you're in Belgium and Holland, it could be a memorable experience.

The two host nations' huge pride in staging Euro 2000 means they have put a lot of effort into making it fun for the million or so visitors expected over the next three weeks. For example, public transport in Holland is free on match day to any fan with a ticket, even if you need to cross the country by train to get to the venue. In Belgium too, buses and trains are going to be cheaper for supporters but not free. It's a terrific idea; nothing like this was done at France 98 or Euro 96.

Travelling by car should be straightforward - on the right, not the left, obviously - and, as the co-hosts are both small countries, none of the Euro 2000 venues is more than a few hours' drive away from any other. However, often Dutch and Belgian motorways are only two lanes in each direction, so leave plenty of time for any road trip to a match - especially if it's in clogged-up Brussels. The continentals are also much better at transport than us: there are park-and-ride car parks in both Eindhoven and Charleroi with easy links to the venues. Again, very helpful.

Accommodation could be a problem for English followers, though. 'Eindhoven and Charleroi are both small towns with limited hotel space and are booked solid,' warns Kevin Miles, co-ordinator of the Football Supporters Association's fans embassy at Euro 2000. His advice is to stay somewhere else nearby such as Brussels, which is 45 minutes by train from Charleroi.

The FSA will have 20 volunteers at the tournament, staffing the FSA's round-the-clock fans' hotline (07956 121314), the mobile fans' embassy (a converted Ford Transit van) and the supporters' embassies being run by the local councils in Eindhoven and Charleroi. Anyone with a query or problem, such as a lost passport, should make full use of them.

From its rebellious roots, the FSA is now thoroughly mainstream and respectable. Ford, One to One, the Home Office and the Foreign Office are all backing the series of initiatives being taken during the tournament. These include an online 'virtual fans embassy' in association with a sports website; 100-page guidebooks to all eight Euro 2000 cities; credit card-sized information giving fans useful phone numbers and tips about, for instance, local laws on drugs, and a fanzine for each one of England's three games. All these are free.

There is also the special 'fans radio' service which BBC Radio 5 Live will be running in host cities for as long as England stay in the competition. It will broadcast daily at 10am and 4pm for fans on the scene and broadcast the usual 5 Live output, including live match commentary, the rest of the time.

The eight host towns and cities are all making a big effort to keep fans entertained, especially those without tickets. Big screens for unfortunates who haven't managed to get a ticket may provide an alternative to watching in a pub, although there are fears that there could be trouble in Charleroi at some of the venues where the potentially 50,000-strong army of ticketless England and Germany fans will watch the big game together.

The locals should be friendly. 'Most Dutch and Belgian football followers are big fans of the English game, have a favourite English team and all watch Match of the Day because they get the BBC there,' says Miles. 'They admire English fans for their passion, knowledge and vocal support. So there should be plenty to talk about.'

The local security forces are unlikely to be so friendly. Expect the worst from them, especially in and around the stadiums on match days with dogs, water cannon, truncheons and arrest for the slightest misdemeanour . It could be the most intolerant 'zero tolerance' policy yet seen. Fans with tickets bought on the black market should beware.

The Dutch and Belgian authorities have the right to refuse entry to any ticket-holder if the name on their prized piece of paper doesn't match that in their passport. Tickets for any game can be bought from touting agencies in London, though the prices are very high, especially for England games and those involving Holland. Face value varies from £17-£60 per ticket in the opening stages.

The elation of securing a ticket from a local or tout may quickly turn to despair-and even detention-if you are barred from going in. Mass checking of tickets is unlikely, and it did not happen in France 98 despite a television advertising campaign. But if you're willing to pay the money and take the risk - wear a jacket and tie.

fields.headline: France 3 - 0 Denmark
fields.trailText:
France: Barthez, Lizarazu, Blanc,
Djorkaeff, Deschamps, Desailly, Anelka,
Zidane, Henry, Thuram, Petit.
Subs: Lama, Rame, Candela, Vieira,
Pires, Wiltord, Micoud, Leboeuf,
Karembeu, Trezeguet.
fields.body:
France: Barthez, Lizarazu, Blanc,
Djorkaeff, Deschamps, Desailly, Anelka,
Zidane, Henry, Thuram, Petit.
Subs: Lama, Rame, Candela, Vieira,
Pires, Wiltord, Micoud, Leboeuf,
Karembeu, Trezeguet.

Denmark: Schmeichel, Schjonberg,
Henriksen, Heintze, A. Nielsen,
Gronkjaer, Tomasson, Sand, Colding,
Tofting, Bisgaard.
Subs: Sorensen, Kjaer, Hogh, Helveg,
Jorgensen, Laursen, B. Nielsen,
Goldbaek, Molnar, Beck, Gravesen.

Referee: G Benko (Austria)

1 min The Danes get us away against the World Champions. Gronkjaer forces a corner early on. The Danish feel another was warranted following the cross, but the Austrian ref gives a goal kick.
2 A familiar sight for Newcastle fans - John Dahl Tomasson, through with just Barthez to beat, barely makes the keeper work with a poor shot. A golden opportunity.
4 Anelka breaks at pace but loses possession on the edge of the area.
5 Could be a fun year ahead at Old Trafford. Barthez comes racing out, misses the ball completely but takes out Lauren Blanc instead. Denmark cannot make use of the lose ball with no-one in between the posts.
6 An immense throw from Schmeichel sets the Danes breaking in numbers with the French badly organised. They fail to capitalise, though, Blanc making a late saving interception with Tomasson loitering.
9 Djorkaeff's 30-plus yard shot following a freekick clips the wall but goal kick given.
12 Ebbe Sand brings a good save from Barthez down to his right after the French defence backed off too much.
13 Anelka benefits from iffy linesman's decision, rounds Schmeichel brilliantly, but the angle and number of Danes back put him off and he puts it into the side-netting.
15 Manchester United keepers past and present indulge in a bit of a kicking competition, won by the Dane by about 15 yards.
16 GOAL! France 1 - 0 Denmark Schmeichel blocks Anelka's darting run, but the ball falls to a curiously placed Lauren Blanc (is that total football, then?) who couldn't miss. Schmeichel has a moan. Reassuring, in a way, to see some things don't change.
18 France playing some lovely stuff. This time the flag does come to Denmark's aid as Anelka (again) shapes up to do some more damage.
20 Gronkjaer looks willing down the Danish left. Takes on Thuram and wins a corner which goes behind without troubling the French at all.
24 Schjonberg thwarts Anelka at the near post. The corner is cleared by Schmeichel's fists.
29 A Danish corner comes to nothing, Barthez leaping for the ball extravagently.
31 The Danes try to find a way through the French back line but apparently lack the guile on this occasion at least.
32 Zidane pings one past Schmeichel's left post from about 25 yards. The French are making chances with measurably greater ease than their opponents.
34 Ooof! Heintze gets in Thuram's way as the Frenchman brings the ball out. It takes the Dane a good few seconds to recover from that.
37 Neilsen's 20 yarder doesn't really test Barthez.
39 Anelka robs the Danes who are lazy in taking a throw just inside the French half. He sets Henry off up the left. Despite the attention of two Danish defenders, the Arsenal man still manages to make his way to within sight of the goal and squeeze in a shot which only just goes wide.
44 Thuram steals possession as the Danes dally once again. He puts it right in front of Nicolas Anelka and only Schjonberg's presence of mind stops a clear run on goal. The resulting corner is cleared.
46 Desailly tries to jockey it out down by his left corner, but is too complacent. The throw-in sets up a few moments of Danish pressure which eventually lead to a corner, but the French deal with it easily.
47 Half time: France 1 - 0 Denmark

46 France kick off for the second half with neither team having made any changes.
47 Some fantastic play by Zidane up the left, working it out to Henry who just fails to keep control. Denmark clear.
48 Henry gets back to tackle a dithering Bisgaard. It seems the whole French team is willing to get their hands dirty.
50 Henriksen's cross following a half-cleared Danish corner keeps the pressure on the French goal but the second centre is no better than the first.
52 Dodgy, over-the-top challenge by Petit is not especially malicious but it gets him a ticking off. From the freekick Schjonberg hits one low which Barthez doesn't collect properly, but Tomasson characteristically faffs up the rebound when at least half a chance was on offer. Still, the Danes are in the hunt.
55 More like it from Denmark. They stamp out an attempted French counter-attack and turn it into a shooting chance. Bisgaard's effort is poor and gets a deflection anyway, but it is that kind of work rate which has thus far given France the advantage.
58 Blanc hits an incredible ball 50 yards to Henry's feet but the striker's attempt to clip it round Schmeichel is negligible.
59 Substitution for France, Patrick Viera replacing Youri Djorkaeff.
60 Gronkjaer, now playing up the right, gently whips in a cross but Sand's header is weak.
63 Henry's cross from the left wing inch perfect except for the fact its recipient, Anelka, hardly ever scores with his head. And he doesn't this time, either.
64 GOAL! France 2 - 0 Denmark Wooah! Henry shifts up the field like, well, something off a shiny shovel and is in the area before anyone in a white shirt can get even close. His pace makes it nigh on impossible for Schmeichel to close down the angles as is his want and the Arsenal man simply rolls it into the bottom right hand corner. Breath-taking.
67Anelka threatens to give us an action replay from the right, but he is blocked a little heavily (though legally, says the ref) and Denmark tidy up.
70 By cruel contrast, the Danes have lost what momentum they were building up at the start of the second half. A lumped ball over the top by Colding is pretty uninspiring stuff.
72 Double substitution for Denmark, roping off Bisgaard and Tofting and bringing on Martin Jorgensen and Thomas Gravesen.
76 Henry is off again and only a challenge by Colding on the goal line stops him from pulling it across for one of three waiting blue shirts. Henry looks awesome.
78 The fresh legged Jorgensen has a dip but his shot is woeful, nearly going out for a throw-in.
80 Substitution by Denmark, replacing the ineffective Tomasson with Mikkel Beck.
81 Henry squares a ball into Anelka's stride across the edge of the area but his shot is underhit into Schmeichel's gloves.
82 French substitution, Anelka coming off for Sylvian Wiltord.
83 A Danish freekick ends up at the feet of the scary-looking Schjonberg. His drive across the six-yard box is blocked somewhat masochistically by Lizerazu.
85 Brilliant play in midfield by France. First Wiltord plays a one-two with Deschamps to carry it out, then, having lost the ball, Petit wins it back before Neilsen could control it.
87 Schmeichel does just enough to stop Wiltord from clipping it past him after breaking through the middle. Zidanesticks the rebound on the Moon.
88 A little too much show-boating from Deschamps lets Jorgenesen have a go from 30 yards, but his shot is fielded well by Barthez.
91 Zidane wellies one hard and low right at Schmeichel and it is all he can do to parry it back out.
92 GOAL! France 3 - 0 Denmark Zidane slips it through to Viera who, confronted by Schmeichel, squares it to Wiltord who pushes it in easily. The scorer was certainly in an off-side position when the original ball was played through to Viera, but that would just be nit picking.
93 The ref puts Denmark out of their misery - full time: France 3 - 0 Denmark.

fields.headline: Home, James...
fields.standfirst: Phil Hogan tours Joyce's Dublin ahead of this week's Bloomsday festival to celebrate the author's drunken, bawdy masterpiece, Ulysses. And along the way Joyce's nephew tells him that Ewan McGregor was a little short for the film role of the 6ft writer
fields.trailText: Phil Hogan tours Joyce's Dublin ahead of this week's Bloomsday festival to celebrate the author's drunken, bawdy masterpiece, Ulysses. And along the way Joyce's nephew tells him that Ewan McGregor was a little short for the film role of the 6ft writer
fields.body:
More has been written about James Joyce's masterpiece Ulysses than any other literary work, though I think it's safe to say that hardly anyone has actually read it - in fact, according to my exhaustive research in the office, it seems to boil down to just me and a few other advanced people. Luckily, none of this has stopped millions of visitors turning up in Dublin every year to celebrate 'Bloomsday', held on 16 June - the day on which, in 1904, all the action in Ulysses takes place - and named after Leopold Bloom, one of the book's two main protagonists. The other is Stephen Dedalus, an undisguised Joyce in his early twenties.

During the course of the novel, the pair each make their separate odysseys through the city, getting into minor social scrapes, the middle-aged Bloom musing on lunch, sex and unsavoury bodily functions, the young Stephen thinking about 'the ineluctable modality of the visible' (don't ask me) and other impenetrable bardic matters.

Really, that's all you need to know to have a good Bloomsday, which in recent years has turned into a week-long festival of dressing-up, tours, performances and readings at various sites around Dublin germane to the plot, though mostly it's about zig-zagging fearlessly in the footsteps of our heroes, drinking Guinness, behaving indecorously and staying up too late.

I am here ahead of the official revels to carry out my own important scholarly studies, accompanied by my old chum Jon, who was best man at my wedding and has selflessly agreed to come along and make sure I've got the map the right way up.

Any aficionado's first stop has to be the Martello watchtower out in Sandycove, where Joyce was an unpaying guest. It features in the opening scene of the book in which Stephen is watching 'stately, plump Buck Mulligan' having a shave on the roof. The tower now houses the James Joyce Museum, and attracts visitors from all over the world (Jamie Lee Curtis dropped by the other week), so needless to say our taxi driver has to radio the office to see if anyone has heard of it.

But when we get there it's interesting to see Joyce's guitar and his walking stick and his death mask, and the circular gunrest up the narrow spiral stone staircase with its view of Joyce's 'snotgreen' sea, though it doesn't look particularly green today. But I would defy anyone remotely 'plump' to get up these steps, and indeed it turns out that Oliver Gogarty - the real-life model for Buck Mulligan - was a person of unexceptional girthly dimensions in addition to being a minor poet, surgeon, self-styled wit, weekend aviator and the man who was paying the rent.

We must infer that the reason Joyce made Buck fatter and more unpleasant was because Gogarty fired a gun over his guest's head when he was asleep, which in those days was the way to ask someone to leave. Confusingly, in Ulysses it's somebody else who fires the gun (read entire book for full details). Suffice to say, Joyce left the tower as soon as he could get his trousers on.

Afterwards we take the Dart railway back into town. It's chucking it down now as we struggle across the O'Connell bridge, too preoccupied with having our eyes poked out by people's umbrellas to stand gawping at the spot where Bloom stopped to throw cake crumbs to the seagulls over the Liffey. We nip into the first pub we can find that boasts a completely barking, white-bearded toothless drunk, who keeps Jon busy with the manifold evils of grasping, bloodsucking women, while I peruse my dog-eared copy of Ulysses (well, dog-eared at the beginning, where I restarted it a million times in 1985). 'Are you an engineer?' our new friend suddenly demands, for reasons best known to his social worker. We make our polite escape to the next watering hole (next door, as it happens), where we eat a hearty Irish stew and have a couple of drinks to prepare us for the literary pub crawl due to start upstairs at the Duke, in Duke Street, at 7.30pm.

The sun comes out. Hurray! But then it starts raining again. The tour kicks off with a few auld ballads and an amusing extract from Waiting for Godot performed by a pair of robust actorly types, whose repertoire teems with jokes, stories and readings from Yeats, Oscar Wilde and the like, as we wind in and out of O'Neill's and the Old Stand, back to the Duke and, finally, to Davy Byrne's, a 'moral pub', where Bloom enjoyed a mustardy gorgonzola sandwich and a glass of Burgundy before going off to buy a lewd book.

We have just time to pop into a further 18 establishments around the riotous Temple Bar area before accidentally managing to find our hotel, by now so much cerebrally stimulated that we hardly notice that the rain has stopped.

Next morning we're up early and as eager as you like to spend half the morning at the Writers' Museum with a full- lard fried eggs and black pudding breakfast churning about inside us, though it does take us a while to find the place with our eyes closed and every hammer drill in Dublin thudding through the city (to commemorate our visit, the council has decided to replace all the roads and pavements at the same time). But soon we are wandering around the hushed Georgian rooms with our audio-guides plugged in, leaning reverently forward to inspect the multifarious first editions, forewords, frontispieces and sundry programmes and playbills and pens and pipes, plus Samuel Beckett's typewriter and telephone, which has a red button on it that he could press to stop incoming calls when he wasn't feeling talkative, or perhaps just had a hangover, which is understandable.

There's not much here about Joyce (who of course has a museum to himself), though I do find out that even at the age of 18 he was busy startling influential people with the ripeness of his mind. Ibsen sent him a gushing letter after Joyce had reviewed one of his plays. By the time Ulysses was published in 1922 he had the literary world at his feet peeling him grapes. Eliot agreed it was a masterpiece; Hemingway was an admirer; Faulkner was too awestruck even to speak to him; F. Scott Fitzgerald offered to jump out of the window to demonstrate his veneration (Joyce said it wouldn't be necessary). Only Virginia Woolf said the book was shite (or something like that). We have a half-hour cavity in our busy itinerary, but we find a brilliant corner newsagent's called the Candy Shop, where Jon gets a souvenir Ha'penny Bridge snowstorm for his girlfriend, and I buy a packet of tissues. We spend 20 minutes looking in the window, because it's not everywhere you can buy the Mirror, a large sliced loaf, a Russian army helmet, a leprechaun alarm clock, a 1962 hurling programme, a pocket-sized Life and Times of John F. Kennedy , a snooker cue, a Nottingham Forest scarf and a set of Singaporean stamps without moving from the counter. Obviously the Candy Shop sells Mars bars as well, but as favourite shops go, this one just about pips the one round the corner from our hotel called Why Go Bald!, which has a massive neon sign depicting a smiling man with his hair flashing on and off.

We traipse down to the James Joyce Centre on North Great George's Street, which is preparing for Bloomsday. Here we meet Ken, a grand, tousled white-haired gent who shows us round, telling us stories about Joyce's father who drank away the family fortune, and of Nora Barnacle who eloped with Joyce to Paris on 16 June 1904 (hence the significance of that date). Ken is slightly anxious about the likely success of a new Bloomsday event based on the Nighttown brothel scene, which according to the blurb will be a 'hallucinatory pageant recreating the dementia of the drunken experience of reeling through Edwardian Dublin's red light district', though it sounds like a hit to me.

I'm a bit slow to spot the clues during all this, but it turns out that James Joyce was Ken's uncle! How cool is that? Though, obviously, it was probably less cool when Ken was growing up in the Thirties and Forties and Joyce's name was Beelzebub in polite Dublin circles. I ask if he's seen Nora , the film about Nora Barnacle. He says it was quite good, though he was a bit alarmed when Ewan McGregor turned up before shooting to research the part. 'Very nice chap,' he says, 'but Joyce was a six-footer and Ewan McGregor is...'

'Short?'

'Well, yes, though they did make him look taller.'

The Joyce Centre is not a museum, but there's a library where anyone can come and browse or carry out research, and a bookshop. The door from 7 Eccles Street is here (Bloom's address in the novel - the actual house was demolished); on the top floor is a gallery depicting the real-life Dubliners who appeared in Joyce's fiction under different names; then there's Joyce's furniture from his apartment in Paris; photographs of Joyce and family and his contemporaries.

Ken is very good value, reciting passages from Ulysses and the truly bonkers Finnegan's Wake as we go along, obliging me to scrape the barrel of my memory to show I've been paying attention. 'Ah, that's in... er... what is it, isn't it? "Lestry gonians"? No, wait, the other one,' I say, starting to sound like one of Joyce's least punctuated interior monologues. It can be a difficult book, I say. Ken tells us even Matisse hadn't read it, and he was supposed to be doing the illustrations. 'He assumed it was a version of Homer's Odyssey ,' he says. Which apparently explains why everyone is wearing Grecian sandals.

Jon intervenes with the theory that Ezra Pound went to the same barber as Brendan Behan, or at least one with a very similar sense of humour.

Ken hands us over to his colleague, Lynn, who lends us a green umbrella and takes us for a walk through north inner-city Dublin, where the declining fortunes of the Joyce family were marked by a rapid succession of 14 different addresses, each less wholesome than the one before it. The last and therefore worst was in Fontenoy Street, a two-bedroom single-storey house. Obviously, they've done it up a bit now - and you have to think of it with a family of 11 living there - but I can't help wondering what the present occupiers think about us standing outside their living-room window discussing their house as an example of Edwardian urban squalor. Lynn assures us they don't mind.

Anyway, it was here that Joyce wrote the filthy letters to Nora. I don't know about the filthy letters, so she reads one out. It is quite filthy. 'And there are filthier ones than this,' she says. We go to Eccles Street and look at the hospital that used to be number seven. Here we have to imagine Bloom coming out, crossing to the sunny side ('avoiding the loose cellarflap of Number 75') and up to the corner to buy some offal for breakfast. We hear the famous extract about Bloom liking 'the inner organs of beasts', especially 'grilled mutton kidneys, which gave to his palate a fine tang of faintly scented urine'. Yum.

Entirely by chance we get back to the hotel in time for a short nap and the afternoon highlights of England v Brazil, before heading out to research some more pubs with Joycean credentials. We go to the ancient Brazen Head (where Ulysses promises 'a decent enough do') and the Ormond, where the 'Sirens' chapter was set ('best value in Dublin') and end up propping up the Octagon Bar at the Clarence, an elegant hotel part-owned by U2's Bono, and a hip designer retreat from the 'colourful' slappers'n'lads scene of Temple Bar.

To be honest, it's not until afterwards that I find the Clarence is even mentioned in Ulysses . Maybe they're all in there somewhere. As Bloom says: 'Good puzzle would be cross Dublin without passing a pub'. On the other hand Bloom is not much of a drinker. As every schoolboy knows, 'he never drank no manner of mead which he then put by and anon and full privily he voided the more part in his neighbour's glass and his neighbour nist not of his wile'.

Whatever that means...

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan, London
fields.body:
The Metropolitan, London

Dan Miles, guest relations

Any famous guests?

I can't actually tell you much about the celebrities, but we target the film and music industries so we get a lot of actors and bands, mainly from the States. There are always paparazzi outside, especially during the weekends, but we don't have a problem with them. It's pointless starting a feud, so we say 'hello' but it's not worth giving them any information. They used to offer me incentives, but they know now that I'm not interested. They probably know more about who's staying than I do anyway. I spent four years as a photography student, but I could never do their job.

Any odd requests?

A guy wanted to waterski down the Thames, which I thought was very original. Unfortunately the river police didn't agree.

What about a day out?

The best things about this job are meeting people, and helping guests. If I have someone over from the States it's great to work out an itinerary with them before they arrive via email, and then sit down with them to go through it day by day. Information is so accessible these days that most people know all about the Eye and the Dome. Tate Modern is huge with Americans, and most people think it is amazing. A lot of people also like to go to Portobello Market on Saturday mornings, which they hear about by word of mouth. For trips outside the M25 we can arrange tour guides with private cars. They usually go to places like Eton, Windsor, Oxford or Bath.

What about a night out?

An important part of our job is going out to bars, clubs and restaurants. If you have genuine contacts with those people you can always help each other out. In terms of bars, at the moment everyone wants to go downstairs at Momo's, which is very difficult to arrange. We also send lots of people to Chinawhite. The most popular restaurant has always been The Ivy, which is also very difficult to get into. Nobu is on a par with it, and the food, a sort of Japanese - South American fusion, is incredible. If guests want to go clubbing I recommend Fabric, which always has a great line-up of DJs, and my favourite club, The End, which is just brilliant. There are several great shows currently in London, such as The Graduate, with Kathleen Turner, and Mamma Mia. I went to see The Lion King last night and it was real edge of the seat stuff!

The Metropolitan: 020 7447 1000

The Millennium Eye: 0870 500 0600

The Millennium Dome: 0870 606 2000

Tate Modern: 020 7887 8000

Fabric: 020 7490 0444

Robin Barton

fields.headline: Burmese glaze
fields.standfirst: The British Museum offers a  taste of  a lost world, says  Sue Arnold
fields.trailText: The British Museum offers a taste of a lost world, says Sue Arnold.
fields.body:
When my niece Aye Aye Mo was studying at Mandalay University, she asked me shyly if I would like to see her room. It was on the second floor of the women's accommodation block, windowless with a concrete floor, and just big enough to hold two beds (she shared with a school friend) and two narrow bedside tables. Nothing else. Light and air, from the central courtyard, filtered in through the 3ft gap between the ceiling and the wall that partitioned Aye Aye Mo's room from the corridor.

The only ornament, indeed the only object apart from clothes and furniture that I can remember from the visit, was a deep round lacquer box, about the size of a biscuit tin, with a pointed lid. This was her junk box where she kept make-up, jewellery, wooden hair combs and photographs of her family back in the Shan States.

It was a wonderful box, but then Burmese lacquer work is a wonderful craft. Its crimson, yellow and dark green pattern glowed richly in that sparse little room, reminding me of all the wealth and warmth that was synonymous with Burma and its people in the old days, the good days. Musing on this, I visited the new exhibition of Burmese lacquer at the British Museum, the first exhibition of any kind to come out of Burma since 1850. What makes it so special, apart from the magnificent artefacts, is that it provides a rare glimpse of a country which, through political isolation, has all but disappeared from the world map.

In the days when tourists did visit Burma - and there were never many at the best of times, thanks to the primitive infrastructure, shabby hotels and terrible roads - you could guarantee their souvenirs included something lacquer. Perhaps it was a le phet jar bought from craftsmen in Pagan, or a tiered tiffin carrier from the floating market on Inlay Lake, or a last-minute set of coasters from the Rangoon airport shop.To visit Burma and come back lacquerless was as unthinkable as returning from Spain minus castanets.

Lacquer, as this exhibition beautifully demonstrates, has been used in every facet of Burmese life - domestic, religious, artistic, and ceremonial since the twelfth century at least. At its most basic, it serves as a protective waterproof heat resistant coating for tableware; at its most ornate, painted, polished, gilded and mirrored, it decorates royal thrones and Buddhist shrines. Unique examples of both, together with ancient manuscripts, magnificently carved screens and statuary are all here.

There is a tourist boycott of Burma now, as its brutal military regime keeps the country's elected leader, the Nobel Peace Prize winner Aung Sang Suu Kyi, under house arrest. And last month the ethical travel pressure group, Tourist Concern, and the Burma Campaign UK, launched a boycott of Lonely Planet guides because publisher Tony Wheeler refused to withdraw a book on Burma. If you are heeding Aung Sang Suu Kyi's heartfelt advice to stay away, until democracy is restored, a visit to this small, tranquil, exotic and curiously moving exhibition will serve as a satisfying hors d'oeuvre for the real banquet ahead.

 Visions from the Golden Land: Burma and the Art of Lacquer is at the British Museum until 13 August.

It was on the second floor of the women's accommodation block, windowless with a concrete floor, and just big enough to hold two beds (she shared with a school friend) and two narrow bedside tables. Nothing else. Light and air, from the central courtyard, filtered in through the 3ft gap between the ceiling and the wall that partitioned Aye Aye Mo's room from the corridor. The only ornament, indeed the only object apart from clothes and furniture that I can remember from the visit, was a deep round lacquer box, about the size of a biscuit tin, with a pointed lid. This was her junk box where she kept make-up, jewellery, wooden hair combs and photographs of her family back in the Shan States. It was a wonderful box, but then Burmese lacquer work is a wonderful craft. Its crimson, yellow and dark green pattern glowed richly in that sparse little room, reminding me of all the wealth and warmth that was synonymous with Burma and its people in the old days, the good days. Musing on this, I visited the new exhibition of Burmese lacquer at the British Museum, the first exhibition of any kind to come out of Burma since 1850. What makes it so special, apart from the magnificent artefacts, is that it provides a rare glimpse of a country which, through political isolation, has all but disappeared from the world map. In the days when tourists did visit Burma - and there were never many at the best of times, thanks to the primitive infrastructure, shabby hotels and terrible roads - you could guarantee their souvenirs included something lacquer. Perhaps it was a le phet jar bought from craftsmen in Pagan, or a tiered tiffin carrier from the floating market on Inlay Lake, or a last-minute set of coasters from the Rangoon airport shop.To visit Burma and come back lacquerless was as unthinkable as returning from Spain minus castanets. Lacquer, as this exhibition beautifully demonstrates, has been used in every facet of Burmese life - domestic, religious, artistic, and ceremonial since the twelfth century at least. At its most basic, it serves as a protective waterproof heat resistant coating for tableware; at its most ornate, painted, polished, gilded and mirrored, it decorates royal thrones and Buddhist shrines. Unique examples of both, together with ancient manuscripts, magnificently carved screens and statuary are all here. There is a tourist boycott of Burma now, as its brutal military regime keeps the country's elected leader, the Nobel Peace Prize winner Aung Sang Suu Kyi, under house arrest. And last month the ethical travel pressure group, Tourist Concern, and the Burma Campaign UK, launched a boycott of Lonely Planet guides because publisher Tony Wheeler refused to withdraw a book on Burma. If you are heeding Aung Sang Suu Kyi's heartfelt advice to stay away, until democracy is restored, a visit to this small, tranquil, exotic and curiously moving exhibition will serve as a satisfying hors d'oeuvre for the real banquet ahead.  Visions from the Golden Land: Burma and the Art of Lacquer is at the British Museum until 13 August.

fields.headline: Expo 'is no Dome flop'
fields.standfirst: Travel News
fields.trailText: Travel News.
fields.body:
The Commissioner General of Expo 2000 in Hanover hit back last week at critics who forecast a Millennium-Dome style flop after disappointing visitor figures immediately after the 1 June opening. Mrs Brigit Breuel said she was confident that the fair would meet the 40 million visitors target before its close on 31 October.

The fair's computer system broke down on the first day and the Polish president had to climb on to a roof to avoid being trapped in a lift, an echo of the four-hour queues for the millennium-eve opening of the Dome at Greenwich. The Hanover Expo attracted 360,000 visitors in the first four days, less than half the anticipated 760,000.

The systems problem, now repaired, is blamed for a lack of up-to-date visitor figures - new figures will not be released until early this week - however, organis ers point to previous Expos like Seville in 1992 when only 4.5 per cent of visitors came in the first month and 12 per cent in the second. They maintain that the majority of visitors will come in the final two months.

More than 300 of 500 visitors polled on the opening day said they would return to Hanover for a further visit and 94 per cent said they would recommend the exposition to friends. 'We have been talking to people all the time,' said Mrs Breuel. 'I did not find anyone who didn't like it. There were very many young people which was encouraging.'

The Dome at Greenwich opened to forecasts of 12 million visitors in the year which have since been revised down to seven million. Mrs Breuel insisted the admission price of DM69 (£22) a day would be maintained despite criticism from trade union leaders.

fields.headline: Peek through a virtual keyhole
fields.standfirst: You don't have to leave home to find a new house, says  Alex Garrett  -  just visit one in cyberspace instead.
fields.trailText: The virtual tour is an internet application tailor-made for the business of buying, selling or renting property.
fields.body:
If Tony Blair's Sedgefield constituents want to inspect their MP's old stamping ground at the other end of the country, they have only to pay a quick visit to a website called homedirectory.com. There, by clicking on a 360 degree tour of Islington, they will find themselves in Richmond Crescent, N1, outside the Prime Minister's former house, where they can gaze up the street and zoom in on what was once the leader's drawing room window.

The virtual tour is an internet application tailor-made for the business of buying, selling or renting property. Instead of relying on one carefully selected estate agent's photograph before deciding to visit a house, you can look around each of the main rooms at your leisure, having a good peek at the vendor's knick-knacks in the process. If you are moving to a strange city, you can look for a suitable neighbourhood from hundreds of miles away. And if you're renting a holiday cottage you can check it really is in a 'quiet, rural setting'.

In the US, virtual tours have taken off in a big way for selling property. Potential buyers can view the outside of thousands of properties at sites such as realtor.com and 'move' around up to a dozen different rooms inside. The idea is catching on fast in the UK. Using a system called Ipix, estate agent Winkworths has been offering 360 degree viewing for almost a year now, and has more than 100 properties that can be inspected with a virtual tour at any one time.

Spokeswoman Lindsay Brown says: 'Nearly all our offices now have the equipment, and our people have been trained to take the pictures. We've even had people purchase properties from abroad without having actually visited them.' Winkworth offers the tour as a free service to its clients, but if you want to sell your own house over the internet, you can pay to have the pictures taken. Houseweb.com, a Cambridge-based internet site, has just launched a service that offers a virtual tour as part of an inclusive advertising package on its website for £199. Alternatively, you can pay £150 just to have the virtual tour pictures taken. Mark Desvaux, Houseweb's founder, says: 'The main advantage for buyers is that they can establish quickly whether a property is of interest. From the seller's point of view, it means you don't have to tidy your home for every viewing appointment, and you get fewer time wasters.'

Homedirectory.com has concentrated largely on getting pictures of local neighbourhoods online (mainly of London districts, although it also has virtual tours of, among others, Edinburgh and Swansea). In total, it has more than 2,000 images which can be viewed in 360 degrees. Rupert Connelly, Homedirectory's chief executive, explains: 'It gives people a feel for the neighbourhood they might want to move to.' Homedirectory.com also offers virtual tours of individual homes, but Connelly says the take-up has been slow, possibly because property has been selling fast. He believes it will be more popular in a stagnant market.

Having a virtual tour made is a simple process, involving a photographer visiting your home for about an hour. Each image is a composite of two 180 degree pictures taken with a 'fish-eye' lens, which are digitally joined together. The tour can usually be online within a couple of days. But it may not be right for every property. A pokey little flat could look even more pokey seen in 360 degrees on a computer screen. Simon Agace, chairman of Winkworth, says: 'The system is most useful when you have a property that is out of the ordinary.'

For many homeowners, security is clearly an issue with this system. As one upmarket estate agent put it: 'You have no way of controlling who is looking at these pictures, and the chance to wander through a home full of antiques is a dream come true for criminals.' Houseweb's strategy is to minimise any risk by giving away limited information about the location of each property.

The virtual tour will hardly replace walking down a street and through the front door of a house, but it could save buyers a lot of wasted time being dragged along by estate agents to unsuitable homes. And even if you're not buying, it means plentiful opportunities to peep through other people's keyholes.

webTitle: Will net shopping send you bananas?

fields.headline: Will net shopping send you bananas?
fields.standfirst: Supermarkets are keen to woo online customers. Buit how good are they at lasting relationships? We tested four
fields.trailText: Supermarkets are keen to woo online customers. Buit how good are they at lasting relationships? We tested four.
fields.body:
I have been to the supermarket only once or twice since Christmas but I'm not going hungry. I have reached this happy state - cupboards restocked without my spending a quarter of my weekend battling with queues and shopping trollies - through becoming a subscriber to Sainsbury's home-shopping service. But the internet version of this otherwise excellent service has been a dismal failure for me. I shop by old technology: the telephone.

My early attempts at internet home shopping resulted in frustrating late-night cursing sessions as I grappled with a website that was slow to access. 'What time did you try?' asked a member of Sainsbury's helpline team.
'Thursday evening.'
'There you are then. That's the busy time of the week. Everyone's trying to get on.'
Of course. Silly me. Fancy expecting to use this modern technology to shop at a time that suited me.

When I did get on to the site I found the instructions confusing. I ordered two bananas instead of 2lbs, for example, and quickly concluded that driving to the shop and trudging around the aisles would be easier.

Recently, Sainsbury's wrote to inform me that it had relaunched its internet shopping site so I decided to give it another try. Logging on at home, I was told it would take three to five minutes for the catalogue to download. Just time enough to make a cup of tea. I made the tea, drank it and ironed a shirt - and still nothing had happened.

Maybe there was a glitch in my system. So I logged on at work. Same problem.

'Some customers are experiencing difficulties,' said a member of staff when I complained. She took my details but 24 hours later no one had contacted me.

So it's back to the telephone service for me and a plea to Sainsbury's; please don't assume the internet version is all us devoted home-shoppers need.
Maria Scott

Best thing about Asda was the delivery man

Anyone with a three-year-old child will understand the joy of not having to struggle around the supermarket on a Saturday morning. So when Asda pushed its CD-rom through my letter box, I loaded it straight away.

The process was difficult and involved several calls to Asda's help desk, but finally I was ready to start ordering. Unfortunately even this proved complicated - many basic items, such as sausages, were 'unavailable', the ranges were limited. Asda offers some organic goods but not fruit and veg.

Asda provides two-hour delivery slots, starting at 8am and ending at 10pm, which means you are not tied to the house all day. Delivery is a very reasonable £3.50; orders over £90 are delivered free. But on several occasions my shopping was missing items, and once the delivery failed to arrive at all. Asda phoned the next day to apologise, arrange a new delivery time and offer £10 off the shopping bill, but this is not much help when you have a hungry family to feed and the cupboard is bare. I finally gave up after trying to update prices. It froze the PC every time.

On to Tesco, which also obligingly slipping its CD-rom through the door. Loading up took about an hour - largely because of internet connection problems at my end - but once I was registered the process was very smooth indeed. The site carries an enormous range of products, including basic, premium, free-range and organic options. It also offers newspapers, magazines and books, recipe advice and information about your previous purchases to save you time when you next order.

Ordering didn't take too long - half an hour to order groceries worth £50. I was warned in advance if an item was unavailable and given the opportunity to pick a different size or brand. Even downloading new prices was easy: it took about five minutes.

Tesco also delivers in two-hour time slots starting at 10am and ending at 10pm, and deliveries cost £5.

Tesco is more expensive than Asda, but the service is much smoother. The only thing I regret losing is the Asda delivery man (think Diet Coke)!
Jill Insley

Nothing wrong with my cookies - but where's the fresh veg?

The 79-year-old lady downstairs swears by Iceland. Every Thursday a white van turns up and delivers her weekly groceries. But if Renee had to order her victuals on the net, she'd give up in less than five minutes.

I'm more than 40 years younger than Renee and if I wasn't getting paid to review Iceland's internet home shopping service, I'd have given up and gone down the shops.

NO CD Rom is needed. But the main problem is for those who have a Macintosh computer: Iceland's site runs only on Netscape, not Internet Explorer. It took the hotline staff about 30 minutes to realise this was stopping me registering. Initially they wrongly thought my cookies weren't enabled.

I then found that my version of Netscape wasn't valid. This took another 30 minutes to sort out. The Merseyside-based hotline staff were undeniably friendly and pro-actively helpful. I received four calls before I was safely registered. Once I was on board, the site was easy to navigate. It was easy to order more or less of a particular item and there were many 'two- for-one' offers which I might have avoided if I wasn't getting the whole lot delivered to my door.

But overall, the selection of goods was limited. No fresh veg - it seemed to be all frozen. No spirits. No fizzy mineral water. And no Haagen Dazs ice cream. Organic baby food was available and organic frozen veg aplenty.

Deliveries are in three shifts between 9am and 8pm but it is hard to get a specific time. But my order came in the allotted time period and was well packed with no spillages.

fields.headline: Turkey 1 - 2 Italy
fields.trailText:
Turkey: Recber, Havutcu,
Temizkanoglu, Akyel, Ozalan,
Buruk, Sukur, Yalcin, Korkut,
Ercan, Davala.
Subs: Catkic,Tuncay, Erdem,
Tugay, Ozkoylu,Kaya, Izzet,
Penbe, Derelioglu, Unsal, Akman.
fields.body:
Turkey: Recber, Havutcu,
Temizkanoglu, Akyel, Ozalan,
Buruk, Sukur, Yalcin, Korkut,
Ercan, Davala.
Subs: Catkic,Tuncay, Erdem,
Tugay, Ozkoylu,Kaya, Izzet,
Penbe, Derelioglu, Unsal, Akman.

Italy: Toldo, Maldini, Albertini,
Cannavaro, Conte, Inzaghi,
Pessotto, Nesta, Zambrotta, Fiore,
Totti.
Subs: Abbiati, Antonioli, Ferrara,
Negro, Di Livio, Del Piero, Di Biagio,
Iuliano, Ambrosini, Delvecchio,
Montella.

Referee: Hugh Dallas (Scotland)

1 min Italy's Filippo Inzaghi kicks off the Dutch half of Euro 2000.
2 First Francesco Toldo in sticks for Italy flaps at a Turkish through ball, then Italy break and force a (wasted) corner. It's all go!
3 Second and third corners for Italy, already showing signs of life. Lots of running from the front two, Inzaghi and Totti.
5 Turkey a shambles - Akyel clears for a fourth Italian corner.
6 Totti hits the post but flagged off, anyway. Still, the Azzurri looking more than a little up for this.
8 Davala tidies up, putting it behind for a fifth Italian corner. Comes out to Conte who cuts inside but his cross is hit more in hope than anything. Cleared.
9 Turkey's first corner comes from nothing but ends up in Toldo's gloves without a sniff of a challenge.
11 Italy's midfield, seen by the press as its weakness, is doing okay here. Once again, the ball is recycled and another corner forced. Again, though, the centre is wasted.
13 A seventh Italian corner fizzes across the area. Turkish hearts a-flutter.
14 First direct shot on goal comes from Turkey, funnily enough. Sergen's effort from 18 yards curls wide.
17 Totti's freekick goes right into the wall but it is sent back wide. Inzaghi then glances the follow-up cross wide with his head when power was needed. A soft miss.
19 Totti forces a throw on the left, level with the Turkish penalty area, but it leads to nothing.
22 Turkish freekick won wide on the left after a nice bit of skill from Abdullah. Comes to nothing - nice touch, though.
26 Sergen has a header blocked after nice work freed Turkey down the left. Turkey coming into this now.
27 Jinky, Ginola-esque run from deep by Italy's Fiore, but no movement from the recently dormant Italian attack.
29 Hakan Sukur jumps with Toldo as he tries to collect an over-hit through ball. The keeper just about tidies up, but Sukur's physical presence is definitely a threat.
30 Once again Sukur gets a bit heavy but this time the Scottish ref isn't having any of it.
31 Lively play from the Turks. Slide rule ball sets Sergen away, but blocked for a corner which, guess what, ends up with the keeper.
34 Tayfun penalised halfway inside the Turkish half for over doing the hard stuff. Albertini pings it into the box, but pretty unimaginative use of set piece.
36 Alpay cuts out a Maldini through ball. The Turkish stopper's looking composed.
37 Alpay sorts it out again after Abdullah surrenders posession out on the left.
39 Sukur wins a corner just by being among the Italians at a long throw. Toldo punches the resultant cross well away.
40 Abdullah fouled out on the left. Sukur's marker reads it well and the ball is cleared.
41 Italy break again, winning a corner whch Fiore hits hard and fast. It floats all the way over, via an unwitting Turkish defender's head, but a goal kick is given. Still, they've had plenty of corners in this half and they don't seem to want to do anything with them. Ingrates.
45 Half-time: Turkey 0 - 0 Italy. An odd half drifts to an end, no time added by a referee who was recently immortalised in song by Glaswegian art-rockers, Mogwai.

46 As in the first half, the Italians left waiting out on the retractable Arnhem pitch. Finally, though, the Turks emerge and kick off the second half.
47 A little spurt through the Italian midfield by Sergen ended seemingly by a tap to the ankles, but play waved on.
48 Turkey win a corner, well claimed by Toldo.
49 Sukur once again keeping the Italin back pair busy with his presence alone on the edge of the Italian box, but the ball squirms away to safety.
50 Maldini has to tackle Umit well, but then gets a rollocking from the young Italian keeper for clearing the subsequent throw when the keeper had it covered.
51 Tayfur's low drive smothered comfortably by Toldo.
52 GOAL! Turkey 0 - 1 Italy Inzaghi mis-hits a shot across the goal which is only partly cleared, and Antonio Conte smartly puts the loose ball in the net with an overhead kick on the six-yard line.
54 First Totti then Zambrotta cut in and take aim, the latter's effort flying well wide after Abdullah lazily let his man go on the Italian right.
56 Tayfur just off-target with a chance similar to Conte's goal, volleying wide of Toldo's left post after Italy pondered on a Turkish freekick.
57 Rustu's goal somehow survives as Totti hits the post and then Inzaghi has a tame rebound cleared off the line with the keeper elsewhere.
58 Italy turning the screw. Albertini's lobbed shot deflected behind for a corner which is only just dealt with by the Turkish defence.
60 Maldini less efficient on Umit this time, giving away a freekick out on the right... 61 GOAL! Turkey 1 - 1 Italy ... which proves costly. The Italian defence, and Francesco Toldo in particular, caught by Okan's sneaky late run and header.
61 Substitution for Italy, Mark Iuliano coming on for Gianluca Pessotto.
63 Inzaghi in like a hawk as he is played through. Again, though, his underhit shot is cleared relatively comfortably by Alpay.
65 Zambrotta's turn to put the frighteners on Turkey, Rustu down to his left.
69 GOAL! Turkey 1 - 2 Italy Well-taken penalty by Inzaghi after Ogun harshly adjudged by Dallas to have fouled the Italian forward.
72 Lively run from Okan leads to a Turkish corner. Italy clear, though.
75 Substitutions - Italy bring on Alessandro Del Piero for Fiore, with Tugay Kerimoglu replacing Umit Davala for Turkey a few seconds later.
76 Del Piero announces his arrival with a swerving 30 yard freekick onto the underside of Rustu's bar. His defence finish the job for him, hacking it away.
76 Italy's Conte stretchered off after coming off worst in a midfield challenge.
78 More sloppy defending by Italy ends up with Sergen getting among the back me. Appeals for a penalty as the ball is awkwardly cleared fall on deaf Scottish ears.
