webTitle: Why papers won't say our freedom is in peril

fields.headline: Why papers won't say our freedom is in peril
fields.trailText: The third most regular reason why stories don't appear in newspapers is - predictably - because they are 'damaging to the interests of the news organisation they're working for'. You can tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth: but not in your own backyard.
fields.body:
Welcome to question time on the Freedom Trail. Did you know that the Local Government Bill, now wending its way through Parliament, removes the statutory right of press and public to attend your local council's decision-making meetings? And to get agenda papers in advance? And to inspect the minutes when the decision's taken?

Did you know that the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill, in similar transition, hands MI5 the right to intercept any private email it chooses, without even prior clearance from a judge? Have you thought what that will mean for journalists' sources or for your own privacy?

Did you know that the Freedom of Information Bill is 'grudgingly drafted... back to front: we haven't got anything at the front saying something like the Bill's purpose is to be as open as possible'? And that, pray, is the opinion of Elizabeth France, the first designated commissioner for FoI?

Now, it's possible you might have been able to answer Yes every time. Perhaps you're preparing a university thesis on botched media law - or just a devourer of the Guardian. But, equally, some - and maybe all - of this will be news to you.

Why isn't your paper keeping you abreast of such unpleasing events? Why (as the sainted Harry Evans, former editor of the Sunday Times, told the Society of Editors recently) does the press fight its battles so feebly? 'If we don't make a stand to maintain the freedoms of a half-free press, we shall be back to some of the worst periods of repression,' he said.

Here - not much for anyone's comfort - is one big reason why. The struggle against censorship keeps falling victim to self-censorship. And if that sounds bizarre, look at what journalists mean when they talk about self-censorship.

British newspaper and broadcasting editors and reporters are not, by and large, an introspective lot. But, happily, American journalism and foundation funding can supply all the sociologically-honed introspection we could possibly need. The Columbia Journalism Review - along with the Pew Research centre - has just polled 300 leading professionals across the States on the reasons why stories they think should be covered aren't covered at all.

The third most regular reason why stories don't appear is - predictably - because they are 'damaging to the interests of the news organisation they're working for'. You can tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth: but not in your own backyard.

The second reason - cited by 43 per cent of national print men and 29 per cent of broadcasters - is that writing a particular story will expose you 'to ridicule by other journalists'. In short, don't break away from the pack. Conform: shape up, go with the gang. Or you'll be buying your own drinks next week. Some cynics may think that an everyday story of Westminster lobby folk.

But the biggest reason why stories that the people involved think we need to know about seldom see the light of day, is something still more mundane. It's because they are 'too complicated'.

Fully 62 per cent of the journalists polled thought, first hand, that 'too complex' stories which had considerable 'public interest' hit the spike or the cutting room floor because they were hard to tell or absorb. Eighty-four per cent said the same about stories which were 'important, but dull'. This is not dumbing down: it is dumbing out.

So: who wants to pick away at the intricacies of the Local Government Bill, apart from a few devoted local editors determined to find out what's going on? Who cares about email privacy until some editor finds he's got weevils in his own mail box? Who cares about the Freedom of Information Bill, clause by clause?

It's all a migraine of complexity, a slaughterer of attention spans. Let's find something simpler.

Here, on reflection, is the ultimate irony. Big corporations employ large, expert teams to hone the news they think that papers and TV stations ought to carry. News management is a buoyant New Labour growth industry. Yet the people who actually manage the news don't run the stories that affect them and their audiences most immediately because (implicitly) they deem them boring.

Any generalisation like this, of course, comes trailing honorable exceptions: reporters such as Nick Cohen, Richard Norton-Taylor, and Andrew Pierce among many others, editors around the land who see the point. But Harry Evans is still right to draw parallels with his own crusade long ago for the victims of thalidomide. That was protracted, expensive, difficult, complicated - and the rest of Fleet Street left it too feebly to the Sunday Times.

Is there a case for the defence? Naturally. Editors are paid to guess what their readers want in a highly competitive trade. Is 'self-censorship', in this quivering American definition, any more than the necessity of choice?

And anyway, everybody knows - or hopes they know - that nasty media law in this country tends to get dropped when the heavyweight barons of our business call on Mr Straw or Mr Blair in private at the eleventh hour. Realpolitik.

But the trouble with that isn't just the difference between early warning and late bailing: it is that, as a process, it's exactly what the row about the Local Government Bill is all about. It leaves the reader as citizen in the cold, beyond a closed door: bereft of the questions, never mind the answers.

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: Ratcatcher | Time Regained | Deep Blue Sea | Mifune Comedy Classics
fields.trailText: Ratcatcher | Time Regained | Deep Blue Sea | Mifune Comedy Classics
fields.body:
Ratcatcher
(1999, 15, Fox-Pathé, VHS/rental)

Scottish film-maker Lynne Ramsey followed up her prize-winning shorts of Glasgow working-class life at the 1996 and 1998 Cannes festivals by being invited to show her first feature there. The setting is a rundown housing estate in the Seventies, the hero a withdrawn 12-year-old lad who accidentally kills another little boy in a polluted canal. This bleak, truthful movie of stunted lives and shattered hopes takes its confident place alongside other studies of lonely childhoods - Kes and My Life as a Dog , the semi-autobiographical trilogies of Bill Douglas and Terence Davies.

Time Regained
(1999, 18, Artificial Eye, VHS/DVD, retail/rental)

Raul Ruiz's magnificent movie, its basic narrative drawn from the final volume of A la recherche du temps perdu , encompasses the whole sequence in a dazzling kaleidoscopic film that captures a world, an era, and plays off Proust the writer against Proust the participant. Marcello Mazzarella, a dead ringer for Proust, leads a cast that includes the cream of French actors abetted by John Malkovich as the Baron de Charlus.

Deep Blue Sea
(1999, 15, Warner, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

Finnish action director Renny Harlin is a stranger to subtlety, but in this cross between Jaws and The Poseidon Adventure he has us gripping the arms of our chairs for 100 minutes. The setting is an isolated, overturned floating laboratory, the enemy a pack of malevolent super-sharks, their assorted potential victims include Samuel L. Jackson, Saffron Burrows and LL Cool J (who has the line 'Brothers never make it out of situations like this. Never!'). The DVD has a commentary by the director and stars, deleted sequences and a making-of documentary.

Mifune
(1999, 15, Alliance Atlantis, VHS, Retail/Rental)

Writer-director Soren Kragh-Jacobsen's bitter comedy is the third film from the Danish Dogme 95 group which is committed to working on location without make-up, artificial lighting, post-synch sound etc. Like the first Dogme pictures, Festen and The Idiots, it is evenhandedly misanthrophic in telling the tale of a successful businessman who has concealed his past from his wife's wealthy family. All is exposed when he is drawn back to his late father's rundown farm to care for a mentally retarded brother. The title refers to a game the brothers play in which the sane one impersonates Toshiro Mifune in The Seven Samurai .

Comedy Classics
(U, Warner Home Video, VHS/Retail)

A mixed batch of nine monochrome movies, available at £10 for two until 31 July. The highlights are four of the Marx Brothers' five MGM pictures, A Night at the Opera, A Day at the Races, At The Circus and the disappointing The Big Store . The other five are Laurel and Hardy features, all with inspired moments, though only Bonnie Scotland (1935), in which Stan and Ollie end up in the Indian Army, is some sort of classic. The others are Nothing But Trouble, Air Raid Wardens, Hollywood Party and The Devil's Brother .

fields.headline: La vie en rosé
fields.standfirst: After Mateus and Anjou, a new generation of producers is proving there's still life in pink wines
fields.trailText: After Mateus and Anjou, a new generation of producers is proving there's still life in pink wines
fields.body:
I have a confession to make. What I'm about to tell you would be considered shameful in some circles, like owning an Engelbert Humperdinck boxed set. But here goes: I like rosé wines. Before I get drummed out of the International Federation of Cork Dorks, perhaps I should explain. I might not drink them on a daily, or even monthly, basis, but there are times when nothing else tastes quite as good. If the summer ever gets started, you'll know what I mean. Good rosés combine the fragrance and freshness of a white with the structure of a lighter red.

The amusing Bluffer's Guide to Wine (Ravette Publishing, £2.99) dismisses pink wines as an irrelevance. Most supermarket buyers feel the same way: 'They're a blip in the summer,' one told me with all the enthusiasm of a career gravedigger. 'If we didn't stock any, it wouldn't be the end of the world. Nobody is very interested.'

Until very recently, I was a pinkophobe too. The stuff on the market from Anjou, Portugal and the south of France was pallid, boring or cloyingly sweet. So what's changed? Two things, in my view. The first is that producers have started to take pink wines more seriously, giving them as much attention as their reds and whites, rather than treating them as frivolous sidelines destined for the nearest ice bucket or posing pouch. It's taken a long time, but rosés have finally come over all respectable. They're even recognised as great food wines.

The second change - this is something of a paradox - is the demand for richer, more flavoursome reds. One way of achieving this is what the French call a saignée , or bleeding. This may sound like a medieval practice achieved with the application of leeches and a shot of eau de vie, but it's a way of concentrating a vat of red wine by running off some of the juice. The result is an increased ratio of skins (and therefore tannin and colour) to juice pre-fermentation.

There are other factors, too. Good rosés are made from decent grapes like Syrah, Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Malbec these days, not from second-tier varieties that self-respecting red-wine drinkers avoid. And then there's the technology. Just as white wines have benefited from the introduction of temperature control, so modern rosés are crisper and livelier than the stuff we drank 20 years ago.

Are they due for a revival? My hunch is that, in common with German Riesling and sherry, decent rosé is an enthusiasm confined to wine hacks. Mind you, people used to say that about Australian wines 15 years ago, and look what happened to them. While we're at it, perhaps it's time for an Engelbert Humperdinck revival.

1999 Arcadia Veronese Rosato (£3.69, Safeway). A Valpolicella-like rosé made from Corvina and Molinara grapes. The wine is light and delicate, with only 11.5 per cent alcohol, but it's still got attractive flavours of cherry and plum. Ideal as an apéritif style or for a hot afternoon in the sun.

1999 Tesco Seriously Fruity Rosé, La Agricola (£4.99). Silly name - can wine be dumbed down any further? - but this Argentine blend of mainly Syrah with a little Bondarda from the excellent La Agricola winery is soft, ripe and well-made, with notes of tea leaf and strawberry and surprisingly well-integrated acidity for a warm-climate rosé.

Silly name - can wine be dumbed down any further? - but this Argentine blend of mainly Syrah with a little Bondarda from the excellent La Agricola winery is soft, ripe and well-made, with notes of tea leaf and strawberry and surprisingly well-integrated acidity for a warm-climate rosé.

fields.headline: World wine web
fields.trailText: 1999 Pouilly-Fumé, Cuvée Pierre Louis, Domaine Landrat-Guyollot
fields.body:
What's the bottle? 1999 Pouilly-Fumé, Cuvée Pierre Louis, Domaine Landrat-Guyollot

Price and stockist? £7.99 from Sainsbury's

What's interesting about the wine? If you're just starting to take an interest in wine, it can be difficult to remember the difference between Pouilly-Fumé and Pouilly-Fuissé, especially if you've had a few sherbets. Pulling the cork should make things a lot easier. Fuissé is made from Chardonnay and is a white Burgundy, while Fumé is a Loire Valley Sauvignon Blanc. In theory, the wines from this famous appellation should display a smoky, gun flint character, which sets them apart from neighbouring Sancerre, but all too often the two are interchangeable. This example from a small family domaine isn't particularly smoky, but it does have the crisp intensity I expect from good Pouilly-Fumé.

What does the wine smell and taste like? On the nose, this could only be Sauvignon Blanc. It's fresh and pure, with pungent, youthful aromas of grass and elderflower. On the palate, the wine is crisp, pointy and well-defined, with a creamy undertone and very good concentration. As well as good fruit, the wine has pronounced acidity, giving it freshness and a lingering zip.

What does it go with? Fish - sea bass, monkfish or salmon - and creamy sauces.

Serving temperature? 10 C or lower.

Will it keep? Yes, but most Loire Sauvignon Blancs are best drunk within two years of harvest.

What are we tasting next? 1996 Bouvier Beerenauslese, Münzenrieder (£5.95 per 50cl, Waitrose or from Waitrose Direct on 0800 188881)

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's strawberry tart recipe
fields.standfirst: Strawberries are best balanced on a meltingly thin crust and laden with something creamy
fields.trailText: Strawberries are best balanced on a meltingly thin crust and laden with something creamy
fields.body:
The brash, loud red of the strawberry is a wake-up call for the start of the scarlet-fruit season - those 12 weeks of the year when tiny red fruit comes at us nonstop, from the crisp-fleshed early cherries to the velvety late-season raspberries. The cheap hooker of the fruit world it may be, but the strawberry never fails to get my attention, and once June is upon us, it is not long before I fall for the vulgar delights of a strawberry tart.

Strawberries, cream and crisp pastry is a once-a-year treat in my house. It may come in the form of a tiny shortcrust tartlet filled with a mixture of cream cheese and cream, piled high with sliced fruit, or a flaky concoction of puff pastry, wobbly custard and icing sugar. Last year, I made wafer-thin shortcakes and sandwiched them with thick yogurt and the ubiquitous Elsanta strawberries. Before that, I had a brief passion for thick American strawberry shortcake - albeit the tombstone of the strawberry-tart world.

Perhaps the most glamourous are the tarts the size of a wheel that you see in Parisian pastry shops, filled with crème ptissière, their huge berries imprisoned in glossy redcurrant glaze. I am not fond of sticky jam coverings on fruit tarts, but I do like the thick custard filling - especially as it is such a fag to make at home.

The good thing about making such things in your own kitchen is that you can experiment with recipes for the more fragile pastry that would probably come to grief in the commercial world. No shop assistant to lift the delicate crust from window to cardboard box, and no journey home perilously perched on someone's lap in a warm car. At home, we can roll out pastry as light as we dare, as it only needs to make the short trip from plate to lips.

The perfect strawberry tart is a finely judged assembly of crumbling pastry, luscious fruit and deep, creamy filling. It must be fragile. So much so that you can barely pick it up. The pastry should break between your fingers. It need not always be filled with the traditional pastry cream made from eggs, milk and sugar; it could be something less sweet and with a bit of a tang to it, such as double cream mixed with fromage frais or yogurt. As I said, I don't go a bundle on those bright, jammy glazes so favoured by pastry chefs, so I use a fine dusting of icing sugar. The choice is yours, I guess.

If our once-a-year orgy of berries and cream is to be memorable, then the pastry must be more interesting than an old-fashioned shortcrust. Maybe try a nut crust for a fruit tart - that is, pastry to which you have added ground hazelnuts or almonds? Nuts of any sort have an affinity with berries (and with stone fruits, such as peaches and apricots), and help to make the pastry even more crumbly. I sometimes add a few chopped pistachios to my strawberries, too.

The idea is to provide a pastry that does little more than support the fruit - it should, I think, be so thin and crisp as to be almost invisible. The bonus here is that pastry such as this barely lasts five minutes when filled with fruit and laden with cream. So you have no choice but to wolf it almost as soon as it is made.

The classical filling for any red-fruit tart is crème ptissière, that thick, creamy yellow custard thickened with a little flour. I do like this, even though it is a bore to make. It would, of course, be easy to fill your pastry with nothing more than a giant blob of whipped cream, but I find this overwhelms the berries, like a newborn baby in a king-size bed. Smarten it up with a half-quantity of mascarpone or crème frache, and you have something with an edge to it that will flatter rather than smother the fruit.

Perhaps the cutest little tart of all is one made with wild strawberries - fraises de bois. When I finally get round to getting the garden done, a patch of these tiny, heavily seeded berries will be one of the first things to go in. Not that I have ever cooked with them; they tend not to make it as far as the kitchen. But for the next few weeks at least, the big red cultivated berry it will have to be - and for me there is no better place for them than all wrapped up with pastry and cream.

Strawberry tart

Almond pastry

A crisp and crumbly pastry (which I sometimes use for frangipani-filled tarts). This is enough for a 25cm tart tin with shallow sides, or 20 small fruit tarts. Serves 8-10.

150g unbleached plain flour
100g cold butter
50g ground almonds
50g golden caster sugar
1 large egg yolk

Tip the flour into a large mixing bowl, cut the butter into small pieces and rub it into the flour with your fingers and thumbs. It should look like breadcrumbs. Stir in the ground almonds and the sugar and add the egg yolk. Mix everything with your hands and squeeze together gently to form a soft ball of dough.

Roll the dough into a short, thick sausage, then cut thin round slices from it. Use the slices to line a 25cm (or thereabouts) tart tin with shallow sides, pushing the pieces together with your fingers. You could, if you are dexterous, roll the pastry and lift it in by hand, patching where necessary, but I find the former method easier with a very short pastry.

Prick the pastry case all over with a fork, then put in the fridge to rest for half an hour. This will stop it shrinking when it gets in the oven.

Bake the pastry case in a preheated oven at 180 C/gas mark 4 for 15 minutes or so, until it is pale biscuit-coloured. Cool in its tin, then carefully remove it and put it in a cooling rack. Small tart cases will need 12-15 minutes in the oven.

for the filling:
200ml double cream
200g thick live yogurt or faiselle or fromage frais
2 tsps icing sugar
1 drop of vanilla extract or 1 tsp rose-water

to assemble the tart:
20 medium-sized strawberries
icing sugar

Place the cooled tart case on a serving plate, then spoon the filling inside, levelling it off with the back of a spoon. Rinse, dry and hull the strawberries, then place on the cream. You have a choice here whether or not to slice them. I prefer to cut each one into six and place them point up in the cream, but you could slice them, if you prefer, or even leave them whole. Dust the berries lightly with sieved icing sugar.

Crème patissière

An alternative filling, the classic French pastry cream. Enough for a 25cm tart.

250ml full-cream milk
1 vanilla pod
4 egg yolks
75g caster sugar
2 tbsps plain flour

Pour the milk into a saucepan, drop in the vanilla pod and bring almost to the boil. Just before the milk boils, remove it from the heat and leave to infuse for 15 minutes.

Whisk the egg yolks and sugar together and stir in the flour. Discard the vanilla pod. Pour the milk on to the egg and sugar mixture, rinse the saucepan and return to the heat, stirring constantly, until the custard starts to thicken. Take care to get deep into the corners of the pan, otherwise you will end up with lumpy custard.

When the custard has thickened, scoop it into a bowl, cover it with clingfilm and leave it to cool. Refrigerate so that it is quite cold and thick before filling the tart.

fields.headline: Cheggers outrage is just skin-deep
fields.standfirst: The press got hot under the collar over TV nudity. No one else blushed, says  Jay Rayner
fields.trailText: The press got hot under the collar over TV nudity. No one else blushed, says Jay Rayner
fields.body:
Pity poor Edward Heathcote Amory. Last week, after a long day at work as a Daily Mail leader writer, he slumped down in front of the television and, as he tells it, chanced upon a game show called Naked Jungle, part of Channel 5's season celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of British naturism. All 10 of the contestants - five men and five women - were completely naked. So, too, was their host, Keith Chegwin, who presided over the proceedings wearing only a pith helmet. On his head.

Heathcote Amory was so appalled that he insisted on joining an estimated audience of two million people to watch the entire hour-long programme, the better to write an editorial piece the next day describing it as 'a new milestone in the degradation of mainstream British television', which appeared complete with pictures taken from a video of the show, little black boxes scattered about the wonder fully saggy bodies on display to protect the readers from things they might not have seen before.

How the paper came by these 'video grabs' was a mystery. Channel 5 did not send out any preview tapes because they did not want newspapers running these kinds of pictures, nor did the paper ask for a tape after the event. The answer came on Friday when a second piece appeared, this time by Leo McKinistry, once more carrying censored shots of Chegwin's portly frame under the headline 'Channel Filth'. For the sake of journalism, McKinstry announced, he had been watching Channel 5's output for four weeks now so that he could examine the station's 'grotesque exercise in vulgarity' before listing all the things - reviews of porn flicks, an adult hypnotism show, the softest of softcore that Hollywood can deliver - that this exercise comprises.

Exactly how scandalised other viewers were by the sight of Chegwin's penis remains to be seen. By the end of last week the Independent Television Commission had received just one complaint from a viewer who said he could 'do without Keith Chegwin prancing around'. An ITC spokesman said it did not believe there was anything in its codes about the choice of Chegwin as a presenter. As to the content of the show itself: 'Late-night nudity in a non-sexual context and in a programme that is well signposted may not be in breach of the programme codes.'

Nevertheless, the war of Keith Chegwin's penis fits neatly into a noble two- pronged tradition, both of nudity in British culture and of the press getting tumescent with fury about it. Last week one newspaper was describing David Elstein, head of Channel 5, as Britain's 'pornographer in chief', an honour previously bestowed upon Michael Grade and Michael Jackson, former and current controllers of Channel 4, for the perceived excesses of programmes such as The Word , and Eurotrash or the Red Light Zone strand. 'Newspapers are happy to put an admiring picture of Joely Richardson in a skimpy dress on their front page,' says Dawn Airey, Channel 5's controller of programmes. 'They'll give acres of space to the women from the WI posing naked for a calendar. But then something like this comes along and they decide it's an outrage.'

As to more general criticisms of the channel's output, Airey was dismissive. 'The adult material comprises less than 2 per cent of our schedule,' she said. 'And we can make a very clear intellectual defence of it. We don't say this is art or high-minded. It's just erotica for erotica's sake.' It was, she said, in the spirit of the Carry On movies and naughty seaside postcards.

Certainly Britain's current crop of adult-orientated programmes has a fine history. It dates back two decades to 1981 and Chris Tarrant's Over The Top - known as OTT - a late-night version of the kids' programme Tiswas , in which scantily dressed women had custard pies thrown at them.

Soon naked people were turning up on prime-time television in the Six O'Clock Show , a Friday evening London TV magazine programme hosted by Michael Aspel. 'That's probably where the present trend started,' says Charlie Parsons of Planet 24, the company behind The Word and The Big Breakfast , who was a producer on the Six O'Clock Show . 'We used to do lots of items about nudists. You'd always cover them up with a strategically placed tea pot or something like that.'

In the Nineties, instead of being labelled as good coarse fun, this kind of programming was now tagged as ironic. 'Any nudity became justified as a postmodern approach to the culture of the Carry On films rather than as the real thing,' says Parsons. 'Which of course was just an excuse for titillation.'

Doubtless this is true. In 1998, BBC2 controller Mark Thompson described a series called Naked , about the human body sans clothes, as 'more about identity than salaciousness'; similarly Touch and Go , a torrid BBC drama about wife-swapping, was, he said, expressing 'a fascination with relationships'.

Keith Chegwin, Parsons says, fits perfectly into an ironic postmodern culture. He had been a children's TV presenter in the Seventies whose career - and celebrity marriage to fellow presenter Maggie Philbin - had both collapsed after he descended into alcoholism. Parsons rescued him by booking him for an item on The Word in an ironic homage to Seventies children's television which eventually turned into a slot on The Big Breakfast .

However, in televisual, terms what defines Chegwin's (naked) move from Channel 4 to Channel 5 - and indeed the whole of Channel 5's adult output - is the death of all that postmodern irony. Channel 5 simply doesn't bother with it. Indeed, Naked Jungle would have been oddly familiar to anybody who has seen evening television in, say, Spain or Italy, both of which have a soft spot for game shows full of nudity.

'We clearly have a problem with sex and nakedness in Britain which they don't have on the continent,' says Jeff Ford, controller of acquisitions for Channel 5. It came as little surprise to Ford that, after the broadcast of Naked Jungle , he received a call from a German TV company which wishes to acquire the format.

The problem for Channel 5 is that nudity is such a contentious issue in Britain that it was always bound to be criticised whatever it did. Last week, shortly before Chegwin's fine body was to be presented to an eager public, the Freedom to be Yourself group, who campaign for the right to be naked where they like when they like, were protesting naked outside Brighton Pavilion. Like the Mail, they weren't impressed by Naked Jungle , though for entirely different reasons. 'The portrayal is exploitative,' said Vincent Bethell of the group. 'It puts the human body forward as something sensational. It doesn't make any valid attempt to address the injustice of the segregation between the clothed and unclothed.'

Wisely Chegwin was not available for comment last week. He was away in Spain filming an item for GMTV. But, after his appearance on Naked Jungle last week, one thing at least can be said with certainty: Keith Chegwin has serious balls.

TV's skins of the flesh

May 2000 Chris Evans's show TFI Friday is reported to the Independent Television Commission after two topless and 'well endowed' women appeared on screen shortly after 6.30pm wearing nothing but flesh-coloured knickers.

March 1999 The ITC issues a report condemning Channel 5 for its endless pre-occupation with nudity and sex and particularly for its Sex and Shopping series.

July 1998 The ITC upholds complaints against Channel 5 for a programme on Stringfellow's nightclub in London which featured scenes of pole dancing, stripping and lap dancing. It went out at 8.30pm, half an hour before the watershed.

August 1997 The ITC upholds a complaint against Tarrant on TV for showing a German advert for ceiling panels, in which a naked couple appear having sex, too soon after the 9pm watershed

June 1995 Channel 4 given a formal warning by the ITC over The Word, particularly an item featuring 'Mr Powertool' in which a man pulled a girl across a studio floor by a rope attached to his penis.

Like the Mail, they weren't impressed by Naked Jungle , though for entirely different reasons. 'The portrayal is exploitative,' said Vincent Bethell of the group. 'It puts the human body forward as something sensational. It doesn't make any valid attempt to address the injustice of the segregation between the clothed and unclothed.' Wisely Chegwin was not available for comment last week. He was away in Spain filming an item for GMTV. But, after his appearance on Naked Jungle last week, one thing at least can be said with certainty: Keith Chegwin has serious balls. TV's skins of the flesh May 2000 Chris Evans's show TFI Friday is reported to the Independent Television Commission after two topless and 'well endowed' women appeared on screen shortly after 6.30pm wearing nothing but flesh-coloured knickers. March 1999 The ITC issues a report condemning Channel 5 for its endless pre-occupation with nudity and sex and particularly for its Sex and Shopping series. July 1998 The ITC upholds complaints against Channel 5 for a programme on Stringfellow's nightclub in London which featured scenes of pole dancing, stripping and lap dancing. It went out at 8.30pm, half an hour before the watershed. August 1997 The ITC upholds a complaint against Tarrant on TV for showing a German advert for ceiling panels, in which a naked couple appear having sex, too soon after the 9pm watershed June 1995 Channel 4 given a formal warning by the ITC over The Word, particularly an item featuring 'Mr Powertool' in which a man pulled a girl across a studio floor by a rope attached to his penis.

fields.headline: Wooden Spoon
fields.standfirst: A mix'n'match menu, service charge at the bar, exorbitant prices... Jay Rayner forks out at Spoon in Ian Schrager's Sanderson hotel
fields.trailText: A mix'n'match menu, service charge at the bar, exorbitant prices... Jay Rayner forks out at Spoon in Ian Schrager's Sanderson hotel
fields.body:
Whenever a critic writes a review of a restaurant in one of the achingly hip hotels owned by Ian Schrager - the man behind the Royalton in New York, St Martins Lane in London and now the Sanderson, on a site just north of Oxford Street - a hand-written card arrives, as if from the man himself. The one I received after I expressed my complete disdain for Asia de Cuba at St Martins Lane said something like 'Please do try us again', which was, and remains, a victory of hope over expectation.

Can I suggest, Mr Schrager, that when you come to sending me a card after this review of Spoon at Sanderson, it says: 'I apologise for running such a greedy operation.' For Spoon is, without doubt, the most outrageous exercise in separating punters from their cash currently at work in the capital. Not that the punters appear to mind; it took me three weeks to get a table. Spoon is what they call hot.

The night I went, the bar - a grand rectangular affair of onyx and shimmering lights - was packed with the sort of people who prefer mirrors on the horizontal rather than the vertical, the better to powder their nose. Perhaps they are also the kind of people who don't notice the price, for it is here that the outrage begins.

While I waited for my companion, I ordered a glass of South African Sauvignon Blanc. I was told it was £7.50 and, swallowing hard, handed over a tenner. I got back £1.40. I looked at the receipt. Apparently a 15 per cent discretionary service charge had been added to my bill - for the serving of a glass of wine at the bar. This is one way to guarantee that a fine glass of white wine will leave a nasty taste in the mouth.

Thus fleeced, we were led to the dining room which, again, is a clever space of pale shades in which everybody can look at everybody else. The menus, like the prices, are of staggering proportions. If you were caught in a forest on a rainy night, one of these could easily serve as a bivouac. But then the menu needs to be big to contain the silliness within. I had always thought that one of the reasons for going to a restaurant is so that clever people, who know how to cook, can come up with interesting ways to combine interesting ingredients. Not at Spoon.

The great Alain Ducasse, who has sired not one but two restaurants in France each boasting three Michelin stars, is the consultant. His big idea is to break dishes up into their ingredients and then let you mix and match. Or, as the almost unintelligible menu puts it: 'If you are like switching and changing we invite you to zig zag through the different columns and think the unthinkable.'

For our starters, we were not yet brave enough to really go for it, so we chose two of the non-fragmented dishes. I had pork and shrimp ravioli with a piquant tomato sauce, which were fine, the kind of thing you could find in Chinatown for £3.50, and certainly not fine enough for a price tag of £14. My companion's ceviche of sea bass - the fish 'cooked' in a citrus marinade - was rather good: delicate, fresh, succulent. As it should be for £16.

For my main course, I decided to think the unthinkable by combining the grilled saddle of lamb at £20 with the truffle sauce that was meant to go with the veal, and the macaroni cheese which, after tasting it, I concluded should not have gone with anything. I was intrigued to see how the kitchen would bring this ad-libbed set of ingredients together. The answer is: it didn't. The lamb and the solid gummy strip of macaroni cheese were situated half a foot away from each other on the plate like a couple on the verge of divorce. As to the sauce, that came in a bowl on the side, complete with a congealed skin. My companion's grilled squid (a mere £17) came with the same tomato sauce as with my starter and a little splodge of truly nasty mango gunk.

The wine list had nothing below £20. We chose the second cheapest, a bottle of New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, at £23. Spoon clearly didn't think this was enough. It appeared on the bill as £45, bringing the total including that 'discretionary' service charge to around £165. I complained. The bill went down to £136. I gave them my credit card. Back came the receipt with the service-charge box left open. I knocked the tip down to 10 per cent.

When they saw what I had done, all hell let loose. What had happened, they asked, what had they done? I explained. Oh, they said. After a five-minute pause, they announced they would designate my table 'non-service'. Hence a bill of £119.

Many of you could be forgiven for becoming rather tired of the recent run of reviews: new London restaurants each worse than the last, throwing up bills well north of £100. For what it's worth, I see this and the previous two as a kind of trilogy, a description of what happens when the economics of restaurants becomes so perverse that the last thing to matter is the food. It's tiresome and it's depressing and I, too, have had enough. Normal service will now resume. Promise.

 Spoon at Sanderson, 50 Berners Street, London W1 (020 7300 1400). Price of dinner for two, including wine and service: whatever the management thinks it can get away with. Jay Rayner can be contacted at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Happy eaters
fields.standfirst: Don't go to war against snails and slugs - they work wonders with compost
fields.trailText: Don't go to war against snails and slugs - they work wonders with compost.
fields.body:
It is easy for gardeners to become obsessed with predation and to feel themselves constantly under attack. I know it can sometimes feel that way in this garden when it comes to slugs and snails. If I walk outside the front door on a wet evening at this time of year, there are literally thousands of snails on the grass, slowly making their way to the walled garden for supper. If you put your hands inside a cardoon (you mean to say you have never done this?) you can, in our garden, pull out more snails from a single leaf than your hands will carry. Young, otherwise healthy cardoon plants can be eaten through overnight, leaving a frayed stub surrounded by chewed-off leaves.

If they just stuck to cardoons I would plant a thicket for them, but there are few things they will not nibble. So I go through periods of loathing the little buggers. But... Here am I creating a wildly unnatural food supply for them and they are merely responding as they know how. If I were to leave them be, the results would not be catastrophic. And they do serve a purpose. Slugs and snails eat all the waste and decaying vegetable matter that would otherwise attract and foster disease and fungal attacks. They love wet, stringy tissue best - young cardoons, lettuces, comfrey - but will try most things. Leave some comfrey or cardoon leaves on the ground near your lettuces or young cosmos seedlings (I have seen a tray of healthy cosmos reduced to chewed matchsticks in the greenhouse overnight) and they will go for those first. This also makes them very useful in the compost heap. Slugs will happily spend their days munching through it all, including any cardboard that you add, processing your waste and representing it as finely digested slug poo. A healthy compost heap should be teeming with slugs, woodlice, brandlings and other invertebrates, all greedily recycling your waste. All these animals are vital, because the equation is beautifully simple: the more compost you can produce, the better.

And of course all these waste-eaters are important food for thrushes, hedgehogs, foxes, toads, ground beetles, ducks and chickens. Ten years ago it would have been necessary in a piece such as this to explain the food chain. Now we are all familiar with it, yet the avid chemical gardener still behaves as though their garden were in a loop quite outside the circle. This is silly and self-centred: no garden is an island. To everything non-human in the garden, your carefully preserved boundaries are merely objects in the landscape. The most obvious result of this is that you will share the wildlife - good and bad - of your neighbours, be they industrial, agricultural or horticultural. What I find interesting is when people plant up an urban or suburban back garden in as tropical a manner as possible. Where do they think the pollinators will be? In creating an environment that hosts none of the wildlife it is designed to support, they are also making an area that is less than friendly to all the local wildlife. A double whammy.

This is not to say that one should self-consciously plant up the garden only with native plants. Gardens are never less than artifice, particularly 'wild' gardens. But it does make sense to create an environment where local ecology feels at home. This is likely to include some grasses to provide seeds and pollen. It would also feature a selection of umbellifers such as angelica, fennel, chervil or dill - all of which are rich in nectar and particularly attractive to hoverflies and lacewings, whose larvae in turn eat aphids. Stinging nettles are essential food for the caterpillars of nymphalid butterflies, so every garden should have a patch of carefully preserved nettles. And a typical suburban street is an ideal environment for songbirds and bees - if it is not drenched in chemicals and has a selection of indigenous plants.

There is no need to be too gloomy about this. A well-stocked garden with a couple of mature trees and plenty of shrubs can support a far higher density of songbirds than a wood. In fact, most gardens are more wildlife-friendly than the average field, although far too many chemicals are still being used. I am sure all garden chemicals are a con trick to get you to part with your money: they do nothing to help your garden and everything to harm the ecology. Ditch the lot now and never buy any more.

But to get your thrushes and blackbirds, you must have food for them in the shape of worms, invertebrates and insects. Indigenous species tend to support a much richer insect life than introductions. The London plane, for example, apparently only supports one insect species in Britain, whereas the pedunculate oak (Quercus robur) supports 284 insect species. How many people plant oak trees in their garden? It is lovely from the first and gives enormous pleasure as it grows.

Successful organic gardening depends on this interrelation of plant and animal life. It is a completely holistic system and, if managed properly, will attain its own balance. This cannot possible happen if man blitzes certain pests when they arise. You need some aphids if you are to have ladybirds or lacewings, and you need slugs if hedgehogs and toads are to visit your garden. Each predator must have enough to feed on to maintain their controlling presence. Then, if and when there is an explosion of one particular 'pest', the predatory population will respond.

It is an entirely self-regulating system and it works fine. But the gardener can help. The most important thing is to have healthy plants. A healthy plant grows strongly enough to survive attack. Of course 'healthy' does not mean a plant that is being forced into unnatural vigour by over-feeding. That simply makes it ideal fodder for aphids, slugs and anything else that feeds off sappy, young growth. Let your garden plants adapt to your soil and grow at their own pace. Overcrowding is another source of all kinds of problems, and yet a good garden should feel packed to the gunnels. The answer is to avoid the massed effect created by lots of weedy little plants and to plant in groups, so that each individual plant has the space to grow healthily and yet, when mature, is jostling its neighbours without crowding them out.

Don't tidy up too much. There is a balance to be struck between the kind of order most people need in their gardens, with healthy plants pruned and supported, and dead vegetation gathered, and enough overgrown and dying vegetation to support the full range of wildlife that the garden needs. Don't cut all your grass short. Have at least a patch that you cut just twice a year. Apart from anything else, this will encourage wildflowers, which will increase insect diversity. And diversity is the key. A healthy garden has as wide a range of insects, birds and mammals as possible.

There are two animals that, as far as I can see, serve no use to the gardener whatsoever. The first is the rat - which is much more prevalent in gardens than most people admit - and the second is the mole. Compared to rats, moles are charming creatures, but are an absolute pain in the garden, as they eat precious worms and do phenomenal amounts of damage in border and lawn alike.

fields.headline: Quest for an authentic voice
fields.standfirst: Does the Orange Prize prove that we now live in a literary Lilliput?
fields.trailText: Really the only requirement of any important book is that it should have something original to say and then say it in an original way. The evidence that ordinary readers instinctively share this expectation underlies the unfortunate row about Linda Grant's When I Lived in Modern Times.
fields.body:
Really the only requirement of any important book is that it should have something original to say and then say it in an original way. The evidence that ordinary readers instinctively share this expectation underlies the unfortunate row about Linda Grant's When I Lived in Modern Times.

Never mind that this fuss turns out, on closer examination, to be more about publishing than plagiarism, it has stirred up all the old demons of literary larceny, artistic appropriation and our post-Romantic insistence on creative authenticity. As the poet and critic Craig Raine said in The Observer in 1988, 'The task of the artist at any time is uncompromisingly simple - to discover what has not yet been done, and to do it.' Ezra Pound put it more concisely in the Cantos: 'MAKE IT NEW.'

What, then, does one look for in a first-rate writer? Delight in language? Absolutely. Humanity? No question. Individuality? For sure. Command of narrative? Of course. A natural grasp of the chosen genre? Probably - though a little voice whispers that the truly great writer will probably also want to rearrange the accepted conventions.

It's a tall order. It always has been. Originality, as we know, is an uncommon achievement, and contemporary literature is almost always riddled with larger or smaller acts of theft.

Landmark books are just about as scarce as hens' teeth or rocking-horse manure. The astounding proliferation of new books of all sorts (there were more than 100,000 in Britain last year alone) has not resulted in a commensurate increase in the number of recent masterpieces, though you might not know this from the confetti-like way some publishers are inclined to throw money at half-completed manuscripts by Oxbridge graduates and glamorous outsiders.

Perhaps because we live at the end of a long and often glorious period of English literature; perhaps because we inhabit a country whose future is to be found in the imperial past; perhaps because we have apparently examined every wrinkle and blemish on the face of our society, from suburbia to academia, in countless fictional ways; there are, at present, very few truly great and original novels being published in the British Isles. It's doubtless ridiculous to second-guess the verdict of future readers, but I defy anyone to name a serious new British novel, published here in the last five years, or even the last 10, which is likely to withstand even the casual scrutiny of posterity.

It's at the periphery, not the centre, that we find the freshest and most untrammelled approach to the eternal challenge of the new blank page. Here, the empire has struck back with a vengeance, as a cursory glance at recent Booker Prize short-lists confirms. If it were not for the English literatures of Australia, India, Canada and South Africa, we would be living in a literary Lilliput. Indeed it is only possible to construct a plausible narrative of contemporary 'English literature' if (to name some of the most obvious) you conjure the names of Ben Okri, Kazuo Ishiguro, Timothy Mo, Vikram Seth, Upamanyu Chatterjee, Rohinton Mistry, Hanif Kureishi, Michael Ondaatje, and now the impressive newcomer Zadie Smith, whose remarkable debut White Teeth was passed over by the Orange Prize this week. In fact, I'd go so far as to say that in the last 25 years only one novel truly matches up to Dr Raine's prescription: Salman Rushdie's Midnight's Children (with Martin Amis's Money and Ian McEwan's Enduring Love as distinguished runners-up).

There are many criticisms you can make of Rushdie's work, but you cannot deny its originality. What distinguished it from the herd was that it broke new ground. It had a subject and a voice all its own, as, in its day, did Gunter Grass's Tin Drum. Open Midnight's Children at any page. You know at once who's written it. There is no simpler, or more searching, test.

The three essentials of any successful work of fiction are character, language and story. But the one quality that transforms these basic ingredients into art is tone. Tone, or 'voice', is the only thing that matters. To achieve this within the booming echo chamber of the Eng Lit tradition is exceptionally difficult. It was this that Midnight's Children pulled off, inspiring a host of imitations. (Arguably, Martin Amis did the same with Money .) Say what you like about Amis and Rushdie, but most of the other new writers published in the last 30 years sound like someone else, and certainly not like themselves. It's that fundamental inauthenticity that automatically excludes them from the premier league, and relegates them to the second, or the third division.

If, as a writer, you can't manage the command of an authoritative and distinctive 'voice', then you can always fall back on 'story'. Here, too, originality is hard to come by. It is a commonplace of this discussion that there are, indeed, only three, or seven, or 10, basic plots in literature.

Shakespeare, as all the leader writers have pointed out, 'depended' heavily on Plutarch and Holinshed. And you find outbreaks of theft all over the literary marketplace, not just in bardofavon.com. Susan Howatch, for example, based the plots of all her early work on Shakespeare.

By a nice coincidence, the week of the Orange Prize rumpus was also the week in which Hollywood was accused of hi-jacking a legitimate and heroic British wartime triumph in its shameful Americanisation of the U571 'Enigma' story. This is doubly ironic because there is, in Britain, a widely held view that it's only the Americans who are able to turn out the Big Story (in print and celluloid) effortlessly from season to season. Not so long ago, so the argument runs, there was Don Delillo's Underworld ; this year there's the new Philip Roth. Other big guns - Mailer, Wolfe, Bellow - continue to rumble impressively over the hills.

If this is true, then part of the explanation lies in America's position as a world power. Its rich and complex national story has become the world's story, and its writers, who address themselves to the continuing American drama, have an automatic place centre-stage which gives their utterance an inevitable consequence. The Americans also have - as we have, too - the inestimable advantage of writing in the world's first global language - English. Finding a voice involves many things (courage, luck, and determination for sure), but being translated out of, for instance, Serbo-Croat or Yiddish is something that no British or American writer has to endure.

But in the end, true originality in literature lies in writing whose genius can be expressed in any language.
fields.bodyText: Really the only requirement of any important book is that it should have something original to say and then say it in an original way. The evidence that ordinary readers instinctively share this expectation underlies the unfortunate row about Linda Grant's When I Lived in Modern Times. Never mind that this fuss turns out, on closer examination, to be more about publishing than plagiarism, it has stirred up all the old demons of literary larceny, artistic appropriation and our post-Romantic insistence on creative authenticity. As the poet and critic Craig Raine said in The Observer in 1988, 'The task of the artist at any time is uncompromisingly simple - to discover what has not yet been done, and to do it.' Ezra Pound put it more concisely in the Cantos: 'MAKE IT NEW.' What, then, does one look for in a first-rate writer? Delight in language? Absolutely. Humanity? No question. Individuality? For sure. Command of narrative? Of course. A natural grasp of the chosen genre? Probably - though a little voice whispers that the truly great writer will probably also want to rearrange the accepted conventions. It's a tall order. It always has been. Originality, as we know, is an uncommon achievement, and contemporary literature is almost always riddled with larger or smaller acts of theft. Landmark books are just about as scarce as hens' teeth or rocking-horse manure. The astounding proliferation of new books of all sorts (there were more than 100,000 in Britain last year alone) has not resulted in a commensurate increase in the number of recent masterpieces, though you might not know this from the confetti-like way some publishers are inclined to throw money at half-completed manuscripts by Oxbridge graduates and glamorous outsiders. Perhaps because we live at the end of a long and often glorious period of English literature; perhaps because we inhabit a country whose future is to be found in the imperial past; perhaps because we have apparently examined every wrinkle and blemish on the face of our society, from suburbia to academia, in countless fictional ways; there are, at present, very few truly great and original novels being published in the British Isles. It's doubtless ridiculous to second-guess the verdict of future readers, but I defy anyone to name a serious new British novel, published here in the last five years, or even the last 10, which is likely to withstand even the casual scrutiny of posterity. It's at the periphery, not the centre, that we find the freshest and most untrammelled approach to the eternal challenge of the new blank page. Here, the empire has struck back with a vengeance, as a cursory glance at recent Booker Prize short-lists confirms. If it were not for the English literatures of Australia, India, Canada and South Africa, we would be living in a literary Lilliput. Indeed it is only possible to construct a plausible narrative of contemporary 'English literature' if (to name some of the most obvious) you conjure the names of Ben Okri, Kazuo Ishiguro, Timothy Mo, Vikram Seth, Upamanyu Chatterjee, Rohinton Mistry, Hanif Kureishi, Michael Ondaatje, and now the impressive newcomer Zadie Smith, whose remarkable debut White Teeth was passed over by the Orange Prize this week. In fact, I'd go so far as to say that in the last 25 years only one novel truly matches up to Dr Raine's prescription: Salman Rushdie's Midnight's Children (with Martin Amis's Money and Ian McEwan's Enduring Love as distinguished runners-up). There are many criticisms you can make of Rushdie's work, but you cannot deny its originality. What distinguished it from the herd was that it broke new ground. It had a subject and a voice all its own, as, in its day, did Gunter Grass's Tin Drum. Open Midnight's Children at any page. You know at once who's written it. There is no simpler, or more searching, test. The three essentials of any successful work of fiction are character, language and story. But the one quality that transforms these basic ingredients into art is tone. Tone, or 'voice', is the only thing that matters. To achieve this within the booming echo chamber of the Eng Lit tradition is exceptionally difficult. It was this that Midnight's Children pulled off, inspiring a host of imitations. (Arguably, Martin Amis did the same with Money .) Say what you like about Amis and Rushdie, but most of the other new writers published in the last 30 years sound like someone else, and certainly not like themselves. It's that fundamental inauthenticity that automatically excludes them from the premier league, and relegates them to the second, or the third division. If, as a writer, you can't manage the command of an authoritative and distinctive 'voice', then you can always fall back on 'story'. Here, too, originality is hard to come by. It is a commonplace of this discussion that there are, indeed, only three, or seven, or 10, basic plots in literature. Shakespeare, as all the leader writers have pointed out, 'depended' heavily on Plutarch and Holinshed. And you find outbreaks of theft all over the literary marketplace, not just in bardofavon.com. Susan Howatch, for example, based the plots of all her early work on Shakespeare. By a nice coincidence, the week of the Orange Prize rumpus was also the week in which Hollywood was accused of hi-jacking a legitimate and heroic British wartime triumph in its shameful Americanisation of the U571 'Enigma' story. This is doubly ironic because there is, in Britain, a widely held view that it's only the Americans who are able to turn out the Big Story (in print and celluloid) effortlessly from season to season. Not so long ago, so the argument runs, there was Don Delillo's Underworld ; this year there's the new Philip Roth. Other big guns - Mailer, Wolfe, Bellow - continue to rumble impressively over the hills. If this is true, then part of the explanation lies in America's position as a world power. Its rich and complex national story has become the world's story, and its writers, who address themselves to the continuing American drama, have an automatic place centre-stage which gives their utterance an inevitable consequence. The Americans also have - as we have, too - the inestimable advantage of writing in the world's first global language - English. Finding a voice involves many things (courage, luck, and determination for sure), but being translated out of, for instance, Serbo-Croat or Yiddish is something that no British or American writer has to endure. But in the end, true originality in literature lies in writing whose genius can be expressed in any language.

webTitle: It's the euro in your pocket...

fields.headline: It's the euro in your pocket...
fields.standfirst: Love it or loathe it, moving into Europe is going to become the central tenet of the election debateEconomic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Love it or loathe it, moving into Europe is going to become the central tenet of the election debate
fields.body:
Every post-war government has been hit by it in the end - and New Labour is about to enter its own travails. Sooner or later, the consequences of policy towards the pound becomes the decisive political issue of the day. The euro promises to be no different.

Suddenly, what has been obvious to the economic cognoscenti is entering the political mainstream. The moment is arriving when it will be clear that Gordon Brown's five economic tests to allow Britain to join the euro will be comfortably passed. The conjunction of an approaching election, growing restiveness among pro-Europeans that the Government has been inadequate in making the case for the euro and Britain's economic convergence with Europe is making the issue jump to life. The Chancellor wanted to negotiate the next 12 months as the Government has the last, saying as little as possible so that there were no hostages to fortune in the run-up to the election. Events are moving so quickly that the debate is moving beyond such control.

Paradoxically, his difficulty is that the British economy is performing very well, a truth underlined by the OECD report on the UK published last week. The Treasury was pleased the Paris- based government club of economic forecasters' verdict on Britain was that our economic track record and prospects were in some respects enviable, but less happy that the OECD felt able to say that Britain was better qualified to be a member of the euro than some of its principal members. On inflation and unemployment alone, we could handle membership of the euro, but what now seems clear is that Brown is delivering what he promised, an economy less prone to boom and bust and which could sit comfortably in the eurozone.

With the interest-rate gap between Britain and the euro area now 1.75 per cent and likely to narrow further, the only remaining technical obstacle to Britain joining the euro is the exchange rate. The treaty says that a prospective member needs two years of currency stability at a rate of proven durability and the current oscillations are far from that. Yet some further strength in the euro and weakness in the pound will see that hurdle passed. Sterling will have moved into the economic holding pen from which it could enter the euro if the country so willed.

Within the Cabinet, the argument has been joined with growing passion. Only six weeks ago, a meeting of the big four - Blair, Prescott, Brown and Cook - called to discuss the Government's strategy proved no more than a rubber-stamping of the position Brown had established in the autumn of 1997. The Chancellor read out his five tests, said they had yet to be passed and declared that the issue was not up for discussion. The meeting closed.

When Peter Mandelson subsequently made a speech on 16 May arguing that the pound was overvalued and we could not control our exchange rate outside the euro, all hell broke lose. For the second time, he had knowingly broken the Chancellor's ordnance insisting on the primacy of the five tests and collective self-denial and, worse, implicitly advocated membership of the euro. Brown told the Prime Minister that he could not countenance a third intervention from Mandelson and that he had better discipline his errant Northern Ireland Secretary. The political stakes were becoming very high indeed.

For Treasury insiders with long memories, the affair had eerie similarities to Nigel Lawson's passionate resentment of the criticism made by Alan Walters, Mrs Thatcher's personal economic adviser, of his policy of shadowing the deutschmark over 1988 and 1989 - and which led to his eventual resignation in October 1989. As Lawson writes in his memoirs, the provocations were so immense that he finally felt his position had become untenable. A chancellor cannot have his policy publicly undermined by a figure the markets and public at large know speaks for the Prime Minister. For Alan Walters read Peter Mandelson, a much bigger political player. And for shadowing the deutschmark, read joining the euro.

Blair could not have been other than alarmed. He is well-versed in Labour history and knows how devaluation shattered the Labour governments in the Sixties and Seventies. He watched the Major government disintegrate after Britain's expulsion from the ERM. He has been careful to avoid New Labour being hung in the same way by a commitment to a totemic exchange rate in the run-up to the next general election, and has backed his Chancellor for that reason. But the relationship is testy and difficult. And he also knows that Mandelson possesses the political equivalent of an Exocet. Another aggressive pro-euro speech from Northern Ireland and Brown could confront him, as Lawson did over Walters, with a back-me-or-back-him ultimatum.

Blair needed to reassert control and he has done so by subtly moving the centre of gravity towards a pro-euro position. When the pound reached the dizzying heights of three weeks ago, briefly trading at above DM3.40, there was an intense debate about whether the Government should start selling pounds and buying euros to lower sterling. It could be presented as the correct economic policy in its own right or made more even more emphatic by saying that it was part of a programme to make sterling more convergent with the euro area. The Bank and Chancellor were against, but agreed that instead they should launch a powerful verbal attempt to talk sterling down.

But the associated pressure on manufacturing industry, the powerful trade union campaign and the hardening of opinion in many Labour seats that the Government had to have an exchange-rate policy has left an impact. If it was politically risky to be positive about the euro in the run-up to the election, it was becoming equally politically risky to say nothing, an argument that Cook, Mandelson and Trade Secretary Stephen Byers have been making with growing force. Brown and Blair, keenly aware that the Government depends on their cohesion, have brokered a new position. Ministers can now talk positively about the advantages of euro membership as long as they are careful to insist that Brown's five tests have still to be passed, a concession on which Byers has taken an early advantage.

For a pro-European like myself, this is a welcome and long overdue beginning. What is also becoming clear is that in the next phase of development of the new economy - mobile phones linked to the internet - mainland Europe is well ahead of the US and set to become the most dynamic part of the globe. If Europe starts to become an economic pacemaker, the advantages of being in rather than out will become less finely balanced. The sceptics have had it their own way for too long. Battle is about to be joined - and the euro is about to become headline news for some time to come.

webTitle: Deadly army plot to frame UDA man

fields.headline: Deadly army plot to frame UDA man
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: British Army agents set up a loyalist terrorist leader for assassination to help their own informer penetrate the highest levels of the Ulster Defence Association (UDA).
fields.body:
British Army agents set up a loyalist terrorist leader for assassination to help their own informer penetrate the highest levels of the Ulster Defence Association (UDA).

A former member of the Army's clandestine Force Research Unit (FRU) has told The Observer that Jimmy Craig, a UDA racketeer, was sacrificed in order to improve ex-soldier Brian Nelson's standing inside the Protestant terror group.

Craig was shot dead in October 1988. The UDA said he was colluding with the IRA.

However, the former FRU soldier who operated undercover in Northern Ireland says his fate was sealed by a leaked RUC video, showing the UDA leader meeting with a senior Belfast IRA man in a Catholic bar.

The ex-soldier claims that officers at the FRU's base in Army headquarters at Thiepval barracks, Lisburn, gave the video to Nelson, who had infiltrated the UDA.

The ex-FRU soldier's allegations are to be given to Sir John Stevens, the former deputy chief constable of Cambridgeshire, in charge of investigating claims of collusion between the British Army and loyalist terrorists.

Speaking from a secret location in Europe, the former undercover soldier said: 'The RUC's anti-terrorist surveillance unit, E4A, had filmed a meeting between Craig and this Provo from Unity Flats in the bar in the Markets area.

'The video was later taken to Brian Nelson who was being run by agents I worked with in Lisburn at the time. Nelson then passed the video on to the UDA's leadership. This was the last piece of evidence to prove that Craig was a traitor... and it helped get him killed.'

The soldier said allowing Craig to be killed, so that Nelson could impress fellow UDA leaders and rise through the ranks, was illegal.

'The security services allowed Craig to be murdered in order to advance their own informer. They colluded in a criminal act. That is something that I feel in a democracy must be exposed.'

Craig was shot dead by the UDA's Special Investigations Unit because it said he had set up fellow loyalists for assassination, including its supreme commander, John McMichael, killed by an IRA bomb in December 1987.

Shortly after the Craig killing, the UDA released a statement. It mentioned a 'tape' which proved he was working with the enemy.

Until his death, Craig was the UDA's chief fundraiser, mainly through extortion rackets on building sites. Craig regularly met members of the Provisional and Official IRA to carve up control of security on building sites across Belfast in the Eighties. Builders were forced to pay both groups and employ their members - or risk being beaten up or killed.

Craig, who loved the good life and took holidays in southern Spain with money he made from protection, told fellow inmates at Belfast's Crumlin Road jail how he kept discipline in the UDA. 'I've got this big fucking hammer and I've told them that, if anybody gives me trouble, I'll break their fucking fingers.'

The Craig affair will only heighten demands for a public inquiry into the clandestine career of Brian Nelson. The unit that ran Nelson, the FRU, one of the army's most secretive, has won more gallantry awards than any other unit in Northern Ireland. However, the FRU has faced controversy over its handling of Nelson, who carried out terrorist acts while working for the state, including the conspiracy to murder Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane and the nationalist Gerard Slane.
