webTitle: The Boys in Blue nab their own hit squad

fields.headline: The Boys in Blue nab their own hit squad
fields.standfirst: France are a better team now than when they won the World Cup
fields.trailText: Life with Les Bleus is a sanctuary for the select few. There's something old fashioned in the way the squad feel about France. Playing for their club is a job, for their country it's a cause. It's a second family.
fields.body:
Life with Les Bleus is a sanctuary for the select few. There's something old fashioned in the way the squad feel about France. Playing for their club is a job, for their country it's a cause. It's a second family.

Take Zinedine Zidane, who endured a difficult season at Juventus marred by injury, a dip in form, and the ultimate sickener of throwing away the Serie A title in controversial circumstances.

Pretty depressed, he joined up with France, the mates with whom he rode shoulder to shoulder to football's summit, and the familiarity of Clairfontaine, the peaceful chateau which is the team's home, where fond memories and good vibrations hang in the air.

'It's a place which has a special place in my head,' he says. 'When I got here I definitely turned the page on this season, which was one of the biggest disappointments in my football career. Negative thoughts went away and I felt happy to be back amongst the France team. Mentally I am channelled to one objective: to win Euro 2000.'

For a large percentage of the squad, national duty puts other concerns on the back burner. Fabien Barthez has a new life in Manchester to plan, Marcel Desailly, Emmanuel Petit and Didier Deschamps seem only too keen to ponder the prospects of a new club. Christian Karembeu and Sylvain Wiltord are also angling for a move. But for now these are side issues.

Take Nicolas Anelka (will-he-won't-he leave for Paris Saint-Germain/Juventus/ whoever?). It's an amazing turnaround to find that a player who refused to train for Real Madrid is only too willing to play in an unglamorous practice match for France's reserves against a team made up of a selection from Croatia's Second Division in the suburbs of Zagreb. He scored a hat-trick. He smiled. He wants to be part of the mission in Holland and Belgium.

For the first time in France's history they are favourites for a tournament outside their own land. Not only because they are the World Champions but because they are the team of 1998 plus strikers. They have evolved.

'We are better then 1998,' chirps Lebeouf. Indeed they seem in ideal shape: the first choice defence has nearly 400 caps between them, the midfield are proven winners, and the attack brims with youthful vigour.

It wasn't too long ago that frustration was welling up about the dearth of striking talent. Everybody admits they were lucky to win the World Cup with Stephane Guivarc'h leading the charge, and only eight months ago the front cover of France Football blared the following advertisement: 'Urgent... France is desperately seeking a goalscorer.'

Anelka, having been hailed as the answer when his brace ripped through England at Wembley, had lost his form to a niggling combination of arrogance and injury. Thierry Henry was quietly acclimatising to a central role. David Trezeguet had never quite turned raw potential into the real deal. Now, to France's delight, all three have the makings of world-beaters and coach Roger Lemerre is spoilt for choice.

Henry seems to be the slight favourite, although Trezeguet had a recent spell with the midas touch and Anelka simply has star quality and a taste for the big occasion.

'Competition is healthy', as the trio of strikers have all been heard saying recently, is the new mantra. But continuity is the foundation. Unforseen injuries and suspensions permitted, if Lemerre had to pick a team to win any given game eight players would know for sure they are in.

Barthez in goal, protected by the defensive core of Desailly and Laurent Blanc with Deschamps and Petit just up ahead. Lilian Thuram and Bixente Lizarazu get the nod as roaming full backs par excellence. Zidane, of course, is guaranteed. That leaves three attacking berths up for grabs and this is where Lemerre's selection becomes interesting.

One of the three out and out strikers plays for definite. One of Robert Pires, Christophe Dugarry, Youri Djorkaeff or Johan Micoud will create from deep alongside Zidane. And the last place? That's the big debate. Will he play another attacker, or another playmaker, or Wiltord, who is something in between? Over to you Roger.

There's a mindboggling number of permutations and he is expected to mix and match according to the opposition. All will play a part, as they did two years ago. Talk of the national team seldom mentions a starting 11, or a 16 including a subs bench, but always the 22. Le vingt-deux. It is a magic number in France. Lebeouf summed up the mood persuasively: 'L'Equipe de France is like a drug.'

The taste of breaking ground as French footballers has served to whet the appetite. Now they are World Champions they want to be the first team to claim both global and European supremacy, a feat never before accomplished, even by the great German, Dutch or Italian sides who have gone close.

'It's fabulous to find ourselves facing a new challenge. It's another way of making football history for our country and for ourselves. This is our chance you see,' muses Zidane.

As Desailly points out, 'Everyone in the group has desire, hunger. We all want to win Euro 2000 but we must be humble. Everything has its moment. We cannot think that just because we are World Champions we only need click our fingers to reach another final. We have to forget our victory in the World Cup to get moving again.'

If France want it enough they have all the attributes to clinch the trophy named after one of their own, Henri Delaunay. Preparation for Euro 2000 was carefully planned to echo the formula for '98. Meeting up at Clairfontaine, then a spell in Tignes for some beneficial mountain air, before a trip to Morocco for some sunshine with a couple of warm-up games thrown in for good measure. For the tournament itself they are staying in a converted castle - not dissimilar to Clairfontaine - on a lake just outside Brussels.

It's all deliberately familiar. Even 18 of the World Cup 22 are the same. For this generation of players France '98 is the eternal reference point, the catalyst, the pinnacle. That summer will forever be remembered as the time their nation fell in love with football.

A passion suddenly bloomed, growing with every game.You could sense it in the Provencal market squares, hear it in the tabacs in Nantes, smell it in Lyonnaise cafes. Football gradually penetrated everyday life in France, and by the time Les Bleus reached the final the country was smitten.

In the subsequent two years the people of France and its football team have drifted apart. League attendances are healthy and the legendary 22 still cause a stir wherever they go, but for your average monsieur et madame the summer of love ran its course.

Success in the Low Countries would remind all the grannies why they had a soft spot for 'Zizou', bring a smile to the folically challenged every time Blanc kisses Barthez's bald head for luck, and get the hip hop kids wanting to be Anelka.

How resonant it will be for Aime Jacquet, the architect who put this extraordinary group together and masterminded that golden period. He knows well the curiously fickle attitude to football in France: 'I hoped that every French man and woman would get behind the French team before the tournament began.

'In reality, what happened was that Les Bleus were forced to prove themselves on the pitch. To prove that they truly were the talented performers, hungry for victory, that I'd been telling people about for ages.'

Now to prove themselves all over again.
fields.bodyText: Life with Les Bleus is a sanctuary for the select few. There's something old fashioned in the way the squad feel about France. Playing for their club is a job, for their country it's a cause. It's a second family. Take Zinedine Zidane, who endured a difficult season at Juventus marred by injury, a dip in form, and the ultimate sickener of throwing away the Serie A title in controversial circumstances. Pretty depressed, he joined up with France, the mates with whom he rode shoulder to shoulder to football's summit, and the familiarity of Clairfontaine, the peaceful chateau which is the team's home, where fond memories and good vibrations hang in the air. 'It's a place which has a special place in my head,' he says. 'When I got here I definitely turned the page on this season, which was one of the biggest disappointments in my football career. Negative thoughts went away and I felt happy to be back amongst the France team. Mentally I am channelled to one objective: to win Euro 2000.' For a large percentage of the squad, national duty puts other concerns on the back burner. Fabien Barthez has a new life in Manchester to plan, Marcel Desailly, Emmanuel Petit and Didier Deschamps seem only too keen to ponder the prospects of a new club. Christian Karembeu and Sylvain Wiltord are also angling for a move. But for now these are side issues. Take Nicolas Anelka (will-he-won't-he leave for Paris Saint-Germain/Juventus/ whoever?). It's an amazing turnaround to find that a player who refused to train for Real Madrid is only too willing to play in an unglamorous practice match for France's reserves against a team made up of a selection from Croatia's Second Division in the suburbs of Zagreb. He scored a hat-trick. He smiled. He wants to be part of the mission in Holland and Belgium. For the first time in France's history they are favourites for a tournament outside their own land. Not only because they are the World Champions but because they are the team of 1998 plus strikers. They have evolved. 'We are better then 1998,' chirps Lebeouf. Indeed they seem in ideal shape: the first choice defence has nearly 400 caps between them, the midfield are proven winners, and the attack brims with youthful vigour. It wasn't too long ago that frustration was welling up about the dearth of striking talent. Everybody admits they were lucky to win the World Cup with Stephane Guivarc'h leading the charge, and only eight months ago the front cover of France Football blared the following advertisement: 'Urgent... France is desperately seeking a goalscorer.' Anelka, having been hailed as the answer when his brace ripped through England at Wembley, had lost his form to a niggling combination of arrogance and injury. Thierry Henry was quietly acclimatising to a central role. David Trezeguet had never quite turned raw potential into the real deal. Now, to France's delight, all three have the makings of world-beaters and coach Roger Lemerre is spoilt for choice. Henry seems to be the slight favourite, although Trezeguet had a recent spell with the midas touch and Anelka simply has star quality and a taste for the big occasion. 'Competition is healthy', as the trio of strikers have all been heard saying recently, is the new mantra. But continuity is the foundation. Unforseen injuries and suspensions permitted, if Lemerre had to pick a team to win any given game eight players would know for sure they are in. Barthez in goal, protected by the defensive core of Desailly and Laurent Blanc with Deschamps and Petit just up ahead. Lilian Thuram and Bixente Lizarazu get the nod as roaming full backs par excellence. Zidane, of course, is guaranteed. That leaves three attacking berths up for grabs and this is where Lemerre's selection becomes interesting. One of the three out and out strikers plays for definite. One of Robert Pires, Christophe Dugarry, Youri Djorkaeff or Johan Micoud will create from deep alongside Zidane. And the last place? That's the big debate. Will he play another attacker, or another playmaker, or Wiltord, who is something in between? Over to you Roger. There's a mindboggling number of permutations and he is expected to mix and match according to the opposition. All will play a part, as they did two years ago. Talk of the national team seldom mentions a starting 11, or a 16 including a subs bench, but always the 22. Le vingt-deux. It is a magic number in France. Lebeouf summed up the mood persuasively: 'L'Equipe de France is like a drug.' The taste of breaking ground as French footballers has served to whet the appetite. Now they are World Champions they want to be the first team to claim both global and European supremacy, a feat never before accomplished, even by the great German, Dutch or Italian sides who have gone close. 'It's fabulous to find ourselves facing a new challenge. It's another way of making football history for our country and for ourselves. This is our chance you see,' muses Zidane. As Desailly points out, 'Everyone in the group has desire, hunger. We all want to win Euro 2000 but we must be humble. Everything has its moment. We cannot think that just because we are World Champions we only need click our fingers to reach another final. We have to forget our victory in the World Cup to get moving again.' If France want it enough they have all the attributes to clinch the trophy named after one of their own, Henri Delaunay. Preparation for Euro 2000 was carefully planned to echo the formula for '98. Meeting up at Clairfontaine, then a spell in Tignes for some beneficial mountain air, before a trip to Morocco for some sunshine with a couple of warm-up games thrown in for good measure. For the tournament itself they are staying in a converted castle - not dissimilar to Clairfontaine - on a lake just outside Brussels. It's all deliberately familiar. Even 18 of the World Cup 22 are the same. For this generation of players France '98 is the eternal reference point, the catalyst, the pinnacle. That summer will forever be remembered as the time their nation fell in love with football. A passion suddenly bloomed, growing with every game.You could sense it in the Provencal market squares, hear it in the tabacs in Nantes, smell it in Lyonnaise cafes. Football gradually penetrated everyday life in France, and by the time Les Bleus reached the final the country was smitten. In the subsequent two years the people of France and its football team have drifted apart. League attendances are healthy and the legendary 22 still cause a stir wherever they go, but for your average monsieur et madame the summer of love ran its course. Success in the Low Countries would remind all the grannies why they had a soft spot for 'Zizou', bring a smile to the folically challenged every time Blanc kisses Barthez's bald head for luck, and get the hip hop kids wanting to be Anelka. How resonant it will be for Aime Jacquet, the architect who put this extraordinary group together and masterminded that golden period. He knows well the curiously fickle attitude to football in France: 'I hoped that every French man and woman would get behind the French team before the tournament began. 'In reality, what happened was that Les Bleus were forced to prove themselves on the pitch. To prove that they truly were the talented performers, hungry for victory, that I'd been telling people about for ages.' Now to prove themselves all over again.

webTitle: Portugal ready to steady the ship

fields.headline: Portugal ready to steady the ship
fields.trailText: A profile of England's opponents tomorrow night: player by player, strengths and weaknesses.
fields.body:
Portugal go into Euro 2000 with several problems surrounding their squad. Eight of the players are unsettled at their respective clubs, not least star striker Joao Pinto who has been booted out by Benfica. He may also find that there is no room for him in the starting eleven, as Portugal seek to bolster their midfield by increasing their defensive options.

The biggest headache for Portugal is, in fact, up front, where there is a lack of a striker who can score regularly. They will play with just one striker and hope that the likes of Luis Figo, Rui Costa and Sergio Conceicao can get forward enough in support. Ricardo Sa Pinto will probably get the nod up front, as Deportivo La Coruna striker Pauleta has been inconsistent and Benfica striker Nuno Gomes still lacks experience.

Experience will, indeed, be a factor, as coach Humberto Coelho plumps for safety first. For players like Paulo Sousa, Ferrando Couto and Dimas Teixera face what could be their last major tournament at national level. Midfielders Vidigal, Capucho and Rui Jorge may be brought in at some point during the tournament. Everton's Abel Xavier should get the nod over former regular Carlos Secretario.

Vitor Baia
(age) 30 Porto (on loan from Barcelona). Caps: 69. Baia seems to have overcome knee problems just in time for Euro 2000. He still lacks match practice and looked shaky in the friendly against Wales. Tall and agile, he is still very much regarded as Portugal's number one.

Dimas Marques Teixeira
31 Standard Liege. Caps: 34. Known simply as Dimas, he has become a globetrotter at club level. Quick and lively, he has recaptured some of his earlier form since moving to Belgium last season. Undisputed choice at left-back.

Jorge Costa
28 Porto. Caps: 26. The hard man of Porto and Portugal's defence, this uncompromising figure stands for no nonsense. He is just what Portugal need to stiffen their traditionally soft underbelly.

Fernando Couto
30 Lazio. Caps: 62/Goals:6. Couto was once a highly respected figure at the heart of Barcelona and Portugal's defence. Since his move to Lazio he has looked clumsy and out of place. This tall and temperamental centre-half will need to recapture his best form quickly.

Abel Xavier
27 Everton. Caps: 13/Goals: 2. Xavier seems to have displaced regular right-back Secretario from the team. After being discarded by PSV Eindhoven, he has settled well at Everton. He is tough-tackling, versatile and dangerous going forward, too. It's just a shame about his hair style.

Paulo Bento
30 Real Oviedo. Caps: 21. Bento is unsettled at Spanish side Oviedo and is targeting a return to Portuguese football. Meanwhile, he remains a useful player who can anchor the midfield allowing his more creative team-mates to get forward.

Rui Manuel Costa
28 Fiorentina. Caps: 51/Goals: 18. Costa is generally considered as world class. He is a true playmaker in the old-fashioned sense. His passing is exquisite and he can switch the play between defence and attack with mesmerising smoothness. He is also very dangerous in front of goal.

Paulo Sousa
29 Parma. Caps: 44. Sousa is a player of great experience gained from playing in Germany and Italy. Sousa usually sits deep in midfield, helping Paulo Bento to snuff out opposing attacks, but also adding some good passing ability of his own.

Luis Figo
27 Barcelona. Caps: 59/Goals:13. Figo is genuinely world class. Some say he is the best in Europe at the moment. Two-footed, he can play on either wing and can also play just behind the striker. His crossing and dribbling are second to none and he is lethal when he gets near the goal.

Sergio Conceicao
25 Lazio. Caps: 23/Goals: 2. Left winger Conceicao has been in good form, but has struggled to get into the national team recently. He should get the nod for Euro 2000. He is a hard-working player who can cut inside as well as attack down the wing.

Ricardo Sa Pinto
27 Real Sociedad. Caps: 36/Goals:8. In the absence of any natural goalscorer, Sa Pinto is the best option up front for Portugal. He is not tall for a centre-forward and will play as lone striker, so he will need support from his midfield team-mates. He will need to control his fiery temper.
